HEADLINE: Confidence Index At 29-Year High

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Consumer confidence in the economy rose in June to a 29-year high, as Americans remained optimistic that the strong labor market and healthy economic growth will continue in coming months.
The Conference Board, a private research group, reported that its index of consumer confidence rose to 137.6 in June from a revised 136.3 in May, a larger rise than Wall Street analysts had expected. 
 June's gain pushed the index above the 29-year high of 137.4 set in February. The last time it was higher was the 137.9 reached in June 1969.
Consumer sentiment is important because consumer spending accounts for two-thirds of the nation's overall economic activity.
The report comes as economists scour new data for signs pointing to the direction of the economy and any inflationary pressures and as Federal Reserve inflation fighters begin two days of meetings in Washington to review interest rate policy.
The Federal Reserve was not expected to raise interest rates at this week's meeting to cool economic growth, especially because of fears that such action would deepen Asia's already serious financial problems.

HEADLINE: Fed Extends Alert on Bank Lending Standards

BYLINE: Bridge News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 30

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve warned banks today to keep up their lending standards as the boom in the economy will not last forever.
"This is a critical time for banks to maintain their lending discipline," the Fed said. "Banks should resist any tendency to assume in evaluating credits that the unusually favorable economic environment of the last few years will continue indefinitely." 
 Officials at the Fed and other bank supervisory agencies have urged the banking industry several times before to guard against excessive easing of lending standards. But the Fed letter sent today to all commercial banks takes the warnings a step further, providing a detailed review of lending trends and a heavy emphasis on "forward-looking analysis" of economic conditions.
The Fed identified three specific areas that need special attention: lending to real estate investment trusts, the use of forward-looking analysis in the loan approval process, and the relationship between loan pricing and risk.
Underlying the Fed's warning is the memory of the bank and savings and loan crisis of the late 1980's, after many banks had concentrated so heavily on real estate loans.
Previous warnings have been based mainly on anecdotal evidence and surveys, but the letter today was based on an intensive study of commercial and industrial loans made by a select group of large banks.
The study compared several hundred loans made in late 1995 with loans made in late 1997 and found that "intense competition" had led to "significant easing of pricing and some nonprice terms."
Although the Fed found no evidence that the quality of loans declined during the two-year period, it concluded that this would not have been the case if economic conditions had not been so favorable. The Fed therefore strongly urged bankers to consider what might happen to their loan portfolios during "periods of possible economic adversity."
Only 20 to 30 percent of the loan documents reviewed by Fed staff members contained formal projections of a borrower's future performance, the Fed said, and an even lower percentage contained an analysis of possible "downside" outlooks.

HEADLINE: A Race for the Soul of the Suburbs

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON 

DATELINE: OLATHE, Kan., June 27

 BODY:
For all the images of Dorothy's farm, the rail lines of Topeka or the aerospace plants of Wichita, the typical Republican voter of Kansas lives here in the traffic-jammed mallscape of suburban Johnson County.
Once the corn-covered Back Forty of metropolitan Kansas City, this affluent area booming with new subdivisions and retail centers has become the state's political quintessence, at least for Republicans, producing far more votes than even Wichita. And it is these newer, distant suburbs that are now a crucial battleground in the Republican primary for governor, between the incumbent, Bill Graves, a social moderate, and David Miller, former Republican state chairman and the leader of Kansas's anti-abortion forces. 
 Among Republicans nationally, the fight is the latest in the party's long and bitter struggle to define its chief mission: balancing budgets or saving souls.
Governor Graves, who has cut taxes four times since taking office three and a half years ago and presided over the kind of prosperous economy seen across most of America in recent years, would scarcely seem likely to face a challenge from his own ranks. He enjoys a 75 percent approval rating, according to one recent poll, and most political analysts say he will be tough to beat come the day of the primary, Aug. 4.
But Mr. Miller, a former state legislator who stepped down as party chairman to run for governor, believes that Mr. Graves's support for abortion rights makes him vulnerable. And while early polls give the Governor a big lead, analysts caution against discounting Mr. Miller, a former leader of the Christian Coalition who can draw on the organizational strength of evangelical churches and anti-abortion groups.
"You wouldn't think that the most popular governor in memory would be challenged by a leader of his own party," said Burdette Loomis, a political science professor at the University of Kansas, who noted that Mr. Graves won 102 of 105 counties in 1994. "But David Miller is a very good politician. He's not in this unless he thinks he can win. He can get out all the evangelicals to vote. It's all going to hinge on turnout."
The outcome, Professor Loomis said, could well depend on voters in suburban communities like Olathe. Disputing the notion that prosperous suburbanites shun the appeals of religious conservatives, he said:
"You go into a lot of these affluent subdivisions -- $200,000 earth-tone houses with three-car garages -- and you'll find that many of these young families are strong fundamentalists. It's not like these people wear a big X on their forehead. They look like a bunch of other well-off, mostly white people."
Indeed, Professor Loomis said, religious conservatives in highest proportions can be found in the newer suburbs, with their winding roads into uniform subdivisions and their isolated cul-de-sacs.
So commanding is the early lead of the 45-year-old Governor Graves, a native of Salina in rural central Kansas, that a poll published on June 21 by The Wichita Eagle found two-thirds of the state's Republican voters supporting him. But low turnout makes primary elections difficult to predict, and surveys have sometimes underestimated the strength of evangelical voters like Cathy Kinsella, who runs a business with her husband, has five children and, as a strong opponent of abortion, says she will be working hard for Mr. Graves's defeat. That the Governor has signed a bill outlawing the late-term procedure that opponents call partial birth abortion does not change Mrs. Kinsella's view.
"He has neglected people like me," she said as she pushed a cart across the lot of an Olathe shopping mall on a wilting recent afternoon. "He's ignored the family, the Bible, the moral issues that are the most important thing facing us."
Mr. Miller, a 48-year-old insurance salesman from Eudora, just west of Olathe, recently held a campaign rally near Wichita that featured the endorsement of James C. Dobson, head of the conservative Focus on the Family, which reaches 28 million people through its radio and television broadcasts. Between prayers and patriotic music, Mr. Dobson stood before a giant American flag and hailed Mr. Miller as "a man of courage, a man of conviction and a man of faith." He criticized Governor Graves, calling him "not pro-life, not pro-family and not conservative."
But Mr. Dobson has campaigned for several social conservatives this year and has not been uniformly successful. His horse in the race for the Republican nomination for Nebraska governor, United States Representative Jon Christensen, finished a distant third.
Yes, Kansas is perhaps the most conservative Midwestern state -- its entire six-member Congressional delegation, including the former track star Jim Ryun, comes from the right end of the Republican spectrum -- but analysts say the rosy economy and the personal appeal of Mr. Graves should translate into bipartisan support. Tom Sawyer, minority leader of the Kansas House, looks like a shoo-in for the Democratic nomination, and among the Democrats who choose to vote in the Republican primary, the Governor is expected to find strong backing.
One of those Democrats, Charlie Bitts, said that while no one could ignore social problems like out-of-wedlock births and drug addiction, he would vote his pocketbook: for Governor Graves.
"Our economy is awfully good right now," said Mr. Bitts, 63, a retired landscaper from rural southeast Kansas. "Our morality in this country certainly needs to be changed. I just don't think politics is the place for it."

HEADLINE: Nike Quarterly Loss Totals $67.6 Million

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: BEAVERTON, Ore., June 30

 BODY:
Nike Inc. today reported a net loss of $67.6 million on lower sales for its latest quarter because of continued economic woes in the Asia-Pacific region and weakness in the United States market.
The athletic shoe and apparel company said its orders for the coming six months were off 54 percent in the Asia-Pacific region and 11 percent in the United States, and worldwide total orders were down 13 percent. 
 Nike said its fiscal fourth-quarter loss amounted to 23 cents a diluted share and included a restructuring charge of $129.9 million before taxes, or $79.5 million after taxes.
Excluding the restructuring charge, Nike's net income was $11.8 million, or 4 cents a diluted share, compared with $155.8 million, or 52 cents a diluted share, in the comparable period a year earlier.
Nike's stock closed today at $48.6875 a share, down 56.25 cents.

HEADLINE: Glimpses of Change in China

 BODY:
President Clinton's trip to China has given Americans an extended look at political life in that complex and changing country. Some of what they have witnessed was predictable, including the Chinese Government's effort to clear outspoken dissidents from Mr. Clinton's path. But a good deal was not, like the uncensored broadcast in China of Mr. Clinton's news conference with President Jiang Zemin. The signs of unexpected openness may be the most encouraging development of the Clinton visit.
Whether the change is a temporary relaxation or a harbinger of greater freedom is not clear. China for the most part remains a repressive dictatorship. But modest liberalizing changes have been under way for much of the last year. They seem to reflect the growing confidence and power of Mr. Jiang. 
 Officially, Mr. Jiang has been China's top leader for the past nine years. But it was only after the death of Deng Xiaoping last year that he defined his own positions, endorsing accelerated privatization of industry, banking reform and slightly freer political debate. Mr. Jiang took another step last weekend by debating some of the most sensitive issues in Chinese politics with Mr. Clinton on live television, including the Tiananmen Square massacre of 1989 and Beijing's policies toward Tibet.
Mr. Jiang's words conveyed important nuances to Chinese listeners. His characterization of Tiananmen as a "political disturbance" departed from the official line that it was a "counter-revolutionary riot." He also offered a dialogue, with conditions, to the Dalai Lama, Tibet's spiritual leader. These words may be taken as a license to broader public debate on both subjects.
Mr. Clinton has also encountered less encouraging attitudes. The nationalistic tone of questions asked by students at Beijing University, China's traditional democratic hothouse, was disheartening. It suggested that heavy government pressure directed against students and faculty there since the Tiananmen repression had changed the intellectual climate.
Ordinary Chinese, however, are somewhat freer today to express political views in private, and freedom can become contagious. Mr. Jiang seems to understand that a society organized around money-making is harder to regiment than one organized around the nostrums of Chairman Mao. Despite censorship and other government restrictions, exposure to global commerce, television and the Internet are chipping away at the old restraints.
As China continues to modernize its economy, it will face new pressures from within and without to open up its political system as well. Mr. Clinton has repeatedly used his public appearances on this trip to point out the connection between economic and political freedom. Millions of Chinese have been listening attentively.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Fierce Run on the Rand by Speculators Shocks South Africa

BYLINE: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr. 

DATELINE: JOHANNESBURG, June 30

 BODY:
Speculators have given the South African rand a nasty shock in the last few days, forcing the nation's central bank to enlist help from the United States and Britain and to raise interest rates sharply to stem the currency's fall.
Until the selloff began, the rand had been drifting slowly down against the dollar, slipping about 12 percent since the beginning of the year. Then, starting last week, it plunged 13 percent after speculators who had been exploiting the turmoil in Asia turned their sights on South Africa. 
 At the Government's request, the American Federal Reserve Bank and the Bank of England both intervened on Friday and Monday.
The lift for the rand was short-lived, however, after it became clear that the two central banks were using the South African Reserve Bank's dollars to buy the South African currency.
Facing its worst currency crisis in years, the Reserve Bank today increased its overnight lending rate to commercial banks to more than 20 percent, from 18.311 percent, prompting most banks to raise their prime rates by two percentage points, to 22.25 percent.
While the tighter credit risked slowing South Africa's economic growth, which has already been hurt by falling commodity prices, it bolstered the rand by making rand-denominated assets more attractive to international investors. The currency closed here today at 17.04 cents, up from an all-time low of 16.26 cents at midday on Monday.
Until last week, the rand had actually outperformed the currencies of Asia, Brazil, Australia and New Zealand with which it is often compared because of similarities in the countries' economies.
"But some speculator must have noticed that on his computer and decided that it was our turn," said Sampie Terreblanche, a professor of political economy at Stellenbosch University. "So the Asian bug hit us -- a little belatedly."
Economists universally expressed surprise at the fierceness of the attack because the South African economy's fundamentals are strong, whether compared with Asian economies or with the situation here before the 1994 elections.
South African banks are very conservative, carry few bad loans and are not in thrall to ruling families like the Suhartos in Indonesia.
Foreign debt is low. State assets are being privatized, albeit slowly. Until the run began, inflation was down significantly, to 5 percent, the Reserve Bank had reserves equal to three months' imports, and the prime rate was high but stable at about 18 percent. Foreign bankers generally applaud the Government's economic policies, which focus on beating inflation and lowering the budget deficit.
By contrast, before 1994, the African National Congress was strongly socialist and talked about nationalizing the mines and cutting unemployment with huge public spending; the budget deficit was at 5 percent of G.D.P. and foreign exchange was heavily restricted.
It is not clear what started this run on the rand. Chris Stals, the governor of the Reserve Bank, has blamed selling by an unidentified American hedge fund. But the background was in place. To drive off speculators, the Reserve Bank had steadily raised the overnight lending rate to nearly 24 percent. When it felt confident enough to lower it to 17 percent to let commercial lending rates relax a little, speculators leaped in.
Simultaneously, foreign analysts wrote some cautionary reports. Particularly alarming, said Kevin Lings, senior economist for Nedcor, a major bank holding company, was one from the Bank of New York that raised the possibility of riots and food shortages. Local economists scoffed at the report, since the first affected by a weak rand are the rich, but it presumably encouraged speculators. Another rumor making the rounds had it that the failure of a Reserve Bank clerk to leave overnight orders with a bank in New York was read as a decision by the bank not to defend the rand.
In a sense, the monetary crisis reflects the growing maturity of the South African economy. The last abrupt currency plunge, in 1996, was brought on by a false rumor that President Nelson Mandela had had a heart attack. Administration officials then cried racism, since the implication was that a black government couldn't keep the country together without Mr. Mandela at the helm.
Now, the markets seem content with the prospect that Thabo Mbeki will become president next year and confident that the African National Congress will continue to pursue conservative financial policies. Indeed, economists say, the rand's latest slide results less from political upheaval than from the mundane realities of a developing country, notably South Africa's exposure to the fallout from Asia and its vulnerability to currency speculators. In addition, investors have become increasingly nervous about the possibility that labor unions will put pressure on the Government to temper its economic austerity measures as the 1999 elections approach.
Because of apartheid-era sanctions, South Africa is somewhat insulated against currency crises. Snubbed by the world, it became self-sufficient in food, steel, chemicals, textiles and other basics. It once produced a third of its own gasoline from coal; that is down to 10 percent, but fuel prices are still relatively low. Its biggest imports are auto parts, computers and machinery.
The people immediately hit hardest -- and complaining loudest -- are the relatively small numbers of upper-middle-class and rich people who buy imported clothes and take vacations abroad. However, anyone with a variable-rate mortgage or car loan will soon be hurt, too, if interest rates stay high, and so will the many stores that sell to the poor on credit.
The poor should not be hurt until high interest rates slow the economy enough to cause more layoffs. That is already a problem -- the economy lost about 130,000 jobs last year while growing only 1.7 percent.
On the other hand, a weak rand could stimulate the moribund economy.
The rand is now "clearly significantly undervalued by any measure," said Nico Czypionka, chief economist for the Standard Bank here. All the country's exports, from gold, platinum, manganese and zinc to chemicals, paper pulp, fruit and wine, should benefit. Gold mines, which have been laying off thousands of workers because gold is below $300 an ounce, may become profitable again, because those workers are paid in rand.
The most important thing for the economy, economists say, is to get South Africans to save. They have one of the world's lowest savings rates.
When the rand was created in 1962, it was pegged at two rands to an English pound, back when the pound was worth about $5 -- giving the rand a value then of $2.50. On Monday, it briefly hit 10 rands per pound.
"When I studied in the United States in the late 1960's, I got $1.40 for my rand," Professor Terreblanche said. "Now it's 16 cents. It's hard to think we can be so degraded internationally."

HEADLINE: Pleading a Case for the Child;
Educator Stresses Developmental Needs Over Methods

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME 

DATELINE: NEW HAVEN

 BODY:
To this day, the winnowing process from his own youth still gnaws at him: how he was able to make it, while so many equally intelligent peers who grew up in less nurturing environments could not.
That memory informed the educational model that made James Comer one of the most celebrated innovators of his time: his approach begins and ends with the notion that, rather than intelligence and will, the experiences children have growing up, good and bad, determine who wins and loses in school and life. 
 In many ways, this should be James Comer's moment, with education near the top of the national agenda and an administration in the White House passionately committed to his view of it. He is a hero to many education advocates, not the least of them Hillary Rodham Clinton, who introduced him at a recent tribute and symposium at the Yale Medical School. They were there to celebrate the 30th anniversary of his School Development Program, a nonprofit project of the Child Study Center at the Yale Medical School that advises schools on the use of his theories.
But at 63, Dr. Comer (pronounced KOH-mer) finds himself not so much a symbol of how education has changed as a marker of where the fault lines are drawn. He is one of the most consistent critics of the ascendant countermodels for school reform: tougher standards, high-stakes tests and experiments with privatization or vouchers. For all the success of his approach, which is used in more than 450 schools in 17 states and several foreign countries, Dr. Comer is at least as aware of the winds blowing away from him as the ones wafting in his direction.
"In many ways, my voice has been heard, and I have had some influence," he said, reflecting on his career at his office at the Yale Medical School, where he is associate dean and a professor of child psychiatry. "But in the one area that's most critical, the role of child development, people are still not paying attention. Our moment is going to come, but right now most of the attention seems to be on things like charters and vouchers that don't do anything for the vast majority of children."
Few educators have looked so hard and so long at how the lives of children relate to educational achievement.
"Before it was a major field of study, Dr. Comer recognized that learning in school, before school and after school is tied to a child's level of development," Mrs. Clinton said in her remarks. "Before charter schools or magnet schools became household words, Dr. Comer was busy designing schools in which parents were involved in everything from curricular development to social activities."
Dr. Comer's education model centers on the idea that many children, minority-group children in particular, struggle in school because their level of social, intellectual and cultural development is far behind that of more affluent students.
Schools, he says, must focus on developmental needs, or even the best teachers and most sophisticated curriculum will be ineffective. That means bringing counselors, psychologists, parents and others into the learning process -- rather than just depending on teachers -- and tailoring lessons to a child's background.
For example, at Isadore Wexler Community School in inner-city New Haven, one school Dr. Comer works with, Shelia Brantley incorporates child development into her third-grade reading curriculum. Thus, the program is not just about reading. It might include a trip to the supermarket so students who have never seen an avocado can learn what the word means, a lesson suburban children might not need.
Discussions are predicated on the children's learning to communicate complex thoughts and ideas they might not be exposed to at home. And the whole teaching and learning experience is based on social skills -- listening, sharing information, expressing clear points of view -- that transcend the individual lesson.
The schools Dr. Comer works with are organized around three principles: problem solving rather than blaming; consensus decision-making, and collaboration.
Much of it sounds uncontroversial. But Dr. Comer's program begins with the unfashionable idea that in a country of growing disparities between haves and have nots, education has to begin by addressing the disparate needs and backgrounds of children so they can learn.
"Even my friends in education still begin by talking curriculum and instruction," he said. "All those things are important, but where's the kid? What's the kid like? What's going on with the kid? All of American education has left the development of the child out of it. We may pay it lip service, but for a whole number of reasons, the needs of the kid get ignored."
His perspective in many ways goes against the ingrained American belief that each individual can determine his or her own destiny.
"My biggest problem with education is we see learning as a function of intelligence and will," he said. "If you have the intelligence and will, you will learn. If you don't, you won't. Well, it's not that simple."
To critics, particularly advocates of vouchers, charter schools and tougher standards and tests, Dr. Comer's agenda, while well meaning, is not systematic enough to create real change in schools.
"He has a soft kind of model that's very Clintonesque," said Chester Finn, a prominent education analyst and a senior fellow at the Hudson Institute. "It says things a lot of educators find appealing, but I'm not persuaded that it can be counted on to produce improved student achievement. It doesn't change the power. It doesn't change the control of resources.
"It doesn't change the ground rules. It doesn't change who's in charge. It doesn't change what we mean by a public school, and it doesn't have the combination of uniform standards, tests and consequences I believe you need for real change."
He added that there were approaches other than Dr. Comer's richly empathetic model to help inner-city students. He cited the ideas of Thaddeus Lott, a Houston principal recently profiled in Policy Review magazine who uses ability grouping, intensive drill, rote learning and other traditional teaching methods to extraordinary result at his Wesley Elementary School.
Dr. Comer is singularly unimpressed by most of the ideas advocated by Dr. Finn and others. Unlike some educators, who see charter schools as a way to develop distinctive, innovative schools, he sees them as little different from voucher proposals that he thinks would skim off the best students, leaving most to fester in schools that have been largely written off.
Dr. Comer likes to cite his life story as a microcosm of his view of education. His mother grew up poor in Mississippi, with little formal schooling but a passionate belief in the importance of education. His father, a steel mill laborer, grew up in rural Alabama with a sixth-grade education. Their five children went on to earn 13 bachelor's and graduate degrees between them.
Dr. Comer grew up in East Chicago, Ind., in an integrated neighborhood with integrated schools. He may have been poorer than some of his white classmates, but his parents were able to inculcate the values, attitudes and discipline that he believes allowed him to succeed.
It taught him two lessons. The first was that education was the key to success and it was open to everyone. The second was that influences on children mean more for their chances of success than does innate intelligence.
Dr. Comer received his undergraduate degree from Indiana University and his medical degree from Howard University. But his work with poor communities soon convinced him he could have the most impact by working with schools.
Like proponents of most reform models, he can provide research showing dramatic results, like the McLeansville Middle School in Guilford County, N.C., where the percentage of eighth graders reading at a competent level rose from 65 to 85 between 1993 and 1997.
But he says that of the schools he has worked with, only a third had dramatic results, a third showed modest gains and a third were little changed.
But all in all, he says, those are pretty good results.
"If you play baseball those results will put you in the Hall of Fame, and this game's tougher than baseball," he said. "You're working against the very undesirable condition of the society: racism, economic adversity, social marginalization, the effects on parents and teachers of dealing with kids who people believe have no future. That's what schools serving low-income and minority kids are always up against. You bat .333 against that, and you feel pretty good."
Dr. Comer has handed off much of the daily operation of the program to others, like the executive director, Edward T. Joyner. But he is not slowing down. He continues to expand his activities.
He now works with districts as well as individual schools. He has joined Project Atlas, a new effort in which a consortium of theorists advises schools on a range of issues. The consultants are Dr. Comer; Theodore Sizer, the retired head of the Coalition for Essential Schools; Howard Gardner, the Harvard education theorist, and Janet Whitlaw of the Education Development Center.
The four theorists' approaches include Dr. Comer's ideas on how to draw diverse influences into a school's daily life; Dr. Gardner's on tests and student assessments; Dr. Sizer's on learning and curriculum, and Ms. Whitlaw's on teacher preparation.
Dr. Comer began his work with the idea that education reform was a long, slow struggle. Nothing has led him to think otherwise.
"The mentality of the moment is to look for the quick fix," he said. "But if we try to gloss over the depth, severity and difficulty of the problems, we will never address the depth, severity and difficulty of the problems."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS -- The Balloon That Refuses To Be Popped;
Investors Keep Lifting Stocks Despite Warnings

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

 BODY:
The warnings that the bubble is about to burst have been sounded each quarter for the last few years, but investors in the stock market continue to ignore them. And so far, despite a series of blows lately that were widely expected to take the air out of the balloon, they have been right.
Sure, the Asian economic crisis poses a threat to already slowing corporate profit growth at home. And yes, the recent rise in wages could eventually mean a revival of serious inflation. Yet all indications are that the American economy is remarkably sound, seemingly indestructible, and therefore, investors surmise, so is Wall Street. 
 That's why, midway through 1998, share prices are once again hovering near their all-time highs. The investing public, for all the complaints of the professionals, remains sanguine about the unheard-of riches being delivered by one of the greatest bull markets in history.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index -- a widely followed proxy for the larger stock market and millions of index-fund investors -- is up nearly 17 percent this year. The Dow Jones industrial average, the best-known market barometer, is up 13 percent in a year that many Wall Street pros had forecast full-year gains of less than 8 percent.
"We've had a year well above almost anyone's expectations," said Frederick B. Taylor, the chief investment officer at the U.S. Trust Company.
Even though share prices fell modestly yesterday, and finished the second quarter with only slim gains of about 2.9 percent for the S.& P. 500, the evidence suggests that investors have not yet cooled to stocks.
Of course, there are dire warnings that weaker profits later in the year could send investors fleeing and erase most of the gains. Or that Asia, already in recession and still on the edge of destruction, could swipe winnings in Europe and topple American markets.
But for now, the United States economy seems to be in the throes of what the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, has called a "virtuous cycle," of powerful growth, little if any inflation, low unemployment and rising wage gains.
That's an almost ideal economic scenario that may be compensating for the gradual slowdown in profit growth, which has drifted down for large companies to a gain of just 3.8 percent in the first quarter compared with a 15 percent advance in the period a year earlier.
This combination of favorable economic factors has been critical to the market's surge, said Mr. Taylor at U.S. Trust. Unemployment, inflation and interest rates are all low, consumer confidence is high, and where Federal budget deficits reigned, now there are surpluses.
"There are a whole group of things that if you had forecast them a few years ago, no one would have believed it," he said. "As an American looking at the U.S. economy these are indeed good times."
And with soaring consumer confidence, Americans are rushing to buy their favorite products -- no less than the shares of companies that create and market those products.
Call investors defiant, narrow-minded, excessively bullish, naive, or even downright silly. But also call them rich -- billions, no trillions, richer with each passing quarter. The "virtuous cycle," for them, is about buying Gap khakis, and then buying into shares of the Gap and its retail brethren.
Indeed, for those counting, the current bull market, which dates back to October 1990, just before the gulf war, clocked day 2,819 yesterday -- making it the third-longest bull market in history. It is now just months away from passing the period that ended disastrously in October 1929.
Not even the audacious 1980's can match the run of the 1990's for durability or distance. In the 1980's, the Dow soared 250 percent to its August 1987 high, before tumbling 22.3 percent on Oct. 19, 1987 -- Black Monday. In the 1990's, however, the Dow has climbed about 280 percent, including a record three consecutive years with gains of 20 percent or more. (In the 1920's, the Dow gained 496 percent before plummeting into the Great Depression.)
But if there is anything to raise a warning flag about the sustainability of the remarkable stock market run of the last few years, it is that the winnings are being concentrated in an ever-smaller group of blue-chip companies that include well-known names like General Electric, Dell Computer, Microsoft, Coca-Cola and Wal-Mart.
Lately, Americans, along with a growing mass of foreigners, have placed their bets largely on companies like Dell Computer, one of the hottest stocks of the decade. And despite its rocket-like rise, Dell has gained another 121 percent this year, pushing its market value to $58 billion -- more than that of the General Motors Corporation.
Many companies seem protected against even dire attacks by something resembling a bullet-proof vest. Microsoft, despite the antitrust action by the Federal Government and at least 20 states, has seen its shares appreciate another 67 percent in 1998, pushing its value up $110 billion in just the last six months to $267 billion, second only to General Electric, which is worth almost $300 billion.
The market value of corporations -- or what investors value them at -- has been growing exponentially in the 1990's, along with the urge to merge.
And when corporations merge, or hint at such deals, share prices soar, feeding the great bull market. Financial deals, like Citicorp's agreement to merge with the Travelers Group for $70 billion, have been among the most lucrative.
Some analysts see the merger deals not so much as a sign of health, but as a symbol of a market that is peaking, and readying for a fall. They argue that companies running out of ways to increase profits have nothing better to do than seek partnerships as a way to keep the game going just a little bit longer.
Of all the warning signs, the sharpest concerns corporate profits. The first-quarter growth was the slowest since 1991, and the second-quarter estimates are for gains of about 3.5 percent, according to First Call Inc., which tracks earnings data.
A profit slowdown, conventional wisdom goes, would weigh heavily on share prices, and at the very least, stall the bull run.
"Stock prices and profits go together, and through the 1990's, you've had a golden age of profits," said Ronald Talley, an economist at the WEFA Group, a forecasting unit in Eddystone, Pa. "However, it looks like that period may be coming to an end. You can't have profits growing faster than the economy forever, and it seems that unusual situation is about to end."
Gail Dudack, the chief investment strategist at UBS Securities, says the first quarter's strong economic growth with meager profit gains portends a difficult second half of the year. "If you put those two pieces of information together, it suggests you could have a negative quarter later this year," she said.
But others, like Abby Joseph Cohen, the widely followed market strategist at Goldman, Sachs & Company, says the "supertanker" economy will continue to steam ahead, buoying the major indexes even if many smaller stocks languish.
Part of the profit picture, though, could be determined by events in Asia, and they do not look good.
Companies like Boeing and Motorola have issued profit warnings, creating a group of losers circling a narrower band of big winners.
Thomas M. Galvin, a market strategist at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, estimates that the top 30 companies that make up the S.& P. 500 provided about half of this year's gains, partly because foreign investors consider them safe and recognizable. Many on Wall Street talk about a two-tiered market, a market of haves and have nots.
"The big surprise this year has been the focus and narrowness of the market," said Laszlo Birinyi, who heads Birinyi Associates, a market research firm in Greenwich, Conn. "Everyone believed that at some point smaller stocks were going to join in and they haven't."
The weaker fortunes of smaller- company issues can be seen in the Russell 2000 index, which has gained just 4.6 percent this year. "It's really been the General Electrics and the Coca-Colas that are getting all the activity," Mr. Birinyi said.
The big losers midway through 1998 are the energy stocks, suffering from a huge decline in the price of oil, as well as semiconductor companies with heavy exposure to Asia. National Semiconductor, an S.& P. 500 stock, is down nearly 50 percent this year. The Rowan Companies, an oil drilling concern, is down 36 percent.
Worries about Asia and profits were said to be behind the anxious moments in the second quarter, when the Dow first soared to a record 9,211.84 in May before falling as low as 8,627.93 earlier in June, a drop of 6.3 percent.
But with each dip has come a resurgence of buying, and that surge sent the S.& P. 500 to a record on Monday, before slipping slightly yesterday. The Nasdaq, despite turbulence in recent weeks, is up 20.7 percent this year. The Dow, meanwhile, closed at 8,952.02 -- hovering around the 9,000 mark.
Could anything end the party? Certainly the Federal Reserve could if it decides to raise interest rates. For the latest on that front, tune in today shortly after 2 P.M. for the conclusion of the Fed's two-day Open Market Committee meeting.

HEADLINE: Donations Rise, Ending United Way Slump

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
Reversing years of declining support, United Way of Tri-State will report today that it raised $103 million in the last year, up 4.5 percent over the previous year after adjusting for inflation, the first real increase in this decade.
The growth is the first since United Way of America was rocked by a scandal six years ago that sent its president to prison for stealing charity funds and the local United Ways saw their support drop. Donations have also suffered from downsizing at major corporations, slow wage growth and less interest in giving to health and human services agencies. 
 Even with the increase, contributions by the 137 large companies and their workers in the New York metropolitan region that give through Tri-State is still 15 percent below the 1991-92 figure, when pledges totaled $121.4 million, adjusted for inflation as are all figures reported here.
The increase in pledges should translate into small increases in allocations in the next 12 months to many of the health and human services agencies that depend on United Way for support. Typically about 6 percent of pledges are not fulfilled, often because people switch jobs.
Tri-State is the largest of the 1,300 United Ways, but is little known because it does not directly allocate money to agencies. Instead, Tri-State divides the money it raises among 30 local United Ways in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, with 41.5 percent of the money going to United Way of New York City.
Gary Wendt, chairman of the 1997-98 Tri-State campaign, noted that the 4.5 percent increase in pledges is significantly higher than the 3 percent average increase reported so far by 11 other large United Ways across the country. Mr. Wendt said he would like to see an increase in giving by the high-income residents of New York City, including those employed on Wall Street, where bonus checks are booming but giving through the United Way is modest.
At Goldman Sachs, for example, the 190 partners each made a minimum bonus of $4 million last year and 215 managing directors each averaged $1.5 million in bonuses. The investment banking partnership and its employees gave $1.1 million to United Way in the last year, a Goldman Sachs spokesman said, but a total of $60 million to all charitable causes.
Mr. Wendt pointed to one investment bank that was generous, Merrill Lynch, "which had more $10,000 givers than any other company in the country."
Mr. Wendt, the chief executive of G.E. Capital, a financial subsidiary of General Electric Corporation based in Stamford, Conn., set a goal for his company and its employees of $1.35 million, 20 percent above the previous year. Pledges exceeded the goal at $1.43 million.
United Way of New York City is the only large United Way that has not reported its campaign results for the fiscal year that ended yesterday. Ann Ormsby, a vice president, said Monday that pledges were running about 8 percent ahead of the previous year.
The Tri-State results, and the preliminary figures from the New York City campaign, indicate that the federated fund-raising organization is doing much better at winning support here than in the nation's second- and third-largest metropolitan areas. Earlier this month, United Way Inc. in Los Angeles reported pledges of $59 million, up a half of 1 percent over last fiscal year. Giving to the United Way serving Los Angeles County is still 46 percent below its peak seven years ago, when pledges totaled $108.8 million, and has been essentially flat since 1995.
Donors may have been turned off this year by a radio advertising campaign that chided Los Angeles residents for spending money on breast implants and caffe lattes, but not on gifts to United Way.
In Ventura County, a booming area northwest of Los Angeles, allocations to 59 member agencies had to be slashed 30 percent in May because United Way of Ventura County's deficit had grown to $1.2 million. The cuts came on top of a 7.5 percent cut the previous September.
In the third-largest city, the Chicago United Way/Crusade of Mercy raised $95.1 million, up 3 percent from the previous year, but still 22 percent below its $121.8 million peak six years ago.

HEADLINE: They're Ready For Their Layups Now

BYLINE: By PAM BELLUCK 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, June 30

 BODY:
In real life, Timothy B. Smith is a "mystery shopper" for Taco Bell, buying chicken incognito at the fast-food joints and reporting to headquarters whether it is cooked too little or served too cold.
This job may have done little to prepare him for his big moment today, but Mr. Smith, 30, had other things going for him. For one, his head was shaved. For two, he had the right answer when the casting director, Julie Ashton, asked him, "Timothy, how tall are you?" 
 Six foot 4, he answered.
"Perfect," Ms. Ashton said.
Mr. Smith became one of a handful of men who may just have a shot at the movie part of a lifetime, the title role in "Michael Jordan: The Untold Story of an American Hero."
This week, television producers have descended on Chicago, hoping that somewhere in this scrappy workingman's town where the six-time National Basketball Association champions, the Bulls, are the municipal religion, they might just find a natural for the part of the world's most famous athlete in a movie to be made this fall and broadcast before the end of the year for the new Fox Family Channel.
"It's unlikely we're going to get the Denzel Washingtons of the world," said Lance H. Robbins, a producer for the channel.
And while actors across the country have been sending in their head shots and bragging on their hook shots, "we haven't seen many professional actors that could play basketball and look like Michael Jordan," Mr. Robbins said. "We've literally had white guys submit reasons why they should play Michael Jordan: 'I may not look like him but I can play him.' "
In Chicago, the producers opened a high school gym on Monday so that Jordan wannabes could show how they looked on a court. Several thousand men, teen-agers and boys showed up, some waiting in line for hours to audition for the boyhood, teen-age and star phases of Jordandom.
"Who wouldn't want to be Jordan?" said Robert Reed, 29, a high school math and science teacher who tried out for the part. Mr. Reed is such a Michael fan that his 5-month-old son's middle name is Jordan.
After the aspiring actors dribbled and took a few shots and read a line in front of a camera, Ms. Ashton selected the 30 or so most promising Jordans for callbacks today.
Michael Parkinson, 27, a firefighter who showed up at the gym after working a 24-hour shift, was one. Today, in an Italian suit with a red silk pocket handkerchief, showing Mr. Jordan's Armani side, Mr. Parkinson sat in a room full of Jordan look-alikes mouthing a scene in which Mr. Jordan, having left basketball for baseball, decides to respect the baseball strike: "I won't cross the strike line, Ron. I'm out of here."
His Airness himself has nothing to do with "The Untold Story." The screenwriter, Michael J. Murray, who has written television movies about the Menendez Brothers and Madonna, has teased a script out of the many books, magazine articles and newspaper stories that have been written about Mr. Jordan.
But "we'd love to have him bless the project," Mr. Robbins said.
The movie will be overwhelmingly favorable, Mr. Robbins said, touching only briefly on his affinity for gambling and a few sensitive scenes, like "the fact that he was very very shy when he was in college, hardly went out on dates, and joined a home economics class and got confidence to interact with women."
Today, Mr. Smith showed he was more than a look-alike, delivering his lines with emotion and nuance and impressing Ms. Ashton well beyond her expectations. "Usually, you're really looking mostly for, like, acting skills," Ms. Ashton said. "But with this project, it's really a look. And basketball skills would be nice too."

HEADLINE: CLINTON IN CHINA: AIRWAVES;
Clinton Enjoys Radio Stint: No Violence, Drugs or Sex

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON 

DATELINE: SHANGHAI, June 30

 BODY:
Talk radio is still new in China, so good behavior counts.
Callers are generally polite, not confrontational. A host would never hang up on anybody, the way Howard Stern likes to do. And the idea of trying anything as risque as voicing a contrary political opinion is altogether foreign, though maybe the vigilant screeners just make it seem that way. 
 When President Clinton turned up today at the studio of Shanghai Radio 990 to make his first appearance on a talk radio program outside the United States, he fielded questions about the need for library exchanges, the requirements for joining the World Trade Organization and the benefits of better education.
One caller even asked about auto emissions. The President seemed thrilled.
"One of the things you need to know," Mr. Clinton replied, "is that when a car, an automobile, burns gasoline, about 80 percent of the heat value of the gasoline is lost in the inefficiency of the engine. But they are now developing new engines, called fuel-injection machines, where the fuel goes directly into the engine, and it is about four times more efficient.
"So I hope that within a matter of just a few years, in the U.S., in China and thoughout the world, all these engines will be much much less polluting. And that will be very good for the health of the people of China and for the health of the world environment."
At that, Zuo Anlong, the host of the program, "Citizens and Society," could not resist a segue into mass transportation and, after a sip of Diet Coke, Mr. Clinton was off and running again. Here was a chance to delve deeply into policy without obnoxious hosts to cut in unexpectedly or resort to "gotcha" questions.
There was no mention of sex, violence or drugs. And certainly no allusions to Monica S. Lewinsky. It was an inveterate talker's paradise.
Allowing Mr. Clinton to answer questions from callers on live radio, uncensored, might have seemed unthinkable only a week ago. The media in China are tightly monitored, and broadcasting is generally kept within the narrow confines of approved programming.
After Mr. Clinton spoke about sensitive political topics like the Tiananmen Square massacre and Tibet in a nationally televised news conference on Saturday with President Jiang Zemin, then addressed students at Beijing University on Monday, having him on Shanghai radio reinforced the signals of greater openness in China, at least symbolically.
Yet the reality of today's program illustrated the firm limits that remain on public discourse in this country. As long as the radio station could screen its callers, even Mr. Clinton's presence could not move the discussion past a collection of safe topics.
Here was one typical question, from Li in Shanghai: "As far as getting the Shanghai Library and American libraries going for better and better exchanges, what can we do to increase the amount of exchange and cooperation between them?"
Mr. Clinton's answer was too long to print here, but suffice it to say: start with more Internet use, then we will ask someone at the Library of Congress to follow up.
Another question, from Yu in Shanghai: "As far as promoting cooperation in science and technology between the United States and China, what are you planning to do?"
The President kept it innocuous, citing earthquake prediction and spina bifida research, and then asked that anyone wth an idea write it down and mail it to him. There seemed to be no need to mention nuclear or satellite technology.
There was one question with a little juice.
"You seem very healthy, and you seem to have a very nice figure, Mr. President," said another Li in Shanghai. "When you were in college, which sports did you like to play? That's the first question. The second question I'd like to ask, if you could answer, Mr. President, is how do you maintain your energy in your work? And then the third thing is: can you predict who's going to win the World Cup?"
The short version: he played basketball in college, started jogging later and finally settled on golf. "It's my favorite sport," he said. "Even though it doesn't burn a lot of calories, it makes my mind calm. So I like it."
And then he threw caution to the winds and predicted that Brazil would be "hard to beat" in the world soccer tournament.
Mr. Clinton's host in Shanghai, Mayor Xu Kuangdi, was also in the studio to answer questions and he could almost hold his own with the President, talking at length about auto emissions and the information superhighway.
Then came a question from Wang in Shanghai: "Can you both talk about education exchanges and the future for them between the United States and China?"
Education seemed to be the favorite topic for each man, so they were off like horses, taking turns racing in the lead. Mr. Clinton spoke for several minutes about the need for computer literacy, affordable education and exchange programs, concluding with a typically innocuous "and I think it will only grow more important as we move into the next century."
Mr. Xu came back with a lengthy discussion about the need for Chinese teachers to consider introducing elements of the American teaching system to foster greater individuality.
"In Chinese eduation we talk about the filling of information into the student, whereas in the United States they try to make students more able," Mr. Xu said. "They try to teach you how to have the ability to do things. So Chinese are very good at tests, but not necessarily when it comes to scientific research."
Mr. Clinton rejoined: "Well, actually, here's a case where I think we would greatly benefit from working together, because there is no perfect system. If you just start with the issue of discipline and order in the classroom, it's impossible for learning to occur. We also know that if there is too much order, where everything is structured, the child may close up and not be open to information and to learning. So we have tried all kinds of things.
"Now on the second matter," and he went on for a while longer.
It was only toward the end of the hour that Mr. Clinton found a way to sound his sole note of political imperative, similar to what he said at the news conference with Mr. Jiang and at Beijing University.
"I believe, as I have said repeatedly, that high levels of personal freedom are quite important to the success of a society in the information age," he said, "because you need people who feel free to explore, to state their views, to explore their own convictions and then live out their own dreams, and that this will add to the stability of a society by enriching it. That's what I believe."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES;
Optimism Over Economic Efforts by Japan Bolsters Yen

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The dollar plummeted more than two and a half yen yesterday -- its biggest loss since the United States and Japan sold dollars two weeks ago -- as traders reacted to signs that Japan was making progress to mend its ailing banking industry.
Traders also bought yen after Taku Yamasaki, the policy chief of Japan's ruling Liberal Democratic Party, said he was considering a permanent tax cut to stimulate economic growth. 
 "People have been clamoring for a permanent tax cut and a deal to bail out the banking system," said Mark Turner, the chief investment officer at the Schooner Asset Management Company in Boston. "It would appear Japan is going to deliver. It's only natural people will review their bearishness on the yen."
In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 139.16 yen, down from 141.69 late on Monday.
Optimism over Japan's financial industry arose after Okiharu Yasuoka, chairman of a committee working on the bank cleanup, gave Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto an early draft of a program for a decision expected tomorrow. That bolstered expectations the Government was speeding up efforts to lift Japan out of recession. Japan's Government is struggling to shore up a banking system beset by 77 trillion yen, or $555 billion, in problem loans.
Comments by Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin also fostered speculation that the United States and Japanese Governments might jointly sell dollars to bolster the yen, as they did earlier this month, analysts said.
"There are a number of bases on which we might judge it proper to intervene" in the future, Mr. Rubin said in Bangkok, Thailand, a stop on his tour of four Asian nations.
The Bank of Japan, along with the United States Treasury and Federal Reserve, sold dollars for yen two weeks ago, shaving six yen off the dollar in a day. The yen's weakness -- which lowers the cost of Japanese exports -- could press Japan's trade rivals to allow their currencies to weaken as well.
The yen also received a boost from a report in the Internet version of the newspaper Yomiuri that said Mr. Yamasaki was considering a permanent income tax cut -- a move Japan's trading partners have urged the Government to make.
In a sign the Japanese economy remains troubled, a report showed yesterday that Japan's unemployment rate in May remained at a record high of 4.1 percent for the second straight month as some of the nation's biggest companies were forced to cut jobs. Other reports showed housing starts in May fell 17 percent from the same month a year earlier, the 17th straight monthly drop.
"If you're looking to buy yen because you think the economy is going to turn around any time soon, you may be sorely disappointed," Mr. Turner of Schooner Asset Management said.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Signs of Slower Growth Lift Treasury Prices

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The prices of Treasury bonds climbed yesterday after reports on manufacturing and retail sales suggested that the economy was slowing and that inflation was tame.
"The economy will slow down," said Jeffrey Eglow, who helps manage more than $250 million at Highlander Capital Management in Parsippany, N.J. "We see lower rates" in the weeks and months ahead, he said. 
 The Chicago branch of the National Association of Purchasing Management reported a bigger-than-expected drop in its manufacturing index, to 52.9 in June from 56.3 in May. The group's prices-paid index, a gauge of inflation, also fell. The report helped bonds recover losses suffered after the dollar plunged against the yen.
The benchmark 30-year Treasury bond rose 9/32 yesterday, to 107 6/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 5.62 percent, from 5.64 percent on Monday.
Bonds also got a lift after a private report by LJR Redbook Research showed a drop of seven-tenths of 1 percent in retail sales in the month through June 27, compared with figures from the corresponding period in May, and as traders bet that the report on employment in June, to be released tomorrow, may fall short of expectations. Some investors also put cash to work at the end of the quarter to put more high-quality bonds on their books before reporting quarterly results, traders said.
"Some of the gains are quarter-end related," said Mark Sauvigne, a trader at Chase Securities Inc.
Benchmark 30-year bonds handed investors returns of 5.8 percent in the second quarter, when price gains and interest are taken into account. In the first half of the year, Treasury bonds gained 7.2 percent, or $72,000 for each $1 million investment made at the start of the year.

HEADLINE: U.S. Nuclear Arms' Cost Put at $5.48 Trillion

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 30

 BODY:
Nuclear weapons have cost the United States at least $5.48 trillion since 1940, and for most of that time neither Congress, the armed services nor the President had a clear idea what was being spent, according to a four-year study sponsored by the Brookings Institution.
The figure, which is stated in 1996 dollars converted under a Defense Department formula, represents about a third of the nation's military spending and about one-tenth of all expenditures by the Federal Government from 1940 to 1996; only non-nuclear defense programs and Social Security cost more. 
 The money spent on nuclear weapons, plus money for environmental cleanup, would buy 290 million automobiles, says an author of the study, William J. Weida, a professor of economics at Colorado College in Colorado Springs and a former director of the Economic Policy and Analysis division of the Defense Department.
Stephen I. Schwartz, editor of the study, said, "Nuclear weapons were considered to give more 'bang for the buck.' " For that reason, Mr. Schwartz said, policy planners have paid little attention to costs.
The study, "Atomic Audit: The Costs and Consequences of U.S. Nuclear Weapons Since 1940," was published today by Brookings, a research center in Washington.
The cost of nuclear weapons programs has never been compiled before, according to the study. The cost includes money spent to invent them and produce them, build the missiles, bombers and submarines to deliver them and to defend against enemy nuclear attacks. In addition, cleaning up environmental damage resulting from the production of nuclear weapons will bring the total cost to $5.82 trillion, based on estimates of what will be needed in the next 80 years, the study said.
The Defense Department and the Atomic Energy Commission or its successor, the Department of Energy, were at the center of most of these programs.
Producing nuclear weapons accounted for only about 7 percent of the total cost, the study said. Deploying the weapons, including the cost of missiles and bombers, accounted for 55.7 percent of the total; defending against nuclear attacks made up 16.1 percent; targeting and controlling the weapons made up 14.3 percent and nuclear waste management and cleanup was 6.3 percent.
The study group said one reason for the high costs was interservice rivalry, with the Air Force getting nuclear arms and then the Navy and Army wanting them, too.
The study's authors said strategic deterrence had prevented nuclear conflict and probably conventional conflict in Europe as well. Although they said that task could have been accomplished more cheaply, they did not say how much more cheaply.
Some of the money went for projects that failed, like the development of a nuclear-powered airplane and the deployment of nuclear bombs under the Greenland ice cap. Far more was spent on producing nuclear weapons that the authors say were far in excess of military requirements. Mr. Weida, the economist, said part of the problem was pork barrel politics. Lawmakers were loath to cut back or cancel production of nuclear weapons in plants in their states or districts.
"The tie between regional economic benefits and nuclear weapons," he said, "created an inertia which made it extremely difficult to curtail nuclear weapons programs after their useful life had expired."

HEADLINE: Whitman Cuts $42.8 Million From Budget

BYLINE: By JENNIFER PRESTON 

DATELINE: TRENTON, June 30

 BODY:
Gov. Christine Todd Whitman signed a new $18.1 billion state budget into law tonight, using her line-item veto power to eliminate $42.8 million in legislative spending, as well as language prohibiting her from turning public employee jobs over to private contractors.
The state budget, approved by lawmakers on Monday, raises spending by almost $1 billion for public schools, state colleges and universities, preservation of open spaces, and various other programs. It also puts $700 million aside in a "rainy day fund." 
 Although Governor Whitman and lawmakers had reached agreement on the broad outlines of the new spending plan for the fiscal year, which begins on July 1, she used her line-item veto power to strike some spending increases that were included by lawmakers and some budget language that her aides said would have reduced her authority.
Governor Whitman eliminated the biggest item that legislators had included for property tax relief: a $10 million increase in state aid for municipalities. Whitman aides said that before allocating more municipal aid, the Governor wanted to see what recommendations her commission on property tax reform would make at its meeting next month.
Mrs. Whitman cut other spending increases, including a $6.5 million addition for park maintenance and $6 million that had been added for capital projects at state colleges and universities.
Expressing concern about the rise in the number of "special appropriations" that lawmakers added to the budget this year for various projects in their districts, she warned that groups and organizations receiving the extra aid should not rely on it in the future.
She also eliminated state spending for about a dozen legislative projects, including $300,000 for a proposed Yogi Berra museum on the campus at Montclair State University and $1.5 million for a new Morris County Fire and Police Academy.
Spending for various legislative projects totaled about $60 million in the new state budget, about $20 million more than this year's budget.
"The increase in special appropriations reflects the availability of revenues generated by our robust economy," the Governor said. "During such times, it is appropriate to support worthy causes and to meet unaddressed needs. The recipients of such special appropriations should not, however, become reliant on state support since such support is, by its nature, temporary."
Some of the cuts that Mrs. Whitman made in the new budget were not popular with lawmakers.
State Senator Robert E. Littell, a Republican and chairman of the Senate Appropriations Committee, said he was disappointed by many of the changes the Governor made. He had recommended the spending increase in park maintenance and he called Mrs. Whitman's decision to reduce the allocation "very shortsighted," particularly since she was pushing to purchase a million acres of undeveloped land over the coming decade.
"You can't ask people to buy more land when you don't take care of what you have," he said.
Governor Whitman also struck out language that would have prevented the administration from withholding funds to municipalities for development projects, like sewers and roads, that are inconsistent with the state's growth-management plan.
On the issue of privatization of state jobs, she eliminated language that would have prevented the administration from turning any state jobs over to private contractors.
But in a move suggesting that Mrs. Whitman may not use privatization this year, she left $7 million untouched that lawmakers had put back into the budget, the amount her aides estimate privatization would save. The Whitman administration is considering privatizing an estimated 500 jobs in the Department of Transportation's engineering department and the Corrections Department's food service division.
Assemblyman Richard Bagger, a Republican and chairman of the Assembly Appropriations Committee, said the language had been inserted because lawmakers did not think it was appropriate for state employees to lose their jobs when the economy was pouring so much extra tax revenue into the state's coffers.
State Treasurer James A. DiEleuterio Jr. said that the question of eliminating some state jobs and turning them over to private contractors was still under discussion.
Despite the urging of some lawmakers and Mayor Milton Milan of Camden, Governor Whitman did not change language that authorizes a state-appointed review board to oversee Camden's finances.

HEADLINE: Commercial Real Estate;
Plan Seeks to Clarify Muddled Lower Manhattan

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

 BODY:
As Nieuw Amsterdam was only 22 blocks in extent, one Dutch colonist could easily find another by suggesting a rendezvous at the market field. Do not try that today.
"If you say, 'I'll meet you at Marketfield and Broad,' even I couldn't get there in 20 minutes," said Carl Weisbrod. And he's the president of the Alliance for Downtown New York. And his office is only a 10-minute walk from tiny Marketfield Street, near Bowling Green. 
 Historic as lower Manhattan's tangled 17th-century street plan may be, it confounds New Yorkers and out-of-towners, leaving them intimidated. The problem is compounded by inadequate signs and insufficient nighttime light.
So the Alliance, which runs the downtown business improvement district, has embarked on a $13.5 million streetscape improvement plan that includes the installation of specially designed "street furniture": simple lampposts, sturdy wastebaskets, benches with spring-loaded seats and a wordless "wayfinding" system.
Wayfinding signs, mounted on poles or at subway stops, will combine one or two pictographs of familiar landmarks -- the Statue of Liberty, World Trade Center, Trinity Church and Brooklyn Bridge among them -- with bold arrows showing whether the destination is straight ahead, to the left or right.
Street signs installed as part of the project will include a numerical range of addresses above the street name. Installation of the signs and 650 wastebaskets is to begin later this year, Mr. Weisbrod said.
Though undertaken privately, the plan fits into the Giuliani administration's downtown revitalization effort, said Joseph B. Rose, chairman of the City Planning Commission.
"The streetscape in lower Manhattan has had a down-at-the-heels quality," Mr. Rose said. "Having it be a pleasant, uplifting, intelligible experience -- as opposed to a bewildering one -- is an important part of shaping attitudes."
The project is to proceed on a "pay-as-you-go" basis, Mr. Weisbrod said, financed by the earmarking of 2.5 cents out of the 12.7-cent-a-square-foot annual assessment paid by property owners in the district. The Alliance will also use a $3 million reserve fund that it has accumulated.
The largest element of the streetscape plan is an $11 million reconstruction of Broadway from Bowling Green to Murray Street, near City Hall, with new sidewalks, curbs and the special fixtures.
As an extra touch, the ticker-tape parades along the "Canyon of Heroes," as lower Broadway is called, will be commemorated in eight-inch granite bands set into the sidewalk pavement every 20 feet, with stainless steel letters spelling out the dates and names of those honored.
Improving the streetscape is a tangible declaration that "downtown is very much alive," said Robert R. Douglass, chairman of the Alliance and former vice chairman of the Chase Manhattan Corporation. "And there would be no more visible evidence than Broadway, which is the major signature street."
The overall design is by Cooper, Robertson & Partners, a firm chosen in part because Alexander Cooper was co-architect of the master plan for Battery Park City.
"The instruction we were given was that we should avoid a 'B.I.D. esthetic,' " Mr. Cooper said. "The esthetic should be targeted to this place and not be 34th Street or 42d Street redux."
That left the question of what the lampposts should look like. At Battery Park City, the "bishop's-crook" design of the 19th century has been brought back to handsome effect.
"A no-brainer would have been historic fixtures," Mr. Cooper said. "But we thought that the approach that would set off historic buildings the best would be to use a contemporary fixture that was classical in its way and understated; that did not call attention to itself."
The result is an unadorned L-shaped lamppost 26 feet high, with an octagonal steel shaft that tapers into a cylinder as it rises. The lamp is housed in a disk at the end of a 6-foot arm. A companion piece is an even simpler 15 1/2-foot-high fixture topped by a slender, 3-foot-high cylindrical lamp.
Pentagram Design is responsible for the signage, Caribiner Communications for the lighting, Quennell Rothschild Associates for the landscaping and Vollmer Associates for the engineering.
More and more attention is being paid to the esthetics of so-called street furniture. Last year, the bidders seeking a citywide franchise for bus-stop shelters, newsstands and public toilets were some of the more highly regarded architects in the world.
Richard Meier, the architect of the new J. Paul Getty Museum at the Getty Center in Los Angeles, designed the proposal submitted by Adshel Inc.; Josef Paul Kleihues designed the proposal by Wall City Design Inc. and Nicholas Grimshaw designed the proposal by Transportation Displays Inc..
For its submission, JCDecaux New York assembled a roster of celebrated architects and designers: Peter Eisenman, Sir Norman Foster, Charles Gwathmey and Robert Siegel, James Stewart Polshek, Robert A. M. Stern, Massimo Vignelli, and Tod Williams and Billie Tsien.
On Friday, however, the Transportation Department informed the bidders that a citywide franchise would not be awarded. Instead, the agency said it would explore a program "that would encourage competition and greater design variation in the structures to distinguish the city's neighborhoods."

HEADLINE: CLINTON IN CHINA: THE OVERVIEW;
Clinton Tells Of Hopes and Risks On Trade

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: SHANGHAI, Wednesday, July 1

 BODY:
President Clinton told American business leaders today that corruption, environmental neglect, weak financial regulation and restrictive trade practices threaten China's growth and full entry into the global economic system.
In an address to the American Chamber of Commerce here, Mr. Clinton said rapid economic growth has brought significant challenges to the Chinese Government and people. 
 He said the dynamic growth of the last 20 years and the rapid pace of reform have changed the lives of Chinese citizens, bringing more career choices and opportunities to run their own businesses, but also breaking the system of guaranteed lifetime employment as Beijing slashes payrolls at Government-owned enterprises.
"China's economy still is burdened with complicated and overlapping barriers," Mr. Clinton said in his 21-minute address at the Portman Ritz Carlton hotel. He said he hoped that Beijing would make the difficult decisions needed to bring China into the World Trade Organization on the same terms that govern the other members of the global trading body.
"China and, indeed, Shanghai, face major challenges in advancing economic progress beyond the present point," the President said.
He specifically cited the problems of inefficient state monopolies, weak legal and regulatory systems, wasteful and polluting energy patterns, corruption, closed markets and poor supervision of the nation's banks.
"The United States is prepared to work with China in meeting these challenges because the success of China will affect not only the Chinese people and Chinese prosperity, but America's well-being and global stability as well."
The White House also announced today that Mr. Clinton would meet in Hong Kong with Martin Lee, the leading advocate for democracy there. This is a calculated affront to Beijing, which took control of the former British colony a year ago. The White House is playing down the meeting, which will take place in the President's suite at the Hyatt Hotel Kong on Friday. No public statements are planned, officials said.
In a concession to Beijing on another sensitive issue, Mr. Clinton formally stated on Tuesday that the United States did not support independence for Taiwan.
The Chinese Government, which considers Taiwan a breakaway province that should be politically reunited with the mainland, had pressed Mr. Clinton to state the American policy while he was on Chinese soil.
Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright and other officials have expressed the carefully worded position on other occasions. But it was important to Beijing that the words come from the President himself, and he obliged during a discussion with Shanghai residents today.
In response to a question from Wu Xinbo, a professor in the American Studies Institute at Fudan University here, Mr. Clinton said he had told Jiang Zemin, China's President, that American policy on Taiwan remained unchanged.
Reiterating what is known as "the three no's," Mr. Clinton said: "I had a chance to reiterate our Taiwan policy, which is that we don't support independence for Taiwan, or two Chinas, or one Taiwan-one China. And we don't believe that Taiwan should be a member in any organization for which statehood is a requirement."
Taiwan reacted harshly, although Mr. Clinton followed the same formula that American officials have used before. "The United States and Chinese Communists have no rights and are in no position to conduct bilateral talks on anything related to our affairs," said Roy Wu, Taiwan's Foreign Ministry spokesman.
There is considerable debate about how new Mr. Clinton's statement is. The "three no's" formula was publicly used last fall by the State Department, which saw it as a reiteration of longstanding policy. But some scholars and supporters of Taiwan say the formula, as it was expressed then, was more detailed and restrictive than past statements, and they called on Mr. Clinton to disavow it.
Officials traveling with Mr. Clinton tried to minimize the importance of the President's statement. He told the same thing to Mr. Jiang, they said, and there was no intention of putting it into a written communique, which would give it more weight.
"The President himself had indicated prior to coming here that he would reaffirm longstanding U.S. policy, and he did so," said Michael D. McCurry, the White House spokesman. "During the course of this visit we've made it clear both publicly and privately that we hope the people of Taiwan and the people of the People's Republic find an amicable resolution to the question of Taiwan."
