HEADLINE: Alabama Governor Wins Runoff in Triumph for the Right

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK 

DATELINE: MONTGOMERY, Ala., June 30

 BODY:
In a convincing victory for religious conservatives, Gov. Fob James Jr. won a decisive majority tonight over the businessman Winton Blount 3d in Alabama's Republican primary runoff for governor.
The Governor's triumph sets up another intriguing battle, in the general election in November, when Mr. James will face Lieut. Gov. Don Siegelman, who easily won the Democratic nomination four weeks ago. Mr. Siegelman, who has hoarded cash while the Republicans skirmished, hopes that his proposal for a new lottery to finance education will help break the Republicans' near stranglehold on statewide offices in this once solidly Democratic state. 
 The caustic Republican campaign was seen very much as a referendum on Mr. James, 63, whose unvarnished political style and strong support for school prayer have made him a modern-day emblem of Southern defiance. In his campaign, the Governor alternated between Christian professions of God-fearing faith and a less charitable take on his opponent, whom he mocked for his heft and his inherited wealth.
The race also provided an unobstructed view of the strains facing the South's newly dominant Republican Party. While each man embraced some of the other's positions, Mr. James spoke most passionately to the state's social conservatives while Mr. Blount harped on the need to accelerate economic growth.
With 93 percent of precincts reporting, Mr. James led Mr. Blount by 56 percent to 44 percent. The Governor finished first in the five-man primary on June 2, but could not enough to escape a runoff.
"It's always good to have a tough scrimmage or two before the big game," said a beaming Mr. James after declaring victory tonight. "And I've had two."
For the adaptable Mr. James, an Auburn University football star who made a fortune selling plastic-coated barbells, today's victory extends a resilient political career. Mr. James has switched parties twice in the last two decades, and he has needed a runoff to win his party's nomination in each of three campaigns for governor. He first renounced his Republican roots before running successfully for governor as a Democrat in 1978. After choosing not to seek a second term, he switched back to the Republican Party to run in 1994.
A poll taken last week showed this year's race to be a dead heat, with Mr. Blount leading by a single percentage point. But in the end, the mechanics of a midsummer runoff with few other races on the ballot favored Mr. James, who apparently succeeded in pulling his Christian conservative supporters to the polls. Last week's survey, which was taken for three Alabama newspapers, showed that he was overwhelmingly favored by those who said they took the Bible to be literal truth.
Mr. James and his advisers did not shy from his identification with the religious right. In advertisements and public appearances, Mr. James boasted about his quixotic efforts to reverse the United States Supreme Court's three-decade-old rulings against school prayer.
Mr. James's lead consultant, Ralph Reed, the former executive director of the Christian Coalition, contended that the election would serve as a national test of the strength of Christian conservatives. "I don't need to tell you that in God's wisdom and planning, the eyes of America are going to be on Alabama on June 30," Mr. Reed told a group of ministers last week.
Mr. Blount took pains to insist that he, too, was for returning prayer to the schools. But he argued that Mr. James's open talk of sedition, including a court brief suggesting that Supreme Court rulings do not bind the states, had been a national embarrassment. In addition to distracting attention from the need to improve schools and recruit new industry, Mr. Blount said, the Governor's approach to school prayer harked back to the days when Gov. George C. Wallace used state's rights arguments to stymie desegregation.
Mr. Blount, 54, is the son of Winton M. Blount, a Montgomery construction and manufacturing magnate. The younger Mr. Blount owns automobile dealerships and a plastics company, and he outspent Mr. James by nearly two to one, financing his campaign with his own money and that of his family. The centerpiece of his campaign was a proposal to eliminate the state's 4 percent sales tax on food, which served to counter Mr. James's pledge not to raise state taxes.
Mr. Blount had hoped to benefit from an unusual provision that allows all Alabama voters to participate in a Republican primary runoff, regardless of whether they voted or how they voted in the first primary. Last week, Mayor Richard Arrington Jr. of Birmingham, a five-term Democrat, endorsed Mr. Blount for the Republican nomination and announced that his mostly black political machine, the Jefferson County Citizens Coalition, would work to turn out Democratic votes for him.
Mr. James's strategists worried that Democratic voters could provide the margin of victory for Mr. Blount. But they worked assiduously in the campaign's final days to encourage a backlash by portraying Mr. Arrington as a liberal Democratic boss who had demanded concessions on appointments and spending priorities from Mr. Blount. That contention was denied by both men.
In a final television advertisement broadcast last weekend, Mr. James charged that "Winton Blount sold out the Republican Party." Picturing Mr. Blount beside Mr. Arrington, who is black, the advertisement asked, "If he wins Tuesday, who'll be the real Governor?" Mr Blount accused Mr. James of making a racial appeal, an accusation he denied.

SECTION: Section D; Page 6; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS;
Corporate Underwriting Soared in First Half of '98

BYLINE: By JOSEPH KAHN 

 BODY:
Wall Street generated more money for corporate America in the first half of this year than any other six-month period in history, as historically low interest rates and a still buoyant stock market gave fresh momentum to the business of issuing stock and debt.
The frenzied pace of underwriting has helped finance consolidation in almost every area of industry, reflected in the record pace of mergers and acquisitions. Companies worldwide completed mergers and acquisitions valued at $1.36 billion in the first half of this year, double the figure from the corresponding period a year ago. 
 The money-raising boom also channeled funds into start-up companies and financed investment in technology and production equipment at larger ones, helping prime America's economy for strong expansion in the second half, analysts said.
"My sense is that this reflects a great entrepreneurial spirit in the economy," said Peter Blanton, an equity capital markets specialist at Credit Suisse First Boston. "You have people who are starting companies or companies investing in new growth areas because of the availability of capital today. That means it is having an effect on the real economy."
At just shy of $1 trillion, securities companies raised almost as much money for clients in the January to June period as they did during the whole of last year, which was in itself a record, according to the Securities Data Company of Newark. That, in turn, has meant soaring profits for Wall Street's leading securities companies. Many have seen their already strong earning growth accelerate so far this year with jumps of one-third or more in first-half profits.
The question for many on Wall Street is whether the underwriting juggernaut will meet resistance in the second half. Some analysts expect that the drop in interest rates this year prompted a one-time jump in companies seeking to take advantage of low rates to refinance earlier debt. That trend will not necessarily continue in the second half, as debt offerings slowed significantly as the second quarter came to a close.
"We have been seeing nearly perfect conditions for people to borrow money," said Jeff Chandler, head of the global debt syndicate desk at Merrill Lynch & Company, Wall Street's leading debt underwriter. "But I would be hard pressed to say that the level of issuance is going to continue."
The outlook for stock issues is also murky. Many securities firms say they have a large backlog of equity offerings that should keep them busy through the year, as hundreds of companies have taken the first steps toward raising capital on the public markets and world governments continue to sell the public stakes in government-controlled phone and energy companies.
But the stock market has turned choppy in recent weeks and investors have become fussier about what kinds of newly issued stocks they want to buy. June was one of the worst months in recent memory for initial public offerings, with at least a dozen companies that were scheduled to issue shares deciding to hold off until market conditions improve.
"We have a combination of a more flattish market and a more selective buyer. Things are slower going into the summer," said Thomas Tuft, co-head of global equity capital markets at Goldman, Sachs & Company.
Others see new stock issues picking up in the fall, however, as some delayed deals from the summer and a bulging backlog of fresh corporate offerings compete for investors' attention.
With Wall Street steaming ahead at top speed, there was enough business to keep every big investment bank bustling. But the battle to lock up clients and generate fees was as fierce as ever, with the major brokerage houses fighting for the top spots on the quarterly league tables, the brokerage house rankings.
For the second quarter, Merrill Lynch was the clear leader in overall offerings of debt and equity. In total, Merrill underwrote $169 billion of securities, for a 16.9 percent market share. Salomon Smith Barney was No. 2, with Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, Goldman, Sachs and Lehman Brothers rounding out the top five.
Ranked by underwriting initial public offerings of stock, the most hotly contested brokerage business because of the large fees associated with that work, Goldman, Sachs took a dominant leadership position. The private bank underwrote about $2.5 billion worth of new issues, for a 22 percent market share. Morgan Stanley, Salomon Smith Barney, Prudential Securities and Credit Suisse First Boston made up the top five.
Merrill Lynch was a surprise laggard in new equity issues so far this year. A Merrill official said, however, that a large initial public offering priced yesterday, the last day of the second quarter, would make it the second-largest underwriter for the period if that deal were added to its total.
Salomon Smith Barney, which itself is the result of a merger late last year, put in a strong equity underwriting performance after slipping in the rankings last year. The company ranked third among brokerage firms for equity underwriting so far this year, compared with a seventh-place performance in the corresponding period a year ago.
"I think this is indicative of the type of equity distribution we put together," said Jim Cowles, head of equity capital markets at Salomon. "After the merger, we are bringing in clients that we did not have before."

HEADLINE: Birth Rate Falls to 40-Year Low Among Unwed Black Women

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 30

 BODY:
The birth rate for unmarried black women, long a focal point in the debate over the causes of poverty among African-Americans, has reached its lowest point in 40 years, Federal health officials said today.
According to figures compiled by the National Center for Health Statistics, there were 74.4 births per 1,000 unmarried black women in 1996 -- the last year for which complete data are available. That rate is significantly below the peak of 90.7 per 1,000 unmarried black women reached in 1989. 
 Today's report showed that the out-of-wedlock birth rate has been dropping for all age groups of black women. Demographers and health officials said that some of the possible reasons -- an increase in contraceptive use, sex education and efforts by some community groups to encourage abstention -- should allow the trend to continue.
"There's just been no letup, and it's not been slowing down," said Stephanie J. Ventura, a demographer with the National Center for Health Statistics who wrote the report. "And it's not just for teen-agers. For all black women under 30, the declines have been really big."
The figures on fertility rates for unmarried black women are part of an annual report on births compiled by the Health Statistics Center, a division of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Using data from birth certificates submitted by the states, the report analyzed the 3.9 million births that occurred in 1996 and highlighted a number of trends, including these:
*Fewer babies were born that year than in any year since 1987; the continued decline put the number of births at 6 percent below the recent high point, which was 1990;
*The number of multiple births rose sharply, and resulted in 5,298 sets of triplets, 560 sets of quadruplets and 81 sets of quintuplets. The multiple births contributed to a 10 percent increase in the number of low birth-weight babies since 1984;
*Smoking among pregnant teen-agers increased, particularly among Mexican-American, Puerto Rican and black teen-agers; but overall smoking during pregnancy continued to decrease.
One of the most closely watched numbers is the out-of-wedlock birth rate for black women, long considered one of the clearest symptoms, and some say causes, of many problems that have plagued poor blacks.
The decline in that rate is part of a continuing decrease in fertility among all black women -- teen-age and adult, married and unmarried -- which means that the percentage of black births to unmarried women remains virtually unchanged from the previous year at 69.8 percent.
There has even been a small but notable decrease in the overall birth rate among unmarried women, to 44.8 per 1,000 in 1996 from 46.9 per 1,000 in 1994. That stems from a drop in the birth rate among unmarried white woman, which had more than doubled from 1980 to 1994 before it began to drop, hitting 37.6 per 1,000 women in 1996.
Even as the number of unmarried black women bearing children has been dropping, the percentage of black children who are born out-of-wedlock remains high. It was 69.8 percent of black births in 1996. The comparable figures for non-Hispanic whites was 21.5 percent and for Hispanics, 40.7 percent.
Some experts said the percentage of children born outside of marriage was more meaningful than the birth rate of unmarried women as a sign that too many black children were being raised in environments where they were most at risk to become engaged in crime, drug abuse, or other anti-social behavior.
"If you care about the link between black poverty and children in single-parent households, you want to know what percentage of black babies are born into one-parent households," said Stephan Thernstrom, co-author of "America in Black and White: One Nation, Indivisible." "I don't think there's been a decline in that. That would be real news."
Demographers say the Government has kept accurate birth statistics by race and marital status since 1955. Until 1969, the statistics lumped black women into a category that included all racial minorities, but experts say the vast portion of births to nonwhites in those years were to black women. The previous low birth rate for unmarried black women was 75.2 per 1,000 in 1984.
The fact that the out-of-wedlock birth rate among blacks is lower now than it was in the 1950's and 1960's surprised even experts who follow these trends.
"If you had asked me about that before these data came out, I would not have been aware of that," Jacqueline Darroch, vice president for research at the Alan Guttmacher Institute. "And I don't think most people would be either."
Ms. Darroch and Federal health officials gave several reasons for the decrease in the out-of-wedlock birth rate for black women: improved contraceptive use, especially a sharp increase among black women of passive, long-acting birth control methods like Norplant, Depo-Provera and intrauterine devices.
Some health officials also say that stepped up efforts by community groups to provide sex education or help young black women abstain from sex are beginning to pay off. And some said that the AIDS epidemic is causing more black women to take precautions like using condoms that can also lower the pregnancy rate.
"We really did scare people," said Dr. Donna E. Shalala, Secretary of Health and Human Services. "The remarkable increase in condom use by African-Americans is directly attributed to AIDS."
Changes in the welfare system have not been a significant factor, according to some people who monitor fertility rates. Noting that out-of-wedlock birth rates for black women have been dropping steadily since 1989, they assert that the decline started before states and the Federal Government enacted welfare reform measures.
"This is happening at a time when the economy is improving," said Kristin Moore, president of Child Trends, a research and advocacy group in Washington. "We're seeing a trend that pre-dated welfare reform, so I would more likely look at the economy as a hypothesis rather than welfare reform."

CORRECTION-DATE: July 2, 1998, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
A front-page article yesterday about birth rates referred incorrectly to the figures given for multiple births in 1996. The numbers represented individual babies, not sets of them. Thus 5,298 babies were born as triplets, 560 as quadruplets and 81 as quintuplets or in higher-order multiples.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Walkouts to Cost G.M. $1.18 Billion in 2d Quarter
General Motors said strikes at two factories in Flint, Mich., which have forced 26 of the auto maker's 29 North American assembly plants to close, will cost the company $1.18 billion after taxes in the second quarter. 
 A dispute at two Delphi Chassis Systems brake plants in Dayton, Ohio, may also lead to another strike by members of the United Automobile Workers union. Page D2.
 
F.D.A. Approves New Sweetener
The Food and Drug Administration has approved the use of an artificial sweetener known as Ace-K in soft drinks. Analysts predict that Ace-K, marketed by Hoechst as Sunett and officially known as acesulfame potassium, will add $55 billion in sales to the nation's carbonated soft-drink industry. An hour after the F.D.A. announcement, Pepsico said it planned to introduce by October a diet cola called Pepsi One using Ace-K and aspartame. D2.
 
Shareholders Are Getting Skeptical
Investors are growing tired and skeptical of the merger frenzy. Indeed, so far this year, stocks of 59 percent of the companies that announced they would buy other public companies fell the day of the announcement, up from 49 percent in the first half of 1997. Market Place. D7.
 
Sales of Windows 98 Robust
Sales of Windows 98 are brisk despite a puny marketing budget and little fanfare. Retailers sold 530,000 copies of Microsoft's new operating system in the first four days and one analyst estimates that Windows 98 will generate revenues of $3.2 billion in its first 12 months from sales to both computer makers and retail customers. D5.
 
Japan's Fiscal Efforts Bolster Yen
The dollar plummeted more than two and a half yen -- its biggest loss since the United States and Japan sold dollars two weeks ago -- as traders reacted to signs that Japan was making progress to mend its ailing banking industry. D8.
 
Nike Reports Loss of $67.6 Million
Shares of Nike fell even before the athletic shoe and apparel company reported a net loss of $67.6 million for its latest quarter because of continued economic woes in the Asia-Pacific region and weakness in the United States market. Nike also said after the market closed that its orders for the coming six months were off 54 percent in the Asia-Pacific region and 11 percent in the United States, and worldwide total orders were down 13 percent. D2.
 
Confidence Index at 29-Year High
Consumer confidence in the economy rose in June to a 29-year high, as Americans remained optimistic that the strong labor market and healthy economic growth will continue. D2.
 
CBS Starts Push for Its Fall Lineup
CBS recruited Lowe & Partners/SMS in New York to create a series of brand-building television commercials for the network, which is gearing up for the 1998-99 television season. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. D4.
 
First Boston Hires Technology Team
Credit Suisse First Boston has hired the leaders of Deutsche Bank's global high- technology banking business in an effort to build its franchise in the fast-growing area of investment banking for computer and software companies. D8.
 
Yield on Treasury Bond Declines
The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond fell to 5.62 percent from 5.64 percent. D8.

HEADLINE: USER'S GUIDE;
Digital Bread Crumbs Through the Forest

BYLINE: By Michelle Slatalla; E-mail address: Slatalla@nytimes.com

 BODY:
FOR a long time, I thought that it was my fault that I could never find the information I wanted on the Web. My search method -- typing one or two words hastily into a query box -- rarely yielded worthwhile results.
So imagine my relief to learn that my approach is typical. A recently published study of one million queries conducted in a single day in 1997 on the Excite search site found that only one in nine users embrace the nuances of Boolean logic to concoct sophisticated queries. The rest of us "are basically entering one or two search terms in the query box," said Amanda Spink, one of the study's authors and an assistant professor in the School of Library and Information Sciences at the University of North Texas. 
 Since there is no evidence that users can be persuaded to change, search sites have begun to mold their tools to fit our habits. The challenge is to improve the search results even if users do not improve their search techniques.
The Excite search site has been the most innovative so far, taking the first steps toward what Chris Charron, an analyst at Forrester Research, describes as "adding real intelligence to the search function." What Excite (www.excite.com) has done is try to guess what a user is seeking -- the specific bit of information the user wants to know even when typing a general query -- and then to use that assumption as a starting point for search results.
Here is how it works: If you type a single keyword in the query box on the Excite home page -- try "orioles," for example -- you will see that Excite's staff has made the assumption (based on users' past patterns) that you want information about the Baltimore Orioles baseball team. The search results will be about the team but will not be limited to relevant Web pages from Excite's index. You will also get information culled from other databases -- including those of current publications, for example -- giving you game scores, the team's schedule and recent news articles. All that information will appear on the first screen of the search results.
Excite's co-founder Joe Kraus describes this approach as creating "channels" of information. It also takes into consideration the fact that some users who type "orioles" will not be looking for information about the sports team. For them, the search results page displays a prominent link to sites relevant to other meanings of the word.
Excite has organized information about public companies into channels, as well. So if you type "Microsoft" in the query box, the search results will display the information that past users have sought most frequently: the company's phone number and address, as well as recent news articles, culled from 350 publications, and the stock price (updated every 20 minutes).
When I tried out Excite's system, searching suddenly seemed fun. Not since the long-ago day when I finally mastered the intricacies of the Dewey Decimal System had I felt so empowered by the giddy knowledge that vast troves of valuable facts were mine for the asking. I felt, for a moment, as if the Web could live up to the so-far-mythical promise of organizing the world's information in a coherent and accessible fashion. Here was proof of the value of such a dynamic medium, where facts are in flux -- things like sports scores and stock prices change from minute to minute -- and the latest bits of data are just a click away.
It was easy to get spoiled, but reality brought me up short. It turns out that Excite has so far organized only a fraction of its available information into channels. So if you are searching for something other than information about a sports team or a public company, no channels for you. Back to the old search results, lists of Web sites that might or might not be relevant to the query.
That frustrated me at first. Why was Excite discriminating against users who wanted to search for "applesauce recipes" or "Chesapeake Bay retrievers"? Were we not entitled to, say, the most recent articles published on those topics? But Mr. Kraus calmed me with the news that Excite will expand the scope of its intelligent search function, with plans in the next few months to create a number of other channels on topics like health, cities and celebrities. These channels are likely to appeal to a broad cross-section of users; Ms. Spink's analysis found that users often searched for information about a specific person or place.
Unfortunately, it is impossible to organize all information into channels, Mr. Kraus said. "If you want to know something very specific -- say, the effects of sleep deprivation on heart disease in men on the East Coast -- we won't ever be able to program a channel to answer that query," he said. "That's what we call a needle-in-a-haystack query." To increase the success rate for those kinds of searches, some sites have borrowed a technique that off-line information retrieval systems have been using for decades: improving the relevance of search results.
Infoseek (www.infoseek.com), for instance, determined from search patterns that when most users searched for "airlines," they wanted search results that included the home pages of major airlines. So search results now include those pages.
Another search site, Cnet's Snap (www.snap.com), uses a recipe for finding relevant results to make searches more successful. When a user types a keyword query, the site's software automatically assesses the potential relevance of all the sites in its index, assigning a weight to each site's Web address, description and content, then using those weights to rank sites. To supplement its method, Snap has human editors assign keywords to specific documents to give them added weight. "We can quickly improve relevancy by responding to seasonal trends, news and current events," said Katharine English, the site's executive producer.
How relevant are the results? In my own unscientific experiments, I conducted searches on both sites to try to answer my 7-year-old daughter's question about the average life span of a house cat, and the results indicated that the technology still has a long way to go. It took me about 10 minutes of clicking on unlikely search results to learn that the answer is probably 15 years (according to a source who identified herself only as Cat Lady in a message she posted on the cat health bulletin board of Acme Pet).
Of course, the search results suggested that I might also find the answer at a link called "Stupid threatened Snakes Don't Deserve to Live." But at least I no longer think that's my fault.

HEADLINE: CURRENTS: URBAN RECLAMATION;
The University Calls In Its Flock

BYLINE: By Barbara Flanagan 

 BODY:
Factories used to be the big employers in American cities, and their workers (and owners) lived right downtown. When manufacturing moved out of cities like Baltimore; Birmingham, Ala.; Provo, Utah; New Haven, and Philadelphia, a strange phenomenon emerged. Colleges and universities replaced steel plants and knitting mills as the largest employers; but the faculties and staffs -- even students -- often commuted from the suburbs.
Now, academia has plunged into redeveloping downtown areas near campuses. Yale University invented a New Haven home buyer program to stabilize neighborhoods by helping faculty and staff members to buy homes. Started four years ago, the program has helped 301 people buy inner-city properties and has inspired other schools, like the University of Pennsylvania in Philadelphia, to offer similar incentives. 
 Under Phase 3 of Yale's program, the university pays $25,000 over 10 years, including a $5,000 initial bonus, to any qualified faculty or staff member who buys a home in a designated area. Over the life of the program, the university will have invested about $7.5 million.
Gila Reinstein, 53, a public information officer at Yale who lives with her teen-age son, bought a town house, top, on Bradley Street through the program. "It's great," she said. "I have an urban garden and I can walk to work." Cheryl Morrison, center in dress, a staff member of the graduate school, bought a house on Howard Street. Information is available at www.yale.edu/hronline/hbuyer.

HEADLINE: Record Immigrant Flow Fuels U.S. Home Market

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
WHEN the Lennar Corporation, a building concern, held some home-buying fairs for Florida properties recently, they turned out to be bonanzas for the company, with some leading to six or seven sales on the spot. That may not seem unusual given the strong United States housing market. But these fairs were held in such countries as Brazil, Colombia, Venezuela and the Dominican Republic.
With immigrants flowing into the United States at a record-breaking rate, the fairs are an example of the importance home builders are placing on a demographic group that many analysts and economists expect to fuel the housing industry in the 21st century. 
 "We feel it's important to establish a relationship with these people as soon as possible," said Rita Gonzalez, the director of marketing for Dade County with Miami-based Lennar, which is the fifth-largest United States home builder.
Attracted by a strong economy and an abundance of jobs, people from all over the world are coming to the United States in search of the dream of financial security -- not to mention a house with a two-car garage.
This has the $800 billion housing industry optimistic, especially now that it can no longer count on a stream of baby boomers to buy new houses, as has been the case for much of the last 30 years. The bulk of these Americans are now middle-aged and on their second homes.
"Without immigrants, home-building starts would level off," said Stan Ross, a vice chairman with Ernst & Young's real estate group. "This is a wake-up call."
According to the Immigration and Naturalization Service, more than 10 million foreigners are expected to enter the United States this decade, surpassing the record of 8.8 million from 1901 through 1910. Unlike in the early part of the century, when Ellis Island served as the gateway for millions of Europeans seeking a new life, today's immigrants are mainly from Latin America and Asia.
"The sheer numbers are immense," said Robert Strudler, chairman of the U.S. Home Corporation, the nation's eighth-largest home builder. "We have to take advantage of what's staring us in the face."
U.S. Home, a Houston-based company, has a joint venture with GIG Desarrolladores Inmobiliarios S.A., one of Mexico's largest builders, to construct homes in Texas, Arizona and Florida, all of them priced at less than $70,000.
Beazer Homes USA Inc. of Atlanta and its Mexican partner, Corporacion GEO S.A., are building homes along the Texas border priced at $35,000 to $45,000. Beazer expects the venture to generate $150 million in annual revenue by 2001.
So far, sales to immigrants have had a small impact on earnings for home builders, the companies say. But that impact is expected to grow. The number of immigrant homeowners, which rose by 47 percent to 4.7 million from 1980 to 1995, is expected to grow an additional 45 percent to 6.8 million by 2010, according to Fannie Mae, the nation's biggest provider of home mortgage funds.
Heading into the 21st century, Miami, Los Angeles, San Francisco, San Diego, New York, Houston and their surrounding areas are likely to be affected the most by immigration, analysts say.
Some builders are tailoring their business to suit immigrants. A development in Irvine, Calif., has no home with the number "4" on it because in certain Asian cultures it is a symbol for death. And many people from Latin American nations prefer homes with more than the usual three or four bedrooms to house extended families, some builders say.
"What we are learning is that the immigrant market isn't just one market; it's 100 different markets," said Randall Lewis, executive vice president of Lewis Homes Group, which builds homes in California and Nevada.
Mr. Lewis says he is hiring members of minorities to bridge the communication and cultural gap between the home office and buyers. "When our sales staff gets together, it looks like a meeting of the United Nations," he said.
At a Lewis development in Fontana, Calif., an hour east of Los Angeles, Latin Americans bought about half of the 170 homes. They were drawn to the development, Mr. Lewis said, because homes were built with the living quarters behind a garage that butted up against the street, a style popular throughout Latin America and which immigrants from those countries like for security reasons.
Many of today's immigrants are more educated and more prosperous than their predecessors, and become homeowners soon after their arrival. About 12 percent of recent immigrants have graduate degrees, compared with 8 percent of native-born citizens, according to the National Academy of Sciences.
Some mortgage lenders are making it easier for immigrants. Among other things, they are requiring borrowers to show only a year of stable employment rather than the usual two years.
Joe Varusco, who is in the export business, moved his wife and four children to a Miami suburb from Sao Paulo, Brazil, four years ago. Last year, Mr. Varusco, 39, bought a $180,000 house from Lennar, and found United States lenders more agreeable to work with than the ones back in Brazil.
"Here, it's much easier to buy a house because banks are willing to lend you money for 20 or 30 years," he said. "In Brazil, they don't want to do that."
Newcomers to the United States who rent are almost three times more likely than adult renters to consider buying a home their "No. 1 priority," according to a survey by Fannie Mae. And immigrants, on the whole, are more likely than all adults to buy a home within the next three years, it found.

HEADLINE: Taking on New Forms, Electronic Books Turn a Page

BYLINE: By PETER H. LEWIS 

 BODY:
LET'S face it, if the printed book had just been invented, it would probably get three stars out of five in reviews from the computer magazines. A review of Paper Book 1.0 might conclude with the following summary:
"Pros: Lightweight, portable, inexpensive, high resolution, practically unbreakable, available in multiple languages, easily annotated with write-only stylus, requires no batteries. Can be read while sitting in the smallest room of the house. 
 "Cons: Pages are static rather than dynamic (they cannot be updated once printed); fonts and type sizes are fixed; lack of backlighting makes it difficult to read at night without an external light source; topic selection is limited; paper is inefficient, bulky and subject to mildew and yellowing; paper production is environmentally unfriendly, and content is vulnerable to rampant copyright violations."
"In subsequent versions," the electronic reviewers might write, "we would like to see the Paper Book add interactivity, hyperlinking, a built-in dictionary, animated illustrations, on-line connections to content repositories, encryption to protect the publisher's copyright and other features we take for granted in electronic books."
Printed books have been popular for five centuries, of course, and have enjoyed great success despite the aforementioned shortcomings. But that hasn't stopped recent generations of science fiction authors, futurists, entrepreneurs and even politicians from fantasizing about electronic and digital books.
Speaker Newt Gingrich told an audience last month that replacing printed textbooks with computers should be a goal of the Federal Government. "I would hope within five years they would have no more textbooks," Mr. Gingrich said. In Texas, the chairman of the State Board of Education has proposed spending billions of dollars in coming years to replace printed books with laptop computers and electronic books.
"Like a comet on some weird, loopy orbit, this idea comes around every 10 years or so," said Paul Saffo, a director of the Institute for the Future, a research group based in Menlo Park, Calif. "Each time we get a closer approximation."
This time around, at least three digital approximations of books are scheduled to be introduced, beginning in the fall. You would casually entrust none of them to a fifth grader and would not, for that matter, take any of them to the beach tossed into a bag with sand and tanning lotion. All are essentially portable computers with touch-activated screens and special modifications for retrieving, storing and displaying digital versions of printed material.
The first scheduled to arrive is the midsize Softbook, a sleek tablet with a supple leather cover. The Softbook weighs about three pounds and has a screen not quite big enough to display a single page of a hardcover book.
The Softbook is expected to cost $299 when it goes on sale in September, but the buyer will also be required to pay a monthly subscription fee of $9.95 for a package of services that will include local telephone access to the Softbook Press library and a bundle of public domain and special publications. Additional fees will be charged for downloading copyrighted books and publications. A $19.95 monthly plan for more active readers will also be available.
To load the Softbook with "content," as writing is known these days, the user will simply plug any standard phone line into the Softbook's built-in modem port and tap a connection icon on the screen, and the Softbook will do the rest. No desktop computer will be needed.
Sometime before the end of the year, the Rocketbook will be on the market. The smallest of the three electronic books, the Rocketbook can be held in one hand; it weighs about half as much as the Softbook (the Rocketbook's designer also designed the Palm Pilot). Nuvomedia, the Rocketbook's creator, has financial backing from the investment arm of the global publishing giant Bertelsmann A.G. and from Barnes and Noble. Both companies apparently see a potential cost advantage in not having to print, ship, stock and store paper-based books.
No subscription fee will be required for the Rocketbook, but the device will cost about $500 when it reaches the market, about the time when winter weather sets in and people are thinking of curling up in front of a fireplace with a good book.
Unlike the Softbook, the Rocketbook will have to be inserted into a special "cradle" connected to an personal computer with Internet access. The user will shop at any on-line bookstore but the book ordered will not be sent by mail; the words will stream into the Rocketbook instead.
Both the Softbook and Rocketbook companies contend that they have struck agreements with almost all of the world's great book publishing and information companies and that current best-sellers as well as specialized publications will be available when they open for business.
The only one of the three new models that actually resembles a book is the EB Dedicated Reader, which is being developed by Everybook Inc. of Middletown, Pa. Now in the prototype stage, the Reader is not expected to reach the market until next year. When it does arrive, it is expected to cost $1,400 to $1,600, a rich vessel indeed for bodice-ripping romance novels but perhaps reasonable for a twin-screened book that can display two full-size, facing pages at once, in the exact format of the printed-on-paper version, with color and the ability to show engineering diagrams and mathematical formulas.
"A single-screen device is not a book -- it's a tablet," said the Reader's inventor, Dan Munyan, who says that his product will be the first true electronic book. "The last person to read and enjoy a tablet was Moses."
Unlike the two other contenders, the Reader is designed to use the Portable Document Format (.pdf) files that recreate a paper document's layout and type styles on any computer screen. Mr. Munyan said he expected the Reader to appeal mainly to customers on the high end of the professional reference-book market, those who spend a thousand or more tax-deductible dollars on reference works a year.
Even the inventors of these first models stress that they are not intended to replace the paperback novel. "You can't beat paperbacks," Mr. Munyan said. "Paperback books are too cheap." Instead, all are trying to win customers among professionals like doctors, lawyers, accountants, engineers and others who need to keep reading updated journals and reference works. Yes, there will be room in the digital book's memory for a guilty pleasure or two -- the smallest digital book can hold the equivalent of 10 trashy novels -- but realistically, the economics of it will make sense mainly for getting instant access to professional texts.
A digital book would have some undeniable advantages. Students would not be bent under bulging backpacks filled with heavy textbooks. Children would not have to read by flashlight under the covers after curfew at night because a button turns on the illumination for the book's display screen (and shuts it off quickly when footsteps approach). The children's parents could dispense with unstylish reading glasses because another button would instantly swell the book's text to a larger size.
In theory, an on-line bookstore could have hundreds of thousands of book titles ready for instant delivery. There would no longer be out-of-print books because once a title was digitized, there would be no cost to "print" another copy, even for one customer. In reality, though, very few books today exist in digital form, so publishers or distributors would have to pay several hundred dollars each to have older books retyped or scanned into a computer. Establishing electronic royalties for authors and illustrators would be a legal morass. Other than that, because the publisher has no paper, printing and distribution costs, one could expect the cost of a digitally delivered book to be less than that of one tattooed onto dried paste made from dead trees. Then again, one would have thought that audio CD's would cost less than vinyl LP's.
For teachers and students, the digital books hold the promise of never being outdated. Unfamiliar words and concepts would be defined with a tap on the screen, calling up a dictionary entry or supplementary text, all through hyperlinks. For professionals, things like medical journal articles and timely tax and legal information would be a click away.
As CD-ROM encyclopedias have shown, digital books can be enhanced with sound, video, animation, hyperlinking, automatic updating and interactive story lines. Of course, paper books don't crash, run out of battery power over Nebraska, spew error messages, demand periodic upgrades, require technical support, attract professional thieves, entice the purchase of expensive upgrades or go to the repair shop for days at a time -- all issues that Mr. Gingrich and the Texas schoolbook officials apparently believe won't apply to digital books.
And experience suggests that even if people own expensive, high-resolution desktop displays, they typically prefer to send long blocks of text to a printer rather than read them on a computer screen.
All things considered, however, digital books appear to be inevitable, not as a replacement, for paper books, but as an alternative. Microprocessors are getting smaller, more powerful and cheaper as displays are getting bigger, thinner and cheaper; memory capacity is getting bigger and cheaper; Internet access is becoming ubiquitous and cheaper, and book production and distribution costs are getting more expensive.
And in the even more distant future, the line between paper and electronic books may blur. In Cambridge, Mass., Prof. Joe Jacobson of the Media Laboratory at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology is trying to create an "ink" sensitive to electronic fields that, when printed on thin plastic, fabric or even paper, will lead to a book that can publish itself. The New York Times is a sponsor of several research projects at the Media Lab.
The ink is actually microscopic particles embedded in the paper, inside tiny capsules, that flip over in response to changes in an electric field. When they are flipped one way, they appear black; when they flop the other way, they are white. Electrical signals originating in the spine of the book tell the particles how to line up, creating text that can be rewritten over and over.
A book printed with so-called electronic ink could very closely approximate a traditional printed book, including paper pages. But depending on what the user wanted to read, the book could erase and redraw itself with new text and illustrations.
Realistically, a digital book printed with electronic ink is years, if not decades, away. But Professor Jacobson has formed a private company, E Ink, to find commercial uses for electronic ink in the near term, in products like clothing and wallpaper that could change patterns and display advertisements. Several newspaper, magazine, advertising and electronics companies see the technology as so compelling that they have poured millions of dollars into the research this year.
What's next? Professor Jacobson thinks that it might soon be possible to print logic circuits, transistors and other computational devices on paper, cloth or plastic, creating, in effect, a two-dimensional personal computer. If his group of physicists, chemists and engineers is successful, someday people won't have to carry books or computers -- they can simply wear them.

HEADLINE: Essay;
Primakov in Cyprus

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Foreign Minister Yevgeny Prima kov of Russia long the K.G.B.'s top operative in the Middle East and still Saddam Hussein's closest ally -- sees himself as a new Andrei Gromyko.
Unlike that Soviet stoneface, Primakov represents no superpower. But because he now runs Boris Yeltsin's foreign policy, and because he has the latest Russian missiles to sell, this Gromyko with a smiling face has found a way to split the NATO alliance by inflaming Greeks and Turks over the island of Cyprus. 
 Cypriots on that independent Mediterranean island near Turkey number 650,000 ethnic Greeks and 200,000 ethnic Turks. When Greek nationalists got pushy in 1974, Ankara sent in troops to protect its Turkish minority in the north, cruelly driving out Greek residents, setting up a republic that the world does not recognize, and establishing air control over the whole island. Cypriots have been glaring at each other ever since. (You have to be Irish to understand.)
The Greek Cypriot Government is irritated at Turkey's air control. It is feeling feisty at the European Union's signs that it could gain membership in the coveted economic club, especially since the E.U. has snubbed Muslim Turkey.
To assert its nationhood, Greek Cypriots went shopping for surface-to-air missiles that could knock down Turkey's planes if war came. First stop was the U.S.; no sale. Then Europe; none of its nations would join in an obvious military provocation of Turkey, a NATO member.
Along comes Primakov, lighting a match in the gas-filled room. How much do you Cypriots have to spend? $200 million. At $5 million a missile, that'll buy you 40 of our best new S-300's, not only threatening Turkish air domination, but capable with some modifications of hitting Turkish soil. When can you take delivery? September. A deal.
The Turks are reacting to this deal today the way the Kennedy Administration did when Khrushchev put the Soviet missiles on ships to Cuba: You put those missiles in and we'll take them out. The nuclear missiles Gromyko lied about were 90 miles from the U.S.; these offensively defensive SAM's are 50 miles from Turkey.
Primakov has a fistful of interests in Cyprus. His commercial interest is in getting hard currency for Russian arms and keeping missile factories humming.
Especially delicious to the ex-spymaster is the espionage interest: Cyprus has long been the intelligence crossroads of the Eastern Mediterranean, of benefit to Syria, Iraq and Libya. Turks charge that along with the missiles would come Russian "technicians" to bolster Russia's intelligence network.
Fourth, international spooks know that corporations in Cyprus's capital, Nicosia -- a city split by a "green line" like a Berlin wall separating Greeks and Turks -- have for years made it the money-laundering capital of the Middle East. Our State Department says the Greek south is now cleaner than the Turkish north, but the whole island launders. Primakov will be able to monitor the flight of Russian rubles to foreign banks, and gain added leverage over Serbia, which gets clandestine foreign money support through Cyprus.
Finally, the strategic interest. Cyprus is the flashpoint of a Greek-Turkish tension that extends into the Balkans. Here was Primakov's way to retaliate at NATO expansion by breaking apart the southern flank of the Western alliance -- not only at no cost to Russia, but at a profit.
Madeleine Albright, in a meeting with Primakov in Luxembourg in May, tried to talk him out of shipping the missiles; she failed.
Richard Holbrooke, unable to negotiate the Cypriot factions into a sensible "bizonal, bicommunal" federation, creatively tried to use the impending Cyprus crisis as a shoehorn to ease Turkey into being fairly considered for E.U. membership. But the Germans and Greeks would have none of that.
As a result of Primakov's maneuvering and European anti-Turk bias, we now have (1) Ankara more adamant than ever about a separate Turkish Cypriot republic; (2) the U.N., which patrols the green line, passing resolutions blaming Turks for everything, and (3) Greeks lurching into a foolish missile provocation.
This thing could get out of hand. President Clinton should get on the horn to Yeltsin and say, "Tell Primakov to cancel that missile order."

HEADLINE: Iran's President Likes U.S. Tone but Says Actions Speak Louder

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO 

DATELINE: TEHERAN, Iran, July 1

 BODY:
President Mohammad Khatami of Iran lauded the Clinton Administration today for softening its tone toward his country but added that a concrete change in American policy toward Iran was necessary.
Until today, Mr. Khatami had made no public comment on a speech by Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright last month in which she called on Iran to help create a "road map" to normal relations or on the conciliatory words by President Clinton that followed. 
 But in a brief question-and-answer session with reporters after a meeting with Prime Minister Romano Prodi of Italy, Mr. Khatami said: "We believe there is change in their tone, but we're always looking for action. Honesty lies in action, not words.
"I hope this change in tone is a gesture of better understanding by American politicians of the status of the Islamic Republic, the Iranian nation and the global situation."
Mr. Khatami did not break new ground with his comments calling on the United States to make a specific policy gesture. Other Iranian officials, including Foreign Minister Kamal Kharrazi, have already articulated that view. But the absence of any direct criticism of the United States or any concrete demand by Mr. Khatami reflects a softer tone on the Iranian side.
Mr. Khatami seemed unaccustomed to the Western practice of a "press availability" after an official meeting, at which officials make a few comments, photographers shoot pictures and reporters fire off a few questions. But Mr. Prodi, who was traveling with a large press corps, was on a high-profile mission, and it was not surprising that the two emerged from their hourlong meeting at the Pink Palace in the presidential compound to greet the media.
Mr. Khatami asked Mr. Prodi in English whether he wanted to go first. Mr. Prodi replied in English: "I don't know. Which is your habit? For me it's O.K."
While reporters politely waited, expecting the officials to make opening statements, Mr. Khatami said in Persian: "Do they intend to ask questions or not? Or do they want to postpone this?"
After two questions, Mr. Khatami ended the brief encounter.
The visit by Mr. Prodi, one of the highest-ranking European officials to visit Iran since its 1979 revolution, was touted by both the Italian and the Iranian sides as a major political event.
For the Italians, the visit put Mr. Prodi in the vanguard of those Europeans who want to forge close ties -- particularly economic ties -- with Iran and are bargaining that Mr. Khatami can deliver on his promise to bring about the rule of law and liberalize the country.
But plummeting oil prices have deeply affected Iran's already damaged economy, and Teheran is not in a position to sign ambitious financial and industrial contracts.
For the Iranians, the visit helps rehabilitate their global image. The European Union countries briefly withdrew their ambassadors from Iran after the verdict by a German court last year that implicated the country's leadership in a terrorist bombing in Berlin six years ago. Recently, the Europeans have agreed informally to allow their foreign ministers to visit Iran.
But Mr. Prodi's visit ups the ante, and officials from a number of European countries were not at all happy that he had decided to make the trip without consulting them.
Early today, Mr. Prodi called his trip important "not only for Italy but also for Europe" and said it would "open a new chapter in relations."
In line with Mr. Khatami's mantra that there must be a "dialogue among civilizations," Mr. Prodi received an honorary doctoral degree from Teheran University and attended the opening of an exhibition at Teheran's Museum of Contemporary Art of graphic works on Islam by Italian artists.
Indeed, the official Iranian press agency reported that Mr. Khatami, in his meeting with Mr. Prodi, said, "Dialogue between civilizations requires Iran as the cradle of Islamic civilization and Italy as the parent of Western civilization to have exemplary and excellent relations with each other."

HEADLINE: In America;
Saving the Cities

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT 

DATELINE: PALM BEACH, Fla.

 BODY:
For many years the goal of people concerned about the nation's cities was, for the most part, simply to stop the hemorrhaging. Crime seemed out of control, longtime residents were fleeing, entire neighborhoods were collapsing into rubble and ash.
Hard-core inner-city neighborhoods -- the South Bronx in New York, the Hough section of Cleveland, the Central Ward in Newark -- were seen by many as incurable concentrations of poverty and pathology. Much of the rest of the country closed its eyes and turned its back. Such neighborhoods, according to a particularly destructive but pervasive view, not only were beyond saving, they weren't worth saving. In the early 1980's a devastated neighborhood in Kansas City, Mo., was used as a location site for "The Day After," a television movie about the aftermath of a nuclear attack. 
 Hard at work but hardly noticed during those terrible years were the many men and women who, in small, often ragtag groups, rolled up their sleeves and did what they could to counter one of the biggest problems -- the desperate need for housing. Sometimes, in the midst of chaos and misery, their goal was to build just one house. Their attitude, invariably, was, "You have to start somewhere."
A couple of weeks ago the Clinton Administration released a report declaring that, finally, after decades of struggling, the nation's cities were rebounding. It's too early to reach for the champagne. The inner cities, especially, are still intensely isolated communities in which joblessness is high, poverty is rampant, drug addiction is flourishing and genuine opportunities are hard to come by.
But some very good things are happening. Crime is down, municipal budgets are in much better shape, and even in hard-core areas there are unmistakable early signs of renewal.
Go back now to the men and women who rolled up their sleeves and decided to build some housing. In the really tough neighborhoods, they are the unheralded heroes. Working with churches and small community organizations, they pulled off surprising early successes. New homes would go up on a block, or old buildings would be renovated, and before long a startling transformation would occur.
"I call it the miracle of small steps," said Paul Grogan, president of a national support group -- the Local Initiatives Support Corporation (LISC) -- that recognized the potential of these local groups, which came to be known, accurately but not very excitingly, as community development corporations, or C.D.C.'s.
Certain things happen when new homes, even a small number, appear in a previously blighted neighborhood. The construction itself creates economic activity. Architects and contractors are hired. New families are drawn to the neighborhood and a new sense of pride can be seen. Graffiti and other forms of vandalism tend to occur with less frequency.
"Blighted and abandoned housing sends a terrible signal," said Mr. Grogan, whose group held its annual meeting here this week. "It's a magnet for drugs and other criminal activity."
What groups like LISC have found is that the new or refurbished housing in most cases became a stabilizing force, a locally developed defense against what had appeared to be unstoppable blight.
Eventually, although very slowly, economic activity would pick up. As a Boston resident described it: "The neighborhood became a neighborhood again."
LISC and some other groups began working with C.D.C.'s several years ago, helping to arrange financing and offering the kind of expertise that allowed the local groups to operate on a much larger scale. What began small is now huge, and hugely important. LISC, the largest of the intermediary groups, has directly raised $3 billion in financing since 1979 and has leveraged $3.5 billion more. With the help of LISC and others, C.D.C.'s have built thousands upon thousands of units of decent affordable housing all across the country.
It's still not enough. There is still a critical shortage of affordable housing in the big cities. And there are many other problems as well. But the cities are better off than they have been in many years. And the men and women who built housing during the worst of times deserve to be applauded.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Selling uranium plants to enrich the private sector?

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
THE Treasury's announcement on Monday that it would soon privatize the Government's half-century-old uranium enrichment plants made waves largely because of the proposed method of sale. While an initial public offering of shares in a Government-owned corporation is not unprecedented, it is certainly a novelty in keeping with the spirit of the high-flying stock market.
But the more important news is that the Treasury is moving forward in spite of years of warnings that the sale would undermine a key initiative for containing nuclear proliferation. For once the United States Enrichment Corporation is privatized, the company will have powerful financial incentives to find a means to back away from an agreement to import 500 tons of bomb-grade uranium from Russia. 
 "Privatization is a foreign policy disaster waiting to happen," argued Richard Falkenrath, an economist at Harvard's Kennedy School of Government.
When the cold war ended and Russia was left with a potent nuclear arsenal, Tom Neff, a physicist at M.I.T., had a brainstorm. Why not buy a chunk of Russia's stockpile of bomb-grade uranium, blend it with natural uranium to make fuel for commercial power reactors and resell it?
Why not, indeed: With much fanfare, Vice President Al Gore struck the swords-to-plowshares deal with President Boris N. Yeltsin in 1993. Russia would manufacture the reactor fuel from its bombs, and Washington would sell the fuel on world markets. Minatom, the Russian nuclear authority, with an estimated one million employees, would get cash to cover the wages of its impoverished nuclear scientists. Far less bomb-grade uranium would be left lying around Russia for someone to steal. And all this would happen without a dime from taxpayers.
The United States Enrichment Corporation, the Federal operator of the plants in Ohio and Kentucky that enrich natural uranium to commercial reactor fuel, was assigned to put the agreement in effect. That seemed the obvious way to go, save for one fact: In an entirely unrelated burst of enthusiasm for privatizing Government assets, Congress had earlier decreed that the public corporation should be sold to the highest responsible bidder.
Joseph Stiglitz, then the chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, pointed to the conflict of interest. A privatized, profit-maximizing United States Energy Corporation, he argued, would have an incentive to buy as little Russian enriched uranium as possible -- at least as long as the price paid to the Russians was higher than the corporation's own (heavily subsidized) cost of producing each extra bit of reactor fuel.
But in a curious role reversal, the Government's national security establishment put the cause of reinventing government ahead of keeping nuclear weapons out of the hands of malefactors. The State Department, Energy Department and the President's National Security Council all insisted that the corporation would do the right thing because Federal watchdogs would otherwise intervene.
Mr. Stiglitz was outgunned, but not outargued: There was already tangible evidence that the business conflict was real. For even as public servants, the corporation's managers had been caught secretly asking the Russians to slow deliveries to allow the corporation to sell more from its own inventory. And by Mr. Neff's analysis, the Government's will to keep the corporation on the straight and narrow is likely to be strained again.
As long as the price paid to Russia is less than the prevailing world price, the fuel can always be resold without cost to the Government. But Mr. Neff notes that the uranium fuel market is weak -- and will probably get weaker unless the Asian economies soon recover from their funk. Thus it would hardly be a surprise if the Government were someday forced to choose between turning a blind eye toward the United States Energy Corporation's machinations or buying up surplus Russian uranium fuel at the taxpayers' risk.
Would Washington invest billions of dollars to keep the fissionable material flowing out of Russia? In a letter to Senator John Glenn, Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin and Energy Secretary Federico F. Pena assured him that "if problems arise the Administration will not hesitate to add or replace executive agents" -- longhand for "yes."
But Mr. Falkenrath is skeptical. "How likely is Congress to appropriate money to buy Russian uranium that had, in effect, been dumped by a privatized U.S.E.C.," he asked?
If economists believe there is trouble looming down the road, so apparently do the Energy Corporation's investment bankers. After subtracting the value of uranium inventories that the corporation will retain and adding debts it will carry, the corporation's advisers estimated that the Government would realize between $1.15 and $1.45 billion from the public offering -- just four or five years' profit, projecting from the corporation's fiscal performance in recent years.
Just how would the taxpayers be better off selling U.S.E.C. at five times earnings rather than banking the cash flow? "It beats me," said a frustrated Representative Ted Strickland, a Democrat who represents the Ohio district where one of the corporation's two plants is situated.

HEADLINE: Usti nad Labem Journal;
A Wall Not Yet Built Casts the Shadow of Racism

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: USTI NAD LABEM, Czech Republic

 BODY:
On the outskirts of this depressed industrial town, about 50 Gypsy families live in two dilapidated, graffiti-strewn apartment blocks along Maticni Street where voices are often loud and celebrations boisterous.
Across the street, stand three prim row houses with gray facades and white lace curtains drawn across the windows. These are the homes of Czech families who have persuaded the City Council to build a 15-foot-wall on the Gypsy side of Maticni Street to separate the Czechs, physically and psychologically, from what they consider their undesirable neighbors. 
 The Gypsies and several Czech human rights groups have called the wall an attempt to create a ghetto. They declare that the project is the latest example of designating the Gypsies, who number between 200,000 and 300,000, as outsiders in the Czech Republic, which has a population of about 10 million.
The Mayor, Ladislav Hruska, makes no apologies.
"This wall is about one group that obeys the laws of the Czech Republic and behaves according to good morals, and about a group that breaks these rules -- doesn't pay rent, doesn't use proper hygiene and doesn't do anything right," Mr. Hruska said as he sat in his office below a portrait of President Vaclav Havel, a prominent spokesman for human rights.
"This is not a racial problem. It is a problem of dealing with decent and indecent people."
In the last several years, the Czech Government -- once widely considered the leader in Central Europe in the transition from Communist rule, which ended in 1989, to a civil society -- has come under increasing criticism for its failure to address the growing disparities between Gypsies and non-Gypsies.
The most recent United States State Department report on human rights around the world gave vivid details of how Gypsies, also called Romany or Roma, "suffer disproportionately from poverty, unemployment, interethnic violence, discrimination, illiteracy and disease." Unemployment among Gypsies is about 70 percent, the report said.
After Usti nad Labem announced that the wall would be built, Representative Christopher H. Smith, Republican of New Jersey and co-chairman of the Commission on Security and Cooperation in Europe, criticized the Czech Cabinet for remaining silent in the face of continuing attacks and discrimination against Gypsies and other minorities. The only criticism of the wall by a Czech Government official so far has come from the Minister Without Portfolio, Vladimir Mlynar, who is responsible for Gypsy affairs.
Representative Smith attributed the Government's silence in part to politics. Public opinion polls have consistently shown that Czechs harbor what the State Department report called a "deeply ingrained popular prejudice against Gypsies," and Czech politicians, like all others, keep a close eye on opinion polls.
The prejudice, of course, is felt acutely among the Gypsies of Maticni Street.
"I don't understand how three families have more sway than 50 families," said Miroslav Demeter, 44, as he looked over at the austere facades across the narrow street. "The wall will make things worse. The Romany are very angry, because all over Europe they are breaking down walls but here they are building walls."
Mr. Demeter and several other Gypsies acknowledged that all was not perfect at the apartment houses. It was true, he said, that many families did not pay rent to the city. It was also true, said Tibor Badi, 48, that some families used the surrounding gardens as a refuse heap.
"I was standing on my veranda smoking a cigarette one day and I was almost hit by a falling chair," he said, when one tenant decided to discard the chair by throwing it out the window.
Complicating the issue is that the Gypsy community is quite diverse.
It includes families like Mr. Badi's, who have held jobs for many years and who lived during the Communist period alongside Czechs in integrated housing. High school certificates on the living room wall in Mr. Badi's apartment attest to the education that he and his wife, Marta, received under Communism.
But other Gypsy families here have little education, have rarely held full-time jobs and show contempt for the better educated like Mr. Badi.
At the bar U Pristavu on the corner of Maticni Street, the owner, Eva Kompertova, says she allows in only certain Gypsies.
"I let in three families -- they don't make any trouble -- but I don't let the others in because they get into fights," Ms. Kompertova said as she sipped a beer with some Czech customers. "On our side of the street, Romanies are not allowed. They don't even go over there because it's so clean they feel uncomfortable."
After a meeting with Gypsies from the apartment houses, Mayor Hruska agreed to postpone construction of the wall to September. In the meantime, the Gypsies are being asked to keep the area clean and reduce the noise level. But Mr. Hruska said he did not believe the Gypsies would meet the required standard.
Mr. Demeter, who was tending a newly planted garden, was not optimistic either. "In three months you can't change things," he said. "It's the culture. Romany people are different."
In Prague, a human rights advocate at the Helsinki Committee for Human Rights, Marta Mikluskova, said it was essential that the City Council drop the plan. "If Usti is allowed to build a wall, it will become a precedent for other towns," she said, "and others will start planning and do it within a year or two."

GRAPHIC: Photo: In northern Bohemia, Czechs want their city to build a 15-foot-high wall to separate them from Gypsy neighbors, whom they call slovenly and worse. The Gypsies, working here on a garden, fear a ghetto. (Julie Denesha for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Labor's Abuse of the City

 BODY:
The construction workers who clashed with police and tied up midtown Manhattan for hours on Tuesday turned a lawful rally against the use of nonunion contractors into an illegal assault on civic life. No union, or its members, should be allowed to take the constitutional right to protest and turn it into a license to paralyze the city and rough up civilians and police officers.
Union leaders have issued an apology and offered restitution for injury and property damage. But their statements seemed so grudging and mechanical that the rank and file could easily conclude that their leaders were really winking at their misconduct. If the unions repeat their roughhouse tactics, arrests and heavy fines will be warranted. 
 Locally and nationally, unions are becoming more aggressive in asserting their interests. That is all to the good in a democratic society. But Tuesday's lawlessness pushed the issue that prompted the rally offstage. The rally's main sponsor, the Building and Construction Trades Council of Greater New York, believes that the Metropolitan Transportation Authority erred in selecting Roy Kay Inc., a nonunion contractor from Freehold, N.J., as the lowest responsible bidder for a $32.6 million project.
In the unions' eyes, city and state laws governing the award of contracts on publicly financed projects to the lowest responsible bidder fail to adequately define what "responsible" means. The unions would like the city and state to adopt legislation that would require bidders to meet new financial, safety and performance criteria in order to be deemed responsible. They have also submitted evidence suggesting that Roy Kay intentionally misled state officials about safety and wage issues. Such charges should be thoroughly investigated by responsible officials, not adjudicated on the streets by lawless demonstrators eager to bully city and state agencies into using only union contractors.
The real issue in Tuesday's demonstration was who will get jobs on publicly financed projects. In a rebounding city economy, unions want as many projects as possible to go to companies that use union crews. Public agencies, most of which already rely heavily on union contractors, want to hold down construction costs. Awarding contracts to the lowest responsible bidders, some of whom may be nonunion contractors, is a means to that end.
If the unions want to change the legal requirements for a "responsible" bidder, they should do so through the normal political process. Although they poured plenty of energy into their street demonstrations Tuesday, not one union raised the issue during the authority's board meeting that same day.

LENGTH: 342 words

HEADLINE: A Warning From the Fed

 BODY:
Banks are lending out cash a bit too easily, with too little regard for the risks that will come if the economy stumbles into recession. So says the Federal Reserve in an unusual letter sent to all banks last week and released to the public this week.
That the Fed should be worried about easy credit now is merely the latest indication that the American economy is out of sync with many other world economies. Most of Asia is in the midst of a severe credit crunch, as suddenly cautious banks try to get back the money they were lending out so willingly as recently as last year. 
 The Fed's letter, based on a detailed analysis of a sample of loans made by large banks across the country last year, falls well short of an indictment of bank lending practices. But the tone is one of caution, and there are specific warnings that credit standards may have slipped in certain areas, among them loans to real estate investment trusts and media companies. The Fed is also concerned that banks may be charging too little on loans to corporate customers. It is a concern that some top bankers privately say is warranted.
To the extent the Fed's warnings are taken to heart by bankers, the letter might serve as a mild drag on the American economy, something some Fed officials would like to see. The Fed has been unwilling to accomplish that through the usual means, raising interest rates, because of concerns that such a move would exacerbate the Asian economic crisis. No one was surprised that this week's meeting of the Fed's Open Market Committee ended without a decision to raise or lower rates.
In good times bankers vie to make loans, and are sometimes willing to use overly optimistic assumptions to justify those loans both to management and to regulators. Then, after errors become apparent, bankers grow too cautious, as may be happening now in Asia. If the Fed's letter does help to hold down excessive optimism now, it could help to reduce or forestall the pain that will be felt if the American economy does suffer a setback.

HEADLINE: Metro Matters;
Sorry, You're Still Too Old To Join Force

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT 

 BODY:
THOUGH starting over is never easy, Michael J. Rosati said that for him the choice was easy. He had always wanted to be a police officer and suddenly it seemed that he might have the chance.
Thanks to the advent of laser surgery, Mr. Rosati was finally able to have his disqualifying nearsightedness corrected. At the same time, thanks to a fight in Congress, the longstanding age limits on becoming a New York City police officer had been suspended. 
 And so, at age 44, Mr. Rosati took the Police Department's written exam and received a high score. He proceeded to pass the background check, the psychological exam and the physical. He was told that he could enter the Police Academy on April 15, 1997, once he had sold his karate school in Franklin Square. So he sold his store.
Then, just four days before the start of classes, he was informed that the age limits had been reinstated. No over-age applicants would be admitted.
"It was like having a lottery number that wins and you lose the ticket," he said the other day.
The injustice, not to say the pathos, of Mr. Rosati's story and a few dozen like it convinced the City Council that an exception should be made. Earlier this year, the Council wrote a law specifically allowing him and about 40 other older candidates their chance to enter the Police Academy.
Yet when Mr. Rosati showed up to try to register for the academy yesterday at 7 A.M., he and the other candidates over 35 were all turned away at the door.
"I don't want to say it's humiliating, but it is embarrassing," Mr. Rosati said after finding himself once again shut out. "It's very frustrating."
Mr. Rosati's hopes are yet another casualty of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's rigorous interpretation of his duties or, if you prefer, his obstinacy.
From the beginning, the Mayor made it abundantly clear that he did not support the cause of the over-age police officers and did not feel an exemption should be made for them.
Though Mr. Giuliani's own celebrated truculence has, it is said, launched a thousand lawsuits, the Mayor maintained that he was extremely worried about opening the city to litigation. If these 40 candidates were grandfathered in, other over-age candidates would, he insisted, use it as an excuse to bring lawsuits against the city and overturn the age limit entirely.
City Council members rejected his argument as legally dubious, noting that exemptions to rules are made all the time for small groups of people who, for one reason or another, seem to deserve special consideration.
While Council members said they agreed with the Mayor that age was a factor in policing, they pointed out that these candidates had acted in good faith, giving up positions, selling businesses and putting considerable strains on their families.
"These people changed their lives and left their jobs," said Michael S. Clendenin, a spokesman for the City Council. "Look, we did this legislation because we felt it was just a question of fairness."
WHEN the Council approved the exemption in April, Mr. Giuliani promptly vetoed it. Last month, the Council overrode his veto by a vote of 43 to 4. Three of the Council's seven Republican members broke publicly with the Mayor to vote with the majority.
Not willing to accept this clear and apparently straightforward legislative defeat, the litigation-fearing Mr. Giuliani sued the City Council himself. In papers filed in State Supreme Court on Tuesday, the Mayor argues that the Council's action represents an illegal infringement on executive authority.
Though Mr. Giuliani did not seek an injunction, he clearly instructed the Police Commissioner to lock out the slowly dwindling group of over-age candidates.
Along with Mr. Rosati, Paul Agli, 42, got up early yesterday morning, hoping that despite the Mayor's opposition he would be allowed into the Police Academy. For his shot at joining the force, Mr. Agli had given up a job as a research technician at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center last year and found himself unemployed for almost 12 months.
It was, Mr. Agli said yesterday, a painful business to watch the doors close in his face. And not just because he himself was being kept out.
"Seeing the police violate the law is very disheartening," he said. "Either this is out of the ordinary or I am very naive."
