HEADLINE: Two States Outline Sanctions on Swiss Banks in Holocaust Case

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
New York and California outlined sanctions yesterday against two Swiss banks, after negotiations collapsed over how much money the banks and Swiss Government will return to Holocaust survivors and heirs.
Despite State Department objections, Treasurer Matt Fong of California said his state would not do any more business with two banks, Credit Suisse and UBS. 
 The New York State Comptroller, H. Carl McCall, and the New York City Comptroller, Alan G. Hevesi, said they would outline this morning a series of sanctions that would begin taking effect in 45 to 60 days unless a settlement was reached.
The decisions were made after all sides of the dispute had spent a day before a committee of state and local finance officials who had until now recommended holding off sanctions, because the talks had appeared headed toward a settlement.
In New York the first step is most likely to be the rejection of bids for overnight deposits of surplus Government money, followed by banning the banks from underwriting Government bonds. Ultimately the state and city pension funds could sell their shares of Swiss companies. The funds are the second and third largest public employees' pension funds in the country, with combined assets of $188 billion.
The three officials, as well as others from Pennsylvania and Delaware, said at City Hall in Manhattan they would recommend to 800 other state and local finance officials that they begin applying sanctions to prod the Swiss Government into joining new negotiations.
"My impression is that the sides are not that far apart and that the problem is with the Swiss Government," Mr. Hevesi said.
Credit Suisse and UBS proposed last month to put $600 million in a "rough justice fund" to help Holocaust survivors, in addition to paying whatever sums a commission led by Paul A. Volcker determined were due based on bank records.
The plaintiffs proposed last week to settle for $1.5 billion, provided that the Swiss Government and the Swiss National Bank joined in the agreement, Mel Weiss, a lawyer from New York who represents the Simon Wiesenthal Center, said outside the closed session.
The $1.5 billion is far less than lawyers for survivors and heirs, and for charities designated to represent those who died heirless, have been seeking. Those people were engaged in a two-step process in which a settlement would first be made with the commercial banks and then the talks would to the Swiss Government.
The banks and Government said that sanctions were not warranted and that imposing them would make it more difficult to settle the case.
"We will review all of our options," Roger Witten, a lawyer from Washington who is the lead negotiator for the banks, said. "But a gun at our head is not conducive to progress in these negotiations."
"State and local sanctions in this matter are wrong both in principle and practice," Under Secretary of State Stuart E. Eizenstat said in a statement to the officials. Mr. Eizenstat later said he hoped that "the parties will resume their talks as soon as possible in a noncoercive atmosphere."
Mr. Hevesi said the impasse "gives us no choice" but to begin taking business from the banks to prod them and the Government to settle.

HEADLINE: Fed Keeps Interest Rates Steady Amid Signs of Cooling

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 1

 BODY:
With signs of a slowing economy and increasing evidence that the Asian economic crisis is beginning to hurt some industries in the United States, the Federal Reserve today decided not to raise interest rates.
Following a two-day private meeting, the Fed said that it was keeping the benchmark Federal funds rate -- the borrowing cost on overnight loans between banks -- steady at 5.5 percent, just where it has been since March 1997. 
 At the same time, other indicators were released today that gave a picture of an economy cooling down from the hectic pace of the last year or so. A key index of manufacturing activity, the monthly purchasing managers' report, fell in June for the first time in two years. This index measures manufacturing production and its sharp decline from 51.4 in May to 49.6 in June was seen as evidence that the Asian economic turmoil is starting to affect American industrial producers.
The Commerce Department also reported today that construction slumped 1.5 percent in May, the worst drop in more than four years, and the Conference Board's indicator of future economic activity remained unchanged from April to May, at 105.2. This is the second consecutive month that the Conference Board's leading indicator stayed fixed, a sign that the economy, while still on a positive track, is expected to be sluggish.
"When you have an economy where inflation is low and the economy is slowing, there is no reason for the Fed to raise rates," said Stan Shipley, chief economist at Merrill Lynch & Company. "And the three indicators also released today indicate that this economy is weakening and weakening rapidly. We think that by December we may begin to see unemployment rise and retail sales fall and then the Fed will have to vote to lower rates."
A number of analysts argue that the economy, after a period of relative weakness, could well rebound in the months ahead and see little reason for the Fed to cut short-term interest rates. Still, Merrill Lynch's view was echoed by others. "A good case is building that the Fed might need to lower interest rates," said James Glassman, senior United States economist at Chase Securities. "The dislocations that were caused by the Asia shock are starting to ripple through the U.S. economy and we are beginning to see lots of indications that economic growth is slowing down."
For months, the American economy has been largely insulated from the Asian downturn. In fact, consumers have benefited in many ways from lower prices for imported goods and from lower lending costs caused in part by Asia's crisis. That has helped curb inflation. But some domestic producers have begun to suffer from reduced demand for American goods in Asia and from the intense price competition from cheaper overseas products.
Edward Yardeni, chief economist at Deutsche Bank Securities, said he was particularly troubled by the drop in the index of manufacturing activity. "The purchasing managers' index is something the Fed watches closely, and the numbers that came out today were significant," he said. "Our manufacturing sector is weakening because of the problems in Asia."
The Fed has stayed its hand even though monetary policy makers have leaned, ever since their meeting in March, toward raising rates in a bid to slow down what some feared was an overripe economy. (The Fed has long raised interest rates as a way of halting inflation, and lowered them when it wanted to stimulate the economy.)
But, since the beginning of the year, inflation has, if anything, retreated even further and is now running at an annual rate of under 1.8 percent. In addition, Fed policy makers are worried that raising United States rates could touch off more financial turbulence in Asia.
"Asia's misfortune is allowing us to enjoy a strong economy here with low inflation," Mr. Yardeni said. "While the Fed might see that strong economy as a threat to reviving inflation, they recognize that's not much of a risk right now. What's really important in these numbers is that we are seeing a weakening price environment for manufacturers."
Currently, many analysts expect that the hot growth rate of 5.4 percent that took place in the first quarter of the year could slow to around 2 percent -- or even lower -- for the rest of the year as manufacturers and retailers work off excessive inventories that have built up in recent months.
In light of these estimates, the Fed warned banks on Tuesday against lowering their lending standards on business loans. In a statement, the Fed said bankers should resist any tendency to assume "that the unusually favorable economic environment of the last few years will continue indefinitely."
A glimpse into the internal reasoning of the Fed may come on Thursday when the Open Market Committee releases the minutes of its May 19 meeting.

HEADLINE: In AT&T-TCI Deal, Cost and Logistical Problems

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, July 1

 BODY:
Sometime before the end of the century, high-speed Internet access and low-cost phone calls alike will make their way into American homes as streams of digital 1's and 0's over television cables.
But in recent days, as executives of AT&T and Tele-Communications Inc. have scrambled to sell Wall Street and the American consumer on the wisdom of their ambitious $31.8 billion merger, one fact has become clear: The technology will tread a costly path on its way from the laboratory into the home. 
 In addition to the $1.8 billion TCI will spend to upgrade its one-way cable network to a two-way service capable of carrying digital video and sound to its 10.5 million customers, AT&T will need to persuade customers to buy advanced set-top boxes that have connectors for video, computer and telephone, and it will have to install a new generation of advanced Internet routers capable of offering clear voice quality, at its own expense.
So, beyond that first $1.8 billion, the final cost for the entire project could run another $10 billion or more based on an initial per-customer cost of $750. That cost could eventually fall as low as $200 per customer sometime after 2000.
The actual amount will vary depending on what percentage of households decide to switch service from their existing phone company and on how quickly the cost of new Internet telephone technology falls.
But even assuming that the cost of the AT&T-TCI plan allows any real price competition on telephone calls, consumers will face sundry logistical problems once the digital telephones arrive in their homes. For example, most set-top boxes are in living rooms -- the one room often not wired for a telephone.
None of this fazes David Nagel, AT&T's unflappable chief technology officer, who points out that the nation's largest phone company has a decade's worth of experience working with the cable industry on the challenges of digital telephony.
"Our guys have crawled all over the cable networks, and the problems are very solvable," he said.
Indeed, AT&T has been welcomed as a conquering hero by the cable industry, which five years ago promised a future of 500 channels and interactive television only to back off when daunting costs and consumer apathy dulled that vision with a stubborn coating of reality.
"I don't care if it takes five years, AT&T is going to make this work," said Paul Kagan, president of Paul Kagan & Associates, a cable industry research firm in Carmel, Calif. Alluding to TCI's chairman -- and the the cable industry's most ambitious salesman -- he added, "There's more here than John Malone trying to make his stock go up."
While he acknowledges that a steep investment lies ahead and several technical challenges must be overcome, others are less sanguine.
"What I've found with technology is that C.E.O.'s don't have a clue about what really needs to be done," said Andrew Seybold, a computer and communications industry analyst and publisher of Andrew Seybold's Outlook, a newsletter based in Boulder Creek, Calif. "The problem is that the technology always takes longer than people expect."
Mr. Seybold worries particularly about reliability, citing the aftermath of California's Northridge earthquake in January 1994. While telephone service was restored in 24 to 48 hours, he said, cable did not begin to come back for a week and in some cases two months.
Here in the San Francisco region, TCI's largest service area, with 1.5 million customers, roughly 10 percent of subscribers have been upgraded to two-way cables. The company says that figure will be 50 percent by the end of the year and 90 percent by the end of the century.
For each city it serves, the first step in an upgrade is for engineers to cover every inch of the network on foot looking for older, one-way amplifiers that must be replaced with two-way equipment.
Next, the placement of fiber nodes -- the intersection points where fiber optic cables meet the coaxial cables that stretch past each home -- is adjusted to a ratio of approximately one for every 500 to 1,000 homes.
This makes the network more resistant to large-scale failures and reduces the capacity requirements for the digital networks that will carry data, voice and video.
Finally, equipment will be added to the central cable plant, or "head end," that will connect the thousands of homes to the Internet and, in some cases, to traditional telephone networks.
In the San Francisco area, switching from today's cables to a digital system promises significant cost savings for the network. TCI owns a powerful fiber optic ring that encircles the Bay Area, which it now uses to distribute television programming. In the future, the huge capacity of that network will make it possible for AT&T to economically centralize its switching and routing equipment.
Once the network is in place in each city, AT&T will immediately be able to offer old-fashioned "circuit switched" telephone service over the cable system.
However, by the fall of 1999, a second generation of cable boxes should be available through consumer electronics outlets nationwide. Based on a yet-to-be determined standard, these boxes will permit the complete integration of voice, data and video. But instead of using circuit switching, which requires a separate copper-wire path for each call, these will employ "packet switching," which allows many kinds of information, including telephone calls, to travel down the same wire at the same time.
It is at that point, industry analysts say, that AT&T will begin to realize the cost savings that will permit competition with local phone companies, plus a range of new services, including CD-quality music and distinctive ringing tones for each member of the family.
Moreover, Mr. Kagan said, the phone company has a powerful financial weapon as it buys its way into these converged technologies: the cable franchises will remain monopolies.
"One of the secrets of this whole deal," he said, "is that AT&T is going to make a bunch of money offering traditional cable television."

HEADLINE: In Seoul, Too, Rubin Urges Japan to Move on Economy

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, July 1

 BODY:
On the last stop of his six-day, four-country sweep of Asia, Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin made his most pointed comments about a country that he did not even visit, Japan.
The Japanese economy was clearly on Mr. Rubin's mind as he met South Korean business, labor and political leaders for a report on the country's economic overhaul. 
 He stressed again and again the "enormous importance of getting Japan back on track to support growth in Korea and the region in general." Mr. Rubin said he was "deeply, deeply concerned" about the recent slide of the yen against the dollar.
But he dodged questions about whether the United States would again step in to prop up the yen with the standard response that the United States would move if and when it deemed that intervention was necessary.
And on the eve of the disclosure of Japan's latest plan to overhaul its financial system, Mr. Rubin exhorted Japanese officials to come up with a credible solution. "The most important key with respect to economic conditions in Japan is to restructure its banking system in an efficient fashion that wins the approval of the world financial markets," he said.
His decision not to include Japan on his trip, but nonetheless to talk a great deal about it, has been a subject of intense discussion in Asia, where Japan's inability to devise a plan to put its economy back on track is seen as prolonging the region's woes.
Mr. Rubin and Mr. Clinton's detours around Japan are widely regarded as a snub to one of the United States' most devoted allies and have raised wide-ranging speculation here about a realignment of American interests.
In his meeting today with Mr. Rubin, President Kim Dae Jung wondered aloud whether the United States and China were forging a "special relationship," a heavily veiled expression of concern that most Asian countries have about how China's power will grow.
"I wouldn't characterize it that way," Mr. Rubin told Mr. Kim, although he added that Mr. Clinton had long regarded better relations between the United States and China as important.
In a day capped by a somber visit to the demilitarized zone between North and South Korea, Mr. Rubin met President Kim and business and labor leaders in hopes of improving his understanding of the issues confronting Korea as its sweeping efforts to reform its economy begin to bite.
The more radical of the two labor confederations gave him a stern lecture on the evils of the International Monetary Fund's rescue program, which includes maintaining high interest rates and introducing greater flexibility in the labor market.
Those two factors are faulted for pushing companies into bankruptcy at the rate of 3,000 a month and putting 1.6 million people out of work.
Mr. Rubin said the participants in the meeting understood the need for broad-based support for reform in spite of the immediate pain. "They were concerned that every sector of the economy bear a share of the pain," he said.
In an attempt to assess that, he met the heads of four of the five largest conglomerates, the Daewoo, Hyundai, Samsung and LG groups, and a senior representative of the fifth group, SK, whose chairman, Chey Jong Hyun, was ill.
Government and other analysts are impatient with the large groups' efforts to change. But in their meeting today they did express their commitment to reform, although the head of Daewoo, Kim Woo Choong, avoided directly answering Mr. Rubin's question about whether the groups would reduce their debt-to-equity ratios to 2 to 1 by the end of the year, according to people at the meeting.
At the end of the meeting, Mr. Kim of Daewoo urged Mr. Rubin to do what he could to further the imports and sales of Korean cars in the United States. The Korean automobile business is running at 40 percent of capacity, because of virtually nonexistent domestic demand and stiffer competition from Japanese manufacturers, who have been helped by the weaker yen.
Mr. Rubin also met representatives of small and midsize enterprises who pleaded with him to advocate lower interest rates, according to those at the meeting. Interest rates on corporate debt have fallen, to 16 percent for three-year notes from highs of 28 to 30 percent when the crisis hit in December.
Mr. Rubin reiterated American support for South Korea, pledging to back additional lending from international sources. But he added that he saw no need for such additional lending, because Korea has $39 billion in foreign currency reserves.
He also noted that the United States went through many of the same painful adjustments that Korea is experiencing before it emerged as the world's economic powerhouse.
"We made a lot of mistakes," he said, "and there's a lot to be learned from our mistakes."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS;
The Japanese Stock Market Extends Its Rally to 7 Days

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Thursday, July 2

 BODY:
The Japanese stock market extended its rally today for the seventh consecutive day, on expectations that the Government's plan for cleaning up the nation's bad bank loans will spur an economic revival.
The yen has also been rising. This morning it cost 138.15 yen to buy a dollar in Tokyo, compared with a level of 145 a couple of weeks ago. 
 The centerpiece of the Government's plan is the use of so-called bridge banks to take over the business of failed institutions so that creditworthy borrowers would not be left in the lurch if their main bank goes under.
The success of the plan is by no means certain. But for the last few days, investors have begun to raise their hopes that it might actually start to chip away large chunks of the nation's bad and doubtful debt, estimated to be at least $560 billion.
There is a growing sense that because of world pressure the governing Liberal Democratic Party and the Government are addressing the problem, although some of the effort is timed to their campaigning for parliamentary elections on July 12.
"We think it's real," said Richard Medley, a principal of the New York-based Medley Global Advisors, after talking with Japanese politicians in Tokyo this week. "These guys realize that the pain of delaying reform is actually worse than the pain of reform."
The benchmark Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 328.52 points, or more than 2 percent, to 16,691.41, at the midday recess early today. The index has risen in the last seven days, with volumes surging. Reports that the Government might also permanently cut income taxes by nearly $30 billion have sent investors into the market.
"I think what's happened is you've got this policy machine, and it's working pretty well -- they've really got it together," said Craig Chudler, a strategist at Salomon Smith Barney in Tokyo. "Portfolio investors have become less negative. Instead of being super-negative, they're just negative."
The bridge bank plan will give extensive powers to two Government bodies, the Deposit Insurance Corporation and the Financial Supervisory Agency, a new agency of about 400 people spun off from the Finance Ministry last month to inspect the banks. As each institution fails, its business will be transferred to a bridge bank, which will be set up under the Deposit Insurance Corporation.
Initially, the Deposit Insurance Corporation will draw on public funds from the bank bailout in February of 30 trillion yen, or $217 billion, some of which has already been disbursed to the nation's largest banks to increase their capital.
In practice, the Supervisory Agency will play the pivotal role in the plan. One critical question will be whether it can hire qualified people and expand enough to accomplish the task. It will essentially be in charge of closing insolvent institutions and appointing new management teams to run the business of the failed banks.
It will also determine which loans in the failed bank are bad and which are good. Then it will transfer the bad loans to the Resolution and Collection Bank, another entity set up to collect bad loans, and transfer the good loans to the bridge bank, which then may extend loans to those borrowers as a bridge until they find a new banker.
Critics have argued that any bailout plan will create a moral hazard, in which private institutions have little incentive to improve because they think they will be rescued by the Government. Partly to prevent this, the bridge banks are expected to last about two years, during which time they are expected to find financially healthy banks to take on the restructured business.
This period could be extended up to five years. After that, any bad debt still left will be transferred to the Resolution and Collection Bank, and the bridge bank will be dissolved.

HEADLINE: SUHARTO REBUILDS HIS POLITICAL BASE TO SHIELD FORTUNE

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 1

 BODY:
Suharto, the former President of Indonesia, is maneuvering to re-establish a political power base to shield his family's financial empire from scrutiny by future Governments, according to Clinton Administration officials and Western diplomats.
There is no direct evidence that the Suharto family has tried to bribe political or military leaders, the officials say. But they add that Mr. Suharto and his six children are offering to underwrite the political campaigns of legislators who vow loyalty to the family, which has a fortune in the billions of dollars. 
 Administration officials and diplomats agree that Mr. Suharto does not appear to be seeking reinstatement as President. He resigned in May after thousands of demonstrators took to the streets of Indonesia's largest cities demanding his ouster.
Instead, they say, intelligence reports reaching the Central Intelligence Agency, the State Department and the Defense Department show that he is making use of his riches and his ties to the military to help his children retain their businesses and their top posts in the ruling political party, at a time when the political moorings of Indonesia are fraying.
Next week the party, known as Golkar, is holding a special national congress to pick new leaders.
Mr. Suharto remains chairman of the party's board of patrons, and two of his children have been appointed to the seven-member organizing committee for the congress. Four of his children are members of the nation's highest legislative body, the People's Consultative Assembly.
That Mr. Suharto, 77, retains close ties to the military, the nation's most powerful institution, was in evidence in June when he accompanied several powerful army generals to Islamic prayers in military mosques in Jakarta.
"Suharto has been very active, rounding up support wherever he can find it," said a senior Clinton Administration official.
Another Administration official said Mr. Suharto "knows that he can't be president again, but he is going to make sure that his kids and his cash survive whatever comes."
Daniel Lev, a professor of political science at the University of Washington and an expert on Indonesia, said the Suhartos "are doing what comes very naturally: they have the wherewithal to buy political support, and I suspect that is in fact what they are trying to do."
Despite the collapse of the Indonesian currency, the Suharto family is still among the richest on earth.
After his resignation on May 21, Mr. Suharto went into seclusion for a few weeks, rarely emerging from his Jakarta home and seeing few visitors apart from his six children. He was reported to be depressed and shocked at his ouster after 32 years of iron-fisted rule.
But diplomats in Jakarta and Administration officials with access to intelligence reports say that his isolation is over and that he has worked aggressively behind the scenes to restore his contacts with political, military and religious leaders.
His family appears eager, they say, to influence next week's selection of Golkar's new leaders, who in turn will control the actions of the party's 325 members in the 500-seat House of Representatives and the selection of the party's candidates in the next national election.
While the House of Representatives has been a rubber stamp for the President in the past, the recent political chaos in Indonesia suggests that it may not be in the future. "The Suhartos want to buy up the loyalty of as many legislators as they can," a Clinton Administration official said. "It's their best hope for survival."
Rumors that Mr. Suharto would seek a return to public life -- and might even try to take power again as President with the help of the army -- have swirled through Jakarta virtually since the day he stepped down.
Military leaders have been forced to deny publicly that they are helping him return to power.
At a news conference on Monday, General Wiranto, the armed forces commander, acknowledged that he and other senior officers remained "close" to President Suharto. But Gen. Wiranto insisted that the situation does not "imply the existence of secret or hidden ties," nor that the military would help Mr. Suharto return to the presidency.
Mr. Suharto was succeeded by his Vice President, B. J. Habibie. While Mr. Habibie was considered a protege of the former President, it is unclear what sort of relationship exists between the two today.
In recent weeks President Habibie has taken some actions that appear to be favors to his predecessor, including his decision last month to dismiss Attorney General Sujono Atmonegoro after Mr. Atmonegoro announced that he was organizing an investigation of the wealth of former government officials, apparently including Mr. Suharto.
But other actions by Mr. Habibie appear to be snubs.

SECTION: Section B; Page 1; Column 3; Metropolitan Desk 

LENGTH: 1514 words

HEADLINE: Keeping 'em Down on the Farm;
Sales of Development Rights Preserve Agrarian Land

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER 

DATELINE: RED HOOK, N.Y.

 BODY:
Fraleighs have been farming the land here ever since John Adams was President, forming part of an enduring rustic tapestry of grazing cows, languid country roads and trees sagging with fruit.
Yet discouraging economics and mounting debts have at times forced Dave Fraleigh, an apple and peach grower, to ponder some distasteful strategies. Two or three years ago, he looked into the possibility of selling part of his land to suburban-style developers the way farmers have done all over the nation. 
 He also considered turning the farm into an agrarian Disneyland, inviting the public to pick their own fruit and gawk at the vanishing ways of farmers. But he rejected that, too.
"I enjoy growing fruit; I don't enjoy being in entertainment," Mr. Fraleigh said, chatting with some visitors as his two Labrador retrievers snoozed in the midday shade.
Now, Mr. Fraleigh has been able to shrug off such possibilities because a white knight in June paid him hundreds of thousands of dollars to bind himself to farm his 125 acres until he retires, then pass it on to another farmer.
For Mr. Fraleigh, the instant infusion of cash will allow him to pay off debt and buy 93 more acres. For Red Hook, it may mean something far more valuable: one more lasting farm to help sustain a rural sense of place far into the future.
The white knight, in Mr. Fraleigh's case, was an environmental group called Scenic Hudson, but similar programs have existed in 20 states for many years. Local and state governments and private preservation trusts have been buying development rights to farmland, permanently limiting the use of the land to agriculture, as a way of sustaining their locales' pastoral character.
What makes Scenic Hudson's program noteworthy is that rather than preserving farms scattershot, the organization is spending $2.5 million to preserve a cluster of seven Red Hook farms with 1,000 acres -- 16 percent of the town's farmland -- on the theory that a rural area needs a critical mass of farms to resist development pressures. Mr. Fraleigh, 44, a stocky man with bulky, sunburned shoulders, said he would not have kept a farm if everyone around him had sold out.
"I didn't want to have a farm in the middle of suburbia," said Mr. Fraleigh (FRAY-lee), who does not yet know whether his three young children -- Peter, 10; Steven, 8, and Sarah, 5 -- will want to farm. "Tractors running at 3 o'clock in the morning aren't popular with neighbors."
What the government and private preservationists do is have farmland appraised for what it would be worth on the open market, then for what it would be worth if it could be used only as farmland. They pay the farmer the difference, sometimes more than 50 percent of a parcel's value.
For instance, if land in Dutchess County is worth $5,000 an acre unencumbered but only $3,000 if limited to farming, then the farmer would be paid $2,000 an acre. The farmer keeps the land, but unless a court intervenes, the deed to the farm is restricted with a conservation easement, a provision that forever prohibits residential or commercial development.
A program pioneered 25 years ago by Suffolk County and its municipalities has preserved more than 8,000 acres of farmland, mostly in the East End, against the enticements of bankers and entertainers seeking to build weekend homes. In an area like the Hamptons, where a 65-acre oceanfront farm recently went to a developer for $11 million, the Peconic Land Trust sometimes uses less expensive variations on a theme -- like encouraging farmers to contribute their land to the trust in exchange for substantial tax benefits.
New York State, a relative latecomer with a program less than three years old, is now spending $5 million for farmland preservation, providing grants to selected municipalities willing to shoulder 75 percent of the cost of development rights.
New Jersey, which started its program in 1973, has spent $168 million preserving 234 farms, and Connecticut has spent $75 million on protecting 169 farms. Some of the programs make use of a $35 million Federal pot of matching funds created in 1996.
Land preservationists like Joseph Gergela, executive director of the Long Island Farm Bureau, make the argument that buying up farmland can end up saving taxpayers money. A single farm requires schooling, police and other services for only one family. A residential development on that same acreage can require services for scores of families.
A 1989 study by Scenic Hudson found that Red Hook spent $1.11 in services for every $1 in tax revenue generated by residential development. By contrast, when farmland or other open land was involved, the town spent 22 cents in services for every dollar it received in revenue.
To understand how important such programs are, it is necessary to grasp what they are battling against. Nationally, one million acres of the country's 945 million acres of farmland are swallowed up every year, transformed into homes and malls, according to the American Farmland Trust, a conservation group.
Southern Dutchess County, now about an hour and 15 minute drive from the New York City line, was not too long ago a sleepy backwater of milk farms and apple orchards. Like Red Hook farther north in the county, it was the kind of place where, as Mr. Fraleigh's wife, Karen, likes to say, "I can't go into the grocery store without running into four people I know on a first-name basis."
But starting in the 1950's, the arrival of two huge I.B.M. plants and the emergence of corporate office parks around White Plains created a thirst for housing, particularly in southern Dutchess. From 1969 to 1995, the last year for which figures are available, one of every four farming acres in Dutchess vanished, leaving 615 farms with 113,000 acres. (Since the 1970's, the number of farms has stayed roughly the same, but bigger farms have been replaced by smaller ones.)
There are no longer dairy farms in towns like East Fishkill and Wappingers Falls that not too long ago had plenty of them.
"Once a farm has been sold, it never comes back," said Dave Tetor, agriculture program leader of Cornell Cooperative Extension in Dutchess County, which furnishes farmers with research.
The downsizing of I.B.M. earlier this decade gave a reprieve to Dutchess's farmers, who generate $409 million a year in sales, but the booming economy has made them brace for the likelihood of another developer onslaught. Anticipating that invasion, Scenic Hudson tapped $2.5 million it received from the Lila Acheson and DeWitt Wallace Fund for the Hudson Highlands and used it for buying development rights rather than saving riverside bluffs or marshland, as it usually does.
"The younger generation is seeing the cards stacking up against them," said Steven Rosenberg, Scenic Hudson's director of land preservation. "They'll say: 'What am I going to do? Go into mom and dad's farm or go to business school?' If the cards continue stacking up the way they do, they go to business school."
These permanent conservation easements are not for everyone. Many farmers who expect to retire without heirs who want to farm would rather sell to a developer. Chuck Mead, who owns 105 acres of orchards and hay fields, did not accept Scenic Hudson's initial offer because it was too low, given what he felt is the possibility of Metro-North trains extending up to nearby Tivoli and driving up land prices. In the hope of getting a better price, he has applied for a separate county program that is buying up development rights.
"If I were to sell the land, I wouldn't have any debt," Mr. Mead said, "but I wouldn't have a farm. This way, I can sell part of the value and still continue to farm."
The preservation programs have helped not only landowners like Mr. Fraleigh, but also prospective landowners like John Hardeman.
Mr. Hardeman, 45, a tall, rangy Red Hook native, owns a tiny seven-acre orchard with a roadside produce stand just outside the village center. He could not afford to buy substantial orchard land in Red Hook, where the prospect of development had pushed prices above $5,000 an acre. So in 1989, he bought apple and peach land in Livingston, 15 miles north, and became what he calls "a commuting farmer."
But that commuting may soon be eliminated. In June, Scenic Hudson bought the development rights to most of the farm near the roadside stand, 173 of Dave Lown's 250 acres, sharply diminishing its value to the point that Mr. Hardeman could afford to buy it. "It enables me to return to my roots," Mr. Hardeman said.
Mr. Lown, 70, a fourth-generation farmer, is ready to retire and his son and daughter have no interest in farming. He could have made more money selling the land to a developer, though Red Hook is still too far north for a home builder to appear in the near future. But he says that he is gratified that he can help keep the land the way it is.
"I'd rather see it stay a farm," he said. "I like to look at trees and open land instead of all houses and traffic. It makes for a nice rural area."

HEADLINE: Political Memo;
Big Victory for the Republican Right

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK 

DATELINE: MONTGOMERY, Ala., July 1

 BODY:
As a battle for the soul of Southern Republicanism, the Alabama primary runoff that Gov. Fob James Jr. won so convincingly on Tuesday reinforced a number of truths about the party and the region. Religious conservatives still wield immense influence. Strong stands against taxes still sell. Race still matters. And even as Southerners take a leading role in national politics, they still deeply resent Federal intrusion.
The result also buttressed a theme drawn from campaigns around the country this year, including the spending spree among Democrats in the race for California governor: money does not always prevail. 
 Governor James was outspent by his challenger, Winton Blount 3d, a wealthy Montgomery businessman, by more than 2 to 1. By financing his campaign heavily with loans from himself and his family, Mr. Blount forced Mr. James to spend twice as much as the Governor had originally budgeted for the primary. But he also handed Mr. James an issue, and the Governor appealed to this poor state's populist sensibilities by using television advertising to mock Mr. Blount's inherited wealth.
Each of those factors played a role in Mr. James's surprisingly decisive victory over Mr. Blount in their hard-fought runoff. With 99 percent of precincts reporting, Mr. James had 56 percent of the vote to Mr. Blount's 44 percent. In the general election for governor, Mr. James will now face Lieut. Gov. Don Siegelman, who easily won the Democratic nomination four weeks ago.
The primary campaign probed the inherent tensions in Southern Republicanism, between the conservative Christians drawn to the party, and to Mr. James, by a deeply felt moral agenda, and the business-oriented voters primarily concerned with the state's economic interests. One of Mr. James's chief strategists was Ralph Reed, former executive director of the Christian Coalition. Throughout the region and beyond, the primary was widely seen as a test of the power of the Christian right, less than two years before the Presidential primary season begins.
Mr. Reed himself said that Tuesday's message was clear.
"If you don't backpedal and don't apologize for taking a strong stand for religious freedom," he said, "you will be rewarded at the ballot box."
In the week before Mr. James's triumph, polls showed the race to be a dead heat. But the polls could not measure the enthusiasm of Mr. James's support among white conservatives in rural and suburban counties. Many of those voters were pulled to the polls by last-minute mailings and telephone calls that emphasized the Governor's devotion to religious causes, like his protests against Federal court rulings prohibiting organized prayer in public schools and his defense of a state judge's displaying the Ten Commandments on a courtroom wall.
In the last month, for instance, the Governor's campaign directed three pieces of mail and three telephone calls to each of 90,000 households gleaned from lists of people who had attended rallies supporting that judge, Roy Moore, a James strategist said. Many of the fliers noted Mr. James's support from evangelical leaders like Pat Robertson, Jerry Falwell and James C. Dobson.
"Anyone who didn't think before that religious conservatives were a big part of the electorate here and the backbone of the Republican Party simply didn't understand Alabama," said State Attorney General Bill Pryor, a Republican.
The polls also did not detect an apparent backlash against the endorsement of Mr. Blount last week by Mayor Richard Arrington Jr. of Birmingham, a black Democrat who urged his supporters to vote in the Republican runoff. An unusual provision allows Alabama voters to participate in a Republican primary runoff regardless of whether they voted in the first primary election, or how.
Mr. James had pursued the Mayor's endorsement himself. But when he did not receive it, his strategists and allies encouraged the backlash by arguing that Mr. Blount would be the captive of "a liberal Democratic political boss" who had demanded a say on appointments and spending.
Television advertisements and mailings produced by the James campaign included photographs of Mr. Arrington. And a flier circulated widely by a black newspaper publisher who supports Mr. James carried a two-decade-old picture of a black Arrington adviser, Donald V. Watkins, with an Afro haircut that had long been shorn.
Mr. James's strategists, who were jubilant about his unexpectedly broad victory, said their advertisements had been designed to raise questions about Mr. Arrington's influence, and not his race. The same tactics would have been used, they said, had Mr. Arrington been white.
But a number of political scientists and strategists, including several Republicans, said today that the advertisements had relied on an implicit racial appeal and that they had worked.
"When you talk about liberal special-interest groups and run pictures of Richard Arrington and Donald Watkins, it's pretty clear which special-interest group you're talking about," said Bradley Moody, an associate professor of political science at Auburn University, Montgomery. "It's not labor unions, and it's not the Alabama Education Association."
Q. Whitfield Ayres, a Republican pollster from Atlanta who has worked for candidates and lobbying groups in Alabama, said that the endorsement by Mr. Arrington's Jefferson County Citizens Coalition seemed to have driven up turnout in some typically Democratic precincts and that Mr. Blount had benefited from that vote. But, Mr. Ayres said, that was more than offset by increases in rural and suburban counties where white conservatives may have been motivated to vote for Mr. James by the Arrington endorsement. "The initial indications are that the endorsement backfired," Mr. Ayres said. "My sense is that Mr. Blount got on the wrong side of a racial issue."
A Republican strategist who has worked on several statewide campaigns in Alabama put it even more bluntly. "When you play the race card in Alabama, it's over," the strategist said, speaking on the condition of anonymity.
Mr. James also played effectively, as he has throughout his political life, to an almost visceral sentiment in Alabama's white electorate: a distaste for elites and outside authority. Several analysts said today that his attacks on the Federal judiciary and critical editorial writers, at whom he poked fun in his victory speech on Tuesday night, appealed to his state's oft-wounded pride. In his speech, he spoke of "a spirit that says deep down, 'I'm proud to be from Alabama.' "
Merle Black, an Emory University political scientist who has written extensively on Republican politics in the South, said Mr. James's ability to strike nativist chords was reminiscent of former Gov. George C. Wallace.
"It's the old Confederate thing of winning by losing," he said. "The important thing is making a stand against the odds. Even if he's losing on these religious issues, it still works with voters."
Although concerned about the damage inflicted on Mr. James during a prolonged and nasty primary campaign, Republican leaders were ecstatic about the record number of voters who were drawn. With few runoffs on the Democratic ballot, the Republican election on Tuesday attracted a stunning total of 455,000 voters, shattering the previous mark of 359,000 Republican voters, set in the primary on June 2. That number, in turn, had smashed a record of 215,000 set in 1996.
Mr. James succeeded by expanding his margin of victory over Mr. Blount in rural counties, and by minimizing his losses in cities like Birmingham and Montgomery.
While Mr. James, 63, depleted his war chest in defeating Mr. Blount, Mr. Siegelman, the 52-year-old Democratic nominee, begins the general election campaign with more than $3.5 million. At a news conference today, he wasted little time in opening a two-front offensive.
He continued Mr. Blount's efforts to make the campaign a referendum on Mr. James, describing him at a news conference as "a do-nothing Governor." And he relentlessly promoted his plan to enact a state lottery that would pay for college scholarships, pre-kindergarten programs and classroom computers.
Polls show that education is by far the most important issue to Alabama voters. But the lottery, like all forms of gambling, may be a hard sell in a state where evangelical churches play so crucial a role in electoral politics.
The lottery plan permits Mr. Siegelman to propose significant increases in spending without raising taxes, a convenient device against an incumbent who pledges not to raise state taxes of any kind. But Mr. James opposes a lottery, and Mr. Siegelman's gambling initiative is also certain to energize the conservative Christians who form the foundation of the Governor's support.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Easing of Worries on Japan Helps the Dow Top 9,000

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The Dow Jones industrial average closed above 9,000 yesterday for the first time in three weeks as concerns about Japan eased and Federal Reserve officials left interest rates unchanged.
The index of 30 blue-chip stocks rose 96.65 points, to 9,048.67, a gain of 1.1 percent. 
 The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks rose 14.72, or 1.3 percent, to 1,148.56, another record.
"I don't think it was any surprise," said Alan Skrainka, chief market strategist at Edward Jones & Sons, referring to the Fed's decision to leave rates unchanged.
"You cannot fight what you cannot see, and right now we don't see any signs of inflation on the horizon."
Today, Japan's leaders are expected to disclose steps to tackle bad bank loans in a bid to restart their economy. This would help drag Asia out of its slowdown, analysts said.
"The market is reacting today to the rally in Japanese stocks, and the sense that Japanese political leaders are no longer in denial and will do something to spur the economy," Mr. Skrainka said.
Stocks in Japan jumped 3.4 percent overnight, the second day of strong gains, bolstered by a rising yen and optimism about Government plans to deal with the banking crisis.
In Washington, the Fed, the nation's central bank, left interest rates unchanged after a two-day meeting.
Investors' hopes that the worst of the second-quarter profit warnings were out of the way also bolstered sentiment.
In the broader market, advances beat declines by better than 2 to 1 on active New York Stock Exchange volume of 701.6 million shares. The Nasdaq composite index, weighted with technology stocks, rose 19.72, to 1,914.46.
Smaller stocks also rallied, with the Russell 2000 index of small issues adding 2.46, to 459.85.
Internet-related stocks were particularly strong on speculation that AT&T, America Online, CBS and others are shopping for Internet partners. Netscape Communications rose 8 5/8, to 35 11/16, in Nasdaq
trading. Doubleclick jumped 14 5/16, to 64; Yahoo gained 12 3/8, to 169 7/8, and Earthlink Network rose 10 1/4, to 87.
These and other Internet stocks rallied in recent weeks after the Walt Disney Company bought 43 percent of the on-line directory Infoseek.
The At Home Corporation surged 6 3/16, to 53 1/2, after the Internet content company said it had reached agreements with Jones Intercable to offer high-speed Internet service over cable television lines in the Washington area.
Nike gained 3 3/8, to 52 1/16, after the footwear company reported fourth-quarter profit of 4 cents a share, a penny above estimates. Analysts at several brokerage firms raised their rating on the stock.
Hambrecht & Quist Group, a San Francisco investment bank, slumped 2 5/16, to 34, after Credit Suisse First Boston said it had hired Deutsche Bank Securities' three most productive investment bankers. Hambrecht had surged 22 percent Tuesday on speculation that Credit Suisse First Boston would make a takeover offer.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
30-Year Treasury Unchanged As Fed Holds Line on Rates

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond was unchanged yesterday, after, as expected, the Federal Reserve policy-making committee decided not to adjust interest rates.
The 30-year bond closed at a price of 107 6/32, leaving the bond's yield at 5.62 percent.
Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management, attributed the Fed's decision to a slowdown in the economy, subdued inflation, the budget surplus and the malaise in Asia.
Treasury securities opened weaker yesterday after the dollar fell in currency trading. A strong dollar makes dollar-denominated investments like Treasury securities more attractive to foreign investors, who also benefit from the currency translation.
But then a report on manufacturing suggested the economy was slowing. "Indeed, economic data released today clearly indicated a slowing of economic momentum, as exemplified by the sharp decline in the National Association of Purchasing Management index, a fallback in construction spending, and the flattening in the index of leading indicators," Mr. Fine said. The June manufacturing index fell to 49.6 from 51.4 in May, the first time in two years that the level has dropped below 50, a sign of contraction in the industrial sector.
Mr. Fine added that some of the declines in the index were for production, employment and inventories, and while some of the sluggishness may be a result of the strike against the General Motors Corporation, he said, the crisis in Asia was playing a much greater role.
Construction spending tumbled 1.5 percent in May to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $633.5 billion as private and public sectors registered declines. And the Conference Board's index of leading indicators was unchanged in May for the second consecutive month, which could be signaling slower growth in the third quarter as well as the second quarter.
The Government will report today on the number of jobs added to the economy last month and on the unemployment rate, both of which are capable of moving the market. Estimates of jobs created range from an increase of 125,000 jobs to an increase of 250,000, placing the consensus at about 190,000 new jobs.
Mr. Fine said the average for the number of jobs added to the economy in the last two months has been plus 300,000. "So even if it comes in at the high end of expectations, it is still below the recent average," he said.

HEADLINE: China Still Trails Russia in What Matters Most;
Gorbachev's Vision

 BODY:

To the Editor:
I agree with Robert D. Kaplan (Op-Ed, June 28) that China's gradual approach to modernization has worked better than Russia's. In retrospect, Mikhail S. Gorbachev was correct when he advocated a similar gradualism for Russia, and it is a pity that he lost power and reputation because he would not move quickly toward a free-market economy. 
 Some transitional market distortion and old-guard hegemony would have been a good investment in the controlled growth of an efficient production plant with minimal social disruption. Russia's leader might have had more to show for his life's work than a quiet retreat and the revenue from a television ad.
 
MARK HOMER
Knoxville, Tenn., July 1, 1998

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;
Japan's Reserve Funds Decreased Last Month

BYLINE: Dow Jones 

 BODY:
Japan's reserves of convertible foreign currencies, gold and International Monetary Fund special drawing rights decreased by $1.1 billion in June from the preceding month, to $205.87 billion, the Finance Ministry said yesterday. 
 The decline followed a rise of $1.22 billion in May from April. A large decline in the value of reserves was expected for June because of the intervention to support the yen in foreign exchange markets undertaken by the Bank of Japan and the United States Federal Reserve on June 17. Traders have estimated that the Bank of Japan and the Fed spent a combined $3 billion to $4 billion in propping up the yen. Normally, in months without intervention, Japan's reserves increase $1 billion to $2 billion because of interest earned on holdings.

LENGTH: 513 words

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

As Expected, Fed Leaves Interest Rates Unchanged
After a two-day meeting, the Federal Reserve decided not to change interest rates, which had been widely expected.
Several new economic reports indicate that the economy is cooling, which might be the reason for the move. The National Association of Purchasing Management index for June fell to 49.6 from 51.4 in May, the first time in two years that the level has dropped below 50. The Commerce Department also reported that construction slumped 1.5 percent in May, the worst drop in more than four years, and the Conference Board's indicator of future economic activity remained unchanged from April to May at 105.2. Page D4. 

States Lose on Patent Ruling
A Federal appeals court judge ruled that a New Jersey Bank can sue the State of Florida over the state's unauthorized use of a college-savings program. The ruling means states can be sued for infringing patent rights owned by individuals or companies. D2.
 
Boeing Report Bolsters Shares
Shares of Boeing rose 6.45 percent after the company gave a glowing report on its recovery to analysts and reporters. The jet maker said it delivered 61 airplanes in June, the highest one-month total ever, and was on course to meet its goal of delivering 550 jets this year. Even so, many Wall Street analysts remain bearish on Boeing, citing price competition with Airbus, its European rival, continuing weakness in Asia and the specter of rising oil prices. Market Place. D6.
 
Dow Climbs Back Above 9,000
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 1.1 percent, closing above 9,000 for the first time in three weeks. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index set another record, jumping to 1,148.56, D5.
 
The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond remained at 5.62 percent. D5.
 
Stock Rally Continues in Japan
The Japanese stock market extended its rally for a seventh consecutive day, on expectations that the Government's plan for cleaning up the nation's problem loans will spur an economic revival. D5.
 
Star Banc to Acquire Firstar
Star Banc announced plans to acquire Firstar for stock worth about $7.2 billion. The deal would create a banking company with $38 billion in assets and outlets in 10 states, mostly in the Midwest. D4.
 
Volvo Confirms VW Talks
Volvo of Sweden confirmed that its chief executive had discussions last Friday with the chairman of Volkswagen amid speculation of a possible alliance or merger between the two auto makers. Although Volvo executives discouraged suggestions that any kind of agreement was imminent, the company has long acknowledged that it is seeking strategic partners. And Volkswagen, which is buying Rolls-Royce Motor Cars, has made no secret of its desire to acquire a truck business. The stock prices of both companies surged. D6.
 
A Stronger Focus on Women
A growing number of companies are marketing directly to women the products and services that were once pitched almost exclusively to men because they want to let women know they want their business. Advertising. D6.

LENGTH: 723 words

HEADLINE: Amid Boom, Workers Fret About Future

BYLINE: By MIKE ALLEN 

 BODY:
Dennis Scudera wears his $7,800 Rolex watch with his hard hat, which he wears while making $34.64 an hour running the 3-ton Caterpillar to scoop out a basement for a Planet Hollywood Hotel being built in midtown Manhattan.
With New York City basking in a building boom, these are hardly hard times for Mr. Scudera -- or most construction workers throughout New York City. But instead of feeling secure in the steady flow of work, they are already worrying about the slowdown they know is inevitable. 
 The workers said it was such a worry that prompted them to turn out by the thousands for Tuesday's rally, which protested the hiring of a nonunion contractor by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.
"If the nonunion companies can pay a Mexican $6 an hour -- not that anything's wrong with Mexicans or Italians or whatever -- and get away with it, what good is our union?" Mr. Scudera asked.
Such fears were so widespread that the organizers of the rally did not need a Web site or a news conference or advertisements or any of the other fancy tools of modern political organizing. Beginning eight days before the rally, the Building and Construction Trades Council of Greater New York sent one-sided black-and-white fliers to leaders of about 60 union locals.
"All jobs in the five boroughs will be shut down for this rally," the poster said. "Bring union banners and American flags."
The union locals copied the leaflets for shop stewards, who posted them at hundreds of job sites. The day before the rally, union leaders passed out copies in Grand Central Station between 6 and 7 A.M., when most construction workers arrive.
Paul E. Fernandes, assistant to the president of the Building and Construction Trades Council, said nearly every union job in the city -- about 60 percent of all construction in the city -- shut down for the rally. Most nonunion jobs are small; the unions said they took such dramatic action because of the size of the M.T.A. project, which will cost $32.6 million.
The march, though marred by injuries to both the police and the demonstrators, was so huge that even the workers said they were startled. "I didn't do it for now -- I did it for down the road," said Paddy Smith, 30, a bricklayer from Queens who was helping finish a luxury apartment tower on Eighth Avenue between 49th and 50th Streets.
Fellow workers at the site pulled out their union cards to show that the idea of brotherhood goes beyond the names of the labor groups.
"Other guys have paid the dues," said Vincenzo Realmuto, 54, a laborer from Lodi, N.J. "You know what I mean? Without the unions, it would be like 200 years ago, when the bosses had slaves."
Charles Gallagher, 58, who was laying wood flooring, compared the hiring of nonunion laborers to the diversion of factory jobs to other countries. "These companies want to make the money you can make in New York, but they don't want to pay what it costs -- and that's union scale," Mr. Gallagher said.
Tuesday's demonstrators included plumbers and carpenters, electricians and steamfitters, lathers and laborers.
Despite criticism over the violence that ensued, union leaders said the rally proved that labor was being re-energized as a political force. And leaders have threatened future actions, albeit smaller, against public agencies if they award contracts to companies the unions consider irresponsible -- a response that is being embraced by labor movements across the nation.
"Working people get it," said Brian M. McLaughlin, president of the New York City Central Labor Council. "When they're asked to respond, they do."
Among the marchers was Gene Bryant, 36, a machine operator who said a nonunion toehold in the city would make a downturn catastrophic for union members. "You've got to make the best of the good times to make it through the slow times," he said.
Mike DePasquale, 33, of the Bronx, took a break from his work on the elevator shaft of a new high-rise in Times Square to recall his stint as a bartender during the construction slowdown of the early 1990's.
Mr. DePasquale said that fresh memory was fueling his fight against the nonunion workers, who he feels lack the training to do safe and skilled work. "It's like hiring a carpenter to do plumbing," Mr. DePasquale said. "You've got to stop it when it starts."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Dennis Scudera and other union construction workers believe that an economic slowdown is inevitable, and they believe that nonunion companies constitute a threat to their jobs. (Chang W. Lee/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: G.M.'s June Sales Soared; Strikes to Hurt July's

BYLINE: By MICHELLE KREBS 

DATELINE: DETROIT, July 1

 BODY:
The General Motors Corporation said today that June car and truck sales were the highest for any month in nine years but that July sales would plummet because of two strikes that have shut down most of the auto maker's North American assembly plants.
Ronald L. Zarrella, vice president in charge of G.M.'s North American Vehicle Sales, Service and Marketing Group, said at a news conference today that sales would drop 30 percent to 40 percent this month compared with sales from the month a year earlier because of the strikes by the United Automobile Workers. That would push G.M.'s market share to a record low of 25 percent and put G.M. behind the Ford Motor Company as the largest volume vehicle manufacturer in the United States. Already, analysts say the strikes at two plants in Flint, Mich., have cost G.M. $1.18 billion. 
 In June, G.M. sold 492,937 cars and trucks, including heavy trucks, a 24 percent increase compared with sales in the month a year earlier. It was G.M.'s best month since May 1989 and its fourth consecutive month of year-over-year increase. Though total industry sales in June will not be available until Ford reports its sales on Monday, Mr. Zarrella predicted G.M.'s market share would be between 31.5 percent and 33 percent for June.
The Chrysler Corporation, which also reported June figures today, said it had a 10 percent increase in sales compared with those in June 1997.
Despite the strong June sales report for G.M., the strikes, which have closed 26 of the company's 29 North American assembly plants, have already diminished G.M.'s sales by preventing shipment of vehicles to daily rental car fleets, which represent about 20 percent of the auto maker's sales. G.M. was unable to fill an order for 15,000 fleet cars in June and will be unable to fill any fleet orders in July, usually the biggest month of the year for fleet sales, Mr. Zarrella said. In addition, G.M. will be unable to build special-order vehicles, which typically account for 10 percent of sales, and sales to employees, which have been running as high as 5 percent of total sales, will most likely plunge.
If the strike lingers beyond mid-July, the consequences will be more dire and permanent as customers buy cars and trucks from rivals instead of waiting for the strike to end, Mr. Zarrella predicted. "If we can't supply it, we're going to lose customers -- 21,000 customers we're likely to lose every day," he said.
Analysts agree with Mr. Zarrella that those customers could be lost forever. "The competition will take as much advantage of the situation as it can," said Joseph Phillippi, an auto analyst with Lehman Brothers in New York. "That's not just Ford and Chrysler but also imports -- every seller from Hyundai to Mercedes-Benz. And the damage may be lasting."
G.M.'s inventory is already dwindling. The company entered June with 1.1 million cars and trucks in dealer inventory; that number dropped to 850,000 by the end of the month, enough to last through July.
"We have enough retail inventory to allow our dealers to keep the sales momentum going in July," Mr. Zarrella said. "Consumers can still go into G.M. dealerships, see plenty of variety and still get great value despite the fact that we have a strike."
Total United States car and truck sales in June are coming in nearly as strong as sales in May. The seasonally adjusted annual selling rate for light vehicles reached 16.3 million cars and trucks in May, the best month since September 1986, and was on track to be just as high in June, auto executives and analysts said.
Chrysler set a new monthly sales record, selling 252,485 cars and trucks, a 10 percent increase compared with sales in the month a year earlier and breaking the record set in May, when Chrysler surpassed the quarter million mark for the first time in a single month.
Toyota Motor sales totaled 117,043 cars and trucks, up 17 percent, a new June record. Likewise, Honda Motor sales set a June record, with 88,928 vehicles sold, an increase of 8 percent from the month a year earlier. Mercedes-Benz sales were up 82 percent from June 1997, at 15,134 vehicles. Also reporting higher June sales were Mitsubishi Motors, Subaru, Volvo and Land Rover. Saab and Hyundai Motor sales dropped.
Regardless of the strikes against G.M., analysts predicted the surge of the last two months would ease somewhat in July. Strong sales in May and June were buoyed by attractive incentive programs, some of which will be discontinued. G.M. has already announced that it will not renew its Loyalty First program, which provided owners of G.M. vehicles with certificates of $500 to $1,000 to use toward the purchase of another G.M. vehicle.
Ford and Chrysler have not said whether they will continue their programs, which provide their customers with similar loyalty coupons and allow their dealers to accept G.M. coupons as well, when they expire next week.
Still, auto makers and analysts predict an unprecedented fifth straight year of sales of more than 15 million cars and trucks because of record consumer confidence, low interest rates and inflation and a healthy stock market.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Ronald L. Zarrella said strikes in Flint would cut into G.M. sales this month. (Andrew Johnston for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CLINTON IN CHINA: THE OVERVIEW;
Clinton Sends Dual Message To China in Interview on TV

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: SHANGHAI, Thursday, July 2

 BODY:
President Clinton, in his last opportunity to address a mass audience in China, said Wednesday that he would continue to speak out on behalf of democracy and individual liberty, but that the United States did not seek to dictate the path of China's development.
In an interview with China's main Government-run television network to be broadcast today, Mr. Clinton said that China's current course of economic liberalization and greater personal freedom was "morally right," and that the status of the United States as the world's lone superpower did not give it the right to use economic and military might to impose its values on China or any other nation. 
 In the course of the interview, Mr. Clinton sent subtle and somewhat contradictory messages to different audiences in China. His words offered reassurance to President Jiang Zemin and other leaders in Beijing that the United States would not and could not impose its will on China. But he also signaled to ordinary Chinese -- and to domestic critics of his policy of engagement with China -- that he would continue to press Beijing to allow greater personal freedom and take steps toward a more open political system.
"I think there's a genuine movement toward openness and freedom in China, which obviously as an American, and as an American President, I hope will continue and increase and which I believe is right -- morally right -- but I also think it's good for China," Mr. Clinton said.
Mr. Clinton was asked whether the world needed a single leader to mediate disputes within and among nations. "The short answer to your question is yes, the world needs a leader, but not in the sense of one country telling everyone else what to do," Mr. Clinton said. "So it's a different sort of world leadership than in the past where it's just a question of who has the biggest army gets to send a list of instructions to another country and you think it will be done. That's not the way the world works now."
He gave as examples the United States' intervention in Bosnia and Haiti and its efforts to mobilize other nations to combat drug trafficking, weapons proliferation and ethnic conflict. He said the way to get results in the post-cold-war world was to forge alliances to exert influence, rather than trying to act unilaterally. "And so the United States' role I think is to try to create a structure where more likely than not the right things will be done when problems arise -- not to just do it all ourselves or tell other people what to do," Mr. Clinton said.
The White House sought this interview because an earlier one with CCTV, held before Mr. Clinton left Washington, was heavily edited by the Chinese authorities and received little notice in China. United States officials said they had received assurances that Wednesday's interview would be broadcast in its entirety. It was conducted by Shui Junyi, anchor of CCTV-1's public affairs program "Focus" and Chen Xiaowei, an anchor on CCTV-4, thenetwork's international channel and host of a Sunday news program.
The questioning was gentle compared to the grilling Mr. Clinton got Monday from students at Beijing University who challenged him on United States policy toward Taiwan and human rights in America. Asked when he became interested in China, he gave a vintage Clintonian response. He said he was 8 or 9 years old and reading an encyclopedia when he came across the entry about China.
"And I was fascinated by what I read," Mr. Clinton said. "I always wanted to come here from that time on."
He said the most gratifying thing about his trip was the decision by Mr. Jiang to allow their Saturday press conference and his speech at Beijing University to be carried live on Chinese television. He said he was surprised and pleased by the decision to allow the "open, sweeping communication" with the Chinese people that those two events afforded.
"That I think was very good," Mr. Clinton said. "I think it was also good for the Chinese leaders."
Mr. Clinton sat for the 20-minute interview at the modern Shanghai Stock Exchange, where he received a rousing welcome from traders on the floor. Mr. Clinton conducted a round-table discussion with young entrepreneurs, who told him of the difficulties in starting a new business, securing venture capital and dealing with the bureaucracy. Mr. Clinton told the business people they were an important force for change in China, and a source of the new jobs that will be needed as state-owned enterprises close.
In the afternoon, Mr. Clinton visited a housing development to witness a relatively new phenomenon in China -- private ownership of homes. The Jin Hui Gardens complex opened five years ago, offering Chinese families the opportunity to buy their own apartments for $42,200 to $96,500, according to figures provided by the developers.
Mr. Clinton told families assembled at the development that home ownership represents an investment in society and the bedrock of middle-class life.
"All China benefits from more home owners because that means more jobs, a stronger economy, stronger families," Mr. Clinton said as low clouds threatened rain. "And, of course, when people own their own homes, they are free to take new jobs without worrying about losing housing benefits. We also see around the world that home owners take more responsibility for the communities in which they live."
The President announced a new joint United States-China program to promote the construction of affordable, energy-efficient housing. He also said that American officials would work with Beijing to create a middle-income mortgage-lending market and to strengthen legal rights for property owners.
Today, the President flew to Guilin, a picturesque city on the Li River, where he delivered an address on the environment. He continues on to Hong Kong, where on Friday he will give a speech on the turmoil in the Asian economy to business leaders and conduct a news conference before returning to Washington on Friday night.
