HEADLINE: Rosy Economy Is Blemished as Factories Slow

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
The nation's manufacturers have slowed production to the lowest rate of growth since 1995, the clearest sign so far that the Asian crisis is hurting the American economy.
The slowdown has become increasingly evident with each new economic statistic in recent weeks. Yesterday, the National Association of Purchasing Management reported that manufacturing activity weakened in June for a majority of the companies that it surveys each month. It was the first time in 22 months that a majority had reported weakening instead of strengthening in their businesses. 
 Manufacturing employment has fallen in recent months. And industrial production has slowed sharply this year, to an annual growth rate of 2 percent or so, down from 6 percent last year.
Production is slowing in large part because stockpiles of unsold goods have grown, but also because companies are worried that the economic boom cannot continue at the brisk pace of the last two years.
Companies that make goods for sale abroad have retrenched the most. Take the Jefferson Smurfit Corporation, based in St. Louis, which makes the raw material for cardboard shipping boxes and sells its wares in the United States and abroad. It shut a big mill in Jacksonville, Fla., yesterday for 40 days because of slumping exports to Asia.
Companies are feeling the pressure from their American customers as well. The Goodman Equipment Corporation near Chicago says that corporate customers are placing fewer orders for its plastic molding machines and mining equipment. "They are more nervous about the future, and more reluctant to expand," said Calvin A. Campbell, the company's chairman.
The production slowdown may help to explain why the Federal Reserve chose, at its policy meeting yesterday, to leave interest rates unchanged. Labor shortages and robust economic growth have suggested that higher rates may be needed at some point to slow the economy and prevent inflation from rising. But concerns about the deepening woes in Asia put counterpressure on the Fed to keep rates steady, thereby making investors less likely to switch into dollars from Japanese yen or South Korean won.
The bright spot in manufacturing, which represents 30 percent of the nation's economy, comes from consumer goods. American consumers are still big buyers, and that is strengthening those businesses that serve them. Rubbermaid Inc., for example, which makes toys and plastic garbage cans and has little competition from abroad, says its output and sales are rising at the same rate as last year.
The strong demand at the retail level fosters the hope that the slowdown in manufacturing will be short- lived. If it was to continue, the robust economic growth of the last two years would undoubtedly disappear.
"We don't know which way manufacturing and the economy will go," said William Dudley, chief domestic economist at Goldman, Sachs. "The issue is how strong is the shock from Asia versus how strong is domestic demand. Our view is that domestic demand will win out, but the contest is under way, and we do not have a clear winner yet."
The numbers of late have not been ambiguous. The manufacturing index compiled by the National Association of Purchasing Management dropped below 50, to 49.6, in June. That means that manufacturing activity weakened in June for a majority of companies surveyed. The General Motors strike, in its 28th day, is only partly reflected in the latest figure and may add to the drag on manufacturing for a while.
"People started to sense that orders were softening, and they are cutting back inventories," said Norbert Ore, a corporate executive who is chairman of the association's survey committee.
Inventories surged in the first quarter to a record $106 billion as companies like Jefferson Smurfit found their exports suddenly evaporating. The Eastman Chemical Company, which makes the chemical ingredients of plastic products and fibers, responded by trimming a few percentage points off its production. "We never close a plant when demand is not there; what you do is shave back production," said Ernest Deavenport, Eastman's chairman.
Nervousness about the future is also a significant constraint. New orders have been coming more slowly since spring, particularly for companies like Goodman, in Bedford Hills, Ill., which makes equipment and machinery for other manufacturers, and the Hiwasse Company in Jacksonville, Ark., which supplies the control panels for washing machines, stoves and other appliances.
"I had gone on sales calls in February, and customers were urgent in their demand for quotes from me," said J. Richard Derickson, Hiwasse's chief executive. "In April the requests for quotes just dramatically fell off, and they are just beginning to pick up again now."
Hannay Reels Inc. of Westerlo, N.Y., near Albany, which makes metal reels for industrial hoses and fuel trucks, has had a similar experience. "Our production this year is matching last year, which means it has slowed; last year production was up 7 percent," said Roger A. Hannay, the chief executive. "People are putting expansion on hold for a while, until they see what happens to the economy and the stock market."
The weaker production is hardly uniform. General Electric and some other appliance manufacturers say their production is up, not down, thanks to strong consumer demand. The Boeing Company, for all its concern about slowing airplane sales in Asia, is running flat out this year to fill a backlog of orders, although production may slow next year. And the nation's auto makers say that in the first five months of the year they produced 5.2 million vehicles, the same as in the period a year earlier.
But Republic Engineered Steels in Massillon, Ohio, concerned about swelling inventories -- given the potential impact of the Asian crisis -- has been selling off steel since early spring and reducing production. "We felt we had to convert those inventories into cash," said Harold Kelly, Republic's executive vice president. "We want to be more liquid."
Overcapacity is also hurting a variety of businesses. Having closed 11 factories in January, the apparel maker Levi Strauss says its jeans production is now in line with sales. "We were seeing that our market strategy could not be based on volume," said Linda Butler, a Levi Strauss spokeswoman. "We had to emphasize innovative products, made in smaller quantities."
Eastman Chemical is similarly struggling with overcapacity. The company had exported from the United States over the last several years while new plants were being built in Malaysia, Argentina, Spain and the Netherlands. "Now that they are on line, we are exporting less," Mr. Deavenport said. The cutback has come as Asian demand collapses.
Sometimes, chemical products going from Europe to Asia "can't find a home there and they land in the United States," Mr. Deavenport added. "And an American customer says, 'I am going to buy them at a lower price,' and we lose the sale. That is happening all the time now."
The slowdown in manufacturing production is helping to feed some forecasts that the economy will grow in the summer and fall at an annual rate of less than 3 percent, down from a strong 5.4 percent in the first quarter. Despite the surge in prosperity of the last two years, annual economic growth has averaged only 2.3 percent in the 1990's -- the slowest growth of any decade since World War II.

HEADLINE: Plugging In to the Internet: Many Paths, Many Speeds

BYLINE: By PETER WAYNER; E-mail address: pwayner@nytimes.com

 BODY:
THE first thing anyone who wants to connect to the Internet has to realize is that the Net is not a single entity -- it is a collection of networks joined by a set of standard ways to exchange data. The name Internet even implies that it links networks. This means that almost any system for carrying data -- wires, radio, fiber optics or even smoke signals -- can be hooked into the Internet if it can send that data in the format known as the Internet Protocol, or I.P.
 The good (or bad) news about this open standard for a network is that there are many options for getting connected to the Web. The most popular way is to use the telephone, but new options using the cable system or the cellular phone system are expanding rapidly. 
 Of course, not all choices are available in all areas. Some of the fanciest systems are just being introduced in tests around the country. Others are offered by companies that serve only small regions. With the array of choices available, it is difficult to give straightforward advice that applies to most people.
 Still, there is one general rule: Faster is better. That sounds like a simple standard to apply, but it's surprisingly complex. Some systems can provide great speed consistently. Others offer it only in bursts. Some require you to share the road with your neighbors, which means that service will be slower when people are home and faster when everyone else is asleep. On others, information moves at different speeds when it travels in different directions. You might be able to download, or receive, large volumes of data quickly, but the time to upload, or send, information could be much slower.
 The problem becomes even more complicated because a fast connection between you and your service provider does not guarantee that information will arrive quickly. Data will often travel through more than 20 connections between your machine and a distant Web site. The weakest link limits the speed at which your computer will get the data.
 Another important detail is service. Some people are comfortable working with computers, while others want someone else to worry about the details. Some of the biggest brands in the on-line business got there by concentrating on making their connecting process as simple and bulletproof as possible.
 Ways of connecting require not only special hardware and software but also a relationship with an Internet service provider, known as an I.S.P. Look before you leap, and add up all the costs and benefits. This is only a general guide; specifics vary considerably from place to place and from company to company.
 So, with that said, here's a thumbnail guide to the sometimes bewildering world of connecting to the Internet.

GRAPHIC: Charts: "Ways to Connect"
 
Phone Line (Analog)
MAXIMUM SPEED*: 56 Kbps.
DOWNLOAD TIME FOR "MOBY DICK" ON-LINE BOOK+: 2.8 minutes at 56 Kbps.
COST: $30-$200 for modem, I.S.P. charges extra.
AVAILABILITY: Nationwide.
 WHILE the telephone system is the most common way for people to connect to the Internet from home, it was engineered to carry voices, not data, over the lines. Modems to carry data were developed as afterthoughts, and the phone companies are fond of saying that they do not guarantee that modems will work. Many glitches people report with modems, like sudden disconnections, are in some ways the result of trying to carry data by turning it into high-pitched squeaks through a modem.
Despite that, connecting with the phone system is relatively easy, and phone service is almost ubiquitous. Most I.S.P.'s offer CD-ROM's or floppy disks with all the necessary software to connect through a modem. These are usually programmed with the standard settings for most major computers and modems, but problems still occur occasionally. The I.S.P.'s also offer some hand-holding advice if things go wrong.
One of the biggest headaches for some I.S.P.'s is providing enough phone lines. They get charged for each line coming in to their headquarters, so they try to minimize the number of lines. Also, growth can swamp an I.S.P. (Remember when America Online gained so many customers so fast that many had problems connecting?) Companies are still trying to find the right balance of prices and service for a sustainable I.S.P. business.
A recent problem has arisen from the slightly confusing transition to 56 K modems. They are supposed to move data at the rate of 56,000 bits (or 56 kilobits) per second, roughly equivalent, depending on the technology, to 1,000 to 2,000 words per second. Often phone systems cannot support high speeds, and these modems are forced to work a little more slowly. Two companies tried to corner the market in the modem business by introducing competing standards that could not interact. A compromise standard, called V.90, has been designed, but it is not widely available, which means that your modem may not communicate well with your I.S.P.'s modem, and the glitches can be maddening because they can seem random.
 
I.S.D.N.
MAXIMUM SPEED*: 128 Kbps.
"MOBY DICK" DOWNLOAD TIME+: 1.2 minutes.
COST: $0-$250 for installation++, $30-$200 per month for service, I.S.P. charges extra.
AVAILABILITY: Most major cities.
 
A.D.S.L.
MAXIMUM SPEED*: 1.5 Mbps-8 Mbps download, 640 Kbps upload.
"MOBY DICK" DOWNLOAD TIME+: Less than a second.
COST: $300 and up for installation, $60-$400 per month for service, I.S.P. charges extra.
AVAILABILITY: Limited mostly to trial areas in major cities, including New York.
 FASTER digital telephone lines are available from phone companies in some parts of the country. The services are called I.S.D.N., for integrated services digital network, and A.D.S.L., for asymmetric digital subscriber line.
I.S.D.N. is older and slower (up to about 128 kilobits per second) than A.D.S.L., but it is available in more areas of the country.
I.S.D.N., the first major attempt by the phone companies to move toward a digital system, allows people with the service to get both voice and data calls on the same line. That is why the system is called integrated.
A.D.S.L. is much faster, but it is available only to lucky people living in the right neighborhoods.
Phone companies are experimenting with many different variations of digital subscriber lines and tagging them with similar names. For this reason, some people use the term xDSL to refer to the entire batch; the "x" stands for any of the possible acronyms.
The prices for these services can be confusing because each phone company has persuaded the tariff board regulating it to allow different rates. As a result, the cost of I.S.D.N. can be reasonable in some parts of the country ($40 per month), but a luxury ($200 per month or more) in others.
A bigger problem is the lack of widespread expertise with the technology. You have to buy a different type of modem to use either A.D.S.L. or I.S.D.N. You might also need a new phone line or two.
People are usually happy with the fast connections -- once they get them working. In many cases, the local phone company will sell a package that includes installation, but the amount of support varies. And you will still need an I.S.P. in addition to your phone line. That makes the hardware and service pretty pricey, but some people think that it's worth it.
 
Cable Modem
MAXIMUM SPEED*: 1 Mbps-10 Mbps download, 768 Kbps upload.
"MOBY DICK" DOWNLOAD TIME+: Less than a second.
COST: $0-$300 for installation++, $40-$50 per month for service above television bill, includes I.S.P.
AVAILABILITY: Limited to major metropolitan areas.
 THE cable television companies realized long ago that their shielded wires, which are protected against electromagnetic interference, could carry much more information than the largely unshielded wires used by the telephone company. The downside is that many homes in the same neighborhood, known as the local loop, share the same cable wire, much like a telephone party line in the past. The first adopters of cable-modem Internet links speak lovingly of their high-speed connections, but it is unclear whether performance will suffer in the long term if everyone in the neighborhood starts downloading big files at the same time. No one knows how usage patterns and service commitments from the cable companies will evolve over time.
Right now, cable access to the Internet requires a special modem that is usually installed by a technician from the cable company. The technician will also check your system to insure that the proper security provisions are in place. That is important because the party-line nature of the technology makes it easier for neighbors to poke into your business.
Access to cable-modem service is limited by economics. The cable companies are rolling out new service in some areas, like Baltimore County and parts of New Jersey, as a test. Each company decides where to offer service based on how much money it thinks it can make in an area, so it helps to live in a place filled with other Internet addicts. Comcast, the cable company serving Baltimore County, is spending heavily to offer the service in that suburban area, while the company serving the city of Baltimore, TCI, has been taking its time.
 
T-1 Line
MAXIMUM SPEED*: 1.54 Mbps.
"MOBY DICK" DOWNLOAD TIME+: 0.105 seconds.
COST: $1,000 and up for installation,
$500-$1,000 or more per month for service, I.S.P. charges extra.
AVAILABILITY: Anywhere a dedicated line can be installed.
BUSINESSES with local networks often get on the Internet by leasing from the phone company high-speed lines that link directly to major I.S.P.'s. All the traffic from an office network is then shipped out on one of these high-speed lines. It is much more reliable and efficient than putting a modem on each desk.
These leased lines, which include T-1 lines, come in a variety of sizes, and the price often depends on the distance to the local switching center. It is hard to generalize about these prices, but lower-capacity lines often run between $300 and $1,000 a month just for the telephone company's fees; T-1's can cost $1,000 to $2,000 a month or more. There are additional costs from the I.S.P. that handles the job of shipping the data to the world.
The idea of sharing leased lines is becoming popular in apartment complexes. Sometimes a group of neighbors will form a cooperative to share the costs. In other cases, a real-estate developer will provide the service as an incentive for home-based businesses and other small companies that cannot afford their own technology staff. And many luxury apartment buildings are starting to offer such lines to attract tenants.
 
"Less-Traveled Roads to Cyberspace"
 
SATELLITE HYBRIDS
Some of the same companies that make the digital satellite dishes used for television reception are offering Internet service through the same system. The good news is that the bandwidth from the satellite to your house is high. The Web pages you request travel down a channel that can easily handle 500 kilobits per second or more.
There are two caveats: First, the channel is a party line shared by all users in the country and, second, the bandwidth out of your house is more conventional because it travels over phone lines using a modem. If your Internet usage involves lots of short requests for big blocks of data, then the imbalance is not a problem. But if you want to ship out as much data as you pull in, this service is not the best solution. Digital satellite systems like Hughes's DirecPC are available at most places in North America where you can hang an 18-inch satellite dish and point it south.
 
CELLULAR-BASED WIRELESS SERVICE
Many cellular phone companies are offering wireless Internet service, which is integrated with the system that provides cellular calls. The Internet service requires a special type of modem with an antenna. The quality of the service, of course, depends upon how well radio signals travel in your neighborhood. Tall buildings can be a problem, and signals will sometimes not penetrate deeply inside other buildings. The quality of the service can also depend on the distance between the modem's antenna and the nearest cellular system antenna.
The radio modem often works well with laptops. That kind of tetherless freedom is its biggest selling point.
The cellular companies are adding new data-carrying service throughout the country, but coverage varies widely and you should check with your local carrier.
 
OTHER RADIO-BASED SERVICE
A wide variety of radio modems are offered by companies that do not sell phone service over their networks. These are often used by businesses like package-delivery companies and cab companies to keep track of their fleets and dispatch them. Still, some offer service that can be used by the average consumer.
The structure of these networks varies. In some cases, there are thousands of small antennas attached to lampposts throughout the city. Metricom is one example of a company using this solution, but it does that in only three major metropolitan areas -- the San Francisco Bay area, Seattle and Washington. In other cases, companies use satellites to broadcast information to reach all of North America. That is popular with trucking companies. Other wireless companies use methods similar to those used by the cellular phone industry, with towers every mile or two.
 
BROADCAST SERVICE
One of the more intriguing ways to get information from the Web is just emerging. Some companies are sending information hidden in the corners of radio and television signals. Users with television cards in their PC's can program their computers to grab this information and store it locally.
These methods are great if you want access to sophisticated and popular information without waiting. It may take too long to download a film clip through a modem, but a news company could broadcast the same clip to people throughout the country simultaneously. The next time you turned to your machine, the entire clip could be stored on your hard disk.
But this approach has several limitations. You can get only what the broadcaster wants to send you, so only the major services with broad appeal, like CNN.com, will arrive this way. Also, you cannot send data through your card. Most people will want to maintain a standard dial-up service to handle E-mail and Web data that the broadcasters do not offer. Still, if you regularly check the weather, headlines, sports news or other popular services, broadcast service has plenty of appeal.
 
*Represents highest speed at which data can be transmitted in ideal conditions. Often lower in actual use.

HEADLINE: At the Movies

BYLINE: By James Sterngold 

DATELINE: HOLLYWOOD, July 2

 BODY:

From Hoops To Heartaches
It is often said in Hollywood that young directors and writers should start with a subject they know well, so why is Kevin Rodney Sullivan making his debut as a feature film director with a movie about a woman's search for love in seemingly the wrong place? 
 Mr. Sullivan (above), a onetime child actor who has written screenplays and directed television movies, has directed "How Stella Got Her Groove Back," a film based on Terry McMillan's popular novel and due in theaters on Aug. 14.
The movie, about a 40-year-old career woman and single mother who falls in love with a Jamaican man 20 years her junior, stars Angela Bassett as Stella and Whoopi Goldberg as her good friend Delilah. It is being distributed by 20th Century Fox.
Mr. Sullivan, who has been eager to direct a feature film, said the choice of this "woman's movie" was not as unusual as it might sound. First, the last movie based on one of Ms. McMillan's novels, "Waiting to Exhale," was also directed by a man, Forest Whitaker. More important, Mr. Sullivan said, "How Stella Got Her Groove Back" is about love, and that is something men can understand.
Still, Mr. Sullivan, 39, whose last television film was "The Soul of the Game," for HBO, about basketball, fathers and sons, said directing "Stella" had, in some respects, been an odd experience. There were plenty of times, he said, when he and Ron Bass, one of the screenwriters, felt a little lonely, since the film focuses on a woman, her best friend and her sisters.
"Ron and I were the only men in the room a lot of times," Mr. Sullivan said. "It made us friends real quickly."
Mr. Sullivan spent years as an actor, appearing in "Star Trek II: The Wrath of Khan," and in the television series "Happy Days."
He then wrote for the television series "Fame" and directed television movies.
"It would be a lie to say there was no difference making a movie like this," he said, referring to "Stella." "But I know what it is like to be into and to fall in love with the most inappropriate person. It didn't feel like I was going on an expedition into unknown territory."
Nevertheless, he said, he and Mr. Bass often had to defer to what the actresses said a woman would feel or not feel at a certain moment.
Mr. Sullivan, who is black, said he felt that the movie was mainly a love story, but that he was concerned it might be perceived as a "black film" and thus marketed to a limited audience.
He expressed some frustration that even though there are many ethnic movies, so-called black movies still have to struggle to attract a broader audience.
"The film business is a little slow in getting around to what the world is thinking," he said. "The world is not Anglo-Saxon. The paying audience wants diversity, and they appreciate good stories no matter what the cultural background.
"Films like this, I think, say the barrier should come down a little quicker."
 
Weird Is Cool
The bigger the entertainment conglomerates get, the more they rely on supposed formulas for making successful movies. And few formulas are embraced more than the one that says that when the weather turns hot, a blockbuster needs lots of special effects, a marketing tie-in with a taco and a strong dose of death and mayhem. Just like, say, "Dr. Dolittle." Huh?
Expectations were shattered when "Dr. Dolittle," an oddball children's film from 20th Century Fox starring the protean Eddie Murphy (above), battered its rivals and brought in an astounding $29 million on its opening last weekend. Jaws dropped around Hollywood because, put simply, the film, about a strange doctor who can talk to animals, does not fit the formulas.
Worse, critics were generally hostile. Richard Corliss, of Time, was typical in calling it a "slow, vacant farce." (Janet Maslin of The New York Times, however, called it "the sunniest family film so far this season.")
"It turns out kids don't read reviews," said Betty Thomas, the movie's outspoken director. "I guess that's good."
Ms. Thomas, 49, was gloating happily about the success of "Dr. Dolittle," but even she admitted that she had no idea the film would open so big.
"I was confused by the initial reaction," she said. "But it's funny. Doesn't anyone remember how to have fun anymore?"
But as improbable as the movie's immense success is the fact that a director like Ms. Thomas made it. Not surprisingly, she said she had initially scoffed at the project. The movie is based on the sweet children's stories of Hugh Lofting and follows by several decades a treacly, musical version of the movie that starred Rex Harrison.
"I don't like cute," said Ms. Thomas (left), which is not hard to believe, given that her last movie was "Private Parts," about the sex-obsessed shock jock Howard Stern. "I'm not a fan of cute. I'm into funny. My kind of funny."
She said her first reaction was swift.
"I said, 'Get serious,' " Ms. Thomas recalled. "Then they said Eddie Murphy was going to do it. That's when I said: 'That's interesting. That's unusual. That's not what people expect.' I like to come out of left field, so that appealed. Eddie was the reason."
With Mr. Murphy's edgy brand of comedy, the movie was given a slightly irreverent tone, with many anatomical jokes.
That contributed, Ms. Thomas said, to the real message behind the movie, which worked hard to be more than just a romp with a silly man who thinks he can talk to animals.
"I really think that the movie's about the artists in the world and how we have to accept them as they are," Ms. Thomas said. "Parents are too busy saying to their kids, you have to get good grades, you have to get into the right schools, you have to do everything right. I felt we had to get across that weird people are where it's at!"
 
Boom Town
Hollywood's stock in trade is illusion, of course, principally about itself.
But one of its greatest illusions is less well known: that the movie studios, as businesses, have never been that significant a presence in the Los Angeles economy.
That is, until now.
The Los Angeles Economic Development Corporation recently issued a report on the film industry in large part to counter some old myths and to underscore the remarkable arc of growth in this booming industry.
The movie studios were once dwarfed as employers by other industries, among them aerospace, particularly in cities like Burbank that had a reputation of being dominated by the studios.
But the recession of the early 1990's hit the aerospace companies hard, and the subsequent boom in all facets of entertainment has made the studios, for the first time, huge businesses with payrolls to match the impact of the movies on the public consciousness.
The report said that 96,000 jobs were added to the movie industry between 1990 and 1997. An additional 6,000 jobs have been added this year, making it, the report said, something of a slow one. The economic development corporation estimates that total movie-related employment in Los Angeles County is now 500,000.
Even those figures understate the impact of the industry on the local economy, however.
According to the report, the new jobs are not ordinary; they pay significantly more than other kinds of jobs, on average. By one estimate, they pay an average of $53,000 a year.
The Motion Picture Producers Association said earlier this year that the industry generated $25.6 billion in economic activity in Los Angeles County in 1996, the latest year for which there are figures, compared with $15 billion in 1992. And the report estimated that between now and 2001, demand for films would grow 7 percent a year.
But one of the more interesting pieces of information about the structure of the movie industry concerned who employs all these people. According to the report, the studios themselves actually account for a tiny fraction of the jobs.
Figures supplied by the United States Department of Commerce showed that a whopping 78 percent of jobs came from companies with one to four employees. An additional 8.6 percent of the jobs were at companies with five to nine employees. Less than 1 percent of the jobs came from employers with 1,000 or more employees.
In other words, the vast majority of the overall employment in the movie industry is not in the most visible entities, the studios, but in tiny companies.
And most of those provide specific services, including everything from costume design to computerized special effects, often on a per-job basis.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Treasury Prices Stage a Rally As the Dollar Gathers Strength

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices rallied in an abbreviated pre-holiday session yesterday, as the dollar gathered strength in currency trading and the Government's latest report on employment suggested the economy was slowing.
The price of the 30-year bond rose 14/32, to 107 19/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, fell to 5.60 percent, from 5.62 percent on Wednesday. Last Friday, the yield was 5.63 percent. The market closed at 2 P.M. yesterday and will be closed today in observance of Independence Day. 
 Gains came early as the dollar rallied against the yen on investors' skepticism over Japan's latest plan to fix its ailing banks. A strong dollar makes dollar-denominated investments like Treasury securities more attractive to foreign investors.
Bond prices were also bolstered by the June employment report, which showed that the pace of job creation slowed in the month. "This report provided some bullish support for the market because it revealed significantly lower wage pressures than the market was expecting," said Anthony Chan, managing director and chief economist for Banc One Investment Advisors Corporation in Columbus, Ohio.
Some analysts have said that if signals of an economic slowdown continue, the market may even begin to price in the possibility of a cut in interest rates by the Federal Reserve. But minutes of the May 19 meeting of Fed policy makers, which were released yesterday, show that the Fed remained concerned about a flare-up in inflation. The decision to hold rates steady at the May meeting came over the objections of two Fed policy makers.
The May meeting minutes "tell us that it will take many more economic reports to convince policy makers that current economic growth is no longer a threat to our long-term inflation outlook," Mr. Chan said. "Recent trends show this may very well occur in the near-term future."
Next week investors have little hard data to scrutinize, with the report on June producer prices on Friday being the most important report.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Dow Slips by 23.41 Points In 3d-Lightest Day of Year

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Stocks fell yesterday on the third-lightest trading day of the year after Government reports on jobs and manufacturing suggested that profits could suffer from a slowing economy.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 23.41 points, or three-tenths of a percent, to 9,025.26. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index dropped 2.14 points, or two-tenths of a percent, to 1,146.42. The Nasdaq composite index had its biggest loss since June 15, sliding 20.46 points, or 1.1 percent, to 1,894. 
 "With the Asian fallout, many companies are finding a fundamental deterioration in the demand for their goods and services," said Ned Riley, chief investment officer for the BankBoston Corporation, which manages $30 billion.
With many traders off early for the Independence Day holiday, volume on the New York Stock Exchange was just 509 million shares, well below the three-month daily average of 607 million.
The Government reported that orders placed with United States factories declined 1.6 percent in May and that unemployment rose to a three-month high of 4.5 percent. Analysts had expected a jobless rate of 4.3 percent, unchanged from May. Manufacturing employment took its biggest drop since March 1996, as Asia's economic crisis and the initial stages of the strike against General Motors took their toll.
The reports did not come as a complete surprise. Some investors were already expecting the economy to slow. In the computer industry, a slump has been dragging down profits for months.
Parametric Technology, which makes software that helps engineers design cars, planes and heavy equipment, was the biggest decliner after warning that earnings are being hurt by slack demand for its software in Asia. Shares of Parametric tumbled 8 3/4, to 16 1/16.
CompUSA, the nation's largest computer retailer, also warned of bad news on profits. CompUSA said it would report an unexpected loss in the fiscal fourth quarter because of falling personal computer prices and weak demand. Shares of CompUSA fell 11/16, to 16 7/8, bringing their decline for 1998 to 46 percent.
Sun Microsystems and I.B.M. declined after John B. Jones Jr., an analyst for Salomon Smith Barney, lowered earnings estimates for the companies -- both of which have extensive operations in Asia. I.B.M. fell 1 9/16, to 115 3/16, and Sun dropped 2 7/16, to 42 1/2.
Mr. Jones wrote to clients that Asia's economic woes were intensifying, which is likely to slow growth in Japan. He added that he expected the yen to weaken relative to the dollar.
On the positive side, Netscape Communications surged for a second day on speculation that the Internet browser pioneer might attract an investment from a large media company. Netscape rose 5 5/8, to 4 15/16, up 55 percent for the holiday-shortened week.
Over all, analysts' expectations for growth in second-quarter operating earnings for the S.& P. 500 dropped to 2.3 percent this week from 3.6 percent last week, according to the First Call Corporation, which tracks company earnings.
More than half the decline came from analysts who reduced their estimates because of the G.M. strike, said Charles Hill, director of research at First Call. The rest of the drop reflects the effects of the economic downturn in Asia, he said.

HEADLINE: Orders to Factories Fell by 1.6% in May

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 2

 BODY:
Orders placed with United States factories declined in May from the previous month, suggesting that manufacturing is losing speed.
Factory orders fell 1.6 percent, to a seasonally adjusted $333 billion after rising a revised seven-tenths of 1 percent in April, to $338.6 billion, previously reported as a 1.2 percent gain, the Commerce Department reported today. Slower demand for electrical equipment and aircraft and parts drove May's decline. 
 In addition, factory orders outside the volatile category of aircraft and other transportation equipment fell 1.5 percent in May after declining three-tenths of 1 percent the previous month. Excluding the military industry, factory orders fell 1.7 percent in May compared with a gain in April of five-tenths of 1 percent.
Factory inventories increased one-tenth of 1 percent in May after rising four-tenths of 1 percent in April. And shipments, a gauge of current demand, fell four-tenths of a percent in May after falling 1.1 percent in April. That suggests that demand is weak.

HEADLINE: Restore Hamilton To His Pedestal

BYLINE: By Michael Lind; Michael Lind, Washington editor of Harper's Magazine, is the editor of "Hamilton's Republic."

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
If you join the crowd on the Mall this Fourth of July, you'll see majestic and luminous monuments to George Washington, Abraham Lincoln and Thomas Jefferson, and even a new memorial to Franklin Roosevelt. But something is missing. There is no Hamilton memorial. This omission is not only unjust, but peculiar. For Alexander Hamilton, as much as any other American, deserves credit for the United States' pre-eminent position among nations.
His imprint on our society is deep and wide, and has never been more obvious than it is today. He favored a more centralized union and wrote two-thirds of the Federalist Papers defending the Constitution. As the first Secretary of the Treasury, Hamilton established the Bank of the United States, precursor of the Federal Reserve, and he spelled out the industrial policy that transformed America into an economic power of unparalleled strength. 
 Hamilton was not only the most brilliant of the Founders, but also the most flamboyant. An orphan raised in the West Indies, he was the only self-made man in a galaxy of patricians. His adulterous affair with Maria Reynolds produced the first great sex scandal in American politics. And his life was cut short, at the age of 49, when he was killed in a duel with Aaron Burr on July 11, 1804.
It is fashionable to invoke Jefferson as the philosopher of American democracy. But his ideal America was based on states' rights, agrarian capitalism and isolationism. Hamilton, on the other hand, envisioned the nation that we have become, a centralized industrial superpower with civil rights enforced by the Federal Government.
Jefferson owned hundreds of slaves and argued that blacks were naturally inferior and should not be emancipated unless they were sent to Africa. Hamilton, by contrast, believed that black Americans deserved citizenship and should be armed as soldiers during the Revolutionary War.
"The contempt we have been taught to entertain for the blacks makes us fancy many things that are founded neither in reason nor experience," he wrote. "The dictates of humanity and true policy equally interest me in favor of this unfortunate class of men." In the first years of the Republic, Hamilton helped found the Society for Promoting the Manumission of Slaves. His ideals, not Jefferson's, were realized when slavery and then segregation were smashed by Federal power.
The idolization of Jefferson and the downgrading of Hamilton is a recent phenomenon. For most of our history their status was reversed, not only in the eyes of Northerners but also in those of enlightened Southern nationalists like John Marshall and Henry Clay. "For many decades after the Civil War," Hamilton's biographer, Forrest McDonald, writes, "his niche in the pantheon of American demigods was beneath only Washington's, if indeed it was not at Washington's right hand."
In "The Promise of American Life," published in 1909, the Progressive thinker Herbert Croly praised Hamilton's view that "the central government is to be used not merely to maintain the Constitution, but to promote the national interest and to consolidate the national organization" while he debunked the misguided Jeffersonian theory that "there should be as little government as possible."
The Hamiltonian tradition of democratic nationalism was carried on, in different ways, by Progressive Republicans and by New Dealers who acted as Hamiltonians even as they appeased Southern Democrats by extolling Jefferson.
In the past quarter century, however, the Hamiltonian ideal of a strong, prosperous and integrated American nation-state has come under attack from all sides. The multicultural left rejects the idea of an integrated American nation, while the fundamentalist right vilifies the Federal Government as an instrument of tyranny, if not a tool of Satan.
Whereas Hamilton wanted industry and finance to serve the national interest, today many executives and investors view the nation-state as an obsolete hindrance to their personal profit in the "global market." Hamilton envisioned a partnership of government and business. Today, the left likes government and hates business, while the right likes business and hates government.
If either side should prevail, America will come to resemble a continental chaos of squabbling ethnic groups with an incompetent military, a feeble government and an economy that enriches only a tiny oligarchy.
To avert that fate we must renew the tradition founded by Alexander Hamilton. Unfortunately, that tradition is not yet symbolized by a Hamilton memorial on the Mall in Washington. Until one is built, we will have to make do with the existing monuments to the Hamiltonian vision: West Point and the Pentagon, the Federal Reserve, the interstate highway and air travel systems, Detroit and the Silicon Valley.
And, not least, the Federal courthouses that attest to the fact that -- no matter what the case is elsewhere -- in our democracy individual rights and national authority are not enemies, but allies.

HEADLINE: New York Officials to Impose Sanctions on Swiss Banks Sept. 1

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
Officials of the City and State of New York said yesterday that they would begin imposing sanctions on Swiss banks on Sept. 1, hoping that the two-month "cooling off period" would persuade Swiss bank officials and lawyers for Holocaust survivors and heirs to reach a settlement.
Barring Swiss banks from bidding on overnight deposits, which average more than $2 billion just for the city, would be the first step, followed in stages by barring other business, canceling existing contracts and selling all stocks in Swiss companies. 
 The State Department said sanctions, last used to bring pressure to end apartheid in South Africa, were "unjustified, unwarranted and counterproductive" to reaching a quick settlement of the claims of Holocaust survivors, whose average age is 81.
Sanctions could undermine New York's position as the financial capital of the global economy by raising doubts about how open American financial markets are, Under Secretary of State Stuart E. Eizenstat said in an interview. He also said he had urged the Swiss Government not to overreact to the sanctions and retaliate with actions that could make a settlement more difficult to achieve.
Two Swiss banks, UBS and Credit Suisse, offered $600 million last month to settle claims.
Mel Weiss, one of the lawyers for the survivors, heirs and charities representing heirless assets, proposed settling the case for $1.5 billion, provided the Swiss Government and the Swiss National Bank joined in a "global settlement."
The talks collapsed after Mr. Weiss made his proposal last month. The sanctions were announced by the City Comptroller, Alan G. Hevesi, and the State Comptroller, H. Carl McCall, a day after a meeting in which they said that the Swiss Consul General in New York, Jacques Reverdin, told a panel of state and local government finance officials that the Swiss Government would never contribute to a restitution fund.
Mr. Hevesi said that Mr. Reverdin's statements revealed a change from the posture the Swiss Government had taken in private talks, which he said was to signal that it would ease a "global settlement" to resolve all claims. These, he said, would include those against the Swiss Government and its central bank.
Mr. Hevesi said the Swiss Government's position amounted to "denying moral responsibility" for buying stolen assets, including gold removed from the teeth of Nazi death-camp victims.
"No punishment is being asked, no penalty," Mr. Hevesi said. "It is restitution we seek."
Mr. Hevesi pointed to a May 25 report by a panel created by the Swiss Government, known as the Bergier Commission, which concluded that by 1942 Swiss Government officials knew that the gold the Nazis sold to them was looted from Jews, a practice that was so obvious that it could be discerned by careful readers of Swiss newspapers. He said the report should have spurred the Swiss Government to "prepare its people" to support a settlement.
Mr. Reverdin said that the Swiss Government had been unwavering in its position that all claims concerning assets that the Nazis stole from Jews and then sold to the Swiss National Bank were resolved by a 1946 agreement reached in Washington and signed by the World War II Allies.
"This is a settled matter and there is no reason to reopen it," Mr. Reverdin said.
Mr. Eizenstat said the Swiss Government had never changed its position that it would support any settlement that the two banks might reach, but that it was not a party to the talks and was not obligated to pay.
Swiss banks were paid about $31 million in investment fees by the city in the last year, more than 10 percent of the $285 million that the city spent on investment management, advice and broker commissions, Steve Newman, the First Deputy City Comptroller, estimated.
Mr. McCall's office could not immediately supply comparable figures.
If all 800 state and local government finance officers were to terminate short-term investment dealings with Swiss banks, the annual fees would quickly total more than the $900 million difference between the banks' offer and Mr. Weiss's proposal.
The sanctions plan calls for the city and state to begin sanctions on Sept. 1 by barring overnight investments with Swiss banks, new letters of credit agreements and taking part in underwriting new state and city debt.
On Nov. 15, if no settlement is reached, Mr. Hevesi and Mr. McCall will recommend excluding Swiss companies like Scudder Kemper Investments and SBC Warburg Dillon Read & Company from searches for new pension fund investment managers and barring existing managers from doing business through Swiss companies.
On Jan. 1 the two officials would recommend canceling existing investment management contracts, like a CS First Boston contract to manage $740 million for the city pension fund. They would also ask the Legislature and City Council to pass laws barring Swiss companies from selling goods and services to the state and city.
Finally, on July 1, 1999, they would seek to have the $106 billion state pension fund and the $82 billion city pension fund begin divesting their holdings in Swiss companies. The city owns $735 million in stock in Swiss companies, including $136.7 million in the Swiss banks, Mr. Hevesi said.

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
Star System Is Declining In the N.B.A.

BYLINE: By HARVEY ARATON 

 BODY:
THE New Jersey philanthropist who envisions the Nets becoming part of Newark's downtown revival apparently did his homework in basketball economics. Ray Chambers, who helped broker the deal that will very likely transfer the team to two real estate developers, called around the sport's power circles and raised the question that most owners haven't satisfactorily answered themselves.
Of at least two sources, Chambers asked why Finn Wentworth and Stanley Gale of Florham Park, N.J., should plunk down $150 million for control of the Nets and then face contract negotiations with Keith Van Horn, Jayson Williams and Kerry Kittles that would ultimately cost them more than the franchise is worth. He was told that under the present system, the Nets will wind up paying Van Horn a $100 million-plus jackpot that would probably preclude them from keeping the other two players. 
 Same story as in Minnesota, where ownership can afford Stephon Marbury or Tom Gugliotta or possibly neither after shelling out $126 million at boardroom gunpoint last summer for Kevin Garnett. This entertaining young team is almost certain to die in its infancy as a result.
"The days of having three stars are gone," one well-connected agent said recently. "It's two stars and then managing well enough to surround them with the right role players."
This works out if those stars are Michael Jordan and Scottie Pippen, John Stockton and Karl Malone. Most of the time, it looks more like Chris Webber and Juwan Howard, teams that function more like insipid monarchs.
Michael Jordan notwithstanding, the concept of the National Basketball Association as a quality team sport is the reason to root for David Stern and the owners in the latest round of labor chess. Hope for them to somehow lower the ceiling on these $20 million-a-year stars, and not because the commissioner has virtue on his side, but because the odds of building and maintaining a cohesive team of diverse skill have become too high.
The bottom line that the players had better read is that the product not only costs too much for the paying fan, it also too often stinks.
The old-school union thinking, espoused long ago by the late Larry Fleisher, is that only the superstars, with their rising salaries, can set the table for everyone else. Not in this market, though. Now a couple of players, often leveraging only their potential, gorge themselves and leave behind only minimum-salary scraps and bones. At last count, there were 150 players making the minimum. It is almost comical when the union claims it is fighting for basketball's "middle class" at the same time it refuses to discuss a system that would restore a modicum of sanity to the top-tier salary.
Patrick Ewing is the association's president, and that helps explain it. For 10 years, Ewing thought collective bargaining meant him, David Falk and someone from the Knicks. Three summers ago, Falk the agent informed Ewing and Jordan that the union was about to cut a deal that would imperil the superstar windfall. Ewing became an instant activist, and he helped save a system that produced a cool $66 million for him last summer.
When Ewing demonstrates sympathy for less fortunate teammates, I will take him more seriously as the representative of all players. Meanwhile, reporters seeking a few complimentary parting words on Charles Oakley last week were hung up on. I ran into Ewing at a dinner in Washington last Friday, asked about Oakley and was promptly shooed away. Six days after the trade, Ewing finally addressed the subject, but only at his own news conference to unveil a painting. What a piece of work.
Ewing complained that no other industry limits salaries, which is news to postal workers, but there is nothing to prevent him and Jordan from selling themselves as prime-time programming to CBS, Disney or Fox. If the $20 million-a-year basketball star makes dollars and sense, you can bet Uncle Rupert or some other television network will pay it.
Basketball has always been a star and ego-driven sport, but the N.B.A. marketeers went too far in exploiting this theme while expanding and diluting their league, and now the system has degenerated too much for the players to stop believing in the parables spun in their behalf. They don't see Mark McGwire coming or Jordan going. They don't recognize the cyclical nature of entertainment and sports. Reebok didn't fire Shaquille O'Neal this week because he doesn't make free throws. People are tiring of the rap and the hype.
Two stars in basketball is no better a review than it is in the movies.

HEADLINE: Notes Show Fed Is Still Worried About Inflation

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 2

 BODY:
Despite signs that the economy might be slowing, the Federal Reserve remained concerned at its May meeting about a potential outbreak of inflation. Two of the 12 members on the Fed's policy-making committee voted against the panel's decision then to hold interest rates steady.
Minutes of the May 19 meeting, released today, suggested that there was considerable unease within the policy-making group, the Federal Open Market Committee, about waiting any longer for an economic slowdown that always seemed to be just around the corner but never quite materialized. For some members, the minutes said, the decision not to raise rates "was a close call." 
 Although the panel voted to hold the Federal funds target rate, the primary short-term rate controlled by the Fed, steady at 5.5 percent, it decided then to maintain its formal policy "bias" toward a tighter monetary policy, the minutes said, a signal that it still leans toward raising rates in the absence of a clear slowdown.
The two members who bucked Alan Greenspan, the chairman, and voted for an immediate interest rate increase were Jerry L. Jordan, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland, and William Poole, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis, who was attending only his second meeting of the committee.
Mr. Jordan had also voted to raise rates at the Fed's March 31 meeting, where he was the lone dissenter. One of the features of Mr. Greenspan's tenure as Fed chairman has been to encourage consensus on interest-rate decisions, and it has been more than four years since as many as two members broke with the majority on a vote. It is particularly unusual that a relatively new member like Mr. Poole, who took office on March 23, would dissent.
On Wednesday, the Fed again decided to keep interest rates on hold after a two-day meeting. The decision came in the wake of further evidence that Asia's financial crisis is helping to slow growth to noninflationary levels. Those reports were reinforced today by the news that the unemployment rate edged up in June to 4.5 percent from 4.3 percent the previous month.
Minutes of this week's meeting will be released on Aug. 20, two days after the Fed's next policy-setting session.
The minutes of the May 19 meeting provided only a dry and sketchy account of the day's debate.
But they gave a summary of the reasoning of Mr. Poole and Mr. Jordan in dissenting from the decision to keep policy on hold. Both men are monetarists who believe that clues to the likelihood of a resurgence of inflation can be discerned in the growth of the money supply. Although rapid money supply growth was discredited as a predictor of inflation during the mid-1980's because of sweeping changes to the nation's financial structure, it has lately shown signs of becoming a reliable early warning signal.
"Mr. Poole dissented because he believed that the sustained increase in money growth in recent quarters and associated accommodative conditions in the credit markets pointed to rising inflation," the minutes said.
Mr. Jordan, the minutes said, was concerned that the rapid growth in the money supply was fueling speculative excesses. "In his view, these high growth rates were fueling unsustainably rapid increases of real estate and other asset prices, and reports of 'too much cash chasing too few deals' were becoming more frequent," the minutes said. Ultimately, Mr, Jordan said, the Fed faced "a choice between smaller increases in interest rates sooner versus larger increases later."
The members of the committee who voted to keep rates unchanged cited a variety of reasons for not moving, according to the minutes.
They said they believed that companies would want to run down the large inventories of supplies and goods built up in the first quarter, resulting in reduced demand. And they expressed concern that Asia's economy continued to deteriorate, likely leading to further downturns in demand for American goods.
"Despite the failure of domestic demand to moderate in line with their earlier expectations, the members were persuaded that appreciable slowing in the growth of economic activity was a likely prospect over the course of coming quarters even though its exact timing and extent was unknown," the minutes said.
Reinforcing the decision on rates, the minutes said, was concern that any increase could have "outsized effects" on Asian financial markets, potentially leading to "substantial adverse repercussions on U.S. financial markets and, over time, on the U.S. economy," the minutes said.
Panel members added, however, "that market considerations could not be allowed to jeopardize the effective conduct of a U.S. monetary policy aimed at an optimal performance of the U.S. economy," the minutes said. "Indeed, such a performance would best serve the interests of troubled financial markets and economies abroad."

HEADLINE: Japan Is Still Key To China's Growth

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "China's Dynamism, Japan's Inertia" (Op-Ed, June 26): The United States is understandably irritated with Japan's slow economic reforms. But it is one thing to criticize Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto for inept leadership and another to belittle Japan, as Stephen S. Roach does. 
 The illusion that China is the geopolitical and economic leader of Asia has led the United States into China's diplomatic blackmail at the expense of relations with Japan. Before President Clinton's visit, China played the yuan card to make Wall Street jittery and manipulated world opinion into thinking China, not the United States, is calling the shots in economic affairs.
China, whose economy cannot grow much without Japanese capital and technology, is begging Japan to bail out its corrupt state-owned businesses and banks. We must ask, Will China's Communist system ever produce world-class manufacturing and trading companies like Sony, Honda and Fuji?

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate;
Midtown Developer Mixes Work With Pleasure

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
Betting that renters will venture into a nontraditional residential area for large loft apartments, the owners of 545 West 34th Street are transforming the 88-year-old warehouse into a rental loft building in which tenants can both live and work.
The six-story, red-brick warehouse, being renamed Infinity Court, will have 25 lofts averaging 2,500 square feet each that can be combined to create even larger units. They will offer open layouts that can be designed to have one to four bedrooms, and some will have private elevators, skylights or views of the Hudson River. There will also be 20,000 square feet of retail space on the ground and basement levels of the building, between 10th and 11th Avenues. 
 The project is being developed by the Moinian Group of Manhattan at an estimated cost of $8 million to $10 million. The company bought the vacant midblock building, which extends from 34th Street to 35th Street and was once the site of the Hobb Electrical Supply Company, in 1997. Moinian did so because while the building sits across from the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center in a mostly commercial and industrial neighborhood, the zoning permits its conversion to residential use and allows tenants "to have their home and office under one roof," said Joseph Moinian, a principal.
Another factor is that this "is one of the few areas left in Manhattan that is not saturated," Mr. Moinian said. And with a strong economy and tight housing market it is also a good time to develop, he said, adding that "the entire West Side from 23d to 42d could be the next area of action."
Right now, however, the development activity is occurring along the perimeter of the nearby Clinton neighborhood, extending from 42d Street east from the Hudson River, up Eighth Avenue to 59th Street. There, thanks to zoning incentives to encourage residential construction, six projects that together total about 3,000 residences have been started in the last two years, according to data from Community Board 4, which monitors growth in the area. There is also development activity in the 20's where old manufacturing buildings are being converted into loft apartments.
"Those areas have a more residential feel to them than the West 30's, which is close to the Lincoln Tunnel and the old Amtrak rail lines, and is a bit like a island," said William H. Kelley, the assistant district manager of Community Board 4. "But if the market stays hot, it is possible to see more development there."
Andrew S. Heiberger, president of Citi Habitats, a rental brokerage in Manhattan and the leasing agent for Infinity Court, said the project was "not all that pioneering" because there are seven existing residential buildings within four blocks, with a total of 1,500 rentals. "And by tapping into the current tight rental market with a product not readily available, large live-work lofts at a good price, we feel the location will attract more tenants," he said, noting that monthly rents for the units, which feature 10.5- to 13-foot-high ceilings, exposed brick walls, marble baths and high-tech wiring, will be $4,000 to $6,000, or $28 to $30 for each square foot on average.
Those prices compare with $40 to $45 a square foot on average for lofts in more traditional neighborhoods like Chelsea, SoHo or TriBeCa, Mr. Heiberger said.
The project is expected to attract young professionals who will share an apartment and more importantly "people with their own businesses who want this kind of hybrid space in which they can live and work," said Robert A. Scaglion, director of marketing at Citi Habitats. In the two weeks since leasing began, leases have been signed for three apartments and are pending on five others, he said.
Steven J. Borne, a 35-year-old film producer and sound designer, is hoping to rent a fifth-floor loft at Infinity Court, which would end a three-month search for what he called "a nice live-work apartment." He said he was "disheartened at the ludicrous rents" asked for apartments that had less space than the two-bedroom apartment on the Upper West Side he wants to leave.
"This space works for me, and it is a reasonable price," Mr. Borne said of the Infinity Court apartment. "The neighborhood is a little removed, but to me space is more important than location."
The 34th Street site is not the only one at which the Moinian Group is converting an older building to live-work apartments. At 100 John Street downtown, the company has built 221 mostly studio and one-bedroom units, and 45 of the studios have home offices, Mr. Moinian said, noting that 10 of them have been leased since renting began two weeks ago.
Another downtown developer finding success with live-work apartments is Time Equities Inc. In the last two years, the company has converted, or has begun to convert, five small buildings into a total of 76 live-work rental lofts. Rents for the units, which range in size from 750 to 2,100 square feet, are $1,900 to $5,950 a month.
Infinity Court, designed by Gene Kaufman Architects of Manhattan, will have a wrought-iron gated entrance on 34th Street that will open onto a landscaped cobblestone courtyard, created from a former loading area. There will also be a staffed video security system in the building, whose red-brick exterior has been cleaned and repointed as part of the conversion. Planned amenities include a rooftop terrace, Mr. Moinian said. The first tenants are expected to move in on Aug. 1.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Live-work lofts are being constructed at 545 West 34th Street. (Dith Pran/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Strong Challenge to Kohl Is Strained by Infighting

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, July 2

 BODY:
Gerhard Schroder, the Social Democratic challenger to Chancellor Helmut Kohl in Germany's national elections in September, has gone out of his way to polish his image as a leader who would be good for business.
But when Mr. Schroder personally introduced members of his potential future cabinet on Monday in Berlin, one person was conspicuously absent: the man who would be his economics minister. 
 And that was no accident. Jolz Stollmann, a 43-year-old self-made millionaire who started and recently sold his own computer-networking company, had just left for vacation. Before leaving, Mr. Stollmann had announced that he would not play a role in the election campaign or be a spokesman for the Social Democrats' economic program.
"I am not a politician and I'm not participating in the election campaign," Mr. Stollmann said in an interview late last week. "There are others who are more capable."
Less than three months before the vote, Germany's Social Democrats have a strong chance of beating Mr. Kohl and his center-right Christian Democrats for the first time in 16 years.
But the strains between the party's left-leaning traditionalists and Mr. Schroder's comparatively pro-business wing are also becoming more apparent. Germany's powerful union leaders who hold sway in the party have been infuriated by Mr. Stollmann's nomination, accusing him of being hostile to workers. Rank-and-file party members, meanwhile, have been rattled by the elevation of an outsider who plainly comes from a different world.
Mr. Schroder has borrowed unabashedly from the election strategies of Prime Minister Tony Blair and President Clinton, packaging himself as a pro-business Social Democrat who could do more than his conservative rivals to stimulate the German economy and reduce sky-high unemployment.
Naming Mr. Stollmann, a political outsider who brought an aura of Silicon Valley-style success, has been his most visible gesture toward business. A graduate of Harvard Business School who worked for a time at the Boston Consulting Group, Mr. Stollmann started his own company at the age of 29. Last year, the company, Compunet A.G., which provides computer-networking services, had sales of about $1 billion and was recently sold to the General Electric Company of the United States.
Until recently, he had never held any political office and does not belong to a political party. The closest he came to politics was three years ago, when he ran a prominent newspaper campaign to rebut critics who said Germany had become too expensive, lazy and rigid for business.
"A land without a future? Rubbish!" said one ad in bold block letters. "Sleeping government workers? Nonsense!"
Aside from those opinions, Mr. Stollmann is a pragmatist. "The days of ideological battles between left and right are over," he said. "The issue is having the political leadership and the political process that can lead to renewal. I can bring a certain leadership to bring together some of the best minds in the country."
But Mr. Stollmann immediately touched off hostility within the party. By pointedly distancing himself from Social Democratic policies, he aroused suspicions of disloyalty.
As if that were not enough, Mr. Stollmann has been openly skeptical about one of the Social Democrats' core ideas: reducing joblessness through a broad "Alliance for Work" between government, labor and industry. Party officials say political leaders might offer to loosen regulations, and unions would be willing to restrain wage increases in return for more ambitious corporate hiring.
"We do need what Americans might call 'a change coalition,' " Mr. Stollmann said. "But that kind of change coalition cannot decide how many new jobs are going to be created. We are a market economy after all."
German union leaders were outraged by what they took to be Mr. Stollmann's dismissive attitude.
"Mr. Stollmann obviously has a lot to learn, when he discredits the Alliance for Work as meaningless," said Franz-Josef Mollenberg, chairman of the union of Germany's food workers. "We hope he learns quickly. If not, he is the wrong man for the job."
Mr. Schroder has not yet betrayed any concern. "I expressly wanted him to keep his own mind, because I rely on his independence," he said at a party gathering last Sunday.
Mr. Stollmann acknowledged that he has already run afoul of traditionalists. "The people who don't like these ideas are playing the old-fashioned political game," he said. "They are trying to spread distrust between me and the Social Democratic Party members, and I need their trust."

HEADLINE: World Bank, A Bit Nervous, Resumes Aid To Indonesia

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 2

 BODY:
The World Bank resumed aid to Indonesia today for the first time since President Suharto was forced from office. It approved a $1 billion loan and predicted that major industrial nations would soon announce another $6 billion in aid.
The $1 billion loan was part of a $4.5 billion contribution from the World Bank that was promised earlier this year, before the rioting and political upheaval that brought down Mr. Suharto after 32 years in office. 
 But the loan comes at a time when international aid officials describe the country as standing on the edge of an economic abyss: its economy is shrinking faster than anyone expected, its unemployment rate is soaring and its currency is unable to recover from a steep fall in value.
As a result, today's loan is enormously risky, and World Bank officials worry that they may not be able to control how it is spent. They are making only $600 million available immediately. The rest will come later this year, if Indonesia meets a number of the economic commitments it has made since Mr. Suharto's departure.
"We see this loan as a critical component in the overall package of assistance provided by the international community," James Wolfensohn, the World Bank's president, said in a statement. "Its objective is to rebuild confidence and help Indonesia make a new start."
The $1 billion is for reform of the financial and banking systems, and to pay for imports of food and other commodities. Rampant inflation, expected to reach 80 percent this year, has set off much of the social unrest in Indonesia, including attacks on the ethnic Chinese minority, which dominates much of the economy.
A week ago the International Monetary Fund announced it had reached a new accord with Indonesia -- its fourth since October -- that would enable the fund to resume its aid this month, too. Its disbursements were halted in May, as the rioting worsened.
The new accord allows for more social spending, and permits Indonesia to run a significant budget deficit, something the earlier agreements prohibited.
The I.M.F. said last week that the total aid package to Indonesia, about $43 billion, would not be sufficient. It appealed to other countries to come up with another $6 billion to help Indonesia subsidize critical commodities, including food and fuel.
"We are very confident that that package will come," Dennis de Tray, the bank's director for Indonesia, said today. He added that the additional aid would take "weeks, but not many," to put together.
"This is not a time to hold back and wait and see," Mr. de Tray said.
American officials say the United States, which has the largest vote in the World Bank, supported today's decision. It was the first official vote of confidence in the new Government of President B. J. Habibie, a longtime friend of Mr. Suharto's.
But Americans who have dealt with Mr. Habibie and his new Cabinet have come away with mixed impressions.
Several encounters with the President have apparently gone in surprising directions, with Mr. Habibie expounding on unusual economic theories or regaling visitors with accounts of his efforts to build a national airplane for Indonesia, a program that the fund halted.
On the other hand the Finance Minister, Ginandjar Kartasmita, is gaining increasing respect in Washington. He appears serious about wide-ranging economic reforms, officials say, and he is coming to Washington next week to seek more aid.
