HEADLINE: G.M. Dealers See Dwindling Supply of Hot Models

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: SYLVANIA, Ohio, July 2

 BODY:
Ask David White Jr., a Chevrolet dealer here, how long he can last during the current strikes against without running out of vehicles, and his initial response is full of confidence: two months, because he has about 220 new cars and trucks in stock and typically sells 110 a month.
But ask about supplies of specific models, and the confidence fades to dismay. There are lots of slow-selling Lumina and Prism sedans, plenty of Astro full-size vans and enough tiny Metro economy cars for at least six months of sales. By contrast, he expects to sell the last of his high-profit Tahoe and Suburban sport utility vehicles and S-10 pickups this weekend, with no prospect of further deliveries until early August even if the strikes end quickly. 
 "You look at your hot products, you're at zero," Mr. White said, holding out the thumb and forefinger of each hand to form little zeros for emphasis.
A shortage of popular models at dealerships now lies at the heart of the troubles facing G.M., the world's largest auto maker. Showdowns with the United Automobile Workers are always costly for auto makers, but G.M. came into the current strikes with extremely low inventories of its most profitable vehicles, and the strikes are obviously making it worse.
So as customers head to showrooms this weekend for the traditionally busy Fourth of July auto sales, they are likely to find the most popular G.M. models in short supply, with few combinations of color and options available. Discounts are evaporating, pushing up the prices that car buyers actually pay. And dealers for Ford, Chrysler and foreign auto makers are trying to woo G.M. customers by offering wider selections, but seldom at lower prices. Even used-car prices are climbing, as dealers flock to auctions, desperate to buy late-model cars to keep their lots from looking empty.
Because of a price war this spring, G.M. had been offering $500 to $1,000 discount coupons on even its most popular models but allowed these to expire on Tuesday night. Chrysler officials have already indicated that their similar coupons will expire on Monday, and Ford is likely to terminate its coupon program on Tuesday. Auction prices for used 1996, 1997 and 1998 cars have already risen by hundreds of dollars, with the few used 1998 models on the market now selling for close to the original sticker price even though they have a few thousand miles on them.
The strikes at two G.M. auto parts factories in Flint, Mich., have forced G.M. to close 26 of its 29 North American assembly plants, so customers who want to order a precise combination of paint color and options from the factory face months of delay -- or must compromise and pick from dealers' dwindling selections.
"What you see is what you get," said Jim Yark, an Oldsmobile dealer in nearby Toledo, as he surveyed the 78 new cars and light trucks on his lot -- less than a third of his usual supply, and only enough for another three weeks of sales, he calculated.
Many G.M. dealers also have franchises for other auto makers, and are using their Ford, Dodge and other dealerships to woo customers unable to find the right G.M. vehicle. The Burdick Companies, a chain of 18 dealerships in central New York, including a Buick dealership, has culled from state auto registration records a list of all nearby owners of G.M. full-size sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks and plans to mail them brochures offering big Dodge Durango sport utility vehicles and Dodge Ram pickup trucks instead.
"Our strategy is to hit at the weakness," said Louis Bregou, the group's director of operations, while acknowledging that the aggressive strategy could produce a shortage later this summer of the popular Dodge light trucks. "We could be out of Durangos and Ram trucks by Labor Day."
The strikes come at a time of record sales for G.M., which announced June results by model today: sales of each of its full-size sport utility vehicle models were the highest ever in June, and its overall light-truck sales have set industry records for the last four consecutive months. The record sales have helped G.M. clear out 1998 models before the 1999 models are introduced, which traditionally happens in late September, but G.M. has been too successful for its own good. Now the auto maker finds itself running out of popular models even as the economy is booming, unemployment is low and people are buying lots of light trucks.
With experience gained from more than a dozen other G.M. strikes over the last five years, Wall Street analysts thought they could estimate with confidence the company's losses from work stoppages and put the damage to G.M.'s after-tax earnings in the second quarter at up to $1 billion. But G.M. said on Tuesday that its actual losses were $1.18 billion, nearly 20 percent higher than Wall Street's highest estimates, mainly because sales of light trucks had dropped especially fast.
Ronald L. Zarrella, G.M.'s group vice president for marketing, tried to reassure Wall Street and vehicle shoppers on Wednesday that G.M. dealers still had ample inventories. G.M. has canceled low-profit sales to car rental companies and other fleets, and its dealerships' remaining inventories of cars and light trucks are equal to 70 days of retail sales, he said.
But such figures mask wide differences in the availability of particular models, as well as big gaps among dealerships. Small cars, on which G.M. loses money, are still plentiful, but full-size sport utility vehicles, on which G.M. makes up to $10,000 apiece, are very scarce. Also, some dealerships that started the summer with unusually large inventories are less worried than dealerships that tried to match up orders and sales more closely and now find themselves with little to sell.
In normal times, dealers sell scarce models to one another at close to invoice prices. But this informal system has broken down now, with dealers nationwide saying in interviews this week that they are hoarding their remaining vehicles and generally selling only to retail customers who pay close to the full sticker price.
The uneven distribution of vehicles poses a problem for G.M. because customer loyalty to dealerships has been its greatest strength. More than any other domestic or foreign auto maker, G.M. relies on sales to previous owners of G.M. vehicles, a legacy of the days in the 1960's and 70's when G.M. controlled half the market. Very few owners of foreign cars, or even owners of other domestic brands, tend to switch to G.M., which is one reason why its market share has been slowly diminishing for a quarter of a century. But now some of those loyal G.M. customers are coming into dealerships that offer an increasingly limited selection.
Drive up and down Central Avenue in nearby Toledo, the main street for auto dealerships, and at first glance nothing is wrong. But on closer inspection, some of the dealerships are suffering. Yark Oldsmobile has even resorted to one of the oldest tricks in the dealer business: parking its remaining cars and trucks with wider spaces between them, so as to reduce the amount of empty asphalt visible from the road.
Mr. Yark also canceled virtually all of his advertising on Wednesday after realizing that his inventory had been depleted by a burst of sales early this week as G.M.'s incentives were expiring. "We realized we didn't have any cars," he said, surveying the nearly empty storage lot behind his showroom.
G.M. is struggling to hold on to loyal customers. Paul E. Eberlein, G.M.'s director of leasing, said that customers with car leases expiring now would be allowed to extend their leases at the same monthly rate until an ample selection of vehicles became available again. G.M. has also been maintaining stockpiles of replacement parts for warranty work and repairs at dealerships; only a few parts, notably hoods and fenders for full-size sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks, are in short supply.
Some customers may wait for G.M. to resume full production. Terry Mantey, a retired Chrysler worker here in Sylvania who only buys Chevrolet cars because he admires their durability, shopped for a Malibu at Dave White Chevrolet today but said that he would wait for the strikes to end if he could not find the right combination of color and options at the right price.
But at mostly deserted dealerships here and in Toledo today, many dealers shared the worry expressed by Mr. Zarrella on Wednesday: that many of the customers would refuse to wait and start trying other dealerships. "Once you lose them," Mr. Zarrella also warned, "it is extremely hard to win them back."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Jim Yark, an Oldsmobile dealer, in the back lot behind his showroom in Toledo, Ohio. Strikes against G.M. have greatly depleted Mr. Yark's inventory. (Peter Yates for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Mayor Promotes Budget Director To Deputy Mayor for Operations

BYLINE: By NORIMITSU ONISHI 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday promoted his budget director, Joseph J. Lhota, to Deputy Mayor for Operations, the position that has traditionally been second in command at City Hall.
Mr. Lhota succeeded Randy M. Mastro, who resigned on Monday to return to private law practice. 
 The appointment of Mr. Lhota, a central player in the recent budget skirmishes with the City Council, is not likely to push the Giuliani administration in any major new direction.
The deputy mayor for operations is responsible for the day-to-day management of government, negotiating the city budget and making deals with Council leaders. As the Mayor's most trusted aide and a sort of alter ego, he fights for the his causes in televised debates and hammers at issues with reporters inside his office at City Hall's western end.
The predecessors to Mr. Lhota in the job were Mr. Mastro, a registered Democrat who was a protege from Mr. Giuliani's days as a Federal prosecutor, and Peter J. Powers, a lifelong friend of the Mayor.
"My job is to carry out the goals of the Mayor and his strategic objectives," said Mr. Lhota, who like Mr. Giuliani is a Republican.
Among the more immediate thoughts on Mr. Lhota's mind yesterday was what shade to repaint his new office. The deputy mayor for operations is the only one of the four deputy mayors to have an office in the City Hall building.
It was unclear whether Mr. Lhota would inherit all the responsibilities held by Mr. Mastro or whether some might be given to other members of Mr. Giuliani's inner circle, which includes Randy L. Levine, Deputy Mayor for Economic Development; Dennison Young Jr., the chief counsel; Anthony P. Coles, a senior adviser, and Cristyne F. Lategano, the communications director. Mr. Giuliani gave no hint yesterday of how power might be divided, saying only, "I will leave it up to them."
The Mayor did not name a successor to Mr. Lhota yesterday.
Before joining the administration in 1994, Mr. Lhota, 43, worked for several years as an investment banker specializing in municipal finance. He was born on City Island in the Bronx, and his father was a New York City police lieutenant.
Mr. Lhota graduated from Georgetown University and received a master's degree in business administration from Harvard. His wife, Tamra Roberts Lhota, is a fund-raiser for Mr. Giuliani and the president of York City Public/Private Initiatives, a private business group. The couple have a 7-year-old daughter, Kathryn.

HEADLINE: Anti-Sweatshop Coalition Finds Itself at Odds on Garment Factory Code

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
Eight months past its self-imposed deadline to set up a code of conduct for apparel factories, a Presidential task force remains at stalemate over a number of pivotal issues, including the frequency with which those factories ought to be inspected and whether any of them ought to be in China.
The working group's corporate members, including Liz Claiborne, Nike and Reebok, are now fighting several proposals recently put forward by its human rights organizations and labor unions, and the split is such that several members warn that the whole effort may soon fall apart. 
 The task force, the White House Apparel Industry Partnership, has 18 members: clothing manufacturers, labor unions, and consumer and human rights groups. It is trying to set up a system of voluntary labor standards, at home and abroad, that will assure consumers that the clothes and the footwear they buy was not made in sweatshops. It envisions an arrangement in which manufacturers that met the standards would be entitled to stitch certifying labels inside their products.
At a White House ceremony 15 months ago, all sides announced an agreement setting maximum work hours (60 a week), a minimum working age (14) and wage guidelines, varying by country, for thousands of factories used by American apparel companies in the United States and overseas. But the group's corporate members remain at odds with the unions and human rights groups on monitoring and other issues.
Deliberations of the task force are confidential, but a copy of the proposals recently set forth by the unions and human rights groups was sent anonymously to The New York Times by a member that, some on both sides suggested, wanted the debate aired in public as a way of pressuring the industry.
One of those proposals called for more stringent monitoring than the companies want, demanding that independent inspectors examine 30 percent of a given manufacturer's plants each year, twice the rate suggested by the corporate members.
Another proposal concerned a suggested study of apparel wages around the world. While the two sides agree that the United States Labor Department should perform such a study, the labor and human rights groups say it should focus on whether those wages are high enough to meet workers' basic needs -- that is, what is called a "living wage."
The industry representatives suggest that the proposal for such a focus is intended to embarrass them, and note that in the earlier agreement they pledged to pay at least the local minimum wage, though not necessarily a living wage, in their overseas factories. The companies also dislike a proposal under which the Fair Labor Association, the organization that would be created to oversee the code of conduct, would examine whether the factories were paying a living wage.
China is also a subject of contention. The nonindustry members have proposed that in any country that does not allow employees freedom of association and collective bargaining, employers shall nonetheless take steps to insure that those rights can be exercised. This proposal says that if, despite such efforts, no participating company can demonstrate progress in guaranteeing its employees those rights, then the Fair Labor Association can determine that producing garments in that country is inconsistent with the code of conduct.
Such a determination might not require companies to leave, but it would certainly apply pressure on them to do so, since they could otherwise no longer assure consumers that they were complying with the code. The nation's largest apparel union, the Union of Needletrades, Industrial and Textile Employees, a member of the task force, has long backed such a proposal, aimed largely at China, which has large numbers of factories that turn out clothes for the American market.
In light of disagreements like these, a representative of one noncorporate member said, "We're teetering on the edge of collapse."
But Michael Posner, executive director of the Lawyers Committee for Human Rights, which is also a member, was less pessimistic.
"We are still engaged in a process about which there are significant areas of agreement, and a few key areas where there are real differences," Mr. Posner said. "I remain cautiously optimistic that we're going to find a path that leads to an agreement."
Roberta Karp, co-chairwoman of the task force and general counsel for Liz Claiborne, criticized the disclosure of the recent proposals and, particularly with regard to the China proposal, suggested that some members were pushing a protectionist trade agenda.
"It is regrettable," she said, "that someone chose to try to leverage through the press a proposal that would impede the mission of the Apparel Industry Partnership. However, we believe many groups remain willing to make further progress by focusing on improving working conditions rather than supporting this proposal, essentially a trade policy that would force companies to pull out of countries like China."
On several occasions, the task force has nearly collapsed, only to lurch forward and reach agreement on thorny issues, like the makeup of the board of the Fair Labor Association. The labor and human rights groups had demanded a majority of board members, while the industry insisted on 50-50. Ultimately there was agreement that the industry and nonindustry sides would have equal representation, with the chairman chosen by both sides.
When the task force reaches an impasse, its members often ask Gene Sperling, economic adviser to President Clinton, to jawbone the two sides. Asked about the latest stalemate, Mr. Sperling said:
"When you're trying to put together a novel and indeed historic partnership, you have to expect it's going to be a rocky road every step of the way. But I'm still confident that we'll get there."

HEADLINE: CLINTON IN CHINA: THE REPUBLICANS;
G.O.P. Delivers Unusual Praise On Clinton Trip

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 2

 BODY:
Even before President Clinton's return from China, many prominent Republicans concede that the trip has been a political success that could deprive their party of a potent election-year issue.
In a series of interviews Republicans said they still had serious questions about the wisdom of Mr. Clinton's policy approaches toward Beijing. 
 But as a political matter, there seems to be a consensus among Republicans that, at least for now, Mr. Clinton has overcome fears among Democrats that the trip would expose the President to damaging attacks on issues like human rights, the exporting of satellite technology to China and campaign finance irregularities.
"I think it was a huge success," said Jack F. Kemp, the Republican Vice Presidential nominee in 1996, who faults the President for seeming to side with China against Japan. "That presents a problem to those Republicans or conservatives who want to make it an issue. I can't imagine that there's any great political benefit to be derived, because the President handled himself very well."
James R. Lilley, the Ambassador to China in the Bush Administration, put it this way: "Clinton got control of the agenda. He ran it like a campaign. And he made it into a political success story."
Republicans say the President gave a polished performance throughout the trip and avoided gaffes. His defense of human rights, and criticism of the 1989 crackdown at Tiananmen Square, at a news conference with President Jiang Zemin, struck the right note, the Republicans said. Mr. Clinton also defended religious freedom in China and Tibet, as well as economic liberalization.
Mr. Lilley said he had advised Republican Congressional leaders to hold their fire and rethink how to handle China as a political issue. "I've counseled them to pull back on this one. Don't hit Clinton at his high point -- or it's going to sound like sour grapes." But Mr. Lilley did say he thought that the President had "swept under the rug" the issue of Chinese military modernization."
Weeks ago, House Speaker Newt Gingrich called on Mr. Clinton to postpone the trip until the Justice Department had determined whether two American companies gave sensitive missile information to Beijing in 1996.
But speaking to reporters on Wednesday in San Antonio, where he was attending a Republican fund-raising event, he praised Mr. Clinton. "I think the President did a pretty good job talking on Chinese radio and TV," Mr. Gingrich said. "It's less expensive to be friends than to be enemies."
Rich Galen, a phrase maker to the Speaker, said: "They set the bar so low for success that the arrival ceremony looked like a limbo dance, and he did better than expectations. You have to say this has been a successful trip for the President."
One explanation for Mr. Gingrich's praise is that he has been trying to repair relations with corporate executives who have soured on giving money to Republicans, and who have championed intensified trade with China.
The positive notices from Mr. Clinton's trip have already affected Republican legislative strategy. The Senate had been expected to vote next week on a package of amendments sponsored by Senator Tim Hutchinson, Republican of Arkansas, that among other features would deny visas to Chinese officials involved in forced-abortion policies and prohibit new American-backed international loans to China.
But today Senate officials said that the vote had been put off by at least a week, partly out of concern that the amendments might not win a positive reception in the afterglow of the summit.
The upbeat reaction even led White House officials to take the unusual step of pointing out an editorial on Tuesday in The Wall Street Journal, whose editorial page is better known for harsh rebukes of the President. The White House communications director, Ann F. Lewis, said she was so stunned by the unexpected praise that "I looked again -- it did not say April 1."
The editorial said, "So we may break convention among the President's critics by saying we think Mr. Clinton has been doing well in China."
The Journal backed off today in an editorial, accusing Mr. Clinton of "kowtowing" to China over Taiwan.
Many Republicans, and Democrats, say they do not expect the relative silence on Mr. Clinton and China to last. Several Republicans said that would depend in part on what polls show about the public reaction to the trip.
And some Republicans may be more willing to speak out against Mr. Clinton after his arrival in Washington -- he is due back early Saturday morning -- out of a tradition that it is inappropriate to denounce a President while he is overseas.
Although most polling organizations are waiting until the end of the trip to question Americans about whether it was a success, surveys beforehand showed wide public support for the trip. A New York Times/ CBS News Poll early last month found that about half of Republicans and two-thirds of Democrats said that Mr. Clinton should go to China.
Representative Benjamin A. Gilman, the Republican of Middletown, N.Y., who heads the International Relations Committee, said it was too early to know how the trip would play politically.
"The opportunity to talk to the Chinese people without any restrictions and focusing on the rights of individuals was a plus," Mr. Gilman said. "The key question is how much else was accomplished? The Chinese achieved a number of important goals at our expense."
The chairman of the Republican National Committee, Jim Nicholson, said he believed that Republicans could eventually score political points over China.
"It will take time for the splash of the trip and the media coverage to wear off and for the real substance of what went on to surface," Mr. Nicholson said. "As that happens and people begin to see the way he gave away the store, they're not going to like it."
Mr. Nicholson said he was deeply concerned by the President's comments about Taiwanese reunification with China, the fund-raising scandals, Mr. Clinton's failure to meet dissidents and the laxity of China's agreement not to point nuclear missiles at the United States. "It was all carrot and no stick," he said.
Still, as with many other Republicans, Mr. Nicholson's language was tamer than before the trip, when he said the President would "walk on the blood of those brave pro-democracy protesters."
Gov. Roy Romer of Colorado, general chairman of the Democratic National Committee, countered that Mr. Clinton's performance had exceeded his expectations. Mr. Romer had been particularly concerned, he said, about how the President would be perceived at the arrival ceremonies at Tiananmen Square, site of the Government's bloody crackdown in 1989.
"I didn't know how he would perform personally," Mr. Romer said. "There was tension with the Tiananmen Square thing. I was apprehensive."
But he said of Republicans: "I think they've lost it as an issue. People understand that one-quarter of the world's population is sitting in the middle of that Asian economy. We've got to know them better, and they've got to be partners of ours."
A Republican media consultant, Michael Murphy, predicted that the trip would provide nothing more than a short-term boost for Mr. Clinton, saying: "It's not unlike the proverbial Chinese dinner -- short-term in its splendor. It was a successful photo op, which is what they wanted."

HEADLINE: June Job Data Show Growth Eased a Little

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR 

 BODY:
The hot United States economy is showing signs of cooling, but by only a few degrees. In June, the Labor Department reported yesterday, unemployment edged up to 4.5 percent and job growth slowed.
There were other signs of moderation. Total hours worked were virtually flat in June, a clear indication that the nation's output of goods and services is growing much more slowly than in recent quarters. And hourly pay rose by a mere penny, suggesting that wage inflation, while higher than a year ago, was not accelerating. 
 The slowdown, however, is from an exceptionally torrid pace. Payrolls grew by 205,000 last month, compared with more than 300,000 in each of the two previous months.
By any historical standard, job creation remains robust and unemployment is very low indeed. As recently as a year ago, joblessness stood at 5 percent.
"Coming after such phenomenal numbers, the June number looks weaker," said Jeffrey A. Frankel, a member of the President's Council of Economic Advisers. "But on some objective scale, it's very positive."
The drag on the job market and the economy mostly resulted from a production slowdown in manufacturing as well as a temporary decline in government jobs. Manufacturing payrolls, which have been flat or down for months, fell by 29,000 in June, after dropping by 22,000 in May. The culprits: superabundant inventories, the initial effects of the strikes against General Motors and other labor strife, and deepening economic woes in Asia.
But elsewhere hiring was robust. The service sector -- from consulting firms and investment banks to hotel chains and shopping malls -- continued to scoop up workers, as did the temporary-help industry, usually a harbinger of future job creation. As Katherine Abraham, the Commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, noted, hiring by the private sector matched the average pace for the last 12 months -- an exceptionally good stretch for job growth.
Investors took the report in stride. They nudged bond prices higher, but pushed stock prices down modestly. Investors have been fretting that continued strength in the labor market will prompt the Federal Reserve to slow the economy by raising interest rates. Despite the slowdown, the pace of job creation is still too fast for the Fed, which does not want to see the unemployment rate fall much further.
"Job growth is slowing to a more comfortable pace, but it's still not within Alan Greenspan's preferred range," said M. Carey Leahey, chief United States economist at High Frequency Economics, a consulting firm.
The Fed chairman's comfort zone, as Mr. Greenspan pointedly hinted in testimony last October, is closer to 100,000 than 200,000 jobs monthly.
Labor Department officials cautioned yesterday against reading too much into the rise in unemployment. June is the month in which millions of students in search of summer jobs temporarily join the labor force, an influx that often results in weird gyrations in employment and unemployment as measured in the department's survey of households. In June of last year, for example, the unemployment rate also ticked up two-tenths of 1 percent, without signaling an upward trend in joblessness.
And business executives do not see much slackening in the demand for workers, young or old. "I don't see any weakness in the labor market," said Mitchell Fromstein, chief executive of Manpower Inc., the nation's biggest provider of temporary help. Manpower's survey of employers' hiring plans for July through September shows further expansion. The National Federation of Independent Business, meanwhile, reported that its June survey found that a record 31 percent of small companies had job openings that they were unable to fill.
Nearly a third of June's decline in manufacturing jobs reflected the initial effects of the General Motors strike, which has now idled more than 160,000 workers. The jobs survey was taken the week of June 12, when 3,000 G.M. workers were on strike and another 6,000 others had been furloughed. If the strike lasts through mid-July, as many expect, the July employment report will be sharply affected.
The deepening crisis in Asia, which has strengthened the dollar and battered demand, also hurt factory employment last month in several industries that sell to Asian customers or compete with Asian rivals. Payrolls were down by 1,000 in heavy machinery; 6,000 in apparel and 4,000 in electronic components, where there was also a strike. The weakness could well continue; the Commerce Department reported yesterday that factory orders fell a sharp 1.6 percent in May after rising seven-tenths of 1 percent in April.
The June decline in government payrolls, especially at the state and local level, was probably temporary. To be sure, the Federal Civil Service has been shrinking for years and will no doubt continue to do so. But a transit strike in Philadelphia accounted for the dip in state jobs. And June is the month that hundreds of thousands of teachers go on summer break; the timing always changes a bit from year to year, so attempts to make seasonal adjustments in the data are rarely perfect.
'You wouldn't want to read too much into that decline," said Tom Nardone, chief of labor force statistics at the Bureau of Labor Statistics. "Outside of manufacturing and government, things look pretty good. Things are growing."
Builders added another 20,000 carpenters, bricklayers and the like; they would probably have hired even more if there had not been heavy rains in the Midwest last month. And the services juggernaut -- data processing, consulting, engineering, health care, health supply, temporary help, retail, finance, insurance, real estate, trucking, wholesale trade, utilities -- added 215,000 net payroll jobs.
How much the economy will slow is a matter of great debate. So far, consumers and businesses continue to spend freely while industry is putting the brakes on production. The question is whether the production cutbacks will continue long enough to bring job creation to a crawl and to rein in spending, or whether spending will stay strong enough to revive production eventually.
"That's the issue," said William Dudley, chief economist at Goldman, Sachs. "Nobody knows for sure. It depends on how long the production weakness lasts."
One damper that seems to be correcting itself faster than expected is the inventory pileup; yesterday's Commerce Department report showed that manufacturers' inventories hardly grew in May. As Mr. Dudley put it, "Manufacturers are responding rapidly to the inventory situation."

HEADLINE: How a Home's Sale Led to Discovery of 2 Murders

BYLINE: By ROBERT HANLEY 

 BODY:
For nearly 14 years, the bodies of two murder victims, a young man and a teen-age girl, were hidden in a crude and shallow grave beneath the crawl space of a tiny Cape Cod house near Atlantic City. The homicides might not have been discovered, the authorities said yesterday, but for the sale of the house and the new owner's plans to remodel it.
After detectives had spent two days digging and sifting dirt from the crawl space and backyard at the house, the Atlantic County Prosecutor, Jeffrey S. Blitz, said yesterday that two skeletons, shreds of clothing, three bullets, a baseball bat and a wallet were found in the three-foot grave beneath 402 Ireland Avenue in Northfield, N.J. Mr. Blitz said his investigators were satisfied that there were no other bodies buried on the property. 
 The former owner of the house, Ernest Ireland, 51, an unemployed bachelor who has been living in a trailer park in Pleasantville, N.J., has been charged with murder and is being held in $350,000 bail at the Atlantic County Jail.
He was charged late Monday, only a few hours after the new owner of the house, Bruce Trielo, began excavations in the crawl space and turned up a thigh bone. Mr. Trielo, who had bought the house as an investment in late May, was planning to enlarge it, first by putting in a full basement, Mr. Blitz said.
The house at 402 Ireland Avenue was the first of six built on the tiny dead-end street. It was named after Mr. Ireland's forebears who were its first settlers, said a woman who has lived on a nearby street for 33 years. The woman, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said Mr. Ireland had lived alone since his mother died of cancer in the mid-1970's. "You saw him alone all the time, walking or riding a bike," she said. "He never talked to anybody, and I passed him almost every day on the street."
Ireland Avenue was an odd mix of images yesterday. Bricks and cinder blocks brought in for the remodeling were piled outside Mr. Trielo's house, next to mounds of freshly dug dirt. Across the street, deliverymen came with supplies for a Fourth of July weekend picnic.
Several neighbors declined to talk about Mr. Ireland or the murders.
The prosecutor refused to say yesterday whether Mr. Ireland had made a statement. But, he said, his staff believed that the murders occurred in Mr. Ireland's kitchen in late January 1985 and that Mr. Ireland dragged the bodies outside and hid them in the freshly dug grave in the crawl space.
One of the victims has been identified as Barry Dallman, of Pleasantville, which is adjacent to Northfield. He died of a gunshot to the spine at age 21, Mr. Blitz said. Mr. Dallman was identified through papers found in the wallet discovered in the grave. Mr. Blitz described Mr. Dallman only as an acquaintance of Mr. Ireland's. He declined to discuss a possible motive for the murders.
The teen-age girl has not been identified. She died of blows to the head, Mr. Blitz said. The county medical examiner has determined, through examination of a pelvic bone, that she was in her early teens, the prosecutor said. He said detectives believed that the remains might be those of a 14-year-old girl reported missing by her foster parents shortly after they dropped her off at Pleasantville High School on Jan. 24, 1985. She is thought to have been Mr. Dallman's girlfriend, Mr. Blitz said.
Detectives are now searching the Atlantic City area for dentists who may have treated the girl and kept dental records.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Judgment In Beijing

BYLINE: By A.M. ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
The President stood to speak to about 100 dissidents gathered in the U.S. Embassy. He said this to them:
"While we press for human rights through diplomatic channels you press with your very lives, day in, day out, year after year, risking your jobs, your homes, your all." 
 And then this: "Coming here, being with you, looking into your faces, I have to believe the history of this troubled century will indeed be redeemed in the eyes of God and man."
President Reagan said many things during his visit to Moscow that May of 1988, but those passages will be remembered by fighters for freedom willing to risk their own -- and by those privileged by their own liberty to help them.
A decade later, President Clinton, in Beijing, could make no such statements. This President, born and raised under liberty, elected in liberty, had no meetings with dissidents, spoke no words about political prisoners by the thousands existing on gruel and beatings, and workers by the millions slaving in "re-education" prison-factories.
This President, who proclaims love for children and women's rights, did not mention what confronts every Chinese woman -- the need for official approval to deliver a child. He did not mention the punishment for carrying to birth more than the allotted one, or sometimes two: forced abortion. It may take a village to raise a child, as Mrs. Clinton wrote, but in the China they admire it takes only one official to order the child extinguished in the womb; no choice.
Beijing gave Mr. Clinton air time before censoring replays. When he called his friends in the U.S. to ask howmIdoin' back there, they said he was a smash. He was; the U.S. press has been spun so often that now it sometimes just spins itself. The Clinton "openness" we heard and read about was to candor as Torquemada to tolerance.
He arrived bearing payoff to China. He offered the chance to make Tibet disappear forever into China, without any Beijing concessions. President Jiang Zemin of China said he would talk with the Dalai Lama, maybe. The Dalai Lama praised both men. He fears that if the Chinese never allow him to return to Tibet, when he dies Beijing will choose and rear the next Dalai Lama or simply eliminate Tibetan Buddhism completely.
In Tibet, dreams of national and religious freedom will not long survive any Clinton-Jiang deal, nor will Tibet's international support groups. But perhaps at least the honored memory of the half-century struggle by Tibetans and the Dalai Lama against genocide will endure despite decisions that China and the U.S. force upon them.
In the "debate" heard by Chinese, it was President Jiang who openly laid down realities to them and the world. The Communist justification for the Tiananmen slaughter stands; objecting Chinese can go to jail. On foreign complaints about human rights: None of your business. And nothing, particularly not the presence of this U.S. President, can save a Chinese dissident from arrest when the police choose.
Mr. Clinton -- he concentrated on concealment. When he had the chance to use public time to speak up against the arrests of Roman Catholic and Protestant clergymen and congregants who do not accept the official "patriotic" churches or Beijing's dictates about liturgy, sermons, clerical appointments and disavowal by Catholics of papal authority and appointments, the President was mute. Nor did he speak of the millions who attend underground "house churches" rather than accept Beijing's rule over God.
And in all those public meetings Mr. Clinton kept his mouth shut about Chinese sales of nuclear weaponry, and Beijing's thefts of American missile technology.
On the Chinese economy, he said nothing about the various special efficiencies that so smartly increase production, profits and exports: 17-cent-an-hour labor, no unions, iron factory discipline, forced labor, the waiting cell -- all now handsomely financed by Western investment, and imports.
A smash. The Beijing-U.S. axis was forged, based on Politburo concepts about the role of human rights and political democracy: zero.
And then -- then, Mr. Clinton announced that China's economic and "freedom" course was "morally right." He said that. The President will go home. On Sundays he will go to church. The Bible will be in his hand, and on his soul will be that judgment.

HEADLINE: Hop On, Hop Off: The Unlimited Metrocard Arrives

BYLINE: By ANDY NEWMAN 

 BODY:
A new era for the New York City's mass transit riders begins at midnight tonight, when the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's unlimited-ride Metrocard passes go on sale, offering what transit officials hope will be a huge new incentive to use subways and buses.
Priced at $17 for a 7-day pass and $63 for a 30-day pass, the new cards could yield significant savings for regular users of the city's mass transit network. 
 But more fundamentally, officials and advocates for riders are hoping that the passes will transform the way New Yorkers use and think about mass transit and create a much more mobile city, where people hop on and off buses and subways with abandon because they no longer have to worry about the cost. New York's century-old transit system is the last major one in the country to begin offering offer unlimited-ride passes.
Advocates for riders have questioned whether the system is prepared to absorb the 100 million new rides a year the passes are expected to attract, an increase of 6 percent over today's levels. They contend that the authority has not added enough service to keep pace with an 18 percent increase in weekday ridership over the last two years.
But the authority maintains that it will be able to add enough buses and subways should they be needed.
The passes, which were announced by Gov. George E. Pataki in December, nearly complete a series of fare breaks that the transportation authority began last year with free bus-to-subway transfers in July and continued with an 11-rides-for-the-price-of-10 bulk discount in January.
Those discounts, along with the city's booming economy, have fueled a 9 percent increase in bus and subway ridership since last year, to 5.5 million rides a day. A one-day unlimited pass, priced at $4, is scheduled to be offered in the fall.
The passes are also expected to benefit Mr. Pataki, who is running for re-election and whose best-known piece of transit policy until a year ago was to reduce state aid to the system in 1995, forcing cuts in service and an increase in the fare, to $1.50 per token from $1.25.
Mr. Pataki said yesterday that he expected the benefits of the discounts to be felt beyond the confines of the buses and subways.
"We know it's going to be good for the economy, we know it's great for the fare payer and we know it's going to be outstanding for the environment," he said. "Everyone's been talking about how congested the city is with too many cars, and by offering these options we will continue to get people out of their cars and onto mass transit."
Interviews with riders this week found them generally welcoming the new cards, with some planning to buy one pass as a trial to see whether they get their money's worth.
"Maybe it would stop me from taking so many cabs," said a 46-year-old advertising buyer on the D train platform at 42d Street who gave her name only as Valerie and who said she was returning to work after a lunchtime appointment. "It has to do with commitment. Once I've made that $17 investment up front, I see it as a free situation, rather than a $5 cab ride minus the dollar-and-a-half public transportation."
Alberta Johnson, who lives in Harlem and works in a print shop in Greenwich Village and who also takes the subway frequently to go shopping or to the movies, was certain the pass was for her.
"I know I'll use it enough," said Ms. Johnson, who got off the A train at the Port Authority Bus Terminal on her way to celebrate her birthday in Atlantic City. "I usually buy my $15 Metrocard every Friday for the week," she said, "but a lot of the time I have to get a new one sooner so I can get around."
The new passes look identical to the pay-per-ride version of the Metrocard, the now-familiar gold card with a magnetic strip that allows fares to be deducted electronically at the turnstile or the fare box and is now used to pay for more than 70 percent of all rides.
They new cards will be sold at all 468 subway stations and at more than 3,200 newsstands, delis and other stores outside the system, though officials said that some stores would sell only the 7-day card, and not the 30-day card, because they want repeat business from their customers.
Passes bought at token booths must be purchased with cash, but the authority expects that in the fall, it will begin to introduce vending machines that take credit or automated teller cards.
The pass is good from the moment it is first used until midnight 7 or 30 days later, depending on the kind of pass. A 30-day pass does not expire automatically at the end of a calendar month.
The only restriction on the passes is that they cannot be used more than once within 18 minutes, except for transfers between buses and subways. This is to prevent people from passing the card to friends and swiping several riders through the turnstiles at once. But there is nothing to prevent riders from lending their passes to others when they are not using them.
Holders of monthly passes on the M.T.A.'s railroads -- Metro-North and the Long Island Rail Road -- will be able to buy a new version of the pass with an unlimited bus and subway pass on the back of the card.
If the pass is stolen or lost, it cannot be replaced, so the authority is urging riders to treat the pass as if it were cash.
Whether the pass is a worthwhile investment will depend on how often it is used. A commuter who takes only 5 round trips a week, or 10 rides, would be better off with an 11-rides-for-the-price-of-10 Metrocard, which effectively reduces the fare to $1.36. At 10 rides a week, a 7-day pass holder would pay about $1.70 a ride and a 30-day pass holder about $1.54 a ride.
But anyone who typically takes even a couple of extra trips a week would save money with the pass. Someone who takes seven round trips a week on a 7-day pass would pay $1.21 per ride, while a 30-day pass holder taking seven round trips a week would effectively pay $1.09 a ride.
Combined with a Federal benefit known in this region as Transitchek, which was modified last month to let companies convert up to $65 a month of their employees' pretax pay into transit benefits, the passes could easily reduce the effective cost of a ride to less than a dollar, where it has not been since 1986.
For someone in the 28 percent tax bracket, a $63 pass bought with Transitchek would in effect cost only $45, the amount the worker would otherwise have taken home after taxes were deducted.
Larry Filler, the executive director of Transitcenter, which administers the Transitchek program, said that while 7,000 companies now offer Transitchek, which is also good on trains and buses in the suburbs around New York, 2,000 more had contacted the center since last month seeking information on the program.
While there has been some concern that less-affluent riders would not buy the passes because of the up-front cost, officials in other cities have found that such passes are used just as widely by people at all economic levels.
"Lower-income people realize that it's the cheapest way to do it," said Daniel Fleishman, a senior consultant at Multisystems Inc., a transit consulting company in Cambridge, Mass., "and those are the people who use transit most because they use it not just for work but for all trips."
And while riders are expected to take a while to get used to the passes, Christopher P. Boylan, a deputy executive director of the transportation authority, said he was sure they would embrace them just as they embraced the Metrocard itself as soon as the free transfers started.
"For all the things people used to say about how attached people were to their tokens, now 71 percent of people have abandoned them," Mr. Boylan said, adding that Metrocards are now so entrenched that he sees them sticking out of pockets in clothing display windows and inserted as props in wallets sold on the street. "The Metrocard has become part of New York culture, and once people recognize the benefits of the pass, it will be the same thing."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Japan Announces a Plan To Tackle Bad Bank Loans
The Japanese Government announced a long-awaited plan to clear away the nation's $550 billion in problem loans in hopes of bolstering global confidence in the country and setting its economy on track for growth.
The centerpiece of the plan is a mechanism to allow banks to fail without provoking chaos in the financial system. Page A1. 

Sports Authority Receives 2d Bid
Shares of Sports Authority rose 9 percent after Gart Sports made a $445.2 million offer for 70 percent of the outstanding shares of the 205-store retail chain. Sports Authority had agreed in May to be acquired by Venator Group, which operates Foot Locker, Lady Foot Locker, Kids Footlocker and Champs athletic stores. D2.
 
Stocks Decline in Light Trading
Trading of stocks was light as investors started their long holiday weekend and Government reports on jobs and manufacturing suggested that profits could suffer from a slowing economy. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 23.41 points, to 9,025.26. D4.
 
The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond declined to 5.60 percent, from 5.62 percent on Wednesday. D4.
 
Welsh Buying Centennial Cellular
Welsh, Carson, Anderson & Stowe plans to buy Centennial Cellular for about $1.5 billion, marking the investment company's first move into the phone business. D15.
 
Russian Concern to Pay Back Taxes
Gazprom, Russia's largest petroleum company and biggest tax delinquent, agreed to pay 4.2 billion rubles ($675 million) in unpaid taxes and to start paying the Government about 4 billion rubles a month. The agreement also requires the Government to pay Gazprom, whose Moscow headquarters are shown here, billions of rubles for oil and gas that Government agencies and state companies order but never pay for. A3.
 
Aid to Indonesia Resumes
The World Bank resumed aid to Indonesia for the first time since President Suharto resigned. It approved a $1 billion loan that was part of a $4.5 billion contribution from the World Bank that was promised earlier this year. A5.
 
Orders to Factories Fell in May
Orders placed with United States factories declined 1.6 percent in May, to a seasonally adjusted $333 billion, suggesting that manufacturing is losing speed. D3.
 
U S Airways Picks Airbus Jetliners
In a blow to Boeing, U S Airways Group announced plans to buy 30 Airbus Industrie wide-body aircraft valued at $3.7 billion. Boeing had been the airline's only supplier of big planes suited for overseas flights. D15.
 
Apparel Group Fails to Agree
The White House Apparel Industry Partnership, a Presidential task force that includes Liz Claiborne, Nike and Reebok and was established to set up a code of conduct for apparel factories, cannot agree on a number of issues. A13.
 
Havoc Ends in Kuala Lumpur
Flights at Kuala Lumpur's new airport took off and landed more or less on time after a computer glitch caused two days of havoc. Since opening, the $2.25 billion airport has been plagued by computer network problems. D2.
 
New York Officials Plan Sanctions
New York City and State officials plan to impose sanctions on Swiss banks, hoping it will persuade the banks and lawyers for Holocaust survivors to settle. A3.
 
U.S. Markets Closed
The stock market and other financial markets in the United States are closed today in observance of the Fourth of July. Most overseas markets, however, are open. United States markets will reopen on Monday.

HEADLINE: African Opportunity

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 2

 BODY:
For the Western Governments that have watched with dismay for the last three decades as much of Africa suffered through chaos and bankruptcy, the news from Nigeria today is the most gratifying from that continent since the establishment of a multiracial Government in South Africa under Nelson Mandela.
If Nigeria could take even a few steps along the path toward democracy, as implied by the reported pledge of its new military Government to release all political prisoners, it could encourage other African governments to follow. 
 It might enable Nigeria itself, a country with real possibilities, to begin a comeback from decades of corruption, dictatorship, ethnic tension and war. And it might ease the fears of other West African leaders that political unrest and economic deprivation would spill into their countries.
When President Clinton and an entourage of more than 800 swept through Africa last spring, they flew over Nigeria twice but never landed.
That pained the Administration's Africa experts, from Assistant Secretary of State Susan E. Rice on down. Nigeria counts. It is the most important country in sub-Saharan Africa, with the possible exception of South Africa. It is big, more than twice the size of California. Its 110 million people make it Africa's most populous nation. It is the fifth-largest supplier of oil to the United States.
But a visit from Mr. Clinton was out of the question, Ms. Rice said at the time. The Government of Gen. Sani Abacha, one of the world's most repressive, annulled democratic elections in 1993, executed nine environmental activists in 1995 and filled jails with its opponents, including Moshood K. O. Abiola, the apparent victor in the 1993 vote.
Suspended from the Commonwealth, subjected to sanctions by the United States and others, Nigeria dug in its heels. Outsiders' leverage ranged from limited to nonexistent, and no early change seemed possible. On a visit to Nigeria, Pope John Paul II appealed to General Abacha to free the political prisoners and got exactly nowhere.
The Clinton Administration sent signals to General Abacha that it would not accept as a reform measure his plan to run as a civilian in elections planned this August. But then Mr. Clinton grew so frustrated with the lack of movement that he said in Cape Town that "if he stands for election, we hope he will stand as a civilian."
That apparent concession brought no constructive response, either.
Then General Abacha died suddenly of a heart attack on June 8, to be succeeded by his colleague in the ruling junta, Gen. Abdulsalam Abubakar. And General Abubakar, to the surprise of Nigerians and diplomats alike, proved in many ways to be different from his predecessor.
Sensing an opening, the United Nations Secretary General, Kofi Annan, visited Nigeria this week, met with Mr. Abiola in jail on Tuesday and declared today that "all political detainees will be released and the Government will make an announcement at the appropriate time."
Mr. Annan also said that Mr. Abiola was ready to relinquish his claim to the Presidency. Diplomats in Washington and London suggested that the Secretary General had reiterated to Mr. Abiola the private urgings of Western nations, including the United States, that he pledge to cooperate with General Abubakar as part of a face-saving arrangement that would grant amnesty to all political prisoners.
A high-ranking British delegation, headed by Tony Lloyd, a minister in the Foreign Office, visited Nigeria last weekend, and an American group, headed by Under Secretary of State Thomas R. Pickering, is to head there this weekend.
"This is a carefully orchestrated process," one European official said, "not a deal exactly, but everyone understands the transaction here. You might call it a political cease-fire leading to the release of hostages."
So far, General Abubakar has managed to hold the junta and the officer corps together, although some analysts in the United States said they feared that many officers were less committed than their leader to national reconciliation.
Presuming that the prisoners are released, General Abubakar's next major task will be to restore not only the army's self-respect but its standing in the country. That will not be easy. Gen. Olusegun Obasanjo, one of the prisoners already released by the new Government, said recently that the army had become "a liability to the nation," with "no credibility."
The military is one of the few truly national institutions in Nigeria, where the Yoruba in the southwest, the Hausa in the north and the Ibo and others in the southeast have often been at odds. Obafemi Awolowo, one of the country's leaders in the early post-colonial days, once said: "West and East Nigeria are as different as Ireland from Germany, and the north is as different from either as China."
These differences greatly complicate matters. Mr. Abiola is a Yoruba, and the army, as always, is dominated by Hausa officers.

INTERNATIONAL A3-11
 
Nigeria Promises to Free All Its Political Prisoners
Secretary General Kofi Annan of the United Nations said that Nigeria's new military Government had pledged to release all remaining political prisoners, among them Moshood K. O. Abiola, who was jailed after apparently winning the presidential election in 1993. A1
 
Northern Ireland Church Fires
Arsonists believed to be members of a dissident Protestant group set fire to 10 Roman Catholic churches in Northern Ireland, causing fears that wider sectarian violence could return to the British province. Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain flew to Belfast, visited one of the churches and met with Protestant and Catholic leaders of the Northern Ireland Assembly in an effort to dispel rising tension in the mostly Protestant province. A1
 
Clinton in Hong Kong
President Clinton, speaking in Hong Kong a day after the former British colony marked the first anniversary of its return to China, said that "cronyism, corruption and overextended credit," unchecked by competent financial regulation, had led to the Asian economic crisis that plunged Hong Kong into recession. A10
 
Company to Pay Russia Taxes
Russia's famously ineffectual tax men threatened to seize control of the nation's biggest and most powerful corporation -- and its executives' dachas, yachts and other perks -- unless it paid billions of dollars in back taxes. The company, Gazprom, gave in and agreed to pay $674 million. A3
 
Sanctions on Swiss Banks
Officials of the City and State of New York said that they would begin imposing sanctions on Swiss banks on Sept. 1, hoping that the two-month "cooling-off period" would persuade Swiss bank officials and lawyers for Holocaust survivors and heirs to reach a settlement. A3
 
Doubt Cast on Pakistani's Story
Iftikar Khan Chaudhry, a self-proclaimed defector from Pakistan's nuclear weapons program is not a scientist at all, but a low-paid accountant for a company that makes bathroom tiles, a director of the company said. Mr. Chaudhry, who is seeking asylum in the United States, told a number of reporters that he had been at an April meeting at which Pakistani military leaders decided to launch a pre-emptive nuclear attack against New Delhi. A6
 
Aid to Indonesia Renewed
The World Bank resumed aid to Indonesia for the first time since President Suharto was forced from office, approving a $1 billion loan and predicting that the world's largest industrial nations would soon announce another $6 billion in aid. A7
 
Algeria to Allow Inspection
Algeria, which has for months resisted outside efforts to investigate the violence that has killed tens of thousands of Algerians since 1992, has agreed to admit a high-level international political mission, the United Nations announced. A6
 
NATIONAL A12-18
 
More Floridians Flee Advance of Wildfires
Hundreds more residents of Volusia and Brevard Counties in Florida fled towns threatened by wildfires, joining the more than 30,000 residents of those counties who were ordered evacuated Wednesday night, state emergency management officials said. A 140-mile stretch of I-95 was closed and the Pepsi 400 stock car race, scheduled for tomorrow, was postponed. No deaths and about 50 injuries have been reported. A1
 
Nerve Gas Report Retracted

Impasse for Apparel Panel
A Presidential task force remains at stalemate over a number of pivotal issues on establishing a code of conduct for apparel factories, including the frequency with which those factories ought to be inspected and whether any ought to be in China. A16
 
High-Level Lapses Found
Failures by the Marine Corps and the Air Force to pass along crucial information cast "substantial doubt" on whether the pilot of a plane that struck a ski lift cable in the Italian Alps in February could be convicted in a court-martial, though a court-martial should be convened for the pilot and the navigator, a Marine hearing officer said in a report. LENGTH: 153 words

HEADLINE: Who Bears Harassment Burden?

 BODY:

To the Editor:
A June 27 editorial rightly praises the Supreme Court decisions holding businesses liable for sexual harassment that occurs in the workplace. But the rulings leave unaffected the abuses inflicted on women in businesses run by American corporations and their contractors abroad. 
 What is the difference between sexually harassing women workers in an auto plant in Normal, Ill., and sexually harassing women making toys in Shenzhen, China? An economist might describe the difference this way: United States labor policies are more rigid compared with China's, giving China a comparative advantage in the global economy.
Most corporations do not have codes of conduct that bar sexual harassment in their foreign operations. And many with a code have no way to enforce it. Rules against sexual harassment must be included in trade agreements.
 
ROBERT A. SENSER
Reston, Va., June 27, 1998

HEADLINE: Japan Is Still Key To China's Growth

 BODY:

To the Editor:
With Japan in a banking crisis (front page, June 27), United States policy has been to urge Japan to stimulate its economy to strengthen the yen. The incredibly low half-percent interest rate has caused a massive capital flight to strong-currency countries paying much higher rates. This flight is not just from banks but also from real estate and the stock market. 
 Japan has maintained low rates to stimulate exports and earn foreign exchange, but this has only served to depress the stock and real estate markets and weaken bank reserve ratios. Japan should instead raise its bank borrowing rate sharply to bring it closer to rates in the United States and Europe. This would strengthen the yen and the real estate and stock markets.
 
JOHN R. BYERS
Scarsdale, N.Y., June 28, 1998

HEADLINE: Failure to End a Gas Tax May Hurt New York Power Plants

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

DATELINE: ALBANY, July 2

 BODY:
Just as New York begins forcing electric power plants to compete with one another for business, experts say that plants in the state will be at a disadvantage against competitors in other states because of the State Assembly's failure to act on a little-noticed bill in the final days of the 1998 session.
The bill -- which was supported by business groups, environmentalists and a bipartisan group of lawmakers -- would have repealed a New York tax on out-of-state purchases of natural gas, the fuel used in most of the plants that supply the state's electricity. The bill passed the State Senate but never came to a vote in the Assembly, so the tax will remain in effect at least until next year. 
 The tax is structured so that the owners of New York's power plants usually have not had to pay it. But changes in the industry are about to take away that protection, forcing gas-fired plants in the state to begin paying the tax.
Opponents of the tax say it will give an advantage to power companies in other states that want to break into New York's newly competitive market, and to plants that burn coal, which pollute far more than those that burn gas.
According to legislators, lobbyists and Assembly staff members who tracked the bill, there was no opposition to it and there were no disagreements over wording. They say it seems to have died of neglect.
"This was so frustrating to us," said Carol Murphy, executive director of Independent Power Producers of New York, a lobbying group for nonutility power producers, "because we have a problem that's happening right now that needed to be dealt with, and nobody was against this bill, and yet nothing happened."
After Gov. George E. Pataki's broad budget vetoes in April, the Assembly Speaker, Sheldon Silver, signaled that he would not allow passage of any bills that might be considered budget-related, but people close to the Speaker said it was not clear if that category included the gas tax bill, or if the measure simply fell through the cracks.
Patricia Lynch, the chief spokeswoman for Mr. Silver, said she was not sure why the bill did not come to a vote.
Each year, the Legislature waits until the final days of the session to take up hundreds of bills. Custom and legislative rules dictate that by then, nearly everything must go through one of a handful of committees that are tightly controlled by the leadership of each house, before reaching the full house for a vote. Lawmakers say it is not humanly possible for them and their staffs, in those frenzied days, to get to each bill, and thus many are allowed to die without a vote.
Since 1991, the state has taxed natural gas purchases from other states at 4.25 percent. The tax generates $18 million a year, little more than a rounding error in the state's $35 billion-a-year general fund.
The tax law exempted the state's giant regional utilities, which own most of the major gas-fired power plants and produce most of the state's electricity.
But New York, like many states, is reshaping the power industry, and one of the first steps will be to force the utilities to sell their power plants. The first round of sales is scheduled for this month. Once those plants are sold, their gas purchases will no longer be exempt from the tax because they will no longer be utility-owned.
Independent power producers -- plant owners that do not directly serve customers, but sell their power to the utilities -- pay the tax. But the law makes the utilities reimburse these producers for the tax and pass the cost on to customers.
The changes under way in the industry mean that the independents will not be selling power exclusively, or even primarily, to the utilities, so they will no longer be reimbursed the cost of the tax. Instead, they will sell directly to customers, or to middlemen, or to the new owners of the plants the utilities are selling off.
Just as the independent power producers begin having to absorb the cost of the gas tax, they will be forced into a new, competitive market, with power producers from around the country trying to undercut one another's prices.
"Ninety-five percent of the cost of operating a plant is the cost of gas, and the margins between competing suppliers are going to be in tenths of a percent, so a 4.25-percent tax is enormously damaging," Ms. Murphy of the power producers' group said.
Environmentalists want the tax repealed so that gas can prevail over coal in the power industry. "Natural gas is much, much cleaner than coal," said Ashok Gupta, an economist with the Natural Resources Defense Council. "We're about to put gas at a competitive disadvantage."

HEADLINE: CLINTON IN CHINA: THE OVERVIEW;
Clinton Vows to Help an Asia in Crisis

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: HONG KONG, Friday, July 3

 BODY:
President Clinton said today that "cronyism, corruption and overextended credit," unchecked by competent financial regulation, had led to the economic maelstrom now sweeping Asia and has spread to Hong Kong, plunging it into its deepest recession in decades.
"The crisis has touched nearly all the nations and households of Asia," Mr. Clinton said in an address at the soaring harbor-front Hong Kong convention center. "Restoring economic growth and confidence will not be easy, but the United States will do all we can to help any Asian government work its way back to financial health." 
 In the first comment by an American official on the steps outlined by Japan on Thursday to deal with its banking crisis, Mr. Clinton today endorsed the proposals, which are intended to create an emergency $200 billion fund to protect businesses and depositors in need of bridge loans to weather the financial storm. He called Tokyo's program "potentially quite significant" and said the United States welcomed it as a partial means to ease the impact of the crisis on the region.
Mr. Clinton also praised Beijing, as he has several times on this nine-day trip to China, for what he called the "disciplined and wise policy" of resisting the temptation to devalue its currency, the yuan, to boost exports and hard-currency earnings. Allowing the value of the Chinese currency to fall, Mr. Clinton warned, could lead to "competitive devaluations that could threaten China, the regional economies and the world."
Mr. Clinton spoke to several hundred business leaders in a morning event sponsored by the Hong Kong Trade Development Council and the American Chamber of Commerce in Hong Kong.
When he arrived here Thursday evening, Mr. Clinton pledged that the United States would do its part to lift Asia out of its economic quagmire.
"I want you to know that the United States considers Hong Kong vital to the future," Mr. Clinton said at a banquet where the chief executive of Hong Kong, Tung Chee-hwa, was the host. "This present financial crisis, too, will pass, if we work together with discipline and vision to lift the fortunes of our neighbors."
Mr. Clinton's visit to Hong Kong, the first by a sitting President, came one day after the former British colony marked the first anniversary of its return to China. And it gives him the opportunity to assess one of the grander experiments in modern political history: China's pledge to let Hong Kong remain a capitalist enclave in the world's last Communist empire.
These days, economics are overshadowing politics here. Hong Kong is suffering badly from the Asian financial contagion.
"Hong Kong is a world symbol of trade, enterprise, freedom and global interdependence," Mr. Clinton said, looking weary despite having relaxed earlier in the day on a two-hour boat trip on the Li River near Guilin, in south China. He used the visit to Guilin to discuss China's dire environmental problems.
Mr. Clinton praised Hong Kong and China for being anchors of stability in a region-wide economic storm -- a reference to the fact that neither Government has devalued its currency, despite the continued weakness of the Japanese yen and a wave of tit-for-tat devaluations across the region.
Mr. Tung, a shipping magnate appointed by Beijing shortly before the hand over, welcomed the President's show of support, saying that "what started as a regional crisis has taken on a global importance."
President Clinton met privately with Mr. Tung for 20 minutes before the banquet, during which they discussed the economy, according to the White House spokesman, Michael D. McCurry. But he said Mr. Clinton also pressed Mr. Tung to accelerate the introduction of democracy to Hong Kong by allowing voters to elect a larger percentage of legislators directly.
Mr. Tung, who long lived in the West, is not known as a champion of democracy. In his remarks at the banquet, he pointedly reminded Mr. Clinton that Hong Kong was a Chinese city. "The fact is, we are Chinese and were brought up in Chinese tradition and values," he said.
Today, Mr. Clinton sampled the new Hong Kong -- with a hectic series of meetings and appearances that brought him in contact with newly-elected politicians, both friendly and hostile to Beijing.
James Steinberg, the deputy assistant to the President for national security affairs, said the Clinton Administration wanted to demonstrate that the United States "continues to be active and involved and concerned about preserving Hong Kong's autonomy and strengthening democracy there."
But the White House has landed in a minor tempest over a meeting with Hong Kong's most prominent pro-democracy leader, Martin Lee. Mr. Clinton was scheduled to meet alone with Mr. Lee today, a move likely to displease Beijing. The White House barred press coverage of the meeting, except for a photographer. It said it would issue no public statements afterward, upsetting Mr. Lee and his supporters.
Mr. Steinberg said the restrictions were "normal practice" when Mr. Clinton meets with opposition leaders. Mr. Lee's aides said the White House was seeking to assuage the Chinese, and had originally balked at a one-on-one meeting, even though Mr. Lee has met Mr. Clinton before in the Oval Office.
If true, the White House may have ended up irking both sides. Mr. Lee said he found the decision "very odd, because it seems to me that President Clinton's whole visit to China has been televised. Why does he stop with me?"
After that meeting, Mr. Clinton was scheduled to sit down with a group of Hong Kong leaders, including Mr. Lee and three other popularly-elected legislators. Among them was Tsang Yok-sing, a former high school principal and avowed Marxist who heads the main pro-Beijing party in Hong Kong.
The President also planned to meet with senior civil servants, and the head of Hong Kong's Government-owned broadcasting outlet, Radio Television Hong Kong, Cheung Man-yee. R.T.H.K. has been harshly criticized by pro-Beijing people here for undermining the local government and being disloyal to the mainland.
President Clinton was among the first passengers to land at Hong Kong's new $20 billion airport -- touching down 10 hours after President Jiang Zemin of China dedicated the vast complex -- and became its first departing passenger.
Like some Hong Kong residents, though, Mr. Clinton expressed nostalgia for the old airport, Kai Tak, which was famous for the rooftop-skimming approaches made by planes as they landed. Mr. Clinton, who sat in the cockpit of a plane as it landed at Kai Tak on a visit to Hong Kong more than a decade ago, said, "It was one of the most exciting and uncertain experiences of my lifetime."
Before flying to Hong Kong, Mr. Clinton spoke Thursday on the environmental hazards confronting China. With the spectacular limestone peaks of the southern city of Guilin as a backdrop, Mr. Clinton said that 5 of the world's 10 most polluted cities are in China and virtually every body of water in the country is tainted with human and industrial waste. But, he said, China did not have to sacrifice its environment to continue to build its economy.
He urged China to build more energy-efficient cars, homes and factories. The alternative, he said, was further environmental degradation and ultimately, slower economic growth.
The President, addressing a small, carefully-screened audience at a park in Guilin, one of China's most popular tourist destinations, said that not long ago American cities were choked with smog and many of its urban waterways were seriously polluted.
"China's extraordinary growth has put the same kind of pressure on your environment, and the costs of growth are rising right along with your prosperity," the President said. "You know better than I that polluted air and water are threatening your remarkable progress. Smog has caused entire Chinese cities to disappear from satellite photographs."
He said China can take immediate steps to slow the damage. "We can use clean, as opposed to dirty, energy sources much more than we do; and we can adopt new technologies to make the energy we have go further much more than we do."

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Union Protest at Bank

BYLINE: AP 

 BODY:
About 200 union members and their supporters gathered outside a Manhattan branch of Banco Popular yesterday to protest the institution's role in the purchase of the Puerto Rico Telephone Company.
The protesters were angry that Gov. Pedro Rossello of Puerto Rico signed a law last month completing the $1.9 billion sale of the telephone company, pending approval from the Federal Communications Commission, to a group led by the GTE Corporation and including Banco Popular, a unit of Popular Inc. 
 Telephone company employees in Puerto Rico have been on strike for two weeks. The workers said the sale would leave 2,700 people jobless and lead to higher telephone rates.
Police herded the protesters, some waving Puerto Rican flags, into a 15-by-60-foot pen made from barricades opposite the bank on West 51st Street, next to the Fashion Cafe in Rockefeller Center.
Employees at the bank gathered in its lobby to watch the protest but would not comment on it.
Bank officials in Puerto Rico, to whom questions regarding the sale were referred, did not immediately return calls for comment.
