HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
JAPAN ANNOUNCES A PLAN TO TACKLE MOUNTAIN OF DEBT

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Friday, July 3

 BODY:
The Government announced a long-awaited plan today to clear away the nation's pile of bad debt in hopes of bolstering global confidence in Japan and setting the world's second largest economy on track for growth.
The "Total Plan," which still needs to be approved by Parliament, amounts to a program for dealing with at least $550 billion in problem loans held by Japan's largest banks. The centerpiece is a mechanism to allow banks to fail without provoking chaos in the financial system. 
 The Government would shut down insolvent institutions and turn over their clients to Government-run "bridge banks" to keep the credit flowing. It would also accelerate sales of depressed real estate held as collateral for bad loans. Shaky companies would close, thousands of people could be put out of work, and bankers could be prosecuted for financial misconduct. The Government hopes that the plan could be completed within the next two to five years.
Hikaru Matsunaga, the Finance Minister, announced that the Government was embracing the plan, shortly after it was approved today by a task force. Markets reacted cautiously to the announcement, which had been widely anticipated, while foreign governments urged that it be followed up with strong measures to put it into effect.
There has been growing apprehension that the Japanese banking crisis is now at the heart of Asia's financial problems and may also threaten the economies in the West and the long boom on Wall Street. And President Clinton and other American officials have been stepping up the pressure lately on the Japanese. In Washington, Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin said in a statement that the plan contained "potentially significant steps," but he stressed that "what is important is for the Japanese authorities to move quickly to translate this approach into concrete actions."
In Tokyo, analysts warned that because the plan would bring about a great deal of pain, Japan's leaders faced enormous obstacles in carrying it out.
"I think there's a great deal of will to clean the bad debt out of the private sector, and I think the politicians are committed to that, but I'm not sure the politicians are willing to restructure the financial sector and restructure the economy," said John Neuffer, a political analyst at Mitsui Marine Research Institute in Tokyo. "They are wonderful when it comes to passing around the pork, but much less willing to pass around the pain."
The benchmark Nikkei index of 225 stocks, which has soared over the last seven days on expectations of the plan and in anticipation of tax cuts, was down 90.81 points, to 16,380.77, at the midday recess today.
The Nikkei finished up 108.69 points Thursday, or sixth-tenths of a percent, at 16,471.58. But currency markets showed hesitancy, weakening the yen to 140.34 to the dollar from 139.17 in early London trading, just as Finance Minister Matsunaga was outlining the plan.
An outline of the plan, which is expected to be approved by Parliament in late July or early August, was disclosed by Mr. Matsunaga and other officials. They insisted that Japan would move toward a market-based economy and pull away from the convoy system in which all the banks support one another and move ahead only as quickly as the slowest bank. Masaharu Hino, head of the new Financial Supervision Agency, suggested that the Government would allow more banks to fail. He said the agency would take "strict measures" after it inspected the nation's 19 largest banks over the next few months.
"We will recover confidence in the Japanese financial system by severing ties with the past convoy administration and shifting to an administration of severe policing, based on clear rules," Mr. Hino said. "That is the main road toward the rebirth of the financial system."
Japan's economy has been languishing ever since the speculative economic bubble burst in the early 1990's, sending property prices crashing and bad loans soaring. For nearly eight years, both the Government and the banks have been sitting tight in the hopes that the real estate market would recover and their problems disappear.
Though the banks have been nibbling away at their bad debts, the problems have worsened with the recession. The Government has let a few banks fail in a controlled, ad hoc fashion, and it has set aside $214 billion to protect depositors and bolster the capital strength of the banks. But it has been loath to take drastic measures to solve the problem -- until now.
Indeed, officials used the English words "Total Plan" to describe the new measure today, perhaps because they sound bolder and more innovative than the equivalent Japanese terms. The effort appears to be modeled on the United States cleanup of the savings-and-loan crisis of the 1980's.
The plan tries to tear off bad debt from the banks through foreclosures on properties held as collateral and by encouraging the revival of the real estate market. It also aims to bring about a more open financial system by increasing disclosure in a traditionally secretive banking community and to impose greater rigor in the system by stepping up inspection standards and controls.
Insolvent banks will be allowed to fail, using a two-stage bridge bank. The plan will first put collapsed banks under Government administration, protecting creditworthy borrowers left in the lurch by the failed bank, while a merger partner is sought. Then the collapsed bank will be either acquired or, if no buyers emerge, it will be nationalized with public money, sending the bad debts to an agency established to collect bad loans.
The advantage of the bridge bank approach is that it insures that corporate customers of a failed bank will continue to have access to loans, reducing the shock of a bank failure. The disadvantage is that it raises questions about whether Japan, which has overcapacity in its financial system, is truly willing to let banks fail and whether the bridge bank system is simply one more way of allowing insolvent institutions to founder a bit longer.
Initially, public money will be drawn from the 30 trillion yen, or $214 billion, bailout fund set up in March at the Deposit Insurance Corporation, which will set up the bridge banks as subsidiaries of a new holding company. The corporation will then try to transfer the business to a healthy bank within two years, though that could be extended to five years. The total cost of the bailout is by no means clear.
One sticky point is how the distinction between good and bad borrowers will be made and whether bad borrowers will be rescued along with the good ones. Naturally, any client of a failed bank will insist that it is a good borrower and should continue to receive loans.
Japan is designing a mechanism that appears similar to the former Resolution Trust Corporation in the United States, which disposed of bad debts during the savings-and-loan crisis in the 1980's. In Japan, the Financial Supervisory Agency, which last month split off about 400 people from the Finance Ministry to inspect the banks, will be given wide authority to direct the process.
Critics of the blueprint, however, say the Total Plan does not address some of the fundamental rigidities of the economy.
"It's not a Total Plan at all," said Chiaki Nishiyama, an economist at the Hoover Institution at Stanford University who is now in Tokyo. "It's a very deceiving term."
Even if the plan purges the banks of their bad loans, many economists feel that a broad restructuring and deregulation of industry are still necessary to bring about a strong economic revival. One difference between the American experience and Japan's situation is that the United States embarked on the painful reworking of the savings-and-loans industry just as the economy was picking up. In contrast, Japan is beginning its plan as it sinks into a recession, and it is already spending $120 billion in fiscal expansion to bolster economic output.
"They might get a mild recovery out of this, but it will not be impressive," said Peter Morgan, chief economist at HSBC Securities Japan. "If there's a promise of a deregulatory effort, they can use fiscal expansion as a down payment. But a fiscal down payment by itself, without restructuring, is a waste."
Some economists, however, are a little bit more hopeful. Resolving the bad debt is the first step toward improving the economy, they say.
"First we have to solve the confidence crisis, and solving the bad loans is a starting point," said Heizo Takenaka, an economics professor at Keio University. Then, he added, we can "promote a deregulated, more transparent open-market system."

CORRECTION-DATE: July 31, 1998, Friday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, a front-page article on July 3 about a plan by the Japanese Government to clear away the nation's bad debts referred incorrectly to the timing of the plan. Government officials have not indicated when the plan might be completed; they did not say they hoped it would take two to five years.

HEADLINE: U.S. Rights Shortfall

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "Clinton, at Beijing University, Presses Call for Liberty" (front page, June 29): While it is appropriate to castigate China for accepting only those human rights that suit its own interests, President Clinton must recognize that even the United States continues to spurn rights guaranteed by the Universal Declaration of Human Rights -- economic and social rights that insure an adequate standard of living. It is not coincidental that the only industrialized country to reject economic and social rights also boasts the highest disparity between rich and poor and the highest child poverty rates among the industrialized countries. 
 That 30 million Americans are hungry, 5 to 7 million are homeless, 40 million have no health insurance, and 1 in 4 children lives in poverty shows how far the United States falls short of its commitment to human rights.
 
ANURADHA MITTAL
Oakland, Calif., June 29, 1998
 
The writer is policy director, Institute for Food and Development Policy.

HEADLINE: Getting Serious About Adultery;
Who Does It and Why They Risk It

BYLINE: By MICHAEL NORMAN; Michael Norman teaches journalism at New York University.

 BODY:
Bertrand Russell, the wide-eyed British logician, simply couldn't understand why people got so worked up about a little bit of dallying, why they seemed unable to "distinguish sexual intercourse from marriage as a procreative partnership" and simply wink at the former and carry on with the latter.
He blamed the "psychology of adultery" for many of the sexual woes of society, the misery, as he put it, that usually follows what the French call liaison intrigue. 
 Views about sex and marriage, of course, are complicated and often contradictory. Americans may be moralistic and conventional (to use Russell's judgment) but they are also tolerant. In the context of a good economy, for instance, polls show that Americans seem to care little about whether their President is chronically concupiscent. And perhaps this ambivalence, in part, explains why tens of millions of American men and women have had extramarital affairs or know well someone who has. Still, there is limited data and only a small amount of research dedicated specifically to infidelity.
"More than any other human behavior, adultery is cloaked in secrecy," said David Buss, a psychologist at the University of Texas at Austin.
Nevertheless, generations of cultural critics, writers, philosophers, clerics, politicians and so on have been trying to explain adultery, and now social scientists have joined them. So far they have assembled only a relatively small body of specific data, and although that work is often colored by ideology, personal experience and research samples too small to be conclusive, the ideas that are beginning to emerge from these efforts offer a fascinating peek at our roiling emotions, biological appetites and libidinous itches.
The research falls roughly under two disciplines: social demography (who does it) and psychology (why they take the risk).
One of the most reliable statistics on adultery comes from the National Opinion Research Center at the University of Chicago. In 1992 the center sent hundreds of interviewers to gather data on the sexual conduct of Americans in the National Health and Social Life Survey. In a face-to-face survey of 3,432 adults born from 1933 to 1974, researchers asked: "Have you ever had sex with someone other than your husband or wife while you were married?"
A quarter of the married men in the United States and a sixth of the married women reported having at least one extramarital affair.
Like all statistics, the data invited different interpretations. The sociologists who conducted the study wrote in "Sex in America: A Definitive Survey" that the figures show a "picture of an essentially monogamous America" and that "each individual spends most of his or her life with only one partner." Although marriage and Divorce rates may seem alarming, those in serial relationships tend to be faithful "as long as the marriage is intact."
More striking, perhaps, is this: Almost 90 percent of the men surveyed and 94 percent of the women believed that extramarital sex was "always wrong" or "almost always wrong." In other words, the overwhelming majority of Americans either practiced monogamy or aspired to it.
"People in the United States almost universally think adultery is wrong even while they are doing it," said John Gagnon, a professor of sociology at the State University of New York at Stony Brook and one of the authors of the Chicago study.
But the same data also suggest a different skein. The Chicago ratios applied to today's population mean that some 19 million American men and 12 million American women have entwined at least once outside the marriage bed. "That's a helluva lot of people being unfaithful," said Todd K. Shackelford, an assistant professor of psychology at Florida Atlantic University.
What is more, many social scientists think the Chicago percentages are low. "Can we really expect people to be honest about such a critical, life-changing event?" Mr. Shackelford asked. And his clinical colleagues agree. "We have to realize that if someone is going to lie to their husband or wife, they sure as hell are going to lie to a poll taker," said Frank Pittman, a psychiatrist in Atlanta who writes widely on adultery. "You're asking them to expose the worst thing they ever did."
Experts divide even more when they are asked why people commit adultery. In the last two decades, some social scientists have insisted that all human behavior is a product of millennia of adaptation, and increasingly human sexual behavior, including adultery, is being examined through an evolutionary lens.
When Helen Fisher, an anthropologist, began to study adultery in the 1980's, she found that "there exists no culture in which adultery is unknown, no cultural device or code that extinguishes philandering."
Intrigued by the conundrum of human mating behavior -- the preference for monogamy alongside the pervasive fact of "extra-pair copulation" -- Ms. Fisher, a research associate at the Center for Human Evolutionary Studies at Rutgers University, recently wrote a paper in which she contends that the neurochemical circuitry of the brain accounts for a person's sex drive, sexual attractiveness and sense of attachment.
 
Humans Can Love 2 People at Once
"The human animal," she said in an interview, "is built to love more than one person at a time. In other words, we are capable of feeling long-term attachment while we feel attracted to someone at the office or the club or on the street. We have neurocircuitry that can lead us to adultery, and we have neurocircuitry that allows us to say 'no' to adultery."
As Mr. Buss describes this idea, across evolutionary history men and women "have evolved short-term and long-term mating strategies." Each strategy has benefits for the species. Long-term mating, or monogamy, as it might be called, aids "pair-bond maintenance," or in acquiring the basic necessities of life, and child-rearing. The short-term mating strategy is adultery.
In men, Mr. Buss says, this is the evolutionary impulse or need to reproduce, to mate with as many different women as possible to make sure the bloodline, and thus the species, survives. In women, however, the evolutionary urge is harder to explain, given the risks: the loss of a mate-provider and all the resources that go with him. "The big mystery," as he puts it, at least in evolutionary terms, is, "what do women get out of it?"
And here he has developed several theories, among them:
*The resources hypothesis. A lover may supply extra food or better protection than a woman's long-term mate.
*The genetic diversity hypothesis. Here, said Mr. Buss, "a woman can produce genetically variable offspring if she has them with genetically different males." or, In Mr. Buss's words, "it's like hedging your bets in the stock market by diversifying your investments."
*The mate-switching hypothesis. Women "might use affairs if they have a mate who has fallen down, not providing resources or hurting the children."
Mr. Buss's colleague, Mr. Shackelford, says that "when the benefits are much higher than the costs, both men and women are wonderfully good at committing adultery." He quickly added with some heat: "Now, that doesn't make it all right. I'm married and don't want my wife to be adulterous. I don't care if there are evolved mechanisms or not."
 
Therapists Ask Which Comes First
Both Mr. Shackelford and Mr. Buss caution that a lot of their work is theoretical and speculative. And some prominent scholars have questioned the whole premise of evolutionary psychology, dismissing much of the work as hypotheses without a shred of proof. Among those who study human sexuality, particularly clinicians and therapists, the notion that infidelity has somehow evolved as adaptive behavior holds little weight.
Neil Jacobson, a professor of psychotherapy research and director of the Center for Clinical Research at the University of Washington, is designing a major study to answer one of the fundamental questions among clinicians. "We want to know to what extent affairs are being caused by existing marital problems or to what extent the affair caused marital problems that did not exist," he said.
The sociologists who conducted the University of Chicago sex survey feel they have answered this question. Edward O. Laumann, the George Herbert Mead Distinguished Service Professor in the department of sociology, said the data he and his colleagues collected in 1992 clearly showed that people get into adultery when the marriage is troubled.
But Mr. Jacobson is not so sure. "We don't want to let the lore from the culture or the clinical lore lead us into thinking we know the answer," he said. So he wants to know: Did marital trouble lead to the affair or did the affair cause the trouble? Do men and women react differently to the news? What makes an adulterer? (The popular wisdom is that women dally for love or emotional satisfaction, men for sex or pure pleasure.)
In Atlanta, Frank Pittman, a psychiatrist who has written often on the subject in books and magazines, estimates that he has treated some 5,000 couples in the last 38 years. Lately he has noticed "women seem to be having more affairs than they did 20 years ago, 10 years ago," in part because as they travel more for work, they have more opportunities for affairs far from home, he said.
"I've also started to see a few female philanderers," he added, "married women who have causal affairs in what used to be the old male pattern of find 'em, bed them, forget them, the kind of sport men used to brag about."
 
Testing the Effects Of Baby Boomers
Pepper Schwartz, a sociology professor at the University of Washington, is trying to test the notion that the baby boom generation, the cohort that began "the sexual revolution," came into adulthood with different cultural and moral values from their parents'. Using data from other studies and some 300 interviews she plans to conduct, she hopes to chart the details of baby boom love, sex and marriage, including extramarital amourettes.
Whatever she and the others discover, the subject of adultery will probably hold the species' collective curiosity for a very long time. Ever since Homer set Odysseus wandering and surrounded the faithful Penelope with suitors, adultery has been a major theme in Western culture. "It has fascinated people," said Professor Schwartz, "because anyone who lives a hidden life is fascinating. We're shocked and fascinated when we find out what is really going on: that lovely couple down the street is having an affair with that other lovely couple down the street."

HEADLINE: Think Tank;
Partisan Fires Burned Bitterly On July 4ths Past

BYLINE: By John H. Cushman Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 2

 BODY:
The hottest holiday argument this weekend may be between partisans of wet or dry barbecue, or over whether a day at the beach is worth half a day spent in traffic.
But there were Independence Days two centuries ago when the consummate celebration of American nationalism deteriorated into bitter disputes between rival political parties, exceeding even the political passions that seized the early republic the other 364 days of the year. 
 In a lecture this week at the National Archives, the historian Len Travers of the Massachusetts Historical Society described how the day became ensconced as a central rite of the emerging republic. And in his book "Celebrating the Fourth" (University of Massachusetts Press, 1977), he recollects an era from the ratification of the Constitution until the War of 1812 when, in some cities, the Fourth of July was strictly partisan.
In those days, a fellow could be beaten for wearing the wrong party's colors on his hat, and Boston routinely threw two separate celebrations, each controlled by one of the two contending political parties of the day.
Divisive partisanship at a celebration of nationhood seems as strange to a modern sensibility as if this year's celebration in Washington were to be divided along party lines: the evening concert on the West Lawn of the Capitol controlled by the Republican majority in Congress, and the afternoon blues concert on the grounds of the Washington Monument controlled by President Clinton and the Democrats.
Two hundred years ago, the Federalists viewed the revolution as beginning with the Declaration of Independence and ending neatly with the Constitution, while the emergent Republicans saw a dynamic, continuing revolution and thrilled to its echoes in France.
Although most American revolutionaries had hoped to avoid a slide into partisanship, the parties often sharply disagreed over economic and international policies. The debate colored relations with England and France as those foreign powers, still entrenched in North America, fought for global dominance.
"In Boston especially, these groups organized competing celebrations, to a large degree transforming the Fourth of July into an occasion for boisterous rallies for the party faithful," Mr. Travers wrote.
Indeed, as the oratory became more confrontational, the Fourth sometimes carried with it an atmosphere of potential violence. By 1794, during the negotiation of the Jay Treaty with Britain, Philadelphia's celebrations verged on mayhem. The treaty settled commercial and other disputes with the British, but was divisive because it favored Federalist mercantile interests and disadvantaged the French in their fight with England. Marching Republican tradesmen who supported France and opposed the accord ultimately retreated rather than fight the fully armed Federalist cavalry that mobilized to meet them.
The war of words, symbols and sometimes fists went on for years. One year a Boston merchant with Federalist sympathies roughed up a French diplomat who wore a tricolor cockade on his hat. The scrap of cloth was a provocative political symbol.
Mr. Travers wrote that the very idea of making the Fourth a holiday took hold partly because the political parties wanted more people at liberty for the contending rallies.
By 1800, the year of Thomas Jefferson's election to the Presidency, the Federalists were in disarray, but they still controlled Boston's city government and the city's official celebrations. By 1802 the Republicans were mounting regular "mustang" or upstart celebrations, and the competition persisted for the next decade.
Federalist oratory reverberated in the Old South Meeting House; the Republicans, not to be outdone, held their events at Faneuil Hall, with its own proud Revolutionary history, complete with Republican militia.
In 1806, after the Republicans trounced the Federalists in statewide elections, Boston's Federalist selectmen took revenge on the victors with the news that Faneuil Hall was "pre-engaged by the Federalists" for Independence Day, the next year and every year after. Driven out of Boston, the Republicans crossed the Charles River and celebrated on Bunker Hill.
Only with the War of 1812 and the peace of 1815 did the political winds shift enough to lessen this partisanship. From then on Independence Day was mainly a patriotic event, Mr. Travers wrote.
Nonetheless, he told his audience at his National Archives lecture to think about what modern Democrats and Republicans, or for that matter, speakers from third parties, might say through the smoke of today's supposedly neutral barbecues.
"The nonpartisan was always the ideal," he said. "However, the subtext was often partisan, and I submit that it often is, even today. Rituals have a purpose."

HEADLINE: Consulting Firm In Acquisition

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, July 3

 BODY:
Metzler Group Inc., an energy industry consulting firm, has agreed to buy LECG Inc., an economic analysis and consulting group, for $274 million in stock, to expand services to customers.
Under the tax-free agreement, which was disclosed on Wednesday, Metzler will exchange six-tenths of a share of its common stock for each share of LECG, or $21 a share, based on the price of Metzler shares when the deal was announced on Wednesday. 
 Shares of Metzler, based in Chicago, fell $3.125 Thursday, to $31.875, in Nasdaq trading. The stock of LECG, based in Emeryville, Calif., jumped $3.4375 a share, to $18.75.
The deal will allow Metzler to profit from energy industry consolidation by instantly expanding the services it can offer. It also expands Metzler's customer base and sites, adding LECG's 14 offices worldwide.
"There are tremendous synergies that our two firms can exploit, particularly in merger analysis, restructuring, modeling, derivatives and auction design," LECG's president, Thomas M. Jorde, said.
Metzler said it expected to complete the transaction in the third quarter, after receiving regulatory approval.

HEADLINE: Tokyo Talks Of Tax Cuts, But Vaguely

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: TOKYO, July 3

 BODY:
Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto suggested today that Japan might adopt permanent tax cuts in an effort to revive the economy and calm the financial markets.
Such a move, coming one day after Japan announced a plan to cleanse onerous debts from its banking system, would delight many investors. It would also please Washington, which has urged permanent tax cuts and other far-reaching measures to strengthen the Japanese economy and reduce the risk that the recession here will spread around the globe. 
 But Mr. Hashimoto's comment was vague, and on Wednesday, Kanezo Mura oka, chief Cabinet Secretary, temporarily chilled expectations of a tax cut by saying that it would be discussed only after parliamentary elections on July 12. Many foreign officials have also learned to be wary, believing that Mr. Hashimoto sometimes is in a position to promise more economic measures than he can deliver.
"I expect that tax system reform will be implemented on a permanent basis, rather than in the form of a temporary tax cut," Mr. Hashimoto told a news conference in Kumamoto, where he was campaigning for July 12 elections in southwestern Japan. "I believe this will materialize."
Mr. Hashimoto said in April that the Government would carry out a one-time income tax cut of about $15 billion, atop a similar tax cut earlier this year and another one effective in a couple of months. Today, however, Mr. Hashimoto made no mention of the size of the possible new tax cut, or whether the Government would simply turn the current temporary cuts into permanent ones. Some economists are also skeptical that any tax cuts will be permanent, because they say the Government will be forced to raise taxes in the near future.
Nonetheless, Mr. Hashimoto's comments lifted the benchmark Nikkei 225 stock market index, which was down at the opening by 160 points, the morning after the Government disclosed the blueprint to tackle the nation's bad debt problem. The index closed today at 16,511.24, up 39.66 points, or 0.24 percent, from Thursday's close. Other Asian markets finished lower, but the turnaround in Japan helped European stock markets rally. United States markets were closed in observance of Independence Day.
The yen zigzagged, rising to 138.20 yen against the dollar after Mr. Hashimoto's remarks. The yen had weakened to 141.03 at one point.
Japan's stock market has risen for eight straight days, partly in anticipation of a tax cut and hopes that the Government's blueprint, called the Total Plan, will clean up the bad loan mess in much the same way that the United States solved the crisis in the savings and loan industry in the 1980's. Indeed, the plan resembles the mechanism established by the Resolution Trust Corporation in 1987.
A day after Masaharu Hino, the head of the new Financial Supervisory Agency, which inspects the banks, said it would take "strict measures" if the big banks were found to be insolvent, doubts arose today about whether officials and politicians were backtracking. Japanese newspapers expressed concern that the bridge bank system, the centerpiece of the Total Plan, may not apply to large banks at the heart of Japan's financial system. Instead, the plan, which envisions the creation of Government-run banks that would temporarily take over the business of failed banks to help prevent chaos in the system, may be used only in regional areas, for medium or small financial institutions.
Kiichi Miyazawa, a Parliamentary member and former Prime Minister, told the Asahi Shimbun in an interview for Saturday editions: "I don't think the bridge bank scheme will be used for the big banks."
"But if pressure from that scheme leads to a re-organization of the industry, as through mergers, then we can say it was worth introducing the bridge bank system."
Mainichi Shimbun, a major daily newspaper, said in an analysis today that it was not so clear if there would be series of bank failures. It said a bridge bank might only be used in failures at the regional level.
"Even in the United States, bridge banks were never applied to major bank failures," it said. It added that one reason was that it would be extremely hard to find a buyer for a financial institution with assets of several hundred billion dollars in a short period of time.
Indeed, Finance Ministry officials today reaffirmed the Government's policy of "too big to fail," which is essentially an assurance that it will not let large institutions go under. The Government has bad memories of the collapse last November of Hokkaido Takushoku Bank, an event that provoked a sudden shortage of money in the banking system and fanned fears of a financial meltdown.
The bridge bank system would work in two stages. The Government would first appoint special administrators to run a failed institution and to support healthy borrowers of the failed bank while it searched for a merger partner. If that did not work, then the collapsed bank's business would be taken over by a bridge bank created with public funds.
Government officials said today that in theory the plan could certainly be applied to any institution, but that in practice it was more likely to be used in failures of regional institutions. Analysts echoed that view.
"The Total Plan may include the largest banks, but the real purpose is the small, secondary regional banks," said Brian J. Waterhouse, financial analyst at HSBC Securities Japan Ltd. "The major 19 banks have the largest number of loans, but smaller banks have a graver danger of going under."
One Japanese banker, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the process of devising the Total Plan and bridge bank system was driven by politicians, who mainly have their regional constituents in mind. The failure of a regional bank has a huge impact on that region's economy, particularly on the ailing companies that borrowed from that bank.
"We're going to see greater instability," James Fiorillo, banking analyst at ING Barings Japan, said of the Total Plan's impact. "It's not a straight and narrow road forward. It's going to be bumpy."
 The Government has been particularly sensitive to the markets recently, in light of the beating last month that certain bank shares, such as those of the ailing Long-Term Credit Bank and Nippon Credit Bank, have suffered. And it has criticized foreign financial analysts for publicly singling out names of weak institutions

HEADLINE: Pollution Puts People in Peril On the Border With Mexico

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK 

DATELINE: EL PASO

 BODY:
Every day Ciudad Juarez, the Mexican city across the Rio Grande from El Paso, produces 75 million gallons of raw sewage, much of which flows through irrigation ditches into the river, the prime source of water for nearly every community in both Mexico and the United States between here and the Gulf of Mexico. Ciudad Juarez has no sewage treatment plant.
In Tijuana, Mexico, near San Diego, a sewage treatment system is in the planning stage, but for now the city continues to discharge sewage into the Pacific, periodically requiring American health officials to close beaches in Southern California. 
 The North American Free Trade Agreement was supposed to provide the border area with billions of dollars to address air and water pollution -- and, in fact, both Ciudad Juarez and Tijuana recently had financing for sewage treatment systems approved by the bank set up under what were known as Nafta's side accords.
But nearly five years after Nafta was ratified, not a single environmental project financed by the bank is in operation. To the more than 10 million people living along the border of the United States and Mexico, the money promised for the region's serious environmental problems is too long and too little in the coming.
"What's happened so far does not at all meet the great promises that were made," said Beatriz Vera, a program officer with the Paso del Norte Health Foundation, which works to improve health conditions in El Paso, Ciudad Juarez and southeastern New Mexico.
No one disputes that environmental conditions along the border are making people sick. On the Texas side, rates of hepatitis, diarrheal diseases and gastroenteritis -- all commonly linked to water and sanitation problems -- are two to six times the state average. And conditions are worse on the Mexican side.
American officials say pollution problems along the border are especially daunting because the solution often lies on the other side, in Mexico. That is true for water pollution in the Rio Grande, stretches of which remain a dumping ground for human and industrial waste, and for air pollution like the gray haze that periodically engulfs the remote Big Bend National Park in Texas, giving it the smoggiest air of any national park in the West.
American officials trace much of the haze to a mammoth complex of coal-fired electricity plants in northern Mexico, about 125 miles upwind of Big Bend, but they have been unable to negotiate an agreement with Mexico to build scrubbers that would cut the plants' emissions.
Mexico remains strapped for money, and many elected officials on the American side are urging that the United States give it much more help to develop solutions that could help people on both sides of the border.
"We look upon the border as an economic and political dividing label," said State Representative Andrew W. Nichols, a Democrat from Tucson, Ariz., who also is director of the rural health office of the University of Arizona College of Medicine. "But disease knows no border. If we worked more collaboratively with the Mexican Government, if we took that broader perspective, we'd be helping our own people. It's not just generosity; it's self-interest."
But spending American money on projects like sewage treatment plants in another country is a sticky diplomatic and political issue.
"It's very hard to convince Congress we need money to deal with problems that seem to be in Mexico," said Doug Farquhar, an expert on environmental health issues for the National Conference of State Legislatures.
For that reason, Nafta provided for a binational agency, the Border Environment Cooperation Commission in Ciudad Juarez, to certify cleanup projects, and a $450 million commitment from both nations for a bank to finance the work. President Clinton and other proponents of the free-trade pact said the bank, the North American Development Bank, could use its lending authority to leverage up to $8 billion for the projects.
But the devaluation of the peso in 1994 forced many Mexican communities to curtail plans for landfills and sewage treatment plants, even with low-interest loans available. In other cases, Mexican officials have disagreed over what technological steps are needed to fix the problems.
The commission has certified 21 environmental projects costing $473 million, including the sewage treatment plants in Tijuana and Ciudad Juarez. But the bank has provided only a fraction of the money so far, and no project is operating yet.
Some experts contend that Nafta's environmental side accords were flawed from the start because they did not provide a specific way for Mexican or American cities to identify tax revenue from new commercial activity generated by the pact's removal of trade barriers.
"There's still no system in place by which the growth, especially on the Mexican side, can begin to pay for itself," said Mary E. Kelly, director of the Texas Center for Policy Studies, an environmental research group that has conducted extensive studies of the border's environment.
Not all of the problems originate south of the border. Mexican officials express outrage over Texas's plans for a low-level radioactive waste dump in Sierra Blanca, a town 80 miles east of here near the border, and that anger has hampered negotiations on air pollution in Big Bend and on other cross-border problems.
Part of the border's environmental problem is simply the population growth on both sides. It is most striking in Mexico; Ciudad Juarez, for example, which had 250,000 people in 1960, now has five times that number. The overall border population has more than doubled, to more than 10 million, and is expected to double again in the next 10 years.
Even as they express frustration over the belated progress, some experts here see signs of hope in the fact that the development bank is approving loans, like the $31.2 million for the first two waste-water treatment plants in Ciudad Juarez's history.
"It's slow, but this is much more than a technical problem," said Jim VanDerslice, a professor of environmental sciences at the University of Texas-Houston School of Public Health at El Paso. "It's politics, it's people, it's organizations. When you're working binationally, it's just difficult."
Officials in charge of cleanup plans say they are working as fast as they can. "A lot of people would say it's slower than expected," said Angeles Villarreal, a spokeswoman for the cooperation commission. "But once you are working on these problems, you realize that it takes awhile. These are complicated issues."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Paper Makers Pursuing a Venture in Korea

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, July 3

 BODY:
Abitibi-Consolidated Inc. of Canada and Norske Skogindustrier A.S. of Norway, two big paper makers, said today that they were in talks with the Hansol Paper Company, South Korea's largest paper maker, to form a joint venture.
Abitibi, based in Montreal, is the world's largest exporter of newsprint. An investment in Hansol could leave more than 65 percent of South Korea's paper industry in foreign hands. 
 Norske earlier agreed to buy the Shinho Paper Manufacturing Company's plant for $174 million, while Bowater Inc. of the United States agreed to buy a newsprint mill owned by the Halla Pulp and Paper Company for $175 million.
Abitibi, Norske and other foreign companies are betting that demand from regional newspapers will increase once Asia's economic problems recede. Other non-Asian newsprint makers are also vying to capture more market share in the region.

HEADLINE: CLINTON IN CHINA: THE OUTLOOK;
Among Hosts, Much Elation

BYLINE: By ERIK ECKHOLM 

DATELINE: BEIJING, July 3

 BODY:
The Chinese, from the top leaders to the man in the street, were elated with the nine-day visit by an American President who struck many here as vibrant and empathetic.
No matter that President Clinton lectured China, gently but firmly, about the merits of freedom, called the bloody 1989 crackdown on demonstrators wrong and praised the Dalai Lama, who is usually portrayed here as a villain. He seemed to come as a respectful friend. 
 President Jiang Zemin's startling, self-confident decision to allow Mr. Clinton to speak on live television only added to the sense of excitement. "In the view of most people here this signals a new acceptance of China after 1989," said Zhang Xiaojin, an international relations expert at the People's University.
The White House, facing mounting complaints at home that it is coddling the Chinese at the expense of American values and interests, and the Chinese, who want American trade, investment, technology and respect, had congruent interests in this state visit. That was to improve China's image in the United States, showing its diversity and social changes and growing freedoms in the personal realm.
In that, the visit appears to have been a success. And it was President Jiang's insight to recognize that a major concession, like the televising of the Jiang-Clinton news conference and Mr. Clinton's Beijing University speech, was needed to make it so.
"This prevented Clinton from coming back with egg on his face," said Roderick MacFarquhar, a China expert at Harvard University.
The visit has certainly bolstered the status here of President Jiang. Equally important, it gives a boost to the many other pragmatic officials, from Prime Minister Zhu Rongji on down, who believe that the success of their transition to an advanced, market-oriented economy depends on better ties with the undisputed economic and political superpower, the United States.
Despite the paucity of diplomatic breakthroughs at the summit meeting, the friendly, tactful demeanor of President Clinton and Mr. Jiang's bold decision to temporarily loosen the usual tight controls on political discourse helped create a happy feeling about Chinese-American relations.
But elation is hard to follow up on, and the Chinese could be in for morning-after dismay when the unresolved differences rear up again.
These include America's huge and growing trade deficit with China and its refusal to consider Chinese admission to the World Trade Organization until painful changes are made to open markets. American concerns over political and religious freedoms may have been muffled this week, but China is not about to become a liberal democracy, and concerns about weapons proliferation have not yet been fully satisfied.
Because of its own economic cycle, its efforts to revamp the vast state-run economic sector and the Asian financial crisis, China may be in for a rough economic period in any case. Seeing no rush of American trade and investment and high technology, some of this week's cheering citizens here may become disillusioned.
Still, the old-guard Communist hard-liners in the Government who might lead an anti-American reaction seem to have been routed from real influence over the last year by Mr. Jiang and the pragmatists.
Chinese officials and experts, sounding quite like American officials on the subject, say they hope that the good will and low-profile technical ties forged by the reciprocal state visits will help the two countries live through their differences.
"The problems are still here," said Xiong Zhiyong, dean of the Foreign Affairs College in Beijing. "But I think both sides now understand each other better."
The hope, in Beijing as well as in the White House, is that an overarching sense of partnership will enable these two giants to avoid dangerous conflict -- a military confrontation over Taiwan being the worst case -- and to reap mutual economic benefits. American officials, rightly or wrongly, also believe that by engaging China they will nudge it to become more open and democratic.
Chinese people, like Americans, are pondering the meaning of President Jiang's decision to allow the televising of an extended discussion of Tibet, human rights and the 1989 killings in and around Tiananmen Square. It was done in the most tentative of ways: there was no announcement before hand, insuring a small Saturday-noon audience, and Mr. Clinton's most direct words on 1989 and the Dalai Lama and democracy were not reported in the official news media.
It is unclear how this limited but genuine public airing will play out -- whether the Government will feel emboldened to allow more free debate at home, whether people's expectations of free speech will change.
But there is no doubt about the short-term gains, for China as well as for Mr. Clinton.
"The cost to China was relatively small compared to the benefits," said Yasheng Huang, a Chinese-born political economist at the Harvard Business School. "The American public and media were happy with the trip."
Mr. Clinton kept the costs for China down, and avoided a more defensive reaction, by holding back on some sensitive topics, said Mr. MacFarquhar of Harvard. For example, he might have spoken about Taiwan's heady democracy, or pointed to the student-led downfall of President Suharto in Indonesia as a grim example to the Chinese leaders, who brook no opposition themselves.
In his final remarks in Hong Kong, Mr. Clinton seemed to credit China's leaders with a stronger commitment to radical political change than they have ever revealed to their countrymen. He said Mr. Jiang and Prime Minister Zhu were "the right leadership at the right time" and are "clearly committed to reform."
Whether that is an accurate assessment of these longtime Communists whose reforms, so far, seem more designed to save the party's rule than to destroy it remains to be seen. At a minimum, Mr. Clinton's American-style politicking may change a new generation's expectations of its leaders.
"President Clinton was widely admired for his directness, quick wit and frankness," said Mr. Zhang, the People's University professor. "Most importantly, he stood out here in his youth."

HEADLINE: CLINTON IN CHINA: THE OVERVIEW;
CLINTON OPTIMISTIC ON CHINA'S FUTURE AS HE HEADS HOME

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: HONG KONG, July 3

 BODY:
President Clinton today called Jiang Zemin, the President of China, a visionary leader who could be the figure who leads China to democracy.
Mr. Clinton, in a news conference that closed his nine-day trip to China, gave a vigorous personal endorsement of the Chinese President, saying Mr. Jiang has the imagination needed to transform China from a single-party Communist state to a pluralistic democracy. 
 The President also praised Premier Zhu Rongji, the architect of China's current economic policies, saying, "There's a very good chance that China has the right leadership at the right time."
Mr. Clinton has sounded increasingly hopeful about China's future as his trip progressed, offering his most optimistic assessment of the nation's political prospects just before departing to return to Washington to celebrate Independence Day.
But his words could come back to haunt him should repression in China harden, leaving Mr. Clinton open to the charges that he was taken in by a seemingly open Mr. Jiang.
Asked whether there will ever be democracy in China, Mr. Clinton said, "Oh, yes, I believe there can be, and I believe there will be.
"And what I would like to see is the present Government -- headed by this President and this Premier, who are clearly committed to reform -- ride the wave of change and take China fully into the 21st century and basically dismantle the resistance to it," he added. "I believe they are."
The President answered questions for 43 minutes, most of them on his trip to China but others touching on the troubled Japanese economy, the prospect of violence in Ireland this weekend and the continuing ethnic bloodshed in Kosovo.
Mr. Clinton offered an overwhelmingly positive summation of his five-city journey through China.
He said that profound differences remain between China and the United States on questions of individual liberty, and he warned that powerful forces still oppose change here.
But he defended his engagement with the Chinese leadership as the course most likely to yield progress on a range of issues from human rights to the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction.
The coming months and years will tell whether these few days in early summer were the beginning of a positive new epoch in relations between the United States and China, or merely a sideways step in an ambiguous relationship. There are groups in both countries with a political investment in confrontation rather than cooperation.
Whatever Mr. Clinton and Mr. Jiang say or do as their nations' leaders, they are but one part of a complex interplay between two diverse and dynamic societies, one that will be shaped as much by transnational corporations, the media, religious groups and even the Internet.
Mr. Clinton tried to reflect that diversity in his appearances here, meeting with villagers, middle-class homeowners, young entrepreneurs, scholars and students.
Absent from the President's schedule was any session with outspoken opponents of the Government. Mr. Clinton defended that decision today, saying he sought to deal with human rights concerns in China "in a way most likely to yield progress."
"I did my best to meet with people who represented all elements of Chinese society," Mr. Clinton said. "The decisions I made on this trip -- and, I remind you, the first trip by an American President in a decade -- about with whom to meet and how to handle it were basically designed, were based on my best judgment about what would be most effective in expanding human rights."
White House officials have said that Mr. Clinton did not want to risk retaliation against those who met with him and that he believed that pressing Mr. Jiang to release groups of political prisoners would be more effective than a theatrical encounter with dissidents.
Mr. Clinton, looking weary from a grueling schedule, said in his opening remarks that his trip to China -- the longest of his Presidency to a single country -- had shown him "the glory of China's past in Xian, the vibrancy of its present in Beijing and the promise of its future in Shanghai and Hong Kong."
"I don't think anyone who was on this trip could fail to appreciate the remarkable transformation that is under way in China, as well as the distance still to be traveled," the President said in the news conference, held in the ballroom of the Grand Hyatt hotel here.
He clearly was struck by Hong Kong's wealth and vitality, and said the region -- which reverted to Chinese control just a year ago -- could be the model for China's development.
He gave his most extensive assessment of Mr. Jiang and Mr. Zhu, praising them in elaborate language.
The President said of Mr. Jiang: "After I met with him for the first time, I felt very strongly that his chances of becoming the leader of China for a sustained period were quite good because he's a man of extraordinary intellect, very high energy, a lot of vigor for his age, or indeed for any age. And I think he has a quality that is profoundly important at this moment in history when there's so much change going on. He has a good imagination. He has vision. He can visualize. He can imagine a future that is different from the present."
At the same time, Mr. Clinton acknowledged that Mr. Jiang has constituencies who oppose him and who distrust American motives in engaging China.
To them, Mr. Clinton said: "I hope more of them understand that America wishes China well, that we are not bent on containing China, and that our human rights policy is not an excuse for some larger strategic motive. It's what we really believe. We believe it's morally right, and we believe it's best for them as a practical matter over the long run."
In response to another question, he noted that "democracy is a universal aspiration," an answer to Mr. Jiang's assertion that China's history and culture have led it to different definitions of human rights from those accepted in the West.
The President welcomed the recent release of several well-known dissidents, but said that he now looked to Beijing to release whole classes of prisoners. He particularly cited the 150 people still held on charges related to the Tiananmen Square democracy demonstrations that were brutally put down by the Government in June 1989. He also called on Beijing to release an unknown number of prisoners held for political activities that the Government has declared to be no longer criminal.
He said that in his talks with Mr. Jiang he had raised charges that China imposes abortion on women to enforce China's one-child policy. "They all say the same thing," Mr. Clinton said. "They say that that is not Chinese policy and it violates Chinese policy." Mr. Clinton added that his view was that "there may be insufficient monitoring of what is being done beyond the capital."
Mr. Clinton offended many in Taiwan this week when he repeated Beijing's preferred formulation of American policy toward Taiwan, which Beijing considers a breakaway province. But he defended his decision, saying that he had not changed the substance of American policy, which is to oppose Taiwanese independence and support peaceful reunification with China.
"I believe I did the right thing," Mr. Clinton said.
In response to a question from a reporter from The Irish Times, Mr. Clinton deplored the recent burnings of churches in Ireland and called for high-level talks among Roman Catholic, Protestant and British authorities in advance of annual sectarian marches set for this weekend that in the past have led to violence.
Mr. Clinton offered tempered praise for a package of banking and financial reforms announced by Tokyo in recent days. He said that Japan's economy had substantial underlying strength and expressed hope that the recession there would bottom out soon and growth would resume "in a reasonable amount of time."
On Kosovo, the President offered nothing beyond a hope that Belgrade would show restraint. "There is some uncertainty about who is willing and who is not willing to even negotiate about it," Mr. Clinton said. "And we're working on it as best we can."

HEADLINE: CLINTON IN CHINA: IN HONG KONG;
'Manhattan Of Asia' Indifferent To Clinton

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: HONG KONG, July 3

 BODY:
They call this city the Manhattan of Asia. And today, as President Clinton wound up his visit to China by motoring around town to give a speech, attend some meetings and do a bit of shopping, Hong Kong treated the leader of the free world with New York-style indifference.
"I'm not paying any attention to him," Chu Shu-san, a 48-year-old newsstand vendor, said with a shrug as he sold copies of papers with Mr. Clinton's picture on the front page. "He's just in transit anyway." 
 To be fair, Mr. Clinton attracted a good crowd for a speech this morning about the relationship between the United States and Asia. But the audience of local and foreign business leaders responded tepidly to his call for a speedier introduction of democracy to this former British colony, which reverted to Chinese rule a year ago.
"We debated this issue for five years in the 1980's," said Vincent Lo, a leading property developer, in a somewhat grumpy tone, as he rose to leave after Mr. Clinton's half-hour speech. "We know the good points and the bad points of democracy, and we know we musn't rush into it."
Mr. Clinton, the first President to visit Hong Kong while in office, came here three times before entering the White House, and he clearly likes the place. "I think it's quite appropriate for our trip to end in Hong Kong, because, for us Americans, Hong Kong is China's window on the world," he said.
Still, the 24-hour stop lacked the high drama of his televised debate with President Jiang Zemin, his freewheeling give-and-take with students at Beijing University or even the solemn welcoming ceremony at Tiananmen Square.
On a rainy day here, few people lined the streets to see Mr. Clinton's motorcade. When Hillary Rodham Clinton and her daughter, Chelsea, slipped away to do some shopping at Shanghai Tang, a boutique that specializes in updated Mao-style clothing, they barely drew a crowd.
Even "Primary Colors," the film adaptation of the thinly disguised satire on the Clinton Presidency, has flopped here. The movie, which opened in Hong Kong the day after Mr. Clinton arrived in China, has earned just a fraction of the box-office of the most popular current film, "True Mob Story."
One reason for the lack of drama is that Hong Kong's troubles are more economic than political. People here are worried about the swooning stock market, the plummeting value of real estate and the stability of the Hong Kong dollar -- topics that do not lend themselves to soaring rhetoric or street theater.
Mr. Clinton praised Hong Kong and China for not devaluing their currencies and he endorsed a $200 billion plan announced on Thursday by the Japanese Government to take over failing banks and protect depositors.
Of course the President did not ignore political issues. He applauded the record voter turnout in Hong Kong's legislative elections of two months ago, saying, "The results were a mandate for more democracy, not less, and faster, not slower, strides toward political freedom."
After his speech, Mr. Clinton met privately for 20 minutes with Martin Lee, Hong Kong's most prominent democratic politician. Mr. Lee, who lost his seat in the legislature when Beijing dissolved the body before the handover and regained it in the recent elections, told the President he hoped that half of the council's 60 seats would be directly elected in 2000 -- compared with 20 seats today.
Samuel R. Berger, the national security adviser, said Mr. Clinton listened attentively to Mr. Lee but did not express an opinion on any specific proposals for speeding up democracy in Hong Kong. "I don't think it's for us to get into the specifics of what the timetable of that might be," Mr. Berger said.
Despite Mr. Clinton's reluctance to talk numbers, Mr. Lee said the meeting was "terrific." He said the President responded positively to his argument that the "Hong Kong Government should be encouraged to develop democracy, so they can see that it works well under Chinese rule."
Later Mr. Clinton met several other democratically elected legislators. One participant, Tsang Yok-sing, the head of Hong Kong's largest pro-Beijing party, said the President "showed that he has a positive attitude toward developing a constructive relationship with the Chinese leadership."
After his news conference, Mr. Clinton and his family stopped off for some last-minute shopping on their way to Hong Kong's new $20 billion airport. The President's use of the airport is about the only part of his visit that has generated local interest. Air Force One landed six hours after the departure of President Jiang, who had been in Hong Kong to mark the first anniversary of the handover.
The Hong Kong Standard devoted much of its article on Mr. Clinton today to a discussion of the dual presidential flights.

HEADLINE: Rewards of a China Summit

 BODY:
President Clinton's visit to China, like most Presidential journeys abroad, was carefully choreographed to further the interests of host and guest. Both sides hoped to move relations past the lingering trauma of the Tiananmen Square massacre nine years ago, and largely succeeded. The trip also burnished the leadership credentials of President Jiang Zemin, let Mr. Clinton talk about human rights directly to the Chinese people and advanced the easing of tensions between Washington and Beijing. But the hardest issues between the two countries were not resolved, and there was a fair amount of show in place of substance.
Mr. Jiang has become more assertive and liberal over the past 16 months as he emerged from the shadow of Deng Xiaoping. He used his appearances with Mr. Clinton to present himself as a statesman who could meet on equal terms with the leader of the world's richest and most powerful country. More surprisingly, through his own statements and by allowing several of Mr. Clinton's appearances to be shown live and uncensored on Chinese television, Mr. Jiang signaled that he was willing to tolerate more open public debate than China has seen since the period just before the Tiananmen Square crackdown. 
 Mr. Clinton also embraced the opportunity for ceremonial statesmanship, a welcome relief for him from troubles at home. More substantively, he wanted to use this trip to show American audiences that today's China is too complex to be understood simply in terms of army tanks rolling through Tiananmen Square in 1989. By doing so, Mr. Clinton hoped to strengthen domestic support for building closer economic and military links with a country many Americans understandably see as a repressive dictatorship and a potential strategic rival.
Mr. Clinton's repeated declarations to Chinese audiences about the importance of human rights and individual freedom, while less sharp than they might have been, have won him some political latitude on these issues at home. But legitimate misgivings remain about the wisdom of American commercial dealings with companies controlled by the Chinese military and Beijing's alleged attempts to buy influence in American politics.
The nine-day Clinton visit marked a modest gain for relations between the United States and China, which were dangerously frayed as recently as two years ago. Increasingly frequent meetings between Mr. Clinton and Mr. Jiang are improving communication and trust between the two leaders. Last week's agreements on issues like retargeting nuclear missiles, working together to resolve the Asian financial crisis and restraining missile sales to Pakistan were largely symbolic, but at least sent the right signals.
Mr. Clinton and Mr. Jiang failed, however, to resolve some of the most serious problems between the two countries. These include the illicit transfer of American space technology to China, Beijing's reluctance to lower trade barriers to qualify for the World Trade Organization and the continued refusal of China to renounce force in its dealings with Taiwan. Having posed for their flattering photo ops and reaped their intended political rewards, both men are now obliged to grapple with these difficult but important problems.

HEADLINE: Obstructing Local Welfare Reform

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph Giuliani made the right moves when he required New York City welfare recipients to work for benefits and asked new applicants to exhaust the search for employment before asking for aid. But as he makes it tougher to obtain welfare, he needs to make sure that the city also has policies and programs that offer tools to move into the work force. Among the big inconsistencies are proposals to limit remedial work at the City University of New York, tighten admission standards and delay student workfare. All are at odds with the aim of preparing more people to be wage-earners.
The city's welfare rolls shrank from 1.16 million in 1995 to about 770,000 this year, partly because of the strong economy and partly because the city tightened screening and required able-bodied recipients to work in exchange for benefits. The rolls will shrink yet again when the city adopts a new system that requires people to search widely for work before receiving public aid. The new system has dramatically driven down applications in places where it has been tested. 
 While steering people toward the job market, however, the Giuliani administration has embraced policies at the City University that make the transition less likely. Over the last two years, for example, the city has steadfastly resisted a program to provide workfare on campus, so that welfare recipients might fulfill their work obligations without disrupting progress toward a college degree. The city will finally begin phasing in a campus workfare plan next fall, more than a year after the State Legislature ordered it to proceed.
Since 1995, the number of welfare recipients attending the City University has dropped from 27,000 to about 12,000, partly because of tuition increases and aid cuts, but also because the initial workfare policy drove them out. The new plan to limit remedial education at CUNY will hit these students even harder, making it less likely that they will acquire the skills they need to earn college degrees. Without degrees, they will be locked out of all but menial jobs.
Welfare reform can succeed only if New York's poorest citizens can get the skills they need to move into the mainstream economy. For that to happen, the city needs to make sure that the people who are being moved briskly toward the work force also have the broadest possible access to training and education.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Jerusalem As Levittown

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

DATELINE: JERUSALEM

 BODY:
So the Israeli Government announces plans to extend the authority of the Jerusalem municipality over the hills and towns, primarily to the west and southwest of the Israeli capital. It says this is to improve city planning and services. The U.S. denounces this as a provocation that could derail peace talks. The Palestinians howl in protest. The U.N. moves to censure Israel. But behind the scenes, everyone is still asking: What is this Israeli move really about? Annexation? Provocation? Better bus service?
The answer may be none of the above. According to the Society for the Protection of Nature in Israel -- which knows every hill, forest and stone in the areas to be brought under this greater Jerusalem umbrella -- what this is most about is real estate development. We're talking Donald Trump, not Trumpeldor (a famous early Israeli pioneer). 
 For the past decade the Nature Society has been fighting successfully to limit development in the terraced hills and Jewish National Fund forests to the west and southwest of Jerusalem, explains Yoav Sagi, its chairman, who, along with Israel Kimhi, a former Jerusalem city planner, and Avram Shaked, the organization's conservation coordinator, gave me a tour of this area where Jerusalem is to be expanded.
"Right now much of this land is controlled by the state and it is designated as forest and parks, with some open spaces reserved for farming," says Mr. Sagi. "In accordance with the national plan, you can't build on these lands, except with great limitations. We have managed to freeze many real estate projects in these areas, to protect the Judean Hills, the parks and nature reserves.
"This move now to expand the boundaries of Jerusalem appears to us as an effort to get around these restrictions," adds Mr. Sagi. "It seems that the real estate powers are hoping that if the authority for development of these open spaces is shifted from the national planning administration to Jerusalem municipal control, it will be easier to get the restrictions on building lifted -- because of the high cost of housing within Jerusalem's current boundaries, the influence of developers on city planning, and because of the political incentive to build Jewish Jerusalem. And once you get your hands on green areas like this, and turn them into real estate, you are talking about big money."
Real estate money has been known to find its way into political campaigns in Israel, noted Mr. Sagi, and some people are not above using nationalism to mask their real interests.
The Nature Society is fighting this urban sprawl everywhere. If you planted a tree in the hills between Jerusalem and Tel Aviv, visit it soon. It may not be there much longer, because by 2020 the area from Haifa to Tel Aviv to Jerusalem is likely to become "one big urban megalopolis," said Mr. Kimhi. "We build here like we are living in Australia -- more is better, bigger is better," adds Mr. Sagi, "but we're not Australia."
It's hard to stop, though. If current population trends continue, Israel, outside the Negev Desert, will soon be one of the most densely populated countries in the world. This population explosion, coupled with the poor use of land inside Tel Aviv and Jerusalem -- which results in these cities'building outward instead of upward -- is increasingly devouring the biblical landscape. The golden arches of McDonald's now dominate a prominent hill as you enter Jerusalem. If there were no Arab-Israeli conflict, the next big Israeli political party would surely be called "Green Now."
Israel can never limit Jewish immigration. But unless it gets much more sensitive about sustainable development, something essential to Zionism is going to be lost.
"Every project that is approved against the national plan, and destroys open space, destroys part of Jewish heritage -- the biblical landscape of David and Solomon's day," said Mr. Shaked. "The Bible refers to the vineyards of Ben Shemen. Today Ben Shemen is the biggest highway interchange in the country. We still speak about 'The Land of Israel' in metaphysical terms, but we forget about the actual land."
Adds Mr. Sagi: "We have to change the culture here from conquering the land to preserving the land. Because if Israel should one day become a normal country, with no more wars, what will sustain us here is the quality of life and connection to the land. But if we keep to this trend, we will have no quality of life and no land to be connected to."

INTERNATIONAL A2-6
 
Clinton Completes Trip, Praising Jiang as Visionary
President Clinton called Jiang Zemin, the President of China, a visionary leader who could be the person to lead China to democracy. Mr. Clinton spoke at a news conference at the end of his nine-day trip to China. A1 

Before leaving for home, President Clinton stopped in Hong Kong, taking the opportunity to drive around town to give a speech, attend some meetings and do a bit of shopping. A4
 
Diplomatic Push on Kosovo
American and French officials vowed to keep pushing for a diplomatic solution to head off a wider war in Kosovo, but they agreed that chances for success in the violence-torn Serbian province were uncertain. Richard C. Holbrooke, above, a special envoy to the Balkans, arrived in Serbia for another round of talks with President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia and the political leader of the Kosovo Albanians, Ibrahim Rugova. A6
 
Serbian forces captured the strategic town of Kijevo after a two-week siege. A6
 
Iran Marks Grim Anniversary
Iranian authorities marked the 10-year anniversary of the shooting down of an Iran Air civilian airliner by an American naval cruiser. Teheran brought relatives of the victims as well as journalists to the port of Bandar Abbas in a chartered Iran Air Boeing 707 and ferried them to the point where the plane hit the water. A6
 
The C.I.A. Sees a Weak Link
A classified Central Intelligence Agency report has zeroed in on early warning systems, starting with an obscure post in charge of contrarian thinking, in an effort by the agency to prevent future intelligence miscalculations. The report comes in the wake of the recent United States intelligence blunder in failing to predict the likelihood of India's testing of nuclear weapons. A3
 
Role Reversal for Mexico's PRI
The governor's election in Chihuahua, Mexico, tomorrow is charged with symbolism. Leaders of the PRI, the party that has dominated Mexico for most of seven decades, are running as the opposition. A3
 
Caribbean Legal Changes
Four Caribbean countries have agreed to form their own high court, abandoning a colonial system that made Britain their final legal arbiter. Barbados, Guyana, Jamaica and Trinidad -- all independent nations with varying links to Britain -- hope to establish the Caribbean Court of Justice next year, freeing themselves to reinstate capital punishment. (AP)
 
Toronto Police Found Negligent
A Canadian judge ruled that Toronto's police were negligent for failing to warn women about a serial rapist. The judge, Jean MacFarland, awarded $150,000 to one rape victim. Even after several rapes in the woman's neighborhood, the judge said, officers refused to put up posters about the attacks, fearing that that would ruin their plan to catch the rapist in a stakeout. (AP)
 
NATIONAL A7-9, 12
 
Florida Evacuates County Threatened by Fires
The entire population of Flagler County in Florida was ordered evacuated as four brush fires threatened to merge and trap the county's 35,000 residents. A few hours later, 10,000 residents were ordered out of their homes in Brevard County. The evacuations raised the number of people ordered out of their homes this week in northeast Florida to more than 100,000. No deaths have been reported. State officials said that about 124,000 of the 453,000 acres ravaged by the fires since May were burned in the previous 24 hours alone. A1
 
The source of the wildfires can be traced to the weather last winter. A8
 
Improving Food Safety
President Clinton plans to press Congress today to provide all $101 million he has sought to insure the safety of the nation's food supply, according to an advance text of his weekly radio address. Administration officials said that Mr. Clinton also planned to announce two steps that the Administration could take without Congressional authority: a requirement for warning labels on all packaged juice that has not been pasteurized or processed to kill harmful bacteria, and the creation of a national institute for food safety research to coordinate research. A1
 
Ex-CNN Producer Stands Firm
The dismissed producer at the center of the controversy over CNN's report on nerve gas in the Vietnam War defended her work, faulted her superiors and said that "strong interests" had "wanted to discredit this report," which CNN retracted. A8
 
Teacher Union Weighs Merger
The 10,000 delegates to the National Education Association gathering in New Orleans are to vote tomorrow on whether to merge with their union's archrival, the American Federation of Teachers. A combined union would create a colossus with almost 3.3 million members, giving teachers more clout in Washington and a single voice in opposing efforts to approve vouchers and end tenure. The merger is favored by the N.E.A.'s president, Bob Chase, but its approval is in doubt. A7
 
Nafta Projects Lagging
The North American Free Trade Agreement was supposed to provide the United States-Mexico border area with billions of dollars to address air and water pollution, but nearly five years after Nafta was ratified, not a single environmental project financed by a bank set up under the agreement's auspices is in operation. And no one disputes that environmental conditions along the border are making people sick. A7
 
Ban on Assisted Suicide
The Michigan Legislature approved a bill on Thursday that bans assisted suicide beginning Sept. 1, and Gov. John Engler said he would sign it into law, largely to try to block the activities of Dr. Jack Kevorkian, above, who has acknowledged attending more than 100 suicides. Under the legislation, assisting a suicide would be a crime punishable by up to five years in prison and a $10,000 fine. (AP)

Mayor Giuliani criticized the Administration for Children's Services, an agency he created two years ago, for allowing two foster children to return to their natural parents, who were later arrested on charges of raping and sodomizing them. He also criticized a family court judge and a private foster care agency. B1

Federal authorities said they had arrested five people in a scheme in which the suspects, working out of apartments in Manhattan and the Bronx, would tap into public pay phones at airports across the country and steal calling-card numbers entered by unsuspecting callers. HEADLINE: Ask the Jobless If Marx Is Relevant

 BODY:

To the Editor:
"Marx's Stock Resurges on a 150-Year Tip" (Arts pages, June 27) claims Marx probably "would not wish to be remembered today for having predicted capitalism's success," and asserts that much of what he called for did not happen. But Marx remains relevant because he was correct in his assessment of history, in terms of capitalism's success and its inherent difficulties. 
 Will the bourgeoisie "become their own gravediggers"? We will have to wait and see. But you cite the "recent layoff of 15,000 workers at Motorola to meet mounting competition, the 18 million unemployed in Europe, the growing disparity in income throughout the world and workers' increasing insecurity."
What does that suggest if not the creation of "an increasingly pauperized proletariat"?
 
BILL MICHTOM
Portland, Ore., June 27, 1998
