HEADLINE: Lack of Lifeguards Limits Choice, but a Beach Is Still a Beach

BYLINE: By ESTHER B. FEIN 

 BODY:
The lifeguard shortage that has vexed New York City this year, causing vast stretches of beaches to be closed, seemed little burden to holiday bathers yesterday basking under a sky of perfect robin's-egg blue, with just enough of a breeze to keep a kite up but not so much that it ruffled the pages of a newspaper.
Where a beach was closed with a "No Lifeguard on Duty -- Swimming Prohibited" sign posted, people walked, without a fuss, a few hundred yards to the nearest section where orange-suited lifeguards patrolled the waters. 
 But to a triad of teen-agers who had set out for a day on the beaches of the Rockaways in Queens, the closing of Beach 74th Street, because of a shortage of people who had passed the city's lifeguard test, was an affront.
Of all the indignities that could befall a group of teen-agers on a quest to be cool and aloof -- they were stuck going to a peanut butter and jelly sandwich of a beach, the kind of beach filled with little children and their pails and umbrellas and those incessant parental cries of "Put on more sunscreen" and "Don't go out too far" that they thought they had outgrown.
"Seventy four is supposed to be where everyone hangs out," said Jose Santiago, 19, from East New York, on a day off from his studies to be a computer technician. "It's famous. You go to 74, and you know you're going to bump into somebody you know. Now we got to go there with all those kids and the pails."
With that special sort of disdain teen-agers reserve for anything that reminds them that they are not quite adults, Charlie Collazo, 15, a sophomore at Bushwick High School in Brooklyn, complained, "We got to be with the families."
Kiki Ramos, 16, a student at John Adams High School in South Ozone Park, Queens, looked longingly at the swath of sand roped off with red plastic flags, then motioned to his friends to get over it and move on. "It's still the beach, man," he said.
Parks Department officials said yesterday that the lifeguard shortage was slowly easing. Through recruiting efforts and with high school students who had passed the test finishing their classes, making them free for midweek shifts, the city was able to open more beaches. Alas, not Beach 74th Street.
Michael Colasante recalled that when he was younger, all of his friends went to Beach 116th Street in Rockaway Park. "We'd hang out, listen to rock 'n' roll, drink beer," he said.
Now he's 32, an electrician in Local 3, married, and the father of 3-year-old little Mike. And so, he's on Beach 119th Street. "It's calmer," he said, swinging his delighted son in the surf. "I'm older."
Sharlene Rodriguz said she had gone out to Orchard Beach in the Bronx looking forward to the solitude of section one, at the very tip of the beach, which is radio-free and this year, unfortunately, a swimming-free zone as well.
"I wish it was open -- it's really quiet out there," said Ms. Rodriguz, a 34-year-old chef from the Bronx. She had to settle for section two, a few feet from the orange streamers that marked the closed area, but still, she had to admit, pretty quiet.
Being a lifeguard used to be the ultimate summer job, said Peter Cholakis, a handyman at Beach Channel High School in Far Rockaway, who was swimming with his children, Nicholas, 9, and Elizabeth, 4.
"It was the greatest job," said Mr. Cholakis, who is back at the same beach, 119, that he went to with his parents. "Now, not even the kids who grow up around here go out for it anymore. Now more kids are going to college and they want internships in their fields. The economy's good and there are, you know, classier jobs for them. They don't want to be lifeguards."
But Jason Carey, a 20-year-old student at John Jay College of Criminal Justice sharing duty at Beach 26th Street, said being a lifeguard was still the best summer job he could think of -- and this is his fifth summer doing it. "You can't beat this," he said, his nose already burned a light shade of tomato soup. "I'm getting paid to sit in the sun, at this point about $11 an hour. I'm 20. I live at home. I don't need much else."
A few of Marvin Mullings's friends wanted to be lifeguards; they just could not pass the test. "They're out of shape," said Mr. Mullings, 17, a third-year lifeguard who just graduated from Far Rockaway High School.
As if trying to minimize any bad publicity to the city that the beach closings had caused, none of the city parks workers in the Rockaways, Coney Island or Orchard Beach would give their names or answer anything more than basic questions.
"You can walk or jog along the surf and you can hang out up to the flags," said one parks enforcement officer in the Rockaways who declined to give her name. "But after the flags, you can't swim or lounge."
A few sea gulls disobeyed, but the officer did not seem to mind.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Michael Colasante, right, relaxed with his 3-year-old son, Mike, at Beach 119th Street in Rockaway Park, Queens, yesterday. (Edward Keating/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Mark Strengthens

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: LONDON, July 3

 BODY:
The mark rose today on an unexpectedly large decline in German unemployment and signs of tax-reform progress in Russia, Germany's biggest borrower.
Germany said unemployment fell by 120,000 people in June, double the previous month's decline. The jobless rate fell to 10.5 percent, before seasonal adjustments, from May's unadjusted 10.9 percent. The data suggested that Germany's economic recovery was finally strengthening the job market, and contributed to speculation that the Bundesbank might raise interest rates. 
 The mark was also helped after the managing director of the International Monetary Fund, Michel Camdessus, said Russia's threat to seize the property of Gazprom, Russia's biggest corporate tax delinquent, to force it to pay taxes was "a positive signal" that could help Russia repay debts.
In London trading, the dollar weakened to 1.8189 marks from 1.8205 in New York on Thursday.
In other markets, the South African currency plunged to a record low against the dollar for a second straight day. The rand settled at 6.37 to the dollar compared with 6.26 late Thursday, after falling to an all-time low of 6.44 earlier in the day.

HEADLINE: CLINTON IN CHINA;
In Upbeat Farewell, Clinton Hails Jiang and Sees Democracy for China

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from a news conference given yesterday by President Clinton in Hong Kong at the end of his nine-day trip to China, as provided by The Associated Press:
I know most of the American journalists here are looking forward, as I am, to returning home for the Fourth of July. But I didn't want to leave China without first reflecting on the trip and giving you a chance to ask some questions. . . . 
 Over the past week, we have seen the glory of China's past in Xian, the vibrancy of its present in Beijing, the promise of its future in Shanghai and Hong Kong. I don't think anyone who was on this trip could fail to appreciate the remarkable transformation that is under way in China, as well as the distance still to be traveled. . . .
Here in Hong Kong we end the trip where I hope China's future begins -- a place where free expression and free markets flourish under the rule of law.
Clearly, China is changing, but there remain powerful forces resisting change, as evidenced by continuing governmental restrictions on free speech, assembly and freedom of worship.
One of the questions I have tried to frame on this trip for the future is how do we deal with these issues in a way most likely to promote progress. The answer, I think, is clear -- dealing directly, forcefully, but respectfully with the Chinese about our values.
Over the past week, I have engaged not only the leaders but the Chinese people about our experience and about the fact that democracy is a universal aspiration, about my conviction that in the 21st century, democracy also will be the right course practically as well as morally, yielding more stability and more progress.
At the same time, expanding our areas of cooperation with China advances our interests -- stability in Asia, nonproliferation, the rule of law, science and technology, fighting international crime and drugs, and protecting the environment.
The relationship between our two countries is terribly important. The hard work we've accomplished has put that relationship on a much more positive and productive footing -- that is good for America, good for China, good for Asia, good for the world. . . .
 
Goals of the Trip
QUESTION Mr. President, from your staff to President Jiang Zemin, it's been hailed as a success. Are we leaving here with one symbolic agreement?
I wonder if you could explain to us what exactly or how exactly you'll show your critics back in Congress that you did reach your expectations on this trip. Thank you.
MR. CLINTON Well, on the substance, I think we have reinforced our common commitment to regional security, which is terribly important, given the progress I believe can be made in the next several months, in the next couple of years in Korea, and the job we have to do in South Asia with India and Pakistan.
We made substantial progress in nonproliferation -- not only in detargeting, but in other areas as well.
We got a significant commitment from the Chinese to take another step toward full participation in the Missile Technology Control Regime.
We had an agreement on the rule of law, which I believe practically, these rule-of-law issues, I think will practically do an enormous amount to change the lives of ordinary Chinese citizens -- not only in regularizing commercial dealings, but in helping them with other daily problems that impinge on freedom if they're not fairly and fully resolved.
I'm pleased by the science and technology initiative that we signed, which has already produced significant benefits for both our people.
I'm very pleased that we now have a Peace Corps agreement with China. And I think we have really broken some ground in cooperation on the environment.
And again, I say I think China and the United States will both have heavy responsibilities to our own people and to the rest of the world in this area.
I believe that the fact that we debated openly these matters at the press conference of our disagreements is quite important as well.
And I might say that a lot of the democracy activists from Hong Kong said that they felt that in some ways the fact that we had this public discussion, the President of China and I, in the press conference might have a bigger impact over the long run on the human rights picture than anything else that happened here.
I have acknowledged in candor that we have not made as much progress on some of the trade issues as I had hoped, but I also now have a much clearer understanding of the Chinese perspective. I think they want to be in the W.T.O. World Trade Organization I think they want to assume the responsibilities of opening their markets and taking down barriers and allowing more investment. But I think understandably, since they are also committed to privatizing state-owned industries, they have big chucks of unemployment for which they have to create big chunks of employment. And they want to have a timing for W.T.O. membership that will permit them to continue to absorb into the work force people that are displaced from the state industries.
So I have an idea now about how we may be able to go back home, put our heads together and come up with another proposal or two that will enable us to push forward our trade agenda with the Chinese. . . .
 
Campaign Financing
Q. Mr. President, during your news conference with President Jiang, he mentioned that you raised campaign fund raising with him. And I wonder if you could share with us just what ideas you expressed to him. And also, since he said that the Chinese conducted an investigation and that they found the charges were totally absurd, did you suggest that he might want to cooperate with Justice Department and also congressional investigations?
A. Let me say, he is interested in a very -- in what I might call a narrow questions here; but a very important one; and in my mind, the most important one of all.
The question here -- the question that was raised that was most troubling was whether people at high levels in the Government of China had either sanctioned or participated in the channeling of funds in violation of American law not only into the Presidential campaign, but into a number of Congressional campaigns.
That charge has been made. He said they looked into that and that he was obviously certain. And I do believe him, that he had not ordered or authorized or approved such a thing, and that he could find no evidence that anybody with governmental authority had done that.
He said that he could -- he could not speak to whether any people pursuing their own business interest had done that. He didn't say that it had happened or that he knew that it happened.
I want to make it clear -- he just said that his concern was on the governmental side.
And I just told him that that was the thing that we had to have an answer to; and that I appreciated that; and that if he were -- if the Government of China were contacted by any people doing their appropriate work, I would appreciate their telling him whatever that could tell them to help them to resolve that to their satisfaction, because I do think that is the really important issue.
Mr. Pelley.
 
The Dissidents
Q. Thank you, Mr. President.
Many democracy advocates were encouraged by your trip to China, and in fact, Bao Tung granted an interview to test the limits of Chinese tolerance.
But, sir, why did you find it impossible to meet with the democracy advocates in Beijing where it would have had the most impact? And would you feel compelled to intervene personally if Bao Tung is arrested after you leave?
A. Well, I have continued -- first, let me answer the second question first. I have continued to raise individual cases, and will continue to do so with the Chinese government and with the president.
I would very much like to see China reassess its position on categories of arrestees as well.
And let me just mention, for example, there probably are 150 people who are still incarcerated as a result of the events in Tiananmen Square who were convicted of nonviolent offenses.
There are also several people still incarcerated for a crime that is no longer a crime, that the Chinese themselves have said we no longer want, in effect, pursue people who have committed certain offenses against the state under which were basically a rubric for political dissidents. And I suggested that they look at that. So in all that, I would -- I will continue to be active.
On your first question, I did my best to meet with people who represented all elements of Chinese society and to do whatever I could to encourage democratic change.
The decisions I made on this trip -- as I remind you, the first trip by an American president in a decade -- about with whom to meet and how to handle it were basically designed -- were based on my best judgment about what would be most effective in expanding human rights.
And I think, at this moment, it looks like the decisions I made were correct, and we'll have to see over the course of time whether that is accurate or not.
Mr. Blitzer.
 
Abortions
Q. Mr. President, in the days leading up to your visit, there was very dramatic testimony in the U.S. Congress about forced abortions, allegations, reports that there were forced abortions still continuing in China. Did you specifically raise the issue of forced abortions with President Jiang Zemin? And if you did, what did he say to you about this allegation?
A. Well, they all say the same thing. They say that that is not Chinese policy and it violates Chinese policy.
My view is that if these reports are accurate, there may be an insufficient monitoring of what's being done beyond the capital and beyond the place where the orders are being handed out to the place where they are being -- the policy is being implemented.
And so I hope our presence here and our concern about this, which I might add was -- this issue was first raised most forcefully a couple of years ago by the first lady when she came to Beijing to speak at the women's conference.
I'm very hopeful that we will see some progress on this and that those who are making such reports will be able to tell us over the coming weeks and months that there has been some real progress.
Q. But did you raise it with President----
A. We talked about it briefly. And -- but they all say the same thing, Mr. Blitzer. They all say that this is not policy, that they've tried to make it clear. And I have tried to make it clear that it's something we feel very, very strongly about. . . .
 
Release of Prisoners
Q.Mr. President, if this trip is followed in the days or weeks to come by the piecemeal release of a few Chinese dissidents, will you consider that a success? And why not set a deadline for China to release all of its political prisoners?
And if I may, sir, you spoke a minute ago about the powerful forces resisting change in China. Do you believe there could ever be democracy here?
A. Oh, yes. The answer to the second question is yes. I believe there can be, and I believe there will be.
And what I would like to see is the present government, headed by this president and this premier, who are clearly committed to reform, ride the wave of change and take China fully into the 21st century and basically dismantle the resistance to it.
I believe they are -- not only do I believe there can be; I believe there will be.
Now, I believe that, again, on your first question, I think I have to do what I think is most effective. And obviously, I hope there will be further releases.
As I said, I would like to see not only targeted, selected, high-profile individual releases, which are very important, but I think that the next big step would be for China to look at whether there could be some expedited process to review the sentences of whole categories of people, because that would tend to show a change in policy rather than just the product of negotiation with the Americans.
In all fairness, while I very much value the role that I and our country have been able to play here, the best thing for China would be when no outside country is needed to advance the cause of human rights and democracy.
 
Taiwan
Q. Mr. President, the U.S. policy is push for negotiated reconciliation between the People's Republic and Taiwan. But some in Taiwan believe that by endorsing the three note you're administration is taking away some of the bargaining power that they would need in a negotiation. Does that concern you?
And can you tell us why you thought it was important to publicly articulate the three note policy when people in Taiwan were saying this would make things more difficult? . . .
A. First, I think that there may be some difference of opinion in Taiwan. But yesterday the Taiwanese leader, Mr. Lee, said that the United States had kept its commitments not to damage Taiwan or its interests in any way here.
I publicly stated that because I was asked questions in public about Taiwan and I thought it was an appropriate thing to do under the circumstances. But I did not announce any change in policy. In fact, the question of independence for Taiwan, for example, has been American policy for a very long time, and has been a policy that has been embraced by the government in Taiwan itself.
So, I believe that I did the right thing there to simply clarify to both sides that there had been no change in our policy.
The substance of the policy is obviously something that the Chinese Government agrees with. I think what the Taiwan Government wants to hear is that we favor the cross-straight dialogue, and we think has to be done peacefully and in an orderly fashion.
And that is, I believe, still the intention and the commitment of the Chinese Government. So I didn't intend, and I don't believe I did, change the substance of our position. . . .
 
Those Still in Jail
Q. Mr. President, during your trip -- in at least the first cities you visited -- we saw a sort of catch-and-release program of human rights dissidents, and of course, thousands of others are still in prison and labor camps.
Since you did not meet with them, sir, what would your message be to those who wanted to meet with you?
And to follow up on your response to an earlier question, why is it that you feel that it would not help their cause to have set down and met with some of them?
A. Because I believe over the long run what you want is a change in the policy and the attitude of the Chinese Government on whole -- not just on this, that or the other specific imprisoned dissident or threatened dissident, although those things are very important.
I don't want to minimize that. I'm glad Wei Jingsheng is out of jail. I'm glad the bishop's out of jail. I'm glad Wang Dan is out of jail. I think these things are important.
But what I am trying to do is to argue to the Chinese Government that, not because we're pressuring them publicly, but because it is the right thing to do -- the right thing to do -- that the whole policy should be changed.
And after all, our relationships have been characterized, I think, by significant misunderstandings, including a misunderstanding of the Chinese of our motive in raising these issues. And so I felt that by going directly to engage the Chinese, starting with the President, and especially taking advantage of the opportunity to have this free and open debate before all the Chinese people, I could do more in the short and in the long run to advance the cause of human rights. . . .
 
Assessing President Jiang
Q. Mr. President, you spent considerable time with President Jiang Zemin this week both in public and in private. I wonder if you could give us your assessment of him, not only as a strategic partner, but as a leader and as an agent for change in China.
A. Well, first of all, you know I have a very high regard for his abilities. I remember not so many years ago there was a -- the conventional wisdom was that he might be a transitional figure and after I met with him the first time I felt very strongly that his chances of becoming the leader of China for a sustained period were quite good because he's a man of extraordinary intellect, very high energy, a lot of vigor for his age, or indeed for any age. And I think he has a quality that is profoundly important at this moment in our history when there is so much change going on. He has a good imagination. He has vision. He can visualize. He can image a future that is different from the present.
And he has, I think, a very able partner in Premier Zhu Rongji who has enormous technical competence and an almost legendary distaste for stalling and bureaucracy and just staying in the same path even if it's not working.
So my view is that the potential we have for a strategic partnership is quite strong. However, I think that like everyone else he has constituencies with which he must work and I hope that more of them are now more convinced that we can build a good positive partnership as a result of this trip.
I hope more of them understand that America wishes China well, that we are not bent on containing China, and that our human rights policy is not an excuse for some larger strategic motive.
It's what we really believe. We believe it's morally right, and we believe it's best for them as a practical matter over the long run.
So I believe that there's a very good chance if China has the right leadership at the right time, and that they understand the daunting, massive nature of the challenges they face.
They want us to understand that there is much more personal freedom now in the practical sense for most Chinese than there was when President Nixon came here or 10 years ago. But I think they understand that this is an unfolding process and they have to keep going. And I hope that we can be a positive force there. . . .

("Three noes" refers to a State Department statement last fall that Washington did not support Taiwan independence, did not favor "two Chinas" or "one China, one Taiwan" and did not back Taiwan membership in international organizations made up of sovereign countries.)

SECTION: Section 7; Page 23; Column 1; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1425 words

HEADLINE: BOOKEND;
Say Hay

BYLINE: By Brenda Maddox; Brenda Maddox's biography of William Butler Yeats will be published next spring.

 BODY:
When the partner of the San Francisco writer Armistead Maupin first heard of Hay-on-Wye, he shouted, "And hold the mayo!" He was not to know that Arthur Miller had made the same joke years ago. Miller, when first invited to go there, quipped: "Hay-on-Wye? Is that some kind of sandwich?"
Hay-on-Wye should be self-explanatory: a town called Hay on a river named Wye. The little Welsh Borders market town sits at the foot of the Black Mountains, the long dark ridge that divides England from Wales. There may be prettier sights in the world than the 45-degree angle of Hay Bluff falling to the green meadows of the Wye valley floor. I just have not seen them. 
 At the end of every May, a throng of writers, readers, teachers and literary groupies descends on the town of 1,200 for the annual Hay Literary Festival. In the informal and intimate surroundings of a local primary school, enlarged by marquees during the Whitsun vacation week, they can sit at the feet of the likes of Alison Lurie, Toni Morrison, Muriel Spark, P. D. James, Maya Angelou, Jay McInerney, Stephen Fry or -- science being a big draw at Hay -- Stephen Jay Gould and Fred Hoyle.
As Hay's reputation has grown over the past decade, bigger and bigger international names have accepted the invitation of the festival's serene young director, the actor Peter Florence. Many Americans arrive without having a clue where they are. Wales, unlike Scotland or Ireland, does not rate high on the American ethnicity scale, and the Welsh Borders seldom appear on the tourist itinerary.
Once initiated, however, the celebrities tend to come back and back, especially if, like Arthur Miller and Lauren Bacall, they merit accommodation in the faux-baronial splendor of Llangoed Hall, Sir Bernard Ashley's five-star hotel with croquet lawn and helipad.
The stamp of approval of Hay as the most fashionable of British literary festivals has come from the Anglophile New Yorker magazine. For the past three years the editor, Tina Brown, seeing the Hay festival as the best place to meet the best of British writers, has flown in a team for a debate with The Sunday Times of London (the festival's sponsor) on a topic of burning interest. This year The New Yorker lost, not surprisingly, as its proposal -- "That the private lives of public figures should remain private" -- sounded dodgy coming from a magazine not shy of exposing politicians and stars.
To call Hay a "market town" is a bit of a touristic euphemism. Its market is secondhand books. Bookstores fill the town, occupying vacated premises, from a former cinema to a Victorian military drill hall. Increasingly narrow specialties are catered to. Balkan books, anybody? Try Marijana Dworski on Lion Street.
An eclectic architectural mix of Norman, Elizabethan, Georgian and Victorian, Hay is kind to its visitors. There is always paper in the public lavatory. But it is, and always has been, in a state of identity crisis. The English-Welsh border runs through the town, which has belonged, at various times over the centuries, to England, to Wales and to Normandy. Technically in Wales, its postal address specifies "via Hereford," the big English city 20 miles away, which offers the nearest train connection (three hours) to London.
Truth to tell, Hay-on-Wye is teetering on the edge of self-parody. A never-never land waiting to be turned into a theme park, it has already been turned into a kingdom. In 1961, Richard Booth, a tall, portly Oxford man, spotted the low-rent potential of some vacant buildings here and opened the first of a string of bookshops. In 1977 he crowned himself King of Hay and threatened to secede from Britain. The predictable publicity followed.
The King, as his friends call him, is a genuine eccentric as well as businessman. He lives in the 13th-century castle in the center of town. He has no difficulty keeping a straight face when, wearing a gilt cardboard crown and carrying a scepter made of a plumber's ball cock, he delivers a monotone harangue against the Wales Tourist Board.
When the festival began in 1989, Booth turned his back. "I never met an author who wrote a secondhand book," he said. Now mellowed by age, illness and success at founding book towns elsewhere, he has been spotted sitting in the festival audience and next year may even take part.
Feuds are endemic to Hay. King Richard's main opponent is Leon Morelli, a rival bookseller who moved into town, running his shops with less charisma but more discipline. The festival itself has split the town. When Peter Florence and his father, who founded the festival, proposed to build a permanent site along the Wye, local conservationists swiftly formed Friends of the North Bank. The Friends successfully fought to preserve unspoiled the view of Hay from the river as described by the Rev. Francis Kilvert, the Victorian diarist, writing from his rectory at Clyro on the opposite bank.
Kilvert's diaries, written between 1870 and 1879, have been called the finest diaries in the English language after Pepys. Kilvert, were he to return, would be surprised to find his walks in the Black Mountains now being retraced by devoted members of the Kilvert Society. Each year's festival opens with a Kilvert Walk. The bachelor curate would also be surprised to find pages from his diaries offered on the World Wide Web under "Famous British Pedophiles," thanks to his vivid descriptions of farmers zealously chastising their nubile daughters.
Maybe this overhanging clerical presence is what gives the festival a theological preoccupation. Hay audiences -- white-haired middle-income Middle Englanders -- are great questioners. When some 1,000 pack the big tent to hear famous scientists talk about the origin of the universe, what they really want to know is whether the scientists believe in God.
This year Richard Dawkins, author of "The Selfish Gene," was asked, "Are you still as godless as you were?" And, "Is the human race still evolving?" Dawkins's eyes rolled to the heaven he doesn't believe in, as for the zillionth time he heard the familiar questions. The answer to both was "Yes."
Stephen Hawking, the author of "A Brief History of Time," got the same treatment. Did he recognize the importance of the spiritual side of people? The audience clearly expected that a man in Hawking's predicament might need the consolations of religion. He doesn't. Slumped like a folded bat in his motorized wheelchair, he croaked out his reply on his voice synthesizer: "When the physical universe is fully explained by a Theory of Everything, we will not need 'nonphysical entities.' I hate mysticism. I like things crystal clear."
What has swollen the festival from a few thousand to the 39,000 or so there in May, including about 1,000 Americans, is its intimate atmosphere: a combination of summer camp and religious retreat. Big-name musicians (Van Morrison last year) and stand-up comics also turn up to provide night life -- not otherwise Hay's strong suit.
There is no need to go to everything at the 10-day festival to come away with nuggets of wit and wisdom.
Peter Carey, on being an Australian novelist: "Britain is the reality for former colonial countries. In Australia I grew up with a feeling of not being in the real place, that the real landscape was the green one, not the brown."
Armistead Maupin on "Tales of the City": "I'm a gay author. I don't like to mince words." (A pause, as laughter began to rise.) "I don't like to mince at all."
Helen Fielding on her best seller, "Bridget Jones's Diary": "It's a singleness-of-Diana book: a woman trying to be independent and it not quite working out."
Hay is worth a detour any time of the year for anyone who loves old books and doesn't mind rain or the smell of mildew. Even if you don't find the book you've long been searching for, its 36 bookshops are great places to come across the unexpected.
Local farmers used to scoff at the whole arty Hay-on-Wye scene. Now, with their beef banned on the Continent because of mad cow disease, and with the world turning vegetarian, they watch the rural economy decline. Malcolm Evans of Defynnog recently sent a poem to the local paper entitled "What Have Farmers Done Wrong?": "Working hard and caring lots / They used to be enough. / Now I have to fight the law / Cos it can get real rough!"
Would Evans have turned to verse if Hay-on-Wye had not been taken over by the literati? My bet is that in a few years he and fellow farmers will find themselves selling secondhand books.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 21; Column 1; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1470 words

HEADLINE: Two Views From the Greenhouse

BYLINE: By William J. Broad; William J. Broad is a science reporter for The New York Times and author of "The Universe Below: Discovering the Secrets of the Deep Sea."

 BODY:

Is the Temperature Rising?
 The Uncertain Science of Global Warming.
 By S. George Philander.
 Illustrated. 262 pp. Princeton, N.J.:
 Princeton University Press. $29.95.
 
 Climate of Fear
 Why We Shouldn't Worry
 About Global Warming.
 By Thomas Gale Moore.
 Illustrated. 175 pp. Washington:
 Cato Institute. $18.95. 
 A secret of science is that its luminaries have always done the easiest things first, contrary to many claims and myths. Newton ignored the messiness of the real world. His gravitational law showed that two planetary bodies could grip each other invisibly. But his mathematical rigor failed to account for the mutual attractions of three bodies, like the earth, moon and sun. That took the efforts of many successors.
Exploring problems of even greater complexity, Lavoisier, and then Mendeleev, helped reveal scores of chemical elements and their odd, recurring similarities. Darwin and Mendel shed light on the tangle of life. And in our own time, scientists are addressing such riddles as the substructure of the atom, the fate of the universe and the workings of the human brain.
Which brings us to climate change, one of the knottiest scientific problems of all. What we lightly call the climate system is actually trillions of variables in flux over billions of years. The factors include wind, rain, ice, clouds, snow, storms, lightning, comets, asteroids, sunlight, land size, sea currents, magnetic fields, cosmic rays, volcanic dust and life itself. In ages past, the atmosphere had little oxygen. But plants arose and changed that. The only constant seems to be variability, as suggested by the planet's erratic cycles of cold and warmth.
Can this turmoil be fathomed and its evolutionary path forecast? More important for world leaders, can we distinguish the natural changes in meteorological conditions from those induced by humans?
Scientists face the riot of variables only with the help of vast simplifications and the world's most powerful computers. To complicate matters, the field itself is in transition as the science improves and experts grow in number. Climate change was once viewed as slow. But recent studies have disclosed past temperature swings so sudden that in theory New England could have Miami-like weather in as little as 25 years. On the other hand, methane, seen as a major spur to global warming, now appears to be accumulating in the atmosphere more slowly than predicted, seeming to reduce the risk of crisis. Moreover, conflicting data are often communicated to the public by environmental zealots at either end of the political spectrum, obscuring things still further.
Into this wilderness comes S. George Philander, a geoscientist at Princeton who writes with skill and cool reserve. "Is the Temperature Rising? The Uncertain Science of Global Warming" is a careful, step-by-step look at confusing data and clarifying science. He is literate, quoting Shelley, Coleridge and Eliot. And he is reasonably sure we are digging our own grave, though he says so with such understatement that it is easy to overlook the doom and gloom.
Rather adroitly, Philander explains why scientists worry about the global rash of fires, generating plants and factories that release carbon dioxide at a furious pace. When sunlight bathes the earth and reflects back into the sky as heat, he says, the radiations have "so little energy that they are unable to interact with the diatomic molecules that account for most of the atmosphere." Such bypassed molecules are mainly pairs of oxygen atoms and pairs of nitrogen atoms. The trouble arises when the weak radiations are absorbed by triatomic and other complex gases, including carbon dioxide, ozone, methane and water vapor. These trap heat in the atmosphere, much like glass in a greenhouse. The question is whether the heat is rising and how much.
To address that puzzle, Philander examines issues such as those raised by clouds. If greenhouse heat evaporates some of the sea and increases water vapor in the atmosphere, the planet may grow hotter still, since the mist is a major greenhouse gas. But, he adds, if the added vapor condenses widely, the earth may cool, since white, fluffy, abundant clouds reflect more sunlight back into space. An added twist is that individual clouds heat or cool the earth depending on their exact form. Clouds, Philander says, are the main wild card in the warming game. Driving the point home, he asks readers to imagine computer simulations "as whimsical as clouds!"
The book's science is clear but formidable. We meet latent heat, quantum theory, the photoelectric effect, the hydrological cycle and plate tectonics, some explained better than others. Equations dot the text and pervade 13 appendixes. Many illustrations aid comprehension. But they, too, tend to be esoteric, with temperatures, for instance, always given in the Celsius scale.
Like a windy but stimulating uncle, Philander also takes us on detours, some tedious. Who cares why water is a poor thermometer fluid? But what fun to learn that weather experts around the globe release 700 balloons every noon and midnight Greenwich mean time and share the resulting data, friend and foe alike. People, he observes, are "more truly united in this activity than any other."
For all its detail, the book makes no mention of such current research topics as the extent to which the air is warmed by the sun's variable brightness, newly discovered in the 11-year sunspot cycle and suspected to occur over longer periods. Nor does it adequately explore whether terrestrial reactions to atmospheric upsets can curb greenhouse warming. "The carbon cycle amounts to a thermostat that keeps temperatures in a moderate range," it says provocatively, missing the obvious follow-up.
At the book's close, Philander draws together some of his strands and concludes that humankind is playing with fire. The problem, he concedes, is "enormously complex." But the balance of evidence, he warns, suggests that serious problems lie ahead unless we take drastic steps to curtail the buildup of greenhouse gases: "The growth is exponential, a dangerous situation that calls for action long before there is clear evidence of impending trouble."
Thomas Gale Moore, an economist at the Hoover Institution in California, rejects such alarm. "Climate of Fear: Why We Shouldn't Worry About Global Warming" argues that any rise in temperatures is likely to help Americans, if not poor people in the tropics. Moore's optimism is similar to that of Svante August Arrhenius, the Swedish chemist who late in the 19th century first proposed that rises in industrial gases might produce "ages with more equable and better climates." Of the greenhouse idea itself, however, Moore is skeptical: "The theory is weak and the models on which the conclusions are based cannot even replicate the current climate." For the sake of argument, he nonetheless assumes that moderate warming may occur, and he explores possible costs and benefits.
First, he reviews the growing literature on past climes and concludes that warm ones favored humans. For instance, balmy weather 800 to 1,200 years ago allowed people in Britain, Prussia and Norway to grow grapes and make wine. "Mankind prospered during warm periods and suffered during cold ones," he writes. He then looks at global warming in the next century. He faults doomsayers as exaggerating woes and ignoring benefits. In sports, he says, pessimists see declines in skiing but overlook rises in golf, camping, tennis, canoeing, hiking and bicycling.
His own tally for the United States from global warming estimates annual costs of $6 billion from such things as smog, wetland loss, hurricane damage and new dikes needed to hold back rising seas. On the plus side, he finds $99 billion in benefits from saved lives, improved health, new recreational and life-style amenities, lower heating bills, new construction and added water supplies.
He ends with an analysis of the costs of greenhouse curbs like those spelled out in the recent accords reached in Kyoto, Japan, and judges them staggering and silly. Moore, who was a member of President Reagan's Council of Economic Advisers, concludes that "the best strategy is to maintain the status quo, continue research on climate and help poor countries improve their economies."
Economics, perhaps no less than climatology and other disciplines that probe complexity, has a hard time foreseeing change. Its subject matter, after all, is people, whose behavior is famously at odds with expert prediction. Moore may be as unrealistic as the prophets of doom, perhaps more so. The truth is that we all live in a great climate experiment, the outcome of which, good or bad, no one is likely to forecast with any certitude.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 9; Column 1; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1495 words

HEADLINE: Rocks of Age

BYLINE: By David Quammen; David Quammen's books include "The Song of the Dodo" and, most recently, "Wild Thoughts From Wild Places."

 BODY:

ANNALS OF THE FORMER WORLD
 By John McPhee.
 Maps. 696 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $35. 
 About 20 years ago John McPhee, until then a writer whose graceful small books had reflected whimsical enthusiasms, muted concerns and discreet bemusements, decided to tackle something big: planet Earth. More specifically, he set out to describe the structure and dynamics of the lithosphere (that is, the planet's stony crust and the fluid mantle that lies beneath) as understood by the science of geology. Plate tectonics, the theory of sliding and colliding crustal slabs and of mobile continents aboard them like igloos on ice floes, would be his central theme. That theory had broken through to acceptance only in the late 1960's (decades after it was first proposed), rushing in upon geologic orthodoxy
like student revolutionaries storming the palace. Its belated arrival, and its astonishing content, promised the framework of a good story. Characteristically, McPhee undertook to tell the tale in an orderly, unassuming way: he would travel back and forth across the United States on Interstate 80, in the company of several well-chosen geologists, looking over each scientist's shoulder while he or she read clues from the exposed rock of road cuts. The jake brakes of speeding semis would serve as soundtrack for a paradigm shift.
As first conceived, this had seemed a modest project that would yield maybe a long article for The New Yorker, or a short book, representing "a sort of cross section of North America at about the 40th parallel, and a picture of the science," McPhee recalls. After a year's travel, he transcribed his notes and roughed out a structural plan, then saw that what he'd outlined was not one book but a handful -- enough, in fact, to "keep me writing for more years than I wanted to spend consecutively on the subject." So he chose to write them intermittently with other work. "Basin and Range" appeared in 1981; "In Suspect Terrain," two years later; "Rising From the Plains" in 1986; and "Assembling California" in 1993. Those four deal with the more overtly dramatic rock of America's eastern and western extremes -- the tectonically rumpled mountains, valleys and faults of the Appalachian region, the Rockies and the Far West. Characters and ideas reappear among them. "Annals of the Former World" now gathers all four together into the Gondwanaland they were always meant to be. It also offers a narrative table of contents, by way of preface, and a new essay titled "Crossing the Craton," which explains why the great American Midwest -- the zone McPhee previously left unexplored -- is not quite so flat and dull as it seems. The combined result is, in some senses, a big book. There are many pages, many facts, many nifty turns of phrase and deadpan ironies and many, many different names for varieties of rock.
McPhee has been fascinated by this science, it seems, since he took his first course at the age of 17. "I used to sit in class and listen to the terms come floating down the room like paper airplanes. Geology was called a descriptive science, and with its pitted outwash plains and drowned rivers, its hanging tributaries and starved coastlines, it was nothing if not descriptive. It was a fountain of metaphor." Given his own estimable talent for description, and his disciplined reluctance to stretch beyond it, the match of writer to subject might seem congenial. Then again, it's perhaps too congenial for comfort; he writes of geology with the ardor of an aficionado, not from his more customary perspective -- of ignorant but curious outsider to any given subject, standing as proxy for the ignorant but curious reader. Those geologists who early captured his admiration communicated in English as opposed to math, McPhee notes approvingly, and "they could name things in a manner that sent shivers through the bones." Maybe. But his own invocations of discordant batholiths, mosaic conglomerates, plagioclase crystals, stratiform gabbros, not to mention migmatite, tincalconite, szaibelyite and phlogopite, don't send shivers through my bones. Still, his prose is never less than musical, even when the music may be cool and opaque.
Of the four interconnected books, each claims its own wedge of the subject, and each features its own presiding expert. "Basin and Range" eases into plate tectonics by exploring the peculiar mountain-and-valley striations in Nevada and western Utah, with help from a Princeton professor of geology named Kenneth Deffeyes, "a big man with a tenured waistline," whose hair "flies behind him like Ludwig van Beethoven's" and who lectures in sneakers. McPhee joins the Beethovian rockmeister on a road trip in quest of insight and economically exploitable silver-ore tailings. "In Suspect Terrain" presents a skeptical critique of the airier leaps of tectonic theory, courtesy of a down-to-bedrock field geologist named Anita Harris. She fled from a Brooklyn tenement upbringing into professional geology and became a world authority on the mysterious little fossils called conodonts, a specialty that seemed hopelessly arcane until conodonts proved useful for finding oil. "Rising From the Plains" surveys the eloquent rock exposures of Wyoming, which reveal a taller column of earth history than visible anywhere else on Interstate 80 between New York and San Francisco. McPhee's guide here is David Love, known as "the grand old man of Rocky Mountain geology," who himself rose to eminence from an isolated ranch in central Wyoming. Finally, "Assembling California" follows the travels and thinking of a tectonicist named Eldridge Moores, by way of wondering where that state came from (it seems to have floated up in sections and added itself to the continent like a redwood deck) and where it will go next. Those, plus the new essay on the Stable Interior Craton, the flat fundament beneath the Midwest, are the major elements of this book.
But of course there's much more. To complement the living experts, there are deft cameo portraits of such scientific precursors as Louis Agassiz and James Hutton, and character studies of more obscure figures -- most notably David Love's diary-keeping mother, a clear-eyed pioneer woman whose ghost carries the narrative structure of "Rising From the Plains." In addition to the long expository marches through deep time and layered rock, there are digressions recounting the California gold rush, the legend of Winona the Indian maiden and the collapsing freeways of the 1989 San Francisco earthquake. As in any McPhee work, there are gemlike sentences, richly rhythmic paragraphs, nicely burnished synecdoches, metaphors as pungent as wasabi and, behind those felicities, vast amounts of painstaking research. There's the grandeur of plate tectonics itself, explained with exhausting thoroughness and, for the most part, clarity. Is all this enough to make "Annals of the Former World" a formidable and compelling book? Well, sorry: in my view, no.
WHY not? Because, though it's full of wonderful expository prose, it's virtually bereft of anything else. There's no argument, no urgency, no passion, no sense of larger purpose or emergent meaning, no point to the whole -- beyond the bland point that geology is interesting. (There's no bibliography, either, an inexplicable discourtesy both to readers and to the many scientists upon whose published papers and books this volume draws.) McPhee is an elegant stylist, but to say that his authorial voice is muffled and reticent would be an understatement. His work is full of ideas, though scarcely ever one of his own. He seems to stroll the world's landscape, alert but undemonstrative, keeping his hands in his pockets and his thoughts to himself.
About this signature self-restraint, there are two schools of opinion. One school includes those such as William L. Howarth (a Princeton professor of English and, two decades ago, editor of "The John McPhee Reader"), who venerates him for the fact that he "never confesses, rarely preaches," and therefore offers an antithesis to "the so-called New Journalists, those celebrities who parade their neuroses or stump for public causes," as Howarth grumbled in his introduction to that early sampler. On the other hand are appreciative but frustrated readers who wish McPhee would say more, give more, risk more -- that he would surprise us occasionally with a resonant self-revelation or a fierce conviction, that he would write with his whole person and not just with his brain. Of these two schools, I once counted myself among the first; but over the years since McPhee began publishing the installments of his geology opus, I've felt myself drift into the second. His rocklike consistency of method, his adamantine reserve have delighted me less and less. Undeniably, John McPhee is a master craftsman who simply doesn't make mistakes -- except maybe an elemental one: the mistake of impeccable caution.

PUB-DATE: July 5, 1998

SECTION: Section 5; Page 5; Column 1; Travel Desk 

LENGTH: 2759 words

HEADLINE: FRUGAL TRAVELER;
Seattle: Latte for a Little

BYLINE: By JESSE McKINLEY; JESSE McKINLEY writes for The City section of The Times.

 BODY:
TO twist the words of Will Rogers, Seattle never met a fad it didn't like. From the early gold-rushers who put the city on the map to the coffee-swilling entrepreneurs who made $2 java a national obsession, the denizens of the city by the sound have always had a keen sense of what was hot -- and profitable. While most of the world was flying by propellers, in Seattle, Boeing began making jets. And when rock and roll was fading, Seattle spawned grunge.
This knack for trendsetting has made it a favorite of the young and restless. I, meanwhile, have always been a little behind the curve, a man who invested in an electric typewriter just about the time that personal computers -- another Seattle specialty -- began popping up on desktops. 
 So, in the hope of gleaning a sense of the future from this forward-looking burg, I traveled to Seattle for four days in early June, just a few weeks after the blossoming of the city's rhododendrons, and just about when its notoriously wet weather starts to give way to more temperate conditions. I knew that such a short-term search for the Zeitgeist would probably be futile, but I also suspected I would have a good time looking.
I was late in getting a ticket, of course, and lost out on the cheaper 14-day advance fares. I checked airline consolidators, who acquire tickets in bulk and sell them at cut-rate prices; they were offering fares in the $450 range, tax included. I wanted something cheaper.
In the spirit of Seattle's favorite son, Bill Gates, I took to the Internet, checking a service called Priceline (priceline.com), where you name the price you wish to pay and then wait to see if an airline will match your bid. The process is advertised as taking an hour and a credit card; I had both.
My first offer was $300, leaving within a week from any New York City airport and agreeing to one stopover each way. I typed in my dates, my e-mail address, and my credit card number and sure enough, an hour later, the computer responded: No dice. I plowed through the application again, this time bidding $320. "Sorry," read the reply.
I had just about resigned myself to the consolidator ticket, but decided to move up my trip by a couple of days and try $350. Bingo: A $350 round trip, tax included, on America West, with a stopover in Phoenix.
My Rough Guide to the United States told me that accommodations in downtown Seattle generally were either snazzy or sleazy; decent midrange lodgings were usually outside the city center. I turned again to the Web, searching seattle.yahoo.com, and found an ad for the Seattle Inn, "the preferred economy inn of downtown Seattle." The site showed inviting pictures of an indoor pool and the Space Needle -- the symbol of the 1962 world's fair -- hovering just above the hotel's roof. The price: $60 for a single, with an additional 10 percent off for reserving by e-mail.
The final logistical detail was a car. A representative at America West suggested Avis, which set me up with a terrific springtime deal: $99 for five days and unlimited mileage.
Mind you, after a 10-hour journey to Seattle via Arizona, I was in no mood to drive. And the dusk and fog looming over the city made my first impressions fairly grim. The Kingdome, the city's aging stadium, sat hulking and gray to the left, while in the distance, the Space Needle seemed almost limp in the damp air, with two of its three legs wrapped in billowy pink construction netting. (Depression threatened. Ah, where is Frasier Crane when you need him?)
My spirits lifted when I got to the hotel, which had a motor lodge feel but a very friendly staff. My room was small and the towels even smaller, but it was clean, comfortable and equipped with cable. I thought about a swim; in that weather, however, the last thing I wanted to do was get wet.
I awoke to a sunny day and a view of the Needle, with its U.F.O.-shaped pinnacle nicely framed against a blue sky.
Seattle rises on a series of lush hills with saltwater Puget Sound to the west and the freshwater Lake Washington to the east. This sloped, spindly topography creates one of the city's ironies: While individual areas are pedestrian friendly, you almost always must drive to get to the place where you can walk. (Interstate 5 separates the east and west parts of the city, while a finger of Lake Washington separates north and south.)
The isolated pockets have fostered a mix of distinct neighborhoods, from the sedate elegance of Queen Anne, north of downtown, to the taste treats in the gritty International District, where Thai and Chinese food are plentiful. My personal favorite was Capitol Hill, on the city's eastern slopes, home of some of Seattle's most quirky restaurants and bars as well as a large gay and student community. I spent almost all of my second day there, on Broadway, and ate at two of the city's nicest cheap dining spots, the Broadway New American Grill and Cafe Septieme.
But my first day was spent downtown, where, still groggy, the first goal of the first day was to sample that dark, steamy and decidedly peppy local beverage. I quickly happened on one of many branches of a place called (what else?) Seattle's Best Coffee, on Second Avenue. The store offered all sorts of exotic variations, from the high-caffeine coffee coffee milkshake to something called an Oregon Chai Tea Latte; I chose a simple tumbler of house blend ($1.45). My haze lifted.
The first brush with a possible fad came right around the corner at the Three Dog Bakery, a new store catering to the untapped market for pastries, cakes and other delectables aimed at an exclusively canine clientele. Though the dog biscotti looked appetizing, I refrained and moved on to more human delights at the Pike Place Market.
The turn-of-the-century downtown marketplace was almost demolished in 1971, during one of Seattle's numerous fits of reinvention. Instead, civic leaders undertook a classy refurbishment, complete with red brick streets and flower-lined alleys. Its dozens of stands sell the best of the region's natural bounty, including just-caught Dungeness crabs, as well as pungent displays of cut roses and freshly baked bread. "Fish up!" shouted a wisecracking salesman at Pike Place Fish Company, throwing a giant slab of fish about 10 feet to a waiting comrade. "Get 'em while they're frish."
I also found a tourist-information stand offering free maps and weekly guides -- and, at noon daily, half-price same-day tickets on anything from opera to cruises. One of the best deals at the market is the Three Girls Bakery, a luncheon that is usually packed and dates back to 1912. Ihad an enormous sourdough and pastrami sandwich ($4.25), and trundled down through the market's four stories of shops toward the harbor.
While the waterfront primarily comprises kitsch shops and fish-and-chip stands, two diversions lured me in. The first was the Seattle Aquarium, where I bought a City Pass ($23.75), which equates to half-price admission to six different Seattle attractions. The aquarium's collection was modest, but swarmed by children. I was especially entranced by the clouds of freshly hatched salmon, all swimming in perfect rows in a circular tank.
The exhibits, strangely enough, piqued my appetite. I headed to Ivar's Acres of Clams, a Seattle institution founded by Ivar Haglund, an eccentric old entrepreneur whose motto was "Keep Clam!" Between the market's fish staff and Mr. Haglund's wit, I determined that bad puns must be an occupational hazard for Northwestern fish merchants.
I ordered a four-piece meal of fish and chips ($4.95) and watched the locals feed the gulls. "Sea gull lovers are welcome," reads a quote from Mr. Haglund, who died in 1985. "Please do not feed the pigeons."
A TROLLEY runs the length of the waterfront, but I walked inland a bit to Pioneer Square, a tree-lined promenade and the jumping-off point for a past generation of treasure seekers. I stopped into the Klondike Gold Rush National Historical Park museum (free), which gives a fine overview of the continent's last great gold rush. It began just over 100 years ago when the S.S. Portland docked in Seattle with two tons of nuggets. The rush petered out a few years later, but the crush of would-be millionaires buying supplies in Seattle for the trip north pulled the little lumber town into the 20th century.
As the crowds streamed south toward the Kingdome for a Seattle Mariners game, I moved north up First Avenue against the current (just like a good salmon).
First Avenue, downtown's main drag, is eclectic, reflecting both the progressive present and frontier past. Chic boutiques and the Seattle Art Museum (a City Pass locale) sit side by side with gun shops and X-rated movie houses.
Darkness was falling as I followed First Avenue uptown, stumbling into Belltown, an emergent district on the northern fringe of downtown. I counted six trendy-looking restaurants on a single block, complete with $14 entrees and skinnier-than-thou waitresses. I moved a little farther north to the Belltown Pub, a handsome bistro featuring two dozen local microbrews and $7 burgers. I chose a pint of something called Mac and Jack's African Amber and a cheeseburger.
I finished the night at the Crocodile Cafe, a bar-cum-club-cum-greasy spoon where local grunge legends Nirvana and Pearl Jam used to play. Decorated with giant papier-mache reptiles, the Crocodile had four bands on tap for $6. I listened intently, half expecting to hear The Next Big Thing. As it turned out, the first entertainer that night had been imported from Australia. Stomach filled, feet tired, ears sated, I retired.
I drove up to Capitol Hill on Saturday, catching the breakfast buffet ($7.95) at the Broadway New American Grill, a sunny, stylish diner with sidewalk tables and a collection of Miro-inspired sculpture. From there, I walked up Broadway, enjoying the colorful tile fringe on the sidewalk and the flowering dogwood and dahlias.
With Seattle University to the south and the University of Washington to the north, Capitol Hill is awash with young artists and music stores and coffeehouses that cater to them. One exemplar is Habitat Espresso, a petition-laden nonprofit enterprise on Broadway with weekly readings of plays, screenplays and poetry. I was a little intimidated by the T-shirt worn by the tattooed counterman: "Sit. Consume. Die." But the coffee was good and strong.
The remainder of the day was spent the hilltop views in nearby Volunteer Park (where I saw an exhibit at the Seattle Asian Art Museum), the park's Conservatory (where I wandered hothouse rooms full of flora, also gratis), and the Japanese Garden at Washington Park Arboretum. (Did I mention that the coffee was strong?)
After a quick portobello mushroom sandwich ($7) at Cafe Septieme, I bopped along with the bustle of Broadway, cutting along side streets and finally ending up in the Baltic Room, a 1930's style speak-easy with nightly jazz, a $3 cover and a clientele that likes to dress with an eye toward the Jazz Age.
I settled in sleepily at the lovely Gaslight Inn, a restored Victorian bed-and-breakfast with a sun-drenched deck and a small outdoor pool. My single room with four-poster bed and a shared bath was $73 a night, tax included.
Sunday was a consummate Seattle day: rainy. I took shelter in the city's museums, and used the City Pass to hit the Museum of Flight's fantastic aeronautic displays, the kid-oriented Pacific Science Center (who knew I would weigh 410 pounds on Jupiter?) and, of course, the 605-foot Space Needle, from which I saw the ghostly pink-tinted peak of Mount Rainier hovering on the southern horizon.
Having been landbound my first three days, I made water sports the goal of my last. My plan for the evening included oysters ($9.25 for six at the grand old McCormick and Schmick's) and fish (an indulgent $16 halibut dish at Flying Fish).
But my first stop was the ferry to Bainbridge Island ($3.60 round trip), a large suburb eight miles across Puget Sound. The sun had burned through the morning clouds, and bright white streaks flashed across the sound's deep water. Sailboats glided by; I settled back for the ride.
As the modern skyline shrunk in the distance, I looked around. Most of my fellow passengers were smiling, eyes closed, faces warmed by the sun.
For such renowned trendsetters, Seattle's citizenry seemed positively content in the face of the next millennium. Then again, I thought, maybe they're just thinking of what they are going to do next.
 
The bottom line
 Including meals, room and car rental, I spent an average of $110 a day in four days in Seattle. Two good investments were "Seattle Best Places," by Nancy Leson and Stephanie Irving, (Sasquatch Books, $16.95), and a City Pass ($23.75), which offers admission to six Seattle attractions: the Space Needle, Pacific Science Center, Woodland Park Zoo, Seattle Aquarium, Seattle Art Museum and Museum of Flight.
I bought my plane ticket, $350 round trip, two days in advance through Priceline (www.priceline.com). During the current high season, 14-day advance-purchase fares on most major airlines should be in the $400 range.
 
What to Do
The Seattle Asian Art Museum, 1400 East Prospect Street in Volunteer Park, has a lovely exhibit of artifacts from India, China, Japan and Korea. Suggested donation is $6, $4 for students. Open 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Tuesday through Sunday, until 9 P.M. on Thursday; closed most Mondays. (206) 654-3100. Free on the first Thursday of every month. The nearby Conservatory is open 10 A.M. to 7 P.M. daily; free.
The Klondike Gold Rush National Historical Park, 117 South Main Street, is open 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. daily; free. (206) 553-7220.
A trip to Bainbridge Island on Washington State Ferries cost $3.60 round trip. Boats leave regularly from Pier 52; (206) 464-6400.
The six City Pass attractions are the Seattle Aquarium, Pier 59, (206) 386-4320; the Pacific Science Center, Seattle Center, (206) 443-2880; the Space Needle, also at the Center, (206) 443-2100; Woodland Park Zoo, (206) 684-4800; the Museum of Flight, 9404 East Marginal Way, (206) 764-5720; and the Seattle Art Museum, 100 University Street, (206) 654-3100. The art museum is closed most Mondays; the rest are open daily.
 
Where to Stay
The Seattle Inn, 225 Aurora Avenue North near downtown, has 150 rooms, an indoor pool, a hot tub and parking. Double rates with breakfast range from $73 to $93. Reservations: (800) 255-7932, fax (206) 728-7666.
The Gaslight Inn, 1727 15th Avenue, is a refurbished Victorian on Capitol Hill with 16 rooms, most with private bath. Doubles: $68 to $158. Continental breakfast included and served in a charming dining room. Reservations: (206) 325-3654, fax (206) 328-4803.
The College Inn, 4000 University Way Northeast, across from the University of Washington, has 27 simple and affordable rooms, from $45 to $83. All have shared bath. Call (206) 633-4441, fax (206) 547-1335.
 
Where to Eat
Three Girls Bakery, 1514 Pike Place in the Market, (206) 622-1045.
Ivar's Acres of Clams, Pier 54, (206) 624-6852.
Mama's Mexican Kitchen, 2234 Second Avenue, (206) 728-6262, offers huge plates of burritos, tacos and enchiladas, most for $6 to $10.
The Belltown Pub, 2322 First Avenue, (206) 728-4311, offers straightforward American cuisine with entrees from $8 to $14.
Broadway New American Grill, 314 Broadway East, (206) 328-7000, has a hearty $7.95 weekend buffet from 8 A.M. to 1 P.M.
Cafe Septieme, 214 Broadway East, (206) 860-8858, has entrees for $6.50 to $15, with cheaper sandwiches.
McCormick and Schmick's, 1103 First Avenue, (206) 623-5500, has a $1.95 bar menu from 3 to 6 P.M. and after 10 P.M.
Flying Fish, 2234 First Avenue, (206) 728-8595, is a pretty (if expensive) seafood spot in Belltown. Entrees are $13 to $19.
The Crocodile Cafe, 2200 Second Avenue in Belltown, features local bands, a diner-style restaurant and separate bar. Cover charges range from $6 to $10. (206) 448-2114.
Garage, 1130 Broadway, is a stylish billiard hall in a converted building along a street once lined with auto-repair places. It has 18 pool tables, a bar and a restaurant. A 10-inch pizza is $7.50 and a Hefeweizen, a local microbrew, is $3.25. Sidewalk seating. (206) 322-2296.
The Baltic Room, 1207 Pine Street, has live jazz Tuesday to Sunday nights. Admission is usually free Sunday through Thursday, with $3 cover Friday and Saturdays, though prices can go higher. (206) 625-4444.
