PUB-DATE: July 5, 1998

SECTION: Section 6; Page 26; Column 1; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 4182 words

HEADLINE: The War Between the States ... and Washington

BYLINE: By Garry Wills; Garry Wills is a frequent contributor to the magazine. In January he wrote about how cultural issues are replacing traditional geopolitcs.

 BODY:
Some people play favorites with the Bill of Rights. The favorite amendment of gangsters is the fifth (no self-incrimination), of liberals the first (free speech), of drug dealers the fourth (no unauthorized search), of gun fondlers the second (to bear arms). Now, many people have a new favorite, the long-neglected 10th (powers not specifically assigned to Washington are reserved to the states). As recently as 1985, when the Supreme Court reversed one of its rare decisions based on the amendment (Garcia canceling Usery), the 10th was being called a dead letter. Certainly few people tried to "take the 10th" the way gangsters and fellow travelers "took the fifth."
But now the amendment has many takers. The Supreme Court used it in 1992, 1995 and 1997 and shows an eagerness to extend that run. Bob Dole, in his last year in the Senate, began carrying the words of the amendment around with him for instant recitation. Newt Gingrich's insurgents relied on it in 1994 to preach devolution of power from the Federal to the state level. Even President Clinton gives states the title Louis Brandeis thought up for them, "laboratories of democracy." Gov. Tommy Thompson of Wisconsin thinks it is high time for the amendment to be resurrected. He claims he has been a voice for the 10th crying in the wilderness for many years. 
 The change is not just a matter of theory. States and localities are manifesting a new energy, almost a frenzy, in starting, altering or killing programs. In education alone, they have pioneered charter schools, vouchers for private schools, the canceling of affirmative action in colleges, the retrenchment of bilingualism, new rules for immigrant children, different approaches to truancy and various approaches to teaching religion in public schools or allowing religious groups to gather on public grounds.
In crime, states have reintroduced capital punishment and passed "three strikes" laws. They have experimented with "truth in sentencing" (no parole), mandatory sentencing, alternative sentencing and victims' compensation.
In politics, they have promoted term limits, tax caps, mandatory spending percentages, public campaign financing, the control of union dues and extensions of the ballot initiative.
On sexual morality, the states have enacted or reversed bills on gay rights, repealed sodomy laws, supported unmarried partners' benefits and proposed or opposed marriage between homosexuals.
On welfare, the states have tried different forms of job training and placement, compulsory work, public employment or compensated private employment and various forms of benefits for mothers on welfare (including child care and health insurance).
On the environment, they have regulated business, formed new protected areas and successfully defied Federal regulations (for example, on the disposal of nuclear waste in New York v. United States in 1992).
On health, they have considered regulations on assisted suicide, H.M.O.'s, late-term abortions and insurance affecting AIDS patients.
On guns, they have passed bills to protect concealed weapons or to impose local restrictions. They have defeated Federal restrictions on guns near schools (Lopez, 1995) and the attempt to use local sheriffs to implement the Brady Bill (Printz, 1997).
On a whole range of such issues, the states have been out ahead of Federal programs, reversing a long-term trend. In the Progressive era, regulation of corporations was sought at the national level. In the Bull Moose movement, and during Woodrow Wilson's first term, intellectuals aspired to policy roles in Washington. With the New Deal, their drift toward the center became a stampede. From that point on, an overlapping series of crises (Depression, world war, cold war) led to central mobilization and control of resources. But now, with the end of this half-century of crisis, people with new ideas and a passion for public policy are turning away from Washington and attacking social issues at the state and local levels. This shift raises deep questions about the virtues of direct democracy, the merits of federalism and the possibility of isolating states from the national society.
California, as usual, has blundered furthest outward. Ronald Reagan went forth from California to shrink the Federal Government and essentially failed. Howard Jarvis stayed home in California and succeeded. His Proposition 13 capped property taxes and thereby (his critics allege) wrecked the state's public education system. The state's punitive measures against immigrants and their children have been checked by the courts, have backfired against their sponsors (including Gov. Pete Wilson) and have unsettled candidates dependent on Hispanic or Asian voters. Draconian term limits (six years for Assembly members) were supposed to curtail careerism, the power of special interests, cronyism and the lobbyists' sway -- but have increased all four.
Peter Schrag, in his sobering new book, "Paradise Lost," describes what occurred at the first great turnovers of office, six years after term limits passed in 1990: "By general agreement, the 1995-'96 term-limits-crunch session of the California Legislature was probably the most mean-spirited and unproductive in memory, a unique combination of instability, bad behavior, political frenzy and legislative paralysis. In the two years between 1995 and 1997, California had five Assembly Speakers, two different Republican Assembly leaders, two Republican Senate leaders and eight special legislative elections, not counting runoffs, among them three recalls."
It is probably unfair to judge any movement by its effect in California. Some local programs have shown initial promise -- school vouchers in Ohio, charter schools in Arizona, inventive policing in New York, job training in Michigan, public campaign financing in Maine. Much of the activity has been stimulated or guided by a new generation of Republican governors, whose careers depend on making the programs work. The emphasis on localism is partly a byproduct of the fact that three-quarters of the American people now live under Republican governors.
The foremost champion of local control among the governors is Tommy Thompson, a short, chunky man from Elroy, Wis. (population 1,500), who has a Cagney strut and very modest amounts of modesty. "We started it," he says. "I was the front-runner because I started looking at the Federal laws and figuring how I'd go to Washington and get waivers." Such waivers are special dispensations from Federal regulations. "I'm the only governor who still has waivers in existence, in the area of welfare, from Presidents Reagan, Bush and Clinton. I think I've got 75 outstanding waivers, which changed Federal law in over 200 instances in the area of welfare."
Welfare is not the only policy on which Thompson has been an innovator. In education, he fought truancy with "Learnfare" and set up choice schools, charter schools, "prep tech" and apprenticing and high-school courses for college credit. He talks of a "broad menu" of options for students. He clearly does not think that local government has to mean minimal government.
In fact, his administration (begun in 1986) has been a kind of mini-New Deal for proliferating programs, acronyms and slogans -- P.F.R. (Parental and Family Responsibility), S.S.F. (Self-Sufficiency First), W.E.J.T. (Work Experience and Job Training Program), Work First, Work Not Welfare, Children First. Many of these have been folded into his master plan, implemented this year as W2 (shorthand for W.W., or Wisconsin Works). His critics say that some of those plans have come and gone so fast they are impossible to evaluate. But he says they should be judged as steps toward his overall plan, whose parts are still being assembled.
He has a health plan for the poor (Badger Care) that awaits more waivers. ("President Clinton is setting on it now.") His job-training program is similarly stymied by Washington: "There are 163 different kinds of rules and regulations dealing with school-to-work and job-ready money from the Federal Government. It's just plain idiotic."
Thompson has moved further and faster than other governors in taking control of his state's activities on many levels, but he says he cannot be judged until his whole plan is in operation and that will not happen until Washington unties his hands. Naturally, since he thinks he is just beginning to get his schemes in place after 12 years in the Governor's Mansion, he is adamantly opposed to term limits: "If you have people dumb enough to keep running for office, like me, you should let the people decide."
Thompson's central planning can look good if you consider the California alternative. There, the governor's hands are tied, not so much by Washington as by popular initiatives that have made a traffic jam of election ballots. In 1990, the state's ballot pamphlet setting forth the voters' choices ran to 222 pages. At a city election in San Francisco, there were more than 100 items. Voters, apparently, did not notice that in 1988 they passed one measure for public financing of campaigns (Proposition 68) and, simultaneously, another measure (Proposition 73) outlawing it.
Nor is California alone in this sharpening appetite for plebiscites. In 1996, 90 ballot initiatives were up for passage in 20 states. The referendum, too, is becoming more important, as Maine's overthrow of a gay-rights law demonstrated.
The contrast between California's free-for-all and Wisconsin's central planning shows that the cry for localism is not for a single good thing (state government) against an equally monolithic bad thing (the Federal Government). Local government can be improvisational or controlled, experimental or rigid, or anything in between.
Governor Thompson is certainly not a champion of localism if that means cities or counties or the State Legislature can defy his general strategy. He boasts of the 290 items he vetoed in the first budget submitted by the Legislature. He has used the line-item veto more than 1,500 times.
Advocates of direct democracy, like Robert Wiebe, the political historian and theorist, oppose "government by experts," and Thompson sometimes makes fun of Washington "know-it-alls" who could not pass his "Elroy test" (what his little hometown knows is good for it). But Thompson also boasts of his reliance on experts, called in from all quarters to help him with planning. One of those experts, Lawrence Mead, wants to make welfare "the new paternalism," frankly telling people what is good for them. Temperamentally, Thompson is inclined to such hectoring certitude, despite his populist campaign rhetoric.
I recently followed Thompson, who was out to greet some constituents at the state environmental center. With men, he has some of Mario Cuomo's locker-room bluster. ("Don't be a wimp.") With women, he is a palsy chin-chucker. Despite the fact that both his parent were teachers and his wife still is (sixth grade in Elroy), he uses what must pass as "street talk" in rural Wisconsin -- "setting" for sitting, "oncommon" for uncommon, "secatary" for secretary.
He presents himself as embattled and with few allies: "I'm the only one still talking devolution." The Republican Congress is "as bad as the President." He feels that he has the spirit of Fighting Bob La Follette, the Wisconsin progressive -- except that La Follette went after big business and Thompson is a sworn foe of big government (at least in Washington). If one of Thompson's projects fails, he wants us to believe, it will be because of his encirclement by foes.
To get a "top down" view of the states' new activism, I interviewed President Clinton in April. He had just come in from a Rose Garden announcement of his education program. Clinton, the policy wonk, was eager to talk governmental relations even when aides were trying to move him to the next event. He finds the states'-rights activism a healthy development.
"What the states did in assuming greater responsibilities was mostly positive -- in education, in taking advantage of the opportunity Congress gave them to be more active in covering more children under child health programs. What my Administration tried to do was, basically, to emphasize two things -- No. 1, states as laboratories of democracy, principally in education, health care and welfare reform; and secondly, actually reduce the aggregate volume of regulations on them in areas where I thought there was too much micromanagement."
Thompson would clearly not see this waiving of authority as sufficient. He would like even less Clinton's caveat that, in giving up some power to the states, the Federal Government was freed to do new things. "We have been more active in some areas than the Federal Government traditionally has been -- in education, in wiring of schools and in trying to actually help them hire teachers to lower class size, the way we broke new ground by helping local law enforcement hire new officers." In short, Clinton does not see the states shoving the Federal Government off the scene but interacting with it in new ways.
Clinton is critical of the Supreme Court's tendency to exclude Washington from state-level activity, going beyond what Clinton praises as "basically a pragmatic reallocation of power between the states and the Federal Government over the last 20 years." He is especially upset by the Supreme Court's Brady Bill decision, "the most troubling of all because it said we couldn't even ask the local law-enforcement officials to do a minor ministerial job" of running background checks on gun purchasers.
On the other hand, Clinton takes a surprisingly benign view of state initiatives that express popular feeling rather than court-imposed mandates: "I don't agree with a lot of those votes, but I think they're votes that people have the right to make as long as they don't contravene a Federal statute or the Constitution.
"Usually there is a legitimate concern that these referenda are designed to address. Either representative government is going to have to move quickly into the breach when one of these proposals is on the ballot, so that it is not necessary by election time, or the progressive populists are going to have to put their own counter-proposals on the ballot. I don't think you can stop this movement any time soon when people want to have a more direct say on public issues."
We can see, by counterpointing the remarks of the Governor and the President, that there is little prospect of agreement in detail on the future of states' rights. The President is well disposed toward ballot initiatives, the most direct form of democracy. Governor Thompson is uneasy about uncoordinated proposals that might intrude on his master strategy. Though he once proposed introducing the initiative into the Wisconsin Constitution, that was when he was a young legislator. Now, he says, he is not interested in raising that issue.
Yet as a 10th Amendment fundamentalist, Thompson welcomes the Court's new interest in states' rights -- while the President resists any effort to break up the partnership. The place where this disagreement causes a head-on collision is the devolution of power over things like welfare. Thompson thinks Washington has been too slow and niggardly in turning over money. Clinton's liberal critics, by contrast, think he was too quick to untie strings over welfare programs. The President himself considered the Republican bill he signed too sweeping on some matters, but feels he remedied that by restoring food stamps and child-care provisions.
I asked him if he thinks that state welfare programs, spotty in their success even during a prosperous time, will stand up when economic reverses come. "Absolutely, as long as we keep the fundamental protection for children. We had, in my view, state-by-state settling of reimbursement for welfare families anyway.
"Before I signed the welfare bill, the reimbursement schedule for a family of three on welfare went from a low of $185 in Mississippi and Texas to a high of $660 in Vermont, and most states had welfare payments that were lower in real dollar terms, considerably lower, than they had been in the early 70's, because they had not kept up with inflation. So the Congress, long before I came along, had de facto ceded the monthly payments to the states anyway. Now the states are responsible.
"In the old days, nobody had to take responsibility for the welfare of the family and of the children, or whether there was a work-based program. Everybody could always kick the responsibility around. They could say that 'in our state the Federal Government has all these rules -- and, oh, by the way, it's operated by the county.' I think that locating responsibility and fixing it with the states will be more positive than negative."
It is here that Thompson gets heated in his comments on the President. "President Clinton has done everything he possibly can to stymie what we're trying to do in Wisconsin." He has words just as harsh for Donna Shalala of Health and Human Services. "I could get matching grants" for new programs, Thompson complains, but the Govenment will not turn over the money he feels he needs. On this point Thompson will get no help from the Federal courts. They have repeatedly ruled that states have to observe Federal conditions if they accept Federal money.
Thompson desperately needs Federal money. As he readily admits, Workfare, at least at the outset and for some time to come, is more costly than welfare. To train people for work, to deal with obstacles to work (alcohol, drugs, mental problems), to find jobs, to motivate employers, to offer child care for those going to work, to provide health insurance -- all this is not only expensive in itself but also has to be closely monitored. That is why the per-person yearly cost for people on welfare has gone up under Thompson, from $9,000 to $15,000.
Thompson's programs bring back the resented "social worker," who was an irritant under the old paternalism. His Learnfare program, for instance, was meant to dock welfare payments to any family whose child was not attending school. This involved keeping accurate truancy records, comparing them with welfare payments and weighing any alleviating circumstances (illness, transportation problems, children no longer living with their families, etc.). According to Pamela Fendt, a policy analyst at the University of Wisconsin at Milwaukee's Center for Economic Development, Learnfare saved $3 million in welfare payments but cost $14 million.
The expenses of Workfare exert tremendous pressure on the system to remove people from the program, one way or another. That is why Governor Thompson has tried to reach job-placement goals faster than required by Federal rules. One way to remove people from the rolls is simply to declare them ineligible. In Wisconsin, as in other states, many of those declared ineligible were reinstated on appeal. In Wisconsin, as in other states, the numbers going off welfare are not matched with reported jobs and income. Marcus White, associate director for the Interfaith Conference of Greater Milwaukee, says that there has been a quantum leap in the people showing up at Milwaukee shelters and soup kitchens, suggesting that not everyone disappearing from the welfare rolls is getting work.
So far, with the help of a booming economy in Wisconsin, the Governor has kept scrambling ahead of any clear signs of failure. When I suggest that Federal oversight might be justified by less commendable showings in other states, he is dismissive. "They're always saying that, that the states were going to be having a race to the bottom. I told them: 'You're wrong. That may have happened in the 40's and 50's. But right now you've got governors who are so darn competitive. They don't want to read that they're not taking care of the poor, and they're not going to let a governor in an adjoining state get ahead of them. We're very competitive."'
But Gov. Phil Batt of Idaho is not, apparently, feeling any competitive pressures. His state has cut welfare rolls by 77 percent, belying President Clinton's claim that disparities will be less acute under the new system. Idaho, which has the highest incidence of child abuse in the nation, spends $17 per capita for child welfare, as opposed to $99.30 in New York.
Peter Edelman, who resigned from the Department of Health and Human Services to protest Clinton's signing of the 1996 welfare bill, has kept a close eye on subsequent developments in the states. "There are some bright spots," he says. "There are some good states -- Maine, Vermont, Rhode Island, Minnesota, Oregon. But there are some very bad states -- Idaho, Mississippi, Georgia -- and some states, like Pennsylvania, are not doing much. In California, the Governor proposed a bad plan that the Legislature blocked."
Governor Thompson claims that the states are sure to do things better than the Federal Government, since they are closer to the peoples' needs and wants. "The new ideas are coming from the governors, and when you have that clash of ideas, you're going to bring out the best in education or in government."
When I suggest that not all the ideas coming from the states are great ones, he is quick, as ever, to the challenge: "Tell me some that aren't." I name term limits, three-strikes, anti-immigration measures, anti-gay measures. "You're right," he says. "I'll grant you there are some examples. But tell me some things in Wisconsin you don't like."
Thompson believes that the government closest to the people is the best government, which many people take to be a truism of democracy. Alexis de Tocqueville, during his 1831 visit to America, noted that "the Federal Government scarcely ever interferes in any but foreign affairs; and the governments of the states in reality direct society in America." The result, according to Tocqueville, was a "tyranny of the majority," by which local prejudice and conformity received no outside challenge.
It is the same complaint Madison had against the states' autonomy under the Articles of Confederation. The people were, in effect, the judges in their own cause -- which always leads to skewed judgments. John Jay, arguing in "The Federalist" for a larger union, said that the people least likely to make wise policy about Native Americans were those in the friction of greatest proximity to them. It is the same lesson we learned, in this century, from the assertions of Southern leaders that they best understood blacks.
Though popular sentiment must be expressed in popular government, it is clear that some kinds of dispute need impartial arbiters. The effort of some states to deny education to the children of illegal immigrants, or legal rights to homosexuals, or organization to unions, shows that popular sentiment can be harsh with unpopular people.
Actually, there is no danger of returning to the Jacksonian days of independent states. Even if you remove the Federal Government from the scene, other national organizations cut across state lines and have to be addressed in a national way.
When I asked Governor Thompson why he did not start his new educational programs in the public schools, he said the teachers' union was too powerful. "If I wanted to hire you from Northwestern to teach in the public schools, I could not give you a contract. The union has to decide what you can teach and where. You might end up teaching music in an out-of-the-way school." Even allowing for hyperbole, teachers' unions are national organizations that can be hard to deal with on the state level.
The best proof of the states' vulnerability to national forces is the flow of outside money and influence into the local arena. When Maine put up its referendum to remove a gay rights law, religious organizations sent in money for ads and teams of "ex-gays" traveled there to support the measure. At an advanced level of communications and transportation, and with the complex organization of religious, ideological and educational enterprises, a return to the independent states of Jackson's time is impossible. To deal with national organizations, whether corporations or unions, philanthropies or crime syndicates, the states are often going to need help from the national Government.
President Clinton ended our interview by noticing how the hard line between domestic and foreign policy is being dissolved. There is a parallel softening of the division between state and national life, not just in government but in every sphere. This does not mean that states are not better at handling some things or at conducting experiments not easily tried on a national scale. There will be, as Clinton says, new kinds of interaction, dialogue and dispute. All that is healthy. But a 10th Amendment fundamentalism that looks back to the muscular states of the Jacksonian era is, by now, an exercise in nostalgia for "good old days" that were not all that good.

SECTION: Section 14CN; Page 15; Column 1; Connecticut Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 890 words

HEADLINE: Through the Lenses of the Connecticut Postcard Man

BYLINE: By BILL RYAN 

 BODY:
FOR nearly half a century, Clifford Scofield has been recording the beauty of his adopted state, Connecticut -- its churches, its beaches, its parks and forests, its monuments, its dogwood trees that burst into color in the spring and its maple trees, the leaves of which die spectacularly in the fall.
Cities, he tries to mostly ignore. They are too dirty and noisy, he says. And they change too much, and too fast. For example, The New Haven Register recently disclosed that the Liberty Belle, a popular cruise ship in the city's harbor for more than two decades, had sailed away to Bangor, Me., presumably for forever. Mr. Scofield is left with many photograph mementoes of the Liberty Belle, now gone. 
 Mr. Scofield is Connecticut's "Postcard Man," a professional photographer who specializes in postcards and the dean of such photographers in the state, all five of them, and probably in the entire nation. After all, how many postcard photographers, or any commercial photographers for that matter, are still active in business in their ninth decade?
Clifford Scofield is 93. He will reach 94 in August, not that another birthday will alter his thinking about retirement. "I don't know what retired means," he says. "What is it, when you just do nothing?" It is not really a question.
He does not delude himself that he is as quick as when he was, say, in his 70's, or 80's. Early in this decade, in a note to some of his customers, he said he had been enjoying the fun, and picture possibilities, of a hot air balloon, a speedboat on the Hudson River and a tube on the Farmington River.
But, he wrote, he was sorry he had to give up skiing. He had dropped that from his itinerary when he was 72.
Now a widower, he has also quit driving because his eyes have gone back on him a bit. He has kept his car, though, depending on friends to ferry him about on business or on pleasure.
The business is supplying his postcards to about two dozen retail outlets -- general stores, gift shops and drug stores -- in the Upper Housatonic Valley and the Lower Connecticut River Valley. The pleasure includes attending all the big camera shows in the state, buying some more cameras and selling some from his collection, which dates back to the first quarter of this century, huge boxy affairs that required flash powder for lighting and were an adventure to operate.
Mr. Scofield is a product of the economics that shaped the United States, and the rest of the world, for most of this century.
He was born in Brooklyn but grew up in Montreal where his father, an insurance underwriter, had been transferred. And one day, when he was 15, he discovered the joys of photography. He won a folding camera for selling the most tickets at a bazaar. He can recall instantly both who held the bazaar and what the camera was. The sponsor was the Daughters of the British Empire. "It was an organization like the D.A.R. here." The camera was a Model IA Kodak Jr.
Eventually he wore out the camera but later bought another one. He still has it.
Photography was just a hobby at first. He went to McGill University in Montreal and then, after his father was transferred back to New York, attended Columbia University and City College of New York. His goal was the common American dream of the time: a good job with a good company.
In 1926, that seemed to be settled. He was hired by Bell Laboratories, the research arm of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, one of the great rocks of American business.
Five years later, the dream dissolved. A.T.&T. proved as vulnerable as any other corporations to The Great Depression. Bell Labs laid off 2,000 of its 5,500 workers and Clifford Scofield was one of them. He had to find something else to do in a time of bread lines and soup kitchens. He turned to his first love, photography.
"I had to borrow money to get film and I started to do weddings and commercial pictures, even for the W.P.A." W.P.A. was the Works Progress Administration, one of the agencies dreamed up by President Franklin D. Roosevelt to get men back to work. Mr. Scofield still talks of the President -- he calls him "Mr. Roosevelt" -- with some awe, even though, he adds, he has never been a Democrat.
And his new career worked out. In the early 1950's he expanded it into postcards. It was a home industry that would never make him rich, he knew that, but it was honest and enjoyable. He and his wife, Jeanette, brought up a son and daughter on postcards.
Over the years, Mrs. Scofield learned to live in a house in Cheshire that was also a workplace: a photo lab in the basement, a working office and storage place for thousands of cards on the second floor. She would warn visitors that they went upstairs at their peril, that it was a real mess there.
She died seven years ago. The mess remains. Clifford Scofield was up there one recent day, sorting through stacks and boxes of postcards here, there and everywhere. He estimated that there were maybe 65,000 cards within grabbing range, give or take. Also around were a sufficient number of the business cards that might best explain Mr. Scofield.
"Clifford Scofield Color Productions," is on one side of one card. On the flip side is a Halloween pumpkin sticking out a red pepper tongue. He took the picture. He liked it. So why not use it?

GRAPHIC: Photos: Clifford Scofield in the attic of his Cheshire home, surrounded by his product and with a tool of the trade: a Graphic Super D. At left, his signature pumpkin shot and one of the rural scenes he favors. (Steve Miller for The New York Times)

SECTION: Section 3; Page 26; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 437 words

HEADLINE: Patent Weaknesses

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "Keep a Strong Patent System" (Viewpoint, June 7), in which Richard C. Hsu and Jeffrey D. Tekanic said the cost of patent litigation was a small price to pay for the benefits of the United States patent process: 
 Unfortunately, our country does not have a strong patent system, and the litigation explosion to which Mr. Hsu and Mr. Tekanic referred is instead a symptom of its weakness.
The patent system is characterized by low standards for gaining patents, unnecessary uncertainty over the scope and validity of patents, and damage awards that are often excessive. The effect is to increase the cost and risk of innovation in our country.
The lower standards mean that more patents are being obtained, even for trivial ideas. This means that innovators must worry more about infringing others' patents when commercializing innovations and must seek more patents on their work to protect their own rights. That means unnecessary costs.
The uncertainty of the process is a profound failing of the patent system. After all, the first function of any legal regime is to inform those affected by it of their rights and duties so they can act accordingly.
Finally, excessive damage awards, which give patent holders more in damages than they would have made had there been no infringement, are an incentive to sue rather than settle. And they offer a strong disincentive for innovators, who do not know if their innovations will run afoul of others' patents and are unwilling to run the risk of excessive, possibly crippling damages.
I was the general counsel for Eastman Kodak during its patent litigation with Polaroid, and that case illustrated many problems with our patent system. Kodak set out to create instant photography products that did not infringe the patents of others, including Polaroid, and believed it had done so, based on the advice of its outside lawyers. Kodak's patent clearance process was characterized by a court as "a model for what the law requires," but it turned out to be wrong as to 7 of the 12 Polaroid patents in the litigation. Obviously, if the best a model process can do is 5 for 12, then the patent system has failed in its primary task of informing those affected by it of their rights and duties.
But interestingly enough, the $873 million judgment, by eliminating uncertainty, resulted in a $795 million increase in the market value of Kodak stock. Uncertainty does have its price!
 
CECIL D. QUILLEN Jr.
Washington, June 8
 
The writer is now a senior adviser at Putnam, Hayes & Bartlett, an economic and management consulting firm.

TYPE: Letter

LENGTH: 1180 words

HEADLINE: ART;
Exotic Accumulations in Miniature Spaces

BYLINE: By Roberta Smith 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THE 16th- and 17th-century Dutch were probably not the first Westerners to be more interested in this world than the next, but they pursued that interest with unusual energy, openness and intelligence.
Their assured, enterprising curiosity is reflected in their advances in cartography, navigation, exploration, lens-cutting, medicine and science, and a bustling sea trade that sustained Amsterdam as a center of international commerce as well as learning. 
 It is also evident in their art, which built upon the observation and accuracy first formulated by Van Eyck and then Durer. With an alacrity suggesting that love of the world engenders love of self, Dutch artists pursued subjects among their immediate surroundings, painting Dutch men and women, their everyday lives and the Dutch landscape. They gave genre painting its first definition and painted so many depictions of objects that the term "stilleven" -- still life -- was coined.
Perhaps the most vivid reflection of this worldliness -- this inclusive embrace of knowledge, experience and beauty -- was the kunstkamer, or art cabinet, the often encyclopedic arrays of art, artifacts and natural specimens assembled by prosperous Dutch or Flemish burghers.
So argues "A Collector's Cabinet," a pocket-size show at the National Gallery of Art. A summer hit now extended to Nov. 1, it qualifies as a blockbuster in a teapot.
"A Collector's Cabinet," organized by Arthur K. Wheelock Jr., the museum's curator of northern Baroque painting, loosely re-creates an eclectic, 17th-century kunstkamer. In all, 180 artworks have been shoehorned into three galleries with a combined area of less than 800 square feet.
The show features walls double- and triple-hung with smallish to tiny oil paintings, mostly Dutch, Flemish and Italian. Handsome built-in vitrines brim with table-top sculptures, decorative objects, Roman coins, jewelry, Chinese lacquers, prints, illustrated books, exotic shells, botanical and zoological drawings, musical instruments, the occasional map, an elephant's tooth and scientific instruments like microscopes, telescopes, globes and a protractor. The kunstkamer was multicultural and multimedia before the fact.
The installation gives claustrophobia a good name, or at least distracts effectively from its anxieties. The slightest shift of the eyes causes images and objects to group and regroup according to subject, style, form or material and creates a shifting flow of thoughts and perceptions.
The fascination with nature's exotica takes different forms. In one vitrine, sea coral, highly prized, appears in its natural state, as an impressive bright-red trident. A nearly identical sprig commands the center of a beautiful, kunstkamer-like still life (by Jacques Linard, a French artist) of shells. A third bit of coral serves as the stem of a finely wrought silver spoon.
In other instances, rare natural forms inspired ostentatious artifice. With the addition of a gilded silver head, wings and feet, an ostrich egg becomes a sculpture of the bird itself (also an ewer). Similarly, a large nautilus becomes a snail when supplemented with a graceful head, rippling foot and tiny fairy astride its back. Above these hang images of unaugmented natural wonders: prints of a rhinoceros and a pig with six legs, both by Durer.
For the most part, the juxtapositions of paintings make the most interesting points, dramatizing the range of realist styles and subjects. After regarding the quiet precision of Pieter Jansz Saenredam's pale interior of a vaulting church nave, from around 1632, the eye is drawn across the way to the serenity and radiance of Jan Olis's "Interior With Young Men Playing Tric-Trac," a tavern scene in whites and creams from around 1632. On the intervening wall, Adriaen Brouwer's "Youth Making a Face" (1632-35) gives a grittier picture of tavern life, as does a tiny gray scene (around 1635) that includes a man relieving himself, this one by David Teniers the Younger, who was influenced by Brouwer.
Amid these different realist styles, and flanked in one instance by two small turbulent Rembrandts, Johannes Vermeer's "Woman Holding a Balance" and "Girl With a Red Hat" communicate a startling modernity -- an economy of form, purity of color and odd flatness that border on the abstract. Vermeer seems almost as removed from the painting of his time as that painting was from the art of the Italian Renaissance, with its idealized treatments of biblical and classical subjects. When Roelandt Savery paints his 1624 image of the Holy Family resting on the Flight Into Egypt, they appear deep in the background of a scene filled with farmers and cattle.
It seems appropriate that the galleries holding this show aren't much bigger than a small one-bedroom apartment. For despite its vivid glimpse of a distant time, place and mind-set, it is not alien. The Dutch or Flemish kunstkamer may be ground zero for a number of familiar phenomena: the private art collection, for one. Neither members of royalty nor the clergy, the Dutch in particular were the first bourgeois art collectors in the West, habitually displaying art in less than palatial homes and thereby encouraging the production of small objects and paintings.
In their ostentation, some of these objects contain hints of bric-a-brac to come and might even qualify as pre-industrial kitsch, despite the uniqueness, consummate craft and high production values.
But the kunstkamer's density also resonates with the chock-a-block displays found throughout the art world these days. In a time as modest as ours can sometimes be, young artists often sneak up on large scale by massing together lots of little things -- small paintings, drawings, photographs, found objects.
OTHER echoes can be found in some recent high-density museum exhibitions organized by noncurators looking to take liberties with the whole exhibition concept. One thinks of the cheek-by-jowl display of portraits that the painter Chuck Close organized, with Kirk Varnedoe, in a small gallery at the Museum of Modern Art in 1991; of the sculptor Arman's dense installation of works from his collection of African art at the Museum of African Art in SoHo last fall, and of "A/Drift," a wild mix of contemporary art and artifacts (record albums, rock posters, T-shirts and music videos) organized in 1996 by the critic Joshua Decter at the Center for Curatorial Studies at Bard College in Annandale-on-Hudson, N.Y. And at the moment, there's "Bathroom" at the Thomas Healy Gallery in Chelsea, one of many thematic compendiums presented by New York art galleries every season.
The National Gallery's exhibition returns to the moment when the experience of art was, in effect, privatized by successful commoners with uncommon amounts of disposable income. Their nonhierarchical collections -- the kunstkamer theory of relativity? -- made these ensembles machines for seeing, like the lenses and microscopes they sometimes included, and exemplars of a multicultural connoisseurship whose relevance endures.

GRAPHIC: Photos: FAVORITE THINGS: "Still Life of Shells," circa 1640, by Jacques Linard, top; "Youth Making a Face," circa 1635, by Adriaen Brouwer, above, and an installation in "A Collector's Cabinet," on view at the National Gallery of Art. (National Gallery of Art)

SECTION: Section 14NJ; Page 1; Column 3; New Jersey Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 797 words

HEADLINE: JERSEY;
Discovering a New Way of Dining Out

BYLINE: By FRAN SCHUMER 

 BODY:
TUESDAY night I ate steak au poivre at Pierre's; Wednesday at noon I'm eating chicken fingers and frozen fries with my children on their school's annual retreat at Camp Fairview in Stillwater. Why me, I wonder as they pass the Day Glo-pink punch in my direction.
Every year, my children's school, like about 150 others in New Jersey, spends two days at the camp, a beautiful, if somewhat rustic, facility run by the Y.M.C.A. The grounds, in southwestern Sussex County, are adjacent to the Delaware Water Gap National Recreational Area and the Appalachian Trail -- if those names mean anything to you. To me, they mean bugs, insect repellent and crunchy mattresses, not to mention -- and as a restaurant reviewer, how could I not? -- bad food. What am I doing here? 
 My children and their school are here to learn about the environment; I'm here because my ex-scout husband, who normally attends these nature fests, couldn't get away this year. I stash imported tea bags and a few premium navel oranges from King's in the trunk and off we go.
My son, a third grader, takes the bus but my daughter, a second grader, accompanies me in the car. The purpose of this two-and-a-half-day adventure is not only for the parents, teachers and children from our small, cooperative school to bond with each other, but also for all of us to bond with nature. I'm not sure that what my daughter and I are doing in the car is bonding, but at least we talk.
Q. "Mom, are we there yet?"
A. "Almost," I answer, more or less honestly, depending on whether we are in the Caldwells or Sparta.
About a half-hour later, my cellular telephone stops working. Welcome to Camp Fairview. Its 600 acres of woodlands, fields and streams are more beautiful than I expected, the Kittatinny Mountains looming blue and hazy in the distance. By the time we settle into our cabin, which is rustic but clean, it's noon. In addition to chicken fingers and fries, the meal consists of iceberg lettuce and a dressing that one teacher dubs Agent Orange. Dare I ask for a drizzle of the Paul Newman Balsamic Vinegar Dressing that another retrieves from her backpack? Fortunately, there isn't time to ruminate, let alone finish my salad.
The first activity on the agenda is a hike. The guide points out interesting facts of nature that neither my daughter nor I absorb. She's too busy trailing an older student whom she idolizes, and I'm too busy worrying what her infatuation means about her self-esteem. My decision to separate her from her friend proves fatal. She cries over the next half mile, past a fairy-like patch of pine trees planted by unemployed workers during the Great Depression, while I try to dig myself out of my lesser one. When she joins her friend back at the cabin, I don't know which of us is more relieved.
In swimsuits, we join my son and the rest of our school by the lake. The children are asked to pair off, and now it's my son's turn to suffer: the person he asks to be his buddy declines and rushes off with someone else. Between that moment and the one in which he does find a companion, I reach my emotional nadir. It is all too much for me to tolerate, this parent-teacher-student bonding. Better to hide myself in my kitchen or at my computer, where I can at least imagine that the hours my children spend away from me are perfect.
Again, however, I am saved and not by my usual 4 P.M. cappuccino. My son and his friend press me into taking them out in a canoe, which I am delighted to discover I remember how to paddle. I missed my favorite aerobics classes by being on this outing, but paddling, I realize, strengthens my biceps and under more meaningful conditions: with my children and on a beautiful lake. Not for the first time, going with the flow, which I always resist, restores me. Dinner is at an unfashionably early 5:30 P.M., but I am starving and even the runny lasagna tastes good. What a novel idea: to eat because food is there and you're hungry.
In the time that remains, I crochet, become interested in the novel I started reading last fall and make a new friend. The highlight in terms of food is the turkey and canned cranberry sauce at our final supper. All around me, people complain, but by then it is hopeless: not only do I fall in love with the turkey, I fall in love with the idea of food being kept in its proper perspective.
That night, the children put on a talent show in the fading light of the campfire. A few weeks earlier, I ate passion fruit chocolate ganache at the Short Hills Hilton and here I lick marshmallow off my fingers.
We have the option of leaving the next day before lunch, which I decline. "Hey, are you going to review the food here?" a parent asks after frozen pizza.
No, but if I were, I'd give it an A plus.

GRAPHIC: Drawing (Nancy Doniger)

HEADLINE: Crusade to Save the Chestnut

BYLINE: By ANDREA ZIMMERMANN 

 BODY:
IT has all the elements of a modern crime novel -- a trail of death from Maine to Georgia, rich perpetrators, DNA clues and the Feds lingering in the shadows. But in fact, it is a century-old mystery that Sandra Anagnostakis, a scientist at the Agricultural Experiment Station, is slowly unraveling in the laboratory and forests. It is the case of the disappearing chestnut trees.
The American chestnut once dominated forests as a 70- to 100-foot canopy tree and provided about half of North America's native hardwood. In the 1880's, however, imported Japanese chestnuts brought in a killer fungus. Nurseries propagated the species and sold the trees through mail order. Pockets of affluent communities soon found their native American chestnuts developing orange cankers. Insects and migratory birds did the rest, transmitting the fungal spores through the country. The blight wiped out the old stands of American chestnuts and, until recently, had the species locked in an interrupted cycle of sprouting and dying. 
 "I know what we're up against. There are massive amounts of fungus out there," says Dr. Anagnostakis, who has spent the past 30 years working on the problem. She identified and has introduced a biological control that prevents the fungus from killing trees, and continues the chestnut cross-breeding project begun by Dr. Arthur Graves in Connecticut in the 1930's.
This time of year, the mycologist says, she feels a little like a bee because she spends hours scouting for flowers in the chestnut orchard at the experiment station's Lockwood Farm in Hamden. "It's pollinating season. Every Fourth of July weekend, when most people are having barbecues, I'm out here pollinating chestnuts." Flowers on selected trees are pollinated, then isolated with bags which remain until nuts are harvested in the fall. The nuts have a requisite cold treatment in a refrigerator, start germinating and are planted in the spring.
The goal of cross-breeding is to produce two types of chestnuts resistant to blight: A splaying orchard tree with tasty nuts, and a tall timber tree that looks like an American chestnut but has as much resistance as Asian chestnuts.
"Anybody who's going to work on trees better be patient," Dr. Anagnostakis notes. "One generation -- from seed to the next seed -- is 10 years."
This year, Dr. Anagnostakis will offer free to nurseries a cultivar, Little Giant, that she developed for its backyard size and good nuts. And, she said, she is very close to producing a timber tree that can compete in the forest.
The Connecticut Agricultural Experiment Station has the largest collection of species and hybrids of chestnuts in the world, including specimens from Russia, China, Japan, Turkey and Europe, all in Hamden and all closely documented. Dr. Anagnostakis sighs when she realizes another small metal identification tag has disappeared off the trunk of a tree. "Its the crows," she explains. "They like the shiny tags."
Blight resistant hybrids are only a partial solution to the problem, she says, because blight fungus could mutate to overcome the resistance gene in a hybrid. The fungus itself, therefore is her target.
At one time, farmers attempted to control the blight by clearing and burning around affected orchards or by spraying trees with a copper fungicide, a technique used in vineyards today to protect the fruit from disease. "The state of Pennsylvania spent a great deal of money because Pennsylvania had a lot of orchards," said Dr. Anagnostakis. "It looked as thought it would kill everything and it did. It was clear for a long time that chemicals were not going to be effective against chestnut blight."
In 1972, Dr. Anagnostakis received samples of diseased chestnut fungus from France. She found the fungus had a virus -- a natural biological control. Although the virus was not lethal, it prevented the fungus from penetrating the chestnut stem and killing the tree; the tree could then produce thick tissue to wall-off the canker. She found when a strain of fungus with a susceptible chestnut tree was inoculated with the viral parasite, the virus could fuse with a killer canker and render it benign.
Seventy American chestnut seedlings were planted at Lockwood Farm in 1976. For the next five years, every canker was treated with the viral agent; no treatment has been administered since 1981. Many of the trees have thrived.
It takes a sharp eye to detect a medallion of blight fungus (insects feed on the cankers, virtually obliterating the fungus' tell-tale orange coloration). But areas where the trees have been treated are difficult to miss -- swollen rings and knots surround dead bark where the canker attacked. One tree at the Hamden site looks as if it had been roto-tilled along 20 feet of bark and then healed over. It may not be beautiful, but the tree is alive and well.
Samples of what appear to be killer cankers at the farm will be studied to see if a virus is present , which virus, and how much of it. "Since this is such a successful orchard, it would be nice to know what we did right," says Dr. Anagnostakis, who remains undaunted by all the questions.
Although natural hypovirulent strains, so named for their relatively benign nature, were effective in an orchard, they were less so in the forest where trees are competing for light, moisture and nutrients. Even after inoculation the blight fungus produced spores that did not contain the virus so infection of untended trees continued. This pushed research to the molecular level.
Donald Nuss at the University of Maryland copied the virus genes and attached them to the genes of the fungus, making fungal strains that were permanently hypovirulent. The spores made by these fungal strains contained the virus so, if compatible with local fungi, the two could fuse and the virus would be passed along, inhibiting the blight.
Drs. Nuss and Anagnostakis then tested the genetically engineered control in the lab and greenhouse to see if it would cause any adverse affects if used in the environment; they found no evidence of harm to other life forms.
In 1994, the Federal and Connecticut regulatory commissions allowed the genetically engineered, biological control to be released into the environment -- the first time such an experiment had been sanctioned in this country. Each year inspectors accompany Dr. Anagnostakis into the field to check on her work.
The initial test site was four acres in the Housatonic State Forest in Sharon. Dr. Anagnostakis and her assistants mapped every American chestnut one inch or more in diameter on the plot. In order to do a scientific evaluation, the mycologist needed to track cankers that appeared at the same time. So she actually inoculated the trees with the killing strain of fungus and then treated one in each pair of trees; no further applications of hypovirulent will be made at the site. Last year, she sampled 81 natural cankers from the plot and found just one had the new recombinant hypovirulent strain.
Again, patience. "That's not bad. It meant it was there," says Dr. Anagnostakis. "I really think we'll start seeing it spread. The only way to keep track is with the human eye; there are no machines that can do this. An old sage said, 'You can see a lot by looking.' I saw two insects I didn't know existed -- quarter-inch-long weevils -- that are carrying the killer and recombinant hypovirulent fungus. It clearly feeds on the chestnut blight fungus. I've talked to an entomologist about raising and releasing them. . . . "
Another method of spreading the biological control is being tested in a timbered and cleared 400-by-400-foot plot in the Meshomasic State Forest, an area where chestnut trees once flourished.
Last year, Drs. Nuss and Anagnostakis sprayed the trunk of every American chestnut sprout with either water (the control plot) or hypovirulent spore mixture made from the most common fungal strains in that area. The process will be repeated at least twice a year for four years. Any competing vegetation will be cut down. The scientists hope to replace the population of killing chestnut blight with the benign form, and are anxious to see if it will spread beyond the test site into the forest.
"By repeatedly putting out massive amounts of hypovirulent strains there will be a lot of hypovirulent spores available," says Dr. Anagnostakis. "Can we make a difference? I don't know. We can't spray it from airplanes; imagine having to grow that much fungus! What I really want is for it to spread by itself."
By learning about and manipulating the chestnut blight system of host-pathogen-parasite, scientists have developed one of the better models for studying plant diseases, says Dr. Anagnostakis. They now have a "fairly good" molecular map of the chestnut tree, along with DNA analysis that might identify blight-resistant genes.
"The science is fascinating," says Dr. Anagnostakis, "but I really want to save the chestnut trees." There are many good economic reasons to restore the chestnut tree -- as a valuable timber crop or to control the blight on orchard cultivars. But the main value is to increase diversity of the forest. Improving diversity is intrinsically a good thing, a healthy thing."

HEADLINE: Who Are We? A Book of Answers

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:
THE latest edition of Westchester's Databook is full of useful information, including facts not only about the county's government, its labor force, its infrastructure and taxes but also about many little-known and sometimes colorful statistical details.
For example, men outnumber women until age 20, according to the Databook, making the county an auspicious place for young women to meet mates. 
 And one does not have to go to the northern reaches of the county to find wooded areas and fresh air. Open space in Westchester exists where one might least expect it: the town of Mount Pleasant in the middle of the county and Dobbs Ferry, a densely settled village to the south. Those spots have the highest proportion of open space -- 43.5 percent and 41.7 percent, respectively. By contrast, Buchanan, a village in the mostly rural northern section, has the least amount -- 3.5 percent.
More than offering data of interest only to statisticians, actuaries and developers, the Databook is aimed at a wide variety of readers. As its authors at the county's Planning Department said recently, it is a lively resource for anyone who wants to know more about Westchester and how it evolved from 1524 -- when Giovanni Verrazano, the first explorer arrived -- to the present, two years before the turn of the millennium, with 893,412 residents and an average household income of $61,861.
"Not just a dust collector or doorstop, it offers a real snapshot of Westchester at any one time, a profile," said Noreen L. Preston, a Planning Department economist and editor of the 250-page Databook, one of the largest single sources of information about the county.
The book offers information on population dynamics -- breakdowns by age, sex and race -- incorporating the latest estimates from the United States Census Bureau; housing statistics with figures documenting the last few years' turnaround in the residential real estate market and details on female- and minority-owned companies.
Also, new median-income estimates and cost-of-living information are included, along with facts about transportation, education, child care, taxes, hospitals, recreation and major job-generating industries.
The Databook weaves into the current statistics a history of the county, observing, for example, that it was not until 80 years after the first explorer that Henry Hudson sailed up the river now named for him and began the often bloody process that left the indigenous population, the Algonquian Indians, without a home.
Soon after, Westchester became what it has continued to be -- a wealthy and predominantly white county. By 1775, the Indians were significantly reduced in numbers, and the newly settled area became the richest, most populous county in the New York Colony.
"Even after the peace treaties -- all primarily advantageous to the newcomers -- were signed, injuries from land battles and diseases brought by the Europeans continued to plague and decimate the Native Americans who eventually disappeared entirely from the area," a section of the Databook reads.
Today, the still mostly white and prosperous Westchester County ranks second in per capita income -- $40,696 -- among counties in the state, with only Manhattan (New York County) surpassing it at $58,096. Among all counties in the United States, Westchester ranks sixth, being 75 percent wealthier than the national average in per capita income. The Databook does not list which county is first in the country, but it is again New York County.
By contrast, Nassau showed a $36,609 per capita income in 1995, Rockland, $30,698 and Putnam, $28,914. For Fairfield County, average per capita income at $42,800, the third highest in the country, was higher than Westchester's, while for Bergen and Passaic in New Jersey it was lower -- at $39,014 and $24,943, respectively.
The richest municipality in Westchester as of 1989 -- the most recent year for which figures are available -- is Scarsdale, with an average per capita income of $59,868.
The poorest municipality is Mount Vernon at $15,835 in 1989.
The average wage in the county in 1996 was $38,237 (somewhat above the state average of $36,816), with the highest average salaries ($64,470) being paid in the manufacturing sector and the lowest average annual salaries ($31,346) being paid in service industries.
Media directors and vice presidents of financial institutions are the highest wage earners in Westchester -- $1,923 a week on average; cashiers, kitchen workers and school crossing guards earn among the least -- less than $200 a week.
The racial and ethnic composition of the county has been steadily shifting, according to the Databook -- with whites still accounting for almost 80 percent of the population in 1996, but blacks making up 15 percent, compared with 13 percent in 1990, and Asians accounting for 5 percent, up from 3.7 percent. Those of Hispanic origin, who can be of any race, accounted for 11.6 percent of the population in 1996, up from 9.9 percent in 1990.
"The population growth of recent years has been strongly affected by migration," the Databook says. "Westchester County is a multicultural community with a racial and ethnic composition not unlike that of the United States."
The original residents, American Indians, now account for 0.2 percent, with their numbers remaining stable in recent years. Of the total population, men outnumber women until age 20, after which the number of men diminishes. For example, in 1996, there were 24,795 women and girls in the 15-to-19 age group and 26,308 men and boys. Ms. Preston at the Planning Department could not say why that occurs in Westchester but not in many other localities. In the 20-to-24 age group, women outnumber men 25,496 to 24,880.
The county's population also continues to grow older, with the number of people 85 and older increasing to 11,928 in 1996 from 10,427 in 1990. By age 85, women outnumber men 11,928 to 4,399 or almost 3 to 1.
Household size continues to grow smaller in the county, down by 7.1 percent to 2.6 people in 1990 from 3.1 people in 1970. And the median price of a home as of 1997 was $300,000 and in 1987 it was $283,900.
Average rents range from $675 a month for a studio apartment to $1,625 a month for five bedrooms. But the range is wide, depending on location, with two bedrooms renting for $848 on average in Yonkers and $1,375 in Rye.
Under the category of business, there are 33 pages of tables, bar graphs and other charts detailing the county's economic growth. The Databook says Westchester's business sector consists of almost 30,000 companies or organizations, representing an expansion rate of 8.4 percent from 1985 to 1995.
"Downsizings, mergers and acquisitions since the late 1980's have changed the profile of many of Westchester's major employers in recent years," the Databook says. Now, 80 percent of establishments have fewer than 10 employees, and 90 percent employ fewer than 20. "Smaller businesses clearly have gained ground in the 1990's," Ms. Preston writes.
After several years of decline, Westchester's labor force has also been growing. The number of jobs in the county -- at 382,900 in 1996 -- has been increasing steadily since 1993, driven by high rates of growth in the health and social-services sector. More than one-third of the jobs are service positions, with about 10,000 new jobs available in health care alone. The high point for job numbers in Westchester occurred in 1988 with 410,000; the low point in 1993 with 375,000 jobs.
Under the category of transportation, the Databook lists express bus routes, Bee-Line feeder routes to train stations, shuttles that provide door-to-door service to corporate sites and airline information. It also includes a map of Interstate routes and parkways, commuter railroads and the Westchester County Airport in Harrison.
Looking ahead to business and infrastructure needs, the Department of Planning included in the Databook a map of telecommunications capabilities. From 1985 through 1996, $60 million was spent on expanding the fiber-optic infrastructure, the book says, with the largest center of corporate and business activity -- White Plains and Harrison -- showing the greatest concentrations of fiber-optic lines.
A section in the Databook on education includes a map of school districts, charts on enrollment and school expenditures, Scholastic Aptitude Scores by school district, the average level of education attained and lists of private schools, colleges and universities.
There are also maps of cultural sites, hotels, conference centers, parks and other recreational sites.
Copies of the Databook may be ordered for $50 from the Westchester County Department of Planning, 148 Martine Avenue, Room 432, White Plains, N.Y., 10601, or by calling 285-4400.

HEADLINE: New Transportation Chief Named

BYLINE: By DONNA GREENE 

 BODY:
COUNTY EXECUTIVE Andrew J. Spano finally gave one County Legislator what he had been pushing for -- the appointment of a black person with the title of commissioner.
Marvin V. Church, who has served as a Deputy Commissioner of Transportation, was named Commissioner of Transportation to head the department that oversees the county's bus system, transit services for the disabled and the County Airport. Mr. Church will be paid $104,370 a year. 
 The appointment must be confirmed by the Board of Legislators, one of whose members, Clinton I. Young Jr., a Democrat from Yonkers, had been critical of what he saw as the lack of diversity in Mr. Spano's top appointments. Mr. Young contended that no blacks or people of Hispanic descent had been named to a commissioner's post.
Mr. Spano, also a Democrat, replied that it was just a matter of semantics, that there were two high-level blacks whose duties put them in Mr. Spano's cabinet even if their title was not commissioner. Indeed, in announcing Mr. Church's appointment, Mr. Spano called it the third cabinet-level position held by a black. (The others are Paula Redd Zeman, the county's Personnel Officer, and John S. Pritchard 3d, the county's Inspector General, a newly created position.)
Mr. Church has worked in various government jobs. A Republican, he had served as Gov. George E. Pataki's regional director with the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal. Before that, he was appointed by then Gov. William F. Weld of Massachusetts as an Associate Commissioner of the Massachusetts State Highway Department.
Mr. Church replaces Eric B. Langeloh, who has held various high-level positions. Mr. Spano said Mr. Langeloh will remain with the county, working on special assignments.
 DONNA GREENE

HEADLINE: Revitalizing the Riverfront in Wilmington, Del.

BYLINE: By MAUREEN MILFORD 

DATELINE: WILMINGTON, Del.

 BODY:
MICHAEL S. PURZYCKI'S mandate is to focus on the future of this city's long-neglected Christina River waterfront. Yet the 52-year-old lawyer can't stop thinking about the past.
"There were 11,000 people building ships on the river at the height of World War II, and for some reason we've let that history evaporate," said Mr. Purzycki as he thumbed through 1943 employee newsletters from the Dravo Corporation's Wilmington shipyard. "There's not a lot of people around here anymore who could tell that story." 
 That slighting of the past is about to change. As head of the Riverfront Development Corporation -- a state-created organization charged with revitalizing the city's waterfront -- Mr. Purzycki intends to capitalize on the Christina's shipbuilding past.
The hope is that the area's industrial history will provide the kind of identity that will attract tourists to an exhibition hall, a catalogue-company outlet center, nightclubs, a riverfront promenade and restaurants now under development just south of the central business district.
Until recently the roughly 100 acres controlled by the development agency consisted largely of a smokestack graveyard filled with strange-looking vegetation and the ghosts of anonymous blue-collar workers whose pay records have turned up during building renovations.
But Mr. Purzycki believes that for a place to succeed it has to have a soul. "We don't want people to have that same empty feeling they have after a visit to a shopping mall," said Mr. Purzycki, whose agency has in two years spent more than $10 million in state money on the project.
He is keeping the six 50-foot cranes used in the construction of some 400 landing craft from 1941 to 1945. He also plans murals and monuments to commemorate famous ships built on the site and is considering using a film of the riverfront's war effort now in the Hagley Museum and Library here.
The cranes will loom over the 400,000-square-foot Ship Yard Shops outlet center, whose only announced participants so far are L. L. Bean and Coldwater Creek. The $36 million complex is a joint venture of the development agency, Ruth and Bill Wizner of the Tri-W Corporation in Nashville and Verino Pettinaro, a local developer who owns much of the undeveloped land along the river.
The Wizners were among the pioneers in the factory outlet concept, building centers in Hilton Head, S.C., and Nashville in the 70's. Work is now under way on the first phase of the center here -- about 20 shops in 100,000 square feet of space, which is expected to be completed by next March.
The centerpiece of the waterfront revival is the First USA Riverfront Arts Center, a 120,000-square-foot hall designed to hold so-called "blockbuster exhibits" -- shows with objects from the era depicted, but with an emphasis on storytelling. These shows are often snubbed by the traditional arts community.
Just months ago, the arts center was a dilapidated hulk that still held the gantry and rail tracks from its days as a landing-craft assembly plant. Now, the cavernous space has been carved into a hall designed to accommodate up to 1,000 people an hour when exhibits are being staged.
IT includes 25,000 square feet of galleries, a 6,000-square-foot gift shop and a 13,000-square-foot lobby. About $1 million was spent on finishing the lobby with such touches as a terrazzo floor featuring a compass rose design 40 feet in diameter.
To cover the cost of the $10 million conversion, First USA Bank, a leading credit-card bank based here, pledged $2.5 million over 10 years. The development corporation chipped in another $2.5 million, while the balance will be financed by Pettinaro Construction and the development agency.
To produce the shows, the development corporation signed a five-year contract with Broughton International Inc. of St. Petersburg, Fla., which describes itself as a full-service exhibition company that conceptualizes the show, does the research, secures the art objects, hires the employees, installs the exhibit and runs the gift shop.
Broughton's first exhibit, called "Nicholas and Alexandra: The Last Imperial Family of Tsarist Russia," will open Aug. 1 with roughly 700 objects from the Hermitage in St. Petersburg, the State Archives of the Russian Federation and the State Palace Museum in Tsarskoe Selo. The development agency expects it to draw at least 500,000 people from the region over its five-month run.
Because blockbuster exhibits can cost $5 million to $8 million to mount, the corporation has lent Broughton $2 million to cover initial costs. Recently, E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Co., the state's largest private employer, agreed to become the show's primary sponsor with a $200,000 grant.
The development agency's loan to Broughton is to be repaid through ticket sales and gift-shop revenues. The deal was structured that way because Broughton was embroiled in controversy at its last job with the Florida International Museum in St. Petersburg, Fla.
The museum held three blockbuster shows -- including the one on Russian tsarist treasures that brought in more than 600,000 people -- but lost $11 million over three years. Some of the Florida community's officials were upset that the museum was losing money, while closely held Broughton appeared to be making money on the gift shop.
James Broughton, head of Broughton International and former creator of Memphis Wonders exhibit series, maintains that the huge losses resulted from the debt the museum incurred when it converted a department store for its arts center, not from its handling of the exhibits.
Mr. Purzycki said he had crafted a contract to avoid such problems, but he conceded that the development corporation could still end up losing money on the shows.
"I'm not going to whine if we lose a couple hundred thousand dollars," Mr. Purzycki said. "I see it as an investment in making this place flourish. We need a unique attraction to bring in people from the region. We can't just rely on locals to make this work,"
That is not the only difficulty Mr. Purzycki has had to overcome in carrying out his vision for the waterfront. Individual landowners on the river have driven hard bargains as the development agency has attempted to assemble land.
" We didn't steal anything," he said. "There's not a seller on the river that needs the money." What's more, some members of the City Council and Mayor James H. Sills Jr. grew critical of what has been perceived as the state's heavy hand in developing the waterfront, which is within the city limits. Mr. Sills charged that Gov. Thomas Carper was treating the riverfront as a personal fiefdom by not including city officials and residents as partners.
Nevertheless, Mr. Sills vetoed a bill in February that would have required waterfront business to hire a percentage of city residents, saying that its passage would most likely result in a lengthy legal battle.
MORE recently, the development agency found itself in an embarrassing situation when Pettinaro Construction was accused of violating Federal environmental laws for illegally disposing of ignitable and toxic material near a riverfront park scheduled to be completed in July.
"Nothing's been easy," said Mr. Purzycki. "But we can't stop. We have to keep going."
That means pressing on with the development of a roughly 20,000-square-foot nightclub and the construction of a river walk extending 1.5 miles from just above the historic Amtrak passenger station to the retail complex. In next two years, construction will begin on boardwalks through a wildlife refuge south of the outlet center.
"We've still got at least five years' worth of work to do," Mr. Purzycki said.
