HEADLINE: YOUR HOME;
Showing Managers The Door

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO 

 BODY:
BREAKING up is hard to do; knowing when to do it is even harder. Hiring a new managing agent -- a firm that handles the details of running a co-op, condominium or other multifamily building -- is similarly dicey; it is essential to gauge with some skill when the the old one must go.
"This is not exactly a refined art," said Arthur Davis, a management consultant in Manhattan. In most cases, he said, the assessment of a managing agent should at least focus on the responsiveness of the on-site manager, the efficiency of the back-office staff and the accessibility of the top management. 
 "One of the things to look for is the time between a request for something and the time it actually takes for the management company to respond," Mr. Davis said. "One of the first signs of a deteriorating relationship is that you're not getting the same responsiveness out of the site manager as you did when the relationship started."
Meanwhile, he said, the boards of buildings must ask themselves if back-office operations have deteriorated since the managing firm was first hired.
"I believe that every board member should get a printout of the financial statement on a monthly basis," Mr. Davis said, adding that with a few years' worth of monthly reports in hand, board members can get a sense of whether the building's finances have been handled consistently, with no significant deterioration.
And the lines of communication should always remain open between the building's board and the top officials of the managing firm.
"If you're coming to a point where the site manager isn't doing his job," Mr. Davis said, "you want to be confident that you can get the president of the company on the phone."
Richard B. Montayne, a co-op accountant in Roslyn, N.Y., said the efficiency of a managing agent could also be determined by deducing what isn't included in monthly financial statements.
"Missing reports or documents may be an indication that there is a problem," Mr. Montayne said. So, too, would increasing amounts of overtime for building employees -- a sign that an agent may be misjudging what is needed for the day-to-day operation of the building.
Marc Shernicoff, a Manhattan co-op accountant, said that in addition to assessing a managing agent's technical skills and its relationship with shareholders, a board must strike a balance in evaluating such criteria.
Some managing agents, he said, excel at building good relationships with residents but are less effective when it comes to paying bills. Others may be fiscal wizards with horrible bedside manners.
"I've seen buildings get rid of excellent managing agents because they didn't like the personality of the on-site manager," Mr. Shernicoff said. "And I've seen buildings stay with managing agents that are terrible just because they love the on-site guy."
If a managing agent has a good relationship with residents and responds quickly to their requests, he said, it may be possible to overlook minor deficiencies in back-office work.
On the other hand, Mr. Shernicoff added, if a managing agent is so determined to establish a cordial relationship with shareholders that it becomes sheepish about aggressively collecting maintenance fees, the board may want to trade in the firm for one that understands tough love.
But when does a board know that it's time to switch?
"You often don't know until it's too late," said Aaron Shmulewitz, a Manhattan co-op lawyer. Mr. Shmulewitz said that some general strategies for assessing a managing agent's performance include determining whether it is taking advantage of all available bulk purchasing agreements, maximizing available discounts, comparison shopping for supplies that can't be bought in bulk and making efforts every year to try to keep down property taxes.
"You should also determine whether the management firm is following a tight and defined procedure for collecting maintenance charges," Mr. Shmulewitz said. "Find out when the first reminder gets mailed to shareholders in arrears. And find out at what point the managing agent will turn the matter over to the building's lawyer."
In addition, he said, boards should determine what criteria are used when a managing agent puts work out to bid.
"You should ask the executives of the management company what bidding procedure they are using," he said. "Are there a minimum number of bids required? Are the bids sealed or open? If the bids are sealed, who unseals them, and where are they unsealed?"
But how does a board determine, say, whether a managing agent is utilizing a "tight and defined procedure?"
"It's easy when you have clear financial statements," said Herb Rose, a co-op consultant in Manhattan.
For example, Mr. Rose said, determining whether the management firm is efficient in collecting maintenance charges is a matter of simple math.
"For me, the red flag is 5 percent," he said, explaining that if uncollected maintenance charges exceed 5 percent of total, the managing agent is not doing its job. Similarly, Mr. Rose said, if the total amount of bills not paid within 30 days exceeds 5 percent of total monthly expenses, that may be a sign that someone somewhere is dropping the ball.
"The managing agent should have a hands-on approach to running the building," he said, adding that another significant attribute is an ability to keep a board focused on a building's economic health.
This might include prodding the board to increase maintenance fees in order to keep reserve funds at an adequate level. "The bottom-line minimum should be two month's maintenance," Mr. Rose said. So, a building that collects $1.2 million in maintenance fees each year should have a working capital reserve of at least $200,000.
If a building is missing that mark, and the managing agent isn't urging the board to hit it, Mr. Rose said, it is possible that the agent is more interested in renewing its contract than in doing the best job possible. Contracts with managing firms generally run year to year.
In fact, Mr. Rose added, there is virtually no income-making or cost-cutting strategy that a competent, dedicated managing agent will overlook.
"If you can get a discount of 1 percent for paying a bill within 10 days, doesn't it make sense to pay the bill early and save the money?" he said.
Mr. Shernicoff, the accountant, offered this advice for boards that are in the process of deciding whether to replace their current managing agent:
"Talk to your other professionals," he said, explaining that since lawyers and accountants generally handle multiple clients, it is likely that they have dealt with a number of different managing agents and should be able to provide a board with some valuable insight.
Mr. Shernicoff also offered one additional and highly effective method for determining whether the time has come for a board and its managing agent to part company.
"Once you start wondering whether your agent is a clunker," Mr. Shernicoff said, "that's probably a good sign that it is."

HEADLINE: REIT's Place Their New York Area Bets

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
AS real estate investment trusts flourished around the country in recent years the New York City area was a comparative exception. But activity by REIT's in the area, each with a distinctive investment strategy, has picked up sharply.
In a little over a year real estate investment trusts have gone from being conspicuously absent from New York City to becoming a major force in the commercial property market. The publicly traded, tax-sheltered companies have bought property valued at $2.8 billion in Manhattan in the last year and a half. 
 The single biggest splash has been made by Vornado Realty Trust, based in Saddle Brook, N.J., but looming increasingly large in Manhattan. The company has made a huge bet that the area around Madison Square Garden will be the next Times Square in terms of economic revival and is preparing to develop it into the urban equivalent of an entertainment-oriented shopping mall.
According to the company, it has invested close to $2 billion in New York City office buildings, including the investments made so far this year, making it one of the city's larger landlords. It has said it plans to invest as much as $1 billion more in the city in the next two years.
Each of the REIT's operating in the region is following its own investment strategy, ranging from SL Green's exclusive focus on older Manhattan office buildings to Mack-Cali and Reckson's policies of completely avoiding the city in favor of suburban properties.
Steven Roth, the chairman of Vornado, said the company had bought most of the office, hotel and retail properties on both sides of Seventh Avenue from 34th to 31st Streets "because there is a lot you can do when ownership is concentrated in one strong hand.
"We bought the properties because we think we think we can redevelop them and improve them," he said. He noted that the Macy's Herald Square store was like one of the anchor stores of a suburban mall, and that the front door to Madison Square Garden is in 2 Penn Plaza, which the company owns.
"The streets are teeming with people day and night," he said, which for someone with deep roots in the retail business translates into potential customers. "The corner of Seventh Avenue and 34th Street is the second busiest in the city, which probably means it is the second busiest in the country."
Although Vornado was the biggest player among the REIT's buying property in Manhattan and the region, it was not the only one. Two home-grown real estate companies, SL Green Realty Corporation and Tower Realty Trust, each formed a REIT (pronounced reet) and sold shares to the public for the first time last year, and then went on acquisition sprees. And two existing suburban trusts, Mack-Cali Realty Corporation of Cranford, N.J., and Reckson Associates Realty of Melville, L.I., continued their expansion in the region, while avoiding New York City itself.
In the city, several prominent companies have taken steps to convert themselves from private ownership to the REIT form. Two New York companies, Macklowe Properties and Loeb Realty, have done the preliminary work necessary for initial public stock offerings, with Loeb in an arrangement to acquire the properties and management business of the George Comfort & Sons investment and management company. Several other companies, including Steven C. Witkoff's Witkoff Group and Larry A. Silverstein's Silverstein Properties, are reportedly primed to follow and form REIT's.
Another REIT, Boston Properties, is also active in New York and is buying the rights to develop two Times Square office sites.
The REIT's have by no means displaced the traditional family-owned companies that continue to own and develop large amounts of property. But as long as they have access to low-cost public capital, the REIT's are capable of fast growth through acquisition.
That access to capital can vary with market patterns, and many REIT's have been trading below their 52-week highs recently. Vornado, which has ranged from $32.50 to $49.813, closed Wednesday at $39.438. Reckson's price has ranged from $22 to $29, closing Wednesday at $24.25. Mack-Cali has fluctuated from $31.375 to $43, closing Wednesday at $34.125. Tower's price has ranged from $20.75 to $28.50, closing Wednesday at $22.438. SL Green, which closed Wednesday at $22.25, has moved between $21.063 and $28. Boston Properties has ranged from $26.25 to $36.063 and closed Wednesday at $34.313.
Share price is important for REIT's that want to expand; since they must pay out 95 percent of their income in dividends to retain their tax-exempt status, they have to return to the securities markets for capital or take on unwanted debt. One attraction of REIT's as investments is that they are typically not as leveraged as closely-held partnerships and thus are better able to ride out a decline in property values.
If they are faced with unresponsive investors, high-flying REIT's would have to slow their pace of growth, and some of the planned initial public offerings might be delayed, or their shares sold at prices below what their owners had in mind.
"The office REIT sector is down about 10 percent, year-to-date," said Lee Schalop, an analyst with J. P. Morgan Securities. "That means that their ability to sell stock to get money to build is curtailed."
Nevertheless, many REIT executives say that the cycle is nowhere near the peak and that now is a good time to buy property in New York, particularly in Manhattan. Some say they will borrow money, if necessary, to continue investing, although they do not want to become as highly leveraged as some closely held developers.
Real estate executives note that Manhattan has built-in protection against an overload of new supply. "If all the projects that are being talked about actually get built, they would add 6 million square feet of office space over a period of about 10 years," said Lawrence H. Feldman, the chairman of Tower Realty Trust. In the context of the 400 million square feet of existing space, he said, that amounts to an addition of about 1.5 percent.
In other words, the market is not likely to be overwhelmed by an influx of new building -- in contrast to the late 1980's, when 40 million square feet of office space was developed and marketed, much of it on a speculative basis.
Mr. Feldman's point, that Manhattan is an island already almost fully developed, was echoed by other real estate executives. They say that New York cannot add to its real estate supply the way that cities with a lot of nearby vacant land have done. If a REIT wants to become part of the New York City property market, its path is much more likely to be acquisition of existing buildings rather than development.
According to Mr. Feldman, whose REIT recently bought the 336,000-square-foot building at 90 Broad Street, the numbers are still favorable for acquisition. At a purchase price of $34.5 million, the Broad Street building cost slightly over $100 per square foot.
Rents there average $23 a square foot annually. Subtracting about $11 a square foot to operate the building produces a 12 percent return on investment, year after year. "Compare that to the $400-a-foot replacement cost," he said.
Mr. Feldman, who developed projects in the Phoenix and Orlando areas while building in New York all but ceased in the 90's, says the city is now the major focus of the company's efforts.
"Two-thirds of the company is in Manhattan," he said, adding that he expected Tower to make $200 million more in acquisitions in the city. The company already owns Tower 45 on 45th Street between Sixth and Seventh Avenues, 100 Wall Street and 810 Seventh Avenue, at 53d Street.
Each of the REIT's operating in the metropolitan area has developed its own growth strategy based on its assessment of the market. For Reckson it has been to expand beyond its roots on Long Island and acquire properties and companies in New Jersey and in Westchester and Fairfield Counties.
Scott Reckler, the president and chief operating officer of Reckson, said his company had no plans to diversify more broadly geographically. "We are very bullish on the New York area," he said. "There are some unique investment opportunities here."
ALTHOUGH REIT's have been a part of the Federal tax code since 1960, they have become more important in the last 10 years as real estate managers have found public offerings a cheaper source of capital than more traditional methods.
Traditional investors, such as life insurance companies, are selling directly-owned properties and reinvesting the proceeds in REIT stocks as a more liquid way to own real estate. Indeed, when Steven C. Witkoff's Witkoff Group bought three towers, Numbers One, Three and Four, in Newark's Gateway Center from Prudential Insurance Company, the announcement said that if the Witkoff Group were to go public, "Prudential would have the opportunity to acquire an equity stake in the company."
The reason behind the REIT's rushing into New York was a change in the 10 percent capital gains tax on sales of over $1 million that had been enacted while Mario Cuomo was governor, said Kevin Haggarty, the executive managing director of Insignia Capital Advisors, a unit of Insignia/ESG. "While the Cuomo tax was in effect, if you transferred your property to a REIT it was considered a sale that triggered tax liability," he said. Since most REIT's in this area were started by family companies contributing their properties, the tax liability discouraged their formation. The tax has since been repealed.
Vornado started the REIT wave in the city early last year by purchasing the Mendik Company, which had itself been preparing for an initial public offering as a REIT. Vornado paid $656 million for four million square feet of office space.
In many cases REIT's can outbid other investors for closely-held properties because they can pay with a form of stock known as operating partnership units, which do not trigger a capital gains tax the way a cash sale would. The units are usually convertible into the REIT's common stock after a "lockup period," during which no such exchanges are allowed.
The overhang of operating partnership units, which dilute the value of a REIT's earnings by increasing the number of shares when converted, could be an issue in REIT stock price, some executives said. The increased number of shares would reduce the reported earnings per share.
REIT's do not always win bidding wars for trophy properties, as the recent contest for the General Motors Building at 58th Street and Fifth Avenue showed. With a bid of $800 million, Donald Trump, backed by the Conseco insurance company of Indianapolis, won the building in a bidding contest that involved several REIT's.
Although forming a REIT can give a developer access to low-cost capital, becoming a public company means complying with complex securities laws, dealing with Wall Street and revealing information many businesses prefer to keep private.
"REIT's have to answer to public markets and answer frequently," said Darcy Stacom, an executive director with Cushman & Wakefield. "With a syndication, there is a reckoning once a year, but with a REIT you are on the phone in a conference call with analysts every Monday morning." This constant attention from analysts may push REIT managers to press for short-term performance at the expense of long-term success, some fear.
It is also not clear that the analytic skills designed to evaluate industrial and commercial companies can be successfully applied to real estate, some people in the industry say. "I don't think Wall Street and the analysts have the ability to distinguish between a good deal and a bad deal," said James D. Kuhn, the president of Newmark & Company Real Estate.
REIT's are tending to push up prices as they work to meet financial goals through growth, and would-be REIT operators are buying aggressively to build their portfolios in anticipation of going public, Mr. Kuhn said. "You have people who are poised to do their initial public offering, and they are buying properties to bulk up before going public," he said.
Not all real estate operators in New York are lured by the attractions of public ownership. Members of both the Durst and Rudin families, both major players in the Manhattan office market, have said they have no intention of forming REIT's.
Anthony E. Malkin, the president of W & M Properties, said his company operated like a virtual REIT, raising money from a pool of investors on a project-by-project basis. Mr. Malkin said that this form of financing allowed the company to focus on long-term performance. "A REIT is accountable on a quarterly basis, and the real estate operation may end up being secondary to the stock market," he said.
ANOTHER question is how REIT's will act in a market downturn. REIT executives argue that they will be in a better financial condition to keep up their properties than are debt-laden private operators. But some question whether the REIT's will have the management skills.
"These people are running big companies and they are good at financial engineering and managing funds from operations," said Robert Ageloff, a senior vice president of Equis, a national tenants' broker, referring to the REIT equivalent of earnings. "But will they be as good as New York's family landlords at tenant retention?"
One limitation on REIT's is that they are restricted largely to income-producing property in the investments they can make; managers have struggled to develop organizations that meet the requirements of the tax code while allowing them to do more than collect rent. One approach was the paired-share REIT, in which a separate company does the non-REIT work while the two have the same management and their stock shares trade as a unit.
But paired-share or "stapled" REIT's are no longer permitted, although a few, including Starwood and Patriot American, continue to operate because they were organized before the rules changed. To cope with the current circumstances the "paper clip" REIT has been developed. Like the paired-share REIT's, the two companies share management, but the shares of the two companies are not firmly linked and can trade separately.
Reckson has adopted the paper-clip format, with the parallel Reckson Service Industries able to invest in companies in developing industries such as the Internet and telecommunications that a pure REIT could not. Stock in Reckson Service was recently spun off to shareholders of the REIT.
Mr. Reckler said the recent low price of the company's stock would affect his plans. "We are long-term players, and adversity can breed opportunity," he said, implying that if planned public stock offerings cannot go forward, those companies who failed to sell stock could become acquisition targets by companies like Reckson.
Because of Reckson's strong balance sheet, he said, the company has no need to return to the equity market any time soon and can continue to grow.
Mr. Reckler has an expansive view of what the future holds for real estate companies like his. In a recent speech he noted that there was something on the order of $1 trillion in real estate held by major corporations, public institutions and municipalities. "I believe that in the future all real estate services will be outsourced to the real estate companies that are best equipped to provide this service," he said. "These services will include design, site selection development, management and, ultimately, ownership."
While Reckson has confined itself to the New York suburbs, what was known as Cali Realty has expanded to the Dallas area via a merger with the Mack Company and has become Mack-Cali. Thomas Rizk, the president and chief executive of Mack-Cali, said the merger was an outgrowth of the company's strategy.
"When we first went public we were basically a New Jersey story," he said. "We decided our strategy was to acquire the best management teams in the markets we wanted to be in." He said Cali had acquired the Robert Martin company, a leading Westchester County office developer, and 4.1 million square feet of office space as a means of getting into the northern suburbs of New York and had acquired properties as far south as Philadelphia. He said Mack-Cali's holdings were now about 75 percent in the Northeast and 25 percent in the southwest as a result of the Mack deal.
Mr. Rizk said the company would emphasize establishing a presence in markets, rather than simply buying widely scattered assets. And like Mr. Reckler, he said that if the stock market remained difficult he might buy properties from private investors who have purchased a lot of property in anticipation of going public and now find themselves saddled with debt.
WHILE some REIT's have emphasized geographic diversification, Stephen L. Green, the chief executive of SL Green Realty Corporation, concentrates on concentration. His strategy is to buy older office buildings in Manhattan, known as B buildings.
Mr. Green's argument is that without the lower rental rates of B buildings (compared to the newer A properties) many tenants would be forced to move from Manhattan to the other boroughs and the suburbs. "New York would not function without B buildings," he has said.
Mr. Green said he was following a strategy of buying well-situated B buildings in need of improvement, such as the properties at 70 West 32d Street and 1372 Broadway in the Garment District. "We are looking to buy deals that are consistent with our business plan," he said. "They are based on our ability to redevelop buildings."
The current low prices of REIT stocks "are a little like a self-inflicted wound," said Louis W. Taylor, a senior real estate analyst with Prudential Securities, who pointed out that a number of REIT's had brought stock offerings to the market in recent months. "There was a strong offerings calendar with equity issues being forced into a market with weak demand," he said. With the rate of offering slowing, he expects prices to recover in the second half of the year.
"It not that the REIT's have been doing anything wrong," said P. Anthony Brown, head of the REIT team at Arthur Anderson, the accounting and consulting company. "In general they have been hitting their earnings targets. It could be simply that other asset classes have been attracting more attention in the stock market."
Mr. Green, who recently raised $316 million for his SL Green REIT in a sale of 13 million shares of common and preferred stock, said he was not overly concerned about the decline in stock prices. "I think it is temporary," he said. "These trends are like the lengths of women's skirts."

HEADLINE: AT THE SHORE;
Wildwood Wants a Casino, but the State Isn't So Sure

BYLINE: By BILL KENT 

 BODY:
During the busy summer season, the Wildwood municipal parking lot at Schellenger and Pacific Avenues fills with cars whose passengers enjoy boardwalk amusements and the city's beach. Daily parking fees help finance the city's $4 million yearly operating budget.
But since 1995, some city officials and representatives of an Oklahoma Indian tribe have wanted to replace the lot with a casino that promises to pay the city $8 million a year, employ 600 to 1,000 residents, and expand Wildwood's tourist season from three months to year round. 
 Unlike the dozen gambling halls in Atlantic City 30 miles due north, the casino, to be built by the Delaware Tribe of Western Oklahoma, would not serve alcohol. It would have no restaurant, showroom or hotel wing, and would therefore not be able to provide favored gamblers with the free meals, entertainment and hotel accommodations that have forced some Atlantic City restaurants and hotels out of business. Gamblers who wanted to eat or stay overnight in Wildwood would be encouraged to patronize existing restaurants and hotels. Although the proposal attracted some local opposition, Wildwood's voters approved the casino project in a nonbinding referendum.
In the three years since Wildwood announced its development partnership with the Delaware Tribe, Camden and Trenton officials have indicated that they, too, would favor some kind of casino development.
State officials have consistently dismissed these proposals as impossible dreams. Because there are no Indian reservations in New Jersey, the 1977 Casino Gaming Act did not consider the possibility of casinos owned by Indians. The act did, however, amend the state Constitution to limit casino gambling to Atlantic City, with the provision that 8 percent of the city's gambling revenues would go to government programs benefiting the entire state. Any casino development outside Atlantic City would require further amendments to the Constitution, a process that no state legislator, even representing Wildwood, has been willing to initiate.
"I think it's safe to say that New Jersey government has shown it has a vested interest in protecting the gaming industry in Atlantic City, even though there isn't a single company operating a casino in Atlantic City that is based in New Jersey," said Andrew Sutor, a Ventnor-based casino development consultant who met with Camden and Trenton officials over waterfront casino projects on the Delaware River.
Since 1988, Mr. Sutor, a former executive at the Harrah's and Trump Plaza casinos in Atlantic City, has consulted on 50 casino projects in the United States, Europe, South America and Asia. Of those, 25 are open for business, thanks to what Mr. Sutor calls "the concept of gaming in the public interest."
"Casinos bring visitors, entertainment, money, tax revenue and jobs and additional economic activity to places where there is a need for these things," he said. "We've had casinos in Atlantic City for 20 years. We've seen what gaming has done to Atlantic City and its surrounding region. We've seen what it hasn't done. The people who live and work in a municipality like Wildwood or Camden or Trenton, who pay taxes to the state, should have the right to decide if they want a casino in their midst and how that casino should operate. Should the state be telling them that they can't have a casino because Atlantic City can have a monopoly?"
Mr. Sutor said he knew of interest in casinos in other New Jersey cities, including Jersey City, Newark and Asbury Park. "Some of these cities have the same problems that Atlantic City had, with unemployment and decaying economic base, and a casino could be the thing to put them back on the map," he said.
"A single casino in Camden would put do better than every casino in Atlantic City because Camden is closer to Philadelphia, Baltimore and Washington than Atlantic City is, and most gamblers favor what's closest to where they live. A casino in Trenton would get a lot of business from New York because Trenton is less than an hour from New York by train. Everybody in the gaming industry is watching what goes on in Wildwood because the outcome could make it possible for all these cities in New Jersey to get gaming if they want it. What the Delaware Tribe is doing to get a casino down there is pure genius."
In March, the Delaware Tribe filed a lawsuit in New Jersey Superior Court against the City of Wildwood, arguing that the land on which the city has been incorporated originally belonged to the tribe and that the tribe was illegally deprived of the land in the 19th century, when the Federal Government compelled it to move to western Oklahoma. The tribe presented archeological evidence obtained in the vicinity of Wildwood that showed Indian habitation as early as 1700.
The suit did not mention the tribe's intention to build a casino, but it did raise concepts of sovereignty crucial to the Federal Indian Gaming Law of 1988. Under that law, a Federally recognized Indian tribe, like the Delaware of western Oklahoma, has the sovereign right to open a gambling hall on land that it owns or that is held in trust for the tribe. Although the tribe must first negotiate with state government, it may not require final approval from state government before opening the casino.
The City of Wildwood owns the parking lot at Schellenger and Pacific Avenues, and Mayor Fred Wager indicated that he was willing to hold the lot in trust for the Delaware Tribe as a possible settlement to the suit.
But the tribe voluntarily dropped the suit shortly after filing it. Jefferey April, a lawyer representing the tribe, said: "The tribe decided that the issues in the suit would better be heard in Federal court. Right now, the tribe is deciding whether it would be more in the tribe's interest to file in Federal court in New Jersey or in Oklahoma."
Mr. April said he expected a decision from the tribe in a few weeks.
The tribe's actions have inspired two Republican Assemblymen, Ken LeFevre of Atlantic County and George Geist, who represents Camden and Gloucester counties, to sponsor a bill calling for a Congressional amendment to the Indian Gaming Act of 1988 that would require state approval for Indian casino operations so that New Jersey can stop the Delaware Tribe from opening a casino in Wildwood.
Of specific concern to Mr. LeFevre was the possibility that a competing casino in Wildwood might affect the winnings of casinos in Atlantic City, thus reducing the tax revenues Atlantic City casinos provide to state government.
Mark Karavan, the Wildwood city solicitor, who expects to defend the city again if the Delaware Tribe files suit in Federal court, declined to comment on what effect this legislation might have on the lawsuit, or whether a settlement of the suit would result in the proposed casino.
"I will say that we had a referendum on the subject and that the referendum passed, showing a clear majority of our citizens in favor of it," Mr. Karavan said. "The mayor is for it because he believes in representing the majority. The majority should rule in some cases. This might be one of them."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Schellenger Avenue in Wildwood, near the site where the Delaware Tribe of Western Oklahoma wants to build a casino. (Laura Pedrick for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
Israeli Exchange Hopes Domestic Companies Keep One Foot at Home

BYLINE: By JESSICA STEINBERG 

DATELINE: TEL AVIV

 BODY:
DUAL citizenship is one advantage that Israel offers to keep immigrants coming. Now it is trying to use dual citizenship to keep stocks from leaving.
Officials of the Tel Aviv Stock Exchange, worried about a flight of prominent Israeli high-technology stocks to the Nasdaq market in the United States, are trying to entice them back. The exchange is hoping that these companies will at least agree to list their shares in both places. 
 But the likelihood of a return home for most of these listings is considered weak. The impediments range from a cumbersome Israeli bureaucracy to a perception that Nasdaq is the pre-eminent market for high-technology companies trying to raise money.
Nasdaq, of course, dwarfs the Tel Aviv exchange. The $266.4 billion market capitalization of Microsoft, perhaps the best-known Nasdaq stock, is three times the size of the market capitalization of all the listings on the Tel Aviv exchange.
More than 100 Israeli companies are listed on Nasdaq, making it the largest foreign source of new listings after Canada. Only five of those companies are also listed on the Tel Aviv exchange.
Worries about Nasdaq are not obvious in The City, the neighborhood that the 60-year-old Tel Aviv exchange calls home. Visitors see tree-lined streets and outdoor cafes filled with young Israeli brokers sipping coffee and speaking rapidly into cellular phones, a reflection of Israeli prosperity and technical advances that contrasts sharply with the economy of years ago, when the nation's best-known exports were Jaffa oranges and Uzi submachine guns.
The Tel Aviv exchange lists more than 650 companies, including banks, insurers, chemical manufacturers and construction companies. Ronit Harel, head of the exchange's listings department, said it was hoping to expand its listings, and her optimism is shared to some extent in Israeli brokerage firms.
"It will become in fashion to list in Israel," said Eli Nachum, head of trading at Zannex Securities, a firm in Tel Aviv. Nonetheless, he said, "the fact that Israeli companies aren't traded in both exchanges is a disadvantage."
TO many Israeli high-technology executives, Nasdaq is preferable because of its enormous liquidity. With far more money in the market, it is easier for stocks to be bought and sold at a fair price.
Moreover, most Israeli technology companies, whether they are selling high-speed modems or Internet security software, are exporting to the United States. More often than not, their investors are Americans who are more willing than their Israeli counterparts to place their faith and finances in risky ventures.
"Israeli investors are a little scared of the high-tech stocks," said Ron Levkovitz, co-general manager of Epsilon, a private portfolio and fund management firm in Tel Aviv.
Mr. Levkovitz said 90 percent of the Israeli equity market was held by local institutional investors, made up of pension funds and other large trust funds that by law can invest only 15 percent of their assets in stocks. Institutional investors in the United States, by comparison, put more than 50 percent of their assets in stocks.
In addition, Israeli fund managers cannot buy more than 10 percent of their stocks outside Israel.
Gil Schwed, chief executive of Checkpoint Software, an Israeli provider of security software, said he never thought about listing in Tel Aviv. Checkpoint listed on Nasdaq in June 1996 at $14 a share with a market capitalization of $450 million. The shares now trade at $32, with an average volume of one million shares a day and a market capitalization of more than $1 billion.
"It's all about prices," Mr. Levkovitz said. "No one in Israel will pay the kind of prices the high-techs are commanding in the U.S."
Mr. Schwed said that from his perspective, the Tel Aviv exchange was not sophisticated, with insufficient trading volume and too little analyst coverage. He also criticized what he called unwarranted restrictions on market freedom imposed by the Israeli Securities and Exchange Commission.
It is a common criticism. David Arzi, chairman of Nice Systems, a provider of telephone computer systems, lists on both exchanges. But he said listing on the Tel Aviv exchange was akin to walking down Jerusalem's Via Dolorosa, or Street of Sorrow, the winding path that Jesus supposedly took from prison to his Crucifixion.
Quarterly reports must be filed with the Israeli securities commission and sent to all shareholders before publication, and the company's full prospectus must be rewritten in Hebrew. There are also restrictions on employee stock options; if options are offered to more than 35 employees, the company must publish a new prospectus.
"It took four months to give stock options to 88 of our people," Mr. Arzi said. "In certain aspects, Israel is the last Bolshevik country."
The Israeli securities commission is re-examining its listing requirements to help lure the Israeli companies back.
Mr. Arzi's decision to list his company on the Tel Aviv exchange has not been all bad. Indeed, Nice Systems' experience is one reason that young Israeli companies might want to list their stock at home.
Nice first went public on the Tel Aviv exchange in December 1991. At the time, the company had $1 million in profits and needed cash to reinvest in its products. Mr. Arzi said he chose Tel Aviv over Nasdaq "because it's easier when the lifesaver speaks your language."
He said that was one of the company's smartest moves, partly because the Israeli market did not punish Nice for low profits in its early years. By the time Nice went public on Nasdaq in 1996, shares were $10. They soon tripled in value.
Elan Zivatofsky, a technology analyst for Goldman, Sachs in Israel, said Nice's experience also showed the wisdom of listing on Nasdaq.
"You don't have to be a rocket scientist to figure out that the U.S. is more sophisticated and that U.S. investors are going to move Israeli shares on Nasdaq," he said.
NICE is currently the most liquid of the dual-listed Israeli shares -- 77 percent of its shares are held by United States shareholders. Teva Pharmaceutical Industries, Israel's largest pharmaceutical company and one of the Tel Aviv exchange's blue-chip stocks, is 60 percent owned by American stockholders.
Dan Suesskind, Teva's chief financial officer, said there was a nationalistic reason for listing on the Tel Aviv exchange, "just like building a Teva plant up north when there's shelling from Lebanon." However, Mr. Suesskind said, he will never leave Nasdaq, his home away from home. "Listing on Nasdaq has made all the difference for us," he said. "It's the difference between watering your company's crops from a plane instead of a pitcher."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Tel Aviv Stock Exchange lists the shares of more than 650 companies, but it is concerned about the flight of Israeli high-technology issues to Nasdaq. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: IN BRIEF;
State Plans to Sell Marlboro Hospital Grounds

BYLINE: By ANDREA KANNAPELL 

 BODY:
The state plans to sell most of the campus of the Marlboro Psychiatric Hospital, which ceased operations last week.
About 411 of Marlboro's 594 acres will be put up for sale, said Dan Emmer, a spokesman for the State Treasurer's Office. He said he did not know what would happen to the remaining 183 acres. The land is a few miles north of Freehold, Monmouth County. 
 Built in 1931 with 800 beds, Marlboro was the second large institution New Jersey closed this year in its slow move to deinstitutionalize people with mental illnesses and developmental disabilities. The state increased Marlboro's out patient and support services and moved some patients into other hospitals, including Trenton Psychiatric Hospital; Greystone Park Psychiatric Hospital, near Parsippany, and Ancora Psychiatric Hospital, in Camden County.
In April, the state closed the North Princeton Developmental Center in Middlesex County, which opened in 1898 and housed mentally retarded people. Slightly more than half of its 1,054-acre campus will be sold, Mr. Emmer said.
For both properties, he said, the state's Economic Development Authority is working "to define the best approach" to selling the property. He said that process included discussions with "interested parties," whom he would not name.
 ANDREA KANNAPELL

LENGTH: 2826 words

HEADLINE: For Banks, A Big Nudge To Do More

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY L. O'BRIEN 

 BODY:
UNION AVENUE between East 156th Street and Westchester Avenue in the Bronx is a small, humble block lined with squat apartment buildings marked by occasional splashes of graffiti. Chain-link fences hem in some yards; nearby, subway cars rattle loudly on an overhead track.
Just five years ago, drug dealers controlled the neighborhood and many of its buildings. Today, the dealers are gone, pushed out by the police and by new residents who have rehabilitated some of the buildings. One morning last week, people chatted amiably on stoops and sidewalks. Some of them would like to see others -- particularly banks -- share their faith in the neighborhood's future. 
George Rabel, the 38-year-old owner of La Marketa Barioa, a tiny bodega on Union Avenue, is among those hoping that a broader economic revival is in store for the neighborhood. But he has his doubts.
"I've been in business for nine years and I go to the bank looking for a credit line when I get short of cash," he said. "They tell me no. To get credit you have to have a credit history, but you can't have a credit history if nobody gives you a chance."
As an unprecedented merger boom continues to spawn new giants in the banking industry, the needs of borrowers like Mr. Rabel are at the center of a heated debate among community groups, lenders and politicians over the financial service industry's commitment to low-income neighborhoods across the country.
The partners in both of the biggest recently announced mergers -- Citicorp-Travelers Group and Nationsbank-BankAmerica -- recently unveiled multibillion-dollar lending packages to low-income communities that dwarf similar commitments previously made by other banks.
The pledges build upon what activists and regulators acknowledge to be a vastly improved record by banks when it comes to low-income lending -- one that has helped, along with a strong economy, to bring some vitality back to many low-income communities in the 90's.
But community groups complain that some of the outsized lending programs announced lately are designed to curry favor with the Federal Reserve, which must approve the mergers, rather than truly meet credit needs in disadvantaged areas. The most egregious example, community advocates say, is Citicorp, the New York bank that is merging with Travelers Group to create the world's largest financial services concern.
As part of their merger application, Citicorp and Travelers, which will be known as Citigroup, have promised the Federal Reserve that they will make $115 billion in loans to low-income and minority communities over the next 10 years. Community groups say that figure, large as it appears, is small relative to pledges from other banks -- notably a $350 billion, 10-year pledge by Nationsbank and the BankAmerica Corporation.
In the past, moreover, low-income lending programs were designed with the needs of a bank's local market in mind. But the Citicorp-Travelers deal is all about creating financial supermarkets, not opening local branches. And community groups say the lack of geographic specificity in the partners' lending pledge may make it less meaningful.
Plus, Citicorp and Travelers are promising about $60 billion in consumer loans, a large but unspecified portion of which will be credit cards presumably bearing high interest rates -- hardly the stuff that fuels home-buying or economic development, say the companies' critics.
"It erodes the concept of community lending to have the most powerful financial institution in the country disinterested in it," said John Taylor, executive director of the National Community Reinvestment Coalition, a Washington organization that represents 678 community groups. "A substantial portion of their commitment represents what has historically been a problem in low-income communities: credit card debt."
FOR its part, Citicorp, which has been orienting its entire business toward more affluent customers and which, until recently, sharply scaled back its mortgage operations in low-income areas, says regulations governing low-income lending do not specify or favor certain types of loans. Citicorp says it considers credit cards to be a legitimate form of low-income lending.
"Each institution, each bank, has to pursue its business and emphasize those things it's good at," said Pamela Flaherty, senior vice president for community activities at Citicorp. "We happen to be good at consumer lending and student loans and credit cards."
What gives community groups a forum is the Community Reinvestment Act, a Federal law passed in 1977 that requires a bank to help meet "the credit needs of its entire community, including low- and moderate-income neighborhoods, consistent with the safe and sound operation" of the bank.
Because a poor record under the law offers regulators grounds for scuttling a merger (though that almost never happens), merger time has come to mean negotiating time for banks and community groups. Last month, the Fed held public hearings in New York on the Citicorp-Travelers merger, evoking a spectrum of responses, including a protest by activists brandishing red umbrellas like those that Travelers uses as its logo.
In the Midwest, community groups and Banc One have reached an impasse in negotiations surrounding the bank's merger with the First Chicago NBD Corporation. The activists would like top executives to commit to a reinvestment plan, but Banc One says it prefers to make commitments market by market.
While many bankers privately say that the negotiating process leaves them feeling shaken down by community groups, activists say that is hardly their intention.
"The position of community groups is not to be opposed to financial modernization, per se," says Matthew Lee, executive director of Inner City Press-Community on the Move, a New York group that often challenges big bank mergers. "It's to insure that C.R.A. doesn't get watered down by these combinations and that low-income people retain access to the financial system."
Because of ambiguities about how the Community Reinvestment Act was to be enforced, the law lay mostly fallow until 1989, when regulators issued clearer criteria for judging banks' compliance. In 1992, Congress followed up by requiring lenders to make data on mortgage applications publicly available.
The fuller disclosure -- and heightened scrutiny by the Clinton Administration -- strengthened the hand of community groups and contributed to big increases in banks' low-income lending.
Since 1992, lending commitments under the law have totaled $875 billion, compared with just $8.8 billion in pledges from 1977 to 1991, according to the National Community Reinvestment Coalition.
"There's no question that banks' volume of lending in low-income and minority census tracts has increased dramatically," Mr. Lee said. "On the downside, the C.R.A. as written doesn't speak to the type of loans being made or what exactly constitutes lending to low-income areas."
According to a report soon to be released by the Urban Institute, a research group in Washington, greater access to housing loans has improved the quality of life in many disadvantaged areas. In low-income areas in 22 of 23 cities studied for the report, access to housing loans remained stable or went up between 1991 and 1997. In 11 of those 22 cities, "significant improvements" were registered.
But community groups say they are concerned that other types of lending, particularly lending to small businesses, might fall by the wayside as big banks link up.
Debates about how broadly the Community Reinvestment Act should be construed have gained momentum because of the changes sweeping through the financial services industry.
The proposed combination of Citicorp and Travelers, for example, would mesh traditional banking with brokerage services, insurance, mutual funds and stock and bond underwriting. But of these businesses, only banking falls under the purview of the law. And as such mergers continue, community groups worry that the momentum gained in low-income lending will be undercut.
"We see the same kind of redlining problems with home insurance as we do with lending, but insurance isn't covered by C.R.A.," said Patrick Woodall, a policy analyst with Acorn, a community group based in Washington. "And if you can't get home insurance, you can't buy a house."
Many banks feel unfairly singled out by the law, arguing that the responsibility for community lending should be extended to competitors like mutual fund companies and brokerage firms.
"About 70 percent of the traditional deposit dollar is now deposited outside of traditional banks, and that issue needs to be addressed," said Catherine P. Bessant, Nationsbank's president for community investment.
It is unlikely, however, that any expansion of the law's scope is on the horizon.
IN the Senate's consideration of a bill that would break down the Depression-era legal barriers separating banking and other financial services, Senator Phil Gramm, a Texas Republican, and other members of the Banking Committee have proposed doing away with the community-lending law entirely.
But President Clinton, Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin and Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, the New York Republican who is chairman of the committee, all oppose gutting the law. So observers say the law is likely to survive without significant changes.
Community groups, however, say the act already has been weakened by banking regulators too willing to give high marks to the vast majority of banks for their low-income lending.
In 1991, according to the Federal Reserve, 11 percent of the banks it examined received "outstanding" ratings under the act, and 80 percent received "satisfactory" marks. Only 8 percent were judged "need to improve" and 1 percent deemed in "substantial noncompliance."
Little has changed during this decade. Although banks previously given low marks receive the closest scrutiny, so far this year, 19.7 percent of the banks examined by the Fed have received "outstanding" marks, 78.2 percent were judged "satisfactory," 1.6 percent were graded "need to improve" and 0.5 percent were found in "substantial noncompliance."
Community activists also complain that the Fed -- one of several agencies that can perform compliance reviews, depending on how a bank is chartered -- is predisposed to big banking mergers. They note, for example, that the Fed held public hearings on the community impact of the First Union Corporation's recent acquisition of Corestates Financial only after the agency was pressured by activists and politicians.
While conceding a certain amount of grade inflation in community-lending examinations, Edward M. Gramlich, one of seven members of the Federal Reserve Board, said that does not mean the Fed disregards banks' lending patterns when it reviews mergers.
"It is not as quantitative as we might like it to be, but it's certainly not a pro forma approval process," Mr. Gramlich said. "There is no formal enforcement mechanism because of the way the law was written. The main enforcement tool is when we look at merger applications, and from my vantage point, we look at them pretty hard."
But Mr. Gramlich acknowledged that the scale of some of the latest bank mergers has complicated the regulators' ability to assess compliance with the lending law, especially as some banks begin to spread their wings across the entire country. The issue is what "community" a bank should be reinvesting in.
"With the megamergers that are engulfing the whole country, it does become difficult to understand what the assessment area is," Mr. Gramlich said. "I think the process will become one of banks negotiating with their regulators about where their assessment area will be."
As it is, anyone trying to examine a pledge under the Community Reinvestment Act is confronted with a welter of numbers that complicate efforts to compare banks' records or sort out exactly what a given bank considers to be a community development loan.
For instance, a study released last month by the Treasury Department's inspector general's office criticized as unreliable examinations in 1996 and 1997 by the Comptroller of the Currency, another bank regulator. And while the Comptroller's office says it has addressed the problems, officials insist that the real issue is not reliability, but the subjective standards of the law.
"We did not create a bright-line standard that establishes a certain percentage or number of loans in a certain category to generate a rating," said Steve Cross, the deputy comptroller for community and consumer policy. "What the inspector general characterizes as inconsistencies, I would characterize as the appropriate exercise of judgment by an examiner."
From the banks' perspective, the law results in what sometimes seems like little more than a numbers game.
"C.R.A. has become a volume-oriented game, with up being good and down being bad," said Ms. Bessant of Nationsbank. "I worry about crazy pricing and crazy credit as everybody tries to generate more loans in order to get a better rating."
Yet Nationsbank, the company's critics contend, is hardly above playing the numbers game itself as it pursues its merger with BankAmerica. The two banks say that their huge C.R.A. pledge, $350 billion over 10 years, is about the same as the total amount pledged by all other banks over the last two decades.
Embedded in that pledge, however, are loans that other banks do not typically count as community investment. For example, Nationsbank is including mortgage loans to upper-income members of minority groups, even though the reinvestment act emphasizes income levels -- not race -- in its guidelines.
"There is a lot in that commitment that is outside of C.R.A. but expands the idea of community development," Ms. Bessant said. "To the extent that minority borrowers have had a more difficult time accessing credit, it's very relevant under this commitment to report our minority lending at all income levels."
Like so many numbers, how the lending pledges are construed depends on who is doing the construing.
On an annual basis, Nationsbank and BankAmerica are promising to lend about 6 percent of their combined assets to low-income borrowers -- a figure that the partners pointedly noted in a press release will not include credit cards. By comparison, the new Citigroup pledges to lend about 1.7 percent of its assets.
BUT Nationsbank and BankAmerica will have more traditional domestic retail deposits than Citicorp and Travelers, noted Ms. Flaherty of Citicorp. Judged against that base -- which, she said, is a better measure of a bank's local lending activity -- Citigroup's lending pledge is more formidable: about 21 percent of the merged companies' domestic deposit base, versus about 10 percent for the combined Nationsbank-BankAmerica.
However the numbers are added up, community groups say the merger partners' big promises are too vague.
"A $350 billion C.R.A. pledge could have no impact on low-income and minority communities because C.R.A. can be interpreted so broadly," said John Gamboa, executive director of the Greenlining Institute, a San Francisco advocacy group.
Community groups say small-business loans to liquor stores or check-cashing outfits can be part of a community-investing tally in a low-income area, even though many residents do not see those kinds of businesses as contributing to economic development. And mortgage loans for low-income borrowers can be structured in ways that make them inaccessible to the borrowers who need them -- if required down payments are too high, for example, or repayment schedules too swift.
"If the commitment is not tied to a specific local credit and capital need as identified by the lender in conjunction with community investment leaders, and does not include a mechanism that allows for community involvement in the monitoring and evaluation of that commitment, then it isn't real," said Mr. Taylor of the National Community Reinvestment Coalition. Citicorp, Travelers, Nationsbank and BankAmerica, he said, put together their big pledges very quickly and with minimal input from community groups.
But bankers are extremely reluctant to be more specific about the types or locations of loans they will make under their community investment pledges, arguing, as does Nationsbank's Ms. Bessant, that such precision would "prevent us from having market flexibility."
Back in the Bronx, just a few miles north of the world's banking center, Union Avenue residents talk about the risks they have taken putting up their own cash to renovate apartments that were once uninhabitable. Now, they would like to advance another notch.
"How are small businesses and people going to get the money they need to move the neighborhood to another level?" asked 22-year-old Roberto Suero. "We have initiative here, but no banks."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 3020 words

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
Gorging On a Diet Of Deals

BYLINE: By REED ABELSON 

 BODY:
THEY are serial acquirers -- companies that play Pac-Man by gobbling up other companies, paying for the purchases with high-priced stock. It's a cycle that feeds voraciously on itself: The more a company acquires, the higher the stock price, fueling even more acquisitions.
The buyers include companies like Republic Industries and Nationsbank, Cendant and Worldcom. They promise investors that they will make money by transforming industries, providing tremendous economies of scale and greater efficiencies. 
 Early in the cycle, it may indeed work out that way. But investors can find it impossible to tell when the game is about to come to a grinding halt -- rudely punishing the acquirer's stock.
Shares in the newly formed Cendant Corporation lost nearly half their value after the company disclosed in April that one of its businesses, the former CUC International, had overstated earnings. Waste Management's troubled accounting and ill-fated diversification attempts eventually crushed its shares and are driving the company into the arms of a rival. U.S. Office Products' profits have slumped and the company recently ended up spinning off four units composed of some of its purchases.
What all serial acquirers -- the successful and the not-so-successful -- have in common is that their finances can confound even the most sophisticated investors. Buyers of these companies' stocks must decide whether to risk being swept up in the deal-making in the hopes of riding a stock up further. The sheer complexity of putting together dozens of companies or more -- in each of its most frantic years, Waste Management bought as many as 100 companies -- makes it nearly impossible to see whether the acquiring company's strategy is working.
Adding to the confusion is that many of these companies employ accounting sleight of hand; in perfectly legal maneuvers, they mask the real cost of their acquisitions through write-offs, leaving the buyers looking more profitable than they really are.
In sorting this out, investors get little help from Wall Street analysts, who often play along. After all, corporations can come down hard on naysayers. Thomas K. Brown, until recently a banking analyst for Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, long criticized the acquisition strategy of the First Union Corporation, which has made more than 70 acquisitions since 1985. As a result, he said, he was excluded from one-on-one meetings at First Union's headquarters in Charlotte, N.C. (First Union said it had never refused to meet with Mr. Brown.)
Another analyst, who asked not to be identified, recalled being threatened with a lawsuit by one serial acquirer after publicly questioning its purchases. Why the heavy-handed treatment? "So much depends on the stock price," he surmised.
Analysts can also be reluctant to look too closely at any one transaction for fear that their company might lose the lucrative investment banking fees on the acquirer's next deal.
 A result of this combination of complexity and analysts' see-no-evil, speak-no-evil approach is that the guidepost usually followed by investors -- the analysts' estimated growth rate of earnings -- can vary so wildly for these companies as to be nearly meaningless. Analysts following Worldcom, for example, peg its annual earnings growth rate at anywhere from 20 percent to more than 50 percent, a range that suggests they are doing little more than guessing.
Enthusiastic analysts are not always wrong, of course, and many investors enjoy long rides up with the stock of acquisition-happy businesses. "Lots of companies have successfully changed the profitability of an industry by acquiring," said John W. Ballen, the chief equity officer for MFS Investment Management in Boston, citing Republic Industries, Computer Associates and Cardinal Health as examples.
But other seasoned investors and analysts are so wary of the serial acquirers that they simply steer clear. "I don't feel comfortable covering a company that makes so many acquisitions," said Stephen Sanborn, the research director for Value Line of New York, which provides stock analysis to individual investors. Value Line does not cover Starwood Hotels and Resorts, for example, whose buying spree of about 40 businesses in the last three years includes this year's purchase of the ITT Corporation for $15 billion.
As a company gets larger, said Robert A. Olstein, a portfolio manager in Purchase, N.Y., "the pressure on keeping that going is growing." Mr. Olstein, who has spent decades scrutinizing companies' financial statements, also avoids these stocks. Eventually, he said, the chief executive "reaches too far," making an acquisition that leads the company to stumble.
Sometimes, of course, the game goes on so long that analysts and investors catch on. First Union has been engaged in its feeding frenzy for more than a dozen years, and the drops in its stock price after several of the bank's recent acquisitions indicate that many on Wall Street have grown tired of the game. But because of the deals' complexities, the so-called experts can be just as ignorant as the average investor about an acquirer's true performance, and the rapid rise in many of these companies' stocks suggests that the game remains as popular as ever.
A close look at three of these companies -- Worldcom, First Union and United States Filter -- illustrates the challenges for investors in evaluating a serial acquirer.
 
Worldcom
Snazzier Results Via a Juggling Act
Looking at the financial results of a serial acquirer is difficult enough -- the footnotes in its reports are full of references to actual results and pro forma results, depending on how the company is putting together the numbers for different businesses. But making it even more difficult to decipher performance are accounting techniques that allow companies to erase "goodwill" -- a measure of how much a company pays over the book value of an acquisition -- and thereby insure that their future earnings do not reflect the hefty price of their purchases.
For Worldcom Inc., the strategy of gobbling up other telecommunications players, mostly through stock-based purchases, has been a raging success to date. "They actually understand their business and make moves that are strategically intelligent," said Michael J. Mahoney, who owns the stock as the manager of the AIM Global Telecommunications fund. Shares of Worldcom, which is based in Jackson, Miss., have gained an average of around 50 percent annually over the last three years.
The overwhelming majority of analysts who follow Worldcom continue to urge investors to buy the stock, despite the drastic changes ahead as the company swells more than four times its current size with its pending $37 billion acquisition of the MCI Communications Corporation. (The final purchase price depends on a number of factors, including the price of Worldcom's stock.)
The analysts' logic goes something like this:
Worldcom is expected to earn $1.95 a share in 1999. With an estimated long-term growth rate around 30 percent a year, the stock can command a price-to-earnings multiple of 25 to 30, roughly in line with its growth rate. Presto: The stock is worth $48.75 to $58.50, making it a buy at its current price of $50.1875.
In that equation, however, the key number is the growth rate. On its own, MCI has been a much slower grower than Worldcom, says Anthony F. Ferrugia, an analyst at A. G. Edwards and one of the rare members of his profession not pushing the stock. And Worldcom is paying a huge premium for MCI. So while there may be substantial savings when the two companies combine, it is not at all clear to him how fast the combined company can grow.
"When I look at all those numbers, I don't have a crystal ball," Mr. Ferrugia said.
Mr. Mahoney acknowledges that achieving the projection of 30 percent-plus growth "takes everything working."
It also takes a little accounting magic. Over the last two years, Worldcom has managed to bolster its future earnings by a little more than $2.5 billion by making a like amount of goodwill vanish through write-offs, which are usually discounted by investors as one-time anomalies.
The technique used by Worldcom is becoming increasing popular, particularly when, because they have been buying back stock or for other reasons, companies cannot treat an acquisition as a pooling of interests, in which no goodwill is created. Instead, the buyer contends that some part of the price of a purchase is acquired research, which must be written off immediately under current accounting rules.
That, effectively, increases future earnings by reducing the amount of goodwill amortized each year, a figure that is subtracted from earnings on a company's income statement. For acquirers, the attraction of this technique is that management gets to determine how much goodwill it can write off: it is the buyer that assigns a value to the acquired research, although managements bring in appraisers to help.
"It is a very, very subjective estimate," said Baruch Lev, a professor at New York University's Stern School of Business who has recently completed a study of the technique.
What concerns Professor Lev is the possibility that investors are failing to discount such companies' future higher earnings. "Some of this growth in earnings and high return on equity will turn out to be bogus," he predicted.
Look at what would happen to Worldcom's earnings-per-share numbers if the company had not taken those write-offs in the last two years. If it had amortized the goodwill over 20 years -- Worldcom's practice varies from 10 years to 40 years -- it would have eliminated roughly $125 million a year in goodwill expenses, or around 12 cents a share. If estimated 1999 earnings were, therefore, $1.83 a share, the stock, at a multiple of 25 to 30, would today be worth $45.75 to $54.90. And that would make it less of a buy.
Investors should be prepared to see the same technique used when Worldcom completes its merger with MCI, which is expected to result in about $25 billion in goodwill, the premium it is paying for MCI. Worldcom may write off some of that sum as acquired research -- about $3 billion, according to the company. "It could very well be a higher number," added Gary Brandt, Worldcom's vice president for investor relations.
Mr. Brandt argues that Worldcom is already being penalized by its accounting for earlier purchases, from which the amortization of goodwill wipes out about 50 cents of earnings per share a year, he said. The company, he added, relies on independent appraisals to determine how much it can write off for research and stays well within accepted accounting practice.
Kevin M. Moore, an analyst with BT Alex. Brown, dismisses the significance of Worldcom's accounting treatment. "The creation of goodwill is an accounting charge and does not change its cash flow," Mr. Moore said, adding that the latter is the most important measure in determining what a company is worth.
And he is not concerned about how Bernard J. Ebbers, Worldcom's chief executive, arrives at his results. "As long as they do $2, however they do it is fine with me," he said.
Professor Lev counters that analysts rely heavily on earnings in valuing companies, so how they come up with those numbers is important.
"Accounting is accountability," he said, adding that managers have little incentive to pay less for an acquisition if they do not have to account for its full price.
 
U.S. Filter
How Fast Does Your Company Grow?
Serial acquirers are so difficult to analyze because of the guesswork in determining even the most basic information about a company. How fast would it grow if it had made no acquisitions? How fast are its new businesses growing?
Few companies have been shopping as busily as the United States Filter Corporation, which has completed more than 150 acquisitions since 1991 -- roughly 60 in the last year alone -- to become the nation's largest provider of water-treatment systems.
There is a logic to the strategy of the company, which is based in Palm Desert, Calif. "You have an industry that's just ripe for consolidation," said Patrick S. Adams, a portfolio manager for Berger Associates in Denver who owns the stock.
But keeping track of all of U.S. Filter's activities is nearly impossible. Its frenetically acquired operations range from waste-water treatment plants to the sale of bottled water. And the sheer number of purchases means that most investors do not know how quickly certain businesses are growing and how profitable they are.
"How many people have done real in-depth models for every division they've acquired?" asked one portfolio manager, who has owned the stock but asked not to be identified. "Probably no one."
The real mystery may be the company's internal growth rate, which is the measure of how quickly U.S. Filter is increasing its business without the benefit of all of its acquisitions. Like a lot of companies, U.S. Filter will tell curious analysts what that rate is -- somewhere in the vicinity of 10 percent -- but the figure never appears in the financial statements available to the average investor. "It is an estimate, yes," said Tim L. Traff, a co-founder of the company and its executive vice president for development.
And while U.S. Filter has been quick to supply anecdotal evidence of how its purchases have fared, a more systematic appraisal is essentially impossible, because the company does not provide detailed information about every purchase, said Rod Lache, an analyst at Deutsche Bank Securities. Mr. Lache, who nevertheless recommends the stock, concedes that the anecdotes "are not helpful in modeling" the company's future performance.
In fact, figuring out how U.S. Filter's purchases have fared proved so challenging that the Securities and Exchange Commission asked the company earlier this year to improve the disclosure in the company's public financial statements.
The S.E.C. declined to comment, and the company said its discussions with the commission were routine.
"We give out as much information as we humanly can on a daily basis," Mr. Traff said.
Like Worldcom, U.S. Filter seems to be a master of accounting wizardry, which contributes to the difficultly in estimating future earnings growth.
According to the Center for Financial Research and Analysis, a group in Rockville, Md., that studies corporate accounting for professional investors, U.S. Filter took several charges in its December quarter that could help inflate future earnings. The company's acquisition last month of Culligan Water Technologies for $1.5 billion in stock complicates matters further because Culligan itself made more than 35 acquisitions in its most recent fiscal year and took several charges.
U.S. Filter defends its accounting as appropriate and has promised to take away at least some of the mystery. Starting with its quarterly results due out in August, the company said, it plans to disclose more information about its individual divisions, like their revenues and operating margins.
"It's the first time we'll be able to dissect the company and judge the progress of the company," said Mr. Lache, who, with the information that is available, ha projected an earnings growth rate of 25 percent or more for U.S. Filter.
 
First Union
Share Sags May Spur Game Plan Change
Eventually, analysts and investors can judge the results of a serial acquirer's strategy. If they grow skeptical -- even sending the stock down on news of another purchase -- a company may send its Pac-Man strategy packing. First Union seems to be taking that step.
In the whirl of acquisitions among banks, First Union has been among the busiest, growing from a single-state bank with about $7 billion in assets in 1984 to a 12-state banking giant with $220 billion in assets.
But some analysts and investors have grown sharply critical of the bank's strategy and say its acquisitions have diluted its earnings. The market's judgment is that First Union has overpaid for its purchases, using stock with a relatively low price-to-earnings multiple to pay for companies with higher P/E ratios. "Guess what -- that causes dilution," said Mr. Brown, the early critic of First Union. He is now working for Tiger Management, a money manager in New York.
The company's stock has certainly suffered. Over the last five years, First Union has returned 184 percent, compared with a 304 percent gain in the Standard & Poor's large-bank index. On the day last November when First Union announced it would buy Corestates Financial in a $17.1 billion deal, First Union's stock lost more than $2 a share -- roughly a 4 percent drop. Regardless of the bank's efforts to show that its acquisitions make sense, "the market is saying that these deals do not have as much economic value," said David Ellison, a portfolio manager for the brokerage firm Friedman, Billings, Ramsey.
First Union has apparently heard Wall Street's complaints, although the bank declined to comment on its strategy. Edward E. Crutchfield, its acquisitive chairman, is now telling analysts and investors that the bank will not pursue deals in which it must pay a premium, like its acquisition of Corestates, but instead will look for a partner with which to achieve a "merger of equals."
Mr. Ellison, for one, is not so easily convinced. He said First Union's management, having watched the bank's stock suffer, would try to increase the P/E ratio. Cynics might argue that executives are trying to get "the currency up so they can do a deal," he said.
In general, it pays to be skeptical of any company whose fast growth is largely a result of a frenetic buying spree. The company will almost surely stumble, said Mr. Ballen of MFS, who is a big shareholder in one recent sufferer, Cendant. "It's going to happen," he said. "I'm sure that it's happened to every company that makes acquisitions."
And that is why investors who are interested in reducing their risks might want to consider sitting out this particular game.

"The Pac-Man Offense"
Like the hero of the classic video game, companies have been dining on rivals, growing through one acquisition after another. What these serial acquirers share are finances complex enough to confound the most sophisticated analyst. Some examples:
 
Levitated
Earnings enhanced by highly subjective write-offs have helped sustain Worldcom's share price.
 
Obscured
Disclosures like this one illustrate how acquisitions make it difficult to follow U.S. Filter's financial performance.
 
Punished
After more than a decade of acquisitions, the market has concluded that First Union is spending too much on its deals. (pg. 1)
