PUB-DATE: July 5, 1998

SECTION: Section 4; Page 3; Column 1; Week In Review Desk

LENGTH: 1322 words

HEADLINE: The World;
Finding the Silver Linings in Japan's Storm Clouds

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
DEN FUJITA, one of Japan's most successful and iconoclastic businessmen, is reveling in Japan's economic woes. As the owner of half of McDonald's Japan, Mr. Fujita has so relentlessly slashed prices of burgers, shakes and fries that it's now cheaper to buy a Big Mac in Tokyo than in New York -- even without the yen's recent tumble. Profits are soaring, and Fujita-san is crowing.
"These bad times are a good thing for me," he said. "No problems at all for us, not one." 
 Mr. Fujita is a rare bird these days, when most economists and world leaders see nothing redeeming in Japan's skid into a recession that took hold last winter and now threatens to undermine the already faltering economies of the rest of Asia.
Instead of taking its medicine seven years ago when recession loomed after the collapse of the real estate market, Japan persisted in a policy of denial, keeping the economy stumbling along with public works projects and lenient accounting rules that allowed banks to paper over bad loans and corporations to dress up their balance sheets.
For all its dodging and feinting, Japan has become the pariah of the global economy, which is itself under threat from a Japanese economic meltdown. Japan is still the world's second-largest market, and as such is an integral part of the global financial system. If Japan sneezes, the world is liable to catch a cold.
But some economists say there is a silver lining in the black clouds scudding across the Japanese economic horizon. The nation's current credit crunch, weaker yen, higher unemployment and lower prices, these economists maintain, actually present an opportunity for an economic restructuring that would return the nation to economic preeminence. "There is a potential strong upside to Japan's downside," said David Asher, a Japan scholar at Oxford University. "Structural adjustment will inevitably be painful and socially and politically disconcerting. However, no pain, no gain."
 
An Alternate Strategy
Mr. Asher is by no means a wide-eyed optimist. He is the co-author, with Andrew Smithers, of a damning portrait of the Japanese economy published last March by the School of Advanced International Studies at Johns Hopkins University. They argue that mountains of debt, growing loan defaults, low productivity and falling asset prices and birth rates will turn Japan into an economic has-been if the Government fails to clean up the banking system, and persists in trying to hold off market forces.
Instead, the authors maintain, tighter bank lending and lower prices should force Japanese businesses to become leaner and more efficient. And rising unemployment need not be a cause for panic, given Japan's demographics, changing workplace culture and the experience of American businesses that rebounded from the downsizing of the early 1990's. Last week the Government did announce a sweeping rescue plan that would close insolvent banks and clear away bad debt, which Mr. Asher says is a good start.
While a Japanese collapse might be in Japan's long-term interest if it forces a thorough economic revamping, it would almost certainly clash with the rest of the world's short-term interests; when the yen went into a free fall last month, the American stock market retreated and exporters around the world began toting up the losses they would suffer from the coming flood of cheaper Japanese products.
But if Japan keeps postponing wrenching reform, its economy will continue to languish, further postponing a recovery in the region -- which will eventually take a toll on economies in Europe and in the United States.
"What if Japan had a hard landing but a fast bounce-back?" said Kathy Matsui, chief strategist at Goldman, Sachs & Company in Tokyo. "That would be good for Japan and ultimately good for the rest of Asia, too."
Take the falling prices that thrill Mr. Fujita. For years, tourists to Japan have dined out on tales of Japan's $200 cantaloupes and $6 strawberries, but Japanese housewives have had to live with the reality of a $2 zucchini and $12 bag of rice. It's no wonder people are flocking to McDonald's, particularly at a time when companies are cutting bonuses and other perks.
The Japanese stand to benefit from lower prices for consumer goods, Mr. Asher said, as well as lower land and asset prices. Once the prices of real estate and other assets reflect their true value, companies will be able to produce higher returns on their investments, which in turn will lead to more investment and economic growth.
The same thinking goes for tighter bank lending. Small and midsize businesses have had difficulty getting loans from banks, which are themselves scrambling to meet international standards for capital and disclosure.
Bankruptcies have skyrocketed as individuals and small entrepreneurs have found themselves unable to get loans, which in the past they had used to repay old debts. The fact that banks are breaking that vicious cycle and saying no -- after years of saying yes with little regard for creditworthiness or business rationale -- is an enormous step toward a more realistic allocation of capital. It is a very painful process but one destined to put the financial system on sounder footing and make businesses leaner and more competitive. Another area of concern is unemployment, which is running at a postwar high. For decades, the West has bemoaned Japan's system of lifetime employment, but now that the system is breaking down, a number of foreign economists are wringing their hands over the accompanying layoffs.
It is true that Japan's social safety net is woefully insufficient. Laid-off workers receive an average monthly handout of about $360 at current exchange rates, according to Douglas Ostrom, who has written extensively about Japanese economic reform. And the Government is far more likely to finance a new bridge or railway track as an antidote to unemployment than commit money to bolstering the welfare system.
But some economists say the anxiety over unemployment ignores the fact that the nation will face a labor shortage after the year 2000 because of low birth rates. Thus, most workers losing their jobs as the economy restructures should eventually find new ones -- as long as the Government fosters programs to develop new skills.
American companies slashed tens of thousands of workers from payrolls in the early 1990's, but now the nation has one of the tightest labor markets in memory. Because of Japan's low birth rate, high education levels and cultural commitment to providing work for those who want it, downsizing in Japan will probably be far more gentle than it was in the United States.
 
Howling Over the Yen
Already, as Japanese companies find themselves stretched by the traditional pay system in which workers are paid based on seniority and regardless of skills and performance, longtime benefits like low-interest loans and transportation costs are being slashed. Some companies are even scrapping the seniority-based pay system and moving toward merit-based systems.
As for the yen, there is more than a little self-interest in the howling from Washington and other nations for its recovery. Japanese companies benefit from the yen's decline because their products become cheaper, which hurts their foreign rivals. And improved sales by Japanese companies are good for the Japanese economy, which after all is what the world is pressing for. A healthier economy means a stronger yen, a stronger Asia and less threat to America and Europe.
Nonetheless, Mr. Asher, for one, wonders if Japan is willing to swallow all these pills, and if the rest of the world wants them to, knowing of the short-term consequences for the global economy. "One cannot help but worry whether both the Japanese themselves and the world around Japan are willing to accept two to three more bad years while Japan reorients itself," he said.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
As the Fed Points Out, History Doesn't Lie

BYLINE: By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
Will today's easy-money atmosphere at American banks lead to hard times tomorrow?
Yes, if the past is prologue. Whenever lenders go from tough guys to E-Z Credit "R" Us, loan losses are almost inevitable. 
 With the economy perking, lenders are the life of the party. "Banks always manage for the up part of the cycle, not the whole cycle," said Charles Peabody, bank analyst at Mitchell Securities in New York.
Bank-stock bulls seem to think the industry is no longer cyclical. As a result, shares are trading at historic premiums to book value. The Philadelphia Stock Exchange bank index -- composed of 24 of the nation's largest money center and regional banks -- is up 16 percent this year. Over the last twelve months, the index has gained 33 percent, beating the 27 percent rise of the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. But a letter that the Federal Reserve Board sent to the nation's commercial banks last month indicates that in this regard, at least, the Fed is not ready to toss traditional standards into history's ashcan.
The letter, written by Richard Spillenkothen, director of banking supervision, isn't alarmist. But because it details the results of an extensive Fed review of bank asset quality and credit standards, it makes surprisingly interesting reading.
In comparing loans made in 1995 with those made last year, the Fed found that intense competition for loan customers had led to a significant relaxation of lending standards. That hasn't resulted in ugly problems, the Fed said, because of the robust economy -- a caveat made more pointed by reports last week that manufacturing activity had slowed in June for the first time in almost two years.
Indeed, ugly may come sooner, not later, if some of the lending practices identified by the Fed are commonplace. Only 20 to 30 percent of the several hundred loans reviewed showed any attempt by lenders to project how a borrower might perform in an economic downturn. In nearly half the loans, approval documents did not describe key financial covenants -- thresholds in financial performance that a borrower must meet -- that might lead to protective action by a bank before a loan goes belly-up. "Management may be inadequately informed as to the risks" associated with loans, the Fed wrote. Another concern was the rapid growth in loans to real estate investment trusts. Although these loans are now sound, the Fed warned that they might represent concentrated credit risk at banks.
Singling out REIT's, Mr. Peabody said, may be a concession to Fed members worried that rocketing real estate prices are one of the wealth effects of an overheated stock market. He thinks a schism may be developing inside the Fed. In May's Open Market Committee meeting, William Poole, president of the St. Louis Fed, and Jerry Jordan, president of the Cleveland bank, dissented from the decision to leave interest rates unchanged. Arguing for a tighter monetary policy, Mr. Jordan cited asset price inflation as a main concern.
Mr. Peabody finds this intriguing, because schisms within the Fed are unusual. There was a similar divergence on policy between regional Fed banks and their Washington counterparts in 1928. The regional members wanted to raise rates, Washington did not.
The split made headlines in March 1929, giving a jolt to stock prices. They recovered, but what happened later that year is, as they say, history.

HEADLINE: VIEW;
In Black, And No Place To Hide

BYLINE: By Elizabeth Hayt 

 BODY:
IT was a female disaster of the first order, up there with meeting someone really cute and realizing you have lipstick on your front teeth. Invited to the Museum of Modern Art's "Party in the Garden," one of the last blowouts on the spring black-tie calendar, I decided to try my gown on ahead of time to check the fit.
It was a very clingy number from three seasons past. But the dress, once fashionably sexy, seemed badly out of date. Unlike this year's sheaths that discretely skim the body, my hip-hugging, low-cut design left nothing to the imagination. 
 In a panic, and with only nine hours to go before the party, I raced to Bergdorf Goodman, arriving just as the store opened at 10 A.M. I bolted to the escalator and landed at the Chanel boutique, a safe haven for the fashionable in desperate straits.
And as if the deity of good taste was smiling on me, the perfect little black dress appeared before my eyes. It was a variation on Audrey Hepburn's gown in "Breakfast at Tiffany's," made of wool crepe with slender straps and a trumpet-flared skirt. It not only fit to a T, but was also on sale.
I sashayed into the museum that night with utter confidence, a green cashmere sweater over my shoulders for an added touch of oh-so-trendy nonchalance. But as the air kisses started to fly, my self-assurance suddenly cracked. All around were radiant young women in sugary-colored, diaphanous confections, the antitheses of my little black look. You could practically hear the "oohs" and "ahs" around the 20-something sisters Jane Lauder and Aerin Lauder Zinterhofer, both in Oscar de la Renta chiffon creations. Aerin was a portrait in lemon yellow; Jane, in yellow and hot pink.
I felt like a black hole in a galaxy of bright young sparklers. The little black dress, I realized, might be suffering the same fate of many great stars, collapsing under the weight of its own history. Nearly 75 years after it was first introduced by Coco Chanel -- a style that Vogue predicted would become the Ford of fashion -- the little black dress is nothing more than a basic Ford Taurus. Even though my dress was Chanel, without a color or even a camellia to set it apart, it might as well have been from the mall.
"The black dress is gone," Samantha Boardman, a medical student who wore a knockout lavender Versace dress that night, told me a few days later. "You do get buried in black. You can disappear in it. You are anonymous in it."
Margaret Walch, director of the Color Association of the United States, which tracks color trends, put it succinctly: "Black is like Perrier, which did itself in."
Certainly the color issue has flip-flopped since the last time I dressed up. Hothouse tones used to be a sure sign that either a tourist or an aging socialite was on the loose. But these days, festive evening finery is neither provincial nor passe. Like their mothers before them, a younger generation of trend-setting social women are now decked out in rainbow hues, infusing color with new cachet.
"For evening clothes, there has been a change," said Brooke de Ocampo, 31, an associate at Sotheby's and a chairwoman of the New York Botanical Garden's junior fund-raising committee. "For day, there's still a black T-shirt and khaki clam diggers. But when I think of the last five black-tie events I've been to, I can't think of any black dresses."
Clearly, I don't get out enough.
But I do read fashion magazines, and it is true that there hasn't been a black evening gown on the cover of Vogue, W or Harper's Bazaar in at least six months. At Bergdorf, I later discovered, there was a full selection of black Versace and Armani gowns on sale, but the colorful Oscar de la Renta racks had been picked clean.
Like the appearance of Christian Lacroix's pouf dress of 1987, the last high point of conspicuous consumption before the current pecuniary frenzy, this season's fashion extravaganzas seem an expression of the bubbly economy.
"With the rebirth of parties and festivities, our generation is enjoying the glamour of dressing up," Ms. de Ocampo said. "Black does wonders for everybody, but it doesn't require much thought. You tend to put on a color, it shows more imagination and courage."
Goodness. Now my black dress was not only out of style, but also a sign that I lacked guts. And all along I had thought that black was a statement of female strength. It is no coincidence that the black dress first emerged in the 1920's after the suffragist movement won women the vote. Again in the 80's, as women ascended the corporate ladder, black dresses were on the rise, their popularity soaring in this decade.
"For the past 10 to 12 years, you've had the 'Armani' phenomenon, not that he isn't a wonderful designer," Mr. de la Renta, the longtime standard-bearer of color, told me. "When a professional woman wanted to dress, she wanted to be taken seriously, which meant not being noticed. Black is the least memorable color. Women have outgrown all that. There is a whole new generation of girls dressing in a pretty manner."
Aerin Lauder Zinterhofer, director of creative product development for Estee Lauder, called the recent explosion of color a reaction against years of androgyny. "People are maxed out on minimalism," she said. "They are looking for something feminine. Floral fragrances and fabrics are popular. Pink chiffon, pink lipstick, high heels and long hair are back."
As color returns, the daughters of the ladies who lunch have rediscovered their mothers' favorite designers -- namely, Mr. de la Renta, Bill Blass and Carolina Herrara, longtime devotees of a luscious palette and feminine styles. "For nighttime, Oscar and Bill have very sleek and sexy things for me, as well as things that would appeal to my mom," Ms. de Ocampo said. "They'll do something in a silk jersey, which is a sort of semi-retro Halston look that has a certain moderness appealing to our age."
In turn, Mr. de la Renta, Mr. Blass and Ms. Herrara are taking a cue from their younger customers, particularly those who are family members. "My sister, Carolina Jr., is my mother's muse," said Patricia Herrara, 24, a daughter of Carolina Herrara. "Her designs haven't exactly changed, but the fabrics are more fluid and there's no more hard construction, which gives them a younger look."
Mr. de la Renta acknowledged the influence of his 29-year-old stepdaughter, Eliza Reed. "Eliza is very feminine, and she influences my eye," he said. "She has so many young friends, and they all wear my clothes. I have these young customers, and I am thinking of them. They're a whole new consumer and a very important one."
Still, not everyone is convinced of the rightness of pink, nint green and baby blue after dark. "All these women who are wearing these sherbety colors, they're going to splash something like summer strawberries on their light-colored dresses or look in the mirror and say, 'Oh my God, I look so fat,' " Amy Edelman, author of "The Little Black Dress," said. "Color is a blip in fashion history. There's been 'death to black' before, but the black dress will never go away."
I, for one, am glad to hear it. Because even though my Chanel dress was 40 percent off, it cost plenty. I can justify the price as an investment in a classic. But the best way to get my money's worth, I figure, is to wear it to death.

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
A Flexing Of Muscle In American Steel

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
PRODUCTION at American steel companies is booming, with the mills cranking out tonnages not seen in decades. Manufacturers are building new plants using new technology and methods that produce efficiencies never dreamed of in the factories that once stood in places like Pittsburgh and Youngstown, Ohio, and still symbolize the industry's rust-belt image for many people.
Last year, mills in the United States produced 107.5 million tons of raw steel, a 22.3 percent increase over 1991, the low point of the decade, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute, a trade group. 
 Production is expected to be as good or better this year, and the outlook for the next few years is promising, too, with a peak of 110 million tons expected in 2001, according to a survey conducted by Locker Associates, a steel consulting firm.
The sector of the industry that makes steel by melting scrap -- rather than treating ore in the standard old-fashioned blast furnace -- has been gaining market share, accounting for 46.4 percent of total production last year, up from the mid-30 percent range early in the decade. Its share is eventually expected to exceed 50 percent.
The scrap-based operations were once known as mini-mills, but they are not so mini anymore. Indeed, if the mini-mill leader, the Nucor Corporation, proceeds with planned and expected expansions, it will emerge as the largest steel producer in the country, eclipsing the USX Corporation.
Lately, though, the steel industry has encountered some speed bumps, and it faces the possibility of longer-term problems.
The strike at the General Motors Corporation is cutting demand for high-quality sheet steel, the principal product of the remaining integrated companies -- those that make steel from raw materials forward, using blast furnaces to process iron ore.
Power shortages in the Midwest are affecting scrap-based companies, which use electric furnaces that require vast amounts of power to liquefy scrap.
Overshadowing the industry are the economic problems in Asia and the weakening of Asian currencies, which has made Asian steel cheaper to buy. The fear is that if large amounts of steel at low prices flood this country, domestic producers will cut prices, hurting profits.
Nevertheless, the steel industry is vastly different now than it was in the 1980's, when mills deemed obsolete were closed, throwing tens of thousands of people out of work.
Because of the impurities in scrap, older steel companies thought the mini-mills could never produce the high-quality sheet steel used in appliances and interior car parts. Nucor proved them wrong with its plant in Crawfordsville, Ind., in 1989.
Today, the former general manager of that plant, Keith E. Busse, and some of those who worked with him there are no longer part of Nucor. They are the top executives of Steel Dynamics Inc., the fastest-growing company in the industry.
To further improve quality and to help protect themselves against rising scrap prices, many scrap-based companies are developing methods of separating iron from ore without using a blast furnace. (Steel is iron with a small percentage of carbon and other additives.)
The integrated companies, meanwhile, are using the symbol of their old ways, the blast furnace, to retain key customers, like makers of the exterior parts of automobiles and light trucks. Because they work with raw materials, these companies can more closely control the chemistry and metallurgy of their products.
Their newer methods have produced lighter, stronger types of steel. The Bethlehem Steel Corporation, which helped build the Golden Gate Bridge and 1,100 World War II ships, is now known for products that were not even made 10 years ago, like ultra-light sheet steel for auto bodies. Steel scientists have calculated that if the 24-year-old Sears Tower in Chicago were erected today, it would require 35 percent less steel because of advances in steel strength.
These improvements have made foreign auto makers that assemble cars in this country, including Mercedes-Benz, BMW, Toyota, Honda and Nissan, happy to use locally produced steel, avoiding the expense of importing it from home.. Some studies show that American steel mills have lower costs than those in Germany and Japan.
The lower costs are a result of improvements in productivity in the American steel industry. One key measure is the amount of labor needed to manufacture a ton of steel. The industry has more than doubled labor productivity, to 3.59 hours of employee work per ton in 1995, the last year for which figures are available, from 10.1 in 1982.
But this understates what has happened. Some new scrap-based mills are so automated they can make a ton of steel with less than a half-hour of a worker's labor.
All of this said, there does not seem to be much money to be made by investing in steel stocks, at least at this time. Many are currently trading near their 52-week lows, with little to excite buying interest.
Even Bethlehem Steel, considered a model industrial comeback story, has suffered recently. Its stock, which doubled in value from January to April, has since fallen more than 20 percent, to trade at the $12.75 to $13 level.
"Asia is the biggest wild card out there," said Robert Schenosky, a metals analyst with Merrill Lynch. He said prices of steel produced in Asia are looking increasingly attractive to potential buyers in the United States, putting pressure on domestic steelmakers.
Eventually, the stocks will be cheap enough to create trading opportunities, but that point hasn't arrived. "The market dynamics are very difficult for steel stocks," Mr. Schenosky said. "Not all the bad news has been built into steel stock prices yet."
Steel imports have already begun to climb. R. Wayne Atwell, an analyst at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, said imports rose 21 percent in April after falling in the first three months of the year.
He sees an exception to the pessimistic near-term outlook for steel stocks in Steel Dynamics, which began commercial operations in January 1996. It is increasing production capacity to 2.4 million tons a year from 1.4 million tons, and is adding higher-priced offerings.
Steel Dynamics shares have fallen sharply on expectations of weak second-quarter earnings. This last week they reached a low for the year of $13.75, off 57 percent from their 1998 high of $23.375 on April 15, closing the week $14.125.
Mr. Atwell said the company's problems were temporary and "the price more than discounts the likely earnings disappointment."

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CROWN HEIGHTS;
A Library for Toy Therapy

BYLINE: By ERIC HUBLER 

 BODY:
Parents are forever trying to teach their children that sharing toys is good.
But such generosity can also yield health benefits. So a Cobble Hill couple are founding one of the region's few toy libraries, to help ill infants who are economically disadvantaged. 
 Pauline's Library is to open as part of the Infant and Child Learning Center at Kings County Hospital in August. It is named for Pauline Lazar, who died in March, one day shy of 10 months, as a result of hypotonia, or low muscle tone. The condition is also known as "floppy baby" syndrome.
"It becomes apparent that you need a lot of stuff," said Paul Lazar, an actor, of his daughter's therapeutic regimen. (His wife asked that her name not be used.) And ordinary toys, it turns out, are among the most helpful. To give Pauline an incentive to lift her arms, for example, Pauline's therapist, Jean MacKenzie, prescribed one of those arches under which babies lie and grab for dangling goodies.
Though Pauline was a patient at Long Island College Hospital and Ms. MacKenzie treated her at home, she has a day job at Kings County. The Lazars were full of questions about families dealing with hypotonia, said Ms. MacKenzie, who explained that many of the patients were inner-city children whose families didn't have the money to buy appropriate toys.
"So when everything happened with Pauline," the therapist said, "they asked if we would be open to accepting donations."
The Lazars posted fliers at their synagogue and in stores in downtown Brooklyn asking for "new and gently used" baby toys, and got a good response. The couple plan to pick up the toys themselves to keep costs down, and to wash the toys once a week at the library, which will also serve children with disabilities besides hypotonia. (Those interested may call 718 245-3296 to donate toys, time or money.)
The Lazars expect that Pauline's Library will be the largest of its kind in New York City. One of the few others, run by United Cerebral Palsy, is on Lawrence Avenue off Ocean Parkway in Borough Park.
New York City is completely without a nontherapeutic toy library that can be used by the general population. The chief obstacle, New York librarians say, is fear of germs and lawyers.
Such libraries are common in Europe and elsewhere in the United States. Membership toy libraries have been operating for decades in Washington and Pittsburgh, and a few public libraries on Long Island and in Connecticut circulate toys as well as books. ERIC HUBLER

HEADLINE: The World: Searching for Tibet;
The Shangri-La That Never Was

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE

 BODY:
IN 1888 an American diplomat-turned-adventurer named William Woodville Rockhill set out to explore Tibet, a territory he described in his journal as "a very imperfectly known portion of the Chinese Empire." It still is.
When President Clinton and President Jiang Zemin of China engaged in a public exchange on the subject last week, they spoke for two diametrically opposed lobbies. One, drawing on a largely Western vision of Tibet, sees a Himalayan Shangri-la waiting to be freed from beneath the Chinese boot. The other imagines a territory rescued from a dark and brutal theocracy by a modernizing government in Beijing. 
 Neither perception, most scholars say, accurately reflects the unique culture that flourished, and still struggles to survive, on the high-altitude Tibetan plateau.
Tibet, a nation that produced one of the world's great medieval empires, striking fear in enemies from Central Asia to the heart of China in the eighth century, did not later develop into a modern, ultimately industrialized nation-state as its counterparts in Europe did. Nor did it sink into the long decline of once-great Islamic civilizations. It became instead a demilitarized, decentralized, isolated country in the shadow of Mongolian and Manchu rulers but dominated by its Buddhist monasteries and lama-kings trying to rule over a collection of quarreling sects. Some of the more hot-headed followers of the Dalai Lama, Tibet's spiritual leader, now blame the religious powers who disarmed the country for its weakness in the face of Chinese might.
Tibet had all but disappeared for a thousand years before 19th-century explorers cajoled their way to Lhasa, the capital. Their heirs are the seekers of the late 20th century, who have mined Tibet, or perhaps an imagined Tibet, for its nonviolence, spirituality, meditative arts and herbal medicines. Many, spurred by Hollywood's recent films on the subject, have found a cause in the exiled 14th Dalai Lama, driven from his sanctuary in Lhasa by the advancing Chinese Army in 1959.
But by the time the Dalai Lama was arriving in India, another school of thought had seized the imagination of influential intellectuals. Promoted by Beijing and by Westerners who became enamored of Mao Zedong's 1949 revolution, the new vision served to justify the Chinese invasion of Tibet that followed by painting the Tibetan monastic leadership as feudal, oppressive and living on the backs of serfs.
 
Monastic Fiefs
Searching for historical analogies, the revisionists fell back on familiar European themes, said Christopher I. Beckwith of Indiana University, a linguist and historian of Tibet and China. Friends of China could also draw on accounts -- including Rockhill's -- of slavery and bonded labor, of vast, corrupt monastic fiefs and abbots who were likely to steal horses. Tibetan monasteries were usually -- and many still are -- breathtakingly filthy, occasionally ramshackle places where a traveler may find the iconography fascinating but the welcome pretty thin, if not hostile, and the monks less than industrious at any pursuit.
"Sure, Tibet was no paradise, then or now," Professor Beckwith said. "But it certainly wasn't anything like the image, which was directly taken from Western medievalist views of medieval Europe. That's almost a classicist view: When the classical world fell, there was darkness and barbarians crawling around on the ground gnawing bones."
Robert A. F. Thurman of Columbia University, a professor and former Buddhist monk who is considered the leading American expert on Tibetan Buddhism, said the movement to relegate Tibet to the Dark Ages was a byproduct of hearts broken by Stalin.
"When Russian writers began to write about what a monster he was, leftist writers and journalists in the West sat down and conspired, basically," he said. "They said: 'Look, the international movement, the idealistic movement, is going to the dogs and there is no example of any decent thing that's happened because of socialism or communism, and Mao may be the one who is going to do it right.' "
Westerners who glossed over the violence perpetrated on Tibet by the Chinese, Professor Thurman said, also invoked anti-papal sentiments of Northern European Protestants. "They basically presented the Tibetans as kind of Catholics," he said. "They had red robes, they had lush rituals. To the Protestant-minded European population, it was perfect to align them with the corrupt Borgias -- princes of the church in all their horrible debauchery and murder and intrigue."
Scholars of Tibet mostly agree that there has been no systematic serfdom in Tibet in centuries. The label was again a Eurocentric one. In 1879, an Indian scholar who had spent his life in the Himalayan area, Sarat Chandra Das, traveled to Lhasa and studied the social order. He found no trace of bonded servitude. He described a place (unlike caste-ridden India) where "the rich may bestow their daughters on the poor; the daughter of a poor man may become the bride of the proudest noble in the country."
But if Tibet's detractors operate on politically inspired myths, the champions of Tibetan independence also have their fantasies. The country was underdeveloped, its people often rapacious and warlike. Tibetan Buddhism is a robust, earthy religion, far less philosophical and pacifist than many of its Western practitioners would like to believe.
 
The Nonviolence Myth
"There is a Buddhist theory of war, of self-defense, and there is also a kind of theory of surgical violence," Professor Thurman said. "The optimal, ideal thing is nonviolence. But sometimes you have to do a little violence to prevent a larger violence. The Buddhists have thought about this and they are not simplistic."
Moreover, Buddhism has not inevitably made the societies it dominates nonviolent. Monks in Sri Lanka have joined or supported extreme Sinhalese nationalists who murdered thousands of "class enemies" in the 1980's. Cambodia's Buddhist society produced the Khmer Rouge. A nominally Buddhist military junta rules Burma.
Geoff Childs, a Tibetan-speaking anthropologist who recently spent a year living in a Tibetan Buddhist village just over the border in Nepal, said romantics in search of otherworldliness often failed to notice the powerful role of economics in religion among Tibetans, who must survive a harsh environment.
His village, 12,000 feet high on the Tibetan plateau, was dominated by lamas -- married men, not celibate monks -- who believed they had inherited their place in society from the last Tibetan emperors. That gave them spiritual and social influence. But they had turned their high prestige into economic advantage. In return for blessing houses, families and livestock, they were repaid in goods or labor, allowing them to prosper at the expense of their spiritual charges.
Because Tibet has been studied mostly by religious specialists, Mr. Childs said, Westerners have lost the ability to look at it pragmatically.
"It's annoying that people want to make it into one thing or another -- it's a Shangri-la, or it's a depraved place," said Professor Beckwith of Indiana University. "It was a normal country. It was a real culture. It still is, though unfortunately in a sad state now. It had everything from human virtue down to the depths of depravity."
Kesang Tseten, a Tibetan writer living in Katmandu, said some Tibetan exiles have begun to complain that the reality of their life has been overtaken by Hollywood. "It's true Tibet has been imbued by Western imaginations of the subject," he said. "Does this mean we're going to be bound by how others see us?" Not, he said, if Tibetans themselves "get a little real."

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS REPORT;
As Stocks Teeter, a Safe Harbor May Be Found in Corporate Bonds

BYLINE: By SANA SIWOLOP 

 BODY:
LIKE sailors flocking to safe ports, mutual fund investors have long turned to bonds whenever stocks appear dangerously close to imploding.
But what are the nervous to do when the safest bonds around -- benchmark Treasuries -- have soared in price? 
 Concerns about Asia's fractured economic machine have caused investors -- especially those overseas -- to pull money out of certain stock and bond markets and pour it into United States Treasury bonds. So prices have risen and yields -- which move in the opposite direction of prices -- have sunk to 30-year lows. As of June 30, the yield on the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond was just 5.62 percent, compared with 6.78 percent one year ago.
The safety-conscious as well as the yield-hungry investor cannot help but wonder if it's time to forage elsewhere. And if so, where?
Funds that invest in corporate bonds, it turns out, may carry the most value now. These bonds pay a higher yield than Treasury securities because the risk of corporate default, of course, is greater than that of a default by the United States Government. The yield spread between corporate and Treasury bonds is the widest it has been in five years and, given the economy's strength, the risk of default seems limited for investment-grade bonds. With inflation low, the yields look quite nice.
What's more, companies have issued a mountain of new debt, taking advantage of low rates to finance capital improvements and to refinance older debt. That has left the market flooded and helped keep prices down -- a situation that, in correcting itself over time, is likely to benefit bond investors.
The big risk is the economy. Potential buyers have been worried that corporate earnings are on the verge of a long snooze. If earnings decline, the prices of corporate bonds will fall, too, leading to lower total returns, even if dividends stay steady.
Oversupply is also a problem in the municipal bond market, which has been second after Treasuries in investor safety. To be sure, after an uninspiring first four months of the year, munis rallied in May, as stocks stumbled and as investors snapped up the first half of the largest muni bond sale ever -- $7 billion in Long Island Power Authority bonds. Demand for these bonds, and their unusually rich yields, effectively drained money from other munis.
The glut remains a problem, with more issues on the way.
Still, for high-income investors looking for the best returns after taxes, municipal bonds may be the way to go. There has been a solid improvement in credit quality: Half as many issues were downgraded in 1997 as in 1996. The good news can be attributed to the booming economy and a surge in local tax revenues.
Also, in the last year, yields on municipal bonds, relative to taxable bonds, have narrowed significantly. According to Richard J. Moynihan, head of tax-exempt fixed-income investing at the Dreyfus Corporation, the typical insured 20-year muni gives investors 91 percent of the yield of a 30-year Treasury bond, up from about 81 percent a year ago.
For people in a 31 percent income tax bracket, "that's roughly equal to the 7.50 percent yield they might get with a taxable security," he said. "And there aren't too many triple A-rated securities on the taxable side that return 7.50 percent."
The downside, however, is that munis are less likely to appreciate, so their total return may be weak.
FOR investors in munis, he recommends longer-term issues. "When it comes to short-term munis -- say five-year issues -- the market is fully priced relative to Treasuries," he said. "Beyond that -- going out 10 years or more -- then these bonds continue to be very cheap relative to Treasuries."
Investors who bought the longest-term issues were rewarded last quarter. The best-performing bond funds had long maturities, including the American Century-Benham Target Maturity funds, several Vanguard long-term funds and T. Rowe Price U.S. Treasury Long-Term.
What about investors who are looking for even better values than corporate and muni issues, as well as potentially higher yields? Les Nanberg, the chief fixed-income officer at Massachusetts Financial Services, says the best opportunities are in high-yield junk bonds and emerging-market bonds, not surprisingly the riskiest areas of the bond world.
He says yields on junk bonds are now 3.5 percentage points more than Treasuries, on average, while emerging-market bonds average about 6.5 percentage points more.
After registering nifty price gains for months, junk bonds are now trading at two-year lows. Funds that invest in junk bonds posted a slight loss on average in the last quarter.
But the news was worse for most emerging-market bond funds. On average, they lost more than 8 percent in the latest quarter, according to Morningstar. Among the bottom performers were Phoenix B Emerging Markets Bond and Merrill Lynch American Income. "If investors can live with the volatility of these bonds, they'll be rewarded," Mr. Nanberg said, "although they're clearly not for everyone." Anticipating more volatility, he is shying away from most of Asia but spots value in Poland, Bulgaria, and other Eastern European countries, as well as Mexico.
What about junk bonds? Again, Mr. Nanberg is treading carefully, focusing on companies that meet at least one of three criteria: they are leaders in their industries, are benefiting from a strong economy or are benefiting from recent acquisitions. One company that he expects to benefit from the strong economy is BE Aerospace, which makes replacement parts for aircraft.
Roger E. King, a senior portfolio manager for high-yield securities at Dreyfus, says the news on the high-yield front isn't all bad.
"Right now, there are no panic sellers," Mr. King said, "so we're in a kind of controlled downturn."
That said, Mr. King advises investors to choose issues with very short maturities, to guard against changes in interest rates and the junk market's current volatility.
Indeed, the greatest risk in bonds today may be credit risk, said John F. Poole, the head of fixed-income group at Mellon Private Asset Management. "We don't think the economy is about to collapse," he added, "but we think that individual companies may be at risk."

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS REPORT;
Three Strategies, One Outcome: A Spring That Came Up Roses

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
IT was a bitter spring quarter for many a mutual fund manager, but it was a very sweet season for others. How did some managers land at the top of the fund performance lists? Different tacks worked well for different managers. 
 Here, some of the winners talk about their strategies -- from short-selling to big bets on technology and European stocks -- as well as their outlooks for the rest of the year.
 
Short-Selling Panache
Michael B. Orkin, manager of Caldwell & Orkin Market Opportunity, might be called Mr. Doom-and-Gloom. His fund, based in Atlanta, landed the No. 12 position on the list of best-performing United States diversified funds in the second quarter, with a 10.1 percent return. Much of that is attributable to Mr. Orkin's short-selling, which involves betting on a decline, rather than an increase, in the price of a stock.
In a short sale, investors sell shares that they have borrowed from a broker, betting that they can replace the stock at a lower price. Mr. Orkin has benefited so much from the practice that he plans to raise the 40 percent cap on short positions in his fund to 50 or 55 percent.
"I believe eventually the stock market will have a significant and long-lasting setback," Mr. Orkin said. "I'm talking about bear markets that happen once in a generation."
Why so downbeat? Mr. Orkin faxed a reporter a 10-page missive to explain his reasoning. The gist of it? "People don't believe the markets can drop," he said. "Massive complacency is becoming firmly established."
Mr. Orkin's solution is to mix stock purchases with short sales. "The criteria for both is we look for change; an acceleration in earnings growth; management change, usually correlated with restructuring, or industry changes like supply or demand for semiconductor chips or oil exploration and development," he said.
A long position, Ames Department Stores, which rose 24.6 percent, helped his second-quarter return. Mr. Orkin calls Ames, which accounts for 1.9 percent of the $247.1 million fund, "a discount retailer that's executing its strategy well."
Ames emerged from bankruptcy, reorganized under new management and is faring well because economic growth has left consumers with money to spend, he said. Ames sells for 16 times 1998 earnings, which analysts expect to grow 15 to 20 percent a year.
Mr. Orkin declined to name companies that the fund is shorting but said he was playing two themes: companies with exposure to Asia and companies that offer subprime loans.
The minimum investment for the fund was just raised to $100,000, from $10,000.
 
Technology Mainstays
Big technology bets did the trick for the Janus 20 portfolio, which, as its name implies, holds just 20 stocks. The fund is managed by Scott W. Schoelzel, who took over when Thomas F. Marsico left Janus Capital to open his own shop in January.
Dell Computer, which surged 37 percent in the second quarter, helped push Janus 20 up to first place for the quarter among diversified funds, and Mr. Schoelzel remains bullish on the company: It now accounts for 8 percent of the fund.
"I like the systemic advantage that they enjoy from their direct-sales model," Mr. Schoelzel said. "The company also has negative working capital, because they get their customers' money immediately but they don't have to pay their suppliers for 60 to 90 days."
And Mr. Schoelzel is also excited about the fact that Dell is moving into selling higher-margin servers and notebook computers.
America Online, which ran up 53.9 percent, also played a big part in the outperformance of Janus 20. It accounts for 6 percent of the fund.
"I like America Online because of the rate at which it's signing up subscribers, advertisers and E-commerce partners," Mr. Schoelzel said.
The company has also been able to increase some of its advertising rates, which Mr. Schoelzel said would help drive up America Online earnings more than expected.
Mr. Schoelzel's winners weren't all of the wired variety. Home Depot, at 3 percent of the fund, rose 22.8 percent in the second quarter.
"Besides the large stores, Home Depot is on the verge of rolling out Expo stores, a high-end format for clients of designers and architects," he said.
Mr. Schoelzel remains bullish on the stock market.
"I believe we're in a secularly declining inflation environment and, as a result, a fairly benign interest rate environment," he said. "The move in financial assets has many years to run."
 
Loyal to Europe
A love affair with Europe landed the $420.8 million Federated International Small Company fund, managed by Tracy P. Stouffer, in third place on the list of diversified international stock funds for the second quarter. The fund returned 10.5 percent.
Ms. Stouffer's charter is flexible. She must only stick with companies with capitalizations of $1 billion or less and stay outside the United States.
Last year, 35 percent of the fund was invested in emerging markets. This year, the total is zero, which, of course, served her well as those markets swooned. The fund's holdings in Europe teeter at 96 percent.
Much of this mix, or lack thereof, has to do with Ms. Stouffer's mandate to hold small-capitalization stocks, which are suffering mightily outside of developed nations. "We're not getting any small-cap effect in emerging markets because all the companies are becoming smaller and smaller, the result of shrinking prices and currency erosion," she said.
European small-cap stocks have thrived, Ms. Stouffer said, because of a general flight to smaller-sized companies in reaction to the Asian problems. "Small companies tend to do business locally, so they're somewhat of a safe haven," she said.
They also tend to have low levels of debt, if for no other reason than that few lenders will give them loans. Moreover, they are benefiting from a trend toward outsourcing among big companies of their noncore businesses, she said.
Ms. Stouffer plans to stay invested in Europe for now. "I don't think it's time to move into the emerging markets," she said. "I don't think the Asia problems will be resolved quickly, and small companies are beneficiaries of European growth and the E.M.U.," she added, referring to European Monetary Union.
The fund holds 185 companies. Among the largest, all well under 2 percent of the fund's assets, are Cofir, a Spanish holding company with hotel and wine businesses; Creyf's, a temporary employment company in Belgium, and Telepizza, a Spanish pizza delivery chain.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: VILLAGES EAST AND WEST;
The Cafe Police Pop In for a Raid

BYLINE: By JESSE McKINLEY 

 BODY:
Surprise inspections at four popular East Village nightclubs last weekend have upset several club owners, who accuse officials of unfairly targeting them and driving away customers.
The inspections, around midnight last Saturday, were carried out by the Social Club Task Force, which includes representatives from the Police and Fire Departments, the State Liquor Authority and other state and city agencies. 
 About 30 officials entered the Continental, on Third Avenue; CBGB's, on the Bowery; the Bowery Bar, and Coney Island High, on St. Marks Place. A co-owner of Coney Island High, Jesse Malin, said the official carried flashlights, asked for music to be turned off and would not allow anyone to enter the club. "The whole thing was very Gestapo-like," he said. "They were looking for drugs, fire violations, fruit flies in the liquor, everything, but they found nothing."
After a 45-minute inspection, no violations were issued at his club, Mr. Malin said. At Continental, task force members issued one violation, for garbage in a sink, said the owner, who called himself Trigger. Bowery Bar received three citations, for an unlicensed bar, overcrowding and an exit blocked by a table, said the bar's general manager, Howard Schaffer. And at CBGB's, where a drag queen rock band was playing, several notices were issued, including one for having a bartender handle ice without a "food protection certificate" issued by the Health Department.
"I guess ice is now food," said a manager at CBGB's, Louise Parnassa.
None of the bars were closed down. The inspections were the second round in the neighborhood in recent weeks. On June 18, three bars and restaurants on Ludlow and Orchard Streets were visited by inspectors. One, Baby Jupiter's, on Orchard Street, was cited for serving alcohol to a minor but was allowed to stay open, said the owner, Gary Auslander.
In April, task force officials temporarily closed four bars on the Upper East Side after complaints about noise prompted inspections that uncovered health and fire code violations. At the time, Deputy Mayor Rudy Washington, the task force chairman, said bars in Manhattan would be the major focus of this summer's inspections.
Mr. Washington was not available for comment last week, but the Mayor's office defended the task force. In a prepared statement, it said: "The task force targets social clubs in response to complaints from club customers and neighborhood residents as well as from intelligence developed from the New York City Police Department. Public safety is the paramount concern in these enforcement efforts."
Club officials said they understood the need for periodic inspections, but some were angered by their timing and manner. "I think they feel they have to give a violation, and if you're borderline you're getting it," said Mr. Schaffer of the Bowery Bar.
Mr. Malin estimated that the presence of the police officers drove away about 70 percent of his customers. "It was prime time for us to make our bread and butter," he said. "It cost me about $4,000."
The president of the New York Nightlife Association, Andrew Rasiej, said that he did not think that the task force had timed the inspections to disrupt business but that while "the nightlife industry is a $3 billion industry, it is unfortunately not seen as a component of the social and economic fabric of New York." JESSE McKINLEY

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: THEATER DISTRICT -- RELATIONS;
At Lamb's Club, a Long-Running, Real-Life Drama

BYLINE: By JESSE McKINLEY 

 BODY:
As many good dramas do, this tale blends love, loss and art, and involves a man and a woman. And, oh yes, one gloriously assembled pile of bricks.
The man in question is James M. Copeland, a soft-spoken Southern architect whose life was empty, he said, until he met the woman in question, Carolyn Rossi, a member of that brashest of New York professional castes, the theatrical producer. 
 The third player is the Lamb's Club, at 130 West 44th Street, the former actors' clubhouse designed by Stanford White and once frequented by the likes of John Barrymore, Fred Astaire and John Wayne.
As formidable as those legends are, few can claim a more personal connection with the building than Ms. Rossi and Mr. Copeland, who over the last 20 years have used No. 130 as a home, a wooing locale, a wedding hall and a place of grieving. And, of course, as a theater.
Our story begins in 1979, shortly after the club sold its building to the Church of the Nazarene. Ms. Rossi was just beginning to direct shows at the church, and soon began living in a tiny room on the sixth floor of the building with a collection of young actors, writers and other unemployed persons.
"My father thought I'd joined a cult," Ms. Rossi said. "He was horrified."
Enter Mr. Copeland, who had come to the big city from North Carolina to apprentice at an architectural firm. His employer was eyeing a renovation of the building, but Mr. Copeland's gaze had fallen on the quirky girl staying in the building's rafters.
"Where I come from, women are not aggressive," he said. "She was, and I kind of liked that."
Mr. Copeland began to visit Ms. Rossi at her office, situated on the third floor. Ms. Rossi was busy establishing the Lamb's Theater Company, which would reside in the club's third-floor theater until 1996. She enlisted him to sew curtains and cushions for the seats. Soon, he asked for her hand.
Their wedding, on April 24, 1982, was held in the theater between the matinee and evening performances of "Cottonpatch Gospel," the Lamb's Theater Company's first production. Ms. Rossi had dogwoods flown in from North Carolina, and dropped an especially frilly curtain in front of the set.
"Producing a wedding is just like producing a show," she said. "Only hopefully it lasts longer."
The marriage did last, and the shows continued, with some hits, some duds. And a newcomer took up residence on the building's sixth floor: Ms. Rossi's mother, who was suffering from Alzheimer's disease. Over the next two years, the couple and the company's actors tended to Ms. Rossi Copeland's mother, visiting her and entertaining her with songs from their shows. In 1984, the mother died in her room, surrounded by family members, during the final chords of a performance in the theater below.
Over the next decade, Ms. Rossi Copeland continued to produce a steady stream of musicals and original plays at the space, giving the first performances of works by Horton Foote, Mark St. Germain and Randy Courts. Mr. Copeland, meanwhile, began to renovate the building, slowly restoring its fine wood panels and facade.
In 1996, Ms. Rossi Copeland decided to fold her company, choosing to spend more time with her own family in Garrison, N.Y., where she had been elected to the school board. It didn't take.
"You ever been to a school board meeting?" she said. "Being a producer is nothing compared to dealing with parents."
So this year, she has returned to the Lamb's Club, as the producer of "Smoke on the Mountain." And Mr. Copeland is considering another overhaul, this time to unearth the marble floors under the lobby's tile.
"I was married here, had my theater here, watched my mother die here," Ms. Rossi Copeland said. "I had so much life invested here. I couldn't really stay away." JESSE McKINLEY

HEADLINE: In America;
Ending A Retail Drought

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT

 BODY:
Big news: Last Tuesday a supermarket opened at the corner of Whalley Avenue and Orchard Street in New Haven.
Most Americans take supermarkets for granted. But they are rare phenomena in the chronically depressed neighborhoods of the inner cities. If you live in the ghetto and you want to shop for groceries, you will most likely pay extortionate prices for super-low quality and hardly any variety at small local stores. Or you will make your way somehow to the suburbs. 
 Imagine a large family with a small income, no car and little access to public transportation. I remember watching a woman in a bodega in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn ask the store owner if he had any peaches. He was reading a newspaper and never looked up. "No peach," he said.
So the 56,000-square-foot Shaw's supermarket that opened in New Haven was a huge deal. It anchors a shopping center that includes a bank branch and a video store. And it is the latest step in what appears to be a halting, tentative, wary but nevertheless very promising return of serious retail activity to such neighborhoods.
It is not happening in a vacuum. For years small neighborhood organizations, known as community development corporations, or C.D.C.'s, have been building or renovating housing that can be afforded by families of very modest means. This new housing has been a stabilizing influence in inner-city neighborhoods across the country, a defense against onrushing blight.
As the neighborhoods stabilize, new families are drawn to them, creating a viable potential market in areas that previously were economically moribund.
"The obvious next step is to take a look at where the families are going to shop," said P. Jefferson Armistead, a vice president with the Local Initiatives Support Corporation (L.I.S.C.), a national organization that helps arrange funding and provides expert assistance to C.D.C.'s.
"The C.D.C.'s," said Mr. Armistead, "have set the stage for this additional phase of retail development."
This entire scenario is being played out with excruciating slowness. But there is reason to believe not only that it is working, but that in the current economic atmosphere, it will accelerate. There is serious money to be made in neighborhoods that once were viewed only as economic wastelands. As Mr. Armistead noted, the per capita income in such neighborhoods is low, but because of the population densities the income "per acre" can be very high.
"We are seeing some recognition on the part of big retail stores that there are substantial opportunities here," he said.
A Pathmark supermarket that opened in Newark's Central Ward in 1990 is one of the most successful in the entire Pathmark chain. It was the first supermarket built in the Central Ward since it was devastated by rioting in 1967.
Large-scale retail projects further stabilize a neighborhood, and they provide substantial employment opportunities. Each new supermarket represents 250 to 300 new jobs.
In the past few years shopping centers anchored by supermarkets have been built or are being built in South Central Los Angeles, on the South Side of Chicago, in Philadelphia and in Harlem. Several others are planned. In each case the projects have been developed in partnerships with C.D.C.'s.
The New Haven project was a $15 million venture sponsored by the Greater Dwight Development Corporation, which operates in the neighborhoods of Dwight, Edgewood and West River. An L.I.S.C. subsidiary is a supporter of the project, and the GE Capital Corporation is an investor.
Each attempt to build large-scale retail outlets in inner-city neighborhoods is a struggle. Private companies are still reluctant to make the initial investment and security continues to be a problem.
But the C.D.C.'s and intermediary organizations like L.I.S.C. have completed several successful projects and many more are planned. Each successful project is a magnet for others.
"This is not the whole economic answer," said Paul Grogan, the president of L.I.S.C. "But this return of the retail market represents a reconnection of these communities with the mainstream economy, and that hasn't been there for a long time. It's a very hopeful sign. It's something to build on."

HEADLINE: DIARY

BYLINE: By BILL WELLMAN

 BODY:

ECONOMY
 
Confidence Is Not High . . .
The nation's manufacturers have slowed production to the lowest rate of growth since 1995, the clearest impact so far of the Asian crisis on the American economy. The National Association of Purchasing Management reported that manufacturing activity weakened in June for a majority of the companies that it surveys each month. It was the first time in 22 months that a majority had reported weakening instead of strengthening in their businesses. Manufacturing employment has fallen in recent months, and industrial production has slowed to an annual growth rate of less than 2 percent, down from 6 percent last year. Production is slowing in large part because stockpiles of unsold goods have surged, but also because companies are becoming worried that the economic boom cannot continue at the fervent pace of the last two years. Separately, the index of leading economic indicators was flat in May, a sign that growth will moderate in the coming months. 

. . . Except Among Consumers
Consumer confidence in the economy rose in June to a 29-year high, as Americans remained optimistic that the strong labor market and healthy economic growth would continue in coming months. The Conference Board, a private research group, reported that its index of consumer confidence rose to 137.6 in June from a revised 136.3 in May, a larger rise than Wall Street analysts had expected. That confidence was also reflected in sales of new homes, which rose in May to a record level. And the Fed helped matters down the road by leaving interest rates unchanged. New single-family home sales rose three-tenths of a percent in May to an annual rate of 890,000 units, the Commerce Department said, breaking the previous record set in April. Unfortunately, the percentage of homeowners who were late on their mortgage payments also rose in the first quarter, according to the Mortgage Bankers Association of America.
 
GENERAL MOTORS
 
Stop-and-Go Manufacturing
The General Motors Corporation said June car and truck sales were the highest for any month in nine years but that July sales would plummet because of two strikes that have shut down most of the auto maker's North American assembly plants and idled almost 172,000 workers. Most other car makers also reported higher sales. A G.M. official said sales would drop 30 percent to 40 percent this month compared with sales from the month a year earlier because of the strikes. That would push G.M.'s market share to a record low of 25 percent and put G.M. behind the Ford Motor Company as the largest volume vehicle manufacturer in the United States. Already, analysts say the strikes at two plants in Flint, Mich., have cost G.M. $1.18 billion.
 
EUROPE
 
Cleaner Air, Costlier Cars
People in Europe's car-filled cities are likely to start breathing a little easier in the next few years because of tough new anti-pollution rules announced in Brussels by the 15-member European Union. The rules, which ban the use of leaded gasoline, require many car engines and all fuels to become cleaner by 2000. Even tougher standards will go into effect in 2005. With the changes, governments hope to cut as much as 70 percent of the pollutants in emissions from cars, which regularly foul the air in some of Europe's most beautiful city centers. The changes are expected to raise the prices of cars between $300 and $600 in the next two years. Car makers will need to invest some $65 billion to meet the new standards, according to European Union officials. The oil industry estimates it will cost $35 billion to put the program into effect. And surprise, surprise, most of the higher costs are expected to be passed on to consumers.
 
JAPAN
 
Bailing Out the Banks
The Government outlined a long-awaited "Total Plan" to clear away bad debts, estimated around $600 billion. The plan seems to be modeled on the United States' bailout of savings and loans in the 1980's and is intended to gradually shut down banks weakened by bad loans while keeping credit flowing to healthy corporate borrowers. Under the plan, insolvent banks will be managed by a new watchdog agency while a merger partner is sought. Bridge loans will be provided to corporate customers dependent on financing from the troubled banks. When no suitor can be found, the banks will be taken over by a state-funded holding company and then sold off or liquidated. Bad loans will be handed over to special institutions and good loans are to be transferred to healthy private banks. The process is to be completed within a maximum of five years and funded by taxpayer money.
 
RUSSIA
 
Balance of Payments, Indeed
Russia's legendarily ineffectual tax men stared down the nation's biggest and most powerful corporation last week, threatening to seize control of the company -- and its executives' dachas, yachts and other perks -- unless it paid billions of dollars in back taxes. To most everyone's amazement, the company, Gazprom, gave in and agreed to turn over 4.2 billion rubles ($675 million) in unpaid taxes by Monday and to start paying the Government about 4 billion rubles a month. Had President Boris N. Yeltsin grown a backbone in dealing with the oligarchs who control the economy here -- or had he staged a deft act of political theater? For the agreement does not merely force Gazprom, the world's largest petroleum company and Russia's biggest tax delinquent, to make good on its back taxes; it also requires the Government to pay Gazprom billions of rubles for oil and gas that Government agencies and state companies purchased but never paid for. By many estimates, the two sums amount to a wash.
 
GOLF
 
Mean and Green
Fore! New golf courses are opening in the United States at the rate of more than one a day, according to the current issue of Audubon magazine, and the more than 16,000 of them take up an area three times the size of Rhode Island. A major cost of golf courses -- both environmentally and bottom line -- involves the heavy use of pesticides and herbicides to keep those greens green. But some courses have found that sound ecology pays twice: The Old Westbury Golf and Country Club on Long Island, for example, spent $150,000 on chemicals in 1990. Today, largely thanks to organic fertilizers, it has cut that budget item to $8,000 a year and is much more user-friendly for both the birdies and those who covet them.
 
BUSINESS TRAVEL
 
Big Pricey Cities
Business executives living abroad may have become used to the astronomical prices they pay in Tokyo and Hong Kong, and maybe even in Beijing and Shanghai. But companies doing business in China for the first time might do a double take when their employees file their first expense statements from Dalian, the globe's ninth-most-expensive city for overseas workers -- and notably more costly than New York, ranked No. 21. According to Corporate Resources Group, a consulting firm based in Geneva, Asia still has seven of the world's 10 most expensive cities for foreign workers. For big savings on expenses, try Harare, Zimbabwe, which ranked at the bottom of the list.
 
JOBS
 
Burger Flippers, Take Note
The United States economy is showing signs of cooling. In June, unemployment edged up to 4.5 percent and job growth slowed. There were other signs of moderation, too. Total hours worked were virtually flat in June, a clear indication that the nation's output of goods and services is growing much more slowly than in recent quarters. And hourly pay rose by a mere penny, suggesting that wage inflation, while higher than a year ago, was not accelerating. The slowdown, however, is from an exceptionally torrid pace. As recently as a year ago, joblessness stood at 5 percent.

HEADLINE: THE NATION: A New Broom Needs a New Handle;
Welfare as We Know It Goes Incognito

BYLINE: By RACHEL L. SWARNS 

 BODY:
WITH a wave of a wand and a mayoral proclamation, New York City's welfare system is vanishing. Job centers are replacing welfare offices. Financial planners are replacing caseworkers. And the entire bureaucracy is morphing into the Family Independence Administration.
In truth, the same workers still do business in the same buildings, but the city has been infected by a name-changing frenzy that has been sweeping the country. Massachusetts' Department of Public Welfare is now the Department of Transitional Assistance. Florida's welfare program is now the Work and Gain Economic Self-Sufficiency Program. And in two weeks, the American Public Welfare Association, a trade group that represents social service agencies, will officially shed the word welfare from its letterhead for the first time in 66 years. 
 In an era when work is prized and welfare disparaged, many state and local officials are scrubbing their programs and groups clean of words tainted, rightly or wrongly, by the sour smell of failure. As Liz Krueger, an advocate for the poor, said somewhat sadly: "We have made welfare a four-letter word in this country. Everyone is running as fast as they can away from it."
 
A Powerful Message
And as the new language of welfare seeps into public consciousness, it has caused some people to wonder what is behind the new names. Are they merely euphemisms for business as usual? Or do they illuminate a whole new world? In one sense, the names reflect a nation transformed by time limits for public charity and work requirements for those who receive it. They send a powerful message to the poor about the change in government expectations.
But these names are also meant to carry a politically potent message to voters who will never step into a welfare office but whose discontent with the status quo helped propel an overhaul in welfare policy. In this sense, the words underscore the desires of politicians and officialdom to project a perception of change -- even if little actually changes -- as they try to curry favor with the electorate.
"Is this a message to people on welfare? Yes," said Robert C. Lieberman, assistant professor of politics and public policy at Columbia University. "But my suspicion is that the naming of programs is directed more at voters, certainly on the part of the elected, who are choosing the way they want their policies to be read."
Mr. Lieberman recalled a similar name change in the 1960's when the Federal welfare program was called Aid to Dependent Children. Criticized for discouraging marriage by supporting only single mothers, Federal officials began providing help to couples. While the vast majority of checks continued to flow to single women, the name became Aid to Families with Dependent Children.
Thirty years later, public disapproval of the welfare mother whose children and grandchildren rely on public assistance helped persuade Congress to change the rules and the name again. Temporary Assistance for Needy Families was born. At the state level, Texas created the Workforce Commission to oversee its welfare programs. Michigan dubbed its welfare agency the Family Independence Agency. And Utah started calling its offices "employment centers" and its welfare recipients "job seekers."
"It's a shrewd kind of move," Mr. Lieberman said of the linguistic shift. "Who can be against personal responsibility or family independence or temporary assistance or any of these things?"
 
Change and Posturing
In New York City, where two more welfare offices were converted into job centers last week, the names encompass both radical change and political posturing. At the centers, poor people are told to look for jobs, not welfare, and to lean on relatives, not charity. The shift has resulted in a staggering change: While 60 percent of the people who walked in the door once ended up on welfare, now only about 10 percent land on the dole, the rest deciding to get by on their own.
"The new names send positive messages to clients and caseworkers that the world of welfare is changing in profound ways," said Elaine Ryan, a director of the American Public Welfare Association, which will soon be called the American Public Human Services Association to reflect a wider membership and revamped thinking.
 
How to Fish
Or as Adrianne Flemming, who runs the new job center in Brooklyn with her team of financial planners, likes to say: "In the welfare offices, we were handing out fish. In the job centers, we're teaching people how to fish."
But while Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani proudly touts the conversion of welfare offices into job centers, he declines to say how many people actually leave those with jobs.
In fact, a draft memo included in a training manual for workers describes employment as a "secondary goal" at the job centers. The "primary goal," the memo says, is discouraging the poor from applying for public assistance.
Advocates for the poor say the whole naming process sounds suspiciously like sloganeering that will appeal to voters but help few welfare recipients find work.
"I can change my name to the division of workforce development, but if there are not enough jobs out there for the people who walk in my door, none of that matters," Ms. Krueger said. "Does it mean more poor people are getting jobs in New York City? I don't think so. It's a lot easier to change a name than to create jobs for people."
City officials insist, however, that finding jobs for the poor is still the program's primary goal. They vow it will be emphasized as New York transforms all 31 of its welfare offices into job centers over the next year. The new signs and letterhead are already on order.
But as the painters paint and the printers print, will no one mourn the passing of a familiar word? Gary Weeks, who headed the name change committee for the American Public Welfare Association, thinks not. He found little nostalgia among members who wanted a new look to reflect the growing importance of health services along with the shift in welfare thinking.
"I don't think we lost anything," said Mr. Weeks, who runs Oregon's welfare program.. "No one was on a soapbox for keeping the terminology."

LENGTH: 602 words

HEADLINE: Albright Hugs Wary Tokyo Smarting From Beijing Trip

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF 

DATELINE: TOKYO, July 4

 BODY:
Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright dropped by today on her way back from China to give Japan a reassuring hug and emphasize that the United States values its ties with Tokyo as much as ever.
But Ms. Albright, in addition to comments about the "unshakable friendship" between Japan and the United States, also prodded Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto to take further steps to bolster the Japanese economy. 
 The mood in Japan is so doleful and insecure these days that many Japanese were hurt by President Clinton's decision to spend nine days in China without even a brief visit to Japan.
So Mr. Clinton sent Ms. Albright to Tokyo to brief Japanese officials on the China summit meeting, to reassure Japan of America's continuing affections and to poke Mr. Hashimoto to insure that he fulfills his promise to tackle Japan's economic mess.
"The alliance between our two nations is the embodiment of an unshakable friendship," Mrs. Albright said at a news conference this afternoon. "It is the foundation for stability in the Asia-Pacific. It is the cornerstone of our strategic policy in Asia."
Foreign Minister Keizo Obuchi, standing beside Ms. Albright, looked slightly mollified at those words, even if Ms. Albright did omit the other cliche that used to be commonplace: that the United States-Japan relationship "is the most important bilateral relationship in the world, bar none."
Japanese scholars have often noted that historically the United States has tilted either toward Japan or toward China but has had difficulty being friendly simultaneously with both. Thus some have speculated that Washington's efforts to build ties with Beijing will now come at the expense of relations with Tokyo.
In addition, Japanese officials who used to complain about "Japan bashing" now fret about "Japan passing" -- a phrase referring to the lack of attention paid to Japan at all. The one thing worse than being insulted, it seems to people in Tokyo, is being ignored.
The Yomiuri Shimbun, Japan's most widely read newspaper, noted in a recent editorial the concerns that the summit meeting "may lead to a weakening of U.S. relations with Japan because Clinton will not be coming here." But it added archly that Washington-Beijing ties and Washington-Tokyo relations "can hardly be considered on the same level."
Ms. Albright went out of her way to make a point that some Japanese officials also make, at least in their more self-confident moments: that "the improvement in U.S.-Chinese relations is very much in Japan's interest as well."
"It is a 'win-win-win' outcome for the people of the United States, Japan and China," she said.
The United States had earlier invited Prime Minister Hashimoto to Washington for a state visit this month, as another consolation prize for not getting a Presidential visit. One purpose of the state visit will be to badger Mr. Hashimoto into taking bolder steps to boost Japan's economy, but Ms. Albright took advantage of her Tokyo stop to offer a nudge of her own.
She said that the United States was encouraged by Mr. Hashimoto's latest plans to deal with bad loans. There has been doubt in the financial markets about how thoroughly Japan will carry out the new policy, and so she added, "We now look forward to Japan's taking swift, concerted action to implement these measures."
Mr. Obuchi, asked about similar remarks by President Clinton urging Japan to take firm action, chose to interpret them as a vote of confidence rather than a kick in the seat.
"We appreciate that President Clinton evinced those invaluable remarks," Mr. Obuchi said.
