HEADLINE: Japan Voters Send Message: No Change

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF 

DATELINE: KOCHI, Japan, July 2

 BODY:
All the world seems to be thumping on Japanese politicians these days, trying to get them to restructure the economy and reduce the risk of a global downturn. But here on the campaign trail, the message to the politicians is different.
When candidates for the July 12 parliamentary elections stump in towns like Kochi, a pretty coastal hub of 320,000 surrounded by coves of weathered fishing boats, the message that politicians get -- and the one they echo -- is Japan's need for more of the same. 
The issues here have less to do with economic policy than with pork: the ability of an official to pick the pocket of the central Government and build roads, bridges and dams. When the topic of economic liberalization comes up, it is often as an evil force to be constrained.
"We Japanese can't eat meat three times a day," Hiroyuki Morishita, the candidate for the ruling Liberal Democratic Party in the Kochi area, told an audience in the Fishermen's Center in the little town of Nakatosa, in a swipe at the Government's willingness to liberalize meat imports. "I would like to respect the culture of fish! I want to protect fishermen!"
Another local politician already serving in Parliament, Yuji Yamamoto, drew vigorous applause when he denounced the deregulation of retailing and finance. Most of the world has regarded Japan's financial liberalization this year as long overdue, but Mr. Yamamoto said that a result has been capital flight from Japan to the United States.
"Stock prices have fallen, the yen has fallen, and the dollar has risen!" Mr. Yamamoto bellowed as the crowd nodded. "We are not living to serve the Americans."
So while Japan is suffering its worst recession in the postwar era, unemployment is at a record and foreign analysts are warning that Japan could set off a world-wide depression, the issue in the electoral districts is which candidate can best divert national funds to build more local dams.
"These dams, these little roads and bridges are very important for the rural areas," said Mr. Morishita, 56, as he loosened his tie and sat on the floor of the auditorium for a chat after the audience had drifted out. "They help everybody in rural areas make a living. It's the only way for these areas to get a cash income."
A genial man with a radiant smile, Mr. Morishita said that in half of the 53 towns in Kochi prefecture, the biggest industry is construction.
"People criticize pork barreling, but Kochi is remote and doesn't have much industry," Mr. Morishita noted. "So for voters in these areas, this is better than nothing."
American officials often complain that Japan's political system is dysfunctional, unable to cope with the economic crisis. But the paralysis in Tokyo may have less to do with the system than with the public mood it reflects, for the excellent prospects of the governing Liberal Democrats in the current campaign suggest that many Japanese do not want the fundamental restructuring favored by the United States.
"Japanese voters basically don't want drastic change," said Hitoshi Toyama, a political columnist for Kochi Shimbun, a local daily. That comment is echoed by almost every politician and voter one speaks to, particularly outside the biggest cities.
Yoshihiko Miyauchi, president of the Orix Corporation in Tokyoand a prominent executive in Japan, says the essential reason for the country's crisis is this deep-seated reluctance in the provinces to embrace a global market economy. Mr. Miyauchi refers to the Liberal Democratic Party, or L.D.P., as the "Japan country party" because of its deep roots in the countryside.
"If you look at most of the L.D.P. representatives, they are elected from the countryside and they are not connected to the global economy," Mr. Miyauchi said. "The majority of people here are not willing to be led by economic forces. And so we have very deep problems."
As in many countries, the electoral system in Japan greatly amplifies the voices of people in rural areas. This election is for the upper house of Parliament, and a member can represent as few as 241,000 voters in rural Tottori Prefecture or as many as 1.2 million in Tokyo.
The upper house is less important than the lower house, but the election could still have important consequences. If the Liberal Democratic Party ends up with fewer seats than before -- it now holds 61 of the 126 seats in contention -- then that could force the resignation of Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto.
Most polls show the Liberal Democrats likely to gain seats, however. Indeed, some experts suggest that the Liberal Democrats could win 69 or more seats, enough to give them a majority of the upper house to go along with their existing majority in the lower house.
One of the gains for the Liberal Democrats is likely to be this district in Kochi, on the southern island of Shikoku. The seat is now held by an opposition figure who is not running this time, and Mr. Morishita is in the lead among the five candidates.
The opposition candidates together will almost certainly garner more votes than Mr. Morishita will, and in a two-party system the Liberal Democrats might well be evicted from power. But Japan is an oddity, something of a one-party state. The opposition is severely fragmented with little chance of taking power, at least in the next couple of years, and a result is a political machine like that of the American South in the decades when Democrats ran the game.
The lack of a credible opposition means that disaffected Japanese stay away from the polls altogether. Because elections are not perceived as a viable choice or a mechanism for change, the voting rates keep dropping -- to 51 percent in the 1992 upper house election, 44 percent in 1995, and an anticipated record low of less than 40 percent this time.
Fewer votes benefit the Liberal Democrats, because they are well-organized and can mobilize supporters more than the opposition parties.
It might seem remarkable that a ruling party could gain seats as it presides over the worst economic slump in half a century, as it is roundly condemned for corruption and cronyism. But the Liberal Democrats are campaigning on the basis that although they may have made the economic mess, they are also the best ones to clean it up.
"The critical thing is to come up with measures to revive the economy, and only the Liberal Democratic Party can do that," said Hiromitsu Ikeda, a town councilman in Nakatosa. "That's why it's very important for the Liberal Democrats to gain a majority in both houses of Parliament."
While there is widespread public annoyance at politicians, there is little of the "throw the bums out" sentiment that periodically sweeps the United States. Indeed, Mr. Morishita is campaigning in part on the basis of his long involvement in politics, including 10 years in Tokyo, as evidence that he can turn on the financing spigots and help his district.
"Mr. Morishita will be more efficient at getting subsidies," said Takao Yorimitsu, a prefectural assemblyman and Mr. Morishita's campaign manager.

HEADLINE: Clinton's Sojourn in China, Viewed From the Cookout

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON 

DATELINE: SPRINGFIELD, Ill., July 4

 BODY:
Sitting on a bench under a maple tree near Abraham Lincoln's old law office in this cornfield-hemmed Illinois capital, Janice Reese, who works on the cleaning staff at a hospital, confessed that she knew little about American diplomacy in China.
But as Ms. Reese watched some of the televised images from that faraway Communist-ruled land, whose leaders and people were greeting President Clinton, she said she saw something more profound than policy. 
 "You saw the smiles of the Chinese people," said Ms. Reese, 33. "They were cheering our President, mothers holding up babies. They don't hate us. It really gives you hope."
At the start of a scorching Independence Day weekend, Midwesterners were mostly thinking about parades and cookouts and fireworks. But the President's foray into China does appear to have made the radar screen, judging from more than two dozen interviews in this city of 105,000, with most people giving the trip favorable reviews.
"Clinton's smart enough to know you can't just ignore a place as big as China," said Ron Sherer, 49, a fire department dispatcher, as he sat in a booth in the Sunrise Cafe and ate a breakfast he called the "cholesterol special" -- two eggs, a slab of ham, fried potatoes, biscuits and gravy. "It's important to open new markets for American companies." He added that he was impressed with the President for "talking candidly" about the crackdown at Tiananmen Square in 1989.
To be sure, some people here denounced the President's decision to travel to China, criticizing him for a weak defense of the rights of political dissidents, or scoffing that Mr. Clinton was simply eager to shift the focus from the embarrassing reports spilling out of investigations in Washington.
"I think it stinks," said Clarence Gatton, a 60-year-old retired bus driver, who was trimming his backyard hedge for a family picnic. "Clinton had no business going over there in the first place. And then he treats these dictators like they're so great."
In the kitchen of her split-level house, Ann Marie Heffernan, 33, said Mr. Clinton had squandered a chance to defend political dissent. "He was not nearly forceful enough in condemning human rights abuses," said Ms. Heffernan, as she tried to quell the noisy rebellion of her year-old son, John, who sat in a highchair with chocolate smeared on his face. "I understand he wants to build a relationship. And it's obvious that the Chinese, like the Americans, are taken with his charm and charisma. But he should stand up for what is right."
Some people did not give a hoot about the ballyhooed trip.
"Doesn't impact me," said Tracey Bohannon, a 31-year-old secretary, "so I just skipped right past it."
And others had not heard about it.
"To be completely honest, I had no clue he'd been to China," said Jenny Lang, a 22-year-old lifeguard.
For those who were paying attention, the trip revealed the face of a changing China.
Liz Handley, a 30-year-old bank lobbyist, was impressed by images of Chinese talking on cell phones as they walked the streets. "It certainly didn't fit with the picture of Chinese people they taught us in the eighth grade," she said.
Others talked about seeing an interview with a technological entrepreneur in China who made his first $1 million before age 30 -- scarcely the embodiment of the revolutionary tenets of Chairman Mao.
But just about everybody -- people who cheered the China trip and those who criticized it -- agreed about one thing: the trip was exquisitely choreographed.
"One gigantic stage performance," said Lou Myers, 66, who works in real estate. "It really was overdone. Why not just go, have your talks and come home?"
An exception to the tight control, and the most memorable image to most people here, was the live broadcast of a news conference with Mr. Clinton and the Chinese President, Jiang Zemin.
During that conference, Mr. Clinton said Americans disapproved of the way that Chinese leaders had crushed the pro-democracy demonstrations in Tiananmen Square at a cost of many civilian lives.
"For China, I thought that was being pretty candid," said Mr. Sherer, the fire department worker, even though President Jiang defended the crackdown. "It says to me that things are changing over there, starting to open up."
In many ways, the China trip has been cast through the prism of the global economy. It is important for American businesses, the logic goes, to gain access to markets in the world's most populous nation.
And yet, it is those economic inroads that make some Americans uneasy, even some of President Clinton's strong supporters, particularly the blue-collar workers suspicious of free-trade accords.
"I'm on the fence on this whole China thing," said Ted Applegate, a 39-year-old union member who works on the boiler at the coal-fired power plant here.
If more American companies did business in China, Mr. Applegate said, it would probably improve rights conditions there, because it would give China an incentive to avoid the political wrath of American lawmakers.
But Mr. Applegate, a bearded man in a St. Louis Cardinals baseball cap, frets about making it easier for American companies to take advantage of cheap, nonunion labor in other countries.
"Who's going to stay here and pay a competitive wage when you can go to China and pay the workers next to nothing?" asked Mr. Applegate, who fiercely opposed the free-trade accords favored by Mr. Clinton but voted for him anyway. "We're seeing a lot of it already. The companies are making these record profits by exporting jobs."
In this city of Lincoln, images of the stovepipe hat seem as commonplace as fireflies in July (there are barber shops and chiropractic offices named for the rail-splitter turned President). There is also a lot of talk about honesty and politics, and how frequently the twain meet.
"The Chinese can say what they want, but how do we trust them?" said Frank Allison, a short-order cook at the Sunrise, a big man hovering over the grill with a toothpick in his mouth. "Talk's easy; talk's cheap. Action is what it's all about."
Down by the Old State Capitol building, now a museum, Ms. Reese, the hospital cleaning worker, said she planned to make a real celebration of Independence Day this year.
"You wouldn't think Clinton and that Chinese President would get along, but they seemed to," said Ms. Reese, as she rose from her bench, making her way down a cobblestone walkway to shop for groceries and maybe a little beer. "If the leaders don't fight, you know, then maybe we can stay out of wars."

HEADLINE: Investors Bet on Revival for Troubled Newark

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

DATELINE: NEWARK, July 4

 BODY:
Real estate investors hungry for new and cheaper territory have begun placing bets on downtown Newark, buying up a dozen buildings over the last 18 months in an early sign that the fortunes of New Jersey's largest city may be reversing after decades of decline.
The city, a national symbol of urban decay since the riots in 1967, has benefited from the real estate boom in Manhattan and its suburbs, where yearly office rents run as high as $60 a square foot. In Newark, by contrast, high-quality office space can be found for $12 a square foot. The price is so attractive that some New York companies have opened offices in Newark -- about 15 minutes from Manhattan by train -- rather than in Jersey City, their usual choice on this side of the Hudson. 
 At the same time, the New Jersey Performing Arts Center, a handsome $180 million brick building in the heart of the business district, has been more successful than even its supporters had hoped. About half a million people have attended events there since it opened last fall.
"Newark had a stigma to it for a long time," said Christian Benedetto, who with his partner, Glen Fishman, bought the 21-story tower at 24 Commerce Street, New Jersey's tallest building during Newark's heyday in the 1920's. "Over the years, you've heard about six different revitalizations. Now you've got a lot of people putting their money where their mouth is."
Steven C. Witkoff, a New York investor who recently bought the Woolworth Building in Manhattan, has also jumped into downtown Newark. He paid $240 million for the four towers at the Gateway Center last month. Two weeks ago, the Tremont Capital Group, a Houston company, bought the old First Union Bank building at 550 Broad Street. Blackacre Capital Group, which owns about $1 billion in real estate in Manhattan and elsewhere, bought 60 Park Place in March.
No one is saying that Newark's revival will be immediate or inevitable. Much of this activity is taking place in a relatively small section of the city and will do little to offset the loss of thousands of manufacturing jobs over the last four decades, or to revive the hardscrabble neighborhoods where schools are substandard and unemployment is high.
And despite the enthusiasm of Newark's new real estate investors, they must still push hard to fill their newly acquired buildings.
"There are a lot of positive signs on the surface," said Donald Eisen, a broker for Cushman & Wakefield. "But I don't see any real major users coming into the city, as opposed to going to the waterfront in Jersey City. We really need a new, major corporate commitment."
Still, many investors are betting that this commitment is coming to Newark, which has an international airport and whose harbor on Newark Bay and network of highways and rail lines made it a manufacturing center before World War II. These amenities may prove crucial to the city's revival.
 
Promising Signs Include Park and Stadium Plans
There are many other hopeful signs. The city, state and Federal governments are pouring millions of dollars into plans for a two-mile esplanade along the Passaic River, a minor-league baseball stadium and a $49 million law school for Rutgers University. New Jersey Transit has planned a milelong trolley line from Symphony Hall on Chestnut Street to Pennsylvania Station, the baseball stadium, the arts center and the Broad Street Station, with connections to Manhattan and the suburbs.
Just as important, the Prudential Insurance Company, one of the city's few remaining civic pillars, has moved 3,800 employees to Newark from suburban sites, increasing its downtown work force to about 7,000.
On Tuesday, a group of private investors led by Raymond G. Chambers bought a majority interest in the Nets, the professional basketball team, with the intention of building a new arena in Newark, near Pennsylvania Station, for the Nets and the Devils hockey team.
But Mr. Chambers and his fellow investors face a difficult task in persuading Gov. Christine Todd Whitman and John McMullen, the owner of the Devils, to support the move. And most economists are skeptical of the economic value of stadiums and arenas for anyone other than team owners and players, although the teams could bring an enormous amount of recognition and prestige to the city.
For more than a year, a private foundation led by Mr. Chambers, a financier turned philanthropist who has become the unofficial godfather of Newark, has been acquiring land along Broad and Halsey Streets, including the long-vacant S. Klein building. The goal is to accelerate a downtown revival and link the business district around Pennsylvania Station, the arts center to the north and the University Heights neighborhood to the west.
Mr. Chambers, who grew up in Newark but now lives in Morristown, and the New Newark Foundation hope to lease or sell the properties to retailers and developers who conform to a design by Tony Goldman, who helped redevelop South Miami Beach in the 1980's. Once a run-down Art Deco district, South Miami Beach is now a bustling enclave of nightclubs, hotels and restaurants.
Mr. Goldman said his plan envisions an urban community of four- and five-story buildings with larger retailers, restaurants and nightclubs along Broad Street and smaller storefronts and local entrepreneurs on Halsey Street. Professional offices and apartments for students, office workers, artists and others would occupy the upper floors. Although the foundation's plans took Mayor Sharpe James by surprise when they surfaced last month in The Star-Ledger, Mr. Goldman hopes to win the approval of local officials. Profits from the venture will be invested in other Newark neighborhoods, Mr. Goldman said.
"This is not just a real estate venture," Mr. Goldman said. "This is a social opportunity to get people who used to live in Newark to come back to the city and interact in this urban village."
 
An Effort to Compete With Jersey City Rents
In the competition for office development, Jersey City has had the advantage of being a few minutes closer to Manhattan and offering views of the New York City skyline that Newark, farther west, cannot. Many of the investment banks that moved some operations out of Manhattan landed in Jersey City.
But a test of the relative merits of Newark and Jersey City is in the works. In the words of one real estate broker, Merrill Lynch has "proposals out all over the place" for a million square feet of office space.
Alfred L. Faiella, Newark's Deputy Mayor for economic development, said he had been negotiating with state officials and representatives of a company interested in building a million-square-foot tower in New Jersey. Mr. Faiella said he did not know whether the company was Merrill Lynch.
"It's hard to take a New York company away from the Jersey City waterfront," Mr. Faiella said, "but we've put together a major package of incentives, everything from tax rebates to low-interest loans."
He cautioned that Newark still faced an uphill climb. He said he wanted to revive downtown and build housing in the neighborhoods, while continuing to use tax breaks and other incentives to encourage business development.
"The Mayor says we're on a roll," Mr. Faiella said. "We've got to keep pushing that tire along, otherwise it'll stop rolling."
Some companies have shown a willingness to consider Newark. The LZA Group, a large engineering and architectural firm based in Manhattan, recently leased a floor for 30 employees at 24 Commerce Street. Jay Prasad, executive vice president of LZA, said he found that rents in Newark were about one-third of those in Manhattan.
"We looked around and we found that Newark is very cost-effective compared with New York and Jersey City," Mr. Prasad said. "It's only 15 minutes away from Manhattan by New Jersey Transit. And by opening an office in Newark, we've been able to attract personnel who don't want to commute into New York."
Worldcom, the giant communications company, recently leased 65,000 square feet in the old Macy's building on Market Street, once the home of Bamberger's department store, for a telephone switching station. It is not a plush corporate headquarters, but Samuel J. Jemal, whose family bought the building 18 months ago, said there was enough demand for wide-open floors and high ceilings to turn the upper floors of the building into office space for telecommunications companies.
"Newark is the best value in the tristate area," said Arthur Stern, chairman of Cogswell Realty Group, which bought two of Newark's largest buildings. "Occupancy costs are one-third cheaper than in Jersey City, and it's got the best transportation in the region."
Mr. Stern's company is spending $45 million to renovate the National Newark Building at 744 Broad Street, once the city's most prestigious office tower. Mr. Stern bought the Art Deco tower for about $11 a square foot, a far cry from the $500 a square foot that Donald J. Trump paid for the General Motors Building in Manhattan. Cogswell plans to convert another nearby building, the Raymond Commerce Building at 1180 Raymond Boulevard, into a dormitory for students at the five colleges and universities in Newark.
 
Hopes Are Raised By Sudden Turnaround
The turnaround here has come suddenly. In late 1996, for example, Townsend Capital, an investment company based in Maryland, bought the Gateway II office building near Pennsylvania Station for $35 million. "It was a tough sale," said Daniel Cramer, a vice president with Townsend. "Our lender turned it down twice because it was Newark."
But in May, Townsend sold Gateway II to Mr. Witkoff for $78 million, more than twice what it paid 18 months earlier. More recently, Townsend paid $12 million for the former Blue Cross and Blue Shield headquarters at 33 Washington Street and is spending millions to renovate it.
"The Performing Arts Center has been a huge plus," Mr. Cramer said. "But Prudential's decision to consolidate its operations has been an incredible shot in the arm. We think that'll spawn other companies to consider the same move. I don't believe this will be a revolutionary change. It's going to take time to emerge."
Mr. Witkoff, who was an aggressive real estate buyer in Manhattan in the mid-1990's, when many investors feared that the market would never recover from the recession, went on to buy the other three buildings in the Gateway Complex.
"I love Newark," Mr. Witkoff said. "It reminds me of lower Manhattan three years ago. It's centrally located, and it's going to take off."
All these developments have thrilled Miles P. Berger, who bought the Holiday Inn at 430 Broad Street in 1976 for $500,000, a tiny sum for a 200-room motel with a ballroom, restaurant and pool on three acres. Renamed the Lincoln Motel, the property began a downward spiral as Mr. Berger housed the homeless under contracts with New York and New Jersey. Mr. Berger also bought the Robert Treat Hotel, once the city's best, and later, the old Hahne's Department Store on Broad Street.
Mr. Berger said that the arts center had improved business at the Robert Treat and that he was leasing the Hahne's building to the New Newark Foundation. On Tuesday, he said, he talked to the Holiday Inn about resuming the franchise at the Lincoln Hotel.
"We've come full circle," Mr. Berger said. "All these signals told us the time is ripe to turn that motel back into a Holiday Inn franchise. For 17 years there was nothing going on here. People ran from Newark."

HEADLINE: True to Form, Clinton Shifts Energies Back To U.S. Focus

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 4

 BODY:
After a long trip to China that his aides believe strengthened the President against the Republican Congress and Kenneth W. Starr, the Whitewater independent prosecutor, President Clinton returned home this weekend and immediately took to the air waves to report on his high hopes for improving . . . fruit juice.
In his weekly radio address this morning, President Clinton tersely summarized his trip before moving on to the focus of his message: new regulations to increase the safety of fruit and vegetable juices. 
 In a favorite formula for this White House, Mr. Clinton dropped his foreign trip cold upon touching American soil and turned to domestic policy. For the coming week, aides have planned events on health care, drugs and juvenile crime to remind voters of the President's devotion to fixing problems that may seem more pressing than Chinese rights or rockets.
With some of his closest advisers deeply pessimistic about the chances of getting major legislation passed during the rest of the year, Mr. Clinton plans to issue a series of executive orders to demonstrate that he can still be effective.
"Stroke of the pen," Paul Begala, an aide to Mr. Clinton, said in summarizing the approach. "Law of the land. Kind of cool."
At the same time, with an eye to the brewing budget fight and the Congressional elections this fall, the President is expected to step up pressure on the Republican Congress, as he did in the radio address.
"Congress must also do its part to insure the safety of America's food supply," Mr. Clinton said.
Some of his closest advisers have concluded that there will be no budget deal this year like the bipartisan balanced-budget agreement struck with much fanfare a year ago. Having failed at one of Mr. Clinton's top domestic priorities, sweeping tobacco legislation. his team hopes to exact a political toll from the Republicans for Beltway gridlock.
On Tuesday, Mr. Clinton intends to hold a ceremony to issue an executive order to promote greater access to health care for Federal employees, aides said. He will couple that move with a plea to Congress to pass his "Patients' Bill of Rights," legislation for standards in managed care.
As a result of all this domestic politicking, the China trip is likely to slip off Washington's radar screen very fast. In the same manner, when Mr. Clinton returned in early April from a lengthy trip to Africa, he immediately held a Rose Garden ceremony to boast about the American economy and to describe his legislative agenda on education, highways and tobacco.
Ann F. Lewis, the White House communications director, put it this way: "We tend not to spend a lot of time talking about what we've just done. Or, to put it differently, we could talk about it, but you wouldn't write about it, so that wouldn't make much sense. The events we do are always forward-looking."
Yet Mr. Clinton's advisers are banking on political momentum from his trip to China. They hope that the success of the trip will blunt Congressional hearings into decisions by the Clinton Administration to permit American companies to launch satellites on Chinese rockets.
Ms. Lewis sorted through a stack of editorials from Fort Worth, Pittsburgh, and Abilene, Tex., arguing that Mr. Clinton had received strong reviews nationwide, including in such editorially chilly pages as those of The Wall Street Journal.
As when he was on his Africa trip, Mr. Clinton is returning home having just received an unexpected lift from the courts. While the President was in Senegal in April, a Federal judge dismissed Paula Corbin Jones's sexual misconduct case against him; this time, while the President was in China, a Federal judge here rebuked Mr. Starr and dismissed the tax evasion indictment he had won against Webster L. Hubbell, Mr. Clinton's old friend and former Justice Department appointee.
One senior adviser said the trip, which resulted in a flood of favorable news articles, showed Mr. Clinton attending to the substance of his job. As a result, the adviser said, Mr. Starr's decision this week to call a high-profile witness, Linda R. Tripp, heightened the contrast between the investigation at home and Mr. Clinton's work abroad, making the former seem "small and petty."
But any such impression could quickly fade, because this White House has a sorrowful history of seeing its well-laid plans vaporized by unpleasant surprises. After all, it was barely two days after Mr. Clinton returned from Africa that the first news report appeared detailing his Administration's decisions to permit satellite launchings in China.

INTERNATIONAL 3-6
 
New World's Treasures Uncovered at Site in Cuba
Archeologists in the Americas have tended to focus on societies with large physical legacies, like the Aztecs. But a Canadian team has turned toward the native people of Cuba and some other Caribbean islands, known as the Taino. Digging at an underwater site in Cuba, they have uncovered the remnants of houses 500 to 700 years old. 1
 
Mixed Reviews for Clinton
Americans appeared at least to take notice of President Clinton's foray into China. In more than two dozen interviews, most gave the trip favorable reviews. Some criticized the President for a weak defense of human rights, or scoffed that he was trying to shift attention from investigations in Washington. Others said they simply didn't give a hoot. 1 

Soldiers Deploy in Ulster
Hundreds of British soldiers ringed the small Drumcree neighborhood in Northern Ireland and installed thousands of yards of barbed wire in an effort to prevent violence at a parade by Protestant marchers scheduled for Sunday. "There's more Brits at Drumcree than there were at Dunkirk," a taxi dispatcher said. 3
 
Protest by Arab Orthodox
About 200 Palestinian Orthodox Christians demonstrated at a gate to the Old City in Jerusalem. The protest was part of an ancient dispute between Arab members of the Orthodox Church and the Greek church officials who have controlled the Jerusalem Orthodox Patriarchate. 6
 
U.S. Reassures Japan
Secretary of State Albright dropped by Tokyo on her way back from China to emphasize that the United States values its ties with Tokyo as much as ever. In addition to remarks about the "unshakable friendship" between the two countries, she also prodded the Japanese to take further steps to bolster their economy. 4
 
NATIONAL 8-12
 
A Somber Ending To AIDS Conference
The 12th World AIDS Conference ended in Geneva in a somber mood. A series of reports about new problems with anti-AIDS drugs and setbacks in vaccine trials left many participants thinking that their best hope against the epidemic is the strategy they have had since it began -- prevention. 1
 
A Hint of Calm in Florida
Favorable winds, high humidity and even some rain combined over the last 24 hours to calm down the fires in Florida. While the forecast called for more thunderstorms and light rain, officials said shifts in wind also threatened to spread the fires to populated areas as long as drought conditions remained. 1
 
No Unity on Teachers Merger
Supporters of the proposed merger of the National Education Association and the American Federation of Teachers have one worry, the hundreds of N.E.A. convention delegates who are urging the 10,000 delegates gathered in New Orleans to vote down the merger, which would create the largest labor union in American history: a colossus of nearly 3.3 million members. 8
 
No Deal for Starr and Lewinsky
One month after Monica S. Lewinsky replaced her legal team, negotiations on a deal with the independent counsel, Kenneth W. Starr, to avoid possible prosecution of the former White House intern have stalled, lawyers on both sides of the talks report. 10
 
NEW YORK 13-19
 
Newark's Renaissance
Real estate investors hungry for new and cheaper territory have begun placing bets on downtown Newark, buying up a dozen buildings over the last 18 months in a sign that the fortunes of New Jersey's largest city may be reversing after decades of decline. 1

A Judicial Mr. Fixit
Often when things need to get done in the criminal justice system, both big and little things, a number of judges and lawyers in New York turn to Hillel Bodek. Technically, Mr. Bodek is a freelance clinical social worker, who spends most of his time evaluating the mental state and recommending the appropriate care for indigent mentally and physically impaired defendants. But he is also something of a judicial handyman who is appointed by judges to do almost anything that needs doing to hasten the process of justice. 13

Transit Passes Debut
Thousands of riders stood at token booths to buy new versions of the Metrocard that went on sale yesterday. The new cards offer unlimited rides on the city's subways and buses for $17 for 7 days or $63 for 30 days. A transit executive said he was pleasantly surprised at the demand, especially given that it was the middle of a holiday weekend. 13

HEADLINE: China and Taiwan Are Warming to Each Other

 BODY:

To the Editor:
In Shanghai President Clinton warned that China was about to assume the distinction of replacing the United States as the largest emitter of greenhouse gases (news article, June 25). 
 Data from the Carbon Dioxide Information Analysis Center suggest that the President's comments are premature. China's total carbon dioxide emissions are unlikely to overtake the United States for another 10 to 20 years, and in per-capita terms China's carbon dioxide emissions are still one-sixth of those of the United States.
It is true that the developing world has begun to claim an increasing share of the world's greenhouse emissions. Ultimately, however, policies informed by an understanding of the relationships between technology, economic growth and emissions will prove more helpful than alarmist rhetoric in addressing these trends.
 
AMAR HAMOUDI
Cambridge, Mass., July 1, 1998
 
The writer is with Harvard's Institute for International Development.

HEADLINE: Bill to Aid Small Airlines in New York Divides Legislators

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 3

 BODY:
On the surface, the two problems seem about as related as toothaches and hangnails: the budget-busting cost of flying on business out of New York's upstate cities, and the nerve-jangling roar of jets using La Guardia and Kennedy Airports in Queens.
But legislation moving briskly through Congress has bound the two together, by proposing a treatment for the first that many New York City officials believe will thoroughly aggravate the second. The result has been a classic bit of regional squabbling within New York's Congressional delegation over whether the city's quality-of-life concerns are drowning out the economic problems of smaller communities upstate. 
 At stake is legislation intended to increase airline competition in mid-size cities like Albany, Rochester, Syracuse and Buffalo, where an unrestricted round-trip ticket to Chicago can cost more than the excursion round-trip fare to Hong Kong.
The bill would help start-up and regional airlines by giving them greater access to major airports, including La Guardia and Kennedy. Large airlines now control virtually all of the landing and takeoff slots at those airports.
But increasing competition at La Guardia and Kennedy requires increasing air traffic. To New Yorkers who live along flight corridors on Long Island and in Queens and the Bronx, that can only mean more ear-thumping, window-rattling, baby-waking noise. "It's unlivable now," said Stephen Hendel, whose home in Larchmont, Westchester County, falls under a flight path to La Guardia on busy days.
The issue has caused a regional rift in the state's Congressional delegation, a relatively cohesive group, uniting upstate Republicans and Democrats against their downstate brethren.
"We get more complaints about air noise than almost any other local issue," said Representative Nita M. Lowey, a Democrat who represents parts of Westchester, the Bronx and Queens. "This legislation will only make the situation worse."
But for House members from Rochester, Buffalo, Syracuse and Albany, which have some of the highest air fares in the country, the issue is a leading business problem.
"Perhaps this bill will increase traffic," said Representative Louise M. Slaughter, a Democrat from Rochester. "But if that is the result, they'll just have to accept it. They have the major airports and get the benefits related to that."
Officials in Rochester, Buffalo and other upstate cities say air fares are so exorbitant that many companies have begun requiring employees to drive rather than fly to places like Boston or Chicago. Some have also raised the specter of moving entire divisions to cities that offer cheaper air transportation.
"When companies evaluate whether to expand in Rochester or elsewhere, the cost of transportation has become a factor," said Craig F. Curran, president of a travel agency in Rochester.
The dispute has created a dilemma for Representative Charles E. Schumer, a Brooklyn Democrat who is seeking his party's endorsement for Senate. Mr. Schumer has made reducing air fares one of his top campaign issues upstate.
But jet noise is also a major issue in his home district, and Mr. Schumer recently signed a letter along with Ms. Lowey and five other members of Congress from the New York metropolitan area urging colleagues to reject the airline bill, known as the Airline Service Improvement Act.
James Kessler, a spokesman for Mr. Schumer, said the Congressman might propose an amendment that would allow regional carriers to increase their flights into La Guardia and Kennedy by giving them slots now controlled by the big airlines, rather than creating new slots. Such a plan would avoid increasing overall air traffic at the two airports, but would also face fierce opposition from major carriers.
Amid growing anger with high air fares across the country and Government accusations of predatory pricing by the major carriers, the airline competition legislation has gained widespread support among legislators in both parties. The Airline Service Improvement Act was approved overwhelmingly by the House Transportation Committee in June and is expected to reach the floor later this summer. Similar legislation is percolating in the Senate Commerce Committee, and its sponsors expect a floor vote by August.
At issue is a 30-year-old system that sets strict limits on the number of landing and takeoff slots available at four airports: La Guardia, Kennedy, O'Hare International in Chicago and Ronald Reagan National in Washington. Starting in 1985, the Federal Department of Transportation allowed the major airlines to treat their slots like property that could be sold, traded, leased or even used as collateral for loans. But rather than sell slots to start-up airlines, the big airlines have tended to hoard them or lease them at high rents, Federal officials say.
That has made it extremely difficult for regional airlines to establish routes to New York City, Washington and Chicago. The smaller airlines pay a premium to lease the few slots available in those cities, which translates into very high fares.
Refundable round-trip fares from Rochester to Chicago, the type of tickets business people traveling on short notice typically must buy, range from $900 to $1,055. A restricted round-trip fare from Rochester to Hong Kong can cost $880. Department of Transportation studies consistently rank Rochester among the nation's five most expensive cities for air travel.
Under the Airline Service Improvement Act, the Department of Transportation could grant additional landing slots at the four restricted airports to airlines that fly to underserved areas. The rule could add as many as two flights an hour at La Guardia and Kennedy.
Debate on the bill comes at a time when the Department of Transportation is preparing rules intended to stop major airlines from driving out new carriers with predatory practices, like flooding competitive routes with cheap seats. The big airlines are lobbying to block or delay those rules.
Over the last year, the department has also added 30 new slots at La Guardia, mainly for regional airlines, under a 1994 provision allowing such action under "exceptional circumstances," a department spokesman has said. Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York and Claire Shulman, the Queens Borough President, have filed a lawsuit seeking to rescind those slots.
For Willard W. Hunter, president of Amarel, a Rochester company that makes optical equipment, increased airline competition could not come soon enough. Mr. Hunter said he requires employees to drive 10 hours to Chicago, where they do much of their business. "To send two or three people there would cost $1,800 or $2,700, which is absolutely ridiculous," he said. But Dr. A. Allan Greene, a Howard Beach, Queens, podiatrist and leader of a community group fighting airport noise, said he and his neighbors could not tolerate even one more flight a day into Kennedy.
"The bipartisan mind-set in Washington is, 'More, more, more is better in the sky,' " he said. "They have no consideration for the people down below. You can't hear anything. You can't have a conversation. I feel like an insect being crop-dusted."

HEADLINE: Reuniting New Yorkers With Forgotten Billions

BYLINE: By JAYSON BLAIR 

 BODY:
Kofi Annan, please call H. Carl McCall. His office has some money for you.
And not just for Mr. Annan, the United Nations Secretary General: Mr. McCall, the New York State Comptroller, has money for the Yankees' outfielder Darryl Strawberry, former Mayor David N. Dinkins, Gov. George E. Pataki and millions of other people whose forgotten bank accounts, uncashed travelers' checks, utility refunds and lost stocks have been turned over to the state. 
 The money is waiting to be claimed in the state abandoned property fund, which was established in 1943 and has reached a record $4.16 billion, a sum larger than the budgets of many nations.
The 15 million accounts range from the $700,000 that a New Yorker has left unclaimed, to small bank accounts forgotten by college students who have moved out of the area with no forwarding address, to $8 to $24 refunds for about 15,000 tickets for a concert scheduled for the Nassau Coliseum on Aug. 22, 1977, that was canceled after the featured performer -- Elvis Presley -- died.
"It is my job to collect unclaimed funds and then give them back to the people who deserve them," Mr. McCall, the State Comptroller, said in an interview. "If you look at the record over the years, you see that we take in much more money than we give out. We are trying to change that."
Under New York law, companies have to turn over money they are holding for consumers, like dormant bank accounts and uncashed refund checks, to the state after two to five years, depending on the type of account. Last year alone, the office received about $304 million in unclaimed funds, but returned only $60 million.
Publishing a list of the names of account holders annually, as required by state law, was not enough to prompt people to fill out claim forms to regain their money, so Mr. McCall placed the unclaimed funds database on a Web site (http:// www.osc.state.ny.us), which has logged 2.7 million searches since its introduction last July. And since this spring, the Comptroller's office has operated booths at high pedestrian traffic areas like train stations and racetracks to try to reunite people with their assets.
This stepped-up campaign has brought Mr. McCall attention, praise and the political boost that comes with mailing out checks, signed by the Comptroller, to voters in an election year. Mr. McCall, a Democrat, faces Bruce A. Blakeman, the Presiding Officer of the Nassau County Legislature, in the November election.
"It is a good thing they are doing by making these appearances, because a lot of people can't make it to an office to pick up forms," said Linda Ramous, a Chase Bank employee who stopped by the booth at Pennsylvania Station recently and found that the state had stock dividends in her dead aunt's name.
Because of the Web site, the number of claims has tripled to 60,000 in fiscal year 1997 from about 20,000 in fiscal year 1996, said Theresa Bourgeois, a spokeswoman for the Comptroller's office. But the more people who file, the slower the processing gets. Mr. McCall increased the number of employees handling unclaimed funds to 128 from 116 in January, but claims can take as much as five months to process.
All 50 states have some method of collecting and returning unclaimed funds, but none of them have collected anywhere near as much money as New York, rich in financial institutions that have to turn over forgotten accounts to the state. The $4.16 billion -- while small potatoes compared with the $100 billion in state pension funds that Mr. McCall also controls -- exceeds or rivals the annual budgets of 23 states. California follows New York with an unclaimed property fund of about $2.3 billion.
According to the National Association of State Treasurers, there are about 1.2 million unclaimed accounts in Connecticut totaling $260 million and about 2 million unclaimed accounts in New Jersey worth $659 million.
The State Treasurer's office in Connecticut returned a record $5 million in unclaimed property last year, said Patrick O'Neil, a spokesman who added that his state was the first to list names of account holders on the Internet in 1995. New Jersey returned about $16 million last year, said Stephen Sylvester, the unclaimed funds administrator with the Division of Taxation.
Most states use the interest made from unclaimed funds to cover the costs of their unclaimed property operations or for education or economic development programs. New York, New Jersey and Connecticut allow owners to collect limited amounts of interest on some funds.
Claimants must provide state officials with proof of their identity and a connection to the address listed on the account. People can also make claims for dead relatives.
The Governor discovered a modest windfall in the last few weeks when he was contacted by an official in the Comptroller's office.
Zenia Mucha, a spokeswoman for Mr. Pataki, said she thought his unclaimed funds were related to a bank account at a former home in Saratoga Springs, N.Y. "He has already filled out the forms for the claim," she said. "He does not have much money in there, I can assure you of that."

HEADLINE: Political Briefing;
Signs of Discontent In the Aloha State

BYLINE: By B. Drummond Ayres Jr. 

 BODY:
The Democratic Party has always carefully cultivated Hawaii's disparate racial and ethnic groups and, as a result, few states are more Democratic than the Aloha State. But that Democratic dominance faces a major test this year because the Hawaiian economy, unlike those of almost all other states, is in a deep, seven-year slump, its tourism sector hammered by Asia's financial crisis and unable to offset steady shrinkage in the agriculture and military sectors.
Hawaii could be a state where Democrats lose both a Governor and a member of the House of Representatives this fall. 
 The latest polls show the probable Republican challengers posing big trouble for state's top elected Democrat, Gov. Benjamin J. Cayetano, and one of its two Congressional Representatives, Neil Abercrombie. Equally serious, the polls indicate that voters, by 2 to 1, believe that Republicans, including those in the heavily Democratic State Legislature, could do a better job of restoring the economy than Democrats.
In the Governor's race, the polls have the expected Republican nominee, Mayor Linda Lingle of Maui, leading Mr. Cayetano by about 5 to 3. Her pitch is that even in the hardest of economic times, Ms. Lingle has managed to keep Maui moving forward, increasing jobs and tourism.
In the Congressional race, the polls show that the expected Republican challenger, State Representative Quentin Kawananakoa of Honolulu, has pulled even with Mr. Abercrombie. Mr. Kawananakoa promises to jump-start the state's economy with tax cuts, if elected.
Governor Cayetano and Mr. Abercrombie, who are expected to be renominated, contend that polls taken five months before the general election do not mean much. Still, they acknowledge that Hawaii's economic slump has left them with a major political problem. As Mr. Cayetano said at a recent rally, "This election is going to be one of the great challenges that we Democrats have faced."

SECTION: Section 2; Page 1; Column 2; Arts and Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 2411 words

HEADLINE: ARCHITECTURE;
Looking at the Lawn, and Below the Surface

BYLINE: By HERBERT MUSCHAMP 

 BODY:
SOMETHING awful is happening to the planet Earth. It has been invaded by the Earth-snatchers. It is being turned into a pod planet, one lawn at a time. Thirty-two million acres have been snatched thus far on the North American continent alone. More land is now occupied by lawns than is given over to the cultivation of wheat, corn or tobacco. It costs $750 million annually to seed this turf. Another $25 billion is invested each year in mowers, clippers, gardening gloves, hoses and other do-it-yourself tools.
Life on the pod planet can be delightful, especially in the month of July. You can lie on your back on the lawn and stare at the sky. Make a grass kazoo. Cut open a maple seed and stick it on your nose. Season your jeans with grass stains. Become a Cheever character and run out sobbing into the night. 
 "The American Lawn: Surface of Everyday Life," a corker of a show at the Canadian Center for Architecture in Montreal (through Sept. 27), begins with a ride on a lawn sprinkler. Or at least the video depiction of one. Back and forth the camera swings, scanning the archetypal patch of grass, oscillating between peripheral glimpses of equally iconic neighbors on either side: the no-nonsense lady trimming her hedge to clipped perfection, the cool kids hanging out by the garage. In the background, water hisses.
The video is projected onto the floor, and you hesitate to step on it. Your shadow might block the projection. Thus the show stylishly connects two kinds of transgression: one associated with land, the other with museums. Keep Off. Don't Touch. That kind of elegant connection occurs throughout this show.
It's probably best seen as one large piece of multimedia design, in which ideas ricochet among artworks, aerial satellite photographs, squares of sod, television news footage, solar-powered robot lawn mowers, even a pink flamingo or two.
The lawn is a natural subject for a summer show, if also a highly perverse one. Even those who don't own a lawn might wish to preserve that small plot of green as a symbolic escape from civilization. This show plunges us into history, economics, sociology, psychology and other cold-weather pursuits. The lawn is our last little shred of Eden. Trees of Knowledge are no more wanted here than weeds. Can't we please keep thinking off the grass?
"The American Lawn" gives little quarter to innocence. There are no pictures of kids leaping through sprinklers. No shots of lovers discovering splendor in the grass. But the show does confer innocence upon the visitor, for we are left feeling that there is everything yet to learn about the everyday world we live in.
IN 1976, Elizabeth Drew wrote a beautiful article for The New Yorker about the mood of the country on the Fourth of July in the bicentennial year. She describes how the news media, the politicians and the salesmen have done everything within their power to appropriate the event, and in the process nearly killed it off. But they didn't kill it off. People found ways to act spontaneously. They ate burgers, drank beer, paraded in small-town marching bands, cheered displays of fireworks as if the spectacle expressed a set of values to which they still subscribed.
Ignoring authority may be one way to resist it, but this show rests on the democratic principle that it's better to be informed.
The curators start with the premise that the lawn represents the fusion of two traditions: the "cultivated" model of great European estates and private parks, and the "vernacular" example of the small colonial garden. This distinction, first analyzed by the historian John Kouwenhoven, held firm until the late 19th century. With the emergence of suburban communities, this distinction began to collapse into the continental green tapestry of today.
"Cultivated" takes on a literal meaning here. In the forthcoming catalogue, Georges Teyssot writes that "certain horticulturalists like Sara Stein have come to consider the lawn a surface that while vegetal is artificial in that it attains its emerald splendor only when subjected to perpetual torture. 'Continual amputation is a critical aspect of lawn care,' Stein has observed. 'Cutting grass regularly -- preventing it from reaching up and flowering -- forces it to sprout still more blades, more rhizomes, more roots, to become an ever more impenetrable mat, until it becomes the perfect lawn, the perfect sealant through which nothing else can grow.' "
Lawn care, in other words, is much like road care and serves a similar purpose. "Like the interstate highway system," the author Michael Pollan has observed, "the lawn has served to unify the American landscape." But differences, conflicts and nature itself are not as easily mowed down as grass.
The architectural historian Reyner Banham used to horrify professional audiences by declaring that architecture is that which changes land use. But the truth of that statement becomes ever more apparent with the daily expansion of urban sprawl. "The American Lawn" is about land use. There are ideas behind the cultivation of wheat, corn and tobacco, and tension lurks beneath the two-inch layer of green stuff on which Americans have staged their placid dreams for more than a century.
"The American Lawn" is the last in an ambitious cycle of shows on "The American Century" organized by Phyllis Lambert, the Canadian Center's dynamic director. The whole series has been a triumph, but the inaugural show, "Scenes From the Life To Come," and the present exhibition are examples of curatorial brilliance.
It was organized by a stellar team: Mr. Teyssot, Allesandra Ponte, Mark Wigley, Beatriz Colomina, Elizabeth Diller and Ricardo Scofidio. Mark Wasiuta and Gwynne Keathly assisted the team. Diller & Scofidio Architects, of New York, designed the installation.
Since cultural values tend to coax up their opposites, a space dedicated to harmony and independence can easily become a battlefield. Is an overgrown lawn a protected form of speech? How about Christmas ornaments on the lawn? Or a cross-burning? Does the Postal Service have right of way when delivering the mail?
Excerpts from court cases in which lawns figured as contested terrain are featured in one gallery, along with a row of stereopticons. Each of these contains a 3-D image of the border between two neighboring lawns. In one shot, it is clear that one neighbor is a fastidious raker while the other has allowed a half-dozen picturesque leaves to gather, the slob. In another, a well-watered plot abuts a parched one. The groomed and the neglected strike a recurring theme, played out across the continent in contrapuntal variations. Sometimes, the grass is less green. Often, it is brown.
In a section on the competitive lawn, the contest at first looks more sporting. The focus here is on the intricate patterns mowed into the grass in sports stadiums. But there is greater competition here than meets the eye. What's at stake is not just victory in a game but lucrative broadcasting contracts. To make sports events more telegenic, stadium managements have commissioned increasingly elaborate designs for animating the playing surface, including plaids, swirls and sunburst motifs. These video lawns are vying for ratings.
Another kind of contest is documented by photographs of golf courses in desert climates like Arizona. The contest here is between nature and our visual image of it. These artificially created terrains have already altered local weather patterns, and, if chaos theory is correct, their impact could well be global. But aren't they beautiful, these emerald islands adrift in what looks like a giant sand trap of planetary proportions? Is this a preview of coming attractions?
The Power Lawn is represented in two formats, corporate and governmental. In the 1960's, as corporate headquarters relocated to the suburbs, their International Style headquarters were typically surrounded by grandiose grass plinths. These served as moats, visual statements of intimidation. This retro-feudal form is handsomely represented by professional black-and-white architectural photographs of the period. These lawns are so stark, so flat, so blatantly designed to hold the world at bay that it would be shocking to pollute them with anything as capricious as color.
The North Lawn of the White House, by contrast, is a backdrop for chaos: the unruly spectacle of political protest. Not that it was designed for that, but here democracy has happily appropriated one of its major symbols. Rallies are presented in television news footage, screened on small monitors suspended from sleek metal arms down the center of the gallery. Another monitor displays scenes of Presidential arrivals and departures by helicopter on the South Lawn.
By now our eyes are so primed to notice sheared surfaces that we may detect a resemblance between a neglected lawn and the autumn-haze mink coat Pat Nixon wore when she and her husband took off for China. On the other hand, in a contrast that recalls one of those stereopticon views, Mrs. Nixon's hairstyle is luscious and as beautifully tended as a French garden, while the President's hair is patchy.
HAND-PAINTED glass slides line the perimeter of a gallery on "Idyll and Anxiety." Drawn from a collection assembled in the 1920's and 30's by the Garden Club of America, they depict scenes as ravishing as pastorals by Boucher and Fragonard. Ah, the poplars, the willows, the urns bulging with moss atop balustrades wrapped around terraces on which visions of loveliness, graceful ladies and their escorts, will momentarily appear!
It is unnerving to think that many of them were painted during the Dust Bowl years.
The flip side of this reverie is projected on a screen that slices into the gallery's center: clips from movies in which the dark subconscious of pastoral bliss punches through the thin green crust.
"Blue Velvet," naturally, but also a great comic sequence from the 1956 version of "Invasion of the Body Snatchers" in which Kevin McCarthy tries to persuade a reluctant neighbor that she should consult a psychiatrist about her wild suspicion that something awful has happened to Uncle Ira (shown obsessively mowing the lawn next door).
Pod person or mental patient, what's it going to be?
Lawns have their pathology, too: fungi, viruses, nematodes, insects, air pollution, dog urine. Color photographs of these and other afflictions are mounted on one wall, the particular strain identified below in a Latinate script of old botany prints.
These are clearly offered for our viewing pleasure with a degree of gleeful relish: they convey a city dweller's delight over trouble in suburban paradise. But these pastoral sores are also easy on the eyes. Even if the artist Mel Chin (not represented in the show) had not called attention to the esthetic dimension of ecological imbalance, the resemblance of these images to abstract painting would be impossible to miss.
This is a visual and philosophical show, not a scientific or ecological one. While it observes the environmental impact of the suburban way of life, it does not preach the virtues of recycling or condemn our failure to adopt methods for sustainable urban growth. The show documents and analyzes. It fertilizes the cultural terrain from which even environmental issues draw meaning.
Across from the disease wall there's a vitrine displaying square samples of grass, natural and artificial. Both types have been engineered to enhance desirable qualities, like springiness, color or resistance to weather. The point of the display is to suggest not that there is no difference between nature and artifice but that modern life has rendered the contrast less extreme. Once, cultural meaning revolved around the polarity dividing the two. Now, it has moved deeper into the space between.
Diller and Scofidio's work occupies a middle space, too: between theory and conventional practice. Though they have published several books, and a housing project of theirs is nearing completion in Gifu, Japan, the team is best known for temporary installations, like those created for the Museum of Modern Art, the Walker Art Center and the Creative Times public-art program on 42d Street. The two are not paper architects. They enjoy making things too much, and their pleasure shows.
"The American Lawn" is not as chillingly analytic as it may sound. It's true that the curators come out of the academy, and their thinking owes much to post-structuralist philosophy. But the show pulsates with such intelligence, wit and even glamour that it can't be taken as a lecture room performance.
The Garden Club slides, for example, are not set up to be mocked. They are gorgeous fantasies, to be cherished as such. The notion that suburban normalcy represses difference might seem obvious if the exchange with Uncle Ira were less enjoyably hilarious. One can admire the stark beauty of Ezra Stoller's architectural photos while recoiling from the meaning of the lawns he depicts.
Diller and Scofidio know how to entertain as well as edify. Though they rely extensively on dialectic, the technique seldom becomes oppressively schematic. And the team always creates seductive hardware.
Little magnifying glasses to highlight passages of text in a row of old gardening books. The thinnest metal vermicelli cable to hold the stereopticons. A glass table, supported atop the soles of athletic footgear, to demonstrate the changing shape of grip. A red zipper LED sign flickers mysteriously behind the reflection of grass in a two-way mirror.
There's a bright shimmer to this exhibition, an aura of energy and delight that you may associate more with walks in the country than with trips to museums. If I had to account for this shimmering effect, I would say that Diller and Scofidio's main concern is the differentiation of meaning and that for them, this process is inseparable from image, space and form.
Diller and Scofidio's work is now much imitated. You can't lead unless you're willing to tolerate followers, and a critic should not cringe each time he encounters a superficial emulation of this pair's visual and intellectual effects. Still, leaders and followers are not of the same cultural order of being, and seeing the real thing is a pleasure. I came away from "The American Lawn" convinced that intelligence is as generous, merciless and playful as nature, and no less increasingly rare.

CORRECTION-DATE: August 2, 1998, Sunday

HEADLINE: Perspective;
Team Profits and Labor Peace

BYLINE: By ANDREW ZIMBALIST; Andrew Zimbalist is professor of economics at Smith College. He has written extensively about sports.

 BODY:
The Florida Marlins lost more than $30 million last year. Right, and Dennis Rodman has no tattoos.
The National Basketball Association contends that more than half of its teams are losing money. The N.B.A. players association says that only five teams lost money last year, and four of those are getting new arenas. 
 The N.B.A. owners say they need a hard salary cap to stop the bleeding. The players say it ain't so, and besides, if some teams on the bottom are really in the red year after year, there are better ways to deal with it than creating more restrictive labor markets.
These issues, now extant in the N.B.A. because of the lockout announced last week, plague labor relations in all the major team sports.
In the N.B.A. and the National Football League, where an explicit salary cap restricts the payroll, the players have every reason to be concerned that team revenue is correctly identified. When the cap was first introduced in the N.B.A. in 1983, Larry Fleisher and the players association were not very sophisticated about the ways owners could hide or rechannel revenue.
The 1983 cap was defined as 53 percent of defined gross revenues, which included only television, radio and gate revenues. Following the 1988 collective bargaining agreement, which defined those revenues as ones "derived from, related to or arising out of the performance of players in N.B.A. basketball games," a dispute arose about what sources of income should be included.
Owners divided luxury box revenue into two parts: the rental payment for the amenities of the comfort and convenience of the box and the ticket price for watching the game. The owners contended that the latter belonged to defined gross revenues and the former did not. This and similar issues led the players to bring an arbitration complaint against the owners, which they won in 1992 with a settlement of some $60 million.
When the 1995 collective bargaining agreement was signed, defined gross revenues was changed to basketball-related income, and the players accepted a lower share in return for a broader definition of revenues applicable to the salary cap. Basketball-related income now includes, for instance, 40 percent of luxury box income, 40 percent of signage (but excludes naming rights according to a curious arbitrator's decision in 1996), a pro rata share of permanent seat licenses and certain related party transactions.
The collective bargaining agreement takes 11 pages to define basketball-related income, and it is still subject to regular dispute. Suppose you are an owner negotiating an arena lease and you are given a choice: pay $2 million in rent and receive 50 percent of a projected $4 million in signage income or pay no rent and receive no money for signage. It might seem that this is a choice between equals, but since the collective bargaining agreement gives 40 percent of signage income to the players, the owner would do better with the option of no rent/no signage. Lease agreements offer manifold opportunities for such juggling, especially when the arena and team are owned by the same person or entity.
Related party transactions are a central component of most teams' finances. For example, if the owner of the team also owns the arena, the arena management company, the concession rights, a local television or radio station, Web pages, local real estate, law or consulting firms that do business with the team, then the owner has tremendous latitude about where to make his or her profits appear.
Abe Pollin, for example, owns the new MCI Center, where both his N.B.A. and N.H.L. teams, the Washington Wizards and the Capitals, play. He can retain arena revenue from naming rights, premium seats, signage, catering, theme activities and so on, in his arena corporation, thereby reducing the revenues earned by his teams by tens of millions of dollars annually. Owners can also pay themselves exorbitant salaries and consulting fees, along with their extensive perks. Thus, Wayne Huizenga, owner of the Marlins, Dolphins, Panthers, Pro Player Stadium, SportsChannel Florida, and arena management and concession ventures can rechannel his teams' revenues to his related businesses, making the world champion Marlins appear to lose money.
When there is a salary cap, such accounting legerdemain comes in handy to directly reduce player payrolls. When there is no cap, owners have still preferred to hide profits to reduce revenue-sharing payments or to argue for larger public subsidies for stadiums, collective bargaining concessions or special treatment under the law.
As the sports industry globalizes, the opportunities for shuffling new income into different businesses will expand and the potential for labor conflict will grow with it.
If the N.B.A. takes in millions of dollars from European or Asian advertisers on its Web page, is this, using the language from the 1995 collective bargaining agreement, revenue that is "derived from, relating to or arising directly or indirectly out of the performance of players in N.B.A. basketball games or in N.B.A.-related activities"?
The trend for media giants to buy up sports franchises so they can control their programming will further complicate matters. When Rupert Murdoch, who owns Fox, sends signals for Los Angeles Dodgers games to hundreds of millions of Asian homes and is able to raise subscription or advertising fees on satellite television service, how can baseball players lay any claim to this revenue they help to produce?
How can other team owners include this income in the revenue-sharing base when there is no direct increase in Dodger revenues, especially when 24 major league baseball teams are dependent on Fox-owned stations for their local TV revenue?
These are extraordinarily complex management and organizational issues. Put them together with the issues of competitive balance, single-entity versus monopoly status and idiosyncratic personalities, and you begin to sense the challenges that lie ahead for the business of team sports.
Greater labor-management cooperation is imperative to confront these challenges successfully. Intelligent leadership and sensible public policy, both scarce commodities, would also help.
