SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 2; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1530 words

HEADLINE: Absent a Battle Cry, War for the House Is Fought at Home

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 5

 BODY:
After two Congressional elections that were seen as referendums on the direction of the nation, this year's battle for control of the House is being fought the old-fashioned way: candidate by candidate and district by district.
In a year marked by a pro-incumbent contentment with the economy, only 65 House races are even considered by the political parties to be truly competitive. Yet with the Republicans holding one of the slimmest majorities of this century, the Democrats need a net gain of just 11 seats to reclaim control of the House. 
 Those numbers mean that Representative Newt Gingrich's longevity as Speaker could depend less on sweeping political themes than on a chain of local circumstances: the decision by Representative Wes W. Watkins, Republican of Oklahoma, not to retire after all, or the question of whether voters in Hawaii decide to punish Democrats, like Representative Neil Abercrombie, for the local economic recession.
"This time you don't have a Presidential race going on and you don't have a national wave one way or another," said Representative Martin Frost of Texas, the chairman of the House Democrats' election committee. "So it's really trench warfare, district by district."
Candidates across the nation are still striking certain common chords. Democrats, for instance, are riding the overhaul of managed health care as a central campaign theme.
"There are key issues out there that are going to have an impact," said Representative Frank Pallone of New Jersey, one of the Democrats the Republicans consider potentially vulnerable this year. "The one I'm focusing on is managed care reform. And I think people will respond because they think this is a do-nothing Congress that is not focusing on key issues."
Mr. Gingrich sent his incumbents out to campaign over the July 4 Congressional recess on a message of tax-cutting. Representative John Linder, the Georgian who heads the Republicans' re-election effort, said his party will be stressing "that we have balanced the budget with tax cuts and put people back to work" who had been on welfare.
But for the first time in almost a decade, the words of the late House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill seem most apt: "All politics is local." Strategists for the two parties sense none of the anti-Washington animus that gave a national cast to recent elections, when voters rallied against a recession, entrenched incumbents or legislative overreaching.
"Ninety-four was an election where the Republicans didn't want to talk about anything but Bill Clinton," said Geoffrey Garin, a Democratic pollster, "ninety-six an election where Democrats didn't want to talk about anything but Newt Gingrich. Ninety-eight will be a different kind of election where candidates talk about each other. There's not a single issue that's driving the election from border to border and coast to coast."
In their drive to hold the majority that they won in 1994, Republicans have history on their side. Traditionally, the party in the White House loses seats in its sixth year in office. And Republicans are forecasting at least a 10-seat gain in November.
Some Republican incumbents, though, are being forced to struggle for their seats. Representative Constance A. Morella, a moderate Maryland Republican, is thought to be facing the strongest, most well-financed challenger of her six terms in Ralph Neas, the former executive director of the Leadership Conference on Civil Rights.
Mr. Neas has accused Ms. Morella of moving to the right during her years in office. After appearing at a Fourth of July parade this weekend, however, Ms. Morella said that by putting an emphasis on health care, technology issues and education, she was a "good mirror of my district."
Democrats see several reasons why they may be able to defy history, starting with the fact that the year's retirements from Congress left them with fewer vulnerable open seats than the Republicans. They also boast some well-financed candidates who may be able to overcome the Republicans' usual advantage in raising money. Even Republicans concede that the voters' "six-year itch" for change may have come four years early, in 1994, when Republicans took control of the House for the first time in nearly 50 years. And, since 1980, no President has had coattails guaranteed to sweep a marginal candidate into office.
"With an 11-seat margin, one or two breaks the right way can make the big difference," said Mark Mellman, a Democratic strategist.
There is no better barometer of how small events can make a difference in the electoral math this year than the sharp mood swings among House Republicans.
They started the year confident of a serene election, then began to panic in late spring that they could lose the House. Now, they have been bolstered by a handful of recent developments that have even nonpartisan campaign handicappers like Stuart Rothenberg and Charlie Cook calling it unlikely that the Democrats can take the majority.
For one, Republican leaders made a successful appeal to Mr. Watkins of southern Oklahoma to reconsider his plans to retire. Mr. Watkins, a longtime Democrat who changed parties and ran for Congress as a Republican in 1996, was considered the sole Republican who could hold a seat so Democratic that his district was long ago dubbed "Little Dixie."
In addition, the California primary in June saw the triumph of two moderate Republicans who are considered the party's strongest candidates to run in districts in Sacramento and the Los Angeles area, now held by Democrats Vic Fazio, who is retiring, and Jane Harman, who made an unsuccessful bid for her party's gubernatorial nomination.
And in a special election in Albuquerque, N.M., to replace Representative Steven H. Schiff, who died, a Republican, Heather Wilson, held the seat for her party, after a Green Party candidate siphoned votes from Phil Maloof, the Democrat.
"We expect to have some momentum from this," Mr. Linder said. Democrats still say they can secure a majority of the 435 House seats by winning 8 of the 10 most competitive seats being vacated by Republicans and then defeating nine of the weakest Republican incumbents. That still leaves room for the Democrats to lose a handful of their own seats.
The Republicans counter that they can increase their majority by at least 10. They are counting on winning 5 of the seats where Democratic incumbents are retiring and defeating 10 other Democrats.
Those calculations allow them to lose as many as five seats, although Mary Crawford, a spokeswoman for the Republican election effort, said, "Our folks really believe that unless something dramatic happens we won't lose a single incumbent."
Both parties are focusing on freshman lawmakers who are less entrenched, like Representative Vince Snowbarger, a Kansas Republican, and Representative James H. Maloney, a Connecticut Democrat. Democrats and Republicans are also fighting hardest in swing districts that are seeing the retirement of incumbents, particularly in the Middle West and along the West Coast.
In California alone, eight seats are considered competitive. The politically volatile North Coast California district where Representative Frank Riggs is retiring could be one of the most difficult for the Republicans to retain. State Senator Mike Thompson, a Democrat, is opposing Mark Luce, the Napa County supervisor.
But Democrats are likely to have trouble keeping the California seats of Mr. Fazio and Ms. Harman. The districts lean Republican and the nomination of two moderate Republicans who support abortion rights, Doug Ose, a businessman, and Assemblyman Steven Kuykendall, is thought to give Republicans an edge. They face Sandie Dunn, a lawyer, and Janice Hahn, a businesswoman.
In some states, the Republicans are counting on popular governors at the top of the ticket to carry weak incumbents. Gov. Tom Ridge of Pennsylvania is expected to help Representative Jon D. Fox of the Philadelphia suburbs. Mr. Fox won by only 84 votes in 1996 over Joseph M. Hoeffel, and had to come through a primary fight this spring. Mr. Hoeffel, a county commissioner, is challenging him again.
Democrats say they will be able to do well in some unexpected places, because this year their candidates better match the philosophy of their districts. In an open seat in Kentucky, for example, the Democrat, Ken Lucas, is a county judge who is an anti-abortion social conservative. He faces Republican State Senator Gex Williams.
The campaign year might yet turn more volatile in its last weeks. In 1994, the collapse of President Clinton's health care plan and the legislative maneuvering over the crime bill late in the Congressional session helped propel the Republicans into the majority. And two years ago, the support for the Democrats began to drop as questions about President Clinton's campaign financing emerged in late October.
A wild card for both parties is the course of the investigation of Mr. Clinton by Kenneth W. Starr, the independent counsel. "The big question none of us has been able to answer," said Ralph Reed, a Republican strategist, "is what happens with the scandal?"

PUB-DATE: July 7, 1998

SECTION: Section E; Page 1; Column 1; The Arts/Cultural Desk 

LENGTH: 1905 words

HEADLINE: Critic's Notebook: The Right to Perform, the Right to Compose;
Loss of 'Peony' and Players

BYLINE: By JAMES R. OESTREICH 

 BODY:
With much of Tibetan culture put at risk by actions of the Chinese Government, it may seem petty and impertinent to fret about the fate of Chinese opera; even more, about one particular corner of it. But Chinese opera, which has long been the central manifestation of the performing arts in China, deftly combining music, drama, poetry, dance, design and acrobatics, is waning. And Kunqu opera, the revered style that began in Kunshan, near Shanghai, in the 14th century and gave birth to so many later varieties, including the dominant Peking opera, appears to be dying. Really dying, not just wallowing in confusion, as so much of Western classical music is doing.
That sober reality was hard to credit for a recent visitor to Shanghai, seeing the remarkable talent, energy, imagination and love being lavished on rehearsals for the ground-breaking production of the Kunqu classic "The Peony Pavilion" that was to have formed the crown jewel of the Lincoln Center Festival, which opens this evening. As Chen Shi-Zheng, the gifted American director now at the center of a storm, put the mostly young performers of the Shanghai Kunqu Opera Company through their paces, the gorgeous costumes arrived bit by bit, handmade in classic fashion by elderly seamstresses in nearby Suzhou, the site of a Kunqu museum. Despite the dinginess of the surroundings, on the fifth floor of a municipal building in the old French quarter of Shanghai, the process seemed one of growth and vitality. 
 But it is suddenly easier to comprehend the dire predictions now that the Shanghai Municipal Bureau of Culture has at the last minute denied the company permission to travel to New York. And it seems clear that the final, fatal blows to Kunqu are being delivered by the very people who proclaim themselves its protectors.
"This is a precious piece of Chinese culture," Ma Bomin, the director of the bureau, rightly says of "The Peony Pavilion," written by Tang Xianzu in 1598 and considered one of the great masterpieces of Chinese literature. Yet that epic drama lay mostly unperformed for centuries, typically represented by an occasional presentation of 1 or 2 of the most famous of its 55 scenes.
The impetus for the Lincoln Center production, which was to have presented the work at its full 20-hour length, seemingly for the first time in at least three centuries, came not from China but from an American, John Rockwell, when he was the director of the Lincoln Center Festival. Mr. Rockwell, who is now the editor of the Arts and Leisure section of The New York Times, is expert in Wagnerian opera, and his curiosity about "The Peony Pavilion" led him to conceive the "Ming Ring," as he called it: a presentation of the complete work in six parts, over six nights or three days. He was also fascinated by the possibility of applying Western methods of early-music research and notions of "authentic" interpretation to this repertory, and he enlisted Mr. Chen, who has lived in New York since he left his native China in 1987.
Here, whatever its origins, was a prime opportunity to inject new life into Kunqu by giving it unprecedented international exposure. The production was to be showcased not only in New York but also at festivals in Paris, Sydney and Hong Kong, and probably released on audio and video. And this at a time when another version of "The Peony Pavilion," directed by Peter Sellars in a truncated and Westernized form, is traveling the globe.
 
The Objections To Changing a Work
Now Mr. Chen's production has been derailed by Ms. Ma, who deemed it unworthy to represent Kunqu tradition and, significantly, modern China to the world. No matter that the largely oral tradition has itself strayed far from whatever Kunqu may originally have been. It is as if someone had been able to decree early in this century that Handel's "Messiah" should be performed only as it had emerged from Victorian England, with bloated chorus and orchestra and perhaps even a few of Thomas Beecham's bells and whistles.
Then, too, one specific at issue was the brief appearance of a prop, a chamber pot, which was alleged to make China appear backward. Yet as Mr. Chen points out, during the Song dynasty, in which the opera is set, or even the Ming, in which it was written, a chamber pot would have been anything but backward.
This was one of four scenes the bureau took issue with in a recent preview. In another, Mr. Chen was accused of injecting superstition by staging a funeral march for the heroine and burning effigies, in line with Chinese folk tradition. In the two other scenes, the material objected to -- the "pornography" of the scene in which Sister Stone tells why, anatomically, she could only be a virgin, and the mocking treatment of a drunken Tartar general -- came directly from the classic text.
After Mr. Chen expressed a willingness to make adjustments, the bureau's censors took the production back into rehearsal and demanded changes in six more scenes. Even then, Mr. Chen said on Friday on his return to New York, "if that would get approval for the performers to leave, I would have done it." But when Ms. Ma walked out on the rehearsal she attended, it became apparent that no amount of compromise would suffice to liberate the production.
Some have suggested that the real reason for refusing to permit the company to travel was a fear of defections. Indeed, the last time this company visited the United States -- Los Angeles, in 1989 -- 8 of the 20 members defected. Several are part of the Kunqu Society in New York. Those who stayed with the company are now the wise old masters on whom Mr. Chen, whose training was largely in other forms of Chinese opera, relied for the niceties of Kunqu. "The practitioners are the real experts," he said, dismissing the "experts" who found his work wanting.
In anticipation of the New York trip, the bureau obtained signed affidavits from the performers' families promising that if an individual did not return, the family would forfeit $12,000, no small amount by Chinese standards.
Whatever the ultimate reasons for detaining the production and however great the loss for Western audiences, the real damage has occurred in China. Eight months of painstaking rehearsal and the exquisite work of innumerable craftsmen have evidently gone for naught, and brilliant young performers have been denied brighter futures.
"Their spirits are totally broken down," Mr. Chen said. If so, it is a calamity for those were clearly strong and vibrant spirits, well suited to the lively characters they were to play.
In "The Peony Pavilion," Du Liniang, the susceptible teen-age heroine, finds a dashing lover in a dream and pines to her death for lack of the reality. But she is resurrected when the embodiment of that lover, Liu Mengmei, a young scholar, discovers her portrait and reciprocates her love. Though the work is set in the Song dynasty (960-1279), its concerns relate at least as much to Tang Xianzu's era, as Ben Wang, a Kunqu expert in New York, explained in a captivating series of lectures at the China Institute in connection with the Lincoln Center Festival. The playwright was especially intent on espousing freedom and initiative in his heroine at a time when Neo-Confucianism found young women suited only to idleness and subservience.
Qian Yi, lovely in a shy and understated way at 22, was to have played Beautiful Du, as the name can be translated. Zhang Jun, tall and charismatic at 23, was to have played Mengmei. Both were members of the last class to have graduated from the Shanghai Kunqu Opera School: possibly the last class ever. In 1986, they were among the 60 students accepted from 20,000 applicants for the eight-year program. When the school recruited for the next class, recently, there were not enough applicants to form one.
Interest in all forms of Chinese opera has eroded in the last decade under a wave of American pop culture and Western arts, including opera. Kunqu, the most refined of the 360 or so types of Chinese opera, has been especially hard hit. Kunqu melody grows directly out of the pitch characteristics of Chinese speech, with its four tones: high, low, rising and falling. And just as speech is elevated to song, movement is elevated to dance, with special significance given to curving motion, since, for the Chinese, the circle represents the perfect union of opposites, the yin and the yang.
Increasingly, parents limited by national social policy to producing a single child are reluctant to consign that child to so rarefied and uncertain an enterprise. The Shanghai company is one of six Kunqu troupes surviving in China, and performances are infrequent and ill attended. The performers are paid less than $100 a month.

What's Next for Performers? They Wonder Themselves
When Ms. Qian and Mr. Zhang, obviously the rising stars in the field, were asked what professional opportunities might await them after "The Peony Pavilion," neither professed to have any idea. Both are taking night courses in Chinese cultural administration as a hedge against unemployment, and Mr. Zhang has already made headway as a pop performer, where prospects are better.
Twenty members of their class have already left the company, but the rest are an ebullient lot, as adept at belting out choruses as at tumbling in the battle scenes and even performing acrobatics on stilts. They work under the continuing tutelage of performers twice their age, for a generation was lost to Chinese opera during the Cultural Revolution, when performances were banned. Mr. Chen, now 35, was among the first to emerge after the revolution ended, in 1976. The members of the company are mostly in their 20's or their 50's.
It was in this fragile ecosystem that Ms. Ma took her draconian action to "protect" Kunqu from Mr. Chen's incursions. And what did those incursions finally amount to? Chiefly, attempts to reimagine the spirit of Kunqu when "The Peony Pavilion" was new, before interpretations and costumes took on their present stiffness. Within conventions still highly stylized, he wanted a hint of naturalism.
He also wanted to show the West Chinese folk tradition and, he said, "the best of China." Thus, not only the hundreds of glorious costumes but also a magnificent wooden set, modeled after the famous gardens of Suzhou and the outdoor theater in the museum.
That Mr. Chen was able to achieve all of this on a budget of $500,000 attests to the modest cost of the highest-quality craftsmanship in China and also to his abilities as producer as well as director. With cell phone at the ready, he fairly reveled in detail during those Shanghai rehearsals, fielding crises like the call from the Shanghai Zoo informing him that it would not furnish songbirds for the preview performance for fear that the clangorous Chinese percussion instruments might induce psychological problems; he would instead have to find birds inured to street noise.
This splendid production would have established Mr. Chen as a star. On the basis of the Shanghai preview, Le Monde in Paris has already called it "one of the major cultural events of the end of the 20th century." No matter; Mr. Chen is resourceful enough that he will find his way another time. One can only wish the same for those wonderful performers tossed aside back in Shanghai, one of them, Mr. Zhang, wearing the new suit he bought for New York.

HEADLINE: Claims for Art Collection Pose a Challenge to Hungary

BYLINE: By JUDITH H. DOBRZYNSKI 

 BODY:
Martha Nierenberg was one of the lucky ones. When the Nazis invaded her native Hungary on March 19, 1944, "the whole family went into hiding with a friend in Budapest," she recalled. "By noon, they were looking for my father." Unlike others with Jewish backgrounds, she and most of her relatives soon escaped, including her father, Alfonz Weiss. The Weisses were so important economically -- employing 30,000 workers to make everything from airplanes and tanks to tin cans and needles -- that they bartered a 25-year lease on their factory for freedom. When they fled, they were escorted by police cars.
But Mrs. Nierenberg, now 74, also remembers what they left behind -- especially the mansion of her maternal grandfather, Baron Maurice Herzog, on Andrassy Boulevard, Budapest's Champs-Elysees. "It was like a museum, like the Frick," she said. 
 Many of those works, widely known as the Herzog Collection, now hang in Hungarian museums, where they were left for safekeeping during the war or placed after being stolen by the Nazis and later returned to Hungary.
She wants them back.
But Hungary, the latest in a string of countries whose national collections have been hit by individuals' claims for wartime plunder, seems torn. As a fledgling democracy just starting to make its way in the West, and as a country that itself is trying to reclaim looted art in Canada and Russia, including many other paintings from the Herzog Collection, it might be sympathetic. But its national politics and cultural aspirations are tugging in the opposite direction. Negotiations between the Nierenbergs' lawyers and Hungarian officials, which began in mid-1996 and went smoothly at first, broke down last winter, just as Hungary was gearing up for a national election in May.
Mrs. Nierenberg and her husband, Ted, who live in Armonk, N.Y., thought they had an agreement last fall on 21 of the 30 works they had so far claimed, including paintings by or attributed to El Greco, Cranach, Zurbaran and van Dyke. A team of experts from Sotheby's had valued the batch at $8 million to $14.5 million. "We were slightly conservative," said George Wachter, the director of Sotheby's Old Master paintings department, partly because the works were viewed on museum walls and could not be studied closely.
Mr. Wachter called the Cranach and Zurbaran paintings "fantastic pictures," but said that the El Greco was best labeled "workshop of El Greco with the possible assistance of El Greco himself," and that a Velazquez was also probably misattributed. "It is a very beautiful, high-quality picture, and if we did more research, we might be able to go further," he said. "But we said it should be attributed to Juan Bautista Martinez del Mazo."
The Nierenbergs were willing to take back 60 percent of this group, and to forgo the rest in lieu of Hungarian taxes. But, they said, Hungarian officials soon reneged, proposing instead to study the case further. The two sides have had no contact for months, and neither agrees with the other's version of what happened.
"They're stalling," Mr. Nierenberg said. "I'm 75, and they think I'll lose interest, and it will go away." (The couple's four children have not focused on the quest.)
The Hungarians, however, differ. "They do have some claims, but we don't know how much," said Ivan Ronai, the director of the department of cultural heritage in the Culture Ministry. "Some paintings were clearly deposited at the museum for safekeeping. Some are less clear. We don't know how they got there." The Nierenbergs have no contracts proving anything, he said.
"The whole collection in Hungary should be handled as a package," he added. "But until we know the exact status of each painting, we are not in a position to bargain. That is why we suggested arbitration. We're waiting for them to come back, but they just refused."
Mr. Nierenberg said he and his wife would agree to international binding arbitration, but not the kind the Hungarians had in mind. "They said, 'We'll go to arbitration, but we pick three Hungarians and you pick three Hungarians,' " he said. "It was utterly ridiculous."
Instead, the Nierenbergs have decided to apply public pressure, despite an early agreement not to talk about the dispute. "The Hungarians said they wanted to get into NATO, and they didn't want any bad publicity," Mr. Nierenberg said. "And then the Government felt it would lose the election if it gave away national treasures."
But with Hungary's entry into the North Atlantic Treaty Organization seemingly assured, and with a new Hungarian Government in place, the Nierenbergs said going public was their best recourse, even though diplomats say the new regime is more nationalistic, less internationally minded than its predecessor.
The designated Minister for Preserving National Cultural Heritage, Jozsef Hamori, just learned of the issue. Donald Blinken, a former United States Ambassador to Hungary who remains interested in the case, raised it with him on a trip to Budapest in late June. Reminding Mr. Hamori that Hungary was the first former East bloc country to allocate funds to pay Holocaust survivors a monthly stipend, "I told him Hungary did it right once and ought to come to grips with this issue of art right away," Mr. Blinken said.
The new Government may also have a hard time taking a tough stance in light of Hungary's activities with Canada. A year ago, the Hungarian Culture Ministry quietly asked the Montreal Museum of Fine Arts to return "The Marriage Feast at Cana," by Giorgio Vasari, which was stolen from the Budapest Museum of Fine Arts during the war. The Montreal museum, which said the painting had been sold in 1961 by a state-owned store in Budapest and acquired later by the museum in good faith, responded that it had no obligation to return the painting. It proposed "co-ownership."
Hungary declined, and a lawyer for the Culture Ministry recently gave letters outlining the dispute to the press. One, to the museum's lawyers, dated Oct. 9, 1997, noted that when war losses were discovered in North American museums, "it has not been the practice to hide behind national laws," but that "a higher moral and ethical standard has systematically been applied."
The Nierenberg case is also complicated by the looted art held by the Russians. They intercepted many paintings stolen by the Nazis in Hungary as the works, including many from the Herzog Collection, were being shipped to Germany.
Over the years, Baron Herzog had donated some paintings to the Museum of Fine Arts in Budapest, but he retained the bulk of the collection. When he died in 1935, followed by his wife in 1941, the collection was left mainly to his three children, one of whom was Martha Nierenberg's mother, Elizabeth. Elizabeth (who married Alfonz Weiss) later inherited the one-third share of her brother Steven, who died in 1966. The other third was inherited by a brother who died in a labor camp during the war and whose share fell to his Italian ex-wife and their two daughters.
Martha Nierenberg, as the oldest surviving heir of Elizabeth Weiss, said that she; her sister, Mary, and brother, John, were entitled to two-thirds of the Herzog Collection.
For years, no one in the family did anything about reclaiming the art. Much of the Herzog Collection, whose 1,500 to 2,500 pieces included decorative objects as well as paintings by Italian, Spanish and Dutch Old Masters and French Impressionists, has simply vanished. Besides, when the family sought compensation for its industrial losses right after the war, what it got was bunch of virtually worthless Hungarian coupons, Mrs. Nierenberg said.
"This precedent dampened the family's whole desire," Mr. Nierenberg said. "Why do anything for the art? We got bupkis for the real estate and the factory," he added, using a Yiddish term for nothing. The family did not know where the art was because of the Iron Curtain, and Mrs. Nierenberg said her mother downplayed the loss: "Her feeling always was, 'We were out, and it was fine.' "
But a few years ago, the Russians acknowledged that they held "trophy art" from the war in their museums and vaults. When they started to exhibit it, some pictures were even labeled "Herzog Collection." The Pushkin Museum in Moscow, for example, displayed "a big picture of El Greco's that was my mother's," Mrs. Nierenberg said. That changed the Nierenbergs' minds. They set their sights on Hungary because Russia has refused to give anything back.
That decision has not helped their cause with the Hungarians, who have been trying since 1991 to retrieve works from Russia. Minutes of the negotiating meetings with the Nierenbergs' lawyers show that the Hungarian officials have tried several times to shift the conversation to the works in Russia.
"The Hungarians said we should help them get the Herzog Collection back from Russia," Mr. Nierenberg said. "They think it belongs to them. If we get this settled, we might do something with the Russians."
But already, the Nierenbergs said, they have spent more than $50,000 on legal fees and on a curator they hired to prepare an inventory of the art they lost and to substantiate their claims that the paintings were left for safekeeping, not donated. Mr. Nierenberg, who with his wife founded Dansk Design, the upscale housewares maker, in 1954 and sold it in 1985 for about $20 million to Brown-Forman, said he was willing to spend another $100,000 on the claim.
New Government or not, it may not get easier. In recent months, there has been a telling change. Previously, "all these paintings in the museum in Budapest were identified as 'Herzog Collection,' " Mr. Nierenberg said. Now, Mr. Blinken and other witnesses said, those labels simply give the date of acquisition.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Mideast Future Shock

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

DATELINE: JERUSALEM

 BODY:
The big talk in Israel last week was that three young Israeli software designers, and their venture capitalist backer, just sold their two-year-old company -- Mirabilis -- to America Online for $287 million. Mirabilis is an Internet communications tool that allows users to talk and exchange computer files while on line. Israel is now second only to the U.S. in the number of computer-related start-up companies spawned in the 1990's.
Meanwhile, up north, Syria is still debating whether to allow in the Internet. A Palestinian businessman from Bethlehem who had just returned from trying to do business in Damascus complained to me: "If I go to Syria and I don't have fax, cell phones or Internet, what do I do? These are my tools." 
 Question: What does it mean for the future of the Middle East that Syria is still debating whether to get on the Internet and Israel is already designing the next generation of the Internet?
I think it means a lot. This widening tech gap between Israel and her neighbors -- Israel's G.D.P. is roughly equal to that of Egypt, Jordan, the West Bank and Gaza, Lebanon and Syria combined -- will simultaneously make Israel much less vulnerable to Arab political pressures, terrorism, boycotts and the ups and downs of the peace process, while making Israel much more vulnerable to conventional or unconventional warfare.
There are several reasons. First, in the old days Israel grew oranges, Morocco grew oranges, Spain grew oranges. So if importing countries were upset with Israel they could easily punish it by buying someone else's oranges. But what happens when there is only one Mirabilis? What happens when an Israeli company near Tiberias is the only one in the world that makes a key Ethernet switching chip? What happens when Israeli companies start to dominate a key tech sector like on-line tools for Internet security, which are built around algorithms developed in the Technion and Israeli Army?
What happens is that everyone comes courting Israel, no matter where the peace process is. Japan, which always shied away from Israel fearing Arab retaliation, is now the second-largest venture capital investor in Israel, after the U.S. Japan is weak in software design and has been gobbling up Israeli software companies. China now has 52 scientists doing research at Israel's renowned Weizmann Institute. India also has 52. "If you have the technology people want," an Israeli business writer told me, "no one cares if you are suppressing Palestinians." In the 1970's the Arabs had what the Japanese needed most to fuel their economy -- oil. Now Israel has a raw material that others covet almost as much -- information technologies.
Another reason Israel is less vulnerable to low-level pressures is that knowledge investors are sophisticated. They understand, unlike tourists, that when a shooting happens in Luxor, Egypt, it is nowhere near their software-design center in Haifa, so they don't run easily. Moreover, high-tech knowledge exports tend to be very light and not easy to disrupt. Some are exported by modem. Also, Israel's high-tech exports go, not to its neighbors, with whom it is in tension, but to faraway markets in Asia, the E.U. and the U.S. Finally, high-tech investment is in people, not factories, which can be easily destroyed.
But it is precisely this last point that underscores Israel's vulnerability as well. Israel is developing a knowledge economy, but knowledge workers are very mobile and they like to live in nice places. If the key knowledge workers in Israel decide that the situation has reached an intolerable point -- because they cannot abide the rising influence of the ultra-Orthodox in political life, or the unresolved conflict with the Palestinians or Prime Minister Netanyahu's mounting attacks on Israeli intellectual elites -- then knowledge people will leave.
Also, while Israel's economy today might be able to absorb more pain without economic costs, there is one thing it cannot absorb, and that is a new war with the Palestinians. With a $17,000 a year per capita income, Israel today has a standard of living close to England's. The Mirabilis kids are the new role models in Israel, where there are now long waiting lists for every engineering school.
If the political situation here deteriorates, and Mr. Netanyahu has to call on Israeli boys to go back and recapture the West Bank and Gaza, the Israeli middle class will be infuriated, and some will be out the door. Israelis will never begrudge Mr. Netanyahu for bargaining hard, but they will not accept a new war of attrition.
There is one more vulnerability -- that Israel will get so far ahead of its neighbors that one of them will, out of humiliation or frustration, lash out in some unconventional manner and try to level the playing field -- and Israel. Those who can't make a bomb will buy a bomb. Those who can't export software will export rage.

HEADLINE: Slower June Growth for Key Part of Economy

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 6

 BODY:
Business activity expanded at nonmanufacturing companies at a slower pace in June than in May, according to the National Association of Purchasing Management.
The index of nonmanufacturing business activity fell to 61.5 in June, from 64 in May. The index was officially begun a month ago by the association, which has been conducting pilot surveys for it since July 1997, when the activity index stood at 57.5. 
 The new survey is a complement to the association's report on manufacturing, which investors use to gauge the direction of factory activity. The new index is a parallel to the production index in the association's manufacturing report and not to the manufacturing report's main composite index.
"Over all in June, nonmanufacturing industries continued to grow and to increase their employment, while reducing inventories and paying less for purchased materials and services," said Ralph Kauffman, chairman of the survey and coordinator of purchasing at the University of Houston-Downtown.
The new-orders index in the survey fell to 59 in June from 63.5 a month earlier. And the index measuring export orders increased to 55 from 48.5. Import orders increased to 56, from 54 in May. Order backlogs fell to 50 from 53.
The manufacturing survey covers about 30 percent of economic activity in the United States, the association said. The nonmanufacturing report was established in an effort to measure the rest by surveying officials in purchasing and supply management at some 370 companies each month.

HEADLINE: India, Eye on China, Insists It Will Develop Nuclear Deterrent

BYLINE: By JOHN F. BURNS 

DATELINE: NEW DELHI, July 6

 BODY:
In talks with the United States on nuclear weapons, which are to resume on Sunday, India will insist on its right to develop a nuclear arsenal capable of giving it a "minimum deterrent" against China, a senior official says.
But in a briefing on Sunday for Western reporters, the official, from the office of Prime Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee, said India would offer concessions, including several the United States has rejected in the past as insufficient. He said India was also willing "eventually" to sign the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty, fulfilling a pledge by Prime Minister Vajpayee that India will not conduct more nuclear tests. 
 The official, who spoke on condition that he not be identified, said India already had nuclear weapons it could use in a conflict with Pakistan or China, its likely adversaries.
Whether India is capable of firing nuclear weapons, or needs months or possibly years to turn its technology into useable weapons, has been an open issue since India announced five underground nuclear tests two months ago. Pakistan followed in late May with two rounds of nuclear tests of its own.
"If you're asking me if we have a delivery system, the answer is, Yes, we do," the official said.
India and the United States have already held one round of inconclusive discussions since the nuclear tests, during a visit to Washington last month by Jaswant Singh, a senior official of the Bharatiya Janata Party, the Hindu nationalist group that leads India's 14-party coalition Government. Mr. Singh is to hold a second round of talks on Sunday in Frankfurt with Strobe Talbott, the Deputy Secretary of State; Mr. Talbott is to follow up with a visit to New Delhi on July 20.
The briefing officer said India was ready to take steps to respond to Western pressures. The most important, he said, would be its readiness to sign the test-ban treaty once Indian negotiators had determined "what we can get."
By this the official appeared to mean that India would use the prospect of signing the treaty as a bargaining chip in its bid to get the United States to lift or at least ease the wide-ranging economic sanctions Washington imposed after the tests.
In a potentially significant reformulation of earlier statements on the treaty, the official said India would no longer demand that the treaty be rewritten to include language committing all nuclear powers to a schedule for reducing and eventually eliminating their nuclear arsenals. The official said India recognized that with more than 140 nations having signed the treaty, it was impractical to expect it to be rewritten.
Instead, he said, India would press its case for total nuclear disarmament within the so-called Non-Aligned Movement and in the United Nations, forums where India has pressed for the elimination of nuclear weapons for decades.
Before possibly signing the treaty, the official said, India is ready to take other steps: turning India's pledge not to conduct further nuclear tests into what he called "a legally binding international commitment;" making a similarly binding pledge not to transfer nuclear technology to other countries, and pledging to join negotiations in Geneva on a new treaty to limit the production of the fuels required for nuclear weapons.
But the official said India would not accept the main demand by the United States: that India give up development of a nuclear arsenal.
He also rejected another American demand, a halt to missile tests, because India sees the tests as essential to develop a deterrent. All five established nuclear powers -- Britain, France, China, Russia and the United States -- have called on India and Pakistan to halt all steps toward developing nuclear arsenals.
The official said India expected China to be the most resolute in pressing for India not to develop a nuclear arsenal. But he said India was equally determined that it would have an arsenal to balance China's.
"Our problem is not Pakistan," he said. "Our problem is China. We are not seeking parity with China; we don't have the resources, and we don't have the will. What we are seeking is a minimum deterrent."
The official made his remark about being able to deliver nuclear weapons in response to a reporter who noted that India has fighter-bombers that could be adapted to carry nuclear weapons. But the official did not specify whether the delivery system he was referring to involved aircraft or missiles. Western intelligence agencies have estimated that India has a few dozen nuclear warheads, but have expressed doubt that the warheads are ready for use.
Most military experts said India and Pakistan could only use their small stockpiles of nuclear warheads after a time-consuming and technically complex process of mating the warheads to delivery systems, either aircraft or missiles. At the same time, having declared themselves nuclear powers, both countries would almost certainly want their adversaries to believe that the weapons were ready for possible use.
The Government's readiness to talk about concessions on the issue appears to have been hastened by the changing public mood in India, which has gone from euphoria over the tests to anxieties over the sanctions.
The uncertainties have aggravated the slump in the economy that had already begun as a result of the crisis elsewhere in Asia.
India has endured a 20 percent drop in share prices since the nuclear tests, a 7 percent fall in the value of the rupee against the dollar and a flight of foreign investments.

HEADLINE: A Record Pace For Viagra Sales

 BODY:
Viagra, the Pfizer Inc. pill for correcting male impotence, smashed all records in its first three months, according to I.M.S. Health, an industry consultant, which released numbers yesterday.
I.M.S. also predicted that sales of Viagra would reach $1 billion in the United States by March 1999. 
 Prescriptions for Viagra from April through June totaled 2.9 million, enough for estimated sales of $259.5 million, according to I.M.S.
Such huge sales appear easily to be a record. For example, one of the leading drugs introduced last year -- Lipitor, a cholesterol-reducing medicine from Warner-Lambert -- had sales of $12.4 million in its first two months.
Analysts were encouraged that prescription renewals remained strong, despite reports of the deaths of some Viagra users. A Pfizer spokeswoman stressed that the drug was safe when used correctly. Yesterday, the company criticized the Prudential Healthcare unit of Prudential Insurance and Humana Inc. for declining to cover the cost of Viagra because they said they regarded it as unsafe.

HEADLINE: Clinton Agrees to Meet Yeltsin In Russia in Early September

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 6

 BODY:
President Clinton has agreed to travel to Russia in early September to meet with President Boris N. Yeltsin, although the Russian legislature has not fulfilled a request to ratify an important arms control treaty signed with the United States, the White House announced today.
The two Presidents have made a practice of annual summit meetings, but for more than a year the White House had postponed responding to Mr. Yeltsin's invitation to Russia. 
 Mr. Clinton never said that ratification of the treaty, known as Start-2, which was signed five years ago, was a requirement for his visit, but he indicated that it was his strong preference. The President had said he hoped to move on to discussing further arms reductions, a topic that White House officials now say will be on the agenda this fall even without approval of the treaty.
"At the end of the day, they just felt that the issues we have to discuss were more important than waiting for the Duma," said an Administration official, referring to the lower house of the Russian Parliament. In describing those issues, he listed the ethnic violence in Kosovo and the state of the Russian economy, badly shaken by the financial turmoil in Asia.
The Senate approved the arms control treaty in 1996. But despite pleas from Mr. Yeltsin, the Communists and nationalists who dominate the Russian Parliament, citing security concerns and the high cost of destroying the weapons, have dragged their feet over ratification of the treaty, which would cut Russian and American nuclear arsenals to about 3,500 warheads apiece. The Parliament plans to take up the issue in September.
The White House said Vice President Al Gore would meet in Moscow later this month with the Russian Prime Minister, Sergei Kiriyenko, to help prepare the agenda for the summit meeting. The precise dates for the President's trip, as well the site of his meeting with Mr. Yeltsin, have not been set.
Mr. Clinton is also anxious to visit Northern Ireland and the Irish Republic this year to celebrate the recently approved peace agreement there. He may make those stops as part of his Russia trip, one aide said today.
The White House squeezed the Russia trip into a Presidential schedule already jammed with foreign travel. Mr. Clinton just returned on Saturday from a nine-day trip to China. Earlier this spring, he spent almost two weeks in Africa. In April, he attended a summit meeting in Santiago, Chile, and in May, he attended one in Birmingham, England, making stops in Germany and Switzerland along the way.
The President is still scheduled to visit India, Pakistan and Bangladesh in November, although the White House is weighing a change of schedule because of the nuclear tests conducted this spring by India and Pakistan. Regardless, Mr. Clinton will be in Asia that month, for a summit meeting in Malaysia.
In a meeting with Mr. Yeltsin during the Birmingham summit, Mr. Clinton urged him to seek ratification of the arms control treaty to help persuade budding nuclear powers like India and Pakistan that they were moving in the wrong direction.
Most of Mr. Clinton's travel was scheduled long before the disclosure in January that Kenneth W. Starr, the independent counsel, had broadened his investigation of the Whitewater land deal to include the President's relationship with Monica S. Lewinsky, a former intern. But the White House has welcomed the spate of foreign travel as an opportunity to escape Washington and to display the President as a global leader.
The packed foreign schedule is also coming in a year when the Administration is struggling to accomplish its legislative agenda. With Congressional elections looming in November, a comprehensive tobacco agreement has eluded Mr. Clinton, and some Presidential aides have all but given up on a budget agreement.
Today, President Clinton appeared in the Rose Garden to lay out his agenda, pressing Congress to act in what he called "the remaining 38 working days" of this legislative session. He called on Congress to approve new money for the International Monetary Fund, bills to change the campaign finance system and the Internal Revenue Service, and a juvenile crime bill, among other measures.
But the President is trying to avoid a vote on another matter once central to his agenda. The House Speaker, Representative Newt Gingrich, said recently that he may bring up so called fast-track trade legislation this fall to give Mr. Clinton enhanced authority in negotiating trade deals.
Last year, the White House lost a bruising fight for the legislation, as Democrats deserted Mr. Clinton over fears of a backlash by organized labor and environmental groups against trade deals. The White House regards Mr. Gingrich's proposal as a political ploy, and today Mr. Clinton made clear that he was in no hurry to see such a vote.

HEADLINE: Duke Tests Nuclear Agency On Renewing Plant License

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS 

 BODY:
Duke Power, the nation's second-largest operator of nuclear plants, filed an application yesterday to extend the life of its biggest nuclear plant, which has been producing power for 25 years.
No utility has gone through the long, laborious and expensive process of having a license renewed by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, and the application by Duke Power, a unit of the Duke Energy Corporation of Charlotte, N.C., is seen as an initiative whose outcome could determine the future of nuclear energy in the United States. Duke's progress in getting the license renewed, which would enable it to operate the three-unit Oconee nuclear power station in western South Carolina another 20 years, will be watched by other utilities that must decide whether to seek renewal or decommission their nuclear plants and build nonnuclear operations to replace them. 
 There are big stakes involved for utilities, consumers and environmental groups.
For many utilities nuclear plants are the cheapest generators of electricity and have become more attractive as the industry deregulates.
Joe F. Colvin, president and chief executive of the Nuclear Energy Institute, an industry trade and lobbying group, said most nuclear plants could produce electricity at about 1.9 cents a kilowatt-hour, which is cheaper than natural gas plants, which average about 3 cents a kilowatt-hour.
"You can beat any competitor coming at you," Mr. Colvin said.
Some utilities have chosen to decommission their aging nuclear plants, which can be very costly. Building new plants is also expensive. Consumers would probably bear most of the cost through higher rates.
For environmentalists, closing older plants would reduce the amount of nuclear waste that must be disposed of. It could also result, however, in building more coal-fired plants, which emit carbon dioxide, a gas linked to global warming.
With so much riding on the outcome, Duke has given itself a great deal of lead time. By filing for a license renewal with the N.R.C. now, it hopes to complete the process in three years, well before its 40-year license to operate the three units of its Oconee Nuclear station expires in 2013.
Oconee, which was built in 1973, is capable of producing 2,538 megawatts of power. It has produced 24 percent of the electricity used by Duke's two million customers in North and South Carolina.
Michael S. Tuckman, the executive vice president for nuclear generation at Duke, said in a telephone conference yesterday that the plant would be a test case for the industry in how the licensing procedure would work and whether the standards set by the commission would be economical to meet.
He said that before filing for its application, Duke had asked other utilities to review and comment on it because they would have to decide whether to seek renewals as well. If Duke encounters difficulty in the renewal process, other utilities might decide not to try a similar effort.
In April, another utility, Baltimore Gas and Electric, filed to renew the license for its Calvert Cliffs nuclear plant, which can produce 1,875 megawatts of electricity.
And the largest operator of nuclear plants, Commonwealth Edison of Chicago, a subsidiary of the Unicom Corporation, said yesterday that it would sell its six coal-fired plants, which have a book value of about $1.1 billion, and use the money to improve the performance of its nuclear plants.
The N.R.C. oversees 107 working nuclear plants that produce 22 percent of the nation's electricity.
Duke has prepared for its renewal effort by consulting with the staff of the commission on how to measure the wear and durability of equipment in plants. Mr. Tuckman, however, said the process could extend another three years, through hearings, inspections and tests.
He said the utility had already spent $8 million preparing its filing, which will be delivered to the commission in Washington today. He said the utility expected to spend another $8 million before a decision was reached.
Mr. Tuckman added that the plant had been continually upgraded during its life and that the utility must demonstrate that it could be maintained in good condition another 20 years after its license expires in 2013.
The plant has generally had a solid safety record, but it had some accidents in recent years. A steam line ruptured in 1995 and seven workers were injured, several seriously. In 1990, a line became disconnected from a reactor head and radioactive water leaked but was kept and treated in the containment building.

HEADLINE: Union Pacific Fights Tougher Regulation

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON 

DATELINE: DALLAS, July 6

 BODY:
The Union Pacific Railroad, seeking to fend off demands for tougher Federal regulation, said today that congestion was easing, capacity expanding and competition with rival carriers intensifying.
And the company said that the whole railroad was now using a single computer system for the first time since its 1996 merger with Southern Pacific. 
 But many customers are hardly reassured. Executives of the Entergy Corporation, a major electricity provider in the South and Southwest, said the utility had not been able to get enough coal delivered to its power plant in White Bluff, Ark., because of congestion on the railroad's tracks. Several weeks ago, the utility came up with a roundabout solution. Entergy now transfers coal from trains to barges near Chester, Ill., and floats them down the Mississippi River and up the Arkansas River to its plant. But the company says it still cannot satisfy its demand for coal and has asked regulators to allow a rival of Union Pacific to share its tracks.
Critics of Union Pacific have until Wednesday to file complaints with the Surface Transportation Board, the principal railroad regulator. The board will decide whether the Government should do more to clean up railroad congestion around the Houston area and the Gulf of Mexico coast.
Under pressure from members of Congress and Union Pacific customers, the board, which is up for Congressional reauthorization this year, is also set to consider broader forms of relief for the railroad's customers and tighter control over the whole rail industry.
Senator Kay Bailey Hutchinson, a Texas Republican, has introduced a bill that would make it easier for shippers to win rate cases that come before the board in areas that lack competition. The bill would also allow the transportation board to double, to 18 months, the duration of emergency orders such as the one now requiring Union Pacific to share some rail yards and tracks. That order, already extended three times, expires next month.
While the chances that Congress will act before its summer recess are remote, such proposals are often meant to prod the Surface Transportation Board to act on its own.
The merger with Southern Pacific to form the nation's largest railroad caused what regulators called an unprecedented breakdown in rail traffic through the heart of the nation. Economists estimate that shippers have lost billions of dollars, and some customers, like Entergy, have sued for compensation. Union Pacific reached a settlement with DuPont, however, just last week.
Union Pacific says there is no need to continue the emergency order or impose any other rules. "I don't think that by any stretch of the imagination there's a congestion crisis on Union Pacific," said Arvid E. Roach, a partner at the law firm of Covington & Burling, which is responsible for presenting the company's case to the Surface Transportation Board.
Especially in Texas, the epicenter of a Union Pacific crisis that began last year, rail yards have opened up and traffic is flowing more smoothly, the company has said in its weekly reports.
But Jim Kollaer, president of the Greater Houston Partnership, a leading business group, said that refineries and chemical plants along the Gulf Coast were still having trouble moving their products. Larry Parsons, the United Transportation Union general chairman for much of Texas and Louisiana, confirmed the improvements while adding that conditions were not back to normal. But because the remedy has included a crash hiring program, he said that inadequately trained brakemen and conductors were working on the trains.
"They don't know one end of a boxcar from the other end," he said. "If you're a conductor and they send you one of these newbies out there, you've got to watch this kid to keep him from getting killed when he's running around."
Union Pacific has said that its new employees receive ample training, and Mr. Roach pointed to reduced accident rates this year. Last year, however, a series of crashes left 11 people dead.
The railroad's worst snarls are now in and around Nebraska, where coal trains, grain shipments and cars bound for ports converge on the nation's busiest tracks and its busiest yard, in North Platte. In its latest reports, Union Pacific blames track maintenance and the construction of new tracks and sidings.
Checks with several utilities indicated that Union Pacific's problems do not appear to be a factor in power shortages around the Midwest. Entergy, however, has said it has had to switch from coal to other fuels or buy power from other producers. Union Pacific says it is shipping only about 75 percent of the coal it has committed to carry, but this share represents a gain from about 50 percent in January.
The transition to a single computer system for the entire railroad has contributed to the tie-ups. Computers that could not talk to each other sometimes lost track of shipments altogether. The railroad said it delayed the final stage of its computer integration, on the West Coast, from May 1 to July 1, adding hundreds of technicians to help with the transition.
While many customers have said the merger squelched competition, Union Pacific has said it left two stronger competitors throughout the Western United States. In the merger, it ceded or shared some routes with Burlington Northern Santa Fe.
"Monopolists earn monopoly profits," Mr. Roach added. "This company has had losses for three quarters." The losses have resulted from lost traffic and new investments to expand and improve the rail system.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Worries Over Japan and U.S. Send Treasury Prices Higher

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Concerns about Japan and signs of a slowdown in the United States sent Treasury prices higher yesterday.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 12/32, to 107 31/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 5.57 percent, from 5.60 percent Thursday, matching the low set on June 15 -- the lowest it has been since the Government began regular sales of securities in 1977. 
 Most of yesterday's gains came from overnight weakness in the Japanese yen compared with the dollar, amid speculation that Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto of Japan was not promising permanent tax cuts. Robert Pugliese, senior vice president and director of the fixed-income department at the J. W. Genesis Financial Corporation in Boca Raton, Fla., called yesterday's session extremely quiet with light trading after the long July 4 holiday.
"The bias is toward higher prices," he said, "especially with all the positive information about inflation. The market's positive tone has a lot to do with foreign buying and the strength of dollar.
"Fundamentally the market is strong, and many believe there are more than a half-dozen reasons why the market will continue to do well."
Only about $32.9 billion of bills, notes and bonds were traded by the major brokerage firms by late in the day, down 35.1 percent from the average Monday during the third quarter of 1997, according to Govpx, the bond pricing service.
Yesterday's regular weekly bill auction was uneventful, with the average rate for a new three-month bill 4.960 percent and 5.010 percent for a new six-month bill.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Black Pioneer Answers the Call;
Detroit Entrepreneur Sees 'Sleeper' Market in Namibia

BYLINE: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr. 

DATELINE: WINDHOEK, Namibia

 BODY:
This windswept capital in the Namibian desert is not the kind of arena where Michael Jackson normally plays. And 500 buttoned-down executives and finance ministers talking tariffs are not his usual audience. But the singer came in May, striding up a conference room aisle in full fedora, lipstick and Sgt. Pepper jacket, with a pushy entourage trailing along, to give a quick speech deploring "the plight of the children of the universe."
It ended: "My new business partner, Don Barden, and I are going to be putting our money where our mouths are. We're going to be looking at global investments that will bring economic development to people and improvement to the lives of children." 
 Getting the Gloved One to declare himself the Global One -- and getting the staid World Economic Forum to make that its kickoff speech here at one of its many regional meetings -- was one of the quirkiest public relations coups southern Africa has ever seen. But the versatile entrepreneur who managed it has some interesting quirks himself.
Donald H. Barden, 54, is one of America's wealthiest black executives. He is the founder of a privately held conglomerate, the Barden Companies, based in Detroit, which had estimated sales last year of $110 million and was No. 14 on Black Enterprise magazine's 1998 list of 100 biggest black-owned industrial/service companies. Mr. Barden is also one of a tiny few who have taken up a challenge thrown down to African-American entrepreneurs by Ronald H. Brown, the late Commerce Secretary: Come back to Africa and build a business.
Some might think Mr. Barden has a fatal attraction for risk. He does not see it that way.
"This market is a real sleeper," he said during a joint interview with Mr. Jackson in a small office in his Windhoek car-rebuilding plant. "Once the free-market system permeates, this continent will be one of the world's most dynamic markets."
Until recently, most of Mr. Barden's risks were confined to the American Midwest. He grew up as one of 13 siblings in Inkster, Mich., outside Detroit. He was captain of his high school basketball and football teams, but had to drop out of Central State University in Ohio in 1963 because he could not afford the tuition. Living with a big brother in Lorain, Ohio, he was a mover and a laborer before opening a record store, then starting a label and venturing into public relations.
That was all before he, by chance, heard that a military recruiting station near his office was looking for new space. Mr. Barden helped it find a spot, and in that switch to real estate he finally began to make some real money.
Mr. Barden later founded The Lorain County Times, a weekly, sat on the Lorain City Council and became a television anchorman, where he realized the profit potential in cable TV. In 1983, after wiring some small Michigan towns, he won the right to wire 375,000 Detroit households in partnership with a Canadian cable company.
Mr. Barden sold his share of the cable TV business for $105 million in 1994. He now owns five Illinois radio stations, an Arizona software company and an Ohio real estate company that has built jails and fancy suburbs. In 1995, he entered the gaming industry; his riverboat, the Majestic Star of Gary, Ind., is America's first black-owned casino.
Mr. Barden doesn't shy from fights. In 1995, he took on Donald J. Trump, publicly accusing him of "extortion" for demanding $25 million as part of a deal to share a wharf site in Gary. Nor is he shy about sometimes using race to his advantage. He did so to win the Detroit cable franchise, and last year he accused the city's mayor of failing blacks and native sons by denying him a casino license.
At first glance, Mr. Barden's entry into Africa seems counterintuitive. He chose Namibia, a country of only 1.7 million people, instead of the obvious place, South Africa, with its higher income and its population of 40 million. On top of that, Mr. Barden is going into businesses he has never been in before: a General Motors dealership and sales of canned food, drinks and mattresses. And his target markets include some of the poorest, most forgotten people in the world: the suffering millions of war-torn Angola and Congo, the former Zaire.
But there is method to his seeming madness. As Mr. Barden is quick to point out, Namibia has excellent roads, railways and phones, a benign if arid climate and a deep-water port at Walvis Bay. It has had eight years of democratic government and a currency linked to the relatively stable South African rand. And, most important, little Namibia really, really wants him.
Mr. Barden's connection with the country began in 1989, when he held a cocktail party at his home for the ambassador of the South West Africa People's Organization, the movement fighting to liberate the country from South African rule. The movement succeeded in 1990, and six years later he invited President Sam Nujoma to Detroit and arranged a tour of a General Motors plant. G.M. was looking for a route back into southern Africa, and Namibia was interested -- but only if it got an assembly plant. The market was too small for G.M. to bother with, but Mr. Barden suggested splitting the difference: if the Namibian Government would buy 800 G.M. vehicles through him, he would build a plant to convert them to right-hand drive.
That appealed perfectly to one of the pet peeves of Mr. Nujoma, a sometimes cranky, sometimes jovial former guerrilla: his resentment of South Africa. White rule is gone, but South African corporations still dominate the regional customs union, and the high tariffs set to protect their Volkswagen, BMW, Mercedes and Toyota local assembly plants make cars in the whole subregion very pricey.
Kano Audley Smith, managing director of the Namibian Barden operations, said he could import G.M. cars, pay the duty, convert them and still charge $1,000 to $18,000 less than a comparable model from South Africa. "If they were to price their vehicles realistically, we'd be in trouble," he said.
When a reporter questioned the deal with Mr. Barden at a recent news conference, President Nujoma cut her off, saying testily: "We want American products, not ones from those whites in South Africa. We don't want to give our money back to white colonials. The cars are cheaper, too -- you can go check."
About 125 pickups, police cars and school buses have already been delivered.
Mr. Barden says he has spent about $16 million to put together the Windhoek plant and to train workers. But the car operation is merely a foot in the African door, he says. He and Mr. Jackson envision "investments eventually in the hundreds of millions," and are particularly looking for casinos, resorts and theme parks. South Africa's three major cities are granting casino licenses right now.
"We'll go 50-50 on everything," said Mr. Jackson, who once looked into buying Sun City, the Indiana Jones-style casino resort complex built in South Africa by Sol Kerzner, the South African casino magnate.
Mr. Jackson and Mr. Barden were a little vague on how that would help children, but Mr. Barden recovered, saying, "If you're involved in creating wealth, it puts you in a position to help the world." Because Mr. Jackson is a role model, he added, his focusing on business would encourage children to grow up and do the same, leading to economic empowerment.
And there is no disputing, for all the controversy that has surrounded Mr. Jackson, that he is indeed a role model for children. The crowds that came out to see him even in tiny Namibia were bigger than any crowds here ever before, including at independence.
Mr. Barden said their next investment would be warehouses in a new tax-free zone on the Angolan border. Namibia may be tiny, but there are millions of people in Angola, the former Zaire and western Zambia with little access to goods because central African roads are atrocious.
Asked if he was crazy to seek out these markets -- Zaire had a fierce civil war last year and a low-intensity war in Angola has dragged on for 24 years -- Mr. Barden said: "You think that if they have a civil war, they're going to stop coming across the border to buy goods? They still have to have food, mattresses, stereos, refrigerators and beer, don't they? And they pay in diamonds -- that is, they pay in cash they got from diamonds. In U.S. dollars. That's pretty attractive."
Namibians back him up on that. Most Angolans are poor, but "we're used to seeing Angolans in the oil and diamond business driving into Namibia in big U.S. cars to shop," said Philip H. Namundjebo, an official in Namibia's offshore development agency.
By investing in Africa, Mr. Barden and Mr. Jackson have become a rare breed. Lots of American corporations send black executives to Africa, but few black-owned companies have invested here.
"He's a pioneer," acknowledged Millard W. Arnold, head of the United States Commerce Department's Johannesburg office. "He's been fairly astute in maximizing an opportunity in a country like Namibia."
Only a few other black-owned companies came. Ebony magazine has a South African edition, for example, but is not widely available.
With a 121 percent sales increase in 1997, Carson Holdings, based in Johannesburg, which makes Dark and Lovely and Let's Jam hair products, is doing better in Africa than its parent, Carson Inc., is in the United States. It is run by Malcolm Yesner, a white Zambian, but owned by an investment group headed by Roy Keith, a black American.
Procter Houston, another American, who arrived in 1995 to distribute institutional furniture and says he is doing about $1.5 million in sales a year, said a "second wave" of black entrepreneurs was landing in southern Africa now. He came out of curiosity about the new Government, he said, and found an amenable environment. The newcomers, mostly engineers and computer specialists, began arriving in the last year, partly thanks to Mr. Arnold's efforts, he said.
Some black investors, however, have been badly stung. Pepsi South Africa, for example, which drew in celebrity investors like Whitney Houston, Bill Cosby and Johnnie Cochran, just could not make inroads into Coca-Cola's market dominance, and closed in a year.
Mr. Barden seems unworried.
"We're excited about being here because Africa is our homeland," he said. "But we don't come in doing a lot of talk. This isn't the first time I've built a building, or a new business. We're here to get a job done, and make money."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Business Roots -- Donald H. Barden, left, one of America's leading black entrepreneurs, has teamed with the singer Michael Jackson to do business in Africa. Their first ventures are in Nambia - a relatively poor country of 1.7 million people with foreign trade of only about $2.5 billion a year. But Mr. Barden sees Namibia as a tax-free base to deal in goods for war-torn Angola, the former Zaire and western Zambia. (Jim Groblem for The New York Times)
