HEADLINE: Gay Rights Movement Meets Big Resistance in S. Carolina

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK 

DATELINE: COLUMBIA, S.C.

 BODY:
It was not by accident that the first shot of the Civil War was fired in this tradition-bound state, where few things are viewed so seriously as an assault on the inherited culture. It is a place where lawmakers still scoff at suggestions that the Confederate battle flag be removed from the Capitol dome and where only a Federal court order enabled women to enroll at the Citadel.
These days, with increasing vigor, the resistance to change extends to another perceived threat: homosexuality. For more than two years, leaders of this state's churches, governments and schools have erected barrier after barrier against what many view as a cultural invasion that offends cherished values. 
 In an election year when there is little economic discontent, the Senate majority leader, Trent Lott, Republican of Mississippi, brought new focus to the politics of morality when he declared in a television interview in June that homosexuality is a sin. But if Mr. Lott was trying to escalate a rhetorical war on homosexuality, the battle was joined some time ago here in South Carolina.
It began in May 1996, when the Greenville County Council adopted a resolution declaring homosexuality incompatible with community standards. The decision, on a vote of 9 to 3, prompted organizers of the run carrying the Olympic torch to Atlanta to shelter the flame in a van as it moved through the county.
Last year Republican Party leaders in Charleston County pressured the county prosecutor, David P. Schwacke, also a Republican, to disclose that he is gay by publicly accusing him of downloading pornography and soliciting gay sex on his office computer. In June, a grand jury chose not to indict Mr. Schwacke, who is divorced from his wife of 14 years, and he apologized to his constituents for "the mistakes in my personal life."
And this year the Mayor of Myrtle Beach joined business and religious leaders in opposing a gay-pride rally there, a high school principal canceled a free concert by the Indigo Girls, at least partly because parents complained that the rock singers, Amy Ray and Emily Saliers, are lesbians, and a Republican candidate for state agriculture commissioner vowed to protect the family farm from the "homosexual movement."
While a recent report by the National Gay and Lesbian Task Force asserts that a growing majority of Americans support equality for homosexuals, gay rights leaders acknowledge that South Carolina may be a microcosm of much of non-urban America. The state is inherently conservative in its politics, religion and social practices, and many here regard the increasing openness of gay life as emblematic of a broader moral decay.
"It's not just homosexuality," said the Rev. Steve R. Hubbard, a 37-year-old Baptist minister from Myrtle Beach who organized a family-values coalition in response to this year's gay-pride rally. "We've got a 60 percent divorce rate. We've got kids killing kids in our schools. We've got gambling that is destroying families. And in the end, what is always hurt is the traditional family."
But gay rights leaders, political scientists and government officials also agree that a distinct confluence of factors has contributed to the rawness of gay rights conflicts here: the pervasiveness of fundamentalist Christianity, which interprets scriptural warnings against homosexuality as God-given truth; the ties between religious conservatives and the state's surging Republican Party; the increasing activism of the state's gay community; the South's history of institutionalized bigotry, and the state's resistance to cultural change, racial and otherwise.
"People here perceive themselves on the defensive, defending their culture, their religion, their communities, against outside forces," said Charles W. Dunn, a political scientist at Clemson University.
South Carolina's gay leaders say homosexuals have been energized by the attacks, with more living openly and more taking an active stand on political issues. Gay rights organizations have been established in all the state's major cities. The gay-pride march in Myrtle Beach this year, the ninth annual such event in the state, attracted an estimated total of 5,000 to 8,000 people.
Gay leaders depict their victimization as in keeping with a legacy of Southern hate. While public expressions of racism are no longer acceptable in the region, they say, there is no such taboo against homophobia.
"There may be discrimination against gays and lesbians everywhere, but here the gay-baiting is so open," said Harriet D. Hancock, a mother of three, including a gay son, and co-chairwoman of the South Carolina chapter of Parents, Families and Friends of Lesbians and Gays. "It used to be race-baiting. Now it's gay-baiting."
Tony Snell, co-chairman of the South Carolina Gay and Lesbian Pride Movement, which has a mailing list of 8,000 to 10,000, said the state's homosexuals were "the scapegoat du jour."
"They've sent a message here," Mr. Snell said of antigay forces, "that it's O.K. to hate."
But church leaders depict their message as one of hate for the sin and love for the sinner.
Like many in the family-values movement, the Rev. Stan Y. Craig, pastor of Choice Hills Baptist Church in Greenville and an organizer of his city's Citizens for Traditional Family Values, cites the Bible as the foundation of his approach to gay issues. Mr. Craig, a beefy, white-haired Vietnam veteran who buffs his dress shoes to a reflective sheen, said he believed that homosexuality was "demonic" and "a stench in the nostrils of God." His organization's blue and white placards proclaim that homosexuality is "Satan's plot for our children."
Wade C. Cleveland, one of the three members of the Greenville County Council who opposed its resolution against homosexuality, said that homophobia might not be more prevalent in South Carolina than elsewhere but that it was perhaps more virulent, "because we get it so honestly from the Bible."
Mr. Snell and Ms. Hancock argue that fundamentalist zeal has influenced policy and political rhetoric because of Republican politicians' dependence on the votes of religious conservatives. The state Republican Party is certain enough of its constituents' views on homosexuality that it does not even poll on the issue.
"It would be like asking everybody if they're for free ice cream," said Trey Walker, a party spokesman.
Recent elections here have shown that the most socially conservative candidate does not always win Republican primaries. That said, in the last 14 months Gov. David Beasley, Lieut. Gov. Robert Lee Peeler, Attorney General Charlie Condon and United States Representative Bob Inglis, who is running this year to take a Senate seat away from Ernest F. Hollings, have all attended family-values rallies that were organized in response to gay rights marches.
In the Senate race, the Republican state chairman, Henry D. McMaster, has already derided Mr. Hollings's sponsorship of a 1983 bill to protect homosexuals from employment discrimination. At the Republican state convention in May, David C. Eckstrom, who later won the party's nomination for state education superintendent, spent more than a third of his speech promoting his support for the cancellation of the Indigo Girls concert, at Irmo High School, near Columbia.
"The time has come to take a stand," said Mr. Eckstrom, who is chairman of the school board that governs Irmo High. "If the Indigo Girls got their feelings hurt, that's too bad."
Taking the political use of gay issues a step farther, Jim Gordon, a Republican candidate for state agriculture commissioner, declared recently that "we can't have farming based on Bob and Bob being married and a new definition of marriage." Mr. Gordon won 31 percent of the vote in a three-way primary on June 9, finishing second to the incumbent.
Not surprisingly, gay rights leaders find much wanting in South Carolina's legal code. The state is one of 14 that outlaw sodomy, both homosexual and heterosexual, according to the National Gay and Lesbian Task Force. It is also one of 29 states with laws prohibiting same-sex marriages.
When the Legislature banned same-sex marriages in 1996, Governor Beasley said that "America is in a moral meltdown today because its leaders, under pressure from special-interest groups, want to always appear tolerant."
South Carolina is also one of nine states without a hate-crime law of any kind. After a racial shooting in 1997, Attorney General Condon proposed hate-crime legislation that would have assigned special penalties to those convicted of crimes motivated by racial bigotry. But when lawmakers introduced a competing bill that would have expanded the definition of a hate crime to include bias attacks against women and homosexuals, Mr. Condon dropped his support, saying it would be impossible to gain passage of such legislation.
Some gay leaders say Mr. Condon and other officeholders have contributed to a climate that encourages antigay violence. Twice in the last seven months, they note, a lesbian named Regan Wolf has been brutally whipped at her home near Lancaster, S.C. Both times Ms. Wolf was knocked unconscious and strung up spread-eagled on a porch. In the first incident, a message was left in spray paint on the steps: "Jesus weren't born for you, faggot." State and local law-enforcement officials have made no arrests and decline to say whether they regard the attacks as homophobic.
Many of those leading the fight against gay rights make clear that they feel their state and their values are under siege.
Mr. Craig, the Greenville minister, said he had grown increasingly disturbed as President Clinton liberalized the nation's policy on homosexuals in the military, as television sitcoms began to feature openly gay characters and as gay and lesbian marchers walked through Greenville last year.
"What is about to happen in Greenville has already happened in places like San Francisco and New York City," Mr. Craig said. "We really believe this is the last bastion of moral decency left in America."
The same sentiment led Mark S. McBride, a City Councilman in Myrtle Beach, to speak out last year against the opening of a gay bar in the resort town's gaudy boardwalk area. The bar, he said, would not blend with the family-friendly image that Myrtle Beach has long tried to promote.
His stand against the bar gave Mr. McBride a platform from which to run for mayor, and he narrowly defeated a longtime incumbent in November. In response, the state's gay-pride movement announced that it would hold its May 1998 march in Myrtle Beach. Mr. McBride again made his displeasure known, and the city's largest developer, the Burroughs & Chapin Company, killed plans by several nightclubs in one of its developments to hold an outdoor concert by the Village People on the weekend of the march.
"We were not going to allow our company's facilities to be used to further a cause that we felt was a negative influence on our community," said Douglas P. Wendel, the company's president.
Although the gay bar opened and the march was held (Mr. McBride sent his wife and two children to Greenville for the weekend), the 34-year-old Mayor still hopes to preserve the traditional-family orientation of his town.
"What we've built ourselves on over the last 60 years is the traditional-family base," he said. "People don't come here to be subjugated to all the progressiveness, all the sophistication, all the enlightenment of big-city life."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Harriet D. Hancock and Tony Snell, above, standing in the front yard of one manifestation of gay pride in South Carolina: a community center in Columbia that does not hide what it is. At left, the Rev. Stan Y. Craig of Greenville, who considers homosexuality "a stench in the nostrils of God." (Kim Truett for The New York Times)

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1771 words

HEADLINE: Three Mile Island: Cleaned Up, and for Sale

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ 

DATELINE: LONDONDERRY TOWNSHIP, Pa.

 BODY:
With a name that most people equate with nuclear disaster, Three Mile Island might not seem to be choice real estate.
But GPU Inc., which owns the plant on an island in the Susquehanna River here, is convinced it can do something that no other company in the country has done: sell a used nuclear reactor. 
 "We've been working on its curb appeal," said Jim Langenbach, the site director, sounding a little like a homeowner who just added a new coat of paint before an open house. "Pulling weeds, picking up trash, planting flowers. The real reality has nothing to do with that, but it doesn't hurt."
Almost 20 years have passed since warning sirens blared, schools closed and more than 100,000 residents fled central Pennsylvania, afraid of radiation poisoning from the most serious nuclear power plant accident in the United States.
While the fear has faded, employees here say that when people find out where they work, they are still asked whether they glow in the dark. And a visitors center attracts thousands of people every year to its observation deck to peer across the muddy Susquehanna River at the hourglass-shaped cooling towers.
Yet in the next month, the fortunes of Three Mile Island, whose mistakes shook public confidence in the nuclear power industry, could signal its ability to survive the worst adversity. At a time when many have predicted that nuclear power will not be able to compete in the increasingly deregulated electricity market, a sale of the remaining operating unit on Three Mile Island would show that one company, anyway, thinks atomic energy can turn a profit -- for the right price.
GPU, based in Parsippany, N.J., has had the reactor actively on the block since December. Fred D. Hafer, the company's chairman and chief executive, said in June that he had been negotiating for months with a prospective buyer, which he declined to identify, and expected to announce a deal by the end of July. Up for sale is just Unit 1, which was not involved in the March 1979 accident. Not for sale is the hulk of Unit 2, from which tons of radioactive rubble were removed after a partial meltdown of its core and which will never produce electricity again.
Mr. Hafer also hopes to sell the Oyster Creek nuclear plant in Forked River, N.J., in the same deal.
A dozen people who follow the industry, including analysts and nuclear critics, say that the Peco Energy Company of Philadelphia, which already operates two nuclear plants, both in Pennsylvania, is the most likely buyer. Peco recently established a joint venture with British Energy to acquire nuclear plants.
"We believe that we can build an even greater competitive advantage by grouping nuclear units to exploit economy of scale," said Jim Waddington, a Peco spokesman, who declined to comment on whether the company would buy Three Mile Island. Jerry Rainey, who heads Peco's nuclear division, added, "I think you'll see a deal announced in 1998," though he also refused to identify the plants that would be involved.
To be sure, these are complicated deals, and nothing is certain until a contract is signed, especially price. Unit 1 is reportedly worth $600 million, but several factors must be weighed, including determining responsibility for the ultimate costs of taking the unit out of service. And even if an agreement is reached, it would have to be approved by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission and state officials.
Nonetheless, the plant is buzzing with the possibility of a takeover, officials of nearby towns have been notified that a change may occur, and Mr. Langenbach said he already had transition plans on his desk.
If the sale comes to pass, Mr. Hafer will have succeeded where others have failed.
Over the last few years, a spate of troubled reactors have been put on the market, but there have been no takers. The owners of one plant, Maine Yankee in Wiscasset, even created a Web page (www.buynuclear.com), complete with color photographs, to promote its sale, but to no avail. The plant was retired, though its equipment is still for sale.
GPU was prompted to divest itself of its nuclear operations by a new law in Pennsylvania that ends the guaranteed rate structure that benefited utility monopolies.
It has opted to get out of the business of generating electricity -- from reactors and all other sources -- and instead concentrate on transmission.
As more states adopt deregulation laws, other companies are likely to follow suit. Connecticut, for instance, passed an electric deregulation law earlier this year that requires the state's largest power company, Northeast Utilities, to try to auction off its nuclear reactors by 2004.
Still, analysts say there are likely to be more sellers than buyers, and even some companies that have successfully managed nuclear plants are wary about adding more.
"We are not looking to increase our nuclear exposure," said Randy Wheeless, a spokesman for the Duke Energy Corporation of Charlotte, N.C., which operates seven reactors. "There's a lot of uncertainty about how nuclear will be treated in a deregulated environment. From our standpoint, it may be best to sit and let those questions be answered." Duke, however, hopes to extend the useful life of existing plants well into the next century.
The idea that someone would want to buy Three Mile Island has some local people reeling.
"I had customers who were just sitting here laughing about it," said Alma Zeager, 42, the owner of Village Homestead, a nearby restaurant. "I still don't think it's safe, but I don't want to move to Philly."
But what makes the deal appear promising is that many think that Unit 1 of Three Mile Island is among the best-run reactors in the world. As company executives are at pains to point out, there are, in a sense, two Three Mile Islands, the bad one of 1979 and the good one of today.
Only a football field away from Unit 2, which will never operate again, Unit 1 last year completed a continuous run of 616 days and 23 hours, a world record for uninterrupted operation of a light-water nuclear reactor, the type in commercial use in the United States.
While many of the 107 reactors now operating in the United States are unable to produce electricity as inexpensively as plants powered by gas, coal and oil, Unit 1 is an example of how nuclear power can compete.
GPU has projected that any power company that has operating costs of more than 3 cents a kilowatt-hour in the New Jersey, Pennsylvania and Maryland market will be unable to survive, and Unit 1 comes in at 2.5 cents. That is in stark contrast to Oyster Creek, for instance, which the company estimates has a cost of 3.7 cents a kilowatt-hour.
"This unit has been one of the industry's best performers," said Kit Konolige, an analyst at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. David A. Lochbaum, a nuclear engineer with the Union of Concerned Scientists, said, "It is very competitive."
Plant workers and company executives say that the industry as a whole, and Unit 1 in particular, learned valuable lessons from the accident at Unit 2.
The accident occurred when operators did not close a pressure-relief valve, allowing a million gallons of cooling water to escape and causing the radioactive core to reach 5,000 degrees. If operators had closed the valve and turned on an emergency cooling system, the accident could have been averted.
The plant had been operating only a few months before the accident, and workers did not comprehend what was happening. They mistakenly thought that a light on the control panel meant the pressure-relief valve was shut.
Advocates for nuclear power contend that this mistake would not be made today. They say that the industry now requires more training, that every reactor has an on-site simulator for practice, that the number of control room workers has increased, that management is required to be more actively involved in daily operations and that Federal regulators have stepped up their oversight.
And if Unit 1 is sold, the deal will confirm the belief of many workers that they have overcome the past. "We were a joke in the industry," said Dave McCurdy, a maintenance supervisor for 29 years. "This would show that we've come back."
Already there are people who once fought to close the plant who now support it. "I've got to be fair about it," Mayor Stephen R. Reed of Harrisburg said. "The plant has made some major advances."
Indeed, Unit 1 was closed six years as the plant revamped operations.
But Eric Epstein of Three Mile Island Alert, an anti-nuclear group, said that improvements were overstated. He noted that only last year, the N.R.C. fined GPU $210,000 for a string of violations, including inadequate engineering designs and poor implementation of emergency preparedness programs.
Still, the N.R.C. has an overall favorable impression of Unit 1. "If you get beyond the image that so many members of the public have," said Neil A. Sheehan, an N.R.C. spokesman, "its performance has been pretty successful."
The idea that the reactor could be sold to Peco troubles Mr. Epstein because of that company's past. In 1987, Federal regulators shut down Peco's Peach Bottom nuclear plant in Delta, Pa., because operators were found sleeping in the control room.
Since then, Peco has overhauled its operations, becoming, according to analysts, a leader in the industry. Peach Bottom was restarted in 1989, and this year it and Peco's other nuclear plant, in Limerick, received Power magazine's Powerplant Award, marking them as among the nation's best-managed reactors.
But Mr. Epstein noted that Peco was fined $55,000 in June by the N.R.C. because scraps of netlike nylon cloth, used for maintenance, were discovered in an emergency cooling pump at Peach Bottom that could have hindered its use in an accident.
A sale of Three Mile Island to Peco, Mr. Epstein said, would be like "transferring the title from the Three Stooges to the Marx Brothers." He said the true lesson of Three Mile Island had yet to be learned: no nuclear plant, he contends, can be operated safely.
Visitors at the observation deck gift shop one recent afternoon did not seem troubled by any of this as they considered buying Three Mile Island T-shirts, mugs and other souvenirs.
Bill Hollinger, who works in the visitors center, said he sees lots of tourists from abroad and that Europeans are surprised they can get so close to the accident site. Schoolchildren sometimes even stand at the bottom of the defunct cooling towers and shout upward to create an echo.
The visitors, he said, "can't believe that this is where it happened."

A chronology of events at Three Mile Island, site of the worst nuclear power plant accident in the United States.
 
Sept. 1974 -- First power plant on island begins operation.'
 
Dec. 1978 -- Unit 2 begins operation.
 
PUB-DATE: March 28, 1979
 
Oct. 1985 -- Unit 1 is restarted and workers begin removing damaged fuel from Unit 2.
 
Jan. 1990 -- Last of 300,000 pounds of damaged fuel is removed from Unit 2.
 
Dec. 1993 -- Decontamination work on Unit 2 is completed, clearing the way for it to be permanently entombed.
 
May 1997 -- Unit 1 completes 616 days, 23 hours of continuous operation, setting a world record.
 
Dec. 1997 -- GPU, the utility that runs Three Mile Island, says that it is in negotiations to sell Unit 1.
 
(Sources: GPU Inc.; Nuclear Regulatory Commission)

HEADLINE: Do Cyprus Arms Threaten NATO?

 BODY:

To the Editor:
William Safire (column, July 2) believes that if Cyprus acquires Russian anti-aircraft missiles, this will destabilize the region and threaten Turkey. The problem is that Cyprus has no air force and is bound to seek some form of air defense system. 
 The solution is for the United States to lift its unofficial arms embargo on Cyprus and sell the Cypriots the Patriot theater defense missile system. The United States would thereby increase its arms exports without the embarrassment of selling to a dictatorship while also depriving the Russians of a sale. The Greek Cypriots would have the air defense they crave. Finally, the Turkish air force would have nothing to fear from the inaccurate Patriots -- given their widely reported ineffectiveness against Iraqi Scuds in the Persian Gulf war.
 
ANDREW APOSTOLOU
Athens, July 2, 1998

HEADLINE: Workers at Rally Should Fear for Jobs

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Your July 2 editorial "Labor's Abuse of the City" chastised the building trades unions for paralyzing Manhattan and roughing up civilians and the police in a June 30 rally. I suggest you look at why so many workers took to the streets. Workers are frustrated and scared because their living standard has been declining since 1973. 
 Even with this booming economy, workers' wages are still lagging. Union construction workers feel especially anxious, because nonunion construction companies, which pay their workers less, are stealing their jobs. Nonunion contractors bid and win projects based on substandard wages and poor working conditions, not management skills.
 
WILLIAM CORLEY
Milton, Mass., July 3, 1998
 
The writer is an organizer for Local 103, International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers.

HEADLINE: Workers at Rally Should Fear for Jobs

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "The Balloon That Refuses to Be Popped" (Business Day, July 1): Standard economic theory predicts that given today's low unemployment and "Asian-flu" economy, the stock market should have taken a hit by now. Contradicting that theory, the market remains near all-time highs. 
 The market remains high because labor lacks political power. After two decades of anti-union assaults worldwide, labor has lost the ability to drive up wages in a low-unemployment economy. And as long as wages are kept in check, stock prices will remain high. Only when labor wins wage increases and prevents job cutbacks will stock prices start to decline. The current strike at General Motors as well as the recent rally of an estimated 40,000 New York construction workers signal that labor is rediscovering its power.
If so, lower stock prices are on the horizon.
 
CHRISTOPHER CHERNEY
Berkeley, Calif., July 1, 1998

HEADLINE: World News Briefs;
U.S. Confident on Funds For Oil for North Korea

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 6

 BODY:
The United States said today that it had not raised enough money to supply North Korea with oil in return for freezing its nuclear program, but expressed confidence that the money would be found.
The State Department said it was talking to Congress and lobbying other countries for the money to provide North Korea with the 550,000 tons of heavy fuel oil that it was promised every year under an accord in 1994. The pact obligated North Korea to shut old graphite-moderated nuclear reactors that the United States said could produce fuel for nuclear weapons. 
 A new consortium, the Korean Peninsula Energy Development Organization, was to have built light-water reactors in North Korea that are less subject to nuclear proliferation, as well as supplying the oil.
A State Department spokesman, James P. Rubin, said the consortium had delivered this year 168,000 tons of oil, with an additional 73,000 to be sent this month. The Administration, Mr. Rubin said, is consulting Congress about extra financing to buy oil and had come up with $5 million on top of $30 million that it had previously agreed to provide.
The European Union, Mr. Rubin said, is expected to contribute $16 million to help the consortium cover its debt for past purchases.

HEADLINE: At Long Last, Candidate for Governor Picks a Running Mate

BYLINE: By MIKE ALLEN 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, July 6

 BODY:
Ending a search so prolonged and public that it threatened to become an embarrassment to her Connecticut gubernatorial campaign, Representative Barbara B. Kennelly plans to announce Tuesday that she has chosen a former state legislator as her running mate.
Joseph D. Courtney, 45, a lawyer who retired from the State House of Representatives in 1994, agreed this afternoon to be the Democratic candidate for lieutenant governor, an aide to Mrs. Kennelly said. They are to make the announcement jointly on Tuesday in Mr. Courtney's hometown of Vernon, east of Hartford, and then greet voters at a diner, the aide said. 
 In an effort to retain an element of surprise about her selection, Mrs. Kennelly confirmed today that she had made her decision but would not say where she would announce it.
Mrs. Kennelly, who is retaining her seat in Congress while she campaigns, has trailed Gov. John G. Rowland, a Republican who is seeking a second term, in polls and fund-raising. Her campaign staff had made overtures about the second slot on the ticket to several prominent Connecticut Democrats, and even a few obscure local officials. All took themselves out of the running.
Her problem became such an open secret that last week a political column in The Hartford Courant carried the headline, "Wanted: Running Mate for Kennelly. Send Resumes."
Mr. Courtney, who was elected to the Legislature four times, was House co-chairman of the Human Services Committee and later House co-chairman of the Public Health Committee. He is known for being liberal but practical, and received high marks for deft handling of cuts to state programs for the poor, elderly and disabled during the recession of the early 1990's.
But he brings Mrs. Kennelly's ticket none of the geographic diversity that candidates often seek in a running mate. Vernon is just 13 miles from Hartford, where Mrs. Kennelly is a lifelong resident.
In Connecticut, voters choose a Governor and a Lieutenant Governor as a pair. The current Lieutenant Governor, M. Jodi Rell, will seek re-election with Mr. Rowland.
Party regulars had urged Mrs. Kennelly to pick a running mate from Fairfield County, home of many wealthy Democrats, or the New Haven area, which is heavily populated. She had settled on a well-known Fairfield County resident, Gene F. Eriquez, who is the Mayor of Danbury, but he developed a kidney ailment last month and withdrew his name from consideration. Mrs. Kennelly's supporters were especially disappointed because Mr. Eriquez, an Italian-American, would have brought ethnic diversity to the ticket.
Nevertheless, party officials, who said they insisted on anonymity because they did not want to spoil Tuesday's announcement, said they were enthusiastic about the choice because Mr. Courtney's legislative experience would help the ticket attack Mr. Rowland's administration for its record on education, the environment and public health.

HEADLINE: After Legal Odyssey, Man Faces 2d Trial in Officer's Death

BYLINE: By SUSAN SACHS 

 BODY:
Many of his alibi witnesses are dead, crucial evidence has been lost and the police officers who arrested him have long since retired. But after a 22-year legal odyssey that has taken him from courtroom to prison to freedom and back again, Vincent James Landano is to go on trial again today for a murder he has consistently maintained he never committed.
Mr. Landano is charged with shooting a Newark police officer, John Snow, during the robbery of a check-cashing office in Kearny, N.J., in August 1976. As he has since he was arrested shortly after the murder, he insists that he was framed and that he was never anywhere near the scene of the crime. 
 Convicted of murder in 1977, Mr. Landano served nearly 13 years of a life sentence before he was ordered released by a Federal judge who ruled that the prosecution had suppressed evidence that might have persuaded the jury to acquit him.
Now a graying 58-year-old with a wife, Camille; a little dog named Sparky; a new house in Manville, and a steady job as a paralegal, Mr. Landano said he expected to be vindicated and regain control over his life. "I've been fighting for 22 years -- half of my life -- and I'll be damned if they are going to beat me," he vowed. "I'm not going into it to lose."
Since Mr. Landano was freed in 1989, a series of Hudson County prosecutors have continued to pursue him, maintaining in court hearing after court hearing that there was convincing eyewitness and physical evidence of his guilt.
The "interests of justice and fair play will be best served" by presenting the evidence again to a grand jury, Donald Gardner, an assistant county prosecutor, said in early 1996. Later that year, a grand jury indicted Mr. Landano once again.
The case will be heard by Judge Shirley A. Tolentino of Superior Court in Jersey City, in a small windowed courtroom where for the last month lawyers have toiled to find jurors with no knowledge of the case. Only last week, they assembled a jury pool of 48 people, who will be winnowed down today just before opening statements.
The Landano case has outlasted all the original judges, prosecutors and defense lawyers and gained a notoriety, not only for its staying power but also for the hostility that has developed among the players.
At various times, Mr. Landano's lawyers have accused the prosecution of coaching witnesses and planting evidence. Prosecutors have demanded that judges order the defense not to discuss the case, and once elicited sympathy from a judge who scolded the defense for trying to "demonize" the Hudson County Prosecutor's office.
And Mr. Landano, who since his release has worn an electronic device that permits the authorities to monitor his movements, is as openly bitter about his experience as he is steadfast about his innocence.
"I have been done the wrong," he said. "I haven't done the wrong."
Mr. Gardner, the prosecutor, was not available for comment yesterday.
Mr. Landano was an unemployed construction worker trying to kick a drug habit when he was arrested in connection with the death of Officer Snow, a 23-year veteran of the Newark Police Department who was shot at close range outside the Hi-Way Check Cashing Service in Kearny.
The officer, in uniform and in a marked patrol car but off duty, was apparently making a scheduled delivery of $46,000 to the owner of the business. He drove up just as two men were robbing the office. One of the robbers ran up to the cruiser, shot Officer Snow through the neck, jumped into a stolen car and fled with his accomplices.
From the first, Mr. Landano maintained that he was never at the scene and that he was being framed by members of a Staten Island motorcycle gang that called itself the Breed. Mr. Landano said he did know one of the gang leaders, a childhood friend named Victor Forni who was later convicted of helping to plan the robbery. But he said he never knew other gang members, although one of them named Mr. Landano as his accomplice in the robbery and the gunman in the Snow shooting.
In the years that followed the first trial, the case took on a new life with enough twists and turns to qualify for a made-for-television script.
Mr. Landano met a West Orange, N.J., lawyer who was visiting another client in prison. The lawyer, Neil Mullin, was intrigued by his story and took Mr. Landano on as a client -- and a personal crusade -- for free. "It was my life's work," Mr. Mullin said recently.
Together with Mr. Landano's wife, who met him when she attended a prison basketball game staged to benefit a charity she supported, Mr. Mullin searched for holes in the case. Eventually, he found enough to convince Judge H. Lee Sarokin of United States District Court that crucial evidence had been suppressed by the prosecution, including evidence that cast doubt on the credibility of some state witnesses and showed that some had expressed doubts about their identification of Mr. Landano.
Then the name of Mr. Forni, the gang leader, reappeared.
In 1996, after Mr. Landano had already been indicted for the second time, documents were made available to the defense from a drug case in Florida. They included a statement from an undercover sheriff's detective who said Mr. Forni had bragged to him in 1988 that he had "killed the cop in New Jersey."
But prosecutors have said they do not believe that Mr. Forni was the gunman, and Mr. Forni, who served eight months in prison for his role in the robbery, is listed as a potential state witness in the new trial, as are two of his former gang cohorts.
But many of the witnesses from the first trial will be heard by the jury only through their 22-year-old words, if at all.
Some are dead, including three people who had testified that Mr. Landano was with them at the time of the robbery and murder in Kearny. So is the owner of the Hi-Way Check Cashing Service, who was present during the robbery. One witness, who recounted the motorcycle gang's past robberies, was found hanged in his prison cell in what the authorities said appeared to be a homicide. Physical evidence is missing, as are some tape recordings that could have been of use to the defense.
Paul Casteleiro, Mr. Landano's trial lawyer, said he could not talk about specific trial strategy. But he said the passage of time presented challenges to both sides, as even the memories of living witnesses are hazier than before and the trail of the crime has grown colder.
Both sides have looked to forensic tools that were unavailable at the first trial, including DNA testing and high-tech computer enhancements of photographs, but have not made any major breakthroughs.
Mr. Landano said he pinned much of his hope for acquittal on the possibility that the jurors would hear what he has gone through for the last 22 years. Judge Tolentino has said either side may bring up in open court the facts that Mr. Landano has been convicted and that the conviction has been overturned. "Time did not stand still after 1976," she said last month in court.
Mr. Landano said he wants little more than to make that clear.
"This case is about the truth -- to put to rest who didn't kill Officer John Snow," he said last week. Then he added, "Hopefully who I am and what has been done to me will all become facts presented to the jury."

HEADLINE: NYC;
Now You Can Ride Forever; Is That Good?

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN 

 BODY:
YOU could call Gene Russianoff a metroholic. To get an idea of what a subway addict he is, consider how he ushered in Independence Day.
Some people can be found in bars or clubs at midnight. But as the third of July melted into the Fourth, Mr. Russianoff was standing at the Union Street Station in Brooklyn with $63 in hand to buy the new monthly subway pass that went on sale that very minute. 
 Not that he was going anywhere, except straight back home on foot. But as a leader of the advocacy group known as the Straphangers Campaign, he wanted to be in the delivery room, as it were, for the birth of the new system of unlimited-ride passes that is being trumpeted as a millennial change.
Mr. Russianoff even pondered hurling confetti at the token clerk, but thought better of it. Just as well. You never know these days if a festive gesture will become a quality-of-life offense.
His desire to celebrate was understandable, though. Passes of this type have long been the Straphangers' Holy Grail, and now they are in hand. So is a big test of whether they will bring about the miracles some are predicting. Mr. Russianoff acknowledged the point yesterday as he rode the No. 6 line from station to station to see how the cards sold during the first morning rush they were in effect.
"We're getting what we want," he said, "and now we'll find out if it makes a difference."
Gov. George E. Pataki proclaimed the other day that the fare discounts would empower the rider. That had a nice ring to it, and will no doubt provide the Governor with a campaign sound bite.
But you might want to remember that it was the same Mr. Pataki who depowered the rider a few years ago when he cut state subsidies for New York mass transit by tens of millions of dollars. He took away so much money, in fact, that he brought about the largest increase ever in the subway and bus fare, an increase that proved to be unnecessary and is effectively being scaled back now.
The Governor's political interests aside, some have described the new monthly and weekly passes as innovations that will alter urban life. That seems a bit much.
Sure, being able to take as many trains and buses as you want is exciting. But life-altering? It is a phrase better saved for truly cosmic change in the subways, like whatever it takes to persuade the jughead standing above you that it is boorish of him to munch on pizza as the train lurches through the tunnel. That would require a real miracle.
The goals of the new passes are less lofty, and some lend themselves to easy measurement.
Will subway and bus ridership increase? That seems to be a given.
Will subway and bus service improve enough to handle the extra load? That cannot be taken for granted. The masters of the underground have not done nearly enough to handle the extra 400,000 riders a day produced by the 11-rides-for-the-price-of-10 discount that went into effect a year ago. So it is not unreasonable to ask how bad the crowding has to get before they add more cars. Arms and legs sticking out the doors as trains leave the station?
ANOTHER obvious test is whether the new passes will lure motorists out of their cars and onto mass transit. The Straphangers Campaign and Mr. Pataki predict that will happen. But the discounts of the last year have yet to do much good in this regard.
While there are more subway riders, there are also more motor vehicles than ever entering Manhattan, nearly one million a day during the week. That no doubt is because these are good times, and many more people are driving to work. Three cheers for the economy! But the city center is choking on traffic, and political leaders have done precious little to discourage people from driving into town.
Mr. Russianoff argued that lowering the mass-transit fare is only part of the solution. Better subway service is also needed, he said, and stern anti-car measures like tolls on the East River bridges. Those kinds of steps are not necessarily out of the question some day, he added.
"It's a Pollyana-ish thought," he said, "but if these passes can happen, maybe other changes can happen."
Maybe. But let us, like Scarlett O'Hara, think about that tomorrow, and deal with a more immediate anxiety. Have you thought at all about how to keep your monthly pass safe? Lose it, and it's goodbye $63. That's real money.

HEADLINE: Gloom in German East May End Kohl's Streak

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: DRESDEN, Germany

 BODY:
Fritz Hahle is one of those bluff party bosses who burnish the silver lining however gloomy the cloud that hovers over their eastern German fiefs. Three months from a pivotal national election, Mr. Hahle is finding it hard to be optimistic.
Chancellor Helmut Kohl, Mr. Hahle's ultimate boss, is fighting an uphill battle for a precedent-setting fifth term. With eastern unemployment stubbornly high -- twice as high as in western Germany -- and a nationwide malaise settling in, the German leader and his Christian Democratic party face a cruel twist of fate. 
 German unity eight years ago was the biggest single triumph of Mr. Kohl's 16 years in office, but now its tribulations could help unseat him by depriving his coalition of a majority in Parliament. That would fundamentally redraw Germany's political landscape, and Europe's too, just as the continent confronts the upheavals of globalization and its own striving for economic unity.
"As things stand, there's not much of a chance," Mr. Hahle said in the smoked-glass-and-steel state legislature building bolted to the old Communist Party headquarters here. "People still regard Helmut Kohl as the Chancellor of unity. But many people are also saying 16 years is enough. That is what is making it difficult for us."
The view finds its echoes on the streets, in the cafes and most of all in the unemployment lines. "The people want hope and Helmut Kohl can't deliver that," said Thomas von Danckelmann, an unemployed Dresden heating engineer who plans to vote for the opposition Social Democrats.
The troubles in eastern Germany are particularly significant because the politically volatile eastern states yield the swing voters that can make or break the narrow margins of success.
The Sept. 27 election will be the third since unification and arguably the most important since World War II. It will determine how the economic powerhouse of Europe defines its future and how it exerts its mighty influence -- with or without a player whose record-breaking stint in office has made Mr. Kohl an immutable center of gravity.
But it will be fought in eastern Germany on one basic question: is the glass half full or half empty? Is reunification a work in progress that will ultimately produce the "blossoming landscapes" that Mr. Kohl promised, or has this remarkable experiment in fusing two Germanys failed?
Four years ago Mr. Hahle delivered a stunning victory here for Mr. Kohl and his party: of Germany's 16 states, his -- Saxony -- scored the single biggest success for the Christian Democrats, even delivering extra seats in Parliament that bolstered Mr. Kohl's narrow majority.
This time, though, the calculations are different.
"In this election every single vote will count, and the Christian Democrats' credibility is under the microscope," said Werner Patzelt, a professor of political science at Dresden Technical University. "If they can't convince people they have done something, then the election campaign will collapse."
Saxony is eastern Germany's richest, most populous state. It is run as a Christian Democratic redoubt by a Governor -- Kurt Biedenkopf -- whose popularity and seigniorial manner have encouraged the nickname King Kurt, and who endures as the party's political heavy artillery.
Its twin big cities, Leipzig and Dresden, have come to symbolize a blend of entrepreneurial spirit, scientific know-how and historic elegance. Tourists flock to the baroque splendors of the opera and the art galleries. The tower of the Frauenkirche in Dresden, destroyed by Allied bombing in World War II, is being rebuilt below a sheath of protective plastic.
Of the hundreds of billions of western German aid dollars poured into the east, often to the advantage of western investors, Saxony has received a substantial chunk.
"Look at the Elbe," exulted Steffen Heitmann, the state Justice Minister. "It was black. It stank. Now there are fish in it. O.K., you can't eat them or swim in it. But look at it."
He gestured toward the river's evening-golden flow where old, refurbished paddle steamers ferry visitors.
"People now speak ironically of the blossoming landscapes," Mr. Heitmann said in an interview, "but they are here -- health care, hospitals, courts, schools. We must show that."
For all that, Saxony labors under the same political blight as follows Mr. Kohl across the land, driving his standing in opinion polls below that of his Social Democratic challenger, Gerhard Schroder, and requiring him to recreate his fabled comeback of 1994.
With Mr. Kohl cemented in history as the titan of German unification, no one doubts his landmark achievement. But like John Major in Britain or George Bush in the United States, Mr. Kohl is depicted, even among his supposed allies, as the tired tail end of a long dynasty that has run its course.
 
Did Helmut Kohl Just Stay Too Long?
Contrast that with eight years ago.
Then, Mr. Kohl's party was seen as the greatest hope particularly among the lower-paid in eastern Germany, and that sense endured for some through the 1994 elections.
Lutz Fischer of Dresden, for instance, was a driver for a Government-owned company in East Germany. Now he runs two vans delivering ice cream on a contract from a big ice-cream company. In 1990, he said, he voted for the Christian Democrats, "because they made the most promises."
Even in the 1994 elections, he said, "four years seemed a short time and you couldn't expect them to do everything."
"But the problem is that nothing has changed," he said. So this time he said he did not plan to vote for Mr. Kohl, though like many eastern Germans he was not quite sure whom he would support.
Even some of Mr. Kohl's stalwart western German supporters are hesitating. "This election is a real dilemma for us," said Josi Kramer, a prosperous housewife in Bonn. "Kohl has been there too long. But who else is there for people like us?"
Younger people, too, sense a disenchantment in many parts of eastern Germany. In one recent local vote in Saxony-Anhalt, an eastern state bordering Saxony, many swerved to the extreme right. Some are heading left.
"At first I thought Helmut Kohl was right to insist on this rapid reunification, this rapid change," said Christian Bernius, 27, a law clerk who plans to vote Social Democratic. "In fact, there was a rapid change on paper, but not in people's heads. Division is going on longer."
Indeed, despite Germany's nominal unity, the election campaign is being fought as two.
In the west, where the bulk of Germany's voters show stable voting patterns, Christian Democratic strategists are waging a "red scare" campaign, accusing Mr. Schroder of working hand in glove with closet Communists in the east.
But in the east, where the challenge is to convince voters that they never had it so good under Communism, the aim is to win back those who believe that reunification -- personified in Mr. Kohl -- has made them second-class citizens.
"The Christian Democrats have written off the east," said Raimund Grafe, a strategist for the Social Democrats. And, said Joachim Herz, the former director of the Dresden State Opera, "what do you expect to achieve by constantly telling 15 million people that everything they did was wrong?"
 
In the East, Little Party Loyalty
The strategy, though, reflects a demographic and political reality: Germany's national elections are fought for the hearts and souls of the big, rich states of the west, where the population is four times that of the east and where voters chafe increasingly at financing the east.
But here in the east, voters are far less entrenched in their party preferences. While 80 percent of western voters display a stubborn party loyalty, Government statistics show, only about half of the easterners show the same fidelity. And they are far more likely to follow their pocketbooks than any sense of political obligation.
Earlier this year, in mayoral votes in two Saxon cities -- Leipzig and Gorlitz -- the Christian Democrats were trounced. In April, in Saxony-Anhalt, Mr. Kohl's party suffered its worst postwar defeat in a state legislative election that produced a sizable showing of 13 percent for the far-right German People's Union. One-fifth of the vote, moreover, went to the former Communists.
Since then, the Christian Democrats in Bonn have taken to castigating the easterners' seeming proclivity for voting for extremes, and for displaying little of the gratitude that westerners expect in return for paying a hated 7.5 percent income tax surcharge to finance the eastern revival.
The ultimate issue in eastern Germany, though, is jobs. At unification, the Communist command economy was rudely dismantled, the West German mark became the currency and an entire way of state-sponsored living collapsed.
But the paradox here is that the vaunted western investment in modern and highly automated industries in eastern Germany has provided none of the guaranteed lifetime jobs of Communism. "The more we modernize, the less jobs there are," Mr. Hahle said glumly.
In the eastern state of Thuringia, for instance, a General Motors plant producing Opel cars is a triumph of reunification that was a stop on President Clinton's tour in May.
The subtext, though, is that the plant, now employing about 2,000 people, replaced an old East German plant that provided five times as many jobs and produced half as many cars.
That pattern is repeated across the east, and the most troubling aspect is that it has produced an entire subclass of 50-somethings who may never work again. Roughly a fifth of the eastern work force is out of a job, twice the western figure. Overall, German unemployment has been stuck at postwar record highs for months.
 
Outbreak of Nostalgia For Cozy Communism
Indeed, what was taken for granted in the old Communist east -- the broad social network, free child care, artificial full employment -- is now glimpsed through the rose tint of loss, paradoxically outweighing gains like freedom and hard currency.
"Apparently it gives no one in Bonn pause for thought that eight years later, there is a nostalgia for the old east, which no one would have thought possible or imaginable in the days of the German Democratic Republic, when we constantly cursed our fate," said Mr. Herz, the former director of the Dresden State Opera.
Come September, said Mr. Heitmann, the Saxon Justice Minister, "it will be a lot" if the Christian Democrats are able to hang on to the seats that proved so valuable to Mr. Kohl in 1994.
"It could still be that the east will tip the scales again," he said, though he did not say in which direction.

HEADLINE: If These Stones Could Talk . . . A Polynesian Mystery Tale;
Easter Island Giving Up Its Secrets, But Only Grudgingly

BYLINE: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD 

DATELINE: EASTER ISLAND, Chile

 BODY:
ON the sacred slopes of Rano Raraku, a Polynesian Mount Olympus, the impassive faces on huge statues carved out of soft volcanic stone look across fields tinted dusty pink by the ripening tall grass and far out to the blue waters of the Pacific Ocean. The vista encompasses the entire world that could have been known to the creators of the enigmatic statues, the most distinctive expressions of an ancient society coping with life in isolation on the most remote inhabited island on Earth.
Down on Easter Island's south coast, also in view of Rano Raraku, 15 more of these gray monoliths, called moais (pronounced MOY-eyes), have been reassembled and restored to their original upright positions in a single row on a stone platform. Archeologists consider the site, Tongariki, one of the greatest religious monuments of early Polynesian culture in the South Pacific. It is certainly the most impressive accomplishment of recent restorations here. 
 Everywhere one looks on this speck of land no more than 64 square miles in size, about three times the size of Manhattan, another moai stands silhouetted against the sky or lies in pasture grass or remains in its quarry, incomplete or too large to have been moved by its over-reaching builders. A comprehensive survey by archeologists from Chile and the United States has counted nearly 900 of these statues, with a few more pockets of land still unmapped.
The statues have long haunted the imaginations of explorers, anthropologists and other visitors. Whatever the sculptors intended, the moais are seen as the lithic embodiment of obsession and mystery. In a time more attuned to ecology, they have also been invoked, rightly or wrongly, as a metaphor for the fate of a society that self-destructs through the heedless use of its limited resources.
Early this century, the English ethnographer Katherine Routledge spent more than a year studying the Easter Island culture and its remarkable sculpture. "The shadows of the departed builders still possess the land," she wrote. "The whole air vibrates with a vast purpose and energy which has been and is no more."
On average, each statue stands 14 feet and weighs 14 tons, though one measures 32 feet and 89 tons. The motif is unvarying: an elongated head with long ears, a prominent nose and pursed lips and a shortened torso with hands placed across the abdomen, fingertips just meeting. Coral eyeballs have been restored to only a few of the heads. The vacant eye sockets seem to render all the others blind to the present and unrevealing of the vision that drove the islanders to a frenzy of statue building between 1,000 and 400 years ago.
Archeologists at last are making progress in recovering the history of Rapa Nui, which is the local culture's name for the island, the people themselves and their indigenous language. They also are gaining a better understanding of the motivations, practices and economic foundations of the statue builders. But the place is in danger of losing its alluring air of mystery.
"All outsiders think the island is so simple and straightforward," said Dr. Jo Anne Van Tilburg, an archeologist at the University of California at Los Angeles and writer of "Easter Island: Archaeology, Ecology, and Culture" (Smithsonian Institution Press, 1994). "The remains are so visible there on the surface, and the place is so small. But I've been working there 15 years and I have more questions now than answers."
One evening after a day among the ruins, Dr. Jose Miguel Ramirez, an archeologist and head of the National Park of Rapa Nui, ticked off some of the most intractable mysteries. "We're not sure when the island was first settled, where exactly the people came from or whether they maintained any contacts with their homelands after they arrived," he said.
But scholars have disproved some of the more fanciful conjecture. "This is not the tip a sunken continent like Atlantis, and has nothing to do with aliens from outer space," Dr. Ramirez said emphatically. "We know it was human beings who came here and erected these statues."
Likewise, scholars say they have laid to rest the notion, made popular in the 1950's by the Norwegian explorer Thor Heyerdahl, that the original people were Indians from South America. He thought he saw similarities between Pre-Columbian Peruvian and Easter Island architecture. To make his point that such contact was possible, he sailed westward from Peru in a reed raft named the Kon-Tiki.
Linguistic, cultural and genetic evidence, most anthropologists agree, shows that the people of Rapa Nui were Polynesians. Their language is Polynesian, though it has changed so radically as to indicate an early separation from the home culture and centuries of isolation. The few surviving examples of ancient writing are in a script that has yet to be deciphered. The statues and other artifacts bear a Polynesian imprint, and in 1994, the DNA from 12 Easter Island skeletons was found to be Polynesian.
 
The Settlers
Polynesians Found Isle Next to Nowhere
The first settlers apparently arrived from the west by canoe sometime between A.D. 400 and 750. This was a time of epic voyages of Pacific settlement. The migrating Polynesians, originally from Southeast Asia, had reached Tahiti and the Marquesas islands by 300 before going on to discover and occupy Hawaii and New Zealand.
Finding Easter Island, though, must have put the Polynesian navigators to their severest test. They would have had to paddle against prevailing winds and currents, traveling far to the south and east of their usual routes and then somehow coming to an island that is next to nowhere: 1,400 miles southeast of Pitcairn Island, the nearest inhabited land, and 2,340 miles west of Chile, Easter Island's proprietor since 1888.
"It's unlikely this could have happened entirely by accident," said Dr. Ben Finney, an anthropology professor at the University of Hawaii who specializes in Polynesian exploration.
Next year, a team of Hawaiians skilled in traditional Pacific island navigation plan an attempt to duplicate the voyage in a replica of a 62-foot-long, twin-hulled Polynesian canoe. In previous expeditions, the same team established that early sea-going Polynesians had the boats and navigational skills for purposeful exploration and widespread settlement of the Pacific.
Dr. Finney, an adviser to the group, known as the Polynesian Voyaging Society, said the expedition would start from Mangareva, an atoll northwest of Pitcairn. Mangareva is considered one of the more likely departure points for the original voyage of discovery; the Marquesas are another candidate. If the winds are favorable, Dr. Finney said, the journey might be completed in 17 days, but it would probably take much longer to wait for favorable breaks in the prevailing winds.
 
The Reasons
Feats of Bravery, Then Stranded Alone
The Polynesians probably sought out Easter Island for the same reasons they crossed much of the rest of the Pacific, Dr. Finney said. It was not necessarily overcrowding that drove them forth.
"The voyages may have been celebrations of technology," the anthropologist said. "The people had developed the world's best ocean-going technology for the tropics. They were proud of it and wanted to test it to the fullest. And then there was their hierarchical social structure. Only the oldest sons could hope to become chiefs. So like the younger sons of Europe who went off on the Crusades or to the New World, the younger sons of Polynesia organized expeditions to find a new island, where guess who would then become chief."
Once they reached Easter Island, however, the people probably found themselves stranded. Scholars can find no evidence of two-way communication between the island and the rest of Polynesia. The settlers, it seems, were stripping the island of trees, especially the hardwoods used in canoe buildings. Without canoes, they had no way back, and were utterly alone until Jacob Roggeveen, a Dutch mariner, reached the island on Easter Sunday in 1722.
By then, the culture's glory days had passed. Recent excavations led by University of Chile archeologists have uncovered old agricultural fields, seeds and roots of former woodlands, house foundations, ceremonial sites as well as the fallen statues. An analysis of the findings indicates that the island population grew steadily from 1000 to the 1500's, when it apparently peaked at 9,000.
Although the first statues were probably erected soon after the island's settlement, archeologists have found that the people went on a building spree between 1400 and 1600. Nearly all of the statues were quarried and carved at the summit of Rano Raraku, a satellite cone of one of the three volcanoes that formed the island. Toward the end, the sculptors were producing bigger and bigger statues, as if they were desperately appealing for greater divine intercession in times of mounting trouble.
Most archeologists view the statues as the central manifestations of ancestral worship. The island was ruled by a religious aristocracy with the power to enlist a large labor force to create the statues as representations of their forebears, the chiefs who were also gods in Polynesian culture. Nearly all the statues faced not to the sea, but inland, toward fields requiring the blessing of fertility and some of the sacred places.
Dr. Van Tilburg explained that the moai is an icon exemplifying the fundamental Polynesian concern with genealogy, generation, status and respect. It served as "a cultural motivator and modifier of group behavior."
In her book, the U.C.L.A. archeologist wrote, "The originators of moai design were absolute masters of the components of traditional art as communication and use of line to convey emotion, and understood the social function of the form they had created."
 
The Decline
Statue Cult Prey To Man and Nature
By the 17th century, the old order of statue builders was disintegrating. Tribes organized into warring confederacies. Rebelling against the religious elite, they toppled and often decapitated the symbols of their influence, the statues. Famine may have led to some cannibalism.
With the waning of the moai cult, the people replaced it with a "birdman" cult. A warrior from each tribe would meet at the ceremonial site of Orongo on a cliff overlooking tiny offshore islands. The young warriors would race out to the outermost island to bring back the first egg of the nesting season from the sooty terns. The winner, according to a tradition that existed into the last century, became the birdman and the island's ruler for the next year, an incarnation of Makemake, the culture's creator god who was born in the sea.
The collapse of the culture is usually attributed to a combination of overpopulation, overuse of the land and the cutting of all trees for firewood and log rollers for moving the statues. Dr. William S. Ayres, an archeologist at the University of Oregon who has studied the island agriculture, has found evidence that many of the large fields were abandoned in the 1600's and the people increasingly had to subsist on the produce of small household gardens. Their numbers diminished.
As an example of the struggle to live on an island denuded of vegetation, Dr. Ayres said, one of his graduate students, Joan Wozniak, looked under the rocky landscape and detected evidence that the people had resorted to a kind of lithic mulch gardening. They used rocks as mulch to keep moisture in the soil. Under the rocks, she found a thoroughly mixed soil typical of intensive gardening and traces of rotted tubers, even part of an ancient hoe.
Both Dr. Ayres and Dr. Van Tilburg think that the people may not have been entirely to blame for the culture's sad decline. Storms and cyclical climate changes could have had a hand.
"There's a strong possibility that an isolated island like that could have been at the mercy of nature, with no help in reach," Dr. Van Tilburg said. "It's one of the biggest mysteries of the island, and we haven't begun to investigate it."
Restoration of the island's monuments was begun in the 1960's primarily by Dr. Ayres and Dr. William Mulloy of the University of Wyoming, who had been a member of the Heyerdahl expedition. Several of the toppled statues were put back on their stone platforms, called ahu, and the stone dwellings were reconstructed at Orongo.
In the most ambitious project, Dr. Claudio Cristino, a Chilean archeologist, directed the restoration of the 15 imposing moais at Tongariki, completed in 1994. A Japanese company provided a crane for lifting the heavy stones into place.

The Present
Trying to Preserve, And Save, a Culture
While some restorations continue, much of the concern has now shifted to preservation of the monuments and the culture itself. The island has revived from the Peruvian slave raids and disease in the late 19th century that almost wiped out the culture, leaving only 111 people in 1877. "We were almost extinct," Dr. Ramirez said.
The people face a new threat because of the island's new-found prominence. The signs of increasing tourism abound in Hanga Roa, the only town, inviting visitors into auto-rental agencies, small hotels, curio shops, a pizza parlor and a disco. Few children are learning the Rapa Nui language, threatening it with extinction in a generation or two.
Frustrated by the changes, many of the island's 2,000 people are demanding that Chile grant them more control of their affairs, the land and the archeological sites. Their demands for autonomy are boldly displayed on a large sign outside the Roman Catholic church here. Inside, the celebration of Mass reflects merging cultures. The service follows the familiar Christian ritual, but the guitars, drums and lilting voices in song echo the sounds of Polynesia. At the altar, the statue of a saint is carved in the traditional elongated style of the moai.
"We are trying not only to preserve but to rescue the Rapa Nui culture," Dr. Ramirez said.
He is especially concerned for the moais. They and the entire island have been declared a world heritage site by Unesco. The most prominent statues are in the national park, which encompasses 40 percent of the land. Still, they are endangered.
"Our most immediate problem is to conserve these statues from people and cattle," Dr. Ramirez said, referring to increased tourist traffic and free-ranging livestock.
He wants the Chilean Government to enact a strict management plan for the park and estimates it would take at least $1 million to develop trails and facilities for visitors to the sites. When an international group of scientists visited here last month, Dr. Ramirez appealed to them for assistance in calling world attention to the island's needs.
Dr. Ayres, the Oregon archeologist, said the Chileans had generally done a good job managing the archeological treasures. "But they have limited funds," he added. "Such a remarkable achievement by the Easter Island culture is of interest and importance to the whole world, and should be treated accordingly."
Dr. Van Tilburg said that in her years of work on the island she has seen the weathering effects on the statues. "All of us must find a way to preserve the statues, if not all of them, at least some," she said.
For her part, Dr. Van Tilburg has produced 5,000 detailed drawings and measurements of what the statues look like as the most complete documentation of the mystery of Easter Island and a legacy to future archeologists who will surely still be puzzling over the fate of a people who once lived alone in the vast emptiness of the sea.

CORRECTION-DATE: July 14, 1998, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Science Times last Tuesday about mysterious statues on Easter Island, Chile, referred incorrectly to Kon-Tiki, the raft used by an explorer to show that Indians from South America could have reached the island. It was made primarily of balsa logs, not reeds.

HEADLINE: At Brunch, The More Bizarre The Better

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GRIMES 

 BODY:
WHEN the weekend arrives and the city's daytime motor shifts into idle, New York prepares to greet its favorite meal. It is called brunch, and it is weird. A linguistic and culinary hybrid, brunch is a breakfast that begins with a cocktail. Or a lunch that's organized around a stack of buckwheat pancakes. It's neither fish nor fowl nor good red herring, although all three can wind up on the same plate.
At Cafe Botanica, in the Essex House, patrons glide past a buffet table that starts with Danishes and bagels on one end, moves quickly to a mountain of peeled cold shrimp, and takes a sharp left turn toward a medley of Oriental dishes like vegetable dumplings with a soy dipping sauce and a three-color seaweed salad. 
 For sheer oddness, however, nothing on the table quite matches the sardine-potato tart at Home restaurant in Greenwich Village.
"We had a lot of mashed potatoes left over one Saturday night, and I remembered some sardines I'd seen at Murray's Cheese Shop, packed in salt," said David Page, Home's owner and chef, explaining the origin of the dish. "I came up with a kind of cake with a red bell-pepper sauce, and a poached egg on top." The dish, now served with a roasted tomato sauce, has never been off the menu since.
The strange world of brunch continues to expand, generating bizarre new life forms, embracing flavors and ingredients never before associated with mankind's pre-noon existence. There was a time when huevos rancheros represented the outer limit of brunchtime experimentation, but as chefs have ranged far and wide, and then farther and wider, in search of new influences, and as diners have adopted a global outlook, the always fluid boundaries of brunch have stretched to the breaking point.
No one is complaining -- not in New York, where every weekend the faithful line up outside hot spots like Isabella's on the Upper West Side, or Friend of a Farmer on Irving Place, or E.J.'s Luncheonette on the Upper East Side. Rain or shine, brunch lures everybody: couples who may or may not have met the night before, young people treating their parents, couples with children, young women in pairs or 10-strong gangs and, in the gay brunch belts of west Greenwich Village and Chelsea, men in pairs and big groups.
New Yorkers notoriously chafe at lines and delays, but come the weekend, they meekly tolerate a wait of 30 minutes for a crack at oysters on the half shell, baby spinach omelets and Irish steel-cut oatmeal.
For the hundreds of restaurants that routinely serve a Saturday brunch as well as the more traditional Sunday one, the brunch stampede is a bonanza. Popover Cafe, a 90-seat restaurant on the Upper West Side, serves nearly 500 brunches on a busy Sunday. Isabella's, a 195-seat restaurant on Columbus Avenue, serves 1,000 or more. Matthew's, on the Upper East Side, does its biggest business of the week at Sunday brunch. "Any restaurant that's open for brunch is packed," said John Villa, the executive chef at Park View at the Boathouse, in Central Park. "It's guaranteed business."
Chefs hate brunch. "They hate cooking it and they hate thinking about it," Bobby Flay, the chef at Mesa Grill, said. "Saturday night tends to be the busiest of the week, and they've probably gone out to have a few drinks afterward. Suddenly it's Sunday morning and you have to come in and cook eggs." Mr. Flay says that he happens to love brunch, but on this issue, he is out there alone.
Mr. Villa said: "To me, it's one of the hardest menus to write. You have to have a balance, but you can't have too many breakfast items, because the meal carries on until 4 P.M." In his case, that means a Thai-influenced shrimp frittata and a grouper club sandwich side by side with granola and yogurt.
If chefs seem to be taking license with brunch, that's because freedom is written into the charter of this oddity among meals.
Although the meal itself came to glory in the United States, the word is a British invention, coined in 1895 by Guy Beringer in a visionary article titled "Brunch: A Plea."
Instead of England's early Sunday dinner, a postchurch ordeal of heavy meats and savory pies, the author wrote, why not a new meal, served around noon, that starts with tea or coffee, marmalade and other breakfast fixtures before moving along to the heavier fare?
By eliminating the need to get up early on Sunday, brunch would make life brighter for Saturday-night carousers. It would promote human happiness in other ways as well.
"Brunch is cheerful, sociable and inciting," Beringer wrote. "It is talk-compelling. It puts you in a good temper, it makes you satisfied with yourself and your fellow beings, it sweeps away the worries and cobwebs of the week."
More than a century later, Beringer's template for brunch remains as valid as the day it was created, perhaps because, in drafting his culinary declaration of independence, he was not overly specific about what dishes should be served. He demanded "everything good, plenty of it, variety and selection." In a postscript, he suggested that beer and whisky could be served instead of coffee and tea, laying down a precedent for the mimosa, the Bloody Mary and the screwdriver.
It took a while for brunch to drift across the Atlantic, but after World War I, Americans embraced brunch and made it their own. The Jazz Age even created a novelty, a kind of second brunch that filled the gap between dinner and the last, mad grab for excitement as dawn poked its intrusive rosy finger into the party.
The Nation, noting that brunch had hitherto been a meal for poor students and "the lie-abed lady," described with some amusement the mad 5 A.M. dash for sausages, pancakes and "doughnuts, as dainty and sugared as our grandmother never knew how to make them." Then it was back to the dance floor for "camel walks and other steps from the zoo."
What might Beringer have made of the "Sunday Strollers' Brunch" served at the Fifth Avenue Hotel in the 1940's, with its sauerkraut juice, its clam cocktails, its chicken liver omelet in Madeira, its calf's liver with hash browns, its Scotch woodcock? Or House & Garden's brunch recipe, offered in 1952, for rice almond pancakes served with herbed shad roe? "A delicate hash, light fish balls, and liver and bacon are all appropriate," one women's magazine wrote in the 1920's.
Well, Beringer asked for variety and selection, which is exactly what the brunch menu at the River Cafe offers. Diners can start with Cheddar soup or codfish cakes before advancing to omelets and pancakes. At Mesa Grill, you can lead into the cinnamon and pecan waffles or ranch-style eggs with a cornmeal-coated chili relleno filled with goat cheese or a grilled white corn taco wrapped around barbecued pork, potatoes and tomatillo relish.
"It's as much a state of mind as it is a meal," said Michael McLaughlin, who ruled that chili, pizza and leg of lamb did not belong in the brunch section of his cookbook "Good Mornings," but chili-rubbed steaks, Gruyere fondue and brownies did.
"Breakfast has regional differences, but it is more clear-cut," he said. "Brunch is much more eclectic, although I would say that it has to be on a weekend, it has a festive aspect to it, and it's social. You never have brunch alone, while breakfast for one is perfect, in my opinion."
Brunch may be short on rules, but people have strong feelings about what makes a good one. "I like the fun of all the different foods you can get," Elizabeth England, a writer, said. Lara Shriftman, a public relations executive, said she gravitates toward Friend of a Farmer because it feels "very country, earthy."
Mr. Page, of Home, says it is no coincidence that family groups turn out for a meal at a restaurant with a name like his, as though searching for the ideal, family-around-the-table experience that Americans regard wistfully on the television screen but never actually put into practice.
Brunch spells warmth, abundance and homeyness. It is, in many of its associations, an invitation to go back to childhood. "People respond to the smell of coffee and bacon in the morning," said Carrie Levine, the chef and owner of Good Enough to Eat, a cozy restaurant on the Upper West Side. "It reminds you of childhood, when someone was cooking for you."
Ms. England said, "I like those places that have that homey, baked-goody sort of feel."
Ms. Levine has observed that bad economic news somehow translates into increased brunch business, as nail-chewing traders and brokers seek solace in the foods that bring them back to a simpler time.
The downside of this gentle picture is that, for the restaurant staff, brunch can be hell. It's not easy feeding hundreds of children.
"Brunch people tend to be very fussy," Marc Propper, the owner of Grove in Greenwich Village, said. "They want their eggs this way, not that way, they want sauce on the side. The list of special requirements goes on and on." One customer actually insisted that the staff butter his toast. "We didn't do it," Mr. Propper said. "We had to draw the line somewhere."
Ms. Levine has seen the same customers. "Even the words they use when ordering tend to be childish," she said. "They'll say they don't want their bacon mushy."
Who can blame them, really? New York is a tough town. No wonder its citizens wake up on Saturday and Sunday desperate for a little coddling, and ready for a spiritual return to the wholesome, abundant meals that good folks out in the heartland are eating. They want lemon ricotta pancakes, a lobster and arugula omelet, and a nice cold pitcher of tequila punch. What's so odd about that?
