HEADLINE: National Origins: Moxee City, Wash.;
So Difficult In the Field, So Sweet On the Tongue

BYLINE: By FRANK J. PRIAL 

DATELINE: MOXEE CITY, Wash., July 2

 BODY:
They were about to start the Rainiers, and Bob Harris was getting himself psyched up. "This is a crazy business," he said, "and anyone who can do anything else should stay out of it."
The business at hand was cherries in this, the nation's prime cherry country, with its acres of luscious garnet Bings and Lamberts, and especially Rainiers, which are some of the sweetest and most highly prized cherries in the world. 
 The day before Mr. Harris begins harvesting his Rainier cherries is a tense time. Hundreds of thousands of dollars hang in the balance. A rainstorm, even a few unexpected gusts of wind, can wipe out the work of a year in hours.
Most earlier-maturing cherries had already been picked, Mr. Harris said. If his Rainiers and some even later cherries came in without incident, it might even be a record crop -- or close.
A relatively new variety, the Rainier was developed at the Washington State University experimental station at Prosser in the 1960's, and it is a cross between the well-known Bing and the little-known Van. The Rainier costs an average of about $2 a pound retail in the United States, but connoisseurs in Taiwan and Hong Kong are willing to pay 10 times that.
Balding and 50-ish, tanned and fit, Mr. Harris grows his cherries, some 300 acres, here in the Yakima Valley, 150 miles southeast of Seattle. He pretends not to like what he does.
I had flown down from the West Side, as people in the hot, dry eastern part of Washington refer to the western slope of the Cascades, which is green, wet and cool. On the drive over to Mr. Harris's, the woman on NPR said it was 64 in Seattle; the dusty thermometer outside Bob Harris's dusty office read 98.
Yakima County produces more cherries than most states. Of course, this one county is almost as large as Connecticut. But cherries are just for starters: the county also produces more apples, more hops, more winter pears than any other in America. It is rapidly becoming one of the most important areas in the country for wine grapes and, for good measure, leads the world in the production of mint.
Yakima farmers work hard, and the fertile land has repaid them, often handsomely. The old farmhouses have given way to spacious air-conditioned mansions. New cars are in every driveway, and private planes are not uncommon. Arizona vacations and foreign tariffs are as much a part of coffee shop gossip as taxes and rain.
Thanks to those dormant (well, mostly dormant) volcanoes off to the west -- Mount Rainier, Mount Adams, Mount St. Helens -- the soil here is largely volcanic and rich in nitrogen. Those snowcapped mountains give the Yakima Valley more than its fruitful soil. Rainfall here is about eight inches a year, so without Mount Rainier's melting snow, much of this verdant land would be a desert. There would be no cherry trees. Rainier, then, is a singularly appropriate name for the new star of these cherry orchards.
But as is the way with stars, the Rainier can be ornery.
"It's murder to grow," Mr. Harris muttered, almost as if he begrudged the fruit its popularity. "It bruises easily, and you have to go through the orchard three times. With other cherries, the whole tree ripens at once. Not with the Rainiers." Even so, he admitted, growers can't keep up with the demand. (In the New York area, Rainiers will be available in most fancy-food markets until the first week in August.)
All cherries are difficult to grow. Not for nothing have they been called the riskiest fruit. Their deadliest enemies are frost, birds and rain, with wind and hail not far behind. Rows of smudge pots in the growers' sheds (some in empty shell casings from a nearby Army artillery range) and airplane propellers mounted on tall shafts throughout the orchards (to circulate the warmed air) testify of the annual battle to fend off frost.
But it takes as much effort to pick 5 acres of Rainiers as it does 50 acres of dark cherries like Bings. Even on a given tree, Rainiers ripen at different rates.
Picking starts at 4 A.M. and ends at noon so the newly picked fruit won't have to sit out in the hot sun. Only skilled pickers work with Rainiers. For one thing, they can be handled only by their stems. Because they are so delicate and bruise so easily, no more than 30 percent of the crop goes into the premium packs. A picker may need two weeks to pick 24 trees, going to each one as many as eight times.
A flock of hungry birds can be as devastating as any frost.
"Look at this," Mr. Harris said, pulling a half-eaten Rainier from a tree. The bird hadn't nibbled much -- just enough to make it unsalable.
Colonists brought cherries to America in 1629. The fruit arrived in the Pacific Northwest with a pioneer named Henderson Lewelling, who planted seeds in western Oregon in 1847. America's best-known sweet cherry, the Bing, was developed on his farm in 1875. It was named for one of his Chinese workers.
Demand for the extra-sweet Rainiers is understandably high, but they make up less than 5 percent of the annual Northwest cherry crop. Bings, which make up about 85 percent of the crop here, begin to appear in supermarkets in mid-June and last until mid-August. They are the biggest cherries and at their best are mahogany colored, in both skin and flesh. The Rainiers, golden-colored with a reddish-pink blush and clear flesh, begin to arrive a week or two after the Bings show up and are available through the first week of August. A third variety, the Lambert, comes to market around the end of June and is available through mid-August. It looks and tastes like the Bing, but is a bit smaller.
The Bing and the Lambert contain 17 to 19 percent fruit sugar; the Rainier, 20 to 23 percent. That extra little percentage adds to the all-important sweetness and helps explain the cherry's popularity.
"The Rainier's only marketing problem is its color," Mr. Harris said. "People like rich color."
To give his Rainiers more color this year, he spread strips of gleaming Mylar film between the rows of trees, to bounce the sun's rays up into the lower branches much as suntan fanatics use reflective collars.
And big cherries sell better than small ones. Most growers carry a seven-hole plastic template in their back pockets. If a cherry fits through only the largest hole, it's called a nine-row; if it can get through the smallest, it's a twelve-row. The jargon dates back to earlier times when cherries were packed in small boxes. If the packers could fit only nine in a row, they had big cherries and were happy. With twelve-in-a-row cherries, they knew they would get less money per box. The boxes are bigger now, but the size principle hasn't changed.
Not all cherries are sweet. Tart cherries, once called sours, come mostly from the Midwest -- Michigan is a major producer. They are the best for canning. Each year about 30 percent of the sweet cherry crop is exported, mostly to Japan, Taiwan and Hong Kong. Because of Japan's economic problems, the prospects for cherry sales there are "guarded" this year, said Eric Melton of Northwest Cherry Growers, the industry's promotional group, but he added that the Taiwan and Hong Kong markets are growing and might take up some of the slack. American cherries count as an exotic fruit in Asia.
Leaving Bob Harris warily eyeing his fruit-heavy Rainier trees, I drove over to Roy Farms, where Mark Roy was receiving flat boxes filled with newly picked cherries. The boxes, in stacks about six feet high, are rolled slowly though what looks like a large bathroom shower. The water, a frigid 35 degrees, drops the temperature of the delicate cherries to preserve them through the packing process, on what is called "the line."
A fourth-generation farmer in the Yakima Valley, Mr. Roy is a bit more relaxed than Mr. Harris, perhaps because the Roys are more diversified. "We started in hops," he said. "When that market died, we moved into apples, and when apples began to slow down, we got into cherries." The hops market slackened when the beer market stalled, but the 20-foot-tall plants are still highly visible throughout the Yakima Valley.
Temperature is everything in cherry shipping. Cherries destined for the Northeast travel directly from packing plants here to the Hunts Point Market in the Bronx in refrigerated trucks. "We put recorders in the trucks," said B. J. Thurlby, promotion director for the Washington State Fruit Commission. "It's a five-day trip to New York, and constant refrigeration at 32 degrees is expensive. Let's say some truckers might be tempted to turn it off now and then."
Cherries may be difficult to deal with, but these are relatively happy days in the Yakima Valley orchards. Demand in the United States continues to grow, and markets overseas are expanding, if slowly. Last year's crop, more than 90,000 tons of all the varieties grown here, was the largest on record, and the experts are predicting that as young trees come into production, crops of 110,000 tons and more are possible over the next five years.
Of course, conditions and tastes change. One day there might even be a glut. Chances of that are slim, though, because everyone who works in the business keeps eating cherries. As he walked through his orchard complaining, Mr. Harris kept pulling cherries off the trees.
"Try this," he'd say. "It's delicious."
I did. It was.
 
CHERRY AMARETTO FOLDED PIE
Time: 1 hour 15 minutes
From Katie Fuller, pastry chef, Macrina Bakery and Cafe, Seattle
 
2 cups stemmed and pitted sweet red cherries
2 tablespoons amaretto liqueur
 1/2 cup plus 1 tablespoon sugar
1 cup ricotta cheese
1 teaspoon vanilla extract
 1/2 teaspoon almond extract
1 tablespoon flour
2 large eggs, separated into yolks and whites
1 12-inch round uncooked flaky pie dough (see recipe)
1 large egg white, lightly beaten
1 tablespoon coarse (decorative) sugar
2 tablespoons confectioners' sugar.
1. In a medium-size mixing bowl, combine cherries with amaretto and 1 tablespoon sugar. Let stand 20 minutes.
2. In another mixing bowl, combine remaining 1/2 cup sugar, ricotta cheese, vanilla extract, almond extract and flour. Separate eggs, and add yolks to ricotta mixture, mixing until well blended. Using an electric beater, whisk the two egg whites until stiff but not dry, and fold into the ricotta mixture.
3. On a baking sheet lined with parchment paper, place the 12-inch round of dough. (It may overlap the edge of the pan.) Mound the ricotta mixture in the center of the dough, and top with the cherries; this will occupy about 8 inches of the center. Pull a 4-inch border up around the filling to make a free-form folded tart; make a round shape by folding a tuck every 2 inches, sealing the folds with beaten egg white. Brush the top of the crust with egg white, and sprinkle the center with coarse sugar. Chill by placing the tart, still on the baking sheet, in the freezer 20 minutes.
4. Preheat oven to 400 degrees. Bake tart until golden brown, 35 to 40 minutes. Sprinkle crust with confectioners' sugar, and serve warm.
Yield: One 8-inch pie (6 servings).
 
FLAKY PIE DOUGH
Time: 20 minutes, plus refrigeration
 
5 1/4 cups pastry flour or all-purpose flour
1 tablespoon kosher salt
1 1/2 sticks (6 ounces) cold unsalted butter, cut into 1/2-inch cubes
1 3/4 cups solid vegetable shortening, chilled, cut into 3/4-inch cubes
1 cup ice water.
1. In bowl of an electric mixer, combine flour and salt, and stir to mix. Add butter, and mix on low speed until mixture is crumbly. Add shortening, and mix until large clumps form. Add just enough ice water (the full amount may not be needed) to make the dough cohere.
2. Turn dough onto a work surface, and gather it into a ball. Wrap dough in plastic, and refrigerate at least 2 hours, and up to 5 days.
3. Divide dough into two, shape into balls and flatten into disks. Roll out dough as desired and use immediately, or freeze for up to 1 month.
Yield: 2 12-inch pie crusts.
 
CHERRY ICE CREAM
Time: 1 hour, beginning preparation 1 day ahead of serving
From Shelly Lance, pastry chef, Palace Kitchen, Seattle
 
3 1/2 cups sugar
2 1/2 cups stemmed, pitted and quartered cherries
 1/3 cup good-quality brandy or Cognac
3 cups heavy cream
3 cups milk
2 vanilla beans, split lengthwise
12 egg yolks.
1. Prepare the cherries and ice cream custard the day before making the ice cream. To macerate the cherries: In a medium saucepan, combine 2 cups of the sugar with 2 cups of water. Bring to a simmer, stirring to dissolve sugar. Add the cherries, and simmer 5 minutes. Remove from heat, and transfer cherries and syrup to a bowl. Stir in brandy. Cover, and refrigerate overnight.
2. To prepare the ice cream custard: In a medium saucepan, combine the heavy cream, milk, vanilla beans and remaining 1 1/2 cups sugar. Heat until just beginning to steam, stirring to dissolve the sugar. Remove from the heat. In a separate bowl, whisk the egg yolks until well combined. Add a ladleful of the hot milk mixture to the eggs while whisking vigorously, to warm and temper the yolks. Add the warmed yolks to the hot milk mixture, and return the pan to medium heat. Stir until the mixture is thick enough to coat the back of a spoon, about 5 minutes; then, immediately pour it through a fine strainer into a clean container. Remove the vanilla beans from the strainer, and scrape the pulp from the vanilla beans into the custard. Cover the container, chill in a bowl of ice water and refrigerate overnight.
3. To finish the ice cream: Place a strainer over a bowl and drain the syrup from the cherries. Set the cherries aside, and discard the syrup or reserve for another use. Freeze the chilled custard in an ice cream maker according to the manufacturer's instructions. Remove the ice cream from the machine while it is still slightly soft. Using a rubber spatula, fold in the cherries. Cover ice cream, and place in a freezer for a few hours or until completely firm.
Yield: 2 quarts.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Prices Drop for Treasury Securities in Line With Dollar's Fall

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities fell for the first time in three days yesterday as the dollar slumped in world currency trading.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 15/32, to 107 16/32. The yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 5.60 percent, from 5.57 percent Monday. 
Analysts pointed out that bonds have moved in tandem with the dollar recently. And yesterday the dollar slumped after statements from Japan increased expectations of an income tax cut to help pull that nation out of its recession.
Several media reported that a Japanese official said Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto had said that Government tax changes would include an income tax cut. Some analysts noted that the comments appeared to run counter to remarks the Prime Minister made the prior day.
Investors are watching to see to what extent the Japanese commit themselves to tax cuts, because a permanent cut could dry up the flight to United States Treasury securities, limiting further rallies in the American market. Still many remain convinced that the weakened Asian economies will place a drag on the United States economy and continue to help subdue inflation.
Doug Burtnick, an analyst with Technical Data in Boston, said trading was light and was mostly currency driven. "Currently," he said, "the bond market is trading very close to the high end of its most recent trading range, an indication that people now need to see more weakness in the economy before rates can go significantly lower."
In the municipal bond market yesterday, $1.02 billion of Detroit Metropolitan Wayne County Airport revenue bonds were priced through underwriters led by Salomon Smith Barney. The securities are in two parts with the bulk, $859.6 million series A, priced to yield a maximum 5.35 percent for a bond due in 2028. For a bond due in 2022, the yield was 5.33 percent. For shorter maturities, yields ranged from 4.30 percent for an issue due in 2002 to 5.31 percent for an issue due in 2019.
In the $163.6 million series B, the maximum yield was 5.22 percent for a bond due in 2028 and 5.19 percent for a bond due in 2023, with shorter maturities initially priced to yield from 4.25 percent in 2003 to 5.17 percent in 2018.
Both series carry insurance from the Municipal Bond Investors Assurance Corporation covering interest and principal payment, which gives the bonds a triple-A rating from Moody's Investors Service and the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

HEADLINE: Roughnecks Of Distinction;
Oilfield Workers Acquire Status in Labor Shortage

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS 

DATELINE: ABILENE, Tex.

 BODY:
For Daniel Shumate, a 32-year-old parolee, it's another chance to get his life on track. For Melissa Bolton, 23 and also a parolee, it's an opportunity to show that a woman can handle heavy work in the oilfields. For Ruben Garza, 20, it's a way to break out of toiling at minimum wage. And for Ben Hilgreth, 21, a college student, it's a way to build up a stake that he can use to invest.
While their goals vary, these four share a single dream: to make it in one of the most physically demanding, dangerous and at times technically challenging jobs around -- being a "roughneck," or laborer, on an oil rig. 
 Dripping with sweat, their clothes stained with grease and dirt, their bodies aching from wrestling with equipment weighing hundreds of pounds, they struggled recently to develop the skills and endurance needed for that life. The site was a school for roughnecks here, run by the Texas Engineering Extension Service, part of Texas A & M University.
With starting pay of $9 to $13 an hour, and with shifts that can last 12 hours -- a typical schedule is 14 days on, 14 days off -- a worker can eventually make more than $200 a day working on an offshore platform.
For everyone in this class of eight, becoming a "weevil," as new workers are called, would be a big step up the economic ladder. That is why they gave it their all in this monthlong class.
The school reopened in early April after closing four years ago, a victim of a boom that fizzled when oil prices hit bottom in the late 80's. That boom left such a glut of workers that for years new opportunities in the field were almost nonexistent.
When prices strengthened several years ago, though, oil service companies suddenly found that a whole generation of workers had vanished, and have been scrambling ever since to catch up.
So while oil prices have again fallen, hitting a nine-year low last month, the underlying need for new blood is so strong that there is still a healthy demand for all kinds of workers -- from starting laborers, or "roustabouts," to chemical engineers.
"In the 1980's, we lost an entire generation," said Gary Lee, vice president for human resources at Grey Wolf Drilling. "There is still a shortage of good skilled people."
This profession has been so volatile that even though Mr. Garza and two other graduates have gotten jobs, history seems to suggest that their budding careers could vanish at any moment.
Like Mr. Lee, though, many industry executives argue that it may be different this time -- that even if oil prices stay low, or drop more, the pool of skilled workers has shrunk so far that the labor shortage will persist for at least several years.
And even though smaller independent drillers have cut back, most larger oil companies are holding firm. They are in the midst of bringing large fields into production, projects that make economic sense despite unexpectedly low oil prices.
One reason the industry can withstand lower prices is that rapidly advancing technology brings down the cost and risks of finding oil.
No matter how high tech it gets, though, the industry still needs strong workers who can take the punishing 12-hour shifts and stay mentally alert. For they play a crucial role in bringing to the surface the vast amounts of oil and natural gas needed to supply the 74 million barrels a day the world now consumes.
Thus recruiters still come to the roughneck school to interview potential trainees.
New recruits could end up on rigs in the deserts of Kazakhstan, where temperatures range from 40 below in winter to 110 in summer, living in isolated barracks for a month at a time and then having a month back home. Or they could toil two weeks at a time on platforms in the North Sea, where storms send huge waves crashing into the concrete and steel structures.
Most get their start with smaller independent companies, then try to move to the majors, where jobs can be steadier and opportunities for advancement more numerous.
In the 1980's, the industry had plenty of experienced roughnecks. Though benefits and pensions were rare, the pay was high.
But "when the drilling stops, they're through with you," said Dennis Hooper, an instructor at the school who started to work as a roughneck when he was 15. He has seen boom and bust many times in his 54 years.
In 1983, a big drop in oil prices led to an almost decade-long retrenchment by oil companies. Tens of thousands of workers were forced to find other jobs or move away. Many were plunged into poverty.
By the time oil prices recovered and a sustained drilling boom took off, the pool of skilled labor had largely evaporated. "The contractors themselves have caused this," Mr. Hooper said, since little effort was made to keep skilled workers in the industry.
The lack of good entry-level workers has caused many drilling companies to begin their own training programs, and even offer benefits like health insurance and 401(k) plans.
Still, many companies now send more veteran managers into the field to supervise workers. Green workers, executives said, are prone to make mistakes while learning a variety of tasks, from painting and scraping to handling expensive equipment.
"It's scary," said Michael V. Ronca, president and chief executive of the Domain Energy Corporation, a medium-size Houston independent that does a lot of drilling and exploration in the United States and the Gulf of Mexico. "We have to send our experienced people to baby-sit."
Even after extensive training, roughnecks "don't know what they are doing sometimes," he said.
One time, he recalled, a worker was unable to turn off the water and ended up flooding equipment.
Suppliers can fall short, too, he said, recalling that Domain recently had to ship back 34,000 feet of defective pipe -- pipe that had passed four sets of inspectors.
Even though the jobs basically take brawn and endurance, one cannot just walk off the street and become a roughneck. Working a drill rig takes teamwork and coordination, with even simple jobs on platforms, like cleaning and painting, involving an element of risk.
Wayne H. Davis, who runs the school and coordinates its safety program, told one class that in Alaska the decks of offshore platforms are about 150 feet above the freezing water, with currents often running at 30 to 40 knots.
"If you fall off," he said, "they've got five minutes to get you."
He also warns students about hydrogen sulfide, a highly poisonous gas that smells like rotten eggs. When released in drilling, it can quickly overcome workers and, in high concentrations, even kill them if they don't make a quick exit or don a protective mask.
And Mr. Davis repeatedly stressed the importance of teamwork. "It takes a while to fit in with everybody," Mr. Hooper stressed. "If you're in a crew that doesn't know what they are doing, it gets pretty tense."
Some of the trainees did not finish the course because they found the adjustment difficult, he said, adding, "You have to have that grit."
Ms. Bolton seemed to have it. After several weeks, she was able to maneuver huge wrench-like tools that weigh 500 pounds. During a training session, amid the roar of motorized drill bits and winches, she moved them smoothly just in time to tighten and loosen drilling pipe.
A couple of months ago, she recalled, she was working as a nursing-home aide for $4.35 an hour. When her parole officer told her she could learn the trade that her father and brother made their living at, she jumped at the chance.
A chunky woman with brown hair gathered into a ponytail under her hard hat, she worked quietly and comfortably with the young men on the rig, training herself for the rigors ahead.
She realized she would have a harder time proving she is up to the challenge. "They wonder, 'Can she do it?' " she said. "It just makes me want to prove more that I can."
Mr. Hilgreth, a wiry University of Texas student, was attracted by the numerous ads offering jobs, but, when he called, found that everyone wanted experienced people. He decided to quit college for a while and come to the school.
"I want to make enough to invest in something," he said, taking quick drags on a cigarette during a lunch break.
With oil prices dropping again, the bloom of the upturn has begun to fade. Rates for drilling rigs have begun to fall as smaller companies have cut back. Wells that made sense to drill when oil was $18 to $20 a barrel do not at the recent $13 to $14.
Randy Smith, an assistant drilling superintendent for Key Energy, a local drilling contractor, had all his 32 rigs working earlier this year. To attract reliable, skilled workers, his company raised the basic starting wage from $9.35 an hour in November to $12.35 and began offering 401(k) plans.
The recent decline in oil prices, however, has caused him to mothball about half the rigs.
And other smaller companies have begun to lay off workers as they shut down less productive wells.
Mr. Smith said that most smaller independent oil companies were waiting to see what happened on the world stage.
At a meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries in Vienna in June, leading oil-producing nations like Saudi Arabia and Venezuela were able to put together cuts of 1.4 million barrels a day. Combined with cuts from non-OPEC countries like Mexico and Norway, this has led to total reductions of close to 3 million barrels a day.
It is unclear how far these cuts will go in helping oil prices recover because demand may also fall because of recessions in big oil-importing nations like Japan.
"We're like puppets on a string," Mr. Smith said.
In a way, so are the graduates.
Mr. Garza, a strapping 6 feet 2 inches tall, has just started working with a crew near Laredo, Tex., for Grey Wolf Drilling. He is working 12-hour shifts, from 6 P.M. to 6 A.M., seven days straight. He earns $10 an hour, but after 40 hours in a week, he gets the $15 overtime rate. When he is working, he lives in a six-bunk trailer with 10 other workers in the middle of a desolate area, often battered by wind-borne dust, where temperatures can reach 110 degrees. About the only diversion is satellite television.
At this point, he often does the simple tasks, like fetching wrenches, tying cables and using his powerful arms to lock down nuts and bolts. His concern is whether this job will last.
Recently some of his co-workers were laid off, but he was kept on because of his training.
For Daniel Shumate, who had been driving a cement truck for $8 an hour -- not enough to enable him to own a car -- the school is his chance to "make it into the middle bracket." After waiting for a over a month and a half he just landed a job with an oil well service company starting at $6.25 an hour and has several prospects to work on an offshore platform at much higher pay. He wants to make it since if things don't work out he said, "I'm back to square one."

HEADLINE: Conseco Expects $498 Million Charge

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: CARMEL, Ind., July 7

 BODY:
Conseco Inc., a life and health insurer, said on Monday that its purchase of the Green Tree Financial Corporation, a lender to buyers of manufactured homes, would strip $498 million from second-quarter earnings.
Conseco said $350 million of the charge came from securities that Green Tree created from its loans that were paid off earlier than expected as interest rates fell. The remaining $148 million was related to severance costs and the investment banking, legal and accounting fees from its $5.76 billion purchase of St. Paul-based Green Tree on June 30. 
 Conseco's chairman, Stephen Hilbert, who built the company, based in Carmel, Ind., using 20 acquisitions in the last 16 years, said he expected the purchase of Green Tree to add to third- and fourth-quarter earnings and to increase next year's profit as much as 3.5 percent.
The falling value of Green Tree's securities reflects the drop in rates that prompted borrowers to refinance loans on prefabricated homes. When Green Tree makes a loan, it typically sells the right to principal payments and keeps the interest payments. So-called interest-only bonds decline quickly in value when rates fall because early home-loan payments eliminate future cash flows.

LENGTH: 1111 words

HEADLINE: California's Budget Struggle Is Bitter Despite Big Surplus

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: SACRAMENTO, Calif., July 7

 BODY:
Gov. Pete Wilson began his tenure here seven summers ago with the largest budget gap that any state ever faced, a $14.3 billion shortfall that forced him and the Legislature to raise $7 billion in new taxes and slash spending by the same amount. The budget was finally passed 17 days after the July 1 deadline, and the next year, the wrangling was even worse, with a record 63-day standoff over how to spread the pain.
Now Mr. Wilson is in his last year in office, contemplating another run for the White House and eager to leave a legacy -- and California is once again without a budget one week into the new fiscal year. But this time, as in other state capitals this season, the fight is over what to do with a surplus -- $4.4 billion generated by the Golden State's booming economic recovery -- and while the question now is about cutting taxes and expanding services, the debate is just as bitter as before. 
 "This is a bigger problem, in a way," said John L. Burton, the beleaguered Democratic leader of the State Senate, who noted that a surplus -- in an election year to boot -- inspires less cooperation and more partisanship than in tough times.
Mr. Wilson agreed, saying dryly of his adversaries in the Democratic-controlled Legislature, "They seem to find it more difficult to come to grips with plenty."
Spurred on by states like Virginia and Arizona, where the issue has proven to be political catnip, Mr. Wilson and his fellow Republicans want a $3.6 billion cut in the state's vehicle license tax over the next four years. That would amount to a 75 percent reduction in the unpopular tax, a Depression-era relic that is based on 2 percent of a vehicle's value (adjusted by a set depreciation schedule) and translates into several hundred dollars a year for owners of newer cars. Such a cut would also allow Mr. Wilson to claim that, over all, he has reduced taxes more than he has raised them in his two terms.
Because the car tax revenues go to cities and counties to finance local services, the Democrats contend that cutting the tax could jeopardize police protection if the economy took a turn for the worse. Last week, in what was regarded as no more than an opening bid, the Democratic-controlled Senate unanimously passed an alternative, a one-year quarter-cent cut in the state's 6 percent sales tax, and on Monday, the Assembly followed suit. But Mr. Wilson derided the idea as "much too little and much too brief" and vowed to veto it.
Mr. Burton said in an interview that he expected face-to-face negotiations with the Governor and the Democratic Assembly Speaker, Antonio R. Villaraigosa, to begin soon, but the Assembly and Senate have yet to agree on an overall budget plan of their own. And Mr. Burton and Mr. Villaraigosa have held their posts for just a few months, replacing colleagues forced to move on by term limits, while Mr. Wilson, himself barred from seeking a third term, is a veteran with a proven stomach for budget standoffs.
And despite being in his last year as Governor, Mr. Wilson enjoys strong advantages in the state's Constitution. It requires a two-thirds vote in each house to pass the budget, making it hard for the Democrats to peel off enough Republicans to force the Governor's hand, and it gives the Governor line item veto power to punish legislators by cutting their pet projects.
"The smart money is looking at late August now," said Dan Schnur, a former top aide to Mr. Wilson who is a political consultant in San Francisco. "In the past, the choices have been so painful that they led to paralysis. It takes two or three months to decide whether you're going to take guide dogs away from blind people. But there isn't any road map for what they're dealing with now."
In an interview today, Mr. Wilson said that it should not take so long to reach agreement, but he added that he would not be surprised if it did, noting that "there doesn't seem to be even common direction" among the Democrats. And the Governor dismissed any notion that the surplus is a short-term phenomenon. Beginning two years ago, with the recovery reaching full force, the state's revenue collections started exceeding forecasts, and there was a somewhat smaller surplus last year, though Mr. Wilson curtailed debate over how to spend it by unilaterally using most of it to replenish a state pension fund.
"We keep having these non-recurring surpluses," he said sardonically, adding that this situation means "California's tax structure takes too big a bite." Mr. Wilson argues that the vehicle tax, which costs the average car owner $185 a year, is particularly onerous and affects almost everyone in a state with 24 million registered vehicles, more than there are houses. His proposal would save the average owner $135 a year.
Twenty states, including New York and New Jersey, impose no value-based taxes on motor vehicles, opting for flat annual registration fees. But the 30 other states impose either a personal property tax on cars or, like California, a value-based tax in lieu of property tax.
In California's case, the car tax is the sole legacy of the state's old personal property tax, in which assessors visited homes each year to survey the value of contents. But cars were always mysteriously absent from driveways on assessment day, so in 1935 the state abandoned the personal property tax in favor of a tax on cars, imposed at annual registration.
A recent survey by the National Conference of State Legislatures found considerable support around the nation for rolling back such taxes, after the successful candidacy for governor of James S. Gilmore 3d in Virginia, who campaigned last year on a platform of reducing that state's local property tax on automobiles. Since then, states including Kansas, Kentucky, Rhode Island, South Carolina and Arizona have either passed reductions or are considering them.
"This tax is particularly disliked," said Mandy Rafool, a conference policy analyst who conducted the study. "People hate property taxes in general and this is a big chunk at once."
All the players here agree that there will be a tax cut, with the only question how big. Both sides are also proposing more spending on education, with the Democrats demanding more than Mr. Wilson has offered. But the Governor repeated today that he was "not interested in temporary relief" from taxes and said that the Legislature had so far offered no more than "this little drill."
As for Mr. Burton, an old Sacramento hand on his second career after a stint here and in Congress collapsed as a result of alcohol and drug abuse, he said in the interview, "All I want is to get out alive."

HEADLINE: The Battle Over Hog Factories

 BODY:
Hogs used to be a staple of the small-farm economy. But as American agriculture has grown more specialized, they have begun to be raised in concentrated numbers in confinement systems. These operations contain between 2,000 and 100,000 sows, which eat, excrete and reproduce in metal barns with concrete floors. The waste is stored in lagoons and eventually sprayed on fields.
Livestock has always played an essential role in the biological cycle of agriculture. But hogs raised in enormous confinement systems no longer belong to the biological cycle. Their manure is now a pollutant. 
 Until recently, the fastest growth in hog production occurred in North Carolina, but now the battle over the impact of hog confinement systems is a national one. In Milford, Utah, the four largest North Carolina hog producers have constructed a facility, called Circle 4 Farms, that will eventually hold 100,000 sows. In Colorado and South Dakota, ballot initiatives have been proposed to limit large-scale pork producers.
Some of the problems with giant confinement systems are obvious. There are the problems of odor and ground-water contamination from leaking lagoons. When liquefied hog manure is distributed over spray fields, it is done at a rate that far exceeds the fertilizer needs of the soil to which it is applied, often causing further contamination. Strong evidence has been gathered to show that the nitrogen in manure lagoons evaporates and is redeposited in what scientists call nutrient-sensitive waters, like those of coastal North Carolina, resulting in oxygen depletion and fish kills.
The battle over hog factories is really a battle over the definition of farming and the legal consequences that follow from that definition. Large-scale pork producers have always sited their facilities where zoning is nonexistent or could be weakened. But farmers, by any reasonable definition of the word, have nothing in common with large-scale pork producers, except when they enter corporate servitude and agree to raise hogs on contract. Consumers are slowly learning that they have nothing to gain from factory hog production either, except cheap pork chops, which by any realistic measure of environmental or social value are far more costly than they seem.

HEADLINE: Liberties;
In All His Feathered Glory

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Erik Tarloff's mother cut a deal with his father.
"If Frank Sinatra ever came on to her, she was allowed to go with him for one night, with no repercussions in the marriage," he recalls. 
 Mr. Tarloff, a writer who saw Washington from a rare perspective as the husband of a Cabinet-level official, the former Clinton chief economic adviser Laura D'Andrea Tyson, thought of his mother's groupie exemption when he wrote his new Washington novel, "Face-Time."
The book, not yet published, is about a young woman who works in the White House, along with her boyfriend, a speechwriter. She succumbs to the advances of a Clintonesque President because she feels it is an experience that transcends infidelity, and even sex.
Or, as Marilyn Monroe mused to her psychiatrist about her relationship with J.F.K.: "Marilyn Monroe is a soldier. . . . The first duty of a soldier is to obey her Commander in Chief."
When all is said and done, Bill Clinton's biggest legacy may not be in politics, but in letters. Aside from the flock of fiction and nonfiction books written about our intriguing President, he has inspired one entirely new and remarkable genre: feminist erotic journalism.
After decades spent trying to dissuade powerful men from thinking they can have their way with less powerful women, feminists now have a terrible confession: They pant for power. They crave droit du seigneur. Take me! Take me!
First Larissa MacFarquhar wrote of Monica Lewinsky in The New Yorker that "It would be a rare young woman who could resist . . . a chance to sleep with a man who is (a) the President and (b) a babe."
Then 10 women, including some feminists, a fashion designer and a retired dominatrix, participated in a panel for The New York Observer that resulted in a story headlined "New York Supergals Love That Naughty Prez."
"I think there has been a shift in the cultural climate since the time of the Anita Hill hearings," said Katie Roiphe, adding: "Now, this virile President is suddenly fulfilling this forbidden fantasy of this old-fashioned, taboo aggressive male. I think women are finding that appealing." Tina Brown wrote her bodice-ripping dispatch from the Tony Blair state dinner about Mr. Clinton: "His glamour is undersung . . . a man in a dinner jacket with more heat than any star in the room (or, for that matter, at the multiplex) . . . his height, his sleekness, his newly cropped, iron-filing hair, and the intensity of his blue eyes. . . . He is vividly in the present tense and dares you to join him there."
The latest swooner is Nina Burleigh, a former White House reporter for Time, who writes in Mirabella about a game of hearts with Mr. Clinton on Air Force One flying to Jasper, Ark., that made her tingle.
"The President's foot lightly, and presumably accidentally, brushed mine once under the table. His hand touched my wrist while he was dealing the cards. When I got up and shook his hand at the end of the game, his eyes wandered over my bike-wrecked, naked legs. And slowly it dawned on me as I walked away: He found me attractive. . . .
"There was a time when the hormones of indignant feminism raged in my veins. An open gaze like that, at least from a man of lesser stature, would have annoyed me. But that evening . . . I felt incandescent. It was riveting to know that the President had appreciated my legs, scarred as they were. If he had asked me to continue the game of hearts back in his room at the Jasper Holiday Inn, I would have been happy to go there and see what happened."
Amazingly, Nina outflutters Tina, casting Bill as Zeus in "Leda and the Swan": "Yeats honored the magnetic sexual pull a powerful male can have on a weaker female. The beating wings of the giant swan enwrap the helplessly infatuated woman, whose 'terrified vague fingers' cannot push the 'feathered glory from her loosening thighs.' "
Ms. Burleigh may have Presidential affairs on the brain since she just wrote a book about Mary Meyer, a J.F.K. paramour who was murdered. Defending her piece to The Washington Post, she noted that she would have happily had a certain kind of sex with Mr. Clinton "just to thank him for keeping abortion legal."
We should stop blaming Ally McBeal for killing feminism. We should even stop blaming Bill Clinton. It is clearly a mass suicide.

HEADLINE: Gore to Unveil Savings Bonds With Rates Tied to Inflation

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 7

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration plans to unveil a new type of Government savings bond on Wednesday with a return that will rise and fall with inflation to protect investors' gains as well as to help finance the Federal debt, Administration officials said today.
The bonds will be sold in eight denominations, $50 to $10,000, and will mature in 30 years. Most of the denominations, which bear the likenesses of Helen Keller, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., Albert Einstein and others, are to go on sale in September. The $200 and $10,000 denominations will go on sale next May. 
 In announcing the new securities, Vice President Al Gore plans to promote them as an attractive means for middle-income people to prepare for retirement or a child's education.
Referring to the bonds as "inflation insurance," a senior Treasury official said today that he expected them "to be attractive for people who want to be able to guarantee that they're earning a substantial inflation-adjusted return on their money, that'll double their money in real terms in less than a generation."
As he prepares for the Presidential race in 2000, Mr. Gore is trying to burnish his economic credentials, one White House official said, and the Administration's decision to have him, rather than President Clinton, present the new bonds is part of that effort. Mr. Gore will make the announcement at the Treasury Department with Robert E. Rubin, the Secretary of the Treasury.
In January 1997, the Treasury Department introduced its first inflation-indexed bonds, which were generally intended for large institutional investors. Until then, the Federal Government had financed the national debt by relying on fixed-rate securities, which have a set, unchanging interest rate. Such bonds, whose returns can be eroded or wiped out by inflation, have not been a popular option compared to stocks, corporate bonds, 401(k) plans and other forms of long-term savings.
The Clinton Administration hopes that the inflation-indexed bonds, or I-Bonds, will appeal to small investors.
"They're meant for and designed for small investors," one official said. "We think this is important to avail small investors of the same benefits of inflation protection that larger investors have."
Unlike other inflation-adjusted bonds, but like other savings bonds, the new securities offer special tax benefits. As long as investors hold their bonds, they may defer paying taxes on their earnings, which are automatically reinvested and added to the principal. The new bonds, like others issued by the Treasury, are exempt from state and local taxes.
The tax protection "would be a very nice feature for someone who is, say, several years from retirement and in a high-income bracket, who wants to protect his portfolio from inflation but without generating higher income," said Dan Pederson, president of The Savings Bond Informer, a Detroit-based information service for investors.
If the bond is redeemed to pay for college tuition or other college fees, investors may exclude part or all of the interest from their income in calculating their taxes.
The average American is far more likely to hold savings bonds than Treasury bonds: Roughly 55 million Americans, or about 1 in 3 households, own savings bonds, Mr. Pederson said. Investors hold about $180 billion in savings bonds, according to the Treasury Department.
Investors' earnings from the new bonds will be determined by two rates. One rate, set by the Treasury Department, will remain the same for the life of the bond. The second, a rate of inflation, will be determined every six months by the Bureau of Labor Statistics to reflect changes in a version of the Consumer Price Index.
Before any inflation adjustment the new bonds are expected to be offered at a rate ranging from 3 percent to 3.5 percent, less than the rate carried by fixed-rate securities that offer no inflation protection.
Investors in the bonds will have some protection if deflation sets in. Any decline in the Consumer Price Index could eat into the fixed rate, but would not touch the underlying principal, officials said.
Mr. Gore has given two major speeches recently on the economy, one in the spring before the Economic Club of Detroit and one last month before the Center for National Policy here. White House aides said that announcement on Wednesday was intended to remind voters of Mr. Gore's role in the Administration's economic policy.
"The whole idea is to start building his profile more and more on the economy, for obvious reasons," one official said.
Mr. Gore has also stepped up his partisan commentary on economic matters. His speech before the Center for National Policy amounted to a sharp critique of Republican economic policies. He accused the Republican-controlled Congress of threatening to "unravel our fiscal discipline, even at the risk of raising interest rates, shattering confidence in our economy and squandering the resources we need to finally close the generational deficit."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Chancellor Media Is Buying Lin TV for $902.7 Million
Shares of Chancellor Media, the nation's second-largest radio company behind CBS, fell after it announced that it was expanding into television with the acquisition of Lin Television for $902.7 million in stock.
The combined company will have Lin's 12 network-affiliated television stations and minority stakes in NBC affiliates as well as Chancellor Media's 108 radio stations. Page D2. 

Russian Aid May Not Be Enough
The International Monetary Fund and the Yeltsin Government are negotiating an aid package that may produce less money than foreign investors say is needed to help ease Russia's financial crisis. Russian officials have publicly stated that they need $10 billion to $15 billion in assistance from the fund and other lenders, but some Western investment bankers say Russia may need $20 billion or more to rebuild investor confidence. A1.
 
2 European Exchanges Plan Alliance
The stock exchanges of London and Frankfurt announced a broad alliance aimed at creating a pan-European trading system. D4.
 
Stocks Fall as Summer Rally Falters
The summer rally stalled as concerns about stock valuations caused investors to sell shares with strong gains. Hardest hit were Internet companies and oil producers. D8.
 
The yield on the 30-year bond rose to 5.60 percent, from 5.57 percent Monday. D8.
 
Alcoa Reports Strong Profit
The Aluminum Company of America, the world's largest aluminum producer, reported a 6.3 percent increase in second-quarter earnings, greater than expected, as increased shipments offset lower aluminum prices. D2.
 
Two Retailers Warn About Earnings
Venator Group and Sports Authority said that their second-quarter earnings would be less than expected, causing their shares to fall and threatening the merger of the two biggest United States sellers of athletic shoes. D7.
 
General Strike in Puerto Rico
Union leaders in Puerto Rico said that about a half-million workers from more than 50 labor unions had joined a two-day general strike that disrupted travel and caused many banks and businesses to close. The strikers are seeking to halt the Government's privatization of the Puerto Rico Telephone Company. A14.
 
VW Fund for Slave Workers
Volkswagen, in an about-face, agreed to set up a fund to compensate workers who were forced into slave labor in World War II. According to a company-financed history, Volkswagen employed 15,000 slave laborers in the war. Volkswagen declined to say how much it would pay or whether it would make payments to victims' families. A3.
 
Paris Aghast at Possible Tower Sale
Can an American company buy the Eiffel Tower? A subsidiary of GMAC, G.M.'s financial arm, is interested, along with the Bass brothers of Texas, in buying a 70 percent interest in the state-owned Credit Foncier de France, which has a stake in the company that manages the famed tower. The move is seen as an outrage by many Parisians, who say that the law forbids aliens of any kind, including Americans, to buy it. D4.
 
Schools' Business Partners
A new nationwide study shows that employers that work closely with their local high schools -- offering everything from materials to tutorials about the world of work -- have a turnover rate among young employees as low as half that of other companies. D20.

HEADLINE: Jailed Nigerian Dies Amid Envoys' Visit

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 7

 BODY:
Nigeria's most prominent political prisoner, Moshood K. O. Abiola, died today, apparently of a heart attack, further complicating an already turbulent political situation in Africa's most populous country.
Mr. Abiola, who was 60 years old, became ill while meeting with American and Nigerian officials at a government guest house in Abuja, the capital. He died shortly afterward in a hospital, American and Nigerian officials said.
 James P. Rubin, the State Department spokesman, said in Washington, "We do not have any reason to believe this is anything but natural causes." But at least one of Mr. Abiola's children said the death was suspicious, and another said the Government that had kept her father imprisoned and denied him medical care was culpable in his death. 
 The Nigerian Government promised a full, prompt autopsy in cooperation with Mr. Abiola's personal physicians.
Mr. Abiola's death was the second stunning development in Nigeria in less than a month. On June 8, Gen. Sani Abacha, the unrelenting dictator who had thrown Mr. Abiola into jail in 1994, died suddenly of a heart attack.
Gen. Abdulsalam Abubakar, General Abacha's successor, had been expected to free Mr. Abiola, the apparent victor in Nigeria's aborted 1993 elections, soon. The United Nations Secretary General, Kofi Annan, said after meeting Mr. Abiola in Nigeria last week that Mr. Abiola had promised to forswear his claim to the presidency and work toward a smooth transition to democracy.
Mr. Rubin said Mr. Abiola fell ill today while speaking to Thomas R. Pickering, the Undersecretary of State for Political Affairs, and Susan E. Rice, the Assistant Secretary for African Affairs.
"In the first 10 minutes, Abiola starts wheezing and coughing and then collapsing in some form," Mr. Rubin told reporters here. "I don't know if he lost consciousness. They get him in an ambulance or car. They get him to the hospital, where he dies."
Mr. Pickering told National Public Radio that when Mr. Abiola came into the meeting he appeared to be in good health and good spirits, but that his condition quickly deteriorated and that he began to cough and was "clearly disturbed."
Mr. Pickering, speaking by telephone to N.P.R., explained that Mr. Abiola excused himself from the meeting, went to a restroom, then returned in more distress. "When he came out of the toilet, he asked for painkillers," Mr. Pickering said, "and then sat on a couch and was overheated and asked for the room to be cooled, and removed some of his garments, and then clearly began to suffer."
Mr. Pickering said he took Mr. Abiola's pulse and said he was "clearly very cold and very disturbed and in some significant pain."
Mr. Abiola was taken to a hospital, accompanied by the American officials, who watched as doctors worked to save him, Mr. Pickering told the radio program "All Things Considered."
Mr. Pickering's delegation extended its stay until Wednesday.
Hafsat Abiola, the 23-year-old daughter of Mr. Abiola, blamed the Nigerian military for her father's death. In a telephone interview from suburban Maryland, where she lives with 5 of her 18 siblings, Ms. Abiola said: "My position is simple. My father was in their custody. Anything that happened to him while he was in their custody is their responsibility. I can't believe they did this."
Her father had not been well lately, Ms. Abiola said, adding that she had repeatedly asked Nigerian authorities to let a doctor see him. An American official involved in African policy said that Mr. Abiola suffered from high blood pressure and swollen limbs.
Another daughter, Wura Abiola, told C.N.N. that the family considered the death "very suspicious."
Mr. Annan said today that he had attempted to inquire about Mr. Abiola's health when he met with him last week. "He was alert and asked questions. But it was obvious from the questions that he was in isolation," Mr. Annan said. "For example, he didn't know who I was. I walked in, shook hands and smiled and started asking about his health. He asked, 'Who are you?' And I explained that I'm the Secretary General of the United Nations. And then he asked: 'What happened to the Egyptian? Is he gone?' " a reference to Mr. Annan's predecessor, Boutros Boutros-Ghali.
Mr. Annan, who spoke in an impromptu news conference at the United Nations today, said: "I'm not in a position to describe the conditions under which he was kept. But he did say that he had been in solitary confinement and was allowed no television, no press, no media except the Bible and the Koran."
Mr. Annan added, "I hope the Government of Nigeria will make good on its pledge to release all remaining political prisoners unconditionally and to define a credible process for the transition to civilian rule."
Mr. Abiola's release had been delayed, in part because Mr. Abiola's followers, mainly members of the Yoruba tribe in southwestern Nigeria, around the old capital of Lagos, insisted that he should be permitted to take office. In Lagos today some rioting and looting was reported after the news of Mr. Abiola's death, Reuters reported.
The Government, which is dominated by Hausa officers from Northern Nigeria, now faces the possibility of severe tribal tensions. In the late 1960's, the Ibo and their allies in southeastern Nigeria precipitated a civil war when they proclaimed the independent state of Biafra. Diplomats have expressed fears in the last few weeks that violence may lie just beneath the surface now.
Any fighting in Nigeria, which with its oil and natural resources has the potential for being the richest country in sub-Saharan Africa, could destabilize the weaker neighboring countries.
Encouraged by Mr. Annan and Western leaders to move his country onto the road to democracy, General Abubakar has already released Gen. Olusegun Obasanjo, a former military ruler, and 25 other political prisoners, but 250 or more still remain in Lagos jails, intelligence officials said. Many of them are not nearly as prominent as Mr. Abiola, a wealthy businessman and tribal chief.
Mr. Rubin said Mr. Pickering "had not received agreement in terms of a firm timetable to let Abiola out, but the Government did make clear that he would be out soon."
President Clinton, in a written statement released today, said, "I was deeply saddened to learn of the sudden and untimely death of M. K. O. Abiola, a distinguished citizen and patriot of Nigeria."
Nigeria remains in economic chaos, ravaged by corruption and incompetence. Despite the country's immense oil reserves -- it is the fifth-largest supplier of petroleum to the United States -- motorists are forced to wait for hours at the small number of functioning filling stations.
Limited sanctions imposed by the United States and others have compounded the country's difficulties. General Abacha ignored the rest of the world but General Abubakar has appeared eager to reach out to friendly nations.
Mr. Annan's mission to Nigeria, which was not announced in advance, followed several telephone conversations with General Abubakar and a secret meeting with the Nigerian Foreign Minister, according to William Shawcross, a British journalist who covered the Annan visit. Mr. Shawcross said General Abubakar told the Secretary General that he wanted to hand power back to a democratically elected government but implied that some other generals were not so sure.

HEADLINE: In Interior Design, a Clash of Rivals;
Owner of Uptown Center Wants Promotional Street Signs

BYLINE: By TERRY PRISTIN 

 BODY:
Just before an annual design and furnishings trade show in Manhattan last fall, a block of East 58th Street sprouted a new, chintz-draped street sign proclaiming it "Designers Way," and East 59th Street was transformed into "Decorators Way."
The new look was temporary, but now the managers of the Decoration and Design Building at 979 Third Avenue, home to 130 showrooms serving the high-end interior-design business, have asked the city to make the designation permanent. They say signs flanking the building would be a fitting recognition of a swatch of the East Side that is the heart of their industry -- really the only place to turn if you need $4,000 worth of suede to cover a client's sofa, say, or some very nice hand-embroidered silk for $2,000 a yard. 
 And who could object to such a harmless bit of industry boosterism? Well, the management of a competing design building, for starters. The owners of the New York Design Center, located at 200 Lexington Avenue at 32d Street, say the designation would give an unfair advantage to the Upper East Side building, and have enlisted the aid of a City Councilman who vows to block the new names.
The dispute between the rival buildings, known in the industry as the D and D Building and 200 Lex, has led to some nasty exchanges, with designers and wholesalers taking sides and questioning the motives -- or worse, the taste -- of their opponents.
"When I'm looking for things, it would never enter my mind to go to 200 Lex," said Robert Bray, a Manhattan interior designer. "It's so middle-class to me."
Things have changed, retorted another Manhattan designer, Adam Dolle. "Decorating was an Upper East Side kind of phenomenon," he said. "But that's not true anymore. Everyone goes everywhere."
In fact, the street sign debate is one small indication of broader changes roiling the world of interior design. Once almost entirely concentrated on the Upper East Side, showrooms sporting a "to the trade" sign -- the signal that, in theory at least, a customer must be accompanied by a decorator -- have migrated to neighborhoods like Chelsea, SoHo and the Flatiron District.
And the D and D Building's effort to market itself and other nearby establishments as the center of the design universe comes as the industry is trying to broaden its reach. The showrooms are seeking to draw a new class of customers who can afford fine furnishings but may have found the idea of hiring a decorator intimidating or simply unnecessary, given the growing number of high-end furniture stores that sell directly to the public.
The D and D Building and 200 Lex, for example, both offer referral services for customers without a decorator in tow.
"The reality is that a lot of people have good taste, but they don't know how to put it all together," said Michael Love, president of Interior Options, the referral service at 200 Lex. "We want to make them feel comfortable about using professional help."
In another break with the industry's fustier traditions, a major fabric house with a showroom at the D and D Building, Brunschwig & Fils, began accepting credit cards, mainly from decorators who in turn bill their clients, a few months ago. Paying with plastic is still unheard of at most showrooms, which have traditionally demanded payment in advance by check, an arrangement that offers less protection for dissatisfied customers. "We decided to do it because more and more clients of ours were asking for it," said Hans Denbroeder, showroom manager at Brunschwig.
James P. Druckman, president of the New York Design Center, argued that the changes in the industry rendered the notion of a designated design corridor obsolete. "I think the story is that New York itself is a design center," he said.
But Charles Steven Cohen, president of the Cohen Brothers Realty Corporation, which owns the D and D Building, professed astonishment at the reception his proposal had received. "I never in a million years suspected that 200 Lex would take umbrage," he said. "We are the center of the design industry."
Mario Buatta, a New York decorator whose clients have included Barbara Walters and Malcolm Forbes, agreed with Mr. Cohen that there really was no room for debate. "The D and D Building is perfection," he declared. "I'm not going to mention names, but if it's not in the D and D Building, you never remember to go there."
Mr. Druckman has found an unlikely ally in Councilman Andrew S. Eristoff, a Republican whose district includes the D and D Building but not 200 Lex. Mr. Eristoff said he moved to block the name change -- which requires Council approval -- when he concluded that the D and D Building was trying to gain an unfair advantage over its long-standing competitor. "This is an attempt to trump a rival in a highly commercial dispute," said Mr. Eristoff, who added that he had received a number of complaints about the proposed designation.
The more D and D officials have pressed for the signs, the more they have antagonized Mr. Eristoff. He said he was outraged when Mr. Cohen asked State Senator Roy M. Goodman, another East Side Republican, to intervene in the dispute. Now Mr. Eristoff said he would oppose even another temporary renaming for this fall's design show, which D and D officials have sought from the city's Transportation Department.
Still, a number of prominent designers agree with Mr. Cohen that the neighborhood surrounding the D and D Building is the focal point of their industry, and they give credit both to the booming economy and to the current management for the building's success after several lean years.
In the two years since Cohen Brothers Realty bought 979 Third for $67 million from the Travelers Group, which had acquired it in a foreclosure, occupancy has risen from 70 percent to 100 percent, with a waiting list of about 50 companies, Mr. Cohen said. Some tenants are now paying annual rent as high as $70 a square foot, he said. (Mr. Druckman said he was asking $30 a square foot.)
For years, many designers looked down on 200 Lex, saying it catered mainly to the lower end of the market. Built in 1926 as the New York Furniture Exchange, the building was converted in 1981 from a marketplace for retail stores into showrooms for decorators and designers. It includes a number of office furniture showrooms, some of them refugees from the ill-fated International Design Center in Long Island City, Queens, which emptied out after the stock market crash of 1987.
But 200 Lex, which has 87 showrooms, is taking steps to burnish its image. Mr. Druckman, whose family has been involved with the building since it opened, has attracted new, prestigious tenants like Wood & Hogan, which sells English period furniture and reproductions. Other longtime high-end tenants include Odegard, which carries hand-woven Tibetan rugs and Venetian lamps with hand-painted silk shades inspired by turbans, shields and pagodas.
"We're more user-friendly than any other design building in town, because we were built just to display furniture," Mr. Druckman said -- a pointed reminder that the D and D Building was built in 1964 as an apartment house, although it was never inhabited. From the outset, it has been used as a design house, and tenants and decorators constantly complain that the elevators are ill equipped for heavy traffic.
Since plans for redoing the living room are often the first thing to be jettisoned when the economy sours, the D and D's fortunes have usually depended on the stock market. Robert Lee Tinker, a former leasing director at 979 Third who now holds the same position at 200 Lexington, said about a dozen companies were behind in their rent when Cohen Brothers Realty bought the building and took over its management from the Merchandise Mart of Chicago.
Most of those tenants are gone now, and a number of well-established companies, like Stark, Donghia and Brunschwig & Fils, have enlarged their showrooms. Although they also carry furniture, they specialize in products like carpets and fabrics that are less vulnerable to swings in the economy.
"I wanted to be able to accommodate the expansion of the brand names and improve the credit-worthiness of the tenants," Mr. Cohen said. "The mom-and-pop showrooms gave way to larger vendors."
Mr. Cohen has added Astra Cafe, an upscale restaurant managed by Charlie Palmer, the owner of Aureole, and begun sprucing up the corridors and the building's lobby (a somewhat perilous undertaking, given that his tenants tend to have very definite ideas when it comes to interiors). Not to be outdone, Mr. Druckman plans to convert the cafe in his building into a more elegant restaurant.
Mr. Druckman, who provides bus service between 200 Lex and the D and D Building to make it easier for decorators to get to his showrooms, said he had tried in vain to get Mr. Cohen to cooperate with him by, for example, holding a joint trade fair. "It would create a broader market week for the city," he said, "but they want to do their own thing."
Mr. Cohen said he did not see the value of joining forces on a trade fair, but he did not rule out other ventures with Mr. Druckman. "I've tried to work with him," he said, "but he's very interested in his own personal ends."

HEADLINE: Commercial Real Estate;
Counting Heads (and Potential Wallets) to Help Sell Midtown

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
Anyone walking through the intersection of Seventh Avenue and 34th Street can see that there are a lot of other people in the area. But how many? The answer is important to retailers, who look at pedestrian traffic and see potential shoppers.
To measure the crowds, officials of the Grand Central and 34th Street Business Improvement Districts sent staff members to 14 major intersections to count the number of people passing by at different times of the day. What they found was a wide variation in the volume of pedestrian traffic, even in locations that are close together. 
 For example, during the morning rush hour in April, an average of 2,406 people walked along the southeast corner of Seventh Avenue and 34th Street. During the same period, an average of 9,834 people passed the northwest corner of the same intersection, most likely because of the nearby exit from the Long Island Rail Road.
The evening rush was even more congested, with an average of 11,856 people streaming by the northwest corner of the intersection and 4,335 passing the southeast side.
The size of those crowds is good news not only for retailers but for real estate investors as well. Steven Roth, the chairman of the Vornado Corporation, cited streets "teeming with people day and night" as the reason why his company has bought more than $1 billion in office buildings, a hotel and retail properties along Seventh Avenue between 31st and 34th Streets. With Madison Square Garden in its midst, he said, Vornado hopes to develop the area into an urban version of a suburban entertainment-retail shopping mall.
With its dense concentrations of relatively well-paid office workers, real estate executives said, Manhattan presents new opportunities for retailers who have developed their businesses in the suburbs.
Research has found that New Yorkers are walkers, willing to tramp longer distances than people in other central business districts to shop for what they want.
They are also far more likely to walk to any destination, be it work or shopping, than their counterparts in other parts of the country.
In some parts of Manhattan, like the heavily residential Murray Hill ZIP code, more people walk to work than arrive by subway, bus or taxi, according to the BID study. Accustomed to walking, they will go farther during lunch breaks to go shopping.
N. David Milder, the president of Danth Inc., a consulting concern that studies the relationship of pedestrian traffic to retailing decisions, wrote that "because of the amount of economic activity found in the midtown area, its geographic density and the propensity of New Yorkers to walk significant distances, one can reasonably expect that retailers in the Grand Central district can tap a much larger captive employee market than retailers in other downtowns or suburban locations."
Mr. Milder said studies had shown that office workers in New York, on average, were willing to walk 2,250 feet, or 0.43 miles, to do midday shopping, compared with under 1,000 feet in other cities. Discussions with researchers "produced a general consensus that people in Manhattan do walk twice as far as people in other downtowns and that this is probably because of midtown's huge range of retail choices and the large stretches of continuous retail space," he said.
The two BID's have been doing pedestrian counts since 1995, said Dan Pisark, director of retail improvement for the two business districts, which are centrally managed. "The retail companies are quite interested in them, and the store leasing industry is interested as a result."
Retailers want pedestrian counts, said Benjamin Fox, a partner in New Spectrum Realty Services, a retail brokerage concern, "especially in midtown where people are likely to shop in spurts, because that will help them plan their staffing levels."
But although the counts are a useful tool, said Alan Victor, an executive vice president of the Lansco Corporation, they do not show how much people are spending. "That's a question we get asked all the time," he said. "Retailers want to know what other people's sales volumes are and who else is there."
Even with their limitations, pedestrian counts are popular with retail brokers and store operators, Mr. Pisark of the business districts said. The counters, he said, chronicle the passing throng in the morning from 7:45 A.M. to 9:15 A.M., at midday from noon to 1:30 P.M. and in the evening from 5 P.M. to 6:30 P.M. They also record the peak traffic at each site, regardless of the time.
The counts are conducted during what are considered normal operating times in the city, like April and October, when the streets are least likely to be thronged by visitors and tourists. "We never count during Thanksgiving or Christmas," he said. "It's too crowded then; a counter could not stand at a place like 42d Street and Vanderbilt Avenue."
With rush-hour counts of more than 7,000 people an hour at that location, Mr. Milder of Danth Inc. concluded that more than two million people a year pass by that corner during the one-hour evening rush.

HEADLINE: Making Threats and Losing Cash in G.M. Strike

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: FLINT, Mich., July 7

 BODY:
A monthlong strike by the United Automobile Workers against the General Motors Corporation is starting to drain the cash reserves of both sides and is prompting G.M. in particular to begin reviewing ways to save money.
G.M. and the U.A.W. both have enormous financial strength, and neither needs to call a truce soon for lack of money. But the erosion of G.M.'s market share as the company's dealers run out of cars and light trucks poses a more serious risk to the company and its employees. Some lost customers may defect to rival auto makers and never come back, G.M. executives warn, and some U.A.W. officials privately acknowledge. 
 Today's negotiations continued far into the night for the first time since the beginning of the dispute, which started with a quarrel over whether workers at a parts factory were collecting a full day's pay for four to six hours of work and over whether G.M. had broken a promise to invest more money here. The dispute has led to walkouts at two parts plants here.
 Talks broke up at the plants late on Tuesday and early on Wednesday.
G.M. has raised the stakes by threatening to close some of its car factories permanently to become more competitive. The U.A.W. has responded by threatening further strikes this autumn at important parts factories in Dayton, Ohio, and Indianapolis, where workers also want G.M. to increase investment.
Richard Shoemaker, the U.A.W.'s vice president for G.M. issues, said that the union would like to settle outstanding issues at the Dayton and Indianapolis factories as part of a deal here. But while both sides would like a deal by Thursday, which would allow a ratification vote over the weekend and a resumption of production on Monday, the growing number of disputes has made it harder to reach a deal.
A constant worry for the union is that if G.M. is pushed too far, it might simply sell Delphi Automotive Systems, its sprawling auto parts subsidiary. A new owner would be a tough bargaining opponent for the U.A.W., because the new owner would not have the numerous, high-cost assembly plants that make G.M. vulnerable to U.A.W. strikes.
Despite union objections, G.M. sold four parts factories in 1996 to Peregrine Inc., an auto parts company. Peregrine announced tonight that it would close two of the factories: one here in Flint and the other in Livonia, Mich. All 1,000 U.A.W. workers at the two closed factories will be allowed to transfer back to G.M. under a deal negotiated by the U.A.W. two years ago, but the closings confirmed some of the union's worst fears.
The company has already said that the strike cost it $1.18 billion in after-tax losses during the second quarter, but in recent days G.M. officials have been expressing more concern about the strike's effects on the company's $13.6 billion in cash reserves. The last big U.A.W. strike against G.M., a 17-day walkout in 1996, temporarily reduced the company's cash reserves by $2.3 billion, as the company continued to pay the salaries of white-collar employees and bills from outside suppliers of auto parts, but no longer took in money from selling new cars and light trucks to dealers.
The current strike has lasted 32 days, although the last 11 days have fallen during the company's annual two-week summer shutdown, when G.M. always experiences a temporary drain of cash. Donald Hackworth, G.M.'s group vice president for North American car operations, said today that the company was seeking to reduce the outflow of cash.
G.M. has already taken many steps to stanch the loss of cash. It has turned the power off at plants closed by the strike, a step that will add a day or two to the time needed to restart them later. G.M. has also reduced business travel, off-site meetings and the use of consultants.
But Wall Street analysts said that G.M. had enough cash for a prolonged confrontation. "It's going to take a very, very long time for G.M. to face any real liquidity concerns as a result of the strike," Scott Sprinzen, the chief auto credit analyst at Standard & Poor's, said. G.M. can easily borrow money or sell car loans to raise money, he said.
Stephen Girsky, an auto analyst at Morgan Stanley, said that in addition to the $1.18 billion in lost profits, G.M.'s cash reserves had likely fallen by an additional $3 billion as bills came due for auto parts purchased before the strike. The impact on the cash reserves should now slow, he said, as G.M. stops further purchases of parts and because the company has laid off many workers.
The union is also finding the strike expensive, but, like the company, can afford to continue on its course. While union officials refuse to provide precise numbers, the strike appears to have taken about $10 million so far from a $725 million strike fund, which is one of the largest in organized labor.
The U.A.W. has been paying $150 a week in strike benefits to 9,200 striking workers here, and has been covering their health care costs since July 1, when G.M. stopped its medical coverage for them.
G.M. has filed petitions with state governments asking that they not pay unemployment benefits to nearly 120,000 U.A.W. workers that G.M. has laid off, because G.M. contends that they are indirectly involved in the strike through their union membership and therefore should be ineligible for unemployment compensation. G.M. filed similar petitions in 1996, and while most states rejected them, Texas agreed.
As a result, union officials said that they had already decided to pay $150 a week in strike benefits to 1,400 workers at a sport utility vehicle factory in Arlington, Tex.
