HEADLINE: Giuliani Picks An Ally's Son As Director Of City Budget

BYLINE: By NORIMITSU ONISHI 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani appointed Robert M. Harding as his budget director yesterday, choosing to fill a critical position with a lawyer with strong political skills but little experience in fiscal matters and who is the son of one of Mr. Giuliani's closest political allies.
Mr. Harding, who has served the last four years as the administration's chief lobbyist in Albany, succeeds Joseph J. Lhota, who was promoted last week to Deputy Mayor for Operations. Mr. Harding will direct a staff of about 350 and oversee the city's $34 billion budget. 
 Mr. Harding, 40, has little experience with municipal budgets compared with his predecessors, and his selection surprised many fiscal experts, government officials and government watchdog groups. Several critics dismissed the appointment as a payoff to Mr. Harding's father, Raymond B. Harding, the Liberal Party leader, who has supported and advised Mr. Giuliani since 1989.
The Mayor defended his decision as being based on pure merit, arguing that Mr. Harding possessed other strengths.
"We have a Mayor and a Deputy Mayor for Operations who have great detailed knowledge of the budget after five years in government," Mr. Giuliani said. "And frankly, we needed to add to the team someone who has a really sophisticated knowledge of government. I think it's the best balanced team you can put together."
Mr. Giuliani made the announcement at a news conference in City Hall, sharing the lectern with Mr. Harding. The room was filled with many of the Mayor's top aides and commissioners. Mr. Harding's wife and their two daughters sat near the stage, but his parents -- Raymond and Elizabeth Harding -- chose to sit in the back.
"Most of you know my mother, Liz, and next to her is her husband, Ray," the new budget director said as he pointed them out, clearly anticipating the inevitable questions about his appointment.
In his prepared remarks, Mr. Harding talked little about the direction of the city's budget. But two props given to him made clear that he was expected to pursue the Republican Mayor's fiscal policies: a black binder with a single sheet of paper that read "Just say no," and an oversized pair of scissors that the Mayor handed him.
Mr. Harding takes over the city's budget in a period of unprecedented plenty -- fueled by Wall Street's boom, the city ended the fiscal year in June with a record surplus of at least $2 billion -- as well as unusual political hostility inside City Hall.
Negotiations over the city's budget for the new fiscal year collapsed this spring after Peter F. Vallone, the Speaker of the City Council and a candidate for the Democratic nomination for governor, proposed a referendum that would ask city voters whether public funds should be used to help pay for a new Yankee Stadium on Manhattan's West Side. The move enraged the Mayor, who accused Mr. Vallone of raising the issue only to further his gubernatorial ambitions. Amid recriminations, the Council adopted its own budget over the Mayor's veto for the first time, and the battle is expected to go on over the next several months.
Mr. Giuliani praised Mr. Harding's knowledge of government and called him "one of the most talented people" he had worked with. But critics said that whatever Mr. Harding's skills, the overriding reason for his appointment was his father.
Gene M. Russianoff, a lawyer for the New York Public Interest Research Group, a good-government organization, said Mr. Giuliani, who has often accused former mayors of cronyism, was being hypocritical.
"This is a mayor who excoriated his predecessors for political patronage," Mr. Russianoff said, "and now he behaves the same way by putting his allies in top posts."
Mr. Harding had been director of New York City's Office of State Legislative Affairs since 1994. After getting his law degree from Brooklyn Law School in 1982, he worked as counsel to Assemblyman William F. Passannante from 1983 to 1990. From 1991 to 1993, he was general counsel to the New York State Science and Technology Foundation, and in 1993, he was counsel to the New York State Facilities Development Corporation.
Yesterday's appointment came a few weeks after Mr. Giuliani promoted Russell Harding, 34, another son of the Liberal Party leader, to run the city's Housing Development Corporation, a public authority that issues bonds for housing projects. That selection also raised eyebrows because Russell Harding, a college dropout, had no experience in housing finance.
In recent years, Mr. Giuliani has faced criticism because Raymond Harding built a prosperous business lobbying city agencies controlled by the Mayor, though he held back from the practice last year.
Raymond Harding said his relationship with the Mayor was not a factor in his son's appointment.
"If anybody thinks Rudy Giuliani would turn over the management of a $34 billion budget for political considerations, they don't know Rudy Giuliani," he said.

SECTION: Section B; Page 2; Column 4; Metropolitan Desk 

LENGTH: 890 words

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES;
Doing the Heavy Lifting for Labor Unions

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

 BODY:
IT'S not very surprising, in retrospect, that it was the hod carriers, the floor sweepers, the stackers of bricks and scaffolding who were at the heart of last week's unruly labor rally in midtown Manhattan.
There were plenty of skilled tradesmen blocking streets and stirring up the air to protest the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's use of a nonunion contractor, as any bruised police officer can attest, but the organizers, the ones who shoved and shouted the hardest, were laborers. 
 They are the ones most vulnerable to swings in the economy and the encroachment of nonunion contractors, the first to be laid off a job when a budget gets cut. Mike Hellstrom, stocky and loud and typical of a new defiance among young labor leaders, said it was no coincidence that his union was at the vortex of the rally, just as it has been trying for two years to energize the other building trades.
"A carpenter needs to be able to use a screw gun and read plans and make cuts with sheet rock knives," said Mr. Hellstrom, assistant organizing director of Local 79 of the Construction and Building Laborers Union and one of a handful of people who brought together 40,000 workers for the protest. "But anybody can be a laborer. Anybody. Anybody can stack brick and shovel mortar and sand and sweep brooms and run pumps and hump stuff around on a job site. So we're not going to be complacent like some of the others."
Mr. Hellstrom and his colleagues have brought what they call a "warrior mentality" to the 7,500 members of Local 79, making it one of the most visible unions in New York for the last two years. Having grown sick of the corruption that long plagued the Laborers, and wary of deals with politicians, the union has created a new arena on the streets outside nonunion job sites, holding mass lunchtime rallies where thousands of members blow pink plastic whistles and deliberately make annoyances of themselves.
Most prominently, the local borrowed an idea from some Chicago unions and bought a pair of 15-foot rat balloons for about $4,000 each. Mr. Hellstrom carries them around in the back of his pickup truck and happily inflates them at a moment's notice when a contractor uses nonunion labor on a building site. The rats attract cameras, the whistles attract passers-by, and the general effect brings a good deal of attention to contractors who often prefer to operate quietly.
"The idea is to create a commotion," said Mr. Hellstrom, 32, grinning at the thought of all the editorials that decried the lawlessness of the midtown rally. "The thing about in-your-face-type organizing and militancy is, you're definitely going to get your point across faster and you're going to be heard faster. Our issues have been ignored for a long time, so if shutting down the city streets got us the attention that we got over this cause, then so be it."
To some degree, it has worked. The union's organizing has brought 1,500 previously nonunionized demolition workers into the local, and the constant rallies persuaded a contractor at 80 John Street to sign with the union. The State Labor Department has begun investigating the practices of Roy Kay Inc., the nonunion contractor that was the target of the midtown rally, based on information provided by union officials.
The other building trades, which hung back from the Laborers' more aggressive tactics for years, are starting to join in.
Edward J. Malloy, president of the Building and Construction Trades Council, which represents 100,000 construction workers, said that Local 79 had done a "tremendous job" re-energizing the trades, and that Mr. Hellstrom was one of a new breed of aggressive young organizers turning up the heat. (But Local 79 backed Sal F. Albanese in the mayoral election, while Mr. Malloy endorsed Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.)
Fred Kotler, who has taught Mr. Hellstrom in union organizing classes at the Construction Industry Program of Cornell University's School of Industrial and Labor Relations in Manhattan, said Mr. Hellstrom was one of the most instinctive organizers he had known. "He's tough and street smart, and he represents a new generation of people who are now in positions of union responsibility, infusing a lot of energy into the building trades," said Mr. Kotler, associate director of the program.
MR. HELLSTROM, the grandson of Swedish immigrants, dropped out of high school in the 11th grade to join the union, having been taken to the union hall by his father -- a laborer even now -- at age 16.
Like a lot of laborers, he became "addicted to the good money," as he put it, and never left, though he eventually got his equivalency diploma. He worked on scores of construction sites over the years, eventually becoming a labor foreman, and after the Federal Government cleaned up and reorganized the local in 1996, he moved into organizing.
He's not sure where the militant streak came from, although he suspects he picked it up reading about the early days of the labor movement in America and the writings of the organizer Saul Alinsky.
By now, he said, even his 3-year-old daughter, Stephanie, sings union chants around the two-bedroom apartment he and his wife Angela rent in Howard Beach, Queens, a few blocks from where he grew up. He hopes she doesn't grow up to be quite as rebellious as her dad.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Mike Hellstrom has made the laborers' union more visible and defiant. (Librado Romero/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: A Hamilton Monument? Not on the Merits

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "Restore Hamilton to His Pedestal" (Op-Ed, July 3): Although a monument dedicated to Alexander Hamilton may be missing from the Mall in Washington, there is a statue of him standing proudly on a pedestal overlooking the Great Falls of the Passaic River in Paterson, N.J. 
 Hamilton envisioned an industrial enterprise along the Passaic River, with 247 mill wheels turning with the force of the Great Falls. He hoped that by producing its own cloth, the United States would become economically and politically independent of England.
 
ROSEMARY STEINBAUM
Montclair, N.J., July 6, 1998

INTERNATIONAL A3-10
 
Nigeria's Top Dissident, A Longtime Prisoner, Dies
Nigeria's most prominent political prisoner, Moshood K. O. Abiola, 60, died, apparently of a heart attack, shortly after meeting with American and Nigerian officials, further complicating the political turbulence in Africa's most populous country. A1 

Mr. Abiola's obituary. A10
 
Russia Aid May Fall Short
The International Monetary Fund and the Russian Government are negotiating an aid package that may produce less money than foreign investors say is needed to help ease Russia's financial crisis. The country's markets suffered as a result of the deficiency. A1
 
U.N. Expands Palestinian Role
The General Assembly voted overwhelmingly to give the Palestinians a larger role in the United Nations and a voice in many of its peripheral activities. The Palestinians, already members of several groups of developing nations, hailed the vote as a first step toward full United Nations membership. Israel's representative denounced the vote as a "transparent effort" to influence talks about disputed territories. A1
 
Inaction on Rwanda Criticized
A former United States Assistant Secretary of State testified before a French parliamentary committee on the massacres in Rwanda in 1994 and was highly critical of the American decision not to intervene. A10
 
Volkswagen War-Era Fund
Volkswagen agreed to set up a fund to compensate workers who were forced into slave labor in World War II, reversing a previous decision. A3
 
Fatherly Reminder: Go to Mass
Pope John Paul II reminded Catholics of their obligation to attend Sunday Mass in a 95-page apostolic letter, reaffirming that the church considers it a sin if a Catholic misses Mass. A5
 
Clinton Criticized on China
The Senate majority leader, Trent Lott of Mississippi, criticized President Clinton for making "serious mistakes" during his trip to China, tempering earlier praise from Republicans that Mr. Clinton's visit was a political hit. A4
 
Pakistan Rejects India Claim
A senior Pakistani official said India was using a fictional threat from China and unverified charges of Pakistani terrorist infiltration into Kashmir to justify its nuclear weapons program and to revive threats against Pakistan. A3
 
Doubts on Defector's Story
Scientists who questioned a Pakistani claiming to be a defector from his country's nuclear weapons program have concluded that he knows nothing about nuclear physics. A3
 
Unicef Focus on Birth Records
Perhaps one-third of all babies do not have their births registered, leaving them in an official limbo that can mean missed educational opportunities and health care, Unicef said in a report. A8
 
NATIONAL A12-19
 
Appeals Court Rejects Secret Service 'Privilege'
A Federal appeals court ordered Secret Service officials to testify before a grand jury about what they knew of any relationship between President Clinton and Monica S. Lewinsky. The three-judge panel rejected the claim that the Secret Service enjoyed a special privilege essential to the President's safety and that shielded its members from having to testify. The judges said it was up to Congress to decide whether to grant such a privilege. A1
 
Maryland officials said they had begun a criminal inquiry into Linda Tripp's taping of telephone conversations with Ms. Lewinsky. A18
 
New Indictment of Fund-Raiser
Maria Hsia, a Democratic fund-raiser in California who has been charged with disguising illegal campaign contributions to President Clinton's re-election campaign, was indicted on Federal tax charges. A18

Union leaders in Puerto Rico said that about half a million workers from more than 50 labor unions had joined a two-day general strike intended to halt the government's sale of the island's phone company. A14
 
CNN Star Heads to Atlanta
The CNN correspondent Peter Arnett went to Atlanta for a meeting today with network executives about his role in a report, retracted by CNN, on nerve gas during the Vietnam War. In an interview, Mr. Arnett said: "I hope they don't saddle me with the blame. I think it's a cop-out." A17
 
Admiral Buys Vaccine Lab
Michigan approved the sale of the nation's only licensed manufacturer of anthrax and rabies vaccine to a company led by Adm. William J. Crowe Jr., a former Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff and the United States Ambassador to Britain until last year. The sale gives the Admiral's company an edge on Pentagon contracts for anthrax vaccine. A19
 
Army Revises Retirement Rules
The Army said that it had revised its procedures for allowing generals to retire, a result of a controversy over the deputy Army inspector general who retired quietly in February even though he was under investigation for sexual misconduct. A19
 
A New Type of Savings Bond
The Clinton Administration will unveil a new type of Government savings bond whose return will rise and fall with inflation, to protect investors' gains as well as to help finance the Federal debt, officials said. A19
 
Killings in Texas
A young man armed with assault rifles killed a mother and a daughter and then fatally shot two Border Patrol agents pursuing him in the lower Rio Grande Valley, officials in Texas said. A16
